title: A 'Bronx Ballet' Turns Tragic
description: A dozen security cameras bear witness at the White Castle on Webster Avenue. Dan Barry describes what they captured early Saturday. Produced by Adam B. Ellick and Kassie Bracken.

title: A Housing House of Cards
description: Financial innovations by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have contributed to sucessful growth of homeownership and largely contributed positively to the housing boom of the past five years. But more than a few critics have said that the innovations are little more than a housing version of gambling in Las Vegas. According to Dudley Baker at www.preciousmetalswarrants.com and subscriber postings to the site, Fannie and Freddie have set up the market for a finanical meltdown should the Federal Reserve increase interest rates. Baker says the meltdown could come as soon as this year with more interest rate increases expected. Amid growing concerns, Freddie Mac CEO and Chairman Richard Syron has defended the company saying it posed no special risk to finanical markets. RON NIXON

title: The Boom Is Over for Condos
description: Its official!The housing boom is over, at least for the buyers and sellers of condominiums in Southern Florida, according to an article in todays South Florida Sun-Sentinel. The article quotes Henry Fishkind, an Orlando economist, who cautions sellers and builders that the housing market for condos has peaked in the Miami and West Palm Beach areas and that banks and real estate speculators could experience problems as a result. One real estate consultant called Miami the ground zero for the housing bubble.  RON NIXON

title: Plantain Odyssey
description: Edwin Rodriguez invented a gadget that makes peeling plantains easier. The Times's Amanda Hesser and Mr. Rodriquez explain why it took him 12 years to get it to market.

title: Key rates
description: In percent

title: 9/11 in History: How Big a Tremor?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia: German Diplomat Assumes Overseer Post
description: Christian Schwarz-Schilling, a German diplomat and former government minister, took over as high representative of the international community for Bosnia and Herzegovina. He replaces Lord Ashdown, a British politician.

title: How Curry, Stirred in India, Became a World Conqueror
description: Curry A Tale of Cooks and Conquerors By Lizzie Collingham Illustrated. Oxford University Press. 315 pages. $28.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GALLO, SAMUEL E.
description: GALLO--Samuel E. Sculptor & muralist. 1925-2006. Educated at Oberlin and the Accademia di Belle Arti in Rome. His work graces many private and corporate collections around the world. Beloved husband of Mildred (nee Coiro) and devoted father of Eliza & Carla. Deeply loved and missed by all who knew him. Service Friday, 11 A.M., St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park.

title: Arts, Briefly; The Bounty of Bonnaroo
description: The Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival, the acclaimed rock-and-country-and-anything-else lollapalooza on a 700-acre farm outside Nashville, is likely to be as eclectic as ever in its fifth year. The initial lineup, to be announced today, includes Radiohead, Tom Petty, Beck, Amadou et Mariam, Bela Fleck, Bonnie Raitt, Death Cab for Cutie, Elvis Costello, the Neville Brothers, Dr. John, Moe, Clap Your Hands Say Yeah, Ricky Skaggs, Buddy Guy, Bright Eyes, Shooter Jennings, Blues Traveler, Nickel Creek, Damian Marley, Cat Power, the Dresden Dolls, Bettye LaVette, Steel Pulse and dozens of others. The three-day festival will begin on June 16, and this year capacity will be reduced by 10,000, to 80,000, "to make a more comfortable environment," festival organizers said in a statement. Information and tickets: www.bonnaroo.com. BEN SISARIO

title: A Big Catch, Sure, but He's a Quarterback
description: DETROIT - EVERY Super Bowl team has a player with a story that illuminates perseverance. Seattle's story is Seneca Wallace.

title: It's Ice Carnival Time in the Catskills, but the Ice Isn't Cooperating
description: LIVINGSTON MANOR, N.Y. - IF you want to be technical, there is ice for what was supposed to be the 47th Annual Livingston Manor Rotary Ice Carnival, but it's not the kind you could skate on, just a thin mushy residue at the skating rink lying under puddles of water from yesterday's intermittent drizzle.

title: Israel moves to tear down illegal settlements
Ex-Employee Kills 5 Others and Herself at California Postal Plant
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Nam June Paik, widely considered the inventor of video art, omitted a survivor. He is his brother, Ken Paik, of Kamakura, Japan.

title: Cuba Releases Names of 60 Players On Provisional Tournament Roster
description: The organizers of the World Baseball Classic have resisted publicizing Cuba's 60-man roster for the 16-team tournament because the country has still not completed its agreement to compete next month. But the Cubans released the names to the news media in Havana yesterday.

title: Recovering McNabb Says the Eagles Need Healing
description: DETROIT, Jan. 31 - Philadelphia quarterback Donovan McNabb, who is recovering from sports hernia surgery that ended his season prematurely, says he thinks he has more than just his injury to rehabilitate. He says he believes the Eagles' locker room could use some healing, too.

title: Saddam trial holds a closed session amid boycott by lawyers
Addicted to Oil
description: So far the democracy wave the Bush team has helped to unleash in the Arab-Muslim world since 9/11 has brought to power hard-line Islamic fundamentalists in Iraq, Palestine and Iran, and paved the way for a record showing by the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt. If we keep this up, in a few years Muslim clerics will be in power from Morocco to the border of India. God bless America.

title: Opening Arguments in the Trial of Ex-Enron Chiefs
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 31 - On the opening day of the much-anticipated trial of Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, lawyers for the government and the defense on Tuesday told a tale of two Enrons, portraying starkly different versions of why the energy company collapsed in late 2001.

title: Amid Inquiry, Builder Is Called to Testify About Work for Kerik
description: A builder who helped renovate former Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik's Riverdale apartment has been called to testify before a Bronx grand jury about who paid for tens of thousands of dollars in work there, the builder's lawyer said yesterday.

title: Not Settling for Less, the Nets Beat the Best
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 31 - The rivalry between the Nets and the Pistons -- fueled by fierce playoff battles -- subsided the past season and a half. Detroit has dominated the N.B.A. this season, so there was not much of a showdown to speak of heading into Tuesday's game.

title: All the Numerals Fit to Print (at Least Until It's 2054)
description: DETROIT, Jan. 31 - Finally, shorthand.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HECK, ALICE HILLMAN
description: HECK--Alice Hillman. February 1, 1994 Love and memory Charles

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Man Sentenced For Killing Technician
description: A Brooklyn man was sentenced to life in prison yesterday for killing an A.T.M. technician during an attempt to steal money from Citibank, Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney, announced. The man, Paul R. Douglas, was convicted in December of killing the Brinks technician, Milton Moran Jr., in Yonkers on April 22, 2004, prosecutors said. Mr. Douglas, a former Brinks employee, had loaded A.T.M. machines, Mr. Garcia said in a statement. Mr. Moran was asphyxiated when duct tape was put over his mouth, prosecutors said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Monday about awards at the Sundance Film Festival misspelled the name of a refugee camp in Kenya that is shown in "God Grew Tired of Us," which won the jurors' and audience's awards for best documentary. It is Kakuma, not Kakuna.

title: 60 Nations Set 5-Year Goals to Aid Afghanistan
description: LONDON, Jan. 31 - The Bush administration pledged Tuesday to seek Congressional approval for a further $1.1 billion in aid to help rebuild Afghanistan next year, roughly the same amount sought for 2006.

title: Atomic Agency Sees Possible Link of Military to Iran Nuclear Work
description: Correction Appended

title: Russia's Sweetheart Deal for Iran
description: Washington - FINALLY, we are told, there is a breakthrough in the Iranian nuclear crisis: the Bush administration and its European allies have persuaded Russia and China to vote, at tomorrow's meeting of the International Atomic Energy Agency, to send Iran's nuclear violations before the United Nations Security Council. Allow us to point out the gray lining in the silver cloud.

title: Inca Show Pits Yale Against Peru
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 26  By any conventional measure, Yale's exhibition about Machu Picchu would seem a windfall for Peru. As one of the most ambitious shows about the Inca ever presented in the United States, drawing over a million visitors while traveling to half a dozen cities and back again, it has riveted eyes on Peru's leading tourist attraction.

title: Women Are Said to Face Hidden Heart Disease Risk
description: Women are more likely than men to have a hidden type of coronary disease in which their heart muscle is starved for oxygen even though their coronary arteries look clear and free of blockages on X-rays, doctors are reporting.

title: Recipe: Chipotle Meatballs
description: Adapted from "Mexican Everyday," by Rick Bayless (W.W. Norton, 2005)

title: Literary Agent Drops Writer of Memoir Larded With Fiction
description: James Frey's literary agent said in an interview published yesterday that she had dropped Mr. Frey as a client after learning, "along with the rest of the world," that he made up substantial portions of his book, "A Million Little Pieces."

title: Arts, Briefly; A Shot in the Arm From a Shot in the Eye
description: Half of CBS's schedule on Monday was repeats, but the network won the night anyway. A new episode of "CSI: Miami" (19.82 million), starring David Caruso, below, which featured what being shot in the eye might look like and was the most-watched show in prime time, was preceded by Week 2 of Jenna Elfman's sitcom "Courting Alex." Since it followed a rerun of "Two and a Half Men" (15.29 million), which delivered a smaller audience than an original episode, "Alex" was down from its premiere (13.46 million, versus 14.9 million last week) but retained a good percentage of "Men" viewers. Fox was a strong second place for the night in total viewers and adults 18 to 49, with the strangely juxtaposed "Skating With Celebrities" (9.93 million) and "24" (13.76 million). On WB's soon-to-be-canceled "7th Heaven," Sandy (Haylie Duff) gave birth to a son, and Martin (Tyler Hoechlin) decided to take responsibility for him after being mean throughout the pregnancy. The episode brought in 6.06 million viewers but failed to help the ratings of "Related," which had an audience of a mere 2.42 million. KATE AURTHUR

title: Palestinians Debate Shades of Islamic Law
description: TAYBEH, West Bank, Jan. 30 - This is a village of three churches, a brewer of very good beer, and no small fear -- if not yet full panic -- about what it means now that Hamas, the radical Islamic party, is in control of Palestinian politics.

title: People Cringed, but 12 Cameras Never Blinked
description: TWELVE security cameras bear witness at the White Castle on Webster Avenue in the Bronx. Mounted high in unobtrusive places, they create a multiframed silent film of life unfolding in a place of transience, a fast-food pit stop.

title: Refined but Ready for the Big Game
description: GRAB a beer and a tea sandwich, football fans, and watch the Steelers and the Seahawks take the field.

title: Saddam is no-show as his trial resumes

Paid Notice: Deaths   HALPERN, ARIE
description: HALPERN--Arie. It is with profound sadness that we mourn the passing of Arie Halpern, a business leader, builder of Jewish communities, philanthropist, and our dear friend. His life of Torah and Mitzvot will continue to thrive through the deeds of his family. To his wife Eva and their children, Bella and George, Shelly and Josef, Nanette and Arthur, Ben, and Sherry and Henry, his grandchildren, his brother Sam, and his family, we pray that you are comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Cecile and Edward Mosberg, Beatrice Mosberg, Louise and Stuart Levine Caroline and Darren Karger, and families

title: On Camera, Tough Times for President Are Evident
description: Solemn, his brow furrowed, President Bush smiled seldom and only winked once during yesterday's State of the Union address. When he introduced the family of Staff Sgt. Dan Clay of the Marines, who was killed last month in Iraq, Mr. Bush looked up, and blinked an eye to signal to them his sympathy.

title: Putin Juggles 64 Questions in Defense of the Homeland
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 31 - President Vladimir V. Putin on Tuesday defended Russia's handling of natural gas disputes with Ukraine and Georgia, boasted of a new strategic weapon and defended the country's contribution to the Group of 8 in response to suggestions from some critics at home and abroad that his policies have disqualified it from the club of elite democratic nations.

title: Leader of Jewish Congress Is Barred From Fiscal Role
description: The New York attorney general's office found that the leader of the World Jewish Congress, Israel Singer, violated his fiduciary responsibilities and barred him and a former executive from any financial role in the organization, according to a settlement disclosed yesterday.

title: Bush hits the roadto reinforce message
description: WASHINGTON  President George W. Bush took his calls for continued U.S. leadership, energy independence and a better educated, more competitive populace to Tennessee on Wednesday, revisiting the core themes of a generally well-received, if somewhat restrained, State of the Union message.

title: Iran vows crushing response if its nuclear facilities are attacked
House Panel to Press Cellphone Industry on Improving Protection of Customer Records
description: The cellphone's emergence as a primary communications device has spawned a cottage industry of con artists seeking to trick mobile phone companies into giving away the phone numbers and calling records of unwitting subscribers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TROSS, LEONARD
description: TROSS--Leonard. Loving and beloved husband of the late Ann. Cherished father of Roberta Cook and Susan Tross, and father-in-law of Michael Cook. Proud Papa of Jonathan and Alexander Cook. Devoted brother and brother-in-law of Frieda and Del Zucker, the late Laura and Jerry Weinthal and the late Madeline and Lou Galanter. Patriarch of a large and loving family, including his nieces and nephew, Wendy, Beth and Howard, their spouses, children and grandchildren. We all love you and will miss you. Service Thursday, February 2, 9:45 am at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Corzine Announces Senior Appointments
description: Gov. Jon S. Corzine tapped a former colleague from Goldman Sachs yesterday to be chairman of the new Office of Economic Growth. The new chairman, Gary D. Rose, 60, a retired partner from the firm's investment banking division, has experience in mergers, acquisitions and finance, and will be asked to come up with a strategic plan to create jobs and expand business opportunities. He joins Bradley I. Abelow, Mr. Corzine's nominee for state treasurer, as former Goldman executives who have been recruited by Mr. Corzine, a former co-chairman. Mr. Corzine also announced two other cabinet positions yesterday: Steven M. Goldman as commissioner of banking and insurance, and Kris Kolluri as commissioner of transportation. DAVID W. CHEN (NYT)

title: How Bernanke Could Outshine Greenspan
description: EVERYONE has felt the tangle of nerves and excitement that comes with a new job. So imagine what it must be like to be Ben Bernanke this morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HECTOR, RONALD D.
description: HECTOR--Ronald D. January 29, 2006. Beloved son of the late David and the late Ellen Hector. Longtime and dear friend of Martin Sonkin. Mr. Hector was the executive assistant manager of the Carlyle Hotel for 40 years. Friends may call Friday, February 3, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Interment to take place Saturday, February 4, 11 AM at Pinelawn Memorial Park, Pinelawn, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SACK, PRENTICE LARRIEU
description: SACK--Prentice LarRieu. An enthusiastic sailor, hiker, birder, world traveler, voracious reader, wife, mother and grandmother. She died at age 77 in her home in San Francisco on January 25, 2006. She is survived by her husband Paul, her brother Barry LarRieu, four children, their spouses and partners, seven grandchildren, the five Chukwudebes who joined the family, and two basset hounds. A celebration of her life will take place in several weeks. No flowers; donations may be made to a charity of your choice. Everyone who knew her loved her.

title: Caught in the Path of a Subway Train? Risks Loom in Every Direction
description: Short of "stand away from the platform edge," there are no hard-and-fast official guidelines to survive an oncoming New York City subway train. "There really is no one thing we can tell people that would work in every situation," said Paul Fleuranges, a spokesman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Israeli Police Clash With Jewish Settlers in West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 1 A In an unusually fierce clash among Israelis, the police battled stone-throwing Jewish settlers today and then tore down nine houses that were built on a West Bank hilltop without government approval. More than 200 people were hurt, including policemen, settlers and two right-wing members of Parliament.

title: Taking Black Family Trees Out of Slavery's Shadow
description: The idea that race is a function of language, myth, social conventions and even personal style captivated academic circles in the 1990's. The concept was a boon for philosophers and literary critics, who churned out books on how racial codes are engineered and deployed. Some of this work was called deconstruction. The literary critic Henry Louis Gates Jr., now chairman of the African and African American Studies department at Harvard, wrote with particular force and imagination on those themes.

title: The Neediest Cases; Down for the Count, and This Isn't All One Big Act
description: Johnny Barnes was a boxer and an actor, and an actor who played a boxer. The actor playing the boxer is his claim to fame.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABRAMS, PHILIP
description: ABRAMS--Philip. On January 10th. Beloved husband of Leonia. Memorial service to be held Saturday, 5 PM, at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel," 1076 Madison Ave., corner 81st St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DROGIN, FANNIE
description: DROGIN--Fannie. January 30 in her 95th year. Much loved wife of the late Paul (Poly) Drogin. Devoted and loving mother of Ira (Janet) grandchildren Laurent (Victoria), Peter (Catherine) and great grandchildren Allison, Dana and Alexander.

description: GIGLIO--Dr. Lydia C., PhD. On January 29. Viewing will be held 10:30AM-12:30PM Thursday, February 2 at "The Riverside" 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Followed by the interment at The Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: For Music Lovers Who Plan, What Next Season Has in Store
description: Clive Gillinson, who became executive and artistic director of Carnegie Hall last year, announced plans yesterday for the hall's 2006-7 season, the first in which he has had substantial input. But the basic contours are much the same as in recent seasons.

title: Investigators Gain Access to Levee for Soil Test
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 31 - It took a special agent of the Louisiana state attorney general's office and some bureaucratic sparring, but members of an independent team of engineering investigators won access on Tuesday to the site of a major levee breach from the Army Corps of Engineers.

title: People Arrested in City Are Often Jailed Past 24-Hour Limit, Study Says
description: In the 13 months ended last October, more than a third of the 360,000 people arrested in New York City sat in jail beyond the legal limit of 24 hours, according to a study released yesterday by the New York Civil Liberties Union.

title: Scarred, Cambodia seeks to salve its trauma
European Papers Publish Cartoons in Stand for Press Freedom
description: COPENHAGEN, Feb. 1 A Several European newspapers reprinted cartoons today depicting the Muslim prophet Muhammad, supporting a Danish newspaper that caused a huge outcry in the Islamic world by publishing them in the first place.

title: New York's Art Scene in the 60's and a Major Player Within It
description: It's unclear what exactly Peter Rosen's documentary "Who Gets to Call It Art?" is about, much less why it was made. Clocking in at 80 minutes, this glib, largely uninformative and poorly organized prcis of the post-World War II art scene, with its emphasis on New York in the 1960's and the curator Henry Geldzahler, succeeds neither as history nor as art history. If you want to know about Geldzahler, who in 1960 became a curatorial assistant in the department of American painting and sculpture at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (he died in 1994), you would do better if you typed his name into your favorite search engine. If you want to know about art in the 1960's, well, the art critic Arthur Danto is a good place to start.

title: After quake, the nightmare lingers
Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANK, MORTON
description: FRANK - Morton. Passed away January 30, 2006. Beloved husband of Charlotte. Devoted father of Peter, Jeffrey and Jonathan; father-inlaw of Carol. Loving grandfather of Dara and David. Caring uncle to many nieces and nephews. Brave officer in World War II. Services Wednesday, February 1, 11 AM at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Boynton Beach, FL. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

title: National Briefing | Washington: G.O.P. Easily Wins Money Race
description: The Republican National Committee raised almost twice as much as its Democratic rival in 2005 and started the new year with roughly six times as much money in the bank, according to reports. The Republican committee raised about $105 million and reported roughly $34 million on hand on Dec. 31, while the Democratic National Committee raised $56 million and had about $6 million left.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about the practical emphasis at film schools like the one at the University of Southern California referred incorrectly to Walter Murch, an Oscar-winning graduate of U.S.C. He is a film editor, and a sound editor and designer, not a cinematographer.

Paid Notice: Deaths   RYAN, PETER J.
description: RYAN--Peter J. Retired pressman, writer, World War II veteran, producer at Carnegie Hall. Beloved husband of the late Frances Kennedy Ryan, loving father of Sally and Angelo, John and Diane, Matthew and Rosalie and the late James. Dear brother of Billy, Julie and the late Rose, Sally, James, Gerard, George and Robert. Cherished grandfather of Jessica, Jacqueline, Curinne, Danielle, Jillian, James and Catherine, fond great-grandfather of Gianna Marie. Also survived by his loving nieces and nephews. Reposing at Cusimano and Russo Funeral Home, 2005West 6th St., Brooklyn, NY. Mass of the Resurrection, Friday 9:45AM, St. Athanasius RC Church. Interment. Long Island, National Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a Political Memo on Friday about rivals' efforts to discredit Andrew M. Cuomo in the race for New York State attorney general referred incorrectly to the political career of one rival, Charlie King. (The same error appeared in five other articles from 2002 to this year.) Mr. King, a lawyer, did not in fact work for Mario M. Cuomo, Andrew's father, when he was governor. A picture caption with the article misstated the day that a candidates' forum took place in Lower Manhattan. It was last Wednesday, not Thursday.

title: For Coaching Staffs, It's the Ultimate Stress Test
description: DETROIT, Jan. 31 - The stress of being an N.F.L. coach -- the sleep-deprived nights, the long hours, the years of poor eating habits -- might have caught up with Ray Rhodes in early September.

title: Exit Greenspan, Amid Questions on Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  Stepping down on Tuesday after 18 years as steward of the nation's economy, Alan Greenspan left his successor a wide berth to set his own policy but some major uncertainties about the future.

title: Gulf States Join Call for Tougher Action Toward Tehran
description: DUBAI, Jan. 31 - After years of hesitating, Persian Gulf states are joining the call for tougher action on Iran's nuclear efforts, increasingly worried that a nuclear Iran could set off a regional arms race.

title: An Australian Sibling Comes Into Its Own
description: HALF a century ago, two wines were born at Penfolds in South Australia. They were like brothers, really. Both were made largely of shiraz, with a little cabernet sauvignon occasionally thrown in, yet they offered completely different expressions of the same grapes. As with so many siblings, each seemed to represent all that the other was not, the apparent differences concealing their shared pedigree.

title: Defense Rests in Killings of Detectives
description: Crowds of police detectives, assistant district attorneys and uniformed officers returned yesterday to the trial of Marlon Legere, 30, who is accused of killing two detectives in September 2004.

title: Drama! Show Tunes! National Security Policy!
description: Drama! Show Tunes! National Security Policy!

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Rebels Warn Kidnappings Threaten Talks
description: The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, ethnic separatists who want their own homeland in the country's east and north, threatened to pull out of approaching peace talks with the government after 10 Tamil aid workers in the east were abducted. The group accused a government-backed paramilitary force of that abduction and of the disappearance of five other people, including pre-school teachers, who were traveling to the rebel capital, Kilinochchi, in the north.

title: French unemployment falls, but where are the new jobs?
WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10 P.M. (TV Land) THAT'S WHAT I'M TALKING ABOUT -- Wayne Brady (second from right) chats with (from left) Paul Mooney, Tour, Diahann Carroll and Harry Belafonte about perceptions of African-Americans, particularly on television. Their topics include how MTV has changed, why Ms. Carroll's "Dynasty" character, Dominique Deveraux, was written as if she were a white male and which shows have been most influential (among them "In Living Color," "The Jeffersons" and "Roots"). Part 1 of 3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISKE, JACK (JACOB Q. FINKELSTEIN)
description: FISKE--Jack (Jacob Q. Finkelstein). 88, died January 24, 2006. Renowned San Francisco Chronicle boxing columnist; inducted to International Boxing Hall of Fame. Bronx born; WWII Veteran. Survived by son David, daughter Linda Guerrero, two granddaughters, 3 nieces and a nephew.

title: Surplus in a Tight Fist
description: Faced with a surprise budget surplus in 1992 after years of fiscal pain, Mayor David N. Dinkins, gearing up for a re-election campaign, proposed using some of the extra money to keep libraries open longer and to build several new health clinics.

Cuomo in the race for New York State attorney general referred incorrectly to the political career of one rival, Charlie King. (The same error appeared in five other articles from 2002 to this year.) Mr. King, a lawyer, did not in fact work for Mario M. Cuomo, Andrew's father, when he was governor. A picture caption with the article misstated the day that a candidates' forum took place in Lower Manhattan. It was last Wednesday, not Thursday.

title: Dysfunction Junction: Boos for Knicks, Ahhs for Kobe
description: WHEN Dastards Collide. Into Madison Square Garden sauntered an energized Kobe Bryant last night, and there on the baseline slumped James L. Dolan, each linked in his moral oblivion, neither aware of consequence.

title: Pentagon Scales Back Review of Military Strategy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 A A comprehensive military strategy review once billed as Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld's architecture for revamping the armed forces eliminates no major weapon systems and calls for only incremental change in other priorities, according to Pentagon officials, outside advisers and independent analysts.

title: Letter From Vienna; Celebrating Mozart
description: For a city of such studied formality where women still wear dresses, a man wouldn't be caught dead in public without a tie, and strollers routinely greet each other with handshakes Vienna sure knows how to party. The winter social calendar features nearly 300 all-night balls, bars and restaurants routinely stay open until the small hours, and a popular local specialty is the "katerfrhstck," or hangover breakfast.

title: Chorale Sings the Puccini Gamut, 'Le Villi' to 'Turandot'
description: "Puccini: A Composer's Journey" was not quite the right title for the fascinating program that the Collegiate Chorale and its enterprising music director, Robert Bass, presented on Monday night at Carnegie Hall.

title: Officer's Leg Amputated as He Struggles to Survive Gunshot Wounds
description: In their continuing struggle to save the life of Officer Eric Hernandez, who was shot by a fellow officer outside a White Castle on Saturday, surgeons amputated part of his right leg yesterday.

title: Briefs: The state of ejections
For Kurds, Chickens Mean Food, Cash, and Now Death
description: ZAKHO, Iraq, Jan. 25 - Musa Jamail leaned against his mud-brick home and drew a pocketknife from his baggy pants to re-enact how he sliced the heads off his 20 chickens about a week ago, when Kurdish authorities paid a visit to his tiny village outside Zakho, near the Turkish border.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOSTELANETZ, BORIS
description: KOSTELANETZ--Boris. On January 31, 2006. A gentleman lawyer. Beloved husband of the late Ethel. Loving father of Lucy and Richard and cherished grandfather of Eliza. Services Thursday 11:45 AM at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Golisano Opts Not to Run, Reshaping Race for Governor
description: The intriguing politics of the New York governor's race, which still has nine months to go, took on much sharper definition yesterday when the Republican billionaire Tom Golisano announced that he would not run.

title: Stew Albert, 66, Who Used Laughter to Protest a War, Dies
description: Stew Albert, who with Abbie Hoffman, Jerry Rubin and a handful of similarly scruffy, leftist anti-establishmentarians formed the Yippie party to protest the Vietnam War, mock institutional authority and nominate a pig, Pigasus, for president, died on Monday at his home in Portland, Ore. He was 66.

title: Mine Safety Nominee Fields Tough Questions From Senators
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 - The Bush administration's nominee to be the nation's top mine safety regulator faced tough questioning on Tuesday at a Senate confirmation hearing that reflected competing visions of a proper oversight role.

title: Profit rises 21% at Time Warner
A Retailing Czar, Looking Out for Mom and Pop
description: National stores have gotten a lot of attention by moving into New York City neighborhoods that were once thought of in the retailing world as about as hospitable as the moon: Old Navy in Harlem, Ikea in Red Hook, Target in Flatbush.

title: The Quest
description: Dorothy Hill's plan was simple -- "find a one-bedroom apartment to rent for $2,200 in one of the best elementary school district zones in the city, P.S. 6." Her lease expired at the end of January, so she spent the month pursuing her dream, her quest, a small homethat could be the educational launching pad for Alex and Sophia, her 4-year-old twins. Maybe even a walk-up (until the nanny nixed that idea).She traveled the Upper East Side with a tape measure and a map, spending lunch hours with real estate people like Perry Buckner,looking at studios with alcoves. Today, Ms. Hill, Alex, Sophia and a cocker spaniel named Daphne will move into their new home,a one-bedroom sun-filled apartment in the desired school district, but the rent is $2,995 a month. Remember, she is a total realist. LENS

title: IRA is given good marks on its pledge to end terror
Paid Notice: Deaths   PAIK, NAM JUNE
description: PAIK--Nam June. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art notes with great sadness the passing of Nam June Paik. A beloved artist in our Permanent Collection, Nam June was a foremost pioneer of video art and remained one of the medium's most influential figures throughout his long and prolific career. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to his family and friends. Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Robert J. Hurst, President Adam D. Weinberg, Director and the entire staff of the Whitney Museum

title: Clinton Raises Millions More as G.O.P. Strains to Field a Challenger
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 - Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York has pressed ahead with an aggressive fund-raising campaign by taking in $6 million in the final three months of 2005, even as her Republican opposition in New York has plunged into disarray.

title: Rowland Leaves Prison, Briefly, for U.S. Grand Jury
description: Former Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut appeared yesterday as a witness before a grand jury in Hartford in response to a subpoena from federal prosecutors, who continue to investigate corruption stemming from his time in office, according to Mr. Rowland's lawyers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCINERNEY, DENIS
description: McINERNEY - Denis. The partners, associates and staff of the firm of Cahill Gordon & Reindel LLP are profoundly saddened by the passing of Denis McInerney, our distinguished former partner and friend of over 40 years. The former President of the New York County Lawyers Association, and a Fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers, he was a skilled advocate at every level including the U.S. Supreme Court. He served his country, his profession, his community and his faith. Our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Irene, and his three children, Kathleen O'Hare, Denis J. and Maura Romano.

title: Delays likely for Estonia and Latvia on euro
Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,237 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Nominations Highlight the Sticky Issue of Credit
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Jan. 31 - More than a month before the Oscar winners are announced, there is already one clear group of victors: the independent production companies and specialty divisions seem likely to grab the industry's most coveted hardware. Movies like "Brokeback Mountain," "Capote," "Good Night, and Good Luck" and "Crash" all of which received nominations today for best picture, were substantially produced outside the studio system. Financing was often cobbled together from a variety of sources, and people involved in the films wore many hats.

title: Citing Public Sentiment, China Cancels Release of 'Geisha'
description: SHANGHAI, Jan. 31 - A week before "Memoirs of a Geisha" was scheduled to open at movie theaters here, the Chinese government canceled the showing of the Hollywood film, reportedly because of concerns that it could spark public anger and rekindle anti-Japanese sentiment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLEMAN, HENRY S.
description: COLEMAN--Henry S. Austin E. Quigley, Dean of Columbia College, The Columbia College Board of Visitors and The Columbia College Alumni Association mourn the passing of Henry S. Coleman, of The Class of 1946 on January 31, 2006. Harry, as he was known, served in many administrative positions during a career of devoted service to Columbia College from 1948 to 1979, including Director of Admissions, Interim Dean of The College, Dean of Freshmen, and Dean of Students. He also served his classmates as their Class Correspondent for The College Alumni Magazine since 1981. He was a 1996 recipient of The College's John Jay Award for distinguished professional achievement. The Dean, The Boards, and The College community extend their deepest sympathy to Harry's widow, Lila, and their family.

title: A Taste of Ghana
description: ACCRA, Ghana - PEOPLE travel to Africa for history and for scenery but never for the food. I don't get it.

title: 'Eclectic' Hospital With a Founder Prone to Legal Problems
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 31 - The hospital in northwestern Mexico where Coretta Scott King died advertises itself as "a truly wholistic health center" where people can find "a very eclectic approach to the treatment of chronic diseases, diseases by and large considered incurable by the orthodox medical profession."

title: Charges Expected in A.I.G.-Related Case
description: The Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission are expected to announce criminal and civil fraud charges as early as Thursday against three former top executives at the Berkshire Hathaway subsidiary, the General Reinsurance Corporation, as well as a former senior executive of the American International Group, according to people with direct knowledge of the charges.

title: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 - Government complacency, poor planning and dereliction of duty during Hurricane Katrina contributed to the deaths of dozens of the frail and sick in New Orleans, and to the suffering of many others who were stranded in area hospitals and nursing homes unable to care for them, Senate investigators said Tuesday.

title: 2 Universities Trade Ideas Across Armed Checkpoints
description: WALTHAM, Mass. - IN the damp chill of a Jerusalem winter three years ago, Jehuda Reinharz returned to Israel, his native land, in his present guise as president of Brandeis University here. From his hotel on the western, Jewish, side of the contested city, he telephoned a peer in the Arab neighborhoods to the east, Sari Nusseibeh, president of the Palestinian university, Al Quds.

title: 9/11 in History: How Big a Tremor?
description: To the Editor:

title: With Hussein and Co-Defendants Absent, Trial Resumes
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 1 A The trial of Saddam Hussein resumed without him today, after he and four other main defendants refused to attend and the judge decided to continue anyway.

title: Free Flow:Lessons learned on deadly London day
Mayor's Budget Calls for Spinach and Few Sweets
description: Resisting political temptation, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed a $55.5 billion budget yesterday that would spend most of a $3.3 billion surplus this year not on politically popular programs, but on paying down debt and other long-term costs that threaten the city's future financial stability.

title: Bush's Bold Visions Have Given Way to New Reality
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 - It was an evening for President Bush to confront America's anxieties -- and his own.

title: Rowland Leaves Prison, Briefly, for U.S. Grand Jury
description: Former Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut appeared yesterday as a witness before a grand jury in Hartford in response to a subpoena from federal prosecutors, who continue to investigate corruption stemming from his time in office, according to Mr. Rowland's lawyers.

title: Hear the Laughter, Pass the Satays
description: THE dining room at Minangasli is not much to look at. It is spartan but spic and span; it does what it needs to and not much more.

title: Egypt and Jordan back Bush on Hamas
Classic French, Twice Fried
description: "You know, they have to be fried twice," Sabi Kampeas, above, said of the French fries he serves at Kitchen Commune, a bright new cafe at 448 Broadway (Grand Street) that he opened with his brother, Jacky, two weeks ago. The fries are excellent, served in a paper-lined cup with a choice of seasoned mayonnaise dressings. Salads, pizzas, panini, crepes, savory pies, macaroni and cheese, and pastries and breads from Balthazar round out the menu. Most items, except for pastries and drinks, are $4.50 to $12.95. There are counters and tables. Stainless steel ladles and whisks, not for sale, decorate the chandeliers and serve as door handles: (212) 680-0140. FOOD STUFF

title: Diplomats see chance to end Azeri-Armenian stalemate
EU averts rise in VAT

description: Taylor Twellman endured the carping and the deep analysis as well as he could.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CZUKOR, ALICE C.
description: CZUKOR--Alice C. 9/18/15--2/1/01. You have missed each day during these last 5 years. Lester

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOSAK, ALVIN I., PH.D.
description: KOSAK--Alvin I., Ph.D. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its Honorary Trustee and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Paul Warhit, President Michael Z. Cahana, Rabbi

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Indicted In Daughter's Death
description: An Arverne man has been indicted on a charge of first-degree manslaughter after the death of his 7-year-old daughter on Oct. 25, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Prosecutors charge that the man, Russell Roberts of Hillmeyer Avenue, severely beat his daughter, Sierra, and failed to seek medical attention for her injuries. Mr. Brown called for stricter penalties for child abuse and more resources for investigations and prosecutions.

title: Under a Big Umbrella, but What Else Do They Share?
description: LONDON, Jan. 31 - Every so often, the British like to ask themselves what it is that makes them British. And just as often, they seem to conclude that if you need to ask, you cannot really know.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a Political Memo on Friday about rivals' efforts to discredit Andrew M. Cuomo in the race for New York State attorney general referred incorrectly to the political career of one rival, Charlie King. (The same error appeared in five other articles from 2002 to this year.) Mr. King, a lawyer, did not in fact work for Mario M. Cuomo, Andrew's father, when he was governor. A picture caption with the article misstated the day that a candidates' forum took place in Lower Manhattan. It was last Wednesday, not Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MECZ, SIDONIE
description: MECZ--Sidonie. On January 30, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Leopold Mecz for sixtythree years. Dear mother of Adrian and his wife Jane. Adored grandmother of Karen and Elizabeth. Cherished friend and relative of Lucille Meidler, Arthur and Carola Rowe. Services today February 1, 1 PM at "The Riverside" 76th St., and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Inca Show Pits Yale Against Peru
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 26 - By any conventional measure, Yale's exhibition about Machu Picchu would seem a windfall for Peru. As one of the most ambitious shows about the Inca ever presented in the United States, drawing over a million visitors while traveling to half a dozen cities and back again, it has riveted eyes on Peru's leading tourist attraction.

title: Motorola Slvr: Gorgeous, but Software Is Infuriating
description: Why does this page look this way?

title: House Extends Patriot Act Another 5 Weeks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 A The House of Representatives voted this evening to extend the antiterrorism law known as the USA Patriot Act to March 10, giving House and Senate negotiators another five weeks to resolve their long-running dispute over the statute.

title: Corrections
description: A David Carr column in Business Day on Monday, about Oprah Winfrey's response to inaccuracies in the book, "A Million Little Pieces" by James Frey, misstated the post held by Nan A. Talese, the book's publisher. She leads a division within Doubleday, she is not the head of it.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Is Bush Ally in Connecticut School Case
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 31 - N.A.A.C.P. officials said on Tuesday that they were trying to intervene in a lawsuit over the No Child Left Behind Law on the side of the Bush administration and against the State of Connecticut because of a core principle: that states do not have the right to ignore federal legislation that aims to help minorities.

title: Dane Defends Press Freedom as Muslims Protest Cartoons
description: LONDON, Jan. 31 - As Islamic protests spread about cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad in a Danish newspaper, Anders Fogh Rasmussen, the Danish prime minister, defended press freedom in his country on Tuesday but distanced himself from the newspaper's decision to publish the drawings.

title: A leaner United Airlines climbs out of bankruptcy
Insulin defects may figure in mental illness
Curry's Conquest
description: How a dish prepared in India grabbed the world by the tastebuds. Books of The Tmies, Page 10. INSIDE

title: Taking Black Family Trees Out of Slavery's Shadow
description: The idea that race is a function of language, myth, social conventions and even personal style captivated academic circles in the 1990's. The concept was a boon for philosophers and literary critics, who churned out books on how racial codes are engineered and deployed. Some of this work was called deconstruction. The literary critic Henry Louis Gates Jr., now chairman of the African and African American Studies department at Harvard, wrote with particular force and imagination on those themes.

title: Sell-off makes some wonder if the luck has left Macquarie
A 'duel without rules': Cartier-Bresson's sway
Gentrification Arrives at a Crossroads in Yorkville
description: The intersection of Lexington Avenue and 86th Street is arguably the crossroads of the Upper East Side of Manhattan, a transportation hub within easy walking distance of some of the costliest real estate in the city. Yet for decades it has resisted gentrification.

title: Bird Flu Case in Hong Kong Raises Questions About China
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 1 A A chicken illegally smuggled across the border from mainland China has died here of bird flu, Hong Kong officials announced late today in a case that raises new questions about whether Chinese provincial officials are concealing the true extent of the disease.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: West Bank: Israeli Forces Kill Islamic Jihad Leader
description: Israeli troops killed two Islamic Jihad militants, including the group's West Bank military commander, Nidal Abu Saada, in a firefight near Jenin. An Israeli soldier was wounded. Islamic Jihad has carried out the last six suicide bombings against Israel and did not take part in Palestinian legislative elections, won by Hamas. Islamic Jihad urged attacks against Israel in response.

title: Wounded ABC Anchor and Cameraman Flown to U.S.
description: FRANKFURT, Jan. 31 - The ABC News anchor and cameraman wounded in a roadside bombing in Iraq arrived Tuesday night at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., after a brief stay at a military hospital in Germany, according to the network's Web site.

title: 9/11 in History: How Big a Tremor?

description: Correction Appended

title: INSIDE
description: Handing Over the Power at the Federal Reserve Stepping down after 18 years as steward of the nation's economy, Alan Greenspan left his successor, Ben S. Bernanke, a wide berth to set his own policy, along with a final increase in short-term interest rates and some major uncertainties. In a new column, David Leonhardt says that Mr. Bernanke has the potential to outshine his predecessor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEINBERG, SAMUEL
description: FEINBERG--Samuel. The Board of Directors of The Zamir Choral Foundation expresses its profound sorrow on the passing of Samuel Feinberg, beloved father of our esteemed Board Member, Vivian Lazar (and father-in-law of our Founder and Director, Matthew Lazar). May they and their extended family be comforted among the mourners for Zion and Jerusalem. His memory will surely be a blessing to all who knew him. Alan Septimus, President

title: Six-Alarm Fire Rips Through Apartment Building in Bronx
description: An early morning fire ripped through a seven-story apartment building in the Morrisania section of the Bronx today, forcing the evacuation of the structure by both occupants and firefighters, a Fire Department spokesman said.

title: A Sea of Comfortable Choices
description: THE new restaurant Barbounia is very easy on the eyes, relatively easy on the ears and not so bad on the stomach, either. But it's kindest of all to another part of the body, which is less delicately evoked and most often consigned to euphemism.

title: United Plans to End Stay in Bankruptcy
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 31 - United Airlines is expected to end its 38-month stay in bankruptcy proceedings on Wednesday, but the carrier may not be profitable this year because of a recent surge in fuel prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVERMAN, MORRIS
description: SILVERMAN--Morris. Lighthouse International mourns the death of Morris Silverman, father of Lorin, a generous supporter of the Lighthouse mission to help people of all ages overcome the challenges of vision impairment. On behalf of the Lighthouse Board of Directors, our staff and clients, we offer our deepest sympathy to the entire family. Tara A. Cortes, President and CEO William B. Follett, Chairman, Board of Directors Lighthouse International

title: Digital Dialogue: Is anyone afraid of Internet anonymity?
Paid Notice: Deaths   SWEENEY, EILEEN M. (NEE CREAVEN)
description: SWEENEY--Eileen M. (nee Creaven). On January 31, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Brian. Loving mother of Carol, Patricia and Catherine. Devoted sister of Jack Creaven. Former District leader in Northern Manhattan, Vice President of Operations-Service Manager for Chase Bank and Legislative Assistant to Herman D. Farrell. Reposing Wednesday and Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Riverdale - on - Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave., Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 9:45 AM at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Poland: Pope To Visit In May
description: Pope Benedict XVI will travel to Poland from May 25 to 28 and will visit Auschwitz, the Nazi death camp, and the southern town of Wadowice, birthplace of his predecessor, John Paul II, the Polish Episcopate confirmed, according to news agencies. He is scheduled to begin the trip in Warsaw and travel on to Krakow and Czestochowa, home of the country's most venerated shrine, the Black Madonna.

title: Alito Sworn In as Justice After Senate Gives Approval
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 - Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. was quietly sworn in Tuesday as the 110th justice of the Supreme Court, taking the oath of office less than two hours after a sharply divided Senate voted roughly along party lines to confirm him.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about Israelis' reaction to the Hamas victory in the Palestinian elections gave the wrong name in some copies for the square where some of those quoted in the article were interviewed. It is Rabin Square, not Begin Square. (Go to Article)

title: Briefs: More victims may be buried in roof rubble
Imported From Spain, via Queens and SoHo
description: After 35 years in business, 17 of them in Jackson Heights, Queens, Angelica and Marcos Intriago, who own DespaAa, an importer of Spanish products, have opened a shop in SoHo, at 408 Broome Street (Lafayette Street).

title: Westward Into War With the Soviet Novelist and Reporter Vasily Grossman
description: It is easier to picture the Soviet writer Vasily Grossman in May 1945, at the end of World War II, than it is at the war's outset. The flesh has dropped away. His eyes have grown larger, his face sharper. He is 39. The photographs show him always in his owlish glasses, and there is sometimes more to be read in his posture or the way he holds a cigarette than there is in his eyes, which have none of the grimness but all of the experience of the generals he interviewed.

title: For cameras, it's a digital world
Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Cameras To Enforce Speeding Laws
description: State officials expect to issue more than 800,000 speeding tickets as part of a proposal in Gov. George E. Pataki's budget to place video cameras at 30 sites. The sites would be either construction zones or especially dangerous stretches of highway, a transportation official said yesterday at a budget hearing. The state is hoping to raise $84 million annually with the measure, which has been proposed by the governor before but failed to pass the Legislature. Signs would alert drivers to the presence of the cameras. DANNY HAKIM (NYT)

title: Ukraine Gas Deal Draws Attention to Secretive Importer
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 31 - Four weeks after Ukraine cut a deal to import natural gas through RosUkrEnergo, a shell entity based in Switzerland, the obscure company is facing an uncomfortable amount of attention.

description: NEW YORK

title: Looking for Comedy in the New World
description: Open on the British ship Star Vehicle, approaching the Virginia Coast, 1607. On shore, Native Americans, including the princess POCAHONTAS, stand watching in awe.

title: The State of the Union: A Citizen's Rebuttal
description: The state of our union is stunned. We democracy spreaders remain shocked, shocked, at the Hamas sweep in the recent Palestinian parliamentary election, never, ever, ever before having experienced a deficit of wisdom on the part of American voters. And that is not only a sarcastic shout-out to the loss of electoral innocence brought on by that time "Dances With Wolves" beat out "Goodfellas" for best picture at the Oscars. No, it is merely a weary barb borne of the ongoing grind that is the current presidency.

title: Entr'acte: Conflicting memories in old and new France
A Fruit That's Good to Eat Before It's Sweet
description: I HAVE no idea why the common bunch banana, which is almost always eaten ripe and sweet and is consequently sometimes called a "dessert" banana, became a staple in the United States, while the equally important plantain has remained largely a part of Latino cuisines. There's nothing negative to be said about common bananas, but of the several hundred species of bananas, plantains are probably the most popular, in part because they can be eaten at any stage of ripeness.

title: National Briefing | West: California: AT&T Is Accused In Eavesdropping
description: The Electronic Frontier Foundation, a civil liberties organization, filed a class-action suit against AT&T in federal court in San Francisco, saying the company was violating the law and customers' privacy in cooperating with the National Security Agency on computerized surveillance. The program has been in the news for more than a month after news reports that President Bush authorized the N.S.A. to intercept international telephone and Internet communications of people in the United States without court authorization. A spokeswoman for AT&T said it would not comment on questions involving national security or privacy.

title: The Good Life
Loan for Foreign Mining in Ghana Approved
description: The board of the International Finance Corporation, the World Bank's investment agency, yesterday approved a $75 million loan to a subsidiary of Newmont Mining, the world's largest gold producer, for a project in Ghana that the investment agency's managers say they hope will be a model for the developing world.

title: YANKEES' CANO TO SKIP CLASSIC
description: Robinson Cano, the Yankees' starting second baseman, said yesterday that he would not play in the World Baseball Classic even though he is on the Dominican Republic's provisional roster.

title: Nepalese king talks of progress as rebels kill at least 20
Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a government study comparing fourth- and eighth-grade math scores of students in regular public, charter and private schools on the 2003 National Assessment of Educational Progress misspelled the surname of the researchers. They are Christopher Lubienski and Sarah Theule Lubienski, not Lubianski.

title: Ackermann gets new contract
Rikers Captain Is Accused of Sexual Abuse
description: A Correction Department captain was arrested yesterday on charges that he forced teenage inmates to take their clothes off and groped them.

title: Angiotech to Buy Needle Maker
description: Angiotech Pharmaceuticals agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held American Medical Instruments Holdings, a maker of custom needles, for $785 million in cash, the company said.

title: The State of Energy
description: President Bush devoted two minutes and 15 seconds of his State of the Union speech to energy independence. It was hardly the bold signal we've been waiting for through years of global warming and deadly struggles in the Middle East, where everything takes place in the context of what Mr. Bush rightly called our "addiction" to imported oil.

title: Former U.S. Official in Iraq to Plead Guilty to Corruption
description: A former American occupation official in Iraq is expected to plead guilty to bribery, conspiracy, money laundering and other charges in federal court on Thursday for his actions in a scheme to use sexual favors, jewelry and millions of dollars in cash to steer reconstruction work to a corrupt contractor, according to papers filed with the court.

title: Cablevision Rethinking a Dividend
description: Cablevision Systems, the giant cable operator, said yesterday that it would consider restoring a special $3 billion dividend that it canceled in December.

title: Two Approaches to Selling Secure Transactions
description: VISA and MasterCard use similar strategies to fight identity theft and fraud, but the companies have come up with two vastly different approaches to market their security efforts.

description: The author James Frey said today that the reason he invented events that never happened and embellished his account of his life in his best-selling memoir, "A Million Little Pieces," is that it made a better book.

He will be greatly missed by his son-in-law Jonathan Feld and step daughter Maria McDonald. Services 11:30 Thursday Plaza Jewish Community Chapel,. 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave.

description: "In a complex and challenging time, the road of isolationism and protectionism may seem broad and inviting, yet it ends in danger and decline."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOYNTON, JAMES
description: BOYNTON--James. Cushing Academy is deeply saddened by the passing of James Boynton, a longtime trustee and the parent of an alumna. Jim's friendship, trusted wisdom and leadership will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Kate, and children Carrie and James. Mark E. Tuller, Board President M. Willard Lampe II, Headmaster

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COUPER, RICHARD W.
description: COUPER--Richard W. The trustees and staff of the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation grieve the passing of a respected colleague and faithful friend who was a dedicated trustee from 1975 to 1994. Richard Couper not only understood and supported the Foundation's goals and ideals, but also had an enduring commitment to gifted artists, scholars, and scientists. We are fortunate to have had the opportunity and privilege of working with this engaging man, who had such a deep feeling for public service. All of us at the Foundation extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Patsy, and to the members of their family. Joseph A. Rice Chairman, Board of Trustees Edward Hirsch President and Trustee Joel Conarroe Pres. Emeritus and Trustee

For Downtown Clubs, the Uptown Classical
description: Classical music is defined, in part, by where it's played. If it's at Avery Fisher Hall, it's probably classical; if it's at CBGB, it's probably not. So-called classical musicians have been happily challenging this traditional divide for years: hence the evolution of the downtown music scene, the erstwhile stomping ground of major artists like Steve Reich or Meredith Monk, who have yet to be fully acknowledged by classical music's old guard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERSTEIN, WENDY
description: WASSERSTEIN--Wendy. The Board of Trustees and staff of Theatre Development Fund deeply mourn the loss of Wendy Wasserstein, a major force in the American theater and our colleague. In addition to Wendy's immeasurable contributions as a playwright and her work as an arts advocate, she also brought the Open Doors Program to TDF in 1998. The program for students was born out of Wendy's conviction that it was the birthright of every child in NYC to have access to the theatre. Through her tireless efforts on the program's behalf, it has grown from one group mentored by her, to 17 groups of NYC high school students mentored by 17 theater professionals. Each group has Wendy's spirit--the spirit of inquiry, curiousity, discussion, love of children and love of the theatre. We extend our deepest sympathies to her family and her many colleagues. David D. Holbrook, Chairman Victoria Bailey, Exec. Dir.

title: A Norman Rockwell Touch for a Farm Family in Trouble
description: What might be called the Norman Rockwell approach to Sam Shepard's "Buried Child" turns out not to work too well for a play that is bipolar funny and hair-raising. Rockwell didn't portray decaying families, infanticide, alcoholism or probable incest -- elements still present in Mr. Shepard's 1995 revision of his 1978 original. So when the lights came up on the revival at the American Theater of Actors directed by Cyndy A. Marion, the couch supporting Dodge, the cantankerous paterfamilias, looked as if a truck had hit it, but the rest of the room and the stairs to the second floor appeared far more cozy than decrepit.

Paid Notice: Deaths   SOMERFIELD, RALPH MURRAY
description: SOMERFIELD--Ralph Murray died at home January 31 in Floral Park, NY. Ralph was a life long resident of NYC, born of immigrant parents, Benjamin and Sophie, in 1915. His childhood was immersed with the joys of dance, opera, the Yiddish Theater, and a precious friendship with Manny Dichter. He was blessed to find his true love, Elsie, at 16 and spent the next 73 years with her at his side through all life's joys and travails. He had a long creative career as a marketing executive holding senior positions at Bulova, Lucien Piccard, including Vice President and Secretary at Gruen. A talented tennis player since childhood, he competed in many tournaments including winning the Sears Tennis Tournament in his 70's beating competitors 30 years his junior. His love of tennis was only exceeded by his love of chocolate to which he attributed his long life. A Shakespeare enthusiast, he often quoted from his work to make points and entertain friends and family. After his retirement he volunteered at LIJ Hospital where he organized educational conferences and read to seriously ill children. He was appointed by the Governor to the Board of Visitors of Queens Children's Psychiatric Center & was its Secretary. He was a fearless fighter for children against the political powers favoring funding cuts for the disadvantaged. He sponsored dance therapy programs and donated musical equipment through the Ralph and Elsie Somerfield Arts Enrichment Fund. He attended every class conducted by the Ailey dance teachers. He enjoyed lively debates at Temple Beth-El Torah study. He was preceded in death by his beloved wife, Elsie. He is deeply mourned by his daughters, Barbara and Benita; his son in law, John; his niece, Joan: his cousins, Bonnie and Sven and his devoted friend, Clem. Donations may be made in his name to the Queens Children's Psychiatric Center, Attn: Carol/Keith Little, 74-03 Commonwealth Blvd, Bellrose, NY 11426 or the National Audubon Society. Memorial services will be held Thursday, February 2, 10AM, Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Blvd, at 76th Road, Forest Hills, Queens. 718-263-7600.

Ramuz's text is spoken in English and Arabic, Igor Stravinsky's score alternates with Arabic music and a music theater work written during World War I is updated to the Iraq war.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Transit Union Calls For New Talks
description: In the first executive board meeting since the New York City transit workers' union rejected a proposed contract with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority by a seven-vote margin, Roger Toussaint, the union's president, indicated last night that the union was looking to promptly renew talks and avoid binding arbitration. "We are hopeful that a meeting will occur and we will meet in the next few days," Mr. Toussaint said after the two-hour meeting, which nearly 40 executive board members attended. The board discussed lingering issues from the 60-hour strike in December, including what to do with members who crossed the picket line. The authority has said it will not identify them, so the union has asked members to supply names. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Ex-No. 2's Aide Told To Repay Millions
description: The Durban High Court ordered an associate of Jacob Zuma, the nation's former vice president, to repay the government $5.5 million the court said was the proceeds of a "generally corrupt" relationship with Mr. Zuma while he was in the government. The man, Schabir Shaik, was convicted last year of bribing Mr. Zuma in exchange for a host of benefits, including a share of a lucrative contract to supply ships to the South African Navy. Mr. Zuma was fired after the conviction and has been charged with corruption; his trial will take place later this year. He had been the leading candidate to succeed Thabo Mbeki as president.

title: Harlem Boys Choir Leaders Are Ordered Out of Their Offices
description: Following days of bitter negotiations, school officials said late yesterday that they had ordered administrators of the Boys Choir of Harlem to vacate their offices and storage space in a Harlem school building by the end of the day, effectively ending a troubled partnership that had given the world-renowned choir its home in a public high school.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Chemical Plant Explosion
description: Nine people were injured, at least four seriously, in an explosion at a chemical plant in Morganton. The explosion at the Synthron Inc. plant around 11:45 a.m. blew out windows in a nearby mobile home park, and residents within a half mile were warned to stay indoors. Clint Patton, the Burke County emergency operations director, said officials had a list of chemicals on the site, but did not know which were involved in the fire. Mr. Patton said that the cause of the incident was still undetermined, but that terrorism was not suspected.

She was 61.

The pizzas are sold by the foot, $12 to $18, and come topped with combinations like pumpkin pure covered with pancetta and scamorza cheese, and walnut spread with Montasio cheese and mozzarella: 198 Allen Street (Houston Street), (212) 614-7252.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Nato Winds Up Quake Relief Work
description: NATO announced that it was winding up its relief operation in the earthquake-stricken areas of Pakistan and Kashmir and said its troops would leave the region within days. As many as 73,000 people were killed and three million were left homeless by the Oct. 8 quake. More than 1,000 NATO troops, including engineers and medics, took part in the relief operation, the first of its kind outside NATO territory. While President Pervez Musharraf praised the operation, opposition religious parties criticized the presence of NATO troops in the country.

title: Earmarks, Wiretaps and New Orleanss Six-Sentence Disaster

Steve Clemons of the Washington Note argues that President Bush, in an April 2004 speech, implied that constitutional law requires you  as President of the United States  to secure a court order before wiretapping. . . . In the Boston Globe, Harvard professor Edward L. Glaeser writes that [W]e are in danger of doing a far worse job rebuilding New Orleans than rebuilding Baghdad.  At the Huffington Post, Congressional Quarterlys Craig Crawford blogs about what he calls New Orleanss six-sentence disaster in the State of the Union address: Can there be any more proof that the federal government is washing its hands of the worst natural disaster in U.S. history? Dozens and dozens of paragraphs on rebuilding other nations, but barely a mention of New Orleans.  Maybe Louisiana should secede and turn over their oil to Islamic radicals  then the feds would invade and finally rebuild.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SUESHOLTZ, HENRICK DANIEL ''HERB''
description: SUESHOLTZ--Henrick Daniel "Herb". 91, Pioneer in TV and Picture - framing industries. Herb Suesholtz was born in Flatbush, Brooklyn in 1914. In 1935 he received a degree in chemical engineering from prestigious Cooper Union. During the war years he worked for RCA under an important government contract. Mr. Suesholtz was among the lead engineers in developing the radar tubes utilized by American navel vessels. This experience led him to a similar position with RCA following the war's conclusion. In 1946 Mr. Suesholtz left RCA to join tiny Transvision of New Rochelle, NY. He would eventually become president of the company and under his stewardship Transvision became the nation's third leading manufacturer of TV sets, trailing only Zenith and RCA. In addition, Mr. Suesholtz's leadership enabled Transvision to accomplish some firsts in the industry. Such innovations that are now taken for granted -remote control units, cable systems, and "educational TV" were introduced by Transvision. During the 1950's Transvision established a picturetube plant in Cuba only to have it "nationalized" by Cuba's communist regime. In fact, Mr. Suesholtz was in Cuba at the time Castro and his pary seized power. Though he lost his factory, Mr. Suesholtz did make friends among his Cuban employees, helping several to escape to the U.S. Though he left the television industry in the early 60's, Mr. Suesholtz carried his innovative spirit with him to his next endeavor. In 1969 he acquired the Gaines picture frame moulding factory, renamed it Gaines-American Moulding Corp., and introduced perhaps the greatest change in that industry with the introduction of "chop service." This enabled many entrepreneurs with little money to establish their own businesses. First met with almost unanimous opposition from the industry, "chop service" is now such a staple of the framing industry that it is more or less taken for granted. From 1982 until his death Mr. Suesholtz worked as an independent sales rep., but never lost his zeal for innovation and invention, evidenced by his registration of four U.S. patents that continue to shape the picture-framing industry. He was noted for stating, many times, that the only disappointment of his life was the loss of his son, Jay B., to leukemia in 1990. However, Mr. Suesholtz is survived by his wife, Florence Monaco Suesholtz of Harrison, NY, son William Suesholtz of Harrison, daughters Wendy Chazin and Amy Cooper of Manhattan, step-son Robert Miraglia of Arizona, and grandson Christipher Chazin of Manhattan. Mr. Suesholtz's family will be receiving friends on Friday between 12 noon and 1PM. Interment to follow at the Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, NY. Harrison Funeral Home, 329 Halstead Avenue, Harrison, NY 10528. 914-835-0282

Arts, Briefly; John Roberts Leaves CBS
description: John Roberts, the CBS News White House correspondent who was once on the shortlist of those who might succeed Dan Rather as anchor of the "CBS Evening News," is leaving the network for CNN. On Feb. 20, Mr. Roberts becomes senior national correspondent at CNN, a posting that enables him to contribute to programs across that cable channel's lineup, Jon Klein, president of CNN's domestic operations, said in a statement. Mr. Roberts, who joined CBS in 1992 as anchor of the "CBS Morning News" and has covered the White House for the network for more than six years, becomes one of the more recognizable reporters on the CNN roster. Any chance that Mr. Roberts had of succeeding Mr. Rather -- a plan favored by several senior CBS News executives -- effectively evaporated after Mr. Rather stepped down as anchor amid the fallout of a disputed "60 Minutes Wednesday" segment about President Bush's Vietnam-era National Guard service. At the time, Leslie Moonves, chairman of CBS, said he hoped the news division would consider scrapping a single anchor format. Sean McManus, the new president of CBS News, said at a gathering of television critics last month that he expected to name a solo anchor -- and preferably an outsider -- as a permanent successor to Mr. Rather. JACQUES STEINBERG

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Jobs Cut in BCE Overhaul
description: BCE, the parent company of Bell Canada, will shed 4,000 jobs and spin off its satellite and rural telephone operations. The company, based in Montreal, which also plans a share buyback, made the announcements yesterday after reducing its profit outlook for 2006 to 1.80 Canadian dollars ($1.57) to 1.90 Canadian dollars ($1.65) a share from 2.05 Canadian dollars ($1.79) last year. About 1.6 million telephone lines in Ontario and Quebec will be turned over to a new income trust, a business structure in Canada that pays out most of a company's cash directly to its owners and avoids most corporate taxes. BCE will retain a 50 percent holding in the trust and its operations will largely be handled in a contract with Bell Canada. BCE will sell Telesat Canada, a communications satellite operator, too, but will increase the company's debt first. Then BCE will transfer about 1 billion Canadian dollars of Telesat's cash to its accounts. It is expected that BCE will generate about 4 billion Canadian dollars ($3.5 billion) from the two asset sales.

title: Germany sees no need to apologize
World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: New Tactic by Grupo Televisa
description: In a new legal maneuver, the Mexican media company Grupo Televisa is looking for a way to break its programming deal with the American Spanish-language broadcaster Univision. As part of a lawsuit seeking back royalties from Univision, Televisa said this week that Univision was in material breach of the licensing deal that supplies the network with most of its prime-time schedule, according to a filing by Univision with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The two companies first negotiated the 25-year deal in 1992, but Televisa executives now believe that their company can earn more for its programming as the Spanish-language audience in the United States has grown. Televisa, which is based in Mexico City, owns about 11 percent of Univision and has been openly critical of Univision's chairman, A. Jerrold Perenchio. "Univision emphatically disagrees with Televisa's characterization of its claims and will take all necessary action to ensure Televisa's continued performance under the programming license agreement until its expiration in 2017," Univision said in its court filing. Univision is based in Los Angeles.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Polio Eliminated In Egypt And Niger
description: The World Health Organization declared two more nations free of indigenous polio, leaving only four -- an all-time low -- where a reservoir of the paralytic disease remains. The two countries where indigenous strains have been eliminated are Egypt and Niger; the four where such strains still exist are Nigeria, Afghanistan, India, and Pakistan. Imported cases have been reported in eight countries: Angola, Chad, Ethiopia, Indonesia, Nepal, Niger, Somalia and Yemen. Niger reported nine imported cases of polio last year; W.H.O. scientists identified the strain of virus in each and found that all had come from Nigeria. LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN (NYT)

The attacks occurred early in the morning as the female victims walked alone. On Oct. 8 at 5:30 a.m., the man robbed a 22-year-old woman, told her he had a gun and then assaulted her. On Oct. 29 at 6:30 a.m., he held a knife to the throat of a 29-year-old woman as he robbed and raped her. The latest attack occurred at 6:30 a.m. yesterday when he grabbed a 38-year-old woman, said he had a gun, took her money and then led her to a secluded area where he assaulted her. The man is described as black, 25 to 30 years old and about 6 feet tall, with short black hair and a goatee.

There is nothing we love better than finding order where we suspect it may not exist and deciphering meaning where meaning may not be intended. We wonder, what is the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences trying to tell us? Couldn't they just send an e-mail message?

title: On The Street: Then; Stylishness That Never Goes Out of Style -- January 22 1989
description: THERE are women in every era who beam a self-assurance that is bred deep in the bone. That confidence was the birthright of a coterie of New Yorkers brought up in an age when one signaled one's correctness through one's accouterments -- and never looked back. To such women a good cloth coat was a signifier of taste, its edges softened by fur or a scarf wound through a buttonhole. The look was majestic, enhanced by a carriage so austere the queen mother comes to mind.
