title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Hails Housing Program
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. is to announce today that it has finished ahead of schedule a five-year program to invest $750 million to help stem a feared post-9/11 exodus from New York City. The program, in which union pension funds were invested in city projects using union labor and to finance mortgages for firefighters, schoolteachers and other city workers so they could afford to remain in the city, will also begin a second phase, totaling more than $2 billion, including $1.5 billion from bank and insurance company lenders. The union federation also plans to start a similar program in New Orleans, with an investment of $300 million. In the New York program, the federation said it invested nearly $849 million in four years, not five. It built or repaired more than 13,000 units of housing, provided 1,760 families with home financing and generated more than 7.2 million hours of union construction work.

title: Vivendi to buy rest of group
Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, STEVEN M.
description: BERNSTEIN--Steven M. On February 1, 2006 of complications of colon cancer. Loving father of Charles Bernstein, devoted husband to Marcia Levy, spectacular brother, and brother-in-law to Susan and Stanley Gebler, Reesa and Steve Levy, Miriam and Leon Luck, warm and supportive uncle to Adam and Nicola, Meredith, Alyson, Ashley & Logan. Passionate lawyer and activist, incredible friend, amazing dancer and adoring of his dog, Bandit. Funeral, February 3, 11:45 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St & Amsterdam Ave, NYC. 212362-6600. Shiva arrangements to be announced.

title: Lights. Mood. Video. All at the Touch of a Screen.
description: Vincent Aita, a partner in a Chicago-based hedge fund firm who does considerable work in New York, bought a two-bedroom apartment overlooking the Chelsea section of Manhattan last year. But before he moved in, he commissioned a months-long makeover complete with new floors, a sleek new kitchen and an updated open profile where there were once walls.

title: High-Rises That Have Low Impact on Nature
description: With its curtain wall and faceted crystal design, the Bank of America building rising at 1 Bryant Park in Manhattan probably seems unremarkable to New Yorkers accustomed to looming glass skyscrapers. But it's not architecture with a capital A that makes the tower unusual.

ECB signals higher rate could come next month
For Boy George, a Repeat Show in a New York Courtroom
description: Boy George, a pair of arching, feminine eyebrows the only hint of the gender-bending makeup that once made him a pop sensation, ambled down the aisle in a Manhattan criminal courtroom yesterday, looking pale and tense.

title: Asia Letter: A diplomatic presence in more than name only
Paid Notice: Deaths   MCINERNEY, DENIS
description: McINERNEY -- Denis, died peacefully at home on January 31, 2006. Beloved husband of Irene Murphy McInerney. Devoted father of Kathleen O'Hare, Denis J. McInerney and Maura Romano. He is also survived by eight grandchildren. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, New York on Thursday from 7-9 p.m., and Friday from 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Mass of Christian Burial will be on Saturday at 10 a.m. at the Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye, New York. His interment will follow at the Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, New York. In lieu of flowers, the McInerney family requests that any donations be made to the McInerney Scholarship for Public Service, Fordham Law School, 140 West 62nd Street, New York, New York 10023.

title: Living Ever Larger: Estates in the Sky
description: FOR more than a decade, McMansions have been a fixture on the American landscape. Now apartments are being supersized, too.

title: Welcome-to-A.C.C. Moment
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Feb. 1 - The Christmas cards from old Big East foes Syracuse, UConn and Rutgers still don't come to Boston College during the holiday season. The university's defection from the Big East to the Atlantic Coast Conference still stings in many East Coast circles.

title: Fulfilling vow, Merkel looks east
G.M. to Spend Up to $15 Billion on Information Technology
description: DETROIT, Feb. 2 A General Motors said today that it would spend up to $15 billion over the next five years to outsource information technology work as it continues to shift business away from its former subsidiary Electronic Data Systems.

title: Top Linebacker Meets Fatherhood Head-On
description: DETROIT, Feb. 1 - When Pittsburgh linebacker Larry Foote looks across the line of scrimmage Sunday, he will not be daunted. Sitting across the dinner table from a vegetable-hating 9-year-old has helped Foote develop the forbearance to hold his ground, even against somebody as shifty as Shaun Alexander, the Seattle Seahawks' luminous running back.

title: A More Impassioned Bush, on the Road, Delivers a State of the Union Encore
description: NASHVILLE, Feb. 1 - President Bush took his upbeat message on the road Wednesday and promised "an active foreign policy, one that aids the suffering and helps the poor" and spreads freedom around the world.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: Pirro Discounts Old Gaffes and Issues to Focus on Attorney General Race
description: A disastrous campaign for the United States Senate? Oh, that. Old news.

title: No Hands? Snakes Are Naturals for That
description: Bluetooth devices for hands-free cellphone use are particularly popular in cars, but some people find the Bluetooth mikes that clip around the ear to be annoying. A device called Snake from Iqua provides an alternative. It wraps around the headrest of your car seat, placing a speaker near your ear and a microphone on a flexible neck near your mouth.

title: False Convictions
description: To the Editor:

title: Budget Measure Increases College Loans and Rates
description: With the narrow passage of the spending bill by Congress yesterday, students and their parents will be able to borrow more money to pay for higher education but will face higher interest rates on these federal loans beginning in July.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in the Circuits pages of Business Day last Thursday with a brief report about a 160-gigabyte portable hard drive from Seagate was published in error. It showed a model holding 120 gigabytes, not 160. (Except for the capacity designation on the case, that model looks identical to the 160-gigabyte version.)

title: Another Young Russian With a Sense of Style
description: Despite the turmoil of post-Soviet Russia, music teachers in Moscow, like the Steinway piano factory in Astoria, keep turning out consistent, high-quality, well-constructed products. Gleb Ivanov, last year's winner of the Young Concert Artists auditions, is a cut above the usual, with a certain musical sensitivity and an appreciation of style to go with the thunder and lightning.

title: Danish writer reflects on uproar
World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Retirement Age To Rise
description: The cabinet has agreed to raise the retirement age in steps to 67 from 65 by 2029, Labor and Social Affairs Minister Franz Mntefering said. The move is necessary to meet the demands of a population that is living longer and having fewer children, he said. VICTOR HOMOLA (NYT)

title: 30-Year Bonds on Sale Again Next Week
description: The Treasury Department will sell $14 billion in 30-year bonds next week, the return after more than four years of a security that had been regarded by many as the world's safest long-term investment.

title: Briefly: Israel intends to reopen goods crossing in Gaza
Quake's Homeless Battle Winter
description: QAZIABAD, Kashmir, Jan. 26 - Three months after the devastating earthquake leveled every house in this mountain village in Pakistani-controlled Kashmir, the newlyweds Zaheer and Shazia found themselves sleeping once more in the open, this time in the snow. Their cotton tent had collapsed on top of them in the night under a heavy snowfall, so for four nights, they huddled in the open on a rope bed by a fire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STONE, NORMA DOLORES
description: STONE--Norma Dolores. After a brief illness, of cancer. Famed beauty and model in her youth, she is survived by her daughter Danielle Steel and loving grandchildren Beatrix, Samantha, Victoria, Vanessa, Maximillian, Zara, Trevor, Todd and the late Nicholas and great-grandson Sebastian. The family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Thursday February 2, 7-9 PM. Memorial service, Church of Our Savior, 59 Park Avenue at 38th Street, Friday February 3, 11 AM.

title: Promise is seenin H5N1 vaccine
Putting Your Very Best Foyer Forward
description: Although foyers offer a first impression of a home, they are often overlooked. Not by Judy Casey, a photographers' representative who lives on the Upper West Side and who not only renovated the foyer of her apartment, above, but mustered every professional skill available to turn it into a work of art.

title: A Really, Really Close-Up View of Water and Sand
description: An artists' cooperative called the Learning Group has designed and helped build a 538-square-foot hexagonal dwelling in Monterrey, Mexico, using wire mesh, concrete and recycled plastic bottles filled with sand or water. Julio Castro, one of the artists, lives in Monterrey and led the project. A couple from a squatters' community is living in the house, called Collected Material Dwelling No. 002, Mexico 2005. (Information on the project: learningsite.info.) Another version, made with cardboard and a tarp roof, below, will be at the Museum of Arts and Design in New York in an exhibition called "Beyond Green: Toward a Sustainable Art" from today through May 7.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAMERMAN, MORTON
description: KAMERMAN--Morton. Died February 1, 2006, at the age of 79, in Martin Memorial Hospital, Stuart, Florida, at the end of a long battle with heart problems. He enjoyed a successful and fulfilling life and will be missed and long remembered by his beloved wife of 58 years, Sheila Brody Kamerman and children Nathan and his wife Hillary, Elliot and his wife Jean, Laura and her husband Alan, and his adored grandchildren Rebecca, Rachel, Oren, Jessica, Melissa, Danielle and her husband Stuart. Funeral services are limited to family and intimate friends. The week of mourning will be observed in New York City at 1125 Park Avenue.

title: As Russia markets soar,Goldman seeks inroads
For $500 million payday, forget Wall St.
In New York Schools, Whole Milk Is Cast From the Menu
description: For generations of children, a serving of whole milk, customarily in a red and white carton, has been as synonymous with school as a yellow No. 2 pencil. When President Harry S. Truman signed the National School Lunch Program into law in 1946, a half pint of milk was one of five dietary staples required by the bill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERSTEIN, WENDY
description: WASSERSTEIN -- Wendy. NYU's Tisch School of the Arts and the Rita and Burton Goldberg Department of Dramatic Writing note with deep sorrow the passing of Wendy Wasserstein, talented playwright, esteemed colleague, and valued friend. As a Goldberg Professor she was an admired faculty member, and as a teacher she was an inspiring role model and mentor to our students. She possessed a special light that would shine warmth and optimism on everyone she met. Her enormous talent was eclipsed only by her enormous heart. We shall miss her friendship but are grateful for the time we had with her. We extend our deepest condolences to her entire family. Mary Schmidt Campbell, Dean, NYU's Tisch School of the Arts Richard Wesley, Chair, Goldberg Department of Dramatic Writing

title: Arts, Briefly; 'American Idol' And American President
description: Between "American Idol" on Fox at 8 p.m. and the State of the Union coverage for the remainder of the night on most networks, Fox had another easy victory on Tuesday. "Idol," in which the normally cheery Paula Abdul said "no" more readily and crankily than she usually does, delivered 28.73 million viewers and a dominant 18-to-49 rating. According to the early ratings approximations for President Bush's live address, Fox also placed first in its broadcast of the speech, followed by CBS, ABC and NBC. (But the latter two networks were so close in their ratings that the order could change when the final numbers come in.) Opposite the first hour of the speech, WB's "Supernatural" scored better-than-usual ratings, with an audience of 5.87 million and a second-place finish among adults 18 to 34 and 18 to 49. On Monday, A&E's "Flight 93," a television movie about one of the planes hijacked on Sept. 11, 2001, brought in 5.9 million viewers, making it the most-watched program in that cable channel's 22-year history. KATE AURTHUR

title: More Training Is Seen as Key to Improving Math Levels
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 - President Bush's proposal, in Tuesday's State of the Union address, to increase the ranks of Advanced Placement and International Baccalaureate teachers in math and science by 70,000 over four years would nearly triple the number of such teachers and, the administration hopes, make college-level courses available to more low-income students.

title: Paramount Cuts 120 Jobs After Merger
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1 - Paramount Pictures, the unit of Viacom Inc. that agreed to acquire DreamWorks SKG for $1.6 billion, said Wednesday that it had completed the deal and was laying off about 120 workers. The largest cuts will be in Paramount's domestic distribution staff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAIFFA, ELLIOT
description: RAIFFA--Elliot. On January 31, 2006. Beloved husband of the late Gloria. Devoted father of Janet, Jonathan and the late Karen. Dear brother of Howard and Pearl. Services Friday 11:30 AM at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Senate Panel Rebuffed on Documents on U.S. Spying
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 - The Bush administration is rebuffing requests from members of the Senate Judiciary Committee for its classified legal opinions on President Bush's domestic spying program, setting up a confrontation in advance of a hearing scheduled for next week, administration and Congressional officials said Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, NAN BIMBLICK
description: BROWN--Nan Bimblick. Born January 10, 1931 in Cincinnati, passed away on January 31 just three weeks after her 75th birthday. Nan was beautiful and strong and the best mother her sons Warren and Gary, and daughter, Anabelle, could have had. An accomplished fashion designer, businesswoman and caregiver to her husbands Robert Bimblick and Marvin Brown, she was a powerful and loving force for everyone she knew. The family asks that tributes be made to Leesburg Regional Medical Center Foundation, 701 W. Palmetto St., Leesburg, FL, 34748, or to any local Hospice.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the Palestinian election victory by Hamas, the radical Islamic group, misidentified the young militants causing tensions with the old guard in the Fatah group, which Hamas defeated. They are from Fatah, not Hamas.

title: Egypt Insists That Hamas Stop Violence
description: CAIRO, Feb. 1 - Egypt insisted Wednesday that Hamas renounce violence, confirm existing agreements between Israel and the Palestinians and recognize Israel's legitimacy if it wants to form the next Palestinian government.

title: Astros' Insurance Plan to Keep Bagwell Away
description: IF Drayton McLane drops in at the Houston Astros' spring camp in Kissimmee, Fla., on Feb. 23 or 24, he should plan on seeing Jeff Bagwell.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Son Charged In Father's Death
description: A 62-year-old man found dead outside his Lower East Side apartment building on Sunday had been strangled and pushed out of his eighth-floor window by his son, the authorities charged yesterday. The father, Edwin Y. Fondo, was found dead in the rear of 77-79 Columbia Street at 6:35 p.m., the police said. His son, also named Edwin Fondo, 21, had argued with him, law enforcement officials said, adding that they did not know the reason for the fight. The son has been arraigned on murder charges.

title: Bettis Left a Broken Neighborhood Behind
description: DETROIT, Feb. 1 - The front door at 10384 Aurora Street is closed. But the broken windows upstairs are flung open and framed by burn marks. A hole in the roof opens wide to the gray winter sky.

title: Dia Official May Be Hired by Los Angeles Museum
description: Correction Appended

title: How to Get to Princeton? Just Grab Onto Its Name
description: For its first 150 years, Princeton University was called the College of New Jersey. Then it adopted the name of its hometown. Now it wants to stop others from freely using the Princeton name.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Bus Fire Indictments
description: George H. Maples, whose company owned a bus that caught fire in September, killing 23 nursing home residents from Houston who were fleeing Hurricane Rita, was indicted on charges of failing to maintain the vehicle and falsifying records regarding the working hours of bus drivers. Also indicted was Mr. Maples's transport company, Global Limo Inc., which federal authorities closed after the fire. Mr. Maples, 65, of McAllen, could be fined $400,000 and sentenced to seven years in prison if convicted. Global Limo could be fined $900,000. STEVE BARNES (NYT)

title: James Puts Foot Down; Nets Hear Footsteps
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 1 - The Nets' Jason Kidd had just stolen the ball and had a clear path to the basket for a layup when he saw the Cavaliers' LeBron James closing from behind. Instead of steaming in for the easy bucket, Kidd hesitated -- and his layup did not fall.

title: Give Long Island a Break
description: To the Editor:

title: Evangelical Filmmakers Criticized for Hiring Gay Actor
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 - Christian ministers were enthusiastic at the early private screenings of "End of the Spear," made by Every Tribe Entertainment, an evangelical film company. But days before the film's premiere, a controversy erupted over the casting of a gay actor that has all but eclipsed the movie and revealed fault lines among evangelicals.

title: Spain joins opposition to Mittal bid for Arcelor
The March of the Straw Soldiers
description: President Bush is not giving up the battle over domestic spying. He's fighting it with an army of straw men and a fleet of red herrings.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Candidate Withdraws
description: A day after announcing her candidacy for lieutenant governor, State Representative Marie St. Fleur, a Boston Democrat, withdrew from the race after The Boston Globe reported that she has been delinquent on taxes and student loans. The Globe reported Ms. St. Fleur owes $40,000 in student loan payments and had a $12,711 federal tax lien filed against her and her husband, an accountant, for failure to pay taxes. Attorney General Thomas F. Reilly, who is running for governor, had chosen Ms. St. Fleur as his running mate. KATIE ZEZIMA (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   JAFFE, EDDA
description: JAFFE--Edda. You are remembered daily with love and missed always. Your devoted children, Susanne and Brett

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHNITZER, RAYMOND LEROY
description: SCHNITZER--Raymond Leroy, 84. Died on January 29, 2006, in NYC. Beloved and devoted husband of Shirley. Adored and adoring father of Michael. As a long-time radio announcer at Station WNYC, he hosted many classical music programs, anchored news broadcasts and was the host of a long-running popular afternoon news and information series. He was admired for his beautiful speaking voice, impeccable diction, and remarkable ability to ad lib in any situation.

title: Much Talk, Mostly Low Key, About Energy Independence
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 1 - Industry experts say that if President Bush wants to make a push to reduce the country's oil consumption, there are some solutions at hand. But with names like carbon composites and new metal alloys, they may seem banal and do not create much buzz.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 23 about the shortage of medical facilities in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina referred imprecisely to the Medical Center of Louisiana. There are other Level 1 trauma centers on or near the Gulf Coast, including those in Houston, Galveston, Tex., and Tampa, Fla. The one in Louisiana is not the only one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZALK, LEE (NEE BLOOMBERG)
description: ZALK--Lee (nee Bloomberg), 86. Of Floral Park, NY and Lake Worth, FL on January 31. Devoted wife of the late Joseph, proud mother of Richard and Connie, grandmother to David, sister of the late Martin Bloomberg and Sylvia Plotkin and sister-inlaw to Milton and Estelle Zalk. Dedicated aunt and great-aunt and special friend to many. Services to be held Thursday, February 2 at Riverside North Chapel in Great Neck at 1PM. Burial Beth David Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEVENS, ALYCE
description: STEVENS--Alyce. Kips Bay Boys & Girls Club deeply mourns the passing of Mrs. William H. (Alyce) Stevens, Jr. in Florida on January 23. Alyce was a longtime member of the Women's Committee, and a founding member of the Kips Bay Boys & Girls Club Decorator Show House in 1973. That first year the Show House Journal was assembled on Alyce's bed. Inspired amateurs had created one of New York City's most enduring and successful charitable events. The Journal remained her special project for the next 25 years. Godspeed, dear Alyce.

title: Icy Ball Is Larger Than Pluto. So, Is It a Planet?
description: A ball of ice and dust discovered last year in the outskirts of the solar system is 30 percent wider than Pluto, a team of German astronomers is reporting today.

title: 36 More Small Schools Due in September, Mayor Says
description: Thirty-six small middle schools and high schools, many with specialties ranging from mathematics and technology to hospitality and tourism, will open in September, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday.

title: The Nerve-Racking Challenge of Playing for the Overtrick
description: We all play contract bridge. But there are variations on the theme, and the scoring system has a marked effect on the correct tactics. There are versions where overtricks are almost irrelevant, as in Swiss Teams, rubber-bridge and Chicago; and there are varieties where overtricks are very valuable, as in board-a-match teams and duplicate pairs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANK, MORTON
description: FRANK--Morton. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Morton Frank. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife Charlotte & their family. Jack Sussman, President Joseph Lehman, Secretary

title: Another Blow to U.S.-French Ties: A Visa Bottleneck
description: PARIS, Feb. 1 - The delicate relationship between the United States and France has withstood freedom fries and frosty friendship, but now it may be facing a more serious test: disappearing French tourists.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Criminal and Civil Charges Expected to Be Filed Against Executives of Two Insurance Concerns The Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission are expected to announce criminal and civil fraud charges today against three former top executives at the Berkshire Hathaway subsidiary, the General Reinsurance Corporation, as well as a former senior executive of the American International Group, according to two people with direct knowledge of the charges. 5th Man Is Held in Bronx Attack
description: A Bronx man was arrested yesterday in the beating of Officer Eric Hernandez on Saturday morning at a Bronx White Castle restaurant, becoming the fifth suspect accused in the attack.

title: World Nuclear Panel Meets Today on Iran; Possible Concession Is in the Works
description: VIENNA, Feb. 1 - Britain, France and Germany introduced a draft resolution on Wednesday asking the 35-nation board of the International Atomic Energy Agency to refer Iran's nuclear case to the United Nations Security Council.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: 20 Die In Avalanches
description: More than 20 people have been killed in avalanches after heavy snowfalls in the north in the last two days, government officials said. Fifteen bodies were dug out from one avalanche that destroyed 38 houses on Monday in Badakhshan Province, and more people were missing, the deputy governor said. Roads to the village were blocked by snow, and local officials said they had appealed to the government and international peacekeepers to provide helicopters for them to reach the buried village. Three people were killed and 20 injured in a second avalanche in the province, and three people were killed in the neighboring Takhar Province

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLFF, WALTER C.
description: WOLFF--Walter C. An omission from yesterday's notice: Also survived by his beloved sister, Ellen Ducat.

description: An article last Thursday about a book on single women and real estate misspelled the surname of a high school friend and neighbor of one of the authors. She is Michele Zack, not Zach.

description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders' Colley Has a Broken Neck
description: The Islanders announced yesterday that forward Kevin Colley sustained a fracture of the fifth cervical vertebrae in his neck against Washington on Tuesday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Looks Like Wood or Metal, But Rolls Up, Up and Away
description: Delia Heilig, a Los Angeles industrial designer who recently moved to Manhattan, designs and produces roller shades patterned after traditional window motifs from around the world, including Chinese wood latticework, Indian stone jali, and, above, French wrought iron. "I've kept the palette neutral, so they are easy to add to any interior," Ms. Heilig said. Because of their architectural look, she refers to them as building elements rather than window treatments.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading with the continuation of a front-page article yesterday about President Bush's State of the Union address included an erroneous observation about topics not included in the speech. Hurricane Katrina was indeed mentioned by Mr. Bush.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: Tuesday Elections Still On
description: After four postponements, the leaders of the interim government reassured the country that elections would be held on Tuesday and urged voters not to be afraid to cast ballots. The officials said that nearly 90 percent of an estimated 3.5 million voter cards had been distributed. Schools and government offices will be closed for the first three days of next week so that the police and United Nations peacekeepers can focus their attention on polling places and electoral offices. American Airlines said it will cancel flights to and from Port-au-Prince on Monday and Tuesday over concern about the elections. American operates three daily flights from Miami, one from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and one from New York. GINGER THOMPSON (NYT)

title: Silk Road: A challenging but worthy trip
World Briefing | Africa: Tanzania: U.S. Grant To Fight Corruption
description: The Millennium Challenge Corporation, the Bush administration's foreign aid program, approved an $11 million grant to help Tanzania combat corruption and qualify for a bigger aid package. The money will pay to train investigative journalists, prosecutors and monitors, conduct audits and set up a unit to analyze and make public suspicious transactions. CELIA W. DUGGER (NYT)

title: Still in Shape and Wowing the Old Neighborhood
description: Performers who retail a cultivated charm are a dime a dozen. A few, like Tony Danza, radiate an unquenchable bonhomie. When they're onstage, the air is so thick with their good vibes you sense it as a chemical secretion wafting through the room; they cannot help but be likable.

title: Settlers in West Bank Outpost Battle Police Who Came to Raze Houses

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TROSS, LEONARD
description: TROSS--Leonard. Loving and beloved husband of the late Ann. Cherished father of Roberta Cook and Susan Tross, and father-in-law of Michael Cook. Proud Papa of Jonathan and Alexander Cook. Devoted brother and brother-in-law of Frieda and Del Zucker, the late Laura and Jerry Weinthal and the late Madeline and Lou Galanter. Patriarch of a large and loving family, including his nieces and nephew, Wendy, Beth and Howard, their spouses, children and grandchildren. We all love you and will miss you. Service Thursday, February 2, 9:45 am at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Nests Imperial or Fashionably Feathered
description: A RIBBON of runway bisects a spacious lobby wing at 20 Pine Street in the financial district, extending some 45 feet down the length of the room, up a rear wall and across the ceiling. Made of glass and lighted from within, it is a near replica of the runway at Giorgio Armani's headquarters in Milan, a copy calculated to suggest the building's lofty fashion lineage.

title: Rutgers Shows Storm How to Close
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Feb. 1 - Ranked in the top 25 for the first time in more than two decades, St. John's showed heart but lacked the firepower and the size to show off its flashy new ranking against Rutgers. In a tight game between an established team and a rising one, Rutgers showed a new kid on the block how to close out a game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YOUNG, BEATRICE
description: YOUNG -- Beatrice. Died peacefully in her 94th year. Dear sister of Ruth Gilbert, devoted mother of Marcia and Joseph (Zwiebel), Susan and Abraham (Pion). Proud grandmother of Debby, Karen, Jonathan, Jan, Paula. Loving great-grandmother of Jason, Daniel, Jamie, Jaclyn, Jacob, Sophie, Emily. Jacob, Jeremy, Jordana, Joshua, Jessica, Jaclyn, Jared, Brett, and Sammy.

title: Hussein's Trial Resumes, but He Stays Away
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 1 - The trial of Saddam Hussein resumed Wednesday without him, after he and four other main defendants refused to attend and the judge decided to continue anyway.

title: For This Comedy Writer, No Is Never an Answer
description: Behind every hit on television there is usually a miss -- or several misses. That is certainly the case with NBC's one true hit this season, "My Name Is Earl," one of the freshest new network comedies in years, which, if its charms had been recognized earlier, might be playing tonight on the Fox network.

Next season, Texas will have to make do without quarterback Vince Young and defensive back Michael Huff, and Southern California will be without quarterback Matt Leinart and running backs Reggie Bush and LenDale White.

title: Car Bombs Kill 16 in Baghdad; 5 Soldiers Killed in Attacks
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 2 A Two car bombs detonated in quick succession this evening near a crowded market in eastern Baghdad, killing at least 16 people and wounding 90 in one of the worst attacks in the capital in weeks.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 - The energy proposals set out on Tuesday by President Bush quickly ran into obstacles on Wednesday, showing how difficult it will be to take even the limited steps he supports to reduce the nation's reliance on foreign oil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STILLMAN, EUGENIA W.
description: STILLMAN--Eugenia W., 86. Funeral at NEW TIME: 3PM on Friday, February 3 at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue at 71 St, NYC 10021.

title: House Approves Budget Cutbacks of $39.5 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 - House Republicans eked out a victory on a $39.5 billion budget-cutting package on Wednesday, with a handful of skittish Republicans switching their votes at the last minute in opposition to reductions in spending on health and education programs.

title: U.S. turns to WTO again over new subsidies to Airbus
Bird Flu Kills Chicken Smuggled From Mainland to Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 1 - A chicken smuggled across the border from mainland China has died here of bird flu, Hong Kong officials announced late Wednesday. The case raised new questions about whether Chinese provincial officials are concealing the true extent of the disease.

title: Overhaul Urged for Laws on AIDS Tests and Data
description: New York City's health commissioner, Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, called yesterday for changing state laws so that health officials could more aggressively test people for H.I.V. and AIDS and use the medical information the city already collects to help treat those infected.

title: Crushing Cookies That Snoop
description: Crushing Cookies That Snoop

title: Greek cellphones tapped
From clay pots to quail eggs in Hanoi
World Briefing | Americas: Bolivia: Bush Calls For Dialogue With New Leader
description: President Bush telephoned Bolivia's newly inaugurated president, Evo Morales, to congratulate him and express the need for constructive dialogue between the countries. Mr. Morales, an Aymara Indian who has long opposed American antidrug practices in Bolivia, has in the past been linked to drug trafficking by American officials and in December called Mr. Bush a terrorist. The United States is worried that Mr. Morales could reverse years of eradication efforts against coca, the plant used to make cocaine. JUAN FORERO (NYT)

title: Concertos, Yes, but a Mozart Never Far From His Operatic Impulse
description: The second installment of the New York Philharmonic's three-week "Magic of Mozart" minifestival is all about concertos. In the first half of the program, on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, Jeffrey Kahane, a conductor who began his career as a pianist, played two of Mozart's meatier piano concertos -- No. 17 in G and No. 20 in D minor -- leading the orchestra from the keyboard. After the intermission, he moved to the podium and presided over the Sinfonia Concertante for Violin and Viola, with Michelle Kim and Rebecca Young as soloists.

title: Yao in China: No. 1 in Hearts, No. 3 in Shirts
description: It is a mystery worth exploring: Yao Ming, the best-known athlete from a country of 1.3 billion people and the top vote-getter among N.B.A. All-Stars, is the name on the back of the third best-selling jersey in China.

title: Regulators check Thai first family
Giving Everything the Supercharged Treatment, Even Ballads
description: Enterprise and industry aren't qualities often attributed to jazz's rambunctious outer fringe. In the case of Ken Vandermark, though, they dominate the discussion. Mr. Vandermark, a saxophonist and clarinetist based in Chicago, has spent his career fusing the exploratory fire of free jazz with the do-it-yourself ethos of underground rock. Over the past decade, his efforts have yielded both a sizable fan base and a cottage industry: Mr. Vandermark's Web site, kenvandermark.com, lists eight releases from 2005, including a studio album and a 12-CD boxed set featuring his signature ensemble, the Vandermark 5.

title: Who Is the Modern Man? What Will He Wear?
description: PARIS - IN an operatic collection that seemed to hold its audience at knife point, Hedi Slimane of Dior closed the French fall 2006 men's shows with svelte tailcoats, starched shirt fronts and one Count Dracula cape, leaving the air charged with an erotic formality as well as many questions.

title: Now, No Condos Shall Come Between Goddesses
description: CAN Minerva now maintain eternal eye lock with Lady Liberty?

title: Death Toll Climbs to 8 in California Postal Plant Rampage
description: GOLETA, Calif., Feb. 1 - The death toll in the shooting spree at a postal plant here climbed to eight on Wednesday after a woman injured in the rampage died and the police discovered that the killer had first fatally shot a former neighbor.

title: Developer Will Compensate Merchants Evicted From Bronx Market
description: The redevelopment of the Bronx Terminal Market into a shopping mall cleared its last major hurdle yesterday after the developer agreed to compensate displaced merchants and create a $3 million job training program for local residents.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 19 about pressure on members of Congress to return political contributions linked to the indicted lobbyist Jack Abramoff referred imprecisely to donations to Representative J. D. Hayworth, Republican of Arizona, who was identified by the Center for Responsive Politics as the largest single Congressional recipient of the donations. The congressman received $101,000 that the center said was donated by Mr. Abramoff and his family, Indian tribes and a gambling cruise ship line that he once owned. It did not include donations from Mr. Abramoff's lobbying partners or other associates. This correction was delayed by research.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: TV Deal Falls Through
description: Axel Springer, Europe's biggest newspaper publisher, dropped a plan to buy ProSiebenSat.1, Germany's biggest private broadcaster, for 4.2 billion euros ($5.1 billion) after failing to win regulatory approval. Axel Springer is based in Berlin and ProSiebenSat.1 in Unterfhring.

title: Travel Deals: New York to London
In Playgrounds Tweedy or Seedy, It's All in the Game
description: Gentlemen & Players By Joanne Harris 422 pages. William Murrow. $24.95.

title: An ultraluxury developer spreads the 'residential wealth'
Met Sending Vase to Italy, Ending 30-Year Dispute
description: Reversing its position of more than 30 years, the Metropolitan Museum of Art announced today that it would relinquish ownership of a 2,500-year-old Greek vase, one of the finest in the world, to the Italian government, which has long contended that the vase was stolen from an Etruscan tomb and smuggled from the country.

title: Her Knees No Longer Feeling 74, Barber Is Ready for Millrose Dash
description: Lisa Barber had a breakthrough year last season. It was a breakdown year, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, ARTHUR
description: COHEN--Arthur. August 26, 1952 to January 30, 2006. You were the best father a kid could have. The best friend anyone could have. We will all miss you so very much. You were an inspiration and someone that we all looked up to. We love you and we will miss you. I love you Dad. Tough times don't last. Tough people do. Services will be held Thursday 10 AM at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street.

title: When You Wish Upon a Merger
description: Amagansett, N.Y. - THE $7.4 billion buyout of Pixar Animation by the Walt Disney Company has generated more public speculation than the typical mega-merger, because everyone seemed to realize that this wasn't just another corporate shuffle. It was the convergence of two institutions that have helped shape the American imagination, and it immediately prompted questions about what it might mean for the future of animated movies as well as what it might mean for the entertainment industry generally. The answer is that it might mean a lot for both.

title: Cinema paradiso in America
3 countries head list for visa-free travel
A Real Body of Work
description: FASHION models are usually hired to show off next season's clothes. But last week Ming Ge, a model from Toronto, came to New York to have a traditional Chinese dress, known as a qipao, painted on her slim, statuesque body.

title: Citing Obesity Rates, Hartford Plans to Ban School Sales of Sugary Drinks
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 1 - Citing concerns about a national epidemic of childhood obesity, Gov. M. Jodi Rell and legislative leaders announced an agreement on Wednesday to ban the sale of soda and other sugary drinks in the state's public schools.

title: Heroin Implants Turned Puppies Into Drug Mules, U.S. Says
description: A Colombian drug trafficking organization was readying purebred puppies as drug couriers by surgically implanting large packets of liquid heroin into their bodies to ship them to the United States, federal officials said yesterday.

title: A Cabaret Original Returns to the Road Not Taken
description: "I may have a nervous breakdown," Joanne Beretta announced over the phone as she contemplated her singing gig at Danny's Skylight Room starting tomorrow night. Yet a few days after that conversation, in her tiny but cozy Greenwich Village apartment, she seemed not an artiste on the verge of a meltdown, but an artist excited -- if admittedly a tad nervous -- about resuming a cabaret career that once won critical raves and loyal fans but has long been dormant.

title: The President and the 'Addicted to Oil' Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHRAGER, FRANCES (NEE SHAPIRO)
description: SCHRAGER--Frances (nee Shapiro). Beloved wife of the late Alexander Schrager, devoted mother of Dr. Laura Fishman and Beverly Laise, adoring grandmother of Emily Fishman. Passed away on January 30 at age 90 in Brooklyn, New York. Forever in our hearts.

title: People: Simon Cowell, Judi Dench, James Bond
Uproar grows on prophet images
Paid Notice: Deaths   KING, CORETTA SCOTT
description: KING--Coretta Scott. The staff and members of our 275,000-member health care union mourn the passing of beloved friend and ally Coretta Scott King. She was an inspiring champion of racial and economic justice, peace and the rights of working women. She was a lifelong foe of racism, poverty and violence. She lived a life of strength, grace, principle, sacrifice and beauty. Mrs. King first met 1199ers through her husband, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.'s close association with our union. After his tragic death in 1968 she became a regular at 1199 rallies, picketlines and cultural events. Members from Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore to Hahneman Hospital in Philadelphia to St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan remember meeting her at rallies outside their workplaces. At 1199 conventions and Black History month celebrations she repeatedly called for justice for working mothers. But her most enduring association with 1199 hospital workers came in 1969 during the 100-day strike of 400 black women at two Charleston, South Carolina hospitals. Mrs. King marched, led prayer vigils, spoke in churches and buoyed the spirits of Charleston strikers in an inspiring display of leadership that fused soul power and union power. Over the years her quiet and eloquent dignity overcame bombs, bullets and tragic loss in her ongoing quest to realize the shared dream of a beloved community. Dennis Rivera, President George Gresham, Secretary-Treasurer, 1199SEIU United Healthcare Workers East

title: Jordanian paper runs Prophet Muhammad cartoons
'Are We There Yet?' No, but This Gadget Could Ease the Ride
description: For those long car trips punctuated by the children's fistfights and the interminable replaying of Hilary Duff's latest CD, the Coby TF-DVD560, a portable DVD/CD player, may offer some relief. It has 12 built-in classic Sega games, a remote control and a DC adapter for use both on the road and at home. And it includes a pair of earphones.

title: Board Accepts Resignation of Medical University Leader
description: NEWARK, Feb. 1 - Trustees of New Jersey's financially troubled medical university voted on Wednesday to accept the resignation of its president, Dr. John J. Petillo, but only after he agreed that his $600,000 severance package could be revoked if a federal investigation of the university finds evidence that he should have been fired.

title: Shell will invest despite decline in earnings
I.R.A. Still Involved in Crime, Report Says, but Has Halted Terrorism
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 1 - The Irish Republican Army continues to spy on public officials and operate an organized crime network, according to an independent report made public on Wednesday, six months after the I.R.A., Northern Ireland's largest paramilitary group, declared an end to its armed campaign against British rule in the province.

title: Slopeside at the Olympics, Designing With Frozen Fingers
description: SESTRIERE, Italy - LAST Friday, Lance Fung, the Admiral Perry of the art world, dressed in black Prada Sport, stood above the slopes here in heroic relief against a backdrop of gallery-white snow, then marched down into it, waving to his workers as he churned through knee-deep drifts toward the bottom.

title: World Briefing: Africa, Americas, Europe and Asia
description: AFRICA

title: Eight-term congressman wins battle to lead House Republicans
Other Views: The Independent, Baltimore Sun, Deccan Herald
U.S. Case on Insurers Is Expected
description: Civil and criminal complaints are expected to be announced today against three former top executives at a Berkshire Hathaway subsidiary, the General Reinsurance Corporation, as well as a former senior executive of the American International Group, according to people with direct knowledge of the charges.

title: Frey Says Falsehoods Improved His Tale
description: James Frey yesterday offered the first detailed explanation of why he embellished and lied about events in "A Million Little Pieces," his best-selling book: it made a better story.

title: Briefly: Capitol Police drop charges over T-shirts
Investigators Criticize Response to Hurricane
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 - No one from the federal government was clearly in charge of the response to Hurricane Katrina, Congressional investigators said Wednesday, and in the absence of clear leadership the general federal approach was "to wait for affected states to request assistance."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MALOOF, LORRAINE (NEE SAMRA)
description: MALOOF -- Lorraine (nee Samra), of Englewood Cliffs NJ on January 30, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Robert E. Devoted mother of Karen (Larry Buksbaum) Maloof of Demarest, NJ and Glen J. Maloof of West Palm Beach FL. Loving grandmother of Brandon and Scott Buksbaum. Dear sister of Victor M. (Alexandra) Samra Jr. Adored aunt of Victor III and Christina Karper. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home 148 Dean Dr. Tenafly NJ on Thursday 2-4 & 7-9. Service Friday 12 noon at funeral home. Interment Mt. Carmel Cemetery Tenafly. In lieu of flowers, family have requested memorial donations may be made to The Salvation Army, 80 State St. Hackensack, NJ 07601 or Meals on Wheels 290 Old HookRd. Westwood, NJ 07675. For directions, visit www. barrettfuneralhome.net

title: Job Cuts and Falling Ad Sales Send Tribune Profit Down 38%
description: The Tribune Company, publisher of The Los Angeles Times and The Chicago Tribune, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit fell 38 percent, hurt by costs to eliminate jobs and declines in advertising sales and circulation.

title: Seducing the Medical Profession
description: New evidence keeps emerging that the medical profession has sold its soul in exchange for what can only be described as bribes from the manufacturers of drugs and medical devices. It is long past time for leading medical institutions and professional societies to adopt stronger ground rules to control the noxious influence of industry money on what doctors prescribe for their patients.

title: Democrats Call for Special Prosecutor in Lobbying Case
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 A Most Senate Democrats called on the Justice Department today to appoint a special prosecutor to take over the criminal investigation centered on the Republican lobbyist Jack Abramoff, who has pleaded guilty to conspiring to corrupt members of Congress and other public officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLEMAN, HENRY S.
description: COLEMAN--Henry S. Harry's classmates are saddened by the passing of our dear friend and leader. We express our heartfelt sympathy to Lila and all the children. Class of 1946 Columbia College

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Women Sue Wal-Mart Over Morning-After Pill
description: Three women have filed a lawsuit against Wal-Mart Stores, claiming the chain violated state law by failing to carry emergency contraception. The women, who are supported by Planned Parenthood and other reproductive rights groups, tried to fill prescriptions at Wal-Marts in suburban Boston, but were told that the stores did not carry and could not order the drug, known as the morning-after pill. The plaintiffs, all of whom work in the reproductive health or women's rights fields, said they knew they would be denied access to the drug at Wal-Mart. KATIE ZEZIMA (NYT)

title: The President and the 'Addicted to Oil' Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption on Tuesday with an article about the history of National Football League championships misstated the result of the 1940 game in some copies. As the article stated, it was the Chicago Bears who beat the Washington Redskins, 73-0, not the reverse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DRUCKER, ROSE
description: DRUCKER--Rose, 92. January 31, of Arlington, VA. Beloved wife of Herman. Devoted mother of Joel and Ruth, Stephen and the late Gloria Choukroun, loving sister of Muriel, Bernard and the late Dorothy & Albert. Cherished grandmother of Erica and Max. Graveside services 11:45AM, today, the Riverside Cemetery, Saddlebrook, NJ.

title: Deutsche Bank Gives Chief Another 4 Years
description: FRANKFURT, Feb. 1 - Deutsche Bank extended the contract of its chief executive, Josef Ackermann, for four years on Wednesday, riding out a tide of criticism against him and focusing on his accomplishments in strengthening the bank.

title: Hamas at the Helm
description: On one side, there is the state of Israel, backed by Washington, which calls for the new Palestinian governing party, Hamas, to recognize Israel and renounce violence. On the other side is Hamas, which calls for the destruction of Israel and defends its right to use arms to combat Israeli occupation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARMICHAEL, JOEL
description: CARMICHAEL--Joel. Noted scholar, author and editor. Midstream Magazine mourns the passing of its Editor Emeritus who served as editor from 1975 to 2001 with distinction. He will be missed. Kalman Sultanik Rabbi Arthur Schneier Leo Haber

title: A Quiet Band Worth Fighting Loudly About Makes Some More Noise
description: Not long ago a query arrived, urgent and unexpected, via cellphone. The caller had made a bet, and the matter was to be settled through an unscientific poll. The question, shouted over a lively din: Which was better  the second Belle and Sebastian album, "If You're Feeling Sinister," or the third one, "The Boy With the Arab Strap"?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOENIG, SIMON M.
description: KOENIG--Simon M., 92. Of Manhattan and Providence, RI, a prominent matrimonial attorney, died January 31 at the Palm Beach, Florida Hospice. He was the husband of Dorothy Oskern Koenig. Born in New York City, the son of the late Samuel and Pearl (Schifter) Koenig, he held degrees from Fordham and St. John's Law School. He was admitted to the New York Bar after spending three years in the Government Service in an investigative capacity. He was a founding Fellow and lecturer of the American Academy of Matrimonial Lawyers. His other credentials include Past Lecturer, New York County Lawyers, section of Family Law; Author, Laws relevant to Marriage (Division, section of) The Sexual Experience, Williams and Wilkins, 1976; Arbitrator, Matrimonial Matters, American Arbitration Association; Lecturer at New York University Medical School, Department of Psychiatry, Post Graduate Division on Sex and the Law; Lecturer, Sex and the Law, Diagnosis and Treatment of Sexual Disorders, New York Medical College, Post Graduate Psychiatric Department; Lecturer, Family Law and Marital Therapy, Division of Continuing Education, Department of Psychiatry, New York Medical College; Faculty, Post Graduate Instruction, New York Medical College, Department of Psychiatry; Visiting Lecturer, Post Graduate Psychiatry, Family Law, Lenox Hill Hospital and St. Vincent's Hospital. Besides his wife of 37 years, he leaves a son, Arthur Koenig (Jane) of Neshanic, NJ, a daughter, Tina Falcoff (Richard) of Lincolnshire, IL and a grandson, Lee Falcoff. Funeral services will be held Friday at 10:00AM at Sugarman-Sinai Memorial Chapel, Providence. Burial will be in Lincoln Park Cemetery. Shiva will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach, 5300 E. Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL. 33407.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about shootings at a postal plant in Goleta, Calif., misstated the name of the chairman of a Postal Service commission that issued a report in 2000 on workplace violence by mail workers. He is Joseph A. Califano Jr., not James Califano.

title: When No. 1 Has a Hard Time Hiring a No. 2
description: Since opening her Indian tea shop in Jersey City 10 months ago, Amy Dubin has interviewed more than 40 people to be her assistant manager. She offered the job to two of them, and each lasted two days. The first balked at cleaning the bathroom, the second at doing the dishes and at actually making tea.

title: Here Comes the Sunshine, Down Go Korean Barricades
description: UIJONGBU, South Korea - In this city that lies between Seoul and the border with North Korea, an odd-looking gatelike structure rises above the main street, ready to be dismantled. It still supports what seems to the naked eye to be several tons of concrete that serve no particular purpose beyond casting a shadow over approaching cars and the small shops nearby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DROGIN, FANNIE
description: DROGIN--Fannie. January 30 in her 95th year. Much loved wife of the late Paul (Poly) Drogin. Devoted and loving mother of Ira (Janet) grandchildren Laurent (Victoria), Peter (Catherine) and great grandchildren Allison, Dana and Alexander.

title: Cash-poor Palestinians unable to pay workers
Metro Briefing | New York: Yonkers: Mayor To Announce Development
description: Mayor Philip A. Amicone, left, is scheduled to announce a development agreement today for the rehabilitation of two miles of industrialized waterfront land in downtown Yonkers, a spokesman for the mayor said yesterday. The project, which would stretch between the Hudson and Saw Mill Rivers, would tie in with the planned construction of a new ballpark, stores and housing on Chicken Island behind City Hall, said the spokesman, David Simpson.

title: House Republicans to Vote on New Leadership Today
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 - House Republicans headed toward a defining leadership election on Thursday with their membership sharply split over how much to shake up the leadership ranks and how to respond to a politically charged lobbying scandal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOSAK, ALVIN
description: KOSAK--Alvin. Inspiring chemistry professor, stoic humanitarian, and special friend. He left a legacy of concern, thoughtfulness and compassion. Special condolences to his wife Judy, his children David, Andrew & their families. Ira Kukin

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Is Killed After Fight At OTB
description: A man involved in an argument inside an Off-Track Betting parlor in Bay Ridge was fatally shot moments after he left, the police said. The man, Daniel McCurdy, 50, of Gelston Avenue in Bay Ridge, was shot once in the chest outside 513 88th Street, just two blocks from the betting room, by the person he had been seen arguing with before leaving, the police said. He was taken to Victory Memorial Hospital, where he died. There were no arrests last night.

title: A Collection of East Side Stories
description: DESTINATION MATERNITY, the national chain, opened a three-level flagship store on Madison Avenue yesterday. It contains three boutiques that sell maternity clothes and accessories (not the jewelry and handbags kind of accessories but things like diaper bags and a breast pump vehicle adapter). The Pea in the Pod boutique offers maternity clothes from labels like Diane von Furstenberg, Lilly Pulitzer and Juicy Couture; Mimi Maternity has dressy and contemporary clothes; and Motherhood Maternity sells casual active wear.

title: Poland resists bank deal
800 Fund Advisers Register
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said that almost 800 hedge-fund advisers met yesterday's deadline to register with the agency under a new rule that subjects the industry to stricter regulation and random inspections.

title: The Nation of the Future
description: Everywhere I go people tell me China and India are going to blow by us in the coming decades. They've got the hunger. They've got the people. They've got the future. We're a tired old power, destined to fade back to the second tier of nations, like Britain did in the 20th century.

title: False Convictions
description: To the Editor:

title: Commercials That Echo
description: Football fans have always enjoyed watching replays, especially during the Super Bowl. Now they will be able to watch replays of the Super Bowl's commercials.

title: Firestorm Over Cartoon Gains Momentum
description: PARIS, Feb. 2 A An international dispute over European newspaper cartoons deemed blasphemous by some Muslims gained momentum today as gunmen threatened the European Union offices in the Gaza Strip and more European papers pointedly published the drawings as an affirmation of their freedom of speech.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Found Dead In Car
description: A Mount Vernon man was found dead in Baychester early yesterday inside his Range Rover by Mount Vernon police officers investigating his disappearance, the police said. The Mount Vernon police identified the man as Norman Crawford, 49. Deputy Chief Joseph Pizzuti, of the Mount Vernon Police Department, said Mr. Crawford had last been seen at his girlfriend's house on Beechwood Avenue. She told officers that a gunman broke into the house shortly after midnight yesterday and told her they had Mr. Crawford and demanded money, Chief Pizzuti said. She said the gunman struck her and fled after she began screaming. The police said Mr. Crawford appeared to have been shot in the leg and might have bled to death.

title: Sight Unseen, Gonzalez Gives Edwards Seal of Approval
description: DETROIT, Feb. 1 - Kansas City Chiefs tight end Tony Gonzalez has not met Herman Edwards, but he has already heard good things about his new coach from Giants defensive end Michael Strahan. Gonzalez and Strahan were here for a news conference for Pro Bowl players.

title: Pixel Counting Joins Film in Obsolete Bin
description: Correction Appended

title: Physical Culture; Saying Goodbye To the Cotton Club
description: Correction Appended

title: Sometimes a Party Favor Is a Place to Sit in Albany
description: THINK of the city's Democratic political clubhouse as a melting iceberg. Tammany's descendant is steadily shrinking, undermined by an indictment here and a conviction there, by the insults of Republicans in City Hall and then another Republican in City Hall, by a judicial slam at fixed court elections and by competition from the real political power today -- expensive political advertising.

title: When the Label Says Lagerfeld
description: Correction Appended

title: A Fitting Conclusion to Long Jeans
description: THE tailor flashed me a haunted, fearful look when I walked in last week carrying a pair of jeans.

title: A Court Remade in the Reagan Era's Image
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 - Conservative lawyers in the administration of President Ronald Reagan had an ambitious agenda. They wanted the courts to pay closer attention to the Constitution's text, to fashion a more limited role for the federal government, to allow religion to have a larger presence in public life, to use skepticism in reviewing race-based classifications in the law and to stop the expansion of protections for criminal defendants.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Child Welfare Worker Arrested
description: A woman who works for the Administration for Children's Services was arrested yesterday and accused of abusing her 7-year-old daughter, the police said. The woman, Sharon Bines, 46, works at the department's office at Bronx Family Court, where she is an administrative assistant, the police said. On Wednesday, teachers at the girl's school in the Bronx called the police after noticing marks on the girl's skin. Ms. Bines was charged with assault and endangering the welfare of a child.

title: Greater-than-ever risk of terror is seen by U.S.
Moira Shearer, Ballerina in 'The Red Shoes,' Dies at 80
description: Correction Appended

INSIDE
description: Review Proposes No Major Changes to the Military A review once billed as Donald H. Rumsfeld's master plan for revamping the military eliminates no major weapon systems and calls for incremental change in other priorities, Pentagon officials and others said. PAGE A17

title: New Team Plans to Identify Nuclear Attackers
description: The Pentagon has formed a team of nuclear experts to analyze the fallout from a terrorist nuclear attack on American soil in an effort to identify the attackers, officials have said.

title: Christopher J. Makins, 63, Expert on Foreign Relations, Dies
description: Christopher J. Makins, who followed his father into the British diplomatic service and then shifted course to become an influential expert on United States-European relations for Washington research organizations, died on Saturday at his home in Washington. He was 63.

title: Images That Offend
description: To the Editor:

title: Driver Shot on Bronx Street After Police Pull Him Over
description: A police sergeant in the Bronx shot and wounded a 27-year old man yesterday who ran a stop sign and then tried to drive away after he was pulled over, the police said. The car had drugs in it, but the man did not appear to have a weapon.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Counselor Is Overwhelmed by Her Own Problems
description: Dolorez Williams, 53, is a job counselor who has spent many of her professional hours listening to other people's troubles.

title: More European Papers Print Cartoons of Muhammad, Fueling Dispute With Muslims
description: COPENHAGEN, Feb. 1 - Broadening a debate that has set Europe against the Islamic world, several European newspapers on Wednesday reprinted cartoons depicting the Prophet Muhammad in an unflattering light, supporting a Danish newspaper that had inspired a huge outcry in the Islamic world by publishing them in the first place.

title: Arts, Briefly; It's Pop, It's Classical, It's No. 1
description: Il Divo, the pop-classical vocal quartet assembled by Simon Cowell of "American Idol," shot to the top of the Billboard album chart this week with its new album, "Ancora" (Syco/Columbia), right, which sold 156,000 copies. It is the first classical crossover album ever to make its debut on top of the Billboard chart, the magazine said. In a week busy with big new releases, the country singer Josh Turner's "Your Man"(MCA Nashville) reached No. 2 with 102,000 sales, the emo band Yellowcard's "Lights and Sounds" (Capitol) entered at No. 5, and "Now No. 1's," a compilation of pop hits, opened at No. 6. Jamie Foxx and Mary J. Blige, who have spent the last month trading the top two spots on the chart, dropped to No. 3 (Mr. Foxx with "Unpredictable" on the J label ) and No. 4 (Ms. Blige with "The Breakthrough" on Geffen). BEN SISARIO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSTELANETZ, BORIS
description: KOSTELANETZ--Boris, The Justices of the New York State Supreme Court, Appellate Divsion First Judicial Department mark with sadness the passing of a great friend of the Court and as Chair of the Character and Fitness Committee from 1985-1998 and later as Chair Emeritus, he served the Court with distinction. His dedication and wisdom will be remembered as his legacy. John T. Buckley Presiding Justice

title: Democrats and Bush Aides Spar in Senate Over U.S. Spying
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 A Senate Democrats today angrily accused the Bush administration of conducting a public relations campaign to defend the National Security Agency's domestic surveillance program while refusing to brief Congressional oversight committees about the secret eavesdropping.

title: GMspending $15 billion to offload high-tech tasks
Brooklyn Jury Gets Case of Killing of Detectives
description: After nearly a month of testimony, jurors adjourned to a private room in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday to decide what happened in the front seat of a Mazda on a street corner in East Flatbush in September 2004.

title: A Museum With Galleries For Earrings and Pinkie Rings
description: The de Young Museum in San Francisco, designed by Herzog & de Meuron, has spun off "architectural" products including picture frames dimpled and punctured like the building's copper mesh skin, and an Australian lacewood jewelry box that mimics the vertiginous twist of the museum's tower, right. The box, above, uncoils to reveal seven velvet-lined compartments. Made by Miki Szabo, an artist, in a limited edition, the box comes in two sizes: 10 inches high ($1,950) and 7 inches ($1,050). The line is at thinker.org/store or (415) 750-3642.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: 19 Indicted In Copyright Case
description: A federal grand jury indicted 19 people on copyright infringement charges and accused them of pirating more than $6.5 million in computer software, games and movies for their own use, Patrick J. Fitzgerald, the United States attorney in Chicago, announced. The defendants are accused of sharing thousands of pirated materials on servers that were accessed by a group of more than 50 people from 1998 to 2005, the indictment said. They range in age from 22 to 57 and are from nine states, Australia and Barbados. GRETCHEN RUETHLING (NYT)

title: To Be or Not to Be? 'Tis Nobler to Nourish

That would be the red-headed Ms. Clark, who spends much of her off time cooking and baking -- and is not one of those actresses who starve themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEHLER, JOHN L.
description: BEHLER--John L. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Wildlife Conservation Society are profoundly saddened by the death of our esteemed colleague, John L. Behler. As Curator of Herpetology, Behler began his WCS career in 1970 in the Reptile Department and as an intern. John's knowledge and love of wildlife included working with WCS field staff on related projects in Madagascar and Asia and is known and appreciated worldwide. His work exemplified the long history of WCS setting standards for others to follow. He assumed a leadership role among his peers in groundbreaking captive breeding programs for endangered crocodilians, tortoises and freshwater turtles and also focused on the ecology and behavior of reptilians. John's wit, charm and dedication allowed him to share his life's work with many. Among his numerous affiliations, John was a founding member of the American Zoo and Aquarium's Crocodilian Advisory Group and worked closely with the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation's Endangered Species Unit. Likewise, Behler served his community on the Sommers Conservation Board and Muscoot Farm Nature Center in Westchester County Park. Behler authored more than 40 popular scientific articles, five guidebooks highlighting reptilians and amphibians and coauthored a book, "Frogs-A Chorus of Colors" with his wife, Deborah Behler. We're all saddened by the loss of our friend, a great scientist and conservationist. Our heartfelt sympathies go to John's wife, Debbie; mother, Mildred; sister, Judy Howells; John's children, Cindy Sibilia, and David Behler and his five grandchildren. David T. Schiff, Chairman Board of Trustees Steven E. Sanderson, President and CEO

title: Quin es ms buff?
description: When the Bagger was at the nominations announcement the other day, he noticed that the Oscar statue is not as buff in the backside as the Actor, the statue given out by the Screen Actors Guild. I think that Oscar ought to look into hiring the Actors personal trainer so that when he arrives at his moment in March, he will be able to pivot in the spotlight with the comfort of knowing that his buns of steel are as firm as they ought to be.

title: In Search of that Elusive Local Angle
description: The Kansas City Star points out that George Clooney would be the first Kentucky native to win one of the Academys major golden guys since 1964. The last native Kentuckian to win one of the major Oscars (either best picture, best director or the four best acting awards) was Packard native Patricia Neal, best actress for Hud, said the Star. According to the paper, Mr. Clooneys mom is refusing to comment on his prospects, saying she doesnt want to jinx him.

title: Yahooing Yer Google
description: One of the collateral effects of the Oscars is that actors who have previously toiled in obscurity get to enjoy a slice of the limelight. According to the Buzz Index at Yahoo, Amy Adams, whose indelibleness is writ to anybody who has seen Junebug, is being searched 2,468 percent more than she was before the awards season. Other folks getting a dumptruck of buzz include Terrence Howard, Keira Knightly and Michelle Williams. According to Yahoo, searches for the Bagger are soaring as well. Well, okay, that is lie, but like James Frey, he just wants to make the story better, thats all.

title: Yes to Human-Animal Hybrids, No to  Isolationism
description: Responding to President Bushs call in the State of the Union to ban human-animal hybrids, biologiest P.Z. Myers defends the creation of chimeras as legitimate and useful scientific research, such as when scientists insert human genes into mice to create an animal model of Down syndrome, so that, for example, we could figure out exactly what gene overdose is causing the immune system problems or the heart defects, and develop better treatments for them.  The New Republics Ryan Lizza says President Bushs SOTU isolationist-bashing was really aimed at the growing ranks of Buchananite Republicans, not antiwar Democrats.  Matthew Yglesias says even if Lizza is right, Bush is misappropriating the term: If by isolationist we mean opposed to preventative warfare against potential WMD proliferators then every president in American history except George W. Bush was an isolationist. If by isolationist we mean doesnt want to use military force to halt genocides then every president except Bill Clinton is an isolationist. I would suggest that definitions of the term that lead to the conclusion that presidents Truman, Kennedy, and Reagan were all leading isolationists is pretty obviously mistaken.

title: Selling the Show

The Bagger was out in Times Square last night making one of those little videos that so many of you have come to expect and ignore. He asked people wandering around the crossroads of America which of the five they thought would win Best Picture. None of the above won in a landslide.

title: The Coast with the Most
description: Now that the Bagger is back ensconced in his crows nest in the East, he will miss certain things about L.A. That girl with the unseasonal Ugg boots at Urth on South Beverly Drive, the pot roast at Jar restaurant and the goddess he ate it with, and the proximity of so much throbbing angst around the Oscars. He will not miss any acceptance speech in almost any form  its bankruptcy as an art form is manifest almost anytime anyone steps near a mic. He will not miss getting his badge scanned everywhere he goes, and he will not miss the efforts of one flak in particular who called to tell him, Dude, you got something TOTALLY wrong, when the Bagger ventured out to write a story for the daily newspaper about the scrum over credits. She was wrong about the Baggers wrongness, thankfully, but managed to spoil his night  when we get something TOTALLY wrong at the Times, as the Bagger has said, flying monkeys come out of the ceiling and kill us  and he wasted a day proving he was right in the first place. Nice to know she is a coast away for the time being.

title: 28 Days
description: We have arrived once again at Black History Month, that time of year devoted to the remembrance and celebration of all things African American as something like a public duty or civic penance, depending on ones view. PBS is rolling out African American Lives, a four-hour special by Henry Gates; Turner Classic Movies will devote a day to Sidney Poitier, Ethel Waters and Paul Robeson; public service announcements on many radio stations will remind us about the lives of great black Americans  an inventor or a civil rights lawyer  who most of the public has never heard of; bookstores will prominently display books by black authors or about black people in their windows; school children will be told about the glories of the civil rights movement. For 28 days the red, white and blue will be swathed in the red, black and green flag of black liberation. And here I am at The New York Times.

title: ViewPoints: Exit, pursued by a bull
RONALD K. BROWN/EVIDENCE
description: Lots of news releases yammer on about fusion, but the choreographer Ronald K. Brown is the real deal. For the last 20 years, his Brooklyn-based company, Evidence, has been exploring dance idioms from across the African Diaspora, mixing Cuban, Caribbean, West African and modern American dance forms with an impressively light touch. The result? Percussive, high-energy works that joyously splice complex rhythms with a deep but down-to-earth spirituality. In dances like "Serving Nia" and "Come Ye," all the world seems to be Mr. Brown's church. On Tuesday, the company (which includes Mr. Brown above, with Tiffany Jackson, left, and Arcell Cabug) opens a week of performances at the Joyce Theater to celebrate its anniversary. Two separate programs highlight works from the latter half of Evidence's existence, including the stunning "Grace," created for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater in 1999; the mysterious meditation "Walking Out the Dark," from 2003; and "High Life," from 2000, which charts the northward migration of African-Americans. There will also be a New York premiere, "Order My Steps," which features the music of Bob Marley, Terry Riley and the gospel singer Fred Hammond. (Tuesday through Feb. 11 at 8 p.m., Feb. 12 at 7:30 p.m., with 2 p.m. matinees on Feb. 11 and 12, the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800; $38.) CLAUDIA LA ROCCO THE LISTINGS: FEB. 3-FEB. 9

At a legislative hearing yesterday, Charles A. Gargano, left, the state's top economic development official, and Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff said it was the best plan possible given their financial and physical constraints. Hotel operators and trade show producers said the plan was still evolving and improving. But a recent memo from consultants for the convention center suggested that there were still some serious design flaws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPEVOK, GREGORY J.
description: SPEVOK--Gregory J. It is with deep regret that we announce the passing of Gregory J. Spevok, of Kenilworth, IL, on Sunday, January 29, 2006 in an auto accident. Beloved husband of Elisabeth (nee Pratt), loving father of Katherine, Eleanor, and Phillip, loved son of Stanley and Catherine. Greg was a Managing Director of the Corporate and Real Estate Capital Markets Groups at LaSalle Bank Corporation. He enjoyed an outstanding reputation at the forefront of the Commercial Mortgage Backed Securities business. Not only was Greg a charismatic and compelling leader, but he possessed an impressive technical command of the real estate lending business. In spite of his professional success, Greg was always humble and approachable. Competitors routinely sought his counsel, and, like those who worked with him, considered Greg to be a steadfast friend. His real estate lending career was extensive. Prior to LaSalle, he was the Director of Originations for Bear Stearns' CMBS unit, where he built the firm's nationwide source network as a member of the senior management team that repeatedly set the CMBS industry's record subordination levels. Previously, he established FINOVA Capital's East Coast commercial real estate lending practice. He also created and led the real estate lending program for Dai Ichi Kangyo Bank's Tokyo Leasing (USA). He began his career as an Analyst in the Financial Institutions Group of First National Bank of Chicago, for which he served in both Chicago and New York. His integrity, acumen and reputation, led to LaSalle Bank hiring Greg to head its CMBS operation out of Chicago. Under Greg's leadership, LaSalle Bank's CMBS unit met with great success. Greg oversaw the unit's growth from a nominal regional player to one of the dominant forces in real estate loan securitization. Greg also served as the driving force behind the emergence of the Bank's Multifamily Finance Group as a "top 3" provider of capital to the apartment and manufactured housing sectors. In 1992, he was the principal founder of the Real Estate Lender's Association, Inc., the largest lenders-only commercial real estate organization in the U.S. Other involvements include Sustaining Fellow of the Art Institute of Chicago; the Founder's Council of the Field Museum; the Real Estate Roundtable's Capital Advisory Policy committee; and the Board of Directors of the National Multi Housing Council. Services will be held Friday, 2:00 at the Holy Comforter Church, 222 Kenilworth Avenue, Kenilworth, Illinois. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to either the Joseph Sears School Foundation, or the Art Institute of Chicago. Greg was a passionate and insightful person, and will be deeply missed by his colleagues, friends, and family.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Is Charged With Rape

The man, Gerard Mitchell, 29, is also suspected of two sexual assaults last year, the police said. Mr. Mitchell was arrested about 10 p.m. in front of 849 Flushing Avenue, the police said. The police said officers recovered some of the victim's property as well as a devil mask matching the description of a mask used in one of the attacks. Mr. Mitchell is charged with raping and robbing a 38-year-old woman who was walking on Wednesday morning in Williamsburg, the police said.
