title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CRARY, MARY CHAPMAN
description: CRARY--Mary Chapman. Of Asharoken, NY, passed away on Sunday, January 29, 2006, at the age of 83. She was a much-loved wife, mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother. Mrs. Crary was an active community volunteer in Huntington Township for more than 50 years. Her philanthropic and community roles included serving as President of the Family Service League of Suffolk County, Trustee and President of The Society of St. Johnland, Director and First Vice President of the Huntington Hospital Board of Trustees, and Chairperson of the Hutton House Lectures' Advisory Board at C.W. Post College. She attended Smith College, graduated Phi Beta Kappa with a BA from Radcliffe College, and earned a MA from the New School of Social Research. As an independent scholar, she was widely read, wrote poetry, kept journals and maintained extensive correspondence. She was known for her culinary skills, garden harvests and hospitality. Family and friends often gathered at her Long Island kitchen and dining room tables for lively and thoughtful conversation. She is survived by her husband of 63 years, Miner Dunham Crary, Jr., her brother James Chapman, of Syracuse, NY and her five children, Edie, of Cambridge, MA, Jim, of Phoenix, AZ, Marcy, of Newton, MA, Holly, of Cambridge, MA and Mac, of Sudbury, MA, as well as eight grandchildren and five great grandchildren. The family requests instead of flowers, donations may be made to Huntington Hospital, Development office, 270 Park Ave, Huntington, NY 11743; The Society of St. Johnland, 395 Sunken Meadow Rd., Kings Park, NY 11725; and the Visiting Nurse Service and Hospice of Suffolk, 505 Main Street, Northport, NY 11768. A memorial service will be held at the Centerport Methodist Church on Friday, February 10, at 2:00 P.M.

One night recently, a group of architecture students staying up late in a loft in Brooklyn took to amusing themselves by stuffing a mattress into a hole cut into the wall above a bedroom door. Then they tried the mattress out for comfort. Not half bad! It occurred to one of them, Nick Freeman, that people might pay money to call that elevated mattress home.

title: Piling laughs on business tragedy
Physical Passion That Conquers All
description: LIKE those other big-screen intangibles, chemistry is easier to recognize than explain. Cary Grant and Ingrid Bergman combust beautifully in Hitchcock's "Notorious," while the then-married Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman just sputter in Kubrick's "Eyes Wide Shut," two soggy sticks without the requisite friction. In "Ocean's Eleven," George Clooney relieved Brad Pitt of the burden of being the most beautiful man in the room, and the results were nose-tickling fizzy, as playfully sexy and artless as the most classic of screwball pairings.

title: Music That Lives Beyond Its Premiere
description: Many a composer has enjoyed the fleeting celebrity that accompanies a world premiere, only to see the work languish in obscurity afterward. "We call them one-shot deals," said Ingram Marshall, whose eclectic music has been played by the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the St. Louis Symphony, the Kronos Quartet and others. "If it's a commission, you're paid, and you're obviously very grateful. But you also hope the piece will have a life beyond its first performance."

title: In a Corner of Costa Rica, a Beachhead for Luxury
description: THE Liberia airport, Costa Rica's new international hub, is not precisely a beacon of modern transportation. The terminal consists of an open-air warehouse with a corrugated tin roof, cooled by an enormous fan whose main effect is to stir the grasshoppers into a frenzy. In the line for customs, visitors are kept company by butterflies and the occasional blas frog.

Will Pigs Fly?
description: Well, it wasn't exactly Nixon to China. But it wasn't bean bag either. I'd say the president's State of the Union speech, when it came to calling for an end to our oil addiction and a real push to improve our educational competitiveness, was more like Nixon goes to New Mexico. It was an important change in direction and tone -- but still a long way from China, a long way from a definitive change in policy and implementation.

title: Jordan's Leader Calls for Unity Among Religions
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 2 - In the first speech by a Muslim head-of-state before the largely evangelical Christian audience at a National Prayer Breakfast gathering, King Abdullah of Jordan called upon Christians, Jews and Muslims on Thursday to discard the idea of a clash of civilizations, emphasizing instead that terrorists have begun an attack on civilization.

title: After Dreary '05, Drug Makers See Brighter Year Ahead
description: Drug industry executives are voicing new hope that their companies are past the worst of the scientific, political and legal problems that dogged them through 2005.

title: IN THE COUNTRY
description: The pianist Morten Qvenild has had a hand in some of Norway's most expressive postmodern jazz ensembles, including the electronic juggernaut Jaga Jazzist, the powder-keg outfit known as Shining and a supergroup called the National Bank. Left to his own devices, Mr. Qvenild seems to favor a more intimate sensibility: In the Country, his acoustic trio with the bassist Roger Arntzen and the drummer Pal Hausken (above center, with Mr. Arntzen, left and Mr. Qvenild), wrings dramatic suspense out of slender quietude and shimmering abstraction. Last year the group issued a gorgeous debut album -- aptly titled "This Was the Pace of My Heartbeat" (Rune Grammofon) -- which occasionally invokes the supple pointillism of the pianist Paul Bley and the drummer Paul Motian. (At other times, its monumental dynamic range and stately thematic development can bring the Bad Plus to mind.) More than anything, the album underscores a collective reverence for melody; Mr. Qvenild's songs have the simplicity of folk lullabies, and he takes virtually no liberties with the two songs he didn't compose, the Handel aria "Lascia ch'io pianga" and the Ryan Adams ballad "In My Time of Need." There's no telling whether the dynamic will mutate with the addition of the guitarist Marc Ribot, who joins In the Country for the group's United States debut at Tonic next week. Adding another layer of mystery, the evening will also include a set by Lars Horntveth, the charismatic saxophonist, guitarist and keyboardist who leads Jaga Jazzist. Mr. Horntveth's most recent solo effort, "Pooka" (Smalltown Supersound), reimagines a Gil Evans-style orchestration for a nine-piece string ensemble, with electronic percussion; this will be his United States debut, too. (Thursday at 8 p.m., Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7501; cover, $12.) NATE CHINEN THE LISTINGS: FEB. 3-FEB. 9

title: Forget the Freedom Fries. All Is Forgiven, Chrie.
description: WE came crawling back, of course. Is anyone out there skipping over the Burgundies on the wine list and, just to twist the knife a littler harder, opting for a tangy Finger Lakes Riesling instead? Does a trip to historic Valley Forge still seem like a better idea than a week in the Dordogne? I personally have returned to Camembert and poisses after an unsuccessful attempt to love the carefully matured, individually wrapped cheeses from the caves of Kraft.

title: Mourning a Child in a Silence That's Unbearably Loud
description: THE Biltmore Theater had better be paid up on its flood insurance. "Rabbit Hole," the wrenching new play by David Lindsay-Abaire that opened there last night, inspires such copious weeping among its audience that you wonder early on if you should have taken a life jacket. Do your best, though, to keep your eyes clear. Otherwise, you might miss some of the most revealingly nuanced acting to be seen on a stage or screen this year.

title: Arts, Briefly; Ride the Subway, See a Movie
description: A ride on the Berlin subways these days is a literal and figurative trip. For 1.5 million passengers daily, a ride means access to the fifth international short-film festival, "Going Underground," in which four ultrashort films a day are playing on 4,000 screens in the trains. Altogether, 14 international productions, each not longer than 90 seconds and all silent, were chosen from 450 shorts from 39 countries. Films from Germany, the United States, Britain and Brazil, for example, feature 3-D characters, monsters and abstract art. Several other films, competing for the Renewable Movie Award, deal with renewable resources. In what is billed as the world's first underground film festival, passengers are asked to vote for their favorites via cellphone text messages or online (www.goingunderground.de). The award ceremony will be on Feb. 12 , with the winner receiving $3,600, which can be used for longer productions. The festival runs through Tuesday. SARAH PLASS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOH, SUZETTE H.
description: LOH--Suzette H.,who was a partner at Eisner LLP, one of the 20 largest regional accounting and advisory firms in the country, died of cancer February 1 at her Scarsdale home. She would have been 45 later this month. A graduate of the Phillips Exeter Academy and Barnard College, Suzette served as financial advisor to trusts, estates, and private foundations, as well as wealthy individuals and their families. Suzette had spoken before various groups and organizations on financial planning, including the NYU Institute of Law and Taxation, the Practising Law Institute, the New York Women's Bar Association, the Network for Women's Services and many others. She taught personal financial planning at the undergraduate and professional levels at Marymount Manhattan College and Iona College. She also appeared on WNBC, CNN, and other media outlets to answer questions on personal financial planning. Active in ChineseAmerican community affairs, she was a past president of the Asian Financial Society and the Westchester Chapter of the Organization of Chinese-Americans. She was also a trustee of The Sister Fund, founded by Helen LaKelly Hunt. She is survived by her husband, Antonio Lee, and her sons Theodore and Thomas, aged 10 and 4. Her father and mother, retired Taiwanese ambassador-atlarge I-cheng Loh and Mrs. Jane Y. Loh; brother Dr. Willie H. Loh and sister-in law Jean C. Loh and their two daughters; and brother Philip H. Loh were all in attendance. A non-denominational service will be held at BallardDurand Funeral Home at 2 Maple Ave, White Plains at 10 A.M. Saturday, February 4th. Internment will follow at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, also in Westchester County. In lieu of flowers, the family respectfully requests that contributions be sent to The Sister Fund (www.sisterfund.org).

title: NILAJA SUN
description: If there were an award for best performance in the worst role, Nilaja Sun would be a leading candidate, since she manages to brighten an otherwise dim formula comedy in "Huck & Holden." This ditsy cross-cultural romance about an awkward Indian student who falls for an African-American librarian includes several characters who appear in dream sequences, including Ms. Sun's Kali, the Indian goddess. Any talented actor can shine in a great play, but it takes a true professional to make weak material look good. To be fair, the comedy is good for a few laughs if you like the kind of humor practiced by the writers of the "American Pie" movies. If not, you can admire the performance of Ms. Sun (above right), who arrives late in a screamingly loud costume with four arms and delivers her admonishments with so much comic energy and conviction that she forces you to pay attention. It almost seems as if she's acting in her own show, which makes sense, since Ms. Sun -- whose performance in her homage to Spalding Gray, "Blues for a Gray Sun," proved that she can be both subtle and broad -- has written and starred in several one-woman shows. Her next one, "No Child," opens in May at the Beckett Theater and is directed by Hal Brooks ("Thom Pain"). Best to keep a close eye on her. ("Huck & Holden" runs at the Cherry Lane Theater, 38 Commerce Street, West Village, (212) 989-2020, through Feb. 11.) JASON ZINOMAN THE LISTINGS: FEB. 3-FEB. 9

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (Discovery) GRIZZLY MAN (2005). At first, Timothy Treadwell (above) has the air of a noble environmentalist, living among grizzly bears in Alaska and fighting for the preservation of their habitat. But as Werner Herzog's documentary continues, Treadwell seems more and more like a deeply disturbed man, looking for fame while rejecting the civilized world. In 2003, after 13 summers in the wilds, a bear did attack and kill Treadwell and his girlfriend. His friends and family comment.

The real issue, though, is not how much the oil companies are making, but what they are doing with the money. title: Celebrating Boris Karloff, the Monster and the Man
description: HE was billed, in the opening credits of the movie that made him a star, as "?". Seventy minutes later, the end credits of James Whale's 1931 "Frankenstein" gave a name to the unrecognizable actor who had incarnated (if that's the word) the unnatural creation of Dr. F., and a fine monster-movie name it was: Boris Karloff. The mysterious Karloff was in fact a middle-aged, middlingly successful English character actor (born William Henry Pratt), skillful and professional enough to have appeared in dozens of pictures in the previous 15 years, yet stubbornly obscure: when he was suggested as a possibility for "Frankenstein," Whale is said to have responded, "Boris -- who?"

description: THIS city -- named after the one in Italy because of its beautiful bay -- is most widely known for its sugar-sand beaches, warm winter weather and sprawling, high-gated communities that attract older, well-off snowbirds who live to golf but go to bed early. (It has the nation's second highest number of golf holes per capita, just behind Myrtle Beach, S.C.). But now Naples is starting to draw a younger, more dynamic crowd attracted to outdoorsy pursuits off the course, high-end shopping and late-night noshing -- all in a laid-back, upscale setting with enough cultural interest to support more than 130 art galleries and a symphony orchestra. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Baby's Death Investigated
description: A 9-month-old girl in Harlem died Wednesday night, possibly by drowning, investigators said, after her mother said she briefly left the girl alone in the bathtub. The girl, Liyah Atkinson, was pronounced dead at Harlem Hospital Center, and an autopsy by the city medical examiner was inconclusive, a spokeswoman said. Liyah's mother, whom neighbors identified as Nelise Hampton, 21, told investigators that she had started a bath for the girl, placing her in an inflatable device. After leaving Liyah to check on her twin brother in another room, Ms. Hampton returned to find her submerged, she told the police.

title: Mourning a Child in a Silence That's Unbearably Loud
description: THE Biltmore Theater had better be paid up on its flood insurance. "Rabbit Hole," the wrenching new play by David Lindsay-Abaire that opened there last night, inspires such copious weeping among its audience that you wonder early on if you should have taken a life jacket. Do your best, though, to keep your eyes clear. Otherwise, you might miss some of the most revealingly nuanced acting to be seen on a stage or screen this year.

title: In Another Threat, Iran Warns It May Block Inspections
description: VIENNA, Feb. 2 - Iran formally notified the International Atomic Energy Agency on Thursday that it would end all "voluntary" nuclear cooperation with the agency if, as expected, its 35-country board referred Iran's nuclear activity case to the United Nations Security Council.

title: Gains Seen in Redesign of S.U.V.'s
description: DETROIT, Feb. 2 - Design changes that automakers initially resisted and then reluctantly adopted have sharply reduced the number of deaths among drivers of cars struck by a sport utility vehicle or pickup, according to results from the first study of the standards.

title: Gathering a Trove of Veronese Paintings
description: Gathering a Trove Of Veronese Paintings

title: Egyptian Ferry Carrying 1,400 Sinks in Red Sea
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Feb. 3 A An Egyptian ferry carrying more than 1,400 people, most of them Egyptian laborers returning from Saudi Arabia, sank early today in rough seas about 40 miles off the coast of Egypt, and by late evening only 314 survivors had been rescued.

title: A Hollywood Adaptation of an Oscar Wilde Play: At Sea on the Italian Coast in 1930
description: If you insist on taking an Oscar Wilde comedy out of its natural habitat, the drawing room, please don't take it any farther than the adjoining climate-controlled hothouse where the carnivorous plants are waiting to be fed.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Officer Exchanges Fire With Gunman
description: An off-duty police officer was wounded in an exchange of fire with a gunman last night, the police said. The gunman appeared to have died at the scene, but the police did not confirm his death or release other details of the shooting. The officer, who was not identified, was shot in the leg and taken to the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, a police officer at the hospital said. The shooting occurred around 8 p.m. on Girard Place near Hawthorne Avenue, along a block of two-story homes.

title: Spare Times
description: Attractions

title: The Lopsided Bush Health Plan
description: The health care proposals put forth by President Bush in his State of the Union address this week will not make much of a dent in the two main problems plaguing the nation's health care system -- the escalating costs and the growing legions of the uninsured. His proposals simply show where he and many conservatives want health care financing to go -- toward a system where consumers will be expected to pay more of their care themselves, in the hope that they will therefore use medical services sparingly and shop for them more wisely.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSTELANETZ, BORIS
description: KOSTELANETZ - Boris. St. John's School of Law notes with sorrow the passing of a most distinguished alumnus, supporter, and friend. Boris Kostelanetz, Esq., Partner at the law firm of Kostelanetz & Fink. Mr. Kostelanetz graduated from St. John's School of Law in 1936 and became one of the premier criminal tax lawyers in the United States. He served with distinction as the President of the Law School Alumni Association from 1955 to 1957. In 1985, St. John's University awarded him an honorary Doctor of Laws degree, in 1988 the Law School presented him with the James Madison Award and in 1999, the Alumni Association presented him with the Charles M. Sparacio Award. The St. John's community and its Alumni Association will miss the friendship of this dedicated alumnus.

title: State of Delusion
description: So President Bush's plan to reduce imports of Middle East oil turns out to be no more substantial than his plan -- floated two years ago, then flushed down the memory hole -- to send humans to Mars.

title: Return to House Leadership
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 - Some defeated politicians make fast comebacks. John A. Boehner made a slow one -- so slow that Mr. Boehner, Republican of Ohio, regarded a decade ago as a rising star in the House leadership, has now become its fresh new face.

title: Does Surveillance Make Us Safer?
description: To the Editor:

title: Leader's Rise Reflects Growing Concern in Republican Ranks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 - The surprise election of Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio as House majority leader was a cry of concern by an entrenched Republican majority, acutely worried that voter unease about corruption and partisan excesses could threaten its control of Congress this November.

title: Bush and Energy: More Fallout
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Metropolitan Diary column on Monday about a recent delay on a Metropolitan Transportation Authority train misidentified the borough where a tree had fallen across the tracks in high winds. It was the Bronx, not Brooklyn. (Go to Article)

title: Chvez Ousts U.S. Diplomat on Spying Charge
description: BOGOT, Colombia, Feb. 2 - President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela announced Thursday that his government had ordered the expulsion of the American naval attach at the United States Embassy in Caracas for spying, further increasing tensions with the Bush administration.

title: Art in Review
Corrections
description: A listing and picture caption in the Television section on Sunday with a highlight for tonight at 10 o'clock on NBC has become outdated. "The Book of Daniel" has been canceled; it has been replaced by a two-hour "Dateline" that begins at 9 p.m.

title: A Radical on the Run, Determined to Escape the Past
description: The prospect of reinventing oneself tabula rasa has always been one of America's foundation myths. Whether it was the earliest colonists leaving Europe to begin new lives in the New World or F. Scott Fitzgerald's Gatsby trying to inhabit his own platonic conception of himself, Americans have long embraced the possibility of remaking their lives: moving West with the frontier to start over or moving East to the big city to erase their provincial roots; shucking off familial legacies and changing their names, their looks, their histories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAMERMAN, MORTON
description: KAMERMAN--Morton. Died February 1, 2006, at the age of 79, in Martin Memorial Hospital, Stuart, Florida, at the end of a long battle with heart problems. He enjoyed a successful and fulfilling life and will be missed and long remembered by his beloved wife of 58 years, Sheila Brody Kamerman and children Nathan and his wife Hillary, Elliot and his wife Jean, Laura and her husband Alan, and his adored grandchildren Rebecca, Rachel, Oren, Jessica, Melissa, Danielle and her husband Stuart. Funeral services are limited to family and intimate friends. The week of mourning will be observed in New York City at 1125 Park Avenue.

title: Bush and Energy: More Fallout
description: To the Editor:

title: Bekele Is Confident He's No Long Shot on Short Track
description: At 23, Kenenisa Bekele is almost the youngest in the field. He has never run a race as short as a mile. He has never run or even seen a miniature indoor banked track, 11 laps to the mile, like the one on which he will race tonight in Madison Square Garden.

title: Tens of Thousands Protest Cartoon in Gaza
description: GAZA CITY, Feb. 3 A Tens of thousands of Palestinians, divided by recent elections, marched in angry unity today against cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad that they consider blasphemous, amid protests around the world against European nations where the cartoons were published.

title: Grooming at Night: Peril on Slippery Slopes
description: IT'S cold and dangerous, the hours long and lonely, and it is often a job without thanks. But someone has to groom ski mountains.

title: For the Love of God
description: WHEN Pope Benedict XVI issued his first encyclical ("Deus Caritas Est" or "God Is Love") last month, it took some people by surprise. Many expected the document to focus on the "dictatorship of relativism," which Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger had denounced in a speech to his fellow cardinals before his election as pope. But love?

title: Defense Fund Raises Money In Libby Case
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 - The trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. has not begun in earnest, but efforts to raise money for his defense are moving ahead briskly.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Changing Sizes
description: A major nationwide study by the fashion industry has concluded that the French are getting taller and heavier. The average Frenchman is now 5 feet 9 inches and 171 pounds, as against 5 feet 7 inches and 159 pounds in 1970, and the average woman is 5 feet 4 and 137 pounds, compared with 5 feet 3 and 133 pounds in 1970.

title: U.S. and South Korea Start on Path to Free Trade Accord
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 3 A South Korea and the United States embarked today on a quick-march, one-year timetable to draw up the United States' largest free-trade accord since the North American Free Trade Agreement went into effect with Canada and Mexico in 1994.

title: U.S. Plans $18 Billion More for Gulf, but Local Officials Are Skeptical
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 - The Bush administration announced Thursday that it would ask Congress to provide $18 billion more for Gulf Coast reconstruction this year, on top of $67 billion appropriated last year. But it provided no details about how the money would be spent, and made clear that it did not plan to request additional aid for the region in its 2007 federal budget.

title: Oil producers not losing sleep
Security crackdowns net nearly 60 suspects
U.S. assails drawings and urges tolerance
Woman in California Postal Shootings Had History of Bizarre Behavior
description: GRANTS, N.M., Feb. 2 - Two months before Jennifer San Marco fatally shot six postal workers in Goleta, Calif., and then killed herself, the police here were alerted to her bizarre behavior, the office manager of a mental health clinic said.

title: It's Halftime and They Like It, They Like It, Yes They Do
description: DETROIT, Feb. 2 - When the Super Bowl began in 1967, pro football stood for marching bands, crew cuts and cold beer. When the Rolling Stones began earlier in the same decade, they represented a different kind of music, a different sort of hairstyle and different types of refreshments.

title: Make Industries' Tax Breaks Permanent, President Urges
description: MAPLEWOOD, Minn., Feb. 2 - President Bush went Thursday to a center of American innovation, the 3M Company, which invented Scotch Tape and Post-it notes, to call for permanent tax breaks for industries that invest in research and development and to improve Republican chances in a pivotal state in a midterm election year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HYMAN, FREDRICK
description: HYMAN--Fredrick. February 1. Predeceased by wife Mildred. Beloved father to Steven, Kenneth and Debra, and loving husband to Gail. Founder of Grand Lumber Jersey City, NJ. Graveside service Friday 12:30, February 3 at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ. Reception at Short Hills Hilton.

description: ON the night a Kobe copycat broke a high school scoring record in New York, LeBron James secured a victory in Cleveland with a pass. How pass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARNSWORTH, MADELINE H.
description: FARNSWORTH--Madeline H., 91. Died January 11 in Concord, NH. Graduate of Wheaton College, MA. She was office manager at Rockefeller Brothers Fund for over 30 years. She is survived by her niece, Martha Bennett, and many friends.

title: Australian Panel Focuses on Possible Government Role in Bribes and Kickbacks in Iraq
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Friday, Feb. 3 - The leader of a high-level investigation here into corruption in the United Nations oil-for-food program said Friday that it would be examining the Australian government's role as it continues hearing testimony that the country's main wheat exporter secretly poured $220 million in kickbacks and bribes into the Iraq treasury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHAIFETZ, JILL
description: CHAIFETZ--Jill. On February 2, 2006. Beloved wife of Daniel Seltzer, devotd and loving mother of Leila, Isaac and Milo Selchaif; beloved daughter of Marilyn and Malcolm Chaifetz; caring daughter-in-law of Joyce and Isadore Seltzer; adoring sister of Lawrence Chaifetz and his wife Renee Chaifetz; dear sister-in-law of Eva Seltzer and Frans Westra, and loving niece of Judith Chaifetz. Funeral services will be private. All donations to the Jill Chaifetz Education Fund, Advocates For Children 151 W. 30th St. 5th Fl, NY, NY 10001.

title: Knicks Make Deal for Rose
description: The Knicks president Isiah Thomas showed that despite the turmoil swirling around him, he remains active in bolstering the teamAs roster. With the Knicks playing in Toronto, Thomas traded the veteran power forward Antonio Davis to the Raptors for the little-used small forward Jalen Rose and a first-round draft pick.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Court Agrees To Extradite U.S. Priest
description: A court in Rome ruled that the Rev. Joseph Henn, an American priest wanted by the authorities in Arizona, can be extradited to the United States to face charges of molesting three boys in a Phoenix parish. He fled the United States in 2002 and was arrested in Italy in July. His lawyer said he would appeal.

description: Ira L. Rennert's colossal house in the Hamptons, built with the riches from his sprawling industrial empire, has withstood lawsuits from angry neighbors, appeals to the local zoning board, even an attempted documentary filming by Michael Moore.

title: Cartoon controversy
Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Driver Accused Of Condoning Force On School Bus
description: A school bus driver was accused yesterday of having a group of students use physical force to keep order on his bus, the authorities said. Students in the so-called Death Cheese Club used headlocks and pushed other students from Intermediate School 34 in Tottenville who were being driven by Michael Cianci of New Jersey, according to William Smith, a spokesman for the Richmond County district attorney, Daniel M. Donovan Jr. On Jan. 17, police began investigating after a student in the group cut the jacket of another student with scissors, which Mr. Cianci failed to report, the authorities said. Mr. Cianci's lawyer, Raymond C. Rodriguez, declined to comment. Mr. Cianci was arraigned yesterday on two counts of endangering the welfare of a child. He was released on his own recognizance.

title: Believing in Doubt
description: JUST before he became pope, Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger warned that Western culture was sliding toward "a dictatorship of relativism which does not recognize anything as for certain and which has as its highest goal one's own ego and one's own desires." In his first encyclical, "Deus Caritas Est" ("God Is Love"), Pope Benedict XVI does not use the word "relativism," but he does fault modern people for missing the transcendent meaning of love and instead caring for one another just because we feel like it.

title: Iran grasps at regional dominance
Metro Briefing | New York: Bloomberg Donates $100 Million To University
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has quietly donated $100 million of his personal fortune to his alma mater, Johns Hopkins University, making him the largest benefactor in its history. Officials of the university, whose main campus is in Baltimore, declined to identify the donor, but the donation was confirmed yesterday by someone with direct knowledge of it. The mayor's office declined to comment. The donation matches a $100 million gift Mr. Bloomberg made in two installments in 1995 and 1998. The latest donation will be used in part to pay for stem cell research and public health programs.

title: Paradou
description: Few restaurants have watched the immediate world around them change as quickly and dramatically as Paradou has. When it opened about four and a half years ago, the meatpacking district was certainly in transition, its seedy past giving way to a stylish future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WASSERSTEIN, WENDY J.
description: WASSERSTEIN -- Wendy J. On January 30, 2006 loving mother of Lucy Jane, cherished daughter of Lola, beloved sister of Bruce, Georgette, and the late Sandra. Aunt of Tajlei, Jennifer, Melissa, Samantha, Pamela, Oliver, Ben, Scoop, Maxwell, Jack, and Dash. She was a source of laughter, love, and kindness and will be deeply missed. Memorial Service at Lincoln Center Theater in the Vivian Beaumont Theater on March 13, 2006 at 4:00 PM.

title: A Hard-Learned Lesson on Dealing With U.S. Regulators
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 - The Food and Drug Administration holds thousands of meetings a year with drug and device makers, but few have as much at stake for a company as the one planned for Friday with Boston Scientific.

title: Stevens, True to Form, Is Taking Honor in Stride
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 2 - Before the Devils play Carolina on Friday, their former captain Scott Stevens will have his number retired. But he does not expect to deliver a rambling speech or dissolve into tears as the Rangers' Mark Messier did last month.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profits Slow At Nissan Motor
description: Profit growth at Nissan Motor stalled in the most recent quarter as sales fell in the United States, its most profitable market. Net income was 135 billion yen ($1.14 billion), little changed from 134.2 billion yen a year earlier, the Tokyo-based company said. Sales gained 10 percent, to 2.3 trillion yen ($19 billion). The chief executive, Carlos Ghosn, is depending on the introduction of 22 new models over the next two years to revive demand.

Bloomberg -- spoke publicly for the first time yesterday about her aborted nomination to head the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, saying she was mystified about why she was passed over.

title: Clinic Where Coretta King Died Attracts the Desperate
description: ROSARITO, Mexico, Feb. 2 - The cafeteria of the alternative medicine clinic where Coretta Scott King died this week was full of true believers on Wednesday afternoon, all swearing by the anticancer treatments of a man who never went to medical school and has a long history of fraud allegations against him in the United States.

title: World Drug Agency to Contest Lund's U.S. Olympic Eligibility
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 2 - The World Anti-Doping Agency announced Thursday that it would appeal the ruling that allows the American skeleton athlete Zach Lund to compete in the Olympics even though he tested positive for a banned steroid masking agent. The case will be heard in Turin, probably as early as next week, by the Court of Arbitration for Sport.

title: Cartoons unify Muslims
World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Suicide Attack Kills 3 Afghan Soldiers
description: Two suicide bombers in a car, one dressed as a woman, blew themselves up at an Afghan Army checkpoint in eastern Khost Province, killing three Afghan soldiers, the provincial police chief said. The car had crossed the border from Pakistan, the chief, Col. Muhammad Ayub, said.

description: GRAHAM--Rev. Margaret M. We grieve at the untimely loss of our beloved friend Meg, and cherish the gifts of faith and humanity she shared with us and others. Virginia and Richard Schubert, Elisabeth Austin, Emily and Robert Carroll, Deborah and Selvyn Seidel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOUNTAIN, JOHN D., MD.
description: MOUNTAIN--John D., MD. We note with great sorrow the death of John D. Mountain, MD, an extraordinary clinician, surgeon, teacher and humanist. In 1953, Dr. Mountain became one of the first surgeons at the newly opened North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, NY, which was then a 169-bed community hospital. He helped the hospital establish a teaching residency program in surgery, allied with the Cornell Surgical Division of Bellevue Hospital. With Dr. Mountain's continued assistance over the years, it grew into a highly regarded surgical graduate medical education program and North Shore became a 788bed tertiary hospital recognized as one of the best in the nation. Dr. Mountain, who remained active at the hospital until a few years ago, was deeply involved in the development of the hospital's emergency dept and Schwartz Ambulatory Surgical Pavilion. We will always remember his enduring wisdom and wise counsel. We offer our sincere condolences to his family. Dennis Dowling Executive Director North Shore Univ. Hospital Martin Edelstein, MD President, Medical Staff North Shore Univ. Hospital

title: Coach Plays a Hunch, and Weekes Is a Winner
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Feb. 2 - Over and over this season, Rangers Coach Tom Renney has made the right call at just the right time, which is why he deserves strong consideration for the Jack Adams Trophy, given to the N.H.L.'s coach of the year.

title: Theater Listings
description: NILAJA SUN If there were an award for best performance in the worst role, Nilaja Sun would be a leading candidate, since she manages to brighten an otherwise dim formula comedy in "Huck & Holden." This ditsy cross-cultural romance about an awkward Indian student who falls for an African-American librarian includes several characters who appear in dream sequences, including Ms. Sun's Kali, the Indian goddess. Any talented actor can shine in a great play, but it takes a true professional to make weak material look good. To be fair, the comedy is good for a few laughs if you like the kind of humor practiced by the writers of the "American Pie" movies. If not, you can admire the performance of Ms. Sun (above right), who arrives late in a screamingly loud costume with four arms and delivers her admonishments with so much comic energy and conviction that she forces you to pay attention. It almost seems as if she's acting in her own show, which makes sense, since Ms. Sun A whose performance in her homage to Spalding Gray, "Blues for a Gray Sun," proved that she can be both subtle and broad A has written and starred in several one-woman shows. Her next one, "No Child," opens in May at the Beckett Theater and is directed by Hal Brooks ("Thom Pain"). Best to keep a close eye on her. ("Huck & Holden" runs at the Cherry Lane Theater, 38 Commerce Street, West Village, (212) 989-2020, through Feb. 11.) JASON ZINOMAN

title: Shadows and Light: Infusing the Inanimate With Life
description: John Szarkowski became part of the history of 20th-century photography by helping to define it, through his writing and a series of groundbreaking exhibitions that he organized during his 29-year tenure as director of photography at the Museum of Modern Art. The photographs he shot for much of his life don't have the same historical weight, partly because they haven't been exhibited much. But they have a similar decisive clarity and suggest a man who, whatever his involvement with the medium, has always been something of a natural.

description: GAZA, Feb. 2 - Hamas has been known and feared for its men, armed or strapped with suicide bombs. But in its parliamentary election triumph here last week, one secret weapon was its women.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCINERNEY, DENIS
description: McINERNEY - Denis, died peacefully at home on January 31, 2006. Beloved husband of Irene Murphy McInerney. Devoted father of Kathleen O'Hare, Denis J. McInerney and Maura Romano. He is also survived by eight grandchildren. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, New York on Thursday from 7-9 p.m., and Friday from 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Mass of Christian Burial will be on Saturday at 10 a.m. at the Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye, New York. His interment will follow at the Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, New York. In lieu of flowers, the McInerney family requests that any donations be made to the McInerney Scholarship for Public Service, Fordham Law School, 140 West 62nd Street, New York, New York 10023.

title: Aspen Gay Ski Week: Was That Liza on the Black Diamond Run?
description: Serena Williams, or at least her drag-queen stunt double, didn't stand a chance. Sporting three blond wigs, a leather corset and faux diamonds the size of cough drops, Miss Elaine Lancaster sashayed down Aspen Mountain and made downhill skiing look as effortless as runway modeling.

title: Surveillance Prompts a Suit: Police v. Police
description: The demonstrators arrived angry, departed furious. The police had herded them into pens. Stopped them from handing out fliers. Threatened them with arrest for standing on public sidewalks. Made notes on which politicians they cheered and which ones they razzed.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday about charges filed in the death of Quachaun Browne, a 4-year-old Bronx boy, misidentified the photographer, and another caption with the article omitted the photographer's name. The picture of Jose Calderon, charged with murder in the case, was by George M. Gutierrez of The New York Times, not David Karp of The Associated Press. A picture of the boy's mother, Aleshia Smith, who is also charged in the case, was by Mr. Karp.

description: GINSBERG--Annette. On February 2, 2006. Beloved wife of Democratic State Committeeman Robert Ginsberg. Loving mother of Elizabeth & David. Cherished daughter of Herbert and Esther Hult. Dear sister of Dennis and David Hult. Services Sunday, 11 AM, at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Stevens Steps Back as Porter Cues It Up
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Feb. 2 - The boom microphone was hanging like a noose in front of Jerramy Stevens, but it was not picking up his voice very well. Stevens, a tight end for the Seattle Seahawks, spoke so softly Thursday it was hard to hear what he had to say about starting Word War XL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOSTICK, MARILYN (GLASS MAN)
description: KOSTICK -- Marilyn (Glass man). Of Boston, MA, on Wednesday, February 1, 2006. For 61 years, the beloved wife of Sam. Loving mother of Susan Kostick and her husband, Bob Hinck of Seattle and Anne Kostick and her husband, Chick Foxgrover of Brooklyn. Devoted grandmother of Megan, Juliann and Laura and great-grandmother of Talia and Iris. For further information, please call 800-367-3708. In lieu of flowers, charitable donations are appreciated.

title: $120 Billion More Is Sought For Military in War Zones
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 - The Bush administration said Thursday that it would seek about $120 billion in additional financing to pay for continuing military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan through 2006.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Award To Smoker's Family Stands
description: The State Supreme Court reaffirmed a punitive damages award of nearly $80 million to the family of a three-pack-a-day smoker who died of smoking-related lung cancer in 1997. The defendant, Philip Morris USA, had contested the amount, calling it excessive. The United States Supreme Court returned the case to the state for review in 2003. Citing the company's "massive, continuous, near-half-century scheme" to defraud and damage the health of the smoking public and the victim, Jesse Williams, 67, the court found the damages consistent with due process. Philip Morris said it would ask that the case be reviewed again by the United States Supreme Court.

title: Sales of Art Glass, Lalique and Beyond
description: Sales of Art Glass, Lalique and Beyond

title: A New Trove of Music Video in the Web's Wild World
description: SEVERAL weeks back, someone directed me to a Web site to see a clip of George Clinton and the Parliaments, in you-will-freak-out tones. I looked on the Internet at youtube.com and found my way to it. I was freaked out, though not just by the music.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: It's Still Not Enough To Buy A Beer
description: Seeking to cope with chronic hyperinflation, Zimbabwe's reserve bank introduced a new $50,000 note, by far its largest denomination yet, but consumers and economists alike quickly judged the denomination too tiny for an economy where inflation runs 600 percent a year by official estimates and 1,000 percent by private ones. Until now, the largest note had been the $20,000 bill, and consumers tote around bags filled with them for even the most mundane purchases. The Zimbabwean dollar, which traded at 55 to the American dollar in 2000, now trades at the official rate of 99,202 to the dollar, making the $50,000 bill worth just over 50 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   JOHNSTON, WILLIAM ELBERT
description: JOHNSTON--William Elbert. 05/25/63--02/03/78. Left us too soon, so long as we remember, you live. Mom and Sis

title: Op-Art; Judge a Book by Its Cover
description: As just about everyone in the Western world knows by now, future editions of James Frey's book, "A Million Little Pieces," will no longer carry that coveted Oprah's Book Club logo on the cover. Additionally, publishers are now debating how to better inform readers of the relative accuracy and truthfulness of memoirs and other nonfiction titles they distribute. Given the industry's, um, struggle with forthrightness, we've come up with a few suggestions. Barbara Glauber, a graphic designer, is co-founder of the Smoking Gun, a Court TV Web site.

title: Palooka Delicacy
description: SISSIES were second-class citizens in mid-20th-century American culture. And art was a he-man's game: booze, broads, Sasquatch manners, the whole nine yards. Sure, a little sensitivity was O.K., as long as you didn't get carried away. It's as if there was a sign at the Cedar Bar door: Girlie-men need not apply.

title: Hi! My Name's Paul. I'll Be Your U.S. Diplomat Today.
description: MEDAN, Indonesia, Jan. 31 - Paul S. Berg, America's man in Medan, the sweltering capital of north Sumatra, was making the rounds the other day.

title: Device Maker Moves to Appease the F.D.A.
description: Correction Appended

title: When clothes make the statesman
Building a Country on Corpses
description: "The Night of Truth" takes place in an unnamed African country where two fictional warring tribes, the Bonands and the Nayaks, have formed a fragile truce. A decade of brutality and bloodshed has left them surrounded by the markers of violence: hastily dug graveyards, stray corpses and vividly bloody graffiti. Local drivers make jokes about the bone-strewn roads, and children make a game of comparing missing limbs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERSON, RONALD
description: BERSON - Ronald. Dear friend for 35 years! A polymath dedicated to his family, colleagues, profession and the social order! You will be missed by all. Herbert

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DORAN, CHARLES E.
description: DORAN--Charles E. 77, beloved husband of Anne (McGovern) passed away on February 1, 2006. Born in Hartford, CT on March 31, 1928, he was the son of the late Charles Edward and Josephine Maher Doran. Charles was a true gentleman in every sense of the word and a loving, devoted and caring husband, father, grandfather and brother. He graduated from Hamilton College Phi Beta Kappa and was a member of Chi Psi. He also earned an M.A. from Yale University. After attending the General Electric Company Training Program and working there for several years, he served as Treasurer of Collins & Aikman Corporation in New York City for over 17 years prior to his retirement in 1988. Charles was a lifetime member of The Yale Club of New York City. He was also a parishioner of St. Patrick's Church in Bedford, NY. Charles served in the United States Naval Reserve from 1946-1948. He was selected to be in Who's Who in Finance and Industry. He will be sorely missed by his family and friends. He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Anne, his son Charles, his son John and daughter-in-law Cindy, his daughter Pamela and son-inlaw John, his sister Patricia Nelson (brother-in-law Don), his brother Robert Doran (sister-in-law Dotsie) his brotherin-law Martin Kadlick and his grandchildren Will, Annie, Kate and Jack and many nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his sister Joan Kadlick. Visitation will be Friday, February 3 from 49 pm and a Church Mass will be held on Saturday, February 4 at 12 pm at St. Patrick's Church in Bedford, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the American Red Cross. Care and Services have been entrusted by the family to Cassidy Flynn Funeral Home 914 - 666 - 4840. www.cassidy flynnfuneralhome.com

title: The Met, Ending 30-Year Stance, Is Set to Yield Prized Vase to Italy
description: Reversing a position it has held for more than 30 years, the Metropolitan Museum of Art said yesterday that it would relinquish ownership of a 2,500-year-old Greek vase, considered one of the world's finest, to Italy. The Italians have long contended that the vase was stolen from an Etruscan tomb near Rome and smuggled from the country.

title: Briefs: Community colleges lure 4-year students
In Philadelphia, You Can Have Your Cheese Steak and Learn Some Science, Too
description: Correction Appended

title: Songs Open to Interpretation Flaunt Their Staying Power
description: One way songs survive is to prove themselves adaptable: to become widely heard through endless rearrangements and multiple genres. Another way is to be just the opposite: so personalized and obstinate that every performance becomes one more imitation of the song's originator.

title: Wife of Knicks' Davis Faces Battery Charge
description: Kendra Davis, the wife of New York Knicks forward Antonio Davis, was charged with misdemeanor battery yesterday in connection with a traffic altercation in a Chicago suburb more than three months ago.

title: A Twisty Tale of Bed-Hopping With a Power-Shifting Pair
description: In "A Bitter Taste," a strait-laced academic, John (Peter O'Connor), makes the mistake of having oral sex with an under-age prostitute while a tape recorder is running. It's no surprise that the threat of blackmail follows. But Kevin Snipes's acid drama about repression, friendship and the intersection between sex and power does not then follow a predictable path: it is the blackmailer -- the Kid (Haskell King) -- who turns out to be the most sympathetic and self-aware character in the play. Presented at the highly respected West Side space Ensemble Studio Theater, "A Bitter Taste" is part of a series, Thicker Than Water, that presents new works by members of the Youngblood theater company.

title: Art in Review; Do You Think I'm Disco
description: Correction Appended

title: AHEAD | Black History Month Events; A Slice of the American Story
description: DESIGNATING February as a time to pay attention to black history seems to some like an idea whose time came and by now should have gone. The actor Morgan Freeman, in an interview for "60 Minutes" last December, called it ridiculous.

title: A Nude Duet With Twists, Anguish and Eroticism
description: There may be legitimate questions about Jeremy Wade's range as a choreographer and dancer -- how much variety of movement and mood he can attain in multiple works. But the program he is presenting this week at Dance Theater Workshop, starting Wednesday and ending tomorrow, is pretty intense.

title: Planning: Handing down values as well as wealth
LIVING HERE | Beach Houses; Sand in Our Shoes
description: WHO -- Michael Weiner, 57, a part-time real estate developer from Scarborough, Me. WHAT -- 4-bedroom house WHERE -- Captiva Island, Fla.

title: Oil Habit Is Hard to Break Under New York Tax Code
description: ALBANY, Feb. 2 - In his address to the nation on Tuesday, President Bush said the United States must move to wean itself from foreign oil.

title: Anti-terrorist program for transit criticized
Rizzuto Keeps Memories, but Will Sell the Keepsakes
description: The gent with the camel's hair blazer, snappy scarf and thinning silver hair walked gingerly to the microphone. For 40 years after the pixieish shortstop's retirement from playing, he had an affectionate relationship with microphones built on his calls of balls, strikes, birthdays and cannoli.

title: G.M. Shifts Information Technology Contracts
description: DETROIT, Feb. 2 - General Motors said Thursday that it would spend up to $15 billion over the next five years to contract out information technology services. Electronic Data Systems, its former subsidiary, will remain the biggest supplier but will receive less work.

title: Rebecca Wright, 58, Dancer Who Starred With the Joffrey, Is Dead
description: Rebecca Wright, a Joffrey Ballet star in the 1960's and 70's and a ballet educator, died on Sunday at her home in Chevy Chase, Md. She was 58.

title: For Hoak, 44 Years as the Steelers' Lifer
description: Detroit - IN pro football, the players are transients. They come to a team from another area of the nation, then often go to another team. If they decide to stay in football as a coach, they usually bounce from one college to another as an assistant. Even if they are fortunate enough to join the staff of an N.F.L. team, they are seldom there for long.

title: Texas's Medicaid Watchdog Shares Some Tips for Success
description: The official in charge of policing Medicaid in Texas gave a tutorial yesterday to New York State lawmakers, showing how his state prevented hundreds of millions of dollars in waste and abuse, while also making it clear how far New York has to go.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Deutsche Bank Profit Triples
description: Deutsche Bank, based in Frankfurt, said its fourth-quarter profit more than tripled, lifted by securities trading and underwriting and a gain from selling DaimlerChrysler shares. Net income rose to 741 million euros ($899 million), or 1.44 euros a share, from 195 million euros ($236.5 million), or 37 cents, in the period a year earlier. Revenue increased 23 percent, to 6.55 billion euros ($7.9 billion). The chief executive, Josef Ackermann, said his goal was to maintain earnings growth of at least 10 percent. Deutsche Bank's pretax return on equity, a measure of profitability, increased to 26 percent last year, beating Mr. Ackermann's target of 25 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOSAK, ALVIN
description: KOSAK--Alvin. The faculty and staff of NYU's Department of Chemistry note with sorrow the passing of Alvin Kosak. Dr. Kosak came to the Department of Chemistry as an Associate Professor in 1955. He later served as Chairman of the department for over 15 years, ending his tenure as chair in 1977 when he was promoted to Acting Dean for the Faculty of Arts and Science. He was a distinguished researcher, passionate teacher and a highly regarded colleague who gave this department forty years of dedicated service. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family.

title: Classical Music and Opera Listings
description: Classical

title: Corrections
description: An appreciation on Monday of the tap dancer Fayard Nicholas, who died on Jan. 24, misidentified the maker of the film "Kid Millions," in which Mr. Nicholas and his brother danced. It was the Samuel Goldwyn Company, not MGM. The article also incorrectly rendered a word in the title of a song in "Show Boat" in comparing the Nicholas Brothers with other black performers. It is "Ol' Man River," not "Old Man River." The appreciation also erroneously included Hattie McDaniel in a description of the performance of that song. While she was in the movie, she did not sing it.

title: Films From All Over
description: When the Oscar is awarded for Best Foreign Film, it's usually time for presenters to fumble some pronunciations and for the rest of us to take a break as those obscure titles roll by. This year might be different. We can't control how some actor or other pronounces "Tsotsi" (it's TSA-tzee, though they're on their own for that), but all five nominees have American distributors, so we can get a jump on things by watching the trailers. The films don't look especially innovative, but in general they seem beautifully photographed and share the political awareness that also characterizes the major Oscar films this awards season.

title: Arts, Briefly; Spring Pop Concerts
description: The spring concert calendar is beginning to come into focus with some big new tours and festivals. The Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, a two-day smorgasbord in Indio, Calif., on April 29 and 30, will feature Depeche Mode, Tool, the Yeah Yeah Yeahs, Bloc Party, Sigur Ros, James Blunt, Clap Your Hands Say Yeah, Devendra Banhart, Coheed and Cambria, Matisyahu and dozens of others. Franz Ferdinand and Death Cab for Cutie will go on a joint monsters-of-indie-rock tour of North America for five weeks beginning March 22; they will come to the Hammerstein Ballroom in New York on April 13 and 14. (Franz Ferdinand will also appear at Coachella, but so far Death Cab is not on the lineup.) Madonna will have a virtual collaborator for her performance at the Grammy Awards on Wednesday: the Gorillaz, below, the cartoon rap-rock group masterminded by the singer Damon Albarn, will appear in 3-D animated color. Other performers at the Grammys will include Mariah Carey, John Legend, Kanye West, Bruce Springsteen, U2 with Mary J. Blige, Coldplay and an all-star tribute to Sly and the Family Stone. Destiny's Child will perform for the last time at the N.B.A. All-Star Game in Houston -- the group's hometown -- on Feb. 19, Billboard reported. BEN SISARIO

title: U.S. officials see increased terror threat
Designs For Living
description: Nothing to wear again? How about a personal uniform? Andrea Zittel, painter, sculptor, architect, inventor, carpenter, seamstress, fashion designer, merchandiser, nutritionist and social engineer, has utopian ideas about making life simpler. Grace Glueck explains. Page 35.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Jan. 2 about "Rollergirls," a documentary-style reality series on A&E, misidentified the player who explained another player's absence by saying, "She had some family issues to deal with, and she also messed up her foot at the Jell-O wrestling." It was Cha Cha, not Lux.

title: Archaeologist vindicated in hunch on antique silver hoard
Federal Costs Dropping Under New Medicare Drug Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 - Federal spending on the new Medicare drug benefit will be 20 percent lower than expected this year because beneficiaries are choosing prescription drug plans with lower premiums, the Bush administration said Thursday.

title: Another Child, Beaten to Death
description: Child welfare officials in New York have been feverishly reviewing cases and procedures in the weeks since 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown was tortured and beaten to death, despite numerous reports that she was at risk. But the reforms came too late for 4-year-old Quachaun Browne, who was horribly beaten to death this week, even though reports of trouble had brought caseworkers to the apartment that the boy shared with his siblings, his mother and her boyfriend, who has been charged with murdering the child.

title: Russia Convicts Human Rights Group Leader, but Won't Jail Him
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 3 A A Russian court convicted the director of a small, American-financed human rights organization today, ruling that he had incited ethnic and religious hatred by publishing newspaper commentaries by two Chechen separatist leaders in 2004.

title: Sheriff Won't Press Charges for 2005 Lake George Boat Accident
description: The Warren County sheriff has decided not to press criminal charges following an investigation into the capsizing of the Ethan Allen on Lake George last year, which killed 20 people.

title: Washington's hypocrisy over Google
Large toll feared in Red Sea disaster
More Political Consultants Are Lobbyists, Too
description: More political consultants in New York have taken on the second role of lobbyists over the last five years, prompting good-government advocates to press the city's ethics board to revive attempts to regulate the practice.

title: When Trust in Doctors Erodes, Other Treatments Fill the Void
description: A few moments before boarding a plane from Los Angeles to New York in January, Charlene Solomon performed her usual preflight ritual: she chewed a small tablet that contained trace amounts of several herbs, including extracts from daisy and chamomile plants.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Ex-Premier Stripped Of His Dacha
description: A court stripped former Prime Minister Mikhail M. Kasyanov, left, of a luxury cottage in Moscow that he purchased from the state in 2004, news agencies reported. Mr. Kasyanov, dismissed by President Vladimir V. Putin after the purchase, has emerged as a critic of the Kremlin and a potential candidate for president in 2008. After he began criticizing Mr. Putin's policies, a deputy in Parliament accused him of illegitimately acquiring the house and property for a steeply discounted price. Mr. Kasyanov called the court's decision politically motivated.

title: INSIDE
description: Twin Car Bombs Kill 16 At a Market in Baghdad Two car bombs detonated in quick succession near a crowded market, killing at least 16 people and wounding 90 in one of the worst attacks in Baghdad in weeks. Most of the dead appear to have been civilian shoppers. American military officials also announced the deaths of five service members.

description: STONE--Norma Dolores. After a brief illness, of cancer. Famed beauty and model in her youth, she is survived by her daughter Danielle Steel and loving grandchildren Beatrix, Samantha, Victoria, Vanessa, Maximillian, Zara, Trevor, Todd and the late Nicholas and great-grandson Sebastian. The family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Thursday February 2, 7-9 PM. description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 2 - Two car bombs detonated in quick succession on Thursday evening near a crowded market in eastern Baghdad, killing at least 16 people and wounding 90 in one of the worst attacks in the capital in weeks.

World Briefing | Middle East: Israel To Reopen Gaza Exports Crossing
description: Israel intends to reopen the Karni crossing from Gaza to Israel on Sunday, Israeli officials said, after nearly three weeks and mounting international criticism. Karni, the main exit from Gaza for agricultural and manufactured products, was shut by Israel on Jan. 15 after reports of a planned attack. Losses to Palestinians from the closing have amounted to about $500,000 a day, according to the United Nations.

title: King Funeral Has Surprise in Site Choice
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 2 - Coretta Scott King's funeral will be held not at Ebenezer Baptist Church, where her husband once preached, but at a much larger suburban megachurch where her youngest daughter is an elder, funeral planners said Thursday.

description: WHEN a roadside bomb blows up in Iraq, the reverberations sometimes reach even to New York. That was the case this week with the explosion that badly wounded the ABC newsman Bob Woodruff and his cameraman, Doug Vogt.

title: Jobless rate in the U.S. falls to 4.7%
36 Hours in Naples, Fla.
description: THIS city  named after the one in Italy because of its beautiful bay  is most widely known for its sugar-sand beaches, warm winter weather and sprawling, high-gated communities that attract older, well-off snowbirds who live to golf but go to bed early. (It has the nation's second highest number of golf holes per capita, just behind Myrtle Beach, S.C.). But now Naples is starting to draw a younger, more dynamic crowd attracted to outdoorsy pursuits off the course, high-end shopping and late-night noshing  all in a laid-back, upscale setting with enough cultural interest to support more than 130 art galleries and a symphony orchestra.

title: Utley Remains Determined
description: DETROIT, Feb. 2 - Mike Utley was paralyzed during an N.F.L. game in 1991, and over the past 15 years, his progress has surprised even some of his doctors.

title: Arts, Briefly; A New 'Idol' Dwarfs Competition
description: With the February ratings sweeps period looming, the networks have largely been hoarding original episodes, and on Wednesday, viewers were offered few new programs. But "American Idol" was new, and slaughtered everything in its path, giving Fox another victory for the night. The talent competition, which apparently found few good singers in its auditions in Austin, Tex., delivered an estimated audience of 30.15 million. At 9 p.m. on Fox, an episode of "Bones" again lost a significant portion of "Idol" viewers, bringing in 12.61 million. Though the bantering procedural placed first among adults 18 to 49 for the hour, a rerun of CBS's "Criminal Minds" attracted a larger audience (13.28 million). The cable-news broadcast of the State of the Union address on Tuesday resulted in the usual pecking order: Fox News (6.46 million), CNN (2.22 million), MSNBC (707,000). Fox News and CNN brought in more viewers for the speech than they did for last year's low-rated address: CNN nearly doubled its 2005 audience, while Fox News had an 8 percent increase. KATE AURTHUR

title: Vision Training
description: Thomas Wilson, author of "Sports Vision: Training for Better Performance" says the following routine can be performed several times a week for about 10 weeks, then intermittently every few weeks thereafter.

description: Enough with those splashy, glitzy rose-petal-covered valentine extravaganzas. Here is a selection of tokens of love that can be used and adored everyday.

title: Brokeback Saddles Up Against 25 Years of Oscar History
description: The Bagger has stared down the more than four long weeks to Oscar night and decided that he will do his best not to sow mischief, mayhem or confusion, although it looks like this month will carry all of the suspense of the second half of the Super Bowl, with little new data and not much of the way of news.

title: Costa Rica: Evergreen Adventure Destination
description: Costa Rica has an array of activities, low prices, and political stability making it an evergreen adventure.

title: Hay and Shelter
description: Selborne Journal: Tuesday, 3 February 1784: 30 1/10; 28; N. Fierce frost, sun, & sharp wind, frost, bright. Much snow on the ground. Paths, & horse-tracks dusty. Cucumber-seeds sprout. A near neighbour shot at a brace of hares out of his window, & at the same discharge killed one, & wounded an other. So I hope our gardens will not be so much molested. Much mischief has been done by these animals.

title: Majority Leader Boehner: Whos Happy?
description: The conservative journalists and bloggers who embraced Rep. John Shadegg as their preferred candidate to become the next House majority leader are disappointed that he lost to Ohios Rep. John Boehner. But they are happy that Rep. Roy Blunt, the establishment candidate, lost too. Ed Morrissey of Captains Quarters sounds a typical note when he writes, [I]n a decision between staying with business as usual or embracing reform, the Republicans chose a path somewhere in between the two.  I didnt dislike any of the three candidates. However, the G.O.P. missed an opportunity to make a bold statement on reform with this election.

title: English-Only SOTUs, the Morality of Abortion and Harper Lee
description: In the Wall Street Journal, first-generation migrant Tunku Varadarajan declares his opposition to the Spanish-language Democratic response to the State of the Union delivered by Los Angeles mayor Antonio Villaraigosa: I believe that in settling abroad, foreigners make a brutal contract with their land of adoption. They may speak their language, eat their food and practice their religionbut at home or by private arrangement. That is as far as I would go with multiculturalism. All elseincluding an insistence on a public affirmation of ethnic frills and fanciescripples the process of integration.  Pro-choicers William Saletan and Katha Pollitt debate the question, Is Abortion Bad? in Slate, extending a debate that began with Saletans Times op-ed and Pollitts response in The Nation.  Should they make a movie about Harper Lee, too? At First Things, Wilfred McClay suggests that To Kill a Mockingbird ranks among the most historically important books of the 20th century: I think one could argue that To Kill a Mockingbird did for twentieth-century race relations, or at any rate for white attitudes toward blacks, what Uncle Toms Cabin did for white attitudes about slavery in the antebellum nineteenth century. And yet it is rarely examined as a work of serious literature, not to mention one whose convicting force changed the moral life of the nation.

description: What makes for a successful real-estate agent? Basic arithmetic skills, for one thing.

title: Spying Game: Ends vs. Means
description: An article by federal judge Richard Posner in the New Republic about the National Security Agency wiretapping scandal  which, by the way, really needs a shorthand name, preferably one that doesnt end in -gate  has prompted an online debate that helps illustrate how the two sides are talking past each other. Supporters of the N.S.A. program want to discuss the substantive aims of the spying; opponents say the administrations national security goals are irrelevant and what matters is that the president made an end-run around Congress, and by extension, the Constitution.

title: The Polka King
description: Jimmy Sturr and his orchestra have won 14 Grammys in the polka album category and have been nominated 19 times. (Producer: Matthew Orr)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FELDMAN, MIRIAM RUTH
description: FELDMAN -- Miriam Ruth. Died February 2, 2006, at her home in Roslyn, NY. Beloved mother of Nancy and Frank. Services will be held Sunday, at "Riverside-Nassau North Chapels," 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Donations in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Politics and Gifts As Owners Pick Super Bowl City
description: DETROIT, Feb. 3 - Most owners of the National Football League's 32 teams are averse to cold-weather sites for the Super Bowl. But they are willing to make exceptions, which is how Sunday evening's game between the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Seattle Seahawks ended up here, a city where the average temperature in early February is 27 degrees.

title: Whitman Defends Finding on Air After 9/11
description: Christie Whitman, the former administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, yesterday rejected as "completely inaccurate" a ruling by a federal judge that found she had misled people near the World Trade Center site about the risks of toxic air contamination after the Sept. 11 attack.

title: Amid Outcry, Chancellor Defends Tutoring Program
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein vigorously defended the new teachers' contract yesterday in the face of a mounting outcry by parents and teachers over the logistics and equity of the contract's tutoring provision, which will require some of the city's failing students to stay after school for 37 1/2 minutes of tutoring in small groups, for up to four days a week.

title: Smells Like Team Spirit
description: To understand what's wrong with politics today, take a good look during the Super Bowl at the Steeler fans with their Terrible Towels. Imagine what's happening inside their minds as they wave the gold rags. This is your brain on partisan politics.

title: INSIDE

description: MATSEOANE--Carol (nee Taylor). On January 28, 2006. Daughter of Nannie W. Taylor and the late Joseph D. Taylor. Loving mother of Dara, Joyce and Karen. Reposing at Benta's Funeral Home, 630 St. Nicholas Ave. Visitation February 5, 2-5 PM. Visitation and funeral services at Riverside Church, February 6, 10 am. Entombment at Trinity Church Cemetery.

description: WEST

title: Winning Was Super; Watching Is Sad
description: DETROIT - THE contents of the sprawling hotel ballroom were being broken down yesterday afternoon after a long day. N.F.L. Commissioner Paul Tagliabue had given his address, and Indianapolis Colts quarterback Peyton Manning had received his award. Most of the past Super Bowl most valuable players posed for pictures, then sat down with reporters.

title: Russia Inc.
description: MOSCOW - RUSSIA today is not the same country it was only six years ago, when Vladimir Putin became president. Back then, the country was unsettled, tumultuous and impoverished, but it was free. Today Russia is richer -- and not free.

title: U.S. Compromises on Wording of Iran Nuclear Resolution
description: VIENNA, Feb. 3 - The 35-nation board of the International Atomic Energy Agency put off a vote on a landmark resolution on Iran's nuclear program on Friday, largely because of American opposition to a clause indirectly criticizing Israel's nuclear weapons status, according to several diplomats.

title: 'Pieces' Editor Now Says He Was Fooled by Frey
description: If anyone was in a position to know that James Frey was lying about his past in the book "A Million Little Pieces," it was Sean McDonald, his editor, who worked closely with Mr. Frey not only on that book but also on the follow-up, "My Friend Leonard," also now known to be largely fiction.

title: An Empire in Your Pocket
description: My quest to unite the warring tribes of the Mongolian plains is in trouble. Half my spearmen are dead, my last knight is trapped behind enemy lines and a battering ram is at the castle gates. Fortunately, the tribes attack one another as often as they attack me, and as the battle grinds on, I begin to gain the upper hand. As my archers' volleys of flaming arrows leave enemy towns in ruins, opposing leaders have no choice but to surrender.

title: Corrections
description: A pop music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday about the singer-songwriter Jesse Harris misstated the days in February on which he will appear at the Living Room on the Lower East Side. They are Mondays, not Tuesdays.

title: Bush Urges Study of Math and Science
description: DALLAS, Feb. 3 - President Bush told the nation's students on Friday that if they studied math and science they would not be joining the "nerd patrol" but helping their own futures and the economic health of the United States.

title: Broad Rise In Hiring Last Month
description: In one of the strongest job reports since the start of the recovery in late 2001, the government reported yesterday that the unemployment rate fell to 4.7 percent, its lowest level in more than four years. The nation's employers hired workers in nearly every industry.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: U.S. To Expel Diplomat
description: A day after Venezuela expelled the American naval attach in Caracas, accusing him of spying, the United States responded by ordering the expulsion of a senior diplomat in the Venezuelan Embassy in Washington. "We don't like to get into tit-for-tat games like this with the Venezuelan government, but they initiated this and we were forced to respond," Sean McCormack, the State Department spokesman, told reporters in Washington. The expelled diplomat was identified as Jeny Figueredo, the chief of staff to Venezuela's ambassador, Bernardo lvarez. JUAN FORERO (NYT)

title: When It Comes to Pay, It Helps to Be the One Signing the Checks
description: IT was a great year to be an employer in the United States. It was not so great a year to be an average employee.

title: Oilmen Meet With Cubans in Mexico, but U.S. Intervenes
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 3 - United States government officials said Friday that they had asked the owner of a hotel here, which is part of an American corporation, to expel a Cuban delegation that was meeting with American oil executives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   QUINN, KEVIN B.
description: QUINN--Kevin B. Of Somers, New York, and Bolton Landing, New York, passed away at home on February 2nd after a long and courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. He was 63 years old. Kevin worked on the trading floor as a stock specialist and partner with M.J. Meehan & Co. for 30 years. He was a proud member of the New York Stock Exchange for 18 of those years before ringing the Exchange's closing bell upon his retirement in December 1998. Kevin was born on November 7, 1942 in the Bronx to William and Elizabeth (Walker) Quinn. He served in both the U.S. Air Force (1960-1964) and U.S. Army (1964-1967) as well as U.S. Army Reserves (1974-1980). Kevin was the loving, devoted husband of Mary (Foley) for 36 years and the proud father of three children, Colleen (Petersen) and husband Joseph, Mary Beth and Kevin, Jr. He was also the loving granddad of Kyle and Shannon Petersen, born to Colleen and Joseph. Kevin is survived by four sisters and predeceased by two brothers, as well as his parents. He is also survived by numerous aunts, uncles, cousins, nieces and nephews. Kevin was a member of the Knights of Columbus, the Elks Club, and the American Legion. Calling hours are Saturday, 7 to 9 p.m. and Sunday, 2 to 4 p.m. and 7 to 9 p.m. at Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home, 288 Main Street, Mt. Kisco, New York. title: Corrections
description: The Books of The Times review in Weekend on Jan. 20, about "Beyond Coincidence," by Martin Plimmer and Brian King, referred imprecisely to the odds that two people share a birthday. The odds that a person you meet shares your birthday are 364-1. The odds that two people in a group will share a birthday are much higher. With a group of just 23 people, there is more than a 50 percent likelihood that 2 have the same birthday.

title: Arts, Briefly; Suit Against Russian Art Is Dismissed
description: A court in Moscow this week dismissed a civil lawsuit brought against an exhibition that a group of artists said had violated their religious freedoms by mocking Russian Orthodoxy and inciting interfaith animosity. The nine artists who filed the suit sought the equivalent of $170,000 for "moral injury" caused by the exhibition, "Russia 2." The show ran at the same time as Moscow's first biennial of contemporary art last year and included works by some of Russia's most prominent artists, among them Gor Chahal, Marina Koldobskaya and the comic pair the Blue Nose (Vyacheslav Mizin and Aleksandr Shaburov). The judge cited the constitution's provisions separating church and state, the newspaper Kommersant reported on Thursday. "It is the first victory for art," Marat Guelman, one of the show's organizers, said in a phone interview, noting the criminal conviction last year of the director and a curator at the Andrei Sakharov Museum in Moscow on a similar charge arising from a 2003 exhibition that many saw as ridiculing the Orthodox Church. STEVEN LEE MYERS

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: ConAgra Foods Plans to Sell Meat Brands, Including Armour, Butterball and Eckrich The packaged food company ConAgra Foods said yesterday that it planned to shed most of its refrigerated meats businesses, including the Armour, Butterball and Eckrich brands. The businesses have combined annual sales of about $1.9 billion. In addition, the company announced changes to streamline its operating structure, including moving its grocery foods headquarters from Irvine, Calif., to Naperville, Ill., and further centralizing other services. ConAgra said it expected to take cash and noncash accounting charges for the organizational changes. The businesses up for sale include Armour meats and hot dogs, Butterball turkey, and Eckrich smoked sausages, hot dogs and lunchmeats. (REUTERS)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Uzbekistan: Opposition Leader On Trial
description: The embezzlement trial of Sanjar Umarov, a businessman who is the chairman of the opposition group the Sunshine Coalition, began in Tashkent, Human Rights Watch reported. Rights groups say they believe the case is politically motivated and have expressed concerns that Mr. Umarov was drugged or tortured in custody. His lawyer, who had earlier said that he had found Mr. Umarov naked and incoherent in his cell, said his mental and physical health appeared normal. Surat Ikramov, the director of Independent Group for Human Rights Defenders of Uzbekistan, said that Mr. Umarov "explained in court that he could not remember anything from his arrest on Oct. 23 until early November." ETHAN WILENSKY-LANFORD (NYT)
