title: Arts, Briefly; Writer Denied Residency
description: Her writing awards include the Pushcart Prize, the Frank O'Connor International Short Story Award and the Plimpton Prize for New Writers, and her letters of support came from Salman Rushdie and David Remnick, editor of The New Yorker. But it wasn't enough for the United States government. This week, an appeal from the Chinese-born writer Yiyun Li for permanent residency on the grounds of "extraordinary ability in the arts" was denied, Ms. Li said yesterday. A letter she received on Monday dismissed her appeal because, she said, when she first filed her petition in 2004, "the very high standard set by Congress" had not been met: she had not yet received her O'Connor award, and her book "A Thousand Years of Good Prayers" (Random House, 2005) had not been published. The rejection of the appeal was first reported yesterday in The Washington Post. "Of course, I'm very sad," said Ms. Li, 33, who has written for The New York Times Magazine and The Paris Review and who teaches creative writing at Mills College in Oakland, Calif. She is married to a Chinese man who is also not a citizen but has two young children who were born in the United States. "It's a long process," she said. "I think we're going to try another petition with Mills sponsorship." FELICIA R. LEE

title: Arts, Briefly; Writing Prize Tightens Rules to Prevent Fraud
description: After news reports that one of its prizewinning authors had faked his identity in a memoir, the PEN American Center has announced that it will take steps to ensure that future contestants are who they say they are. PEN's decision this week came after a recent article in L.A. Weekly said that a memoirist calling himself Nasdijj, whose three books under that name are about the troubled life of an American Indian man, is actually Timothy Barrus, left, a white man who has written gay pornography. In the three Nasdijj books, he says he was born on a Navajo reservation and was raped by his white father, and describes in hyperpoetic style a life of hardship and loss. One book, "The Boy and the Dog Are Sleeping," was one of five winners of the 2004 PEN/Beyond Margins Awards for writers of color, and another, "The Blood Runs Like a River Through My Dreams," was a finalist for a PEN memoir award. Michael Roberts, the executive director of PEN, said the center would not rescind the Margins prize since it did not come with any money, but he added that from now on publishers and individuals who nominate writers will be asked to confirm the writers' eligibility. According to L.A. Weekly, Nasdijj posted a statement on his Web site (www.nasdijj.typepad.com) using his real name; the name has since been removed. DINITIA SMITH

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Roof Collapse At Store
description: Record rainfall caused a roof collapse at a Bed Bath & Beyond store in St. Petersburg that washed three employees, the windows, waffle makers and other merchandise out the front of the store. One employee sustained minor injuries. St. Petersburg, on the Gulf Coast, received a record 12 inches of rain in three and a half hours, causing four roofs to collapse and streets to flood, said Mayor Rick Baker. The collapse at the store was the most serious, Mr. Baker said. A police spokesman, Bill Proffitt, said, "It was crazy out here." He added, "Visibility was poor, we couldn't drive in the parking lot, rain was blowing sideways, and you couldn't see 50 feet in front of you." LYNN WADDELL (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Battle of the Reality Titans
description: The February ratings sweep period is upon us. And though entertainment programs will soon be challenged by NBC's Olympic coverage, Thursday featured another kind of intense competition: the premiere of the new "Survivor" went up against its reality-show opposite, "Dancing With the Stars." Both drew large audiences, as the 90-minute "Dancing" on ABC brought in an estimated 18.74 million viewers, and CBS's "Survivor" -- which, in this installment, has four tribes instead of the usual two -- delivered 19.34 million. CBS, which won the night in Nielsen's estimates, picked up steam at 9 p.m. with "CSI" (27.99 million), by far the most-watched show of the night. And the network's "Without a Trace" (20.8 million) easily beat NBC's "ER" (13.78 million). KATE AURTHUR

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Inquiry Ordered Into Olympics Phone Tapping
description: The government ordered an investigation into revelations that cellphones used by the prime minister and other members of the government, senior military officials, the United States Embassy in Athens and others were tapped by unknown persons for about a year, beginning before the Olympics in Athens in 2004. The high-tech surveillance was revealed on Thursday when the government confirmed a report in the newspaper Ta Nea. Others subjected to the eavesdropping included Arab journalists and businessmen in Athens and anti-globalization activists, the government said. Public Order Minister Giorgos Voulgarakis told reporters that an initial investigation had shown that the phone tappers used interceptors traced in the vicinity of the United States Embassy in central Athens, but a government spokesman, Theodoros Roussopoulos, denied any American involvement. After winning the right to serve as host for the 2004 Summer Games, Greece faced international scrutiny over its security plans for the event. ANTHEE CARASSAVA (NYT)

title: Now, Even Whisenhunt Knows He Can Really Coach
description: DETROIT, Feb. 3 - It was in 1987, when Ken Whisenhunt was a tight end for the Atlanta Falcons, that Al Groh took notice.

title: Mexico Closes Alternative Care Clinic Where Mrs. King Died
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 3 - Mexican health officials on Thursday night shut down an alternative medicine clinic where Coretta Scott King died this week, saying the doctors there were using unproven treatments and were never licensed to run a full-service hospital.

title: Let's Hold a Benefit for the C.E.O.
description: AFTER reading "Don't Mess With CEO Pay," in the current issue of Across the Board, you might be tempted to organize a bake sale or car wash to give the big boss a raise.

title: Weather Is Great, if Not Timing
description: DETROIT, Feb. 3 - It is too warm here. The snowshoers have no snow, and the mushers have no slush. There are weight restrictions on the man-made tubing hill, to help keep what is left of the artificial snow from getting pushed to the bottom and melting in the street.

title: Back at the Studio, CBS Announces a Shake-Up
description: In a series of changes expected to be announced Monday, James Brown will leave as the host of Fox Sports' N.F.L. pregame program to take the same job on CBS's "The NFL Today."

title: Halliburton Subsidiary Gets Contract to Add Temporary Immigration Detention Centers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3  The Army Corps of Engineers has awarded a contract worth up to $385 million for building temporary immigration detention centers to Kellogg Brown & Root, the Halliburton subsidiary that has been criticized for overcharging the Pentagon for its work in Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRUNWALD, SUSAN TEVAN
description: GRUNWALD--Susan Tevan. Died February 2, 2006. Greatly beloved by many. Wife of the late Armand; Mother of Andrew and Linda, David and Ellen; Grandmother of Michael, Matthew, Danielle, Hannah, Sonia. Loving companion of Adrian Berlescu. Funeral services: on Sunday February 5, 12:15PM, Sinai Chapel, Queens. The family encourages donations to good causes in her honor.

title: The Muhammad Cartoon Furor
description: To the Editor:

title: The High Cost of Public Information
description: The Bush administration has made a habit of keeping public information from the very public that owns it. A good example can be found at the United States Department of Education. After dragging its feet for months, the agency has asked a tiny nonprofit group to pay a ruinous sum for information on the impact of a law that bars students who have committed drug offenses from receiving federal grants and loans.

title: Arts, Briefly; In His Words, Why He Left
description: It was stress and not a mental breakdown that prompted the comedian Dave Chappelle to leave his hit show on Comedy Central, he told Oprah Winfrey in an interview that was broadcast on Ms. Winfrey's show yesterday. "I wasn't crazy, but it was incredibly stressful," said Mr. Chappelle, 32. In his first television interview since walking away from "Chappelle's Show" and a deal that could have earned him $50 million, Mr. Chappelle, right, said that he felt conflicted about the material he was producing. "I was doing sketches that were funny, but were socially irresponsible," he said. He denied that drugs or too much partying had anything to do with his departure. He also denied reports that he had sought treatment at a psychiatric hospital in South Africa. "Who goes from America to Africa for medical attention?" he asked. Late last year, Comedy Central announced that the show would go on; the network has cobbled enough material for four half-hour episodes, which are scheduled to run in late spring or early this summer. Mr. Chappelle did not rule out returning to finish filming the third season, provided that he was given more "control" and that a portion of the proceeds from DVD sales went to people who were not "exploiting me," he said. In a statement yesterday, Comedy Central said, "Dave is a comedic genius whose work we truly value, and our door will always be open to him." LOLA OGUNNAIKE

title: Must We Say Goodbye to the Grecian Urn?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHAIFETZ, JILL
description: CHAIFETZ--Jill. The Trustees and staff of the Center for Alternative Sentencing and Employment Services (CASES) note with sorrow the passing of Jill Chaifetz. Her distinguished work on behalf of court involved students and all students in the New York City School system made a real difference for all children. She was passionate in her commitment. We extend our deepest sympathy and heartfelt condolences to her entire family. Joel Copperman, CEO CASES Leslie Gimbel, Chair of the Board of Trustees

title: Must We Say Goodbye to the Grecian Urn?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HELD, JAMIE
description: HELD--Jamie. Where's my everything. Love, Vern

title: Rainy Day Contemplation and a Burst of Breeziness, Too
description: Marc Johnson has a round, resonant tone on the double bass, and an almost offhandedly prodigious technique. In the late 1970's and early 80's, these made him an ideal partner for the pianist Bill Evans, who enlisted Mr. Johnson for what turned out to be his final working trio. Since then, Mr. Johnson has applied his expertise to his own ensembles, but sparingly: while his sideman credits are extensive, his albums are few and far between.

title: Chinese Collectors Resist Investing in Western Art
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 3 - As with many mansions and luxury apartments of the emerging commercial elite across China, Linus W. L. Cheung's elegant home overlooking Victoria Harbor here is almost entirely decorated with Chinese art.

title: Oilmen Meet With Cubans in Mexico, but U.S. Intervenes
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 3  United States government officials said Friday that they had asked the owner of a hotel here, which is part of an American corporation, to expel a Cuban delegation that was meeting with American oil executives.

title: Oilman Plays Ozone Man
description: WASHINGTON - The Saudi ambassador summoned me to the embassy on Thursday, across the street from the Watergate.

title: Planning a Trip With Peace of Mind in Mind
description: WHEN planning a vacation, I think of sun, sea, great dinners and fascinating sights.

title: The Muhammad Cartoon Furor
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief art review in Weekend on Jan. 27 about a show of photographs by Erwin Olaf at the Hasted Hunt gallery in Manhattan misstated Mr. Olaf's exhibition history. It is not his first show in the United States; his work was featured at the Laurence Miller Gallery, also in Manhattan, in 2001.

title: Kansas' Top Court Limits Abortion Record Search
description: WICHITA, Kan., Feb. 3 - The Kansas Supreme Court restricted on Friday an unusual and divisive investigation by Attorney General Phill Kline into illegal abortions and child rape, ruling that the names and personal information of 90 women and girls must be removed from the records he is seeking from two abortion clinics.

title: Mardi Gras Medical
description: In two weeks, Mardi Gras parades will begin rolling in New Orleans, bringing revelers intent on proving they can still party in the Big Easy. Unfortunately, New Orleans is down to one working adult hospital. That is a recipe for disaster.

title: METS SIGN A PLAYER
description: Since defecting from Cuba in 2004, Michel Abreu has changed agents twice, lived in Mexico and Costa Rica and, most recently, had a contract voided with the Red Sox.

title: Changes at ABC, Where the War Is More Than News
description: Charles Gibson, the co-anchor of "Good Morning America," and David Westin, the president of ABC News, had long been scheduled to have lunch last Monday in Mr. Westin's plasma-screened office five floors above West 66th Street in Manhattan.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Clinton To Push Tax Credit
description: Former President Bill Clinton announced that he was putting his political muscle, and $275,000 from his Clinton Foundation, behind an effort in 10 cities to help victims of Hurricane Katrina receive money under the federal Earned Income Tax Credit. At a news conference in Harlem, Mr. Clinton said he would spend this tax season trying to raise awareness among victims that they could qualify for the credit even if they have been out of work since the storm. The cities the program will operate in are Birmingham, Ala.; Little Rock, Ark.; Atlanta; Baton Rouge, La.; Lake Charles, La; New Orleans; Jackson, Miss.; Dallas; Houston; and San Antonio. PATRICK D. HEALY (NYT)

title: Australian Testifies on Wheat Company's Payments to Hussein
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 3 - A former wheat export executive on Friday delivered devastating testimony indicating that executives of AWB Ltd., an Australian company, had paid millions of dollars in kickbacks to Saddam Hussein's government in exchange for lucrative contracts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDFRANK, SYLVIA GLASS
description: GOLDFRANK--Sylvia Glass, 93. Of Santa Cruz, CA, devoted wife of the late Max; loving mother of Walter and David; doting grandmother of Naomi, Daniel, Benjamin, Sarah, Joseph, Helen, and Max; great-grandmother of Julia, Diego, and Abigail; fond aunt of Dorothy and the late Michael Glass. Graduate of Hunter High School, Wellesley College, New York University. Founding member of New York Teachers' Union, lifelong fighter for justice, translator and interpreter for the French government, dedicated teacher of English and French literature at Mamaroneck High School and elsewhere. Mermorial services to be announced. Contributions preferred to Doctors Without Borders.

title: Tax Talk Goes Orwellian
description: President Bush had it exactly backwards in his speech Tuesday night when he exhorted lawmakers to keep cutting taxes. He noted that when the going gets tough, leaders are tempted to take stands that are crowd pleasing yet counterproductive, like championing protectionism in the face of global competition. Fair enough.

title: BRADY TO HAVE SURGERY
description: Tom Brady, the New England Patriots' quarterback, will have surgery in the coming weeks to repair a sports hernia, according to an article in the MetroWest Daily News of Framingham, Mass. The article said that Brady played half the season with the injury.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend yesterday about "Andrea Zittel: Critical Space," at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in Manhattan, misstated the year of her A-Z Deserted Islands work, when a fleet of fiberglass structures floated in the Central Park Boat Basin. It was 1997, not 1977.

title: Flight of O'Neill's Emperor, Streamlined for Three Actors
description: The mind's eye and the real-life ears both receive an invigorating workout from Arthur Adair's streamlined version of "The Emperor Jones" at La MaMa E.T.C.

title: Cartoons Force Danish Muslims to Examine Loyalties
description: COPENHAGEN, Feb. 2 - As a Danish citizen of Pakistani descent, a onetime television anchor and now a prominent author married to a Dane, Rushy Rashid has led what could be depicted as a high-profile life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAHAM, REV. MARGARET M.
description: GRAHAM--Rev. Margaret M. We grieve at the untimely loss of our beloved friend Meg, and cherish the gifts of faith and humanity she shared with us and others. Virginia and Richard Schubert, Elisabeth Austin, Emily and Robert Carroll, Deborah and Selvyn Seidel.

title: Slowly, St. Bonaventure Is Finding Its Way Back
description: OLEAN, N.Y., Feb. 1 - Three years ago, as he stood in the rubble of the St. Bonaventure basketball program, Ahmad Smith had a decision to make.

title: Indonesian Says Waste From Mine Tainted Fish
description: MANADO, Indonesia, Feb. 3 - A star government witness in a criminal trial against the American mining giant Newmont told a court on Friday that waste from the company's mine near here was deposited in the sea at too shallow a depth, causing the contamination of fish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBERG, MURRAY I.
description: ROSENBERG -- Murray I. Died on February 2, 2006. Preceded in death by his cherished wife Sandra. Beloved father of Donna, Joe and Amy. Loving grandfather of Noah, Emma, Juliet, Hannah, Ilana and Abby. Born August 1, 1923. Grew up on Hopkinson Av. in Brooklyn and graduated Brooklyn College. Served in World War II. Made his mark on the basketball courts and in the dining rooms of the Borscht Belt. Executive in the consumer electronics industry. A kind and generous man with a keen intellect and interest in others. Lover of Shakespeare, Sinatra, tennis, appetizing and the Knicks. A critical and humorous observer of life. He will be missed by all who were touched and inspired by him. Services Sunday, February 5, 11:15 AM at "The Riverside", 76th St. & Amsterdam Av. Interment to follow at Beth Moses Cemetery. Donations in memory of Murray and Sandra Rosenberg can be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Grand Central Station, PO Box 4777, New York, NY, 10163.

title: Turning Television Inside Out, and Art Upside Down
description: Lots of artists spend their youth finding new ways to flout established aesthetic protocols, but few maintain the renegade status fruitfully into old age. That was the achievement of Nam June Paik, widely considered the inventor of video art, who died Sunday at 73. Mr. Paik was forever young in the best sense of the phrase, although his perennial joviality, which sometimes bordered on clownishness, could disguise the extent of his achievement.

title: Vaccine Against Diarrhea-Causing Virus Is Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 - Federal drug regulators on Friday approved an oral vaccine against a common form of diarrhea that kills half a million children around the world each year.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE UPSIDE OF ANGER -- (2005). It is so nice to be able to like Kevin Costner again. He plays a lovable slob, a retired baseball player who develops something more than a friendship with a suburban neighbor (the superb Joan Allen, above, with Mr. Costner), whose husband has just disappeared. They both enjoy daytime drinking.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "It is not the job of public-affairs officers to alter, filter or adjust engineering or scientific material produced by NASA's technical staff."

title: Investigator at NASA Faces Inquiry Over Safety
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 - NASA's chief investigator is being investigated by a federal watchdog agency on charges that he retaliated against whistle-blowers and failed to look properly into safety and security issues at the space agency, officials said Friday.

title: U.S. Moves to Seize Bankrupt Steel Maker's Pension Plan
description: The federal government said it filed suit yesterday to seize the pension plan of the bankrupt WCI Steel, saying the plan was more than $100 million short of the amount it needed. The move is a first step toward holding WCI's corporate parent, the Renco Group, responsible for the money.

title: Taliban Battle Afghan Forces in Drug Region
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 3 - Heavy fighting in southern Afghanistan between the Taliban and Afghan police forces left three policemen and at least six Taliban militants dead, Afghan officials said Friday.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Poland: Stabilization Pact
description: Four months after winning the national elections, the conservative Law and Justice Party signed a 12-month cooperation agreement with two opposition fringe parties, ending months of parliamentary gridlock and averting the risk of new national elections. The accord was signed with the far-right League of Polish Families, which demands higher spending on social programs, and the far-left Self-Defense party, which opposes European Union membership and the adoption of the euro. VICTOR HOMOLA (NYT)

title: U.S. Says It Also Finds Cartoons of Muhammad Offensive
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 - The Muslim world erupted in anger on Friday over caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad published in Europe while the Bush administration offered the protesters support, saying of the cartoons, "We find them offensive, and we certainly understand why Muslims would find these images offensive."

title: House Republicans Try to Get Back on Course
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 - House Republicans began trying to put themselves back on course Friday after a leadership election that exposed party fractures and a crisis of political confidence.

title: Betty Friedan, Who Ignited Cause in 'Feminine Mystique,' Dies at 85
description: Betty Friedan, the feminist crusader and author whose searing first book, "The Feminine Mystique," ignited the contemporary women's movement in 1963 and in so doing permanently transformed the social fabric of the United States and countries around the world, died yesterday, her 85th birthday, at her home in Washington.

title: As Tribal Leaders, Women Still Fight Old Views
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: A listing of credits on Saturday with a television review about "The First Emperor: The Man Who Made China," on the Discovery Channel, included an erroneous credit from the show for the narrator. He is Eric Myers, not Samuel West.

title: Jack Frost, Napping
description: After a cold start to December, this winter has been unusually warm. January was tied for the fourth warmest since 1870, when records were first kept in Central Park. Yesterday's temperature hit 62 degrees. With a change toward cooler patterns forecast for next week, a look back:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLUEGER, HANS
description: KLUEGER--Hans. On February 2, 2006. Beloved husband of the late Anna; devoted father of Robert and Jane and father-in-law of Patricia; darling grandfather of David & Elizabeth; longtime companion of Erna Samet.

title: Egyptian Ferry Sinks in Red Sea; 1,000 May Be Lost
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Saturday, Feb. 4 - A ferry carrying more than 1,400 passengers and crew, most of them Egyptian laborers returning from Saudi Arabia, sank Friday about 40 miles off the coast of Egypt, and by late evening, only 324 people had been rescued.

title: In Full Flight for Serkin in an Ambitious Pair of Concertos
description: Lately it has seemed that the Orchestra of St. Luke's is New York's all-purpose symphonic ensemble. It recently played in the Lincoln Center production of Osvaldo Golijov's opera "Ainadamar." On Monday night at Carnegie Hall it joined Robert Bass and the Collegiate Chorale for concert performances of Puccini's first opera, "Le Villi," and part of his last, Act III of "Turandot" (with Luciano Berio's amazing completion of the unfinished final scene).

title: Greenspan Heads Out and the Enron Two Head to Court
description: ONE important era ended this week and another entered its final lap. In Washington, Alan Greenspan presided over his last meeting as chairman of the Federal Reserve at the same time as the Senate was voting to confirm his successor. In Houston, the two most senior former executives of Enron went on trial for conspiracy and fraud.

title: Security Council Agrees to Send Troops to Darfur
description: Correction Appended

title: Met Agrees Tentatively to Return Vase in '08
description: A Classical vase that has long been the crown jewel of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Greek galleries will probably be handed over to Italy at the beginning of 2008, the museum and Italian officials said yesterday, in their first public agreement on a date.

description: In His Words, Why He Left

title: What $II.V Million Buys on Super Bowl XL
description: More than two dozen advertisers are buying commercials tomorrow night during Super Bowl XL on ABC. The network is charging a record price, estimated at $2.5 million for each 30 seconds; some spots will run for 15, 45 or 60 seconds. Several advertisers bought time in the last few days, including American Honda Motor, for the Ridgeline truck; GoDaddy, the Web site registrar; and Starwood, for Westin hotels. Here is a look at the lineup of commercials that are planned to appear nationally during the game; the schedule is subject to changes at the last minute based on factors like the flow of the game. STUART ELLIOTT

title: Gridiron City
description: Pittsburgh - THE electronic signs above the windshields on city buses here alternate their destination with a flashing message: "GO STEELERS!" In stores, in restaurants, on the street, people are wearing team jerseys. The news is All Steelers, All the Time: for the past two weeks, the war in Iraq and the Samuel Alito confirmation have been supplanted by Jerome Bettis's mom, Coach Bill Cowher's decision to wear the white "away" uniforms, opinion forums ("Is God for the Steelers?"), and a raspy song by a local band setting Troy Polamalu's name to music.

title: Aides Re-edited News Articles on Candidate's Web Site
description: As William F. Weld runs for governor of New York this year, his campaign has put a new spin on the old political rule of having a positive message.

title: Retiring Stevens's Number Gives Devils Inspiration
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 3 - Scott Stevens, wearing rimless glasses and his familiar No. 4 Devils jersey, leaned toward the microphone atop the lectern that had been set up at the red line Friday night. Two teams and a capacity crowd hushed and listened.

title: A Turning Point for New York Courts
description: The myth that New Yorkers choose their top trial judges by democratic election was exploded last week by a 77-page federal court decision striking down the clubhouse-controlled selection process for violating the rights of candidates and voters.

title: For Miller, Skiing Is Far Easier Than Post-Race News Conference
description: CHAMONIX, France, Feb. 3 - After the rarest of vacations, Bode Miller returned to World Cup competition Friday, finishing third in a super combined event and addressing a number of controversies that he escaped, for a week, while golfing in Dubai.

title: Bush to Propose Curbing Growth in Medicare Cost
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 - In his budget next week, President Bush will propose substantial savings in Medicare, stepping up his efforts to rein in the growing costs of social insurance programs, administration officials and health care lobbyists said Friday.

title: Amid Outcry, Chancellor Defends Tutoring Program
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein vigorously defended the new teachers' contract yesterday in the face of a mounting outcry by parents and teachers over the logistics and equity of the contract's tutoring provision, which will require some of the city's failing students to stay after school for 371/2 minutes of tutoring in small groups, for up to four days a week.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Jan. 13 about the expectation that the United States population would reach 300 million in October misstated the proportion of Americans who are Anglo-Saxon Protestants. According to current surveys, about 40 percent of the population is white Protestant. Anglo-Saxon Protestants, therefore, do not account for "most Americans."

title: Tana Hoban, 88, an Author Whose Specialty Was Pictures, Dies
description: Correction Appended

title: Home Bursting With Children, and Troubles, Reaches Fatal Breaking Point
description: Aleshia Smith's oldest daughter was living with a relative, but the two-bedroom apartment on Kossuth Avenue in the Bronx was still crowded with her five other children -- and two cats. Then on a November afternoon she invited Jose Calderon, 18, a virtual stranger with a nice smile but a bad temper, to move in, friends and relatives said.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about meetings by Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and other foreign ministers in London on the impact of the Palestinian election victory by Hamas, the militant Islamist group, misidentified a sum of money in the fiscal crisis confronting the Palestinian Authority, which Hamas will inherit when it takes power. The figure, $600 million, is the authority's annual deficit, not annual expenses. (Go to Article)

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Policing Darfur
description: Darfur, Sudan, has become a giant crime scene littered with shell casings and full of suspects on the run.
Selborne Journal: Wednesday, 4 February 1784: 30, 29 8/10; 30, 34; NW, W, SW. Hard frost, sun, paths thaw, fleecy clouds, sky muddled, halo. Thaw in the sun.

title: Grammys Overview
description: The Times's Tom Kuntz, in a roundtable discussion with Jon Pareles and Kelefa Sanneh, tries to answer the question: Are the Grammy Awards relevant? (Producer: Craig Duff)

title: Building the Army
description: The Times's Damien Cave examines the current challenges facing the United States Army as it seeks to enlist more recruits. Producer: Erik Olsen.

title: The Times Wont Publish Cartoons
description: The New York Times has decided not to publish cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad that Muslims consider blasphemous and anti-Muslim.

title: With Heath Miller
description: The rookie Heath Miller, a first-round draft pick from Virginia, was the first Atlantic Coast Conference player to win the John Mackey Award as college football's best tight end. He was the Steelers' second-leading receiver, behind Hines Ward, with 39 catches for 459 yards and 6 touchdowns. In the playoffs, he caught 7 passes for 107 yards and a touchdown.

title: Handle With Millions of Dollars Worth of Care
description: When the Metropolitan Museum of Art unveiled its exhibition of Fra Angelico paintings in the fall, critics and audiences responded with a collective gasp. (In these pages, Roberta Smith called it "the exhibition of a lifetime.") It wasn't just the exquisite brushwork, the innovative compositions or the buckets of saintly gore on view. Part of the wonder involved their improbable presence in 21st-century Manhattan.

title: Specter Says Surveillance Program Violated the Law
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 A The Republican who chairs the Senate Judiciary Committee said today that he believed the Bush administration had violated the law with its warrantless surveillance program and that its legal justifications for the program were "strained and unrealistic."

title: God, Country, Florida State
description: I don't live in Beaumont, Tex., and wouldn't want to -- sorry, where's the team? -- but Beaumont is where I watched the Orange Bowl last month, in a hotel room off the interstate on my way back home to Florida. The Geezer Bowl, as the wags described it: Joe Paterno versus Bobby Bowden, college football's legendary silverbacks who seem content to die with their headsets on, inhaling that last earthly scent of pigskin on the sidelines. The next day, in a banner headline, The Tallahassee Democrat called the game a thriller, but honestly it wasn't, and I don't say that just because my team lost. Two dazzled-out icons, three unnecessary overtimes, no delicious scandals and no animosity (like we once felt for Steve Spurrier and the Florida Gators but now direct toward the Miami Hurricanes) -- a total Chamber of Commerce event, excuse the yawn.

title: Skate or Diet
description: Two years ago, Mike Modano, a center for the National Hockey League's Dallas Stars, knew that something had to change, or his career would be over. "Physically, I wasn't feeling the way I did when I was younger," says Modano, who is 35. So the six-time all-star called on Paul Chek, a nutrition and exercise specialist who has worked with elite athletes like the big-wave surfer Laird Hamilton and the snowboarder Shaun White.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE LOOKING AT UMDNJ
description: Ranking members of the United States Senate Finance Committee have requested information on finances at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey from the governor and federal Medicaid and Medicare officials, the committee announced last Monday. In letters to the governor and federal officials, Senators Chuck Grassley of Iowa and Max Baucus of Montana said they were seeking assurance that the state would reverse problems that led to allegations of mismanagement and fraud. Gov. Jon S. Corzine said he would cooperate with the committee's investigation.

description: YACCARINO - Joe. Tenth birthday away yet ever close. Happy Birthday, dear friend. Tony

title: The Tenafly Councilman and 40 Bags of Heroin
description: TENAFLY - IT was around 1:30 on an afternoon last November, prosecutors say, when Jeffery Romano, a councilman from Tenafly, pulled his 2006 Chevrolet Corvette up to the Joseph P. Bradley Court housing complex, a notorious collection of 20 dreary, low-slung brown brick buildings on the outskirts of Newark.

title: Working the Seam
description: I'm calling this play's signals out of the shotgun. No, wait -- I see their lockdown corner is set for a corner blitz, and Sam, Mike and Will are in a 4-3 press coverage with their secondary in a cover-2. So I'll audible a pistol offense with a max protect and have my tight end try to work the seam or run a skinny post to beat the zone.

title: For Two Chefs, a Singular Medley
description: MOSAIC is aptly named. The stylish cafe has food that ranges over a worldwide spectrum of culinary traditions, with individual dishes of varying colors, tastes and textures.

title: Mayor Considers Moving Against Senate G.O.P.
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is considering using his considerable wealth and popularity to help a Democratic Queens city councilman challenge one of the State Senate's longest-standing Republican lions this fall, aides to the mayor said on Friday.

title: Health Care Begins at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Curry: A Tale of Cooks and Conquerors
Turin
description: WHY GO NOW From Feb. 10 to 26, Turin will play host the 20th Winter Olympic Games, surpassing Rome, Florence and Venice as the place to be in Italy. During that time, organizers expect 2,500 athletes, 10,000 journalists and more than a million spectators to descend upon the city. From March 10 to 19, it will revive its Olympic spirit as the host of the Paralympic Games.

title: Going Condo in Harlem
description: RICHARD SHIU'S brownstone on West 123rd Street was once an abandoned wreck, but now he looks on proudly as would-be buyers trek up the stairs to stare at the gas-burning fireplaces and mantels, the high ceilings and granite counters and the roof deck with clear views of the Midtown Manhattan skyline.

title: Christine Murphy and Kevin Costello
description: Christine Kennedy Murphy, the daughter of Mary Jane Kennedy Baxter and Robert Bruce Baxter of Providence, R.I., was married yesterday to Kevin McCormack Costello, a son of Ann Waterman Costello and John B. Costello of Hobe Sound, Fla. Bishop William J. McCormack, the great-uncle of the bridegroom who retired as the auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: 2006 BMW M5: Two Ways to Skin 500 Horsepower
description: A LOT of drivers, in a moment of urgent need or an episode of speed deprivation, have wished for a magic button to call up an extra 100 horsepower. The 2006 BMW M5 has one. Marked "power," it is right there on the console next to the gearshift.

title: Up Front
description: IN his review of James Risen's "State of War" (Page 11), Walter Isaacson writes that "one of the great questions of the post-9/11 era" is how to balance national security with our belief in civil liberty. Partly as a result of Risen's revelations, that question now bedevils the Bush administration. It's also one that Isaacson, who is the president and C.E.O. of the Aspen Institute, a public policy center, finds hard to answer. As a former managing editor of Time magazine and chairman of CNN, Isaacson is aware of how the press can and should function, but he is also the author of a biography of Henry Kissinger and the co-author, with Evan Thomas, of "The Wise Men," a study of six policy makers who helped guide the country through the early years of the cold war. "During my years as a journalist," he wrote in an e-mail message, "one of the most sensitive issues was balancing security concerns with our instinct to report everything we knew. Now, given the terrorist threat, it's even more difficult. I would be inclined these days to hold back information if it could help terrorists. Yet at a certain point, in a constitutional democracy, you need to debate policies that might lead to torture or unauthorized wiretapping. Journalists have an important role in this process, especially when there is little other oversight."

title: Competing Plans to Transform a Town
description: A DEVELOPER proposing to create what amounts to a new waterfront town within Sayreville on 400 acres of polluted land claimed last week that the project could eliminate the need for current residents to pay taxes.

description: The State Department of Transportation said Tuesday that it would soon place road signs on the state borders warning of the state law against using hand-held cellphones while driving.

description: BELFER--Ira. 1911--2001. He cherished the gift of life. Belfer Family

title: Doing It Right Matters
description: ONE vivid memory is my mother ironing. My father was a janitor and my mother was a maid. And she would take in laundry to iron. I remember being impressed at how she did this boring, tedious job. She would press every item with absolute attention to every single detail. How, I thought, could any human being do that repetitive task with so much attention to detail?

title: U.S.-Cuba trade gathering is disrupted by embargo
Where Lender Meets Borrower, Directly
description: ABOUT 10 years ago, a man named J. Richard Fredericks, who focused on commercial banking during a career in the securities business, made an interesting observation. "Banking is essential to a modern economy," he said. "But banks are not."

title: Seahawks Keep Rhythm to Up-Tempo Beat
description: DETROIT, Feb. 4 - When the Seattle Seahawks have the ball, they do not like wasting time.

title: A Devil Battles a Kidney Ailment
description: Devils defenseman David Hale had never heard of IgA nephropathy, a kidney ailment, until he received the diagnosis in 2001, after his freshman season at the University of North Dakota.

title: Fear for America's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: 1976: Innsbruck, Austria
description: Innsbruck took on its second Olympics in a dozen years after Colorado voters revolted against holding the 1976 Winter Games in Denver because of environmental and economic issues. No city is likely to land two Olympics within such a short time span again, but Innsbruck was able to reprise its role without much fuss.

title: Lipstick on Your Caller
description: IT would not have taken much for Chloe, a spurned wife played by Emily Mortimer in the movie "Match Point," to confirm that her husband, Chris, played by Jonathan Rhys Meyers, was cheating on her.

title: Precious Metal
description: Luge is the fastest event at the Winter Games, with riders reaching 90 miles per hour. At such speeds, an inch can separate first place from fifth, which is why luge is one of two Olympic sports timed to the thousandth of a second (short-track speedskating is the other). In the fall of 2003, USA Luge, seeking an edge, turned to scientists at the United States Steel Automotive Center in Troy, Mich., to improve upon the team's European-made steel runners (or "steels," as they are known).

title: The Show's 'Uneven,' but Not the Party
description: Two NBC mainstays A NBC Universal's chairman, Bob Wright, and the cast and creative team of "Saturday Night Live" A were honored at a dinner in New York last week held by the Museum of Television and Radio. Fittingly, many past and present network stars showed up, including Tom Brokaw, Conan O'Brien, Jimmy Fallon, Darrell Hammond and Tina Fey.

title: 100-M.P.G. Cars: It's a Start
description: Imagine if we could develop a passenger car that averaged more than 100 miles per gallon -- or, if used only for short trips, 1,000 miles per gallon. What if it could cost the equivalent of only 75 cents a gallon to operate and needed to go to a filling station only every other month?

title: MYSTERY SOLVED
description: Journalists at the Detroit auto show were a bit puzzled to run into Steven J. Harris, General Motors' popular former chief spokesman. Was Mr. Harris, who retired from G.M. in 2003, on a busman's holiday? Or was G.M., whose image has been battered, looking for advice?

title: Great Beer Ad Debate: Funny or Irresponsible
description: A popular beer commercial this football season depicts two young men wearing togas who break the arms off the Venus de Milo in ancient Greece to get the bottles of Bud Light in her hands.

title: Entertainments; General (Mis)Manager
description: You probably think you're smart, and maybe you are. You probably think you understand sports -- maybe not in their totality, but certainly more than most of your beer-guzzling friends. This is why you join rotisserie baseball leagues: you want to validate your brilliance, at least as it applies to predicting the quantitative potential of Ichiro.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Manhattan

title: An Accidental Sportsman in Hollywood
description: Great moments in sports rarely occur at a student council meeting. Nor does a game played around the world usually evolve from someone's idea of a joke. And yet, as documented in a new book, "Ultimate: The First Four Decades" (ultimatehistory.com), that's exactly what happened when Joel Silver introduced a motion to the council at Columbia High School in Maplewood, N.J., in 1968.

title: Star Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Barcelona: Hard Candy
description: Drawn by the smell of cooked sugar wafting down a quiet street in the Barri Gtic, Barcelonans loiter around a candy shop called Papabubble in the late afternoon. They hope to grab one of the still-hot scraps of homemade hard candy that Christopher King and Nigel Chouri freely hand out after the latest batch has been pulled and cut.

title: At Canaans Edge
description: February 28, 1965

title: Fighting Rages as U.S. and Afghans Hunt Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 4 - Fighting raged in the southern province of Helmand for a second night as Taliban fighters attacked two government offices, while Afghan and American forces continued to pursue a large group of militants into the mountains on Saturday, officials said.

title: From Russia, With Blood and Shape-Shifters
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. - IT'S 17 degrees below zero in his adopted hometown of Moscow, but on a January afternoon here, the sun is warm and the filmmaker Timur Bekmambetov is contemplating a margarita the bartender at the L'Ermitage hotel has prepared for him.

title: Knit Up the Loopholes
description: All it takes is a quick look at K Street in Washington these days to remember that money affects politics about the same way that salt corrodes a fine old automobile. The erosion of political separation between lobbyist and candidate is steady and real, and, to stretch this analogy near its limits, this is a great time for politicians -- especially those in Albany -- to start heading for the campaign car wash.

title: A Survivor Figures Out What to Do With Himself
description: BACK in October, Jeff Probst, the host of the "Survivor" series, considered quitting the show after this coming season. He implied that his problem was with his higher-ups at CBS. "I honestly have no idea what they think about me," he told Entertainment Weekly. "If they even know what I do, or if they look at me as disposable."

title: Property-Tax Appeals Can Be Filed Online
description: For years, owners of homes or commercial property in Nassau County who believed their property has been overassessed have been sending a blizzard of grievances to the assessor's office. Now they can do it electronically, free of charge, on the county's Web site, www.nassaucountyny.gov/arc/AROW.

title: Warning: Pregame Develops Bloating
description: The Super Bowl pregame show is no mere show but a symbol of the rampant gigantism endemic to the event. It was once a fairly ordinary presentation, a couple of hours long, back in a prehistoric era when TV executives had a sense of proportion and Terry Bradshaw wore a hair system.

title: Stable and Steady Has Won Race for Steelers
description: DETROIT, Feb. 4 - The National Football League was engaged in one of its periodic discussions about ways to increase marketing opportunities when a custom-designed team jersey arrived. Adorned with sponsorship decals, it resembled a Nascar driver's uniform. Dan Rooney, chairman of the Pittsburgh Steelers and one of the league's patriarchs, used the jersey to send a message to the league. His point?

title: School Scandals: A Scorecard
description: Correction Appended

title: Oil Graft Fuels the Insurgency, Iraq and U.S. Say
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 4 - Iraqi and American officials say they are seeing a troubling pattern of government corruption enabling the flow of oil money and other funds to the insurgency and threatening to undermine Iraq's struggling economy.

title: Along the Lanes, and Behind the Gates
description: Correction Appended

title: Sunset for Brooklyn-Queens Day
description: LAST week, a new teachers' contract, which affects New York City's 83,000 public school teachers, went into effect. We can be sure that three-fifths of them are feeling, if not joy, a distinct feeling of schadenfreude about one of the changes in the contract: teachers in Brooklyn and Queens will no longer be celebrating the exclusive and obscure holiday known as Brooklyn-Queens Day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARCUS, MARY P.
description: MARCUS--Mary P. 93. Wife of the late Dr. David Marcus, loving mother of Sue Marcus, Dr. Stephen H. Marcus and Judith Marcus. Cherished Grammy to Amy, Jennifer and Anthony. Beloved sister of Bertha P. Grodsky and Dr. Ada P. Rosen. Yiddish folk singer extraordinaire! Her wit, wisdom, smile and gentle nature gave everyone she touched great joy and comfort. Services Sunday 12:30 pm, Boulevard Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: A Toast to Her Second Century
description: Hastings-on-Hudson - IT was Christmas, either 1906 or 1907 -- she can't quite recall whether she was 2 at the time or 3 -- but Margaret Buchsteiner perfectly remembers the gift she received from her father, a dry goods merchant: a teddy bear, who "sat at a table with a cup of tea in his hand."

title: Save the Tappan Zee By Privatizing It
description: To the Editor:

title: Nursing Shortage? Or Smart Government?
description: To the Editor:

title: Germany's Chancellor Emphasizes Urgent Need for Action to Quash Nuclear Program in Iran
description: MUNICH, Feb. 4 - Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said Saturday that the world must act now to stop Iran from developing a nuclear bomb, evoking her nation's own history as a cautionary tale of what can happen when threats to peace remain unchecked.

title: Knit Up the Loopholes
description: All it takes is a quick look at K Street in Washington these days to remember that money affects politics about the same way that salt corrodes a fine old automobile. The erosion of political separation between lobbyist and candidate is steady and real, and, to stretch this analogy near its limits, this is a great time for politicians -- especially those in Albany -- to start heading for the campaign car wash.

title: Iran the Great Unifier? The Arab World Is Wary
description: TEHRAN - THE streets of Tehran are decorated with black banners and black flags. Children parade through the Martyr's Cemetery with headbands that read "Hussein" and stores sell metal chains that some people will use to beat themselves, all part of a period of public mourning that commemorates the killing of Imam Hussein, the Prophet Muhammad's grandson, during a battle 1,300 years ago in Karbala, Iraq. That military defeat solidified a split between what became the two main branches of Islam, the Shiite and the Sunni.

title: Pity the Scientist Who Discovers the Discovered
description: IN 1996, Rakesh Vohra, a professor at Northwestern University, and his colleague Dean Foster published "A Randomized Rule for Selecting Forecasts," a paper in the journal Operations Research. It illustrated how a random investor could outperform a group of professional stock pickers simply by following a "buy and hold" investment strategy.

title: A Shoulder to Cry on (Highlights Included)
description: LOS ANGELES - USHERED into one of the small rooms at B2V, a salon in West Hollywood favored by blond celebrities, Jennifer Murphy, a contestant on "The Apprentice" last season, had some exciting news to share.

title: Tolerating Death in the Mines
description: Federal safety officials, faced with the death of two more West Virginia miners, are asking the coal industry to "stand down for safety" tomorrow to check the nation's mines for lethal working conditions. This smacks of public relations more than worker protection. The safety agency, notorious for its political appointees from the coal industry, is also suddenly finding more inspectors for West Virginia, which has suffered 16 miner deaths recently.

title: In Geneva, a Cable Car Ride, a Chocolatier Tour: Delights at Any Age
description: FAMILIES visiting Geneva in the winter usually find themselves there for one of two reasons: They are en route to a ski vacation or a parent has business to do.

title: On 'Evolutionism'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Whirlwinds of Revolt
description: AT CANAAN'S EDGE

title: The Long Road Back
description: Zach Randolph was worried. It was March 2005, and the 24-year-old Portland Trail Blazers forward had decided to undergo surgery to repair cartilage in his right knee, injured two months earlier. The procedure, called microfracture surgery, is daunting: an orthopedist removes loose cartilage and drills holes in the end of the femur. These "microfractures" bleed and clot, leading to the formation of new cartilage. The list of players who have had the surgery and struggled to return to peak level reads like an all-star team from the late 90's: Penny Hardaway, Jamal Mashburn, Allan Houston, Chris Webber. "You hear stories of guys not coming back, or coming back less strong," Randolph says. "This was my first surgery, and everything I was hearing about it was bad." On March 31, he went under the knife. Then the hard work began. Here's how Randolph got his knee back.

title: Basil V. Worgul, 58, Biologist at Columbia, Dies
description: Basil V. Worgul, a biologist at Columbia University who studied radiation's harmful effects on the eye, particularly as a cause of cataracts, and helped lead a long-term international study of thousands of workers exposed to radiation in the Chernobyl disaster in 1986, died on Jan. 19 at his home in Edgewater, N.J. He was 58.

title: When Fame and Talent Collide
description: Since every sports fan, consciously or not, is a fan of myth, it may be useful, before considering the question mark appended to the figure of Bode Miller, to bring to mind the example of a free-spirited boy named Icarus. Icarus was given wings of feathers and wax -- high-tech, aerodynamic equipment in its day -- with which to flee the confines of his existence. His flight coach warned him to avoid hovering too low, lest he wipe out on a wave, or soaring too high, lest he flame out. But Icarus was a fiend for novelty and daring. Flying felt good. It felt free. Icarus caught tremendous air, as the saying goes, and launched himself through the sky. He could sense the temperature rising. It must, he thought, be the heat of the moment, that special flush that animates adventure seekers. But it was more than that. It was the sun. Soon, Icarus' gear was toast. He fell. He streaked across the horizon, and disappeared into the sea with a splash. Some observers were saddened by the spectacle. Others found the humbling of Icarus to be a case of just deserts.

title: Iraqi Security Forces Prepare for Shiite Holy Day
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 5 A Five Iraqis were killed in scattered violence across Iraq today, as thousands of Iraqi soldiers and police officers began to move into place to protect Shiite pilgrims for a religious holiday this week.

title: Belfour Bails Out Toronto in Victory Against Devils
description: TORONTO, Feb. 4 - As far as excuses for early-game jitters go, this one was pretty solid.

title: CALENDAR
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Westchester and Putnam Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance by e-mail, to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail, to Westchester Cultural Calendar, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036-3959.

title: With Marquand Manuel
description: Seahawks safety Marquand Manuel became a starter last October when Ken Hamlin was beaten and seriously injured outside a Seattle nightclub. Manuel has been superb, intercepting a pass in the National Football Conference championship game, and making a career-high 67 tackles during the regular season. Manuel also leads the Seahawks in siblings; he is the ninth oldest of 18 children.

title: Style; Presumed Innocent
description: Do not be taken in by all the ruffles and eyelet. Spring's pretty little dresses are not as nave as they appear.

title: 2006 Corvette Z06: A 500-Horsepower Time Machine
description: THE turnpike exit was not the one I had planned to take, but I found myself at the bottom of the off ramp anyway, waving the E-ZPass tag at the toll booth and merging onto Route 18. Overruling the plan to continue farther south, a Corvette and my subconscious conspired to drop me into a different, but still familiar, landscape.

title: Priest in Turkey is killed
Reading Lists That Are as Vague as Possible
description: AT the Village Bookstore in Pleasantville, the owner, Roy Solomon, has decided to keep track of the store's frequent-buyer program by stamping cards he gives out, rather than by using a computer database. That is because all the software packages he looked at would also automatically keep track of his customers' purchase histories.

title: China's art collectors not ready for buying spree in West
A Cuban Revolution, Only It's in New Jersey
description: Call it the caf con leche revolution.

title: Here a Museum, There a Museum
description: IT took about 100 years, but last week the Smithsonian Institution moved ahead with its National Museum of African-American History and Culture, selecting a site on the National Mall near the Washington Monument.

title: Do Robots Dream of Electric Lovborgs?
description: ISAAC ASIMOV'S First Law of Robotics, as any science fiction fan can tell you, states, "A robot may not injure a human being." Perhaps Hans, a gleaming, barrel-chested automaton, hasn't read Asimov. At a recent rehearsal for Les Freres Corbusier's coming play "Heddatron," he defies his radio-controlled commands and zips downstage, thwacking notebooks and coffee cups, as well as the director Alex Timbers and the playwright Elizabeth Meriwether.

title: A Mansion With a History (Some of It True)
description: BESIDE the lead-paned window in the petite salon, just past the entry foyer and the carved wooden staircase of the Chteau des Thons in Upper Brookville, there is a writing desk. The desk, surrounded by oak-paneled walls, a stone fireplace and soaring 20-foot ceilings, seems to wait for someone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PIGNONE, SISTER JEAN M., F.M.M.
description: PIGNONE--Sister Jean M., F.M.M. The administration, trustees and staff of St. Francis Hospital, The Heart Center in Roslyn, New York, mourn the passing of Sister Jean M. Pignone of the Franciscan Missionaries of Mary. Sister Jean served St. Francis Hospital in a number of different capacities for over 50 years and was a living and spiritual bridge from the hospital's early days as a summer camp for children to its position today as one of the nation's leading heart centers. Sister Jean was a much beloved member of the St. Francis family. She began her service in 1941 as one of 55 nuns caring for 200 underprivileged children with rheumatic heart disease who lived at the St. Francis Sanatorium. In addition to cooking, cleaning, and providing nursing care, her work included traveling to local farms and asking for contributions of produce to help feed the children. Later, when the institution opened its doors to adult patients and became St. Francis Hospital, Sister Jean directed the volunteers at the information desk and was always a welcoming and cheering presence. Throughout her service, Sister Jean's steadfast commitment to philanthropy became legendary. We will be forever grateful to Sister Jean for her selfless dedication to St. Francis Hospital and her love for all the members of our family. We will cherish her legacy and always be inspired by her example. We extend our deepest sympathies to Sister Jean's family and to the many friends who were touched by her devoted, caring and generous spirit.

title: U.S. firm blamed for polluting sea
Chardonnay, Two Ways
description: TWO newly released chardonnays show the range of chardonnay styles emerging in the young region.

title: The Polka King Rolls Out the Barrel for the 19th Time
description: WITH one hand, Jimmy Sturr, the polka king, reached for his pen. With the other, he picked up a glossy promotional flier featuring his brightly smiling head shot and the words "FOURTEEN TIME GRAMMY AWARD WINNER."

title: Roundup: Woods wins Dubai after shot sinks Els
Islam on the Outskirts of the Welfare State
description: In few places on earth is the air fresher than in a Swedish housing project. Take Bergsjon, which sits five miles from the center of Sweden's second-largest city, the stately Dutch-built port of Gothenburg. Home to a Volvo plant and some of the world's biggest shipyards, Gothenburg was long an industrial powerhouse. Bergsjon was built between 1967 and 1972 to reward the workers who made it that. Bergsjon resembles the places Swedes love to retreat to in midsummer -- quiet, pristine, speckled with lakes and smelling of evergreen trees -- but it is only a short tram ride away from the city's giant SKF ball-bearing plant. The center has no cars. Its 14,500 people live in apartments set within a lasso-shaped ring road, on grassy hills that climb toward the country's rustic uplands. As Asa Svensson, a municipal coordinator for the development, notes, "It was planned for people who like to be in the country."

title: Equipment; Look, Ma: No Tape!
description: It's hard to imagine hitting moguls with a video camera duct-taped to your helmet, but thanks to a paradigm shift in camcorders, it's now possible. Tape -- miniDV, Hi8 or otherwise -- is going the way of the steam engine, and with no tape, things get really small. You might not understand the tiny hard drives or delicate inner workings of the latest camcorders, but you should have no problem with the duct tape.

title: BNP Paribas bids for Italian bank
The Pleasures of the Text
description: I am aghast! I read your essay and realized that in some places written language as I know it no longer exists. From what I see, the messages are written in hieroglyphics. Atmy ancient age, there is no way I could decode what is written, nor learn how to do it. I remember the old days when I learned pigLatin, thinking I was speaking in code.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARROW, MARILYN
description: BARROW--Marilyn. On Fridday, February 3, 2006, after a long battle with Alzheimer's, of Bergen County, NJ. Devoted mother of Nancy Barrow (Michael Moroch), Tami Richman (Steven) and Neal Barrow. Sister of Ellie Hessl. Cherished grandmother of Leah Richman, Seth and Scott Moroch. Services 2 pm, today at Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Paramus, NJ.

title: Trading Season Focuses on Future And Present Fixes
description: By the time Indiana traded Ron Artest to Sacramento for Peja Stojakovic last month, the anticipated move had, well, lost its punch.

title: Correction
description: An article on Jan. 15 about Santa Fe and the minimum wage misstated the percentage of teenagers among workers in the country who make less than $7.25 an hour. It is 28 percent, not 35. The article also referred imprecisely to the origin of the Santa Fe ordinance that increased the minimum wage for city workers. Paul Sonn was an adviser to the people who drafted it and the amendment that extended the law to some private businesses, including Jerilou Hammett, a local resident, and Matthew Ortiz, a City Council member; Sonn did not write it.

title: Health Care Begins at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Declare War on Diabetes
description: The recent four-part series in The Times offered grim insights into the incurable disease diabetes. Ignore it, and it can lead to heart disease, strokes, amputations and shortened lives. It is the leading cause of blindness. Most of those who have diabetes have Type 2, in which obesity and poverty are key contributors, especially among blacks and Hispanics, who are disproportionately stricken. It is not uncommon in poor and minority communities, the worst hit, to see amputees in wheelchairs.

title: Double Fantasy
description: Fantasy E-Sports Leagues

title: When a Building Goes Condo
description: Does a Rent-Regulated Tenant Have the Right to Remain?

title: Soccer: Joys and sorrows felt beyond Africa
Above It All in Colorado
description: Creede, Colo. - MAYBE it's growing up under a bowl of bluebird-colored sky, or among groves of quaking aspens, or surrounded by snow that falls and falls and never turns black. Maybe it's learning to ski double black diamond slopes at the age of 3, or the possibility inherent in 53 peaks that rise 14,000 feet above sea level. Maybe it's because the median household income in Colorado is well above the national median, and the people per square mile average is well below it, but Coloradans consistently tend toward the optimistic, rarely confuse cynicism with intelligence and are willing to articulate their hopes for the future without fear.

title: $1.6 billion settlement by AIG is expected this week
NEW YORK STORY
description: Richard D. Parsons, chairman and C.E.O. of Time Warner, took a break from combat with the financier Carl C. Icahn last week to attend a celebration for the 50th anniversary of the Public Theater in New York. Time Warner was the major corporate sponsor of a performance at City Center and the only sponsor of a party at Time Warner's new headquarters. Mr. Parsons said the company supports the Public Theater because it is "probably the most innovative engine in New York for new writers, new composers."

title: Pan-Asian Classics, Deftly Rendered
description: BRONXVILLE - THE soups at Haiku, a pan-Asian bistro that opened here a year and a half ago, are a far cry from the thick soups -- often filled with monosodium glutamate -- offered at the ubiquitous Asian restaurants in the county.

title: 2 Men Are Stabbed, One Fatally, in Fight in Brooklyn Barbershop
description: One man was fatally stabbed and another injured late on Friday during a knife fight among card players in the back of a Brooklyn barbershop, the police and area residents said.

title: Go for Two?
description: If a National Football League executive wanted to devise a perfect ending to the Super Bowl, it would look like the finale of the Week 10 shootout between the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Washington Redskins. The Buccaneers scored in the final minute and needed only to kick the extra point to tie the game and send it into overtime. But when an offside penalty negated a blocked kick and nudged his team to the 1-yard line from the 2, head coach Jon Gruden went for the 2-point conversion, a rare move under normal circumstances and almost unheard of late in a game. (Only once before had an N.F.L. game been won by a last-minute 2-point conversion.) GrudenAs decision was successful A his team won, 36-35 A and significant for both teams. It kept the Bucs in playoff contention and sent the ASkins into a tailspin: they lost two more games and had to win their last five to make the playoffs (where they exacted revenge on the Bucs in the first round). Some participants and observers break down the play:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHACHTER, JUDY
description: SCHACHTER--Judy. On February 3, 2006. Beloved wife of Harvey. Devoted mother of Karyn Rubin and Lisa Gretah. Adored grandmother of Dylan and Jakob. Services today, 1 P.M. at "Gutterman's", 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Where the Shadows Have Shadows
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq - ON a Baghdad street last month, one of the darker visions of Iraq's future suddenly materialized.

title: Nuclear Dispute Arouses Patriotism Among Iranians
description: ISFAHAN, Iran, Feb. 4 - Iran's nuclear program will not help Ali Shafiei pay his bills, or Muhammad Soheili Pour sell appliances or Yussefi Janali sell rugs, but they all said that they support Iran's right to nuclear energy and do not much care how other nations of the world react.

title: Ignore the Ups and Downs at Your Peril
description: FOR the last three years, investors have benefited from two concurrent trends: rising stock prices and rapidly declining market volatility. But while investors have focused on the prices, the volatility -- or lack thereof -- has gone somewhat unnoticed.

title: 1984: Sarajevo
description: Memories of the four-year civil war that gutted much of the city in the early and mid-90's are still fresh, and many of them are intertwined with the facilities used in 1984 in the first Winter Games in a Communist country.

title: How Do You Say Shank in Mandarin?
description: "Hao qiu!" your caddie is apt to murmur sweetly if you manage an even halfway decent drive after teeing off in China. Good shot! If you hit a "bu hao" -- a stinker -- there will be a moment of embarrassed silence.

title: Letters
description: The Animated Self

title: VIEWS OF CAMBODIA
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from Cambodia ourselves, we concur with Matt Gross's article "Why Is Everyone Going to Cambodia?" (Jan. 22) that despite their hardships, the Cambodians are "some of the sweetest people you'll ever meet." They are also some of the most resilient and hopeful people on earth, despite living through politically dangerous times.

title: ON THE MARKET
description: Park Slope Town House $3,500,000

title: Remaking the Epic of America
description: On this, our holiest day of the year, when Americans gather, overeat and enjoy the outpourings of our greatest advertising agencies, it is fitting to reflect upon the core myth that animates our nation. No, I don't mean the western, which is so 19th century. I mean the sports movie, the epic that defines contemporary America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   APPLETON, JOHN JOHNSTON
description: APPLETON--John Johnston. 81, on January 30, at home in NYC. Editor, writer, friend of all who crossed his path. Survived by his wife of 43 years, Myra; a brother, William W.; a sister, Tina Bishop; various nephews, nieces, cousins and godchildren. A memorial service to be announced.

title: 1998: Nagano, Japan
description: Ringed by the Japan Alps in the central part of the country, Nagano was an unknown quantity to much of the world before it staged Japan's second winter Olympic Games. It is not, however, difficult to find. The high-speed train from Tokyo gets there in a little more than an hour; the regular train, about four hours. Direct air service is also available from Osaka and Japan's better-known winter sports destination of Sapporo, site of the 1972 Games.

title: Mixing Religion With Business
description: DANIEL P. BUTTAFUOCO, a personal injury lawyer in Woodbury, often provides his clients with more than legal advice. Mr. Buttafuoco, an elder in the Bethpage Assembly of God and a seminary student as well, also offers pastoral care.

title: The March of the Scary Amazons
description: WHAT if women ruled the world? There would be no more war, no looming energy crisis, and those knotty environmental problems would ease.

title: Nothing but Party Girls, Vapid or Hard to Get
description: Pink

title: Pottery Profits
description: In my city high school specializing in the arts, some people leave amazingly good work behind after completing ceramics projects. My teacher allows us students to take any of these pieces we want and throws out the rest. I think this is a waste. I would like to try to sell some of it on eBay. The problem: I cannot find the names of the student potters to give them a percentage. Is my plan ethical?

title: Don't Tread on Steelers' Receivers
description: DETROIT, Feb. 4 - They have been overshadowed by a running game as ingrained in Pittsburgh's image as steel mills.

title: On Long Island, Catholic Church's Shift Draws Critics
description: Among American Catholics raised in the years after the Second Vatican Council of 1962-65, church teaching has usually mixed orthodoxy with contemporary notions about the value of dialogue, self-exploration and the full-fledged participation of women in society. Whether by coincidence or not, theirs has been the generation of Catholics that produced the first widespread alarm about the sexual abuse of children by priests, a problem said by some to date back many generations.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Feb. 5 - Feb. 11; CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: The world of visiting orchestras is feeling small these days. SIR SIMON RATTLE, having just left Carnegie Hall after a four-night stand with the Berlin Philharmonic, returns on Tuesday with the PHILADELPHIA ORCHESTRA (and the Czech mezzo-soprano MAGDALENA KOZENA) to perform Bruckner, Mussorgsky and Lutoslawski (8 p.m., (212) 247-7800; $25 to $99). And lest we forget the scope of Berlin's musical life, DANIEL BARENBOIM, RADU LUPU and the STAATSKAPELLE BERLIN bring two all-Mozart programs to Carnegie starting Saturday (8 p.m., $38 to $130) and concluding next Sunday. The city's many other orchestras just may be waiting in the wings.

title: John L. Behler, 62, Dies; Influential Voice for Saving Reptiles
description: John L. Behler, a naturalist and curator of herpetology at the Bronx Zoo who became an influential and international voice for saving endangered turtles, snakes and other reptiles, died on Jan. 31 at his home in Amawalk, N.Y. He was 62.

title: An AIDS Center In East Harlem

title: Curtain Rises on a Co-op Board
description: Charles Grodin looks a bit nervous. It's almost as if the actor, who lives in Connecticut, were about to go before the board of a high-priced East Side co-op. Almost.

title: Hurricanes Get Jump on Trading Deadline
description: The upstart Carolina Hurricanes made the first bold splash among the Stanley Cup contenders Monday by trading for Doug Weight, a playmaking center. The Hurricanes acquired Weight and left wing Erkki Rajamaki from St. Louis for forward Jesse Boulerice, center Mike Zigomanis, the rights to forward Magnus Kahnberg, first- and fourth-round draft picks this year and a fourth-round pick in 2007.

title: At Grand Central, Your Life Is in Their Hands
description: SAL OLIVA had a hunch that the woman he knew as Cha would make a great firefighter, even though, at 5-foot-1, she didn't look the part.

title: 10 Characters, 2 Actors
description: LONG BRANCH - THE challenge facing any play built on a gimmick is that it have enough substance to sustain it once the novelty of the conceit wears thin. For all of its spirited desire to entertain, "Tour de Farce," currently at New Jersey Repertory Company here, never really faces that test; the conceit that the authors, Philip LaZebnik and Kingsley Day, trade upon betrays them before that point.

title: Carson Makes Hall at Last
description: DETROIT, Feb. 4  When the call Harry Carson wanted finally arrived, his phone went unanswered and his voice mailbox was full, presumably with a mix of good wishes and heartfelt congratulations.

title: Martha Gilbane and Jeffrey Busconi
description: Martha Gilbane, the daughter of Mary Gilbane and Thomas Freeman Gilbane Jr. of Providence, R.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Jeffrey Leigh Busconi, a son of Elizabeth and Ronald G. Busconi of Medfield, Mass. The Rev. Robert J. Randall, a Roman Catholic priest performed the ceremony at St. Edward Church in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURRAY, PHYLLIS
description: MURRAY--Phyllis. Of Rockville Centre, NY, on February 3, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Raymond P. Loving mother of Timothy and Leslie. Devoted grandmother of David and Joanna. Sister of Mickey Ferretti. Friends may call Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 pm, at the Thomas A. Glynn & Son Funeral Home, 20 Lincoln Ave., Rockville Centre. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10 am, at St. Agnes Cathedral. In lieu of flowers donations to American Lung Association appreciated.

title: $2 Billion Later
description: MONROE MILSTEIN was working with his father in the wholesale women's coat business in 1972 when he became interested in a little deal in Burlington, a tired-looking town about a 100-mile drive from his home in Long Beach, N.Y., on Long Island.

title: Attorney General's Credibility May Be at Stake at Spy Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 - A year ago, Alberto R. Gonzales sat before the Senate Judiciary Committee as the Bush administration's nominee for attorney general and a potential candidate for the Supreme Court. He will return on Monday in dramatically different circumstances, testifying as the chief legal defender of a domestic eavesdropping operation that has touched off a stormy debate over its legality.

title: An Electronic System For Medical Records
description: A group of legislators and health care professionals announced a plan Monday for a statewide electronic filing system for medical records. Under the plan, doctors and other heath care personnel would be able to access the medical records of state residents at any time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADAMS, MARK
description: ADAMS--Mark. Prominent San Francisco artist, died peacefully January 24, 2006. Born in Fort Plain, New York, 1925, son of Earl and Edith Wohlgemuth Adams, brother of Lucile Adams Smithe. Survived by wife of 52 years, Beth Van Hoesen; nieces Judy Bailey and husband Vernon, Davenport, New York, and Barbara Nalli and husband Albert, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, and their families; Van Hoesen family; and devoted caregiver and friend Mary N. Connors. Attended School of Fine Arts at Syracuse University, studied at Columbia University and with Hans Hofmann in New York and Jean Lurcat in France. Mark excelled in a variety of media and his works are in prominent collections. His many commissions include stained glass windows for Grace Cathedral, Temple Emanu-El, and St. Thomas More Catholic Church, San Francisco, and others. In 1993 he created a watercolor to benefit the Metropolitan Opera Guild of New York, which was also published as a lithograph. His tapestries are in the De Young Museum, San Francisco International Airport, and many other collections. Mark was a charming and humble man with great strength, wit and integrity. He loved life and shared that love through his artistic talents and accomplishments. He was greatly loved by all who knew him. Donations may be made to Carmelite Monastery, 27601 Hwy 1, Carmel, CA. 93923.

title: Lori Bandazian and Louis Montorio
description: Lori Bandazian, a film executive, and Louis Montorio, a record executive, were married last evening in New York. The Rev. Mardiros Chevian, an Armenian priest, performed the ceremony at the St. Vartan Armenian Cathedral.

title: Bob Costas's Personality Problem
description: For as long as he has been delivered into our living rooms, Bob Costas has seemed too perfect for sports television. While Dick Stockton and Hubie Brown look like they've just wandered in from the dog track, Costas, even at age 53, maintains his boyish charms. He has an uncreased face and a Little Jimmy smile; you're not sure if he's planning to interview Bud Selig or just sit on his knee. What keeps Costas's perfection from being grating -- almost -- is the ironic distance he maintains from his persona. As Costas once said, in a joking self-assessment to The New York Times: "He's bright, but not pretentiously intelligent. He's assertive, and yet charmingly low-key." Over the last several years, Costas-watchers have added this: he's a sportscaster, but he's also an intellectual.

title: Somewhere, an Austrian Is Trembling
description: Daron Rahlves

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAZAR, NORMAN K.
description: LAZAR--Norman K. On February 2, 2006. He enjoyed a successful and fulfilling life and will be dearly missed by his beloved wife of 58 years, Marilyn, and children Ronald (Gloria), Andrew (Carol) and Douglas, and his grandchildren Lori (Eric), Michael, Jason and Ethan. A sweet, gentle and extraordinary giving man who touched the lives of all who knew him. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Sylvester Cancer Center, 1475 NW 12th Avenue, Miami, FL. 33136.
