description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis: On Iran, West sees race against time
THE WEEK AHEAD: Feb. 5 - Feb. 11; FILM
description: In the summer of 1973, Elaine May almost met her Waterloo. After years of planning, she began shooting one of the unsung films of that cinematically vaunted decade, "MIKEY AND NICKY," the story of two smalltime hoods -- Peter Falk as the slow-to-burn Mikey, John Cassavetes as his lifelong friend Nicky -- who, over the course of one bleary-eyed night revisit old hurts and reconfigure the balance of power between them. In his recently published biography of Cassavetes, "ACCIDENTAL GENIUS" (Miramax Books), the critic Marshall Fine lays out the story behind the film, including Cassavetes's hands-on contribution and Ms. May's astonishing ability to burn through celluloid. Mr. Fine notes that Ms. May shot more than twice as much film as it took to get "Gone With the Wind" in the can, but her struggles to get her modestly scaled wonderment into the world were worth every frame, dollar and drop of blood. "Mikey and Nicky" shows tonight at the Anthology Film Archives, 32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village, (212) 505-5181, and again later this month during a tribute to the filmmaker that is part of the "FILM COMMENTS SELECTS" series at the Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, (212) 875-5600.

title: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 4 - Every day the line snakes down a spartan corridor on the eighth floor of City Hall here, as hundreds of people clutch a piece of paper inscribed with a fateful percentage that could force them to abandon their home.

title: Carnegie Hall 4 Vry Lo Rnt
description: THE posters outside Carnegie Hall one night last month trumpeted appearances by the magnificent Berlin Philharmonic and its star-powered music director, Simon Rattle. But inside the storied hall, humbler pie was being served: the Houston Symphony Orchestra and its unaffected Austrian conductor, Hans Graf.

description: Most of us want a jacket to work out in -- not one that announces, in safety-cone colors, that we just worked out. The latest high-performance shells are subtly styled and easy to toss over a sweatshirt -- but substantial enough to stand on their own.

description: An article on Jan. 22 about tenants' problems in New York City misstated the neighborhood of the building at 2201 Amsterdam Avenue, at 169th Street. It is in Washington Heights, not Harlem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FLYNN, LORETTA C., ESQ. (NEE CORCORAN)
description: FLYNN--Loretta C., Esq. (nee Corcoran). Of East Northport, NY, on Febraury 1, 2006 in her 83rd year. Graduate of the College of New Rochelle (1942), Fordham Graduate School of Arts and Sciences (1943) and Fordham Law (1951). Served as an officer and director of Suffolk AHRC. Active in CNR Alumni Association. Loving wife of the late Robert Emmet. Dearly beloved mother of Christopher, Robert (Fidelia), Joseph, James (Dara), Jeremiah and Dr. Regina (Daniel) Olasin. Cherished grandmother of Sean, Catherine, Olivia and Rachel. Dear sister of Margaret Mary Quinn. Reposing Nolan & Taylor-Howe Funeral Home, 5 Laurel Ave, Northport, NY 11768. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 9:45 AM at St. Anthony of Padua R.C. Church, East Northport, NY. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. Donations to AHRC, 2900 Veterans Memorial Highway, Bohemia, New York 11716, in her memory, appreciated. Visiting Hours Sunday 2-5 & 7-9 PM.

title: Providing Insurance for Board Members
description: IT would be a rare and perhaps foolish person who would serve on a co-op or condo board that wasn't protected by a directors and officers (D & O) insurance policy. But even savvy board members, insurance experts say, may be unaware of significant variations in coverage.

title: My Father's Abortion War
description: I am a nurse midwife (Eyal Press, Jan. 22). I have delivered babies for 21 years. I have never performed an abortion but also never wavered in my belief that every child should be "wanted and precious" and that sometimes the painful realities of life make a woman wisely choose a termination of pregnancy over an unwanted and unplanned pregnancy. Until the pro-life people agree to support for 18 years the children who are unplanned and unwanted, the abortion option is a necessary moral choice in the messy quagmire of real life. Dr. Press, whose quiet courage is so eloquently depicted in his son's essay, is a heroic figure to every pro-choice woman and midwife. I salute him.

title: New Bar Cars Coming For the Ride Home
description: Bar cars will be among the fleet of rail cars that the state plans to buy with New York, an official with the State Department of Transportation has said.

title: Review This Book . . . Please!
description: Galleys are the advance copies of a book sent to editors and reviewers several months before the book's publication. Sometimes these advance reading copies are accompanied by letters from publishers or editors making an extra effort to sell what they consider a significant book. Recently, such letters have become more common, and the letters themselves more elaborate and complex, even literary. What follows are various examples of the types of notes a book editor or critic might come across in the course of opening the morning's mail.

title: Allstate's New Policy: None for Homeowners
description: HOMEOWNERS still have options, but as of Jan. 1, those looking to buy homeowner insurance in Westchester, New York City or Long Island should scratch Allstate off their lists.

description: To the Editor:

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Feb. 5 - Feb. 11; POP/JAZZ
description: LAS RUBIAS DEL NORTE are two classically trained North American singers, Allyssa Lamb and Emily Hurst, who have been exploring an antique but wide repertory of New World music, heavy on the pan-Latin side; the list of genres includes cumbia, cha-cha, ranchera, Peruvian vals criollo, and cowboy songs from the Sons of the Pioneers songbook. Some of it has that dreaded Brooklyn tinge -- precious worldliness -- but the two are going about it carefully, and backing it up with good local musicians. Their new album is "PANAMERICANA" (Barbs Records), and the group celebrates with a handful of Saturday-night performances this month at Barbs, its Park Slope headquarters. They will play this Saturday and again on Feb. 18. 376 Ninth Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-9177; $10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENE, ELIZABETH I.
description: GREENE--Elizabeth I. City & Country School's Board of Trustees and community mourn the loss of our devoted alumna and Trustee, Elizabeth Ivory Greene. We will miss her youthful spirit, innovative thinking and deep commitment to City & Country. Stuart Gold, Chair Kate Turley, Principal

title: This Soul Train Stops in Newark, Felix Hernandez Conductor
description: NEWARK - IF Felix Hernandez had only been born a couple of decades earlier, he might have entered the pantheon of transcendent disc jockeys like Dewey Phillips in Memphis and Murray the K in New York.

title: WHY WE TRAVEL: LISBON
description: AT THE SO JORGE CASTLE, NOVEMBER 26, 2005 -- Charles Barratt, 25, currently moving from Los Angeles to San Francisco. "Part of the reason my girlfriend and I were in Europe was that we were moving on to different careers in a different city. This trip was a reset button on our lives. Lisbon is like San Francisco: the red bridge, the cable cars, very hilly, rains off and on all the time -- it reminded me so much of San Francisco that I was wondering what awaited me there. After the photo was taken, there was the most beautiful rainbow, as if someone had painted it in the sky. We thought 'Wow, we better soak it in, we're not going to see another rainbow like this in our lives.' But then there was another rainbow like that, every day we were in Lisbon."

title: Religion's Role
description: To the Editor:

description: Correction Appended

title: The Animal Self
description: What a great article (Charles Siebert, Jan. 22)! We have come a long way since Jane Goodall was ridiculed for giving names to the chimpanzees she lived with and observed. It is affirming to know that scientists are learning about animals that are seemingly "removed" from ourselves and finding unexpected things like "personalities." Affirming because there are still so many wondrous things about others waiting for us to understand. And perhaps if we can connect to animals, we will respect their rights to live shy or temperamental or celibate lives, in their own ways, in their own habitats. Just like us.

title: Dangerous When Wet
description: The beauty industry has a new enemy, and it's lurking in your tap.

title: What Sets Leaders Apart From the Pack
description: LEADERSHIP is scary.

title: Juli Simon Thomas and Russel Philip
description: Elisabeth Julia Simon Thomas, a daughter of Betty Simon Thomas and Maarten Simon Thomas of Houston, was married yesterday to Russel Philip, a son of Carollyn Philip and John Philip of Manhattan. Judge Sidney H. Stein of the Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Thais hold big protest over deals by Thaksin
Looking for the Lie
description: Liars always look to the left, several friends say; liars always cover their mouths, says a man sitting next to me on a plane. Beliefs about how lying looks are plentiful and often contradictory: depending on whom you choose to believe, liars can be detected because they fidget a lot, hold very still, cross their legs, cross their arms, look up, look down, make eye contact or fail to make eye contact. Freud thought anyone could spot deception by paying close enough attention, since the liar, he wrote, "chatters with his finger-tips; betrayal oozes out of him at every pore." Nietzsche wrote that "the mouth may lie, but the face it makes nonetheless tells the truth."

title: Ghost Writers
description: THAT gurgling sound is the plot of Carol Goodman's suspense novel, THE GHOST ORCHID (Ballantine, $24.95), choking on literary symbols and forced allusions to classical myths, pagan rituals and American Indian legends. But the ghost story buried under all these layers of reference is worth excavating -- if only for its voluptuous views of the haunted garden, built on an elaborate system of underground waterworks, that's the book's most seductive feature.

title: A Little Flabby Around the Eyeballs
description: Brett Basanez, a senior at Northwestern University, swears by a workout routine that, for a star quarterback, is pretty unathletic. Twice a week, he puts on 3-D glasses, settles down in front of a computer and punches at the keyboard to move arrows and dots across the screen. These half-hour sessions of souped-up Pac-Man are meant to improve Basanez's ability to scan an entire football field and zero in on a target -- crucial skills if you hope to find a receiver before a linebacker finds you.

description: FELDMAN -- Miriam Ruth. Died February 2, 2006, at her home in Roslyn, NY. Beloved mother of Nancy and Frank. Services will be held Sunday, 3 PM at "Riverside-Nassau North Chapels," 55 N. Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Donations in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Staff of life, stuff of jokes

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ASH, DAVID H.
description: ASH--David H. July 4, 1922-January 24, 2006. David passed with his loved ones at his side. Born in E. Norwalk, Conn., David was preceded in death by parents Bessi and Harry, brothers Jacob and Barney, and sisters Miriam, Nedi and Ruth. His children Jodi, Marc and Robin, his grandson Morgan, and a loving extended family survive him. David was a graduate of Stamford High, Class of 1940. After graduation he served as an officer and fighter pilot in the United States Air Force. His passion for all things cars, especially racecars, led him to a highly accomplished career in the automotive world. He was a regular and distinguished competitor at Sebring, America's premier race. Between 1952 and 1957, David earned the title of "Mr. MG" as the only driver to start and finish five twelve-hour-long endurance races at Sebring in five tries. He also set numerous "land speed" records on the Bonneville Salt Flats in 1957. David later pursued a career in automotive journalism. His pieces appeared in "The New York Times," "Argosy Magazine" and "Esquire Magazine." He also served as publisher and editor of "Sports Car Magazine," and from 1966-1977 authored and published "Automobile Almanac." An avid sports fan, he "Loved the Yankees, and never, ever gave up on the NY Giants." His most cherished times were spent with his children on Fire Island, fishing, swimming and glassing. Family and his many friends will miss his unending quest for knowledge, enthusiasm, energy, and charm. Memorial services are planned for Sunday, February 12th. Family and friends may contact 617.308.6441.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLEMAN, HENRY S.
description: COLEMAN--Henry S. The Senior Society of Nacoms honors Henry S Coleman for his service to Columbia and his 60 years with the Society. Harry's words and memory will always inspire us. The Advisory Committee

title: Giving a Tired House a Tower
description: Mattituck, N.Y. - ARCHITECTS are not known for their modesty, so it was not entirely surprising when Duo Dickinson leapt out of his little red car, took one look at the rather forlorn-looking (but waterfront) weekend house recently for sale here and pronounced he could "turn this into a showplace -- it's a piece of cake."

title: Cycling: Biker waits for a dream ruling
Lurking in the Pines: Ghosts
description: Barbara Solem-Stull's ghost towns aren't the classic variety found out West. There's nary a vulture or bleached steer skull to be found.

title: Post Office Mystery: Who Left the Medals?
description: TWO weeks after two Purple Hearts and a Bronze Star were found in a Cos Cob mailbox, there has been little progress in the search for the owner. The medals are on display at the Cos Cob Post Office, which has received calls from people claiming that the medals belonged to them, but none could prove ownership.

title: Greener Pastures
description: Hauppauge - LAST Tuesday's State of the Union message offered intriguing rhetoric but little substance on how to actually reduce our addiction to foreign oil. Long Island should position itself to fill this void in our national and economic security concerns. We can do it, because we have in the past.

title: Have Commodities Become the New Tech Stocks?
description: RETURNING to basics has been a major theme in the markets. If investors in the late 1990's took a bold leap into the future with technology stocks -- off a high ledge, as it turned out -- they are now embracing age-old economic mainstays like copper, lumber, oil and gold.

title: In Turin, Italy, Passion Is the Name of the Games
description: IT goes without saying that speed is a building block of almost any Olympic success. But if you're Italian, so are passion, energy and style.

title: The Thin Place
Wendy Wasserstein's Women
description: IN the late 1970's and 1980's, when Wendy Wasserstein was emerging as a leading playwright, Ms. magazine had begun its decline.

title: The Pleasures of the Text
description: As I was reading Charles McGrath's highly amusing essay (Jan. 22), I received a text message from my son, who left earlier that day from New York City to go to Bogot, Colombia. The two words in the message, "Arrived safely," had all the intimacy and substance I could have expected. It revealed a son's awareness of his father's worrying about him.

title: Benefits
description: Honoring the Commissioner

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Feb. 5 - Feb. 11; ART/ARCHITECTURE
description: Art is what you see in museums; design is what you live with at home, no? No. Design is all over museums: ancient Egyptian headrests, Navajo blankets, Chinese ceramics, not to mention all those fancy pots and pans at the Museum of Modern Art. Which means that at least some of what you live with at home is, or should be, art.

title: Cell
The Show's 'Uneven,' But Not the Party
description: Two NBC mainstays -- NBC Universal's chairman, Bob Wright, and the cast and creative team of "Saturday Night Live" -- were honored at a dinner in New York last week held by the Museum of Television and Radio. Fittingly, many past and present network stars showed up, including Tom Brokaw, Conan O'Brien, Jimmy Fallon, Darrell Hammond and Tina Fey.

title: What if Exxon Mobil Went on a Little Shopping Spree?
description: To think that in the old days, $36 billion was serious money. But suppose Exxon Mobil went on a shopping spree today with that $36.13 billion in annual profit in its wallet (the highest corporate profit ever, but who's counting?). Why, after it had bought both Ford and General Motors -- it may not want to, but it does owe them for making all those big, thirsty vehicles -- it would have a mere $7.7 billion left over.

title: For a Big Dreamer, a Little Tokyo
description: HIROYUKI TAKENAGA, a 39-year-old Japanese native who lives in Woodside, Queens, is the first to admit that his mind doesn't work the way other people's do. For the past dozen years, Mr. Takenaga has disseminated his singular musings about New York's Japanese community in a self-published Japanese-language newsletter he calls Weekly Nuts. The name refers to his admittedly unconventional ideas.

title: I Cannot Tell a Lie (From an Amplification)
description: A DISTURBING question lurks behind the literary scandal that won't die: Does authenticity still matter? It is a quality that most people say they admire and value -- revere, even -- in people, in products and in information. And it is something to which media brands and marketers alike pay homage, with adjectives like "real," "genuine" and "trusted." Yet as a business model, authenticity seems to be an increasingly tough way to make a living.

title: 2002: Salt Lake City, Utah
description: Long a destination for skiers, Salt Lake's Olympics broadened its winter sports menu, prompted infrastructure improvements that make it more tourist-friendly, and increased the number of foreign visitors. Salt Lake County now has 17,500 hotel rooms, 8,000 of them downtown, an expanded, updated airport and a light-rail system.

title: The Pleasures of the Text
description: I appreciated McGrath's essay but felt that his conclusion, "We don't really have much we want to say," was off the mark. As a 40-something whose wife travels on business and is frequently in meetings, I often stay connected to her through informational ("Call me when you're free -- quick question") and personal ("Just wanted you to know I'm thinking of you") text messages. I use messaging rather than calling not for trendiness or from a lack of intimacy, but to communicate with her in a nonintrusive manner, when she may be busy and unable to take a call.

title: A Hip and Raw Outpost Opens in Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITY - JERSEY CITY'S art scene, ever twitchy and strenuously hip, continues to evolve with several galleries opening this winter. Topping the list is Allura Gallery, a raw, dicey place on the first floor of an old cheesecake factory on a street that exudes funk.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Feb. 5 - Feb. 11; DANCE
description: DANCE THEATER WORKSHOP is presenting what promises to be a frisky double bill this week, full of odd names and odd titles. HEATHER KRAVAS, who has been dancing around town for a few years, most notably with DD Dorvillier, is collaborating with ANTONIJA LIVINGSTONE, from Montreal by way of Berlin, on a world premiere called "XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX -- A SITUATION FOR DANCING." That's 20 X's, no more and no less. Set to music by Moondog, it promises a "four-part investigation of the subversive nature of a shadowy character," with a new section each night. Equally shadowy -- "a dramatically different look at intense isolation" -- will be "3PETIX," a duet in its United States premiere from PO.V.S. TANZE, a Moscow dance collective. Wednesday through Saturday at 7:30 p.m., 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077 or www.dtw.org; $12 and $20.

title: His Morning After
description: TO appreciate fully how complicated Jay McInerney's personal life is these days it helps to know how he began his relationship with the socialite Anne Hearst.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: VIEWS OF CAMBODIA

title: A Renowned Architect's Less Renowned Designs
description: THE architect Rosario Candela is famous for the string of superluxury apartment houses he designed in the second half of the 1920's, culminating in the sumptuous co-op at 740 Park Avenue, at 71st Street. Candela made his name in unprecedented boom times, like those of recent years. After the stock market crashed in 1929, his quantity diminished -- but his quality persisted.

title: For Skiers, Fashion Follows Function
description: THE most-discussed Winter Olympics garb is always that of female figure skaters, as sportswriters titter over skirt length and sequin count. Far fewer words, however, are spent meditating on the skin-tight suits worn by alpine skiers. But in a sport where a few hundredths of a second can separate gold from also-ran -- and, in turn, determine whether a post-Olympics career will include endorsing pricey ski equipment or a local used-car lot -- aerodynamic clothing can make a real difference.

title: Blasts From the Past
description: IF you walk out the back door of the Chelsea Market, housed in the old Nabisco Building, and onto Tenth Avenue, you will be standing in the shadow of history. Any sunlight will be eclipsed by the rusted relic of an improbable railroad track that spans the street 30 feet overhead. While the scent of fresh-baked Oreo cookies and the screech of train brakes have vanished, the massive elevated rail tracks known as the High Line still snake north to the deserted 30th Street Rail Yards and south to Gansevoort Street.

title: Chardonnay, Two Ways
description: Two newly released chardonnays show the range of chardonnay styles emerging in the young region.

title: Rising Prices Lift All Bonuses
description: EXXON MOBIL announced record earnings last week: $36.13 billion for 2005, a 43 percent increase over the previous year. That was the highest annual profit any American company has ever earned. Shareholders of energy companies are surely delighting in the gains that sky-high oil prices bring. But their windfalls pale next to the bonanzas received by the executives running these companies, proving again how imperfect the current state of pay-for-performance can be.

title: A Bold Plan to Go Where Men Have Gone Before
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. - ASK Elon Musk what he wants to do with his life -- after having amassed a $300 million fortune from the Internet -- and the answer is surprising. At 34, he says he is too young to retire. Philanthropy is a bit staid. Starting another Web-based venture is hardly a challenge, not for a man who bought the idea for PayPal, built it up and then sold it to eBay for $1.5 billion.

title: The Real Cost of Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: From the Editor: Why Play?
description: For as long as he can remember, a friend of ours has had a deep and consuming passion for the San Diego Chargers. He dissects every draft pick, every trade, every injury report, every game -- even the exhibitions. In the midst of this obsession, he has managed to reach the top of his own profession, start a family and attract a large circle of friends who couldn't care less about his team. "Sports," he says, "may not be my life, but it is my religion."

title: ON THE WEB: Olympic Places
description: With the Olympics in Turin less than a week away, we take a look at former Winter Olympics sites, from Innsbruck, Austria (above) in 1976 to Salt Lake City in 2002. George Vecsey, a Sports of The Times columnist, and Neil Amdur, a former Olympics writer for The Times, talk about their favorite moments from each of those Games.

title: Health Care Begins at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Nebraska's Nostalgia Trap
description: Omaha - ON average, Nebraska's economy is doing just fine. But a man whose head is in the oven and whose feet are in the freezer takes no comfort in knowing that his average body temperature is perfectly normal. In the same vein, a casual glance at a graph of Nebraska's population growth shows slow, steady increases, going all the way back to 1900, and conceals the fact that 74 of Nebraska's 93 counties are in extremis, with lower populations today than they had in 1920.

title: Other Views: The Times, Le Figaro, Toronto Star
Maintained in Perpetuity, Or in Perpetual Squabbles?
description: JUST because an appellate panel of the State Supreme Court has ruled that the Mamaroneck school district has the right to move a World War II monument to make room for a soccer field doesn't mean that the rancor stirred up by the case has been resolved.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINSTOCK, LILLIAN
description: WEINSTOCK - Lillian. 94, Pompano Beach, FL, January 29, 2006. Survived by herloving children, Leonard (Terry) Weinstock and Deborah (Martin) Bloch, her grandchildren, Kenneth (Jacqueline) Perlmutter, S. Michael Perlmutter, Lauren (Rob Widell) Weinstock, and Adam Weinstock, great grandchildren, David, and Jeffrey Perlmutter, and her brother, Saul (Lois) Ricklin. Predeceased by her brother Joseph Ricklin. A woman of valor, her worth is above rubies. Donations in her memory to The Crohns & Colitis Foundation of America.

title: The Most Dangerous Stroke
description: It was a year ago this month that Rafael Nadal, a 19-year-old from Majorca with bulging biceps and a uniform fit for a salsa instructor, dispatched five opponents in Costa do Sauipe, Brazil, to begin one of the great debuts in tennis history. Nadal won the next week too, in Acapulco, on his way to six clay court titles in four months, capped by a Grand Slam victory, the French Open, in June. By the time he collapsed in celebration on the red clay of Roland Garros Stadium in Paris, Nadal had been nicknamed both El Matador and the Prodigy by the news media, and welcomed by tennis fans as the most exciting player since Andre Agassi appeared on the scene in acid-washed denim and a sun-streaked mullet.

title: Comparing Quarterback Career Arcs

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MALOOF, LORRAINE (NEE SAMRA)
description: MALOOF -- Lorraine (nee Samra). Of Englewood Cliffs NJ on January 30, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Robert E. Devoted mother of Karen (Larry Buksbaum) Maloof of Demarest, NJ and Glen J. Maloof of West Palm Beach FL. Loving grandmother of Brandon and Scott Buksbaum. Dear sister of Victor M. (Alexandra) Samra Jr. Adored aunt of Victor III and Christina Karper. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAHAM, REV. MARGARET M.
description: GRAHAM--Rev. Margaret M. We grieve at the untimely loss of our beloved friend Meg, and cherish the gifts of faith and humanity she shared with us and others. Virginia and Richard Schubert, Elisabeth Austin, Emily and Robert Carroll, Deborah and Selvyn Seidel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HENRY, CHARLES
description: HENRY--Charles, 78. Of Las Vegas, NV. A 31 year veteran of the New York City Police Department died in Las Vegas on February 1, 2006 after a brief illness. Henry was appointed to the NYPD in 1951 and was one of the Department's first African American Chiefs. Henry worked a majority of his career in Brooklyn North, having a significant role in the Ocean HillBrownsville, Brooklyn riots during the Mayor Lindsay administration in 1968. Henry rose through the ranks to the position of Deputy Chief, Manhattan North Area, before being appointed the Chief of the NYC Housing Authority Police in 1979; retiring in 1982. Henry is survived by a son Laurence, a retired NYPD detective; his wife Tracy, an NYPD detective, Spring Valley, NY; daughters Andrea Henry, Queens, NY, Melanie Turner and her husband David of Norwalk, CT; and grandchildren, Andrew, Jourdan, Miles and Amanda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAMERMAN, MORTON
description: KAMERMAN--Morton. The Board of Directors and all tenant shareholders express our deep sorrow at the passing of Morton Kamerman, a resident at 1125 Park Avenue for nearly 50 years. A gentle, thoughtful, intelligent and witty man, Mort's passing is a great loss. Our condolences to his wife Sheila, and all of the Kamerman family. 1125 Park Avenue Corp.

title: The Real Lady of the Canyons
description: WENDY WASSERSTEIN, who died on Monday at 55 of complications of lymphoma, was celebrated as a Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright and a witty essayist, a dogged champion of the arts and a mentor to young playwrights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLEMAN, MATTHEW TREANOR
description: COLEMAN--Matthew Treanor. Age 24 of New York City and Palm Beach FL, passed away suddenly on February 2, 2006. Loving son of Denis and Annabelle Coleman of Palm Beach, FL. In addition, he is survived by his dear brothers Denis, Nicholas and Timothy. Visitation will be held Saturday and Sunday 2-4 PM at the O'Connell Funeral Home, 30 Little Plains Rd, Southampton, New York. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Monday at 10:00 AM at Sacred Hearts of Jesus & Mary RC Church, Southampton. Interment will follow at Sacred Hearts RC Cemetery, Southampton. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in Matthew's memory to the Community Foundation of Plam Beach and Martin County, 700 South Dixie Highway, Suite 200, West Palm Beach, FL 33401.

title: Q & A
description: My wife and I arrived in Paris on KLM and plan to make a quick trip to Italy before returning home from Paris. We had planned to take our four bags (total weight about 265 pounds) with us to Italy, but we understand that we may face charges for excess weight or number of bags. Can you explain why we would face these charges in Europe, but not, apparently, in the United States? Should we store our bags at Charles de Gaulle Airport? -- John Mitchell, Madison, Wisc.

title: A Nose in the Beholder's Eye

title: A Structural Pro and His Empty Space
description: RIDDLES of identity and truth, as writers from Mark Twain to James Frey have demonstrated, are not always easy to reconcile. In Twain's "Mysterious Stranger," the title character comes to town and stirs everyone's reality into chaos and doubt. As for James Frey -- well, his whole reality is in doubt.

title: Beth Greenberg and Beth Simon
description: LIKE many New Yorkers, Dr. Beth Ilene Greenberg excels at worrying and laughing, but definitely not at cooking.

title: Israel to Pass on $54 Million to Palestinian Authority
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 5 - Israel agreed today to pass on $54 million in taxes collected on behalf of the Palestinian Authority, but a cabinet minister warned that the monthly transfer would stop once the militant Islamic faction Hamas formed the next Palestinian government.

title: At 13-6, Davis Is Not No. 1 in the Hearts of Indiana Fans
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Feb. 4 - Mike Davis, the Indiana University men's basketball coach, leaned on the wooden lectern in the media room at Assembly Hall on Saturday afternoon, again feeling as if he had to defend his team.

title: 1992: Albertville, France
description: The unremarkable way station of Albertville, a low-lying town of 17,000 at the confluence of the IsA re and Arly Rivers, was the site of the opening and closing ceremonies, as well as the figure skating and speed skating competitions, where Kristi Yamaguchi and Bonnie Blair won gold medals. The rest of the action took place over a far-flung array of venues in the vast apron of mountainous playground that spreads out around the city.

description: We have had nothing like it in this country in living memory: a commanding moral voice, attached to no political party or public office, that moved governments and changed social institutions. That was Martin Luther King Jr.

description: There he was, the man people will always call governor, witnessing the swearing in of a top female public official inside the State House. Too bad he didn't have time to drop in on the other swearing in that another governor was attending -- at exactly the same time -- of another top female public official: Zulima V. Farber, the new attorney general.

title: Israel's Top Envoy: Lawyer Who Evokes Meir
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 4 - Tzipi Livni, 47, is the first woman to serve as Israel's foreign minister since Golda Meir did so half a century ago. Some think she may be the first since Ms. Meir to be prime minister.

title: Floodwaters Reveal a Divide Between Upstate and Down
description: GODEFFROY, N.Y. - EVEN before last April's disastrous floods, the Meyers Grove neighborhood along the Neversink River wasn't exactly Malibu, just an unpretentious jumble of modest houses, trailers and bungalows, many of them converted from summer vacation cottages.

title: Soccer: Juventus keeps on winning
Sleeping Beauty
description: GOVERNORS ISLAND, 172 acres of American history lying just off the southern tip of Manhattan, is terra incognita to most New Yorkers. Commuters, glimpsing it from the Staten Island Ferry, see only an array of abandoned modern buildings and two unpromising landmarks: a white ventilation tower belonging to the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, and Castle Williams, a grim 19th-century fortification, dark red and pierced by black windows.

Paid Notice: Deaths   ALVAREZ, ERNESTO
description: ALVAREZ - Ernesto. The Board of Trustees and Staff of Casita Maria, the oldest settlement house in New York serving the Hispanic communities of the South Bronx and East Harlem, are deeply saddened by the sudden loss of their esteemed colleague and fellow Trustee, Ernesto Alvarez. His longtime and steadfast devotion to Casita Maria was exemplary. His warmth, wit and creativity will be sorely missed by all who knew him.

title: Creating Condos and Controversy in Minneapolis
description: THREE years ago, when he was 28, Clark Gassen persuaded an investor to lend him about $700,000 to buy and fix up a $500,000 apartment building on a leafy street near a lake in southwestern Minneapolis. He sold all six units in weeks.

title: Redrawing the Political Map
description: THE decennial process of Congressional redistricting is fundamental to a functioning democracy. But unfortunately it is often abused for partisan purposes.

title: 1994: Lillehammer, Norway
description: The Games took place here just two years after the previous edition, as Olympic officials decided to stagger the Summer and Winter Olympics permanently. Lillehammer may always be remembered as the place where the figure skating soap opera starring Tonya Harding and Nancy Kerrigan A Harding was accused of hiring a hit man to try to break Kerrigan's leg at the United States Olympics trials A had its denouement. Despite that lurid plot line, this town and its quaint downtown Storgata pedestrian area provided a picturesque backdrop for the Games, enhanced by Norway's passion for the oldest and most basic Nordic sports.

title: Ricochet Sends Rangers Soaring Into First Place
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 - After a stunning 4-3 overtime victory over the Philadelphia Flyers on Saturday, the Rangers are in sole possession of first place of their division this late in a season for the first time in nearly a decade.

title: Amateurs again threaten to tip world upside down
Paperback Row
description: GILEAD, by Marilynne Robinson. (Picador, $14.) Published 24 years after "Housekeeping," Robinson's luminous second novel won a Pulitzer Prize last year and was chosen by the Book Review as one of the 10 best books of 2004. "Gilead" is set in 1956 in the small town of Gilead, Iowa, and is narrated by a 76-year-old pastor named John Ames. His health failing, Ames decides to write a letter to his young son. This novel is that letter: full of moral advice, metaphysical yearning and storytelling (his grandfather, also a preacher, fought on the Union side in the Civil War). " 'Gilead' is a beautiful work -- demanding, grave and lucid," James Wood wrote here.

title: Back to the Past With Moondoggie
description: BEFORE Dr. Evil ventured back to Swinging 60's London in his -- insert air quotes here -- time machine to purloin a certain International Man of Mystery's mojo in the 1999 film comedy "Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me," and before Sam Beckett began jumping from body to body and era to era on NBC's popular "Quantum Leap" in 1989, James Darren was somersaulting through the centuries in a pair of very tight pants.

title: Other Voices: But What News Goes in That News Hole?
description: I have often wondered what determines international news coverage -- that is, what is deemed worthy of being published.

title: It's Not Just Another Fancy Hotel Meal
description: THERE is a trend in hotels, epitomized by super-deluxe resorts such as the Wynn Las Vegas and the MGM Grand, offering clients upscale restaurant dining in the hotel, often with a big-name chef at the stove. The restaurant then serves as a destination independent of the hotel.

title: Once Just an Aide, Now a King of K Street
description: WASHINGTON - ONCE, the archetype of the Capitol Hill aide was a humble policy wonk fresh from graduate school who moved to Washington to pursue a gratifying but mostly anonymous life in public service.

title: REALITY IN LITHUANIA
description: To the Editor: I am writing to comment on "Lithuania: Finding a Future in Its Soviet Past" (Jan. 22) by Denny Lee. It is hard to imagine a more superficial and silly assessment of what is going on in Lithuania at the moment. I understand that this is not exactly hard news, but it still must have some connection to reality. The overall comments were bad enough, but the remarks about Grutas Park and the statues in Vilnius (on the Green Bridge, not identified in the article) were totally ridiculous. I have spent the last five summers teaching and living in Vilnius and traveling throughout Lithuania. The author in this short piece has created a serious misrepresentation of what is taking place. Too bad, since Lithuania and the Lithuanians have so much to offer.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Feb. 5 - Feb. 11; THEATER
description: Call it a rematch, dj vu or just a very welcome coincidence. JOHN PATRICK SHANLEY ("Doubt") and MARTIN McDONAGH ("The Pillowman") -- who battled it out for the best play Tony last season -- return this week with new plays, each of which, incidentally, is part of a trilogy. Judging by reports from London, where Mr. McDonagh's "LIEUTENANT OF INISHMORE" had its premiere four years ago, this black satire, which includes enough dead animals and severed body parts to appeal to fans of the horror film "Hostel," should make "Pillowman" look like a Disney musical. A comedy about terrorism and torture, it tells the story of a brutal terrorist who thinks nothing of murdering people. His motto is "Shoot first, ask idiotic questions later" -- but he has a real soft spot for his pet cat. Performances begin on Wednesday at the Atlantic Theater Company, 336 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 239-6200; $60.

title: Voices Take Flight at Grand Central Terminal, in Competition of Gospel Choirs
description: The painted starlit sky of Grand Central Terminal has watched over everything from the mundane to the profane. But in the terminal's marble-vaulted Vanderbilt Hall yesterday, the tilt was toward the sacred.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   QUINN, KEVIN B.
description: QUINN--Kevin B. Of Somers, New York, and Bolton Landing, New York, passed away at home on February 2nd after a long and courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. He was 63 years old. Kevin worked on the trading floor as a stock specialist and partner with M.J. Meehan & Co. for 30 years. He was a proud member of the New York Stock Exchange for 18 of those years before ringing the Exchange's closing bell upon his retirement in December 1998. Kevin was born on November 7, 1942 in the Bronx to William and Elizabeth (Walker) Quinn. He served in both the U.S. Air Force (1960-1964) and U.S. Army (1964-1967) as well as U.S. Army Reserves (1974-1980). Kevin was the loving, devoted husband of Mary (Foley) for 36 years and the proud father of three children, Colleen (Petersen) and husband Joseph, Mary Beth and Kevin, Jr. He was also the loving granddad of Kyle and Shannon Petersen, born to Colleen and Joseph. Kevin is survived by four sisters and predeceased by two brothers, as well as his parents. He is also survived by numerous aunts, uncles, cousins, nieces and nephews. Kevin was a member of the Knights of Columbus, the Elks Club, and the American Legion. Calling hours are Saturday, 7 to 9 p.m. and Sunday, 2 to 4 p.m. and 7 to 9 p.m. at Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home, 288 Main Street, Mt. Kisco, New York. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Mary's of the Assumption, Monday, 10 a.m. In lieu of flowers friends may send memorial donations to pancan.org or mail to Pan Can, 2141 Roseerans Ave., Suite 7000, El Segundo, CA 90245 or call 1-877272-6226. Donations can also be made to Hospice Care in Westchester and Putnam, Inc., 100 South Bedford Road, Mt. Kisco, New York 10549.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RYAN, DONALD CARNEY
description: RYAN--Donald Carney.Died New York City October 12, 2005. Born in Burlington, VT on December 6, 1920, son of Owen E. and Alice Carney Ryan. Graduate of Burlington HS, 1939 and the University of VT, 1949. Served three years in WW II. Studied banking and finance at NYU. Worked for many financial institutions in NY as bank officer, bond salesman and bond broker. Retired in 1989 from Fundamental Brokers. Predeceased by wife Marybel Sloan Ryan; parents; brother, William Ryan; sister-in-law, Clara Ryan; brothers-in-law, Anthony Beauvais, Robert Sloan, Jr. and his wife, Dorothy. Survived by friend, Gloria Shepherd of the Bronx; brother, Robert P. Ryan; sister, Ursula Ryan Beauvais; sister-in-law, Margaret W. Ryan, all of Burlington, VT; also many nieces, nephews and cousins. Burial took place at Homewood Cemetery in Pittsburgh PA. An announced Mass will be held at Epiphany Church on 22nd St. & 2nd Ave. in Manhattan at 7AM on February 20, 2006.

title: The hidden legacy of war
Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 22 about the media habits of young adults misstated two survey results on the creation and use of blogs. Among teenagers and adults under 29 surveyed for the Pew Internet and American Life Project, about 20 percent, not 40 percent, said they had created blogs; about 40 percent, not 80 percent, said they regularly read blogs.

title: Newark's Brazen Voice
description: NEWARK - A BIT more than 10 years ago, Tracey Scott Wilson descended to the lobby of her apartment building to find a teetering tower of packages addressed to her. It seemed not only that all the manuscripts of her novel had been rejected, but that all 30 had arrived back on her doorstep the same day.

title: MALARIA IN THE CARIBBEAN
description: To the Editor: It was extremely irresponsible to promote the Dominican Republic as the next hot family travel destination in Caren Osten Gerszberg's article "Golf, Sure, but Bring the Kids" (Jan. 22) without even mentioning that the island has malaria -- unlike the rest of the Caribbean and the Mexican resorts with which it competes. The State Department currently recommends malaria medicine for travelers, including children, to the eastern end of the Dominican Republic, where many of the resorts you recommended are situated.

description: France once traded hulking Canada for the butterfly-shaped Caribbean island of Guadeloupe, and  without wishing to ruffle any flannels among the lumberjacks  in the bleak midwinter, at least, it's easy to see why it might have struck that bargain.

description: VIENNA, Feb. 4 - The 35-nation board of the United Nations atomic energy agency voted here on Saturday to report Iran to the Security Council, a move that reflects increasing suspicion around the world that Iran is determined to develop nuclear weapons.

description: My first glimpse of what I came to recognize as a seasoned woman came in a chance encounter at an Oakland restaurant. A popular entertainer who was seated at the next table overheard me talking with my husband about my book. She leaned over to ask what it would be about. title: Corrections
description: The Going To column on Jan. 8 about Leipzig, Germany, misstated the relationship between Johann Sebastian Bach and the St. Thomas Church, or Thomaskirche. He was cantor (director of music and choirs) at the church, not the organist.

title: Fiddling With Lens as a City Burned
description: SOON after Oct. 17, 1989, I stood on a hill in San Francisco, watching as my apartment and all my worldly possessions burned to the ground in the aftermath of the Loma Prieta earthquake. A photographer had already captured me for posterity, sobbing as I saw the smoldering rubble of my building for the first time, and for a while, photographers seemed to attend my and my neighbors' every move, whether we were scavenging the remains of our building or waiting in Red Cross lines.

description: ELLERS--Peter, 50. Much beloved husband of Pam Sommers, died at home on February 2nd. Peter is also survived by his parents Elaine & James Ellers, sister Penny Ellers-Britton, her husband Michael & daughter Emma, mother-in-law Carol Sommers, sister-in-law Florie Sommers Huppert and her husband Barry & son Nathan, and father-in-law Joseph Sommers. Peter died as he lived, with grace and with dignity. His spirit will live on in the hearts of those who loved him. title: Inside the List
description: THE HISTORIAN: The third and final volume of Taylor Branch's epic biography of Martin Luther King Jr., "At Canaan's Edge: America in the King Years, 1965-68," reviewed on this week's cover, sneaks onto the hardcover nonfiction list this week at No. 16. (Branch, who is 59, initially thought that writing King's biography would be three years' worth of work; it has taken him 24 years. The combined trilogy clocks in at 2,912 pages.) The previous two volumes also appeared here in hardcover. The first, "Parting the Waters," made the list for three months in 1989, rising as high as No. 6. The second, "Pillar of Fire," was a best seller for three weeks in 1998, rising as high as No. 12. In an interview with Joe Burris of The Baltimore Sun, Branch said that while there are "100 movies" he could imagine being made from the material in his trilogy, he's all but given up hope of seeing any kind of film version. (At one point, ABC had planned an eight-hour mini-series, and Jonathan Demme considered making a feature film.) "It's been close but no cigar," Branch said, "with a lot of heartache." Also on this week's hardcover nonfiction list: Oprah Winfrey's new pick, Elie Wiesel's memoir "Night," moves to No. 5. On the paperback nonfiction list, "Night" appears at No. 1, bumping James Frey's "Million Little Pieces" out of the top slot, which it has occupied for the last 17 weeks.

title: Fevered Pitch
description: For unbridled passion, there's nothing like The soccer match between Roma And Lazio This Month. By Jeff Z. Klein In America, we take our sports rivalries seriously, as anyone who has been to a Yankees-Red Sox game can tell you. But for pure operatic heat and spectacle -- and that special sense of menace you get from the sight of riot police in retreat -- nothing beats the game on Feb. 26 between Roma and Lazio, a culture war between Rome's two top-level soccer teams played out in the monumental setting of the Stadio Olimpico. Road flares, bonfires and huge banners, fans surging over crowd-control barriers and throwing things: it's a perfect maelstrom of danger, passion and fun, often accented by a drifting pall of colored smoke that obscures the field for the game's first 20 minutes.

title: Hiking the Inca Trail: Procrastinators Need Not Apply
description: Travelers who want to hike the Inca Trail to the stunning ruins of Machu Picchu in Peru this summer should get a move on. To help protect the ancient trail, the Peruvian government is enforcing the limit of 500 trekkers starting the hike each day by requiring that tour operators submit the names and passport numbers of their clients to purchase necessary permits.

title: Cayman Islands: Ritz-Carlton Grand Cayman
description: THE BASICS -- After a one-year delay -- thanks to Hurricane Ivan of September 2004 -- the long-planned Ritz-Carlton has finally opened its doors. Set on the island of Grand Cayman, a British territory and a thriving banking center, the Ritz is all about tasteful opulence, with partnerships with La Prairie spa and Eric Ripert, chef of Le Bernardin in New York, ratcheting up the luxury factor on an island already known for its first-rate diving and snorkeling.
