title: Bush penciling in Russia as atomic energy partner
Down With Torture! Gimme Torture!
description: Whenever I hear the president mention, oh, every 12 minutes, that his greatest responsibility is "to protect the American people," the insufferable civics robot inside my head mutters: "Actually, sir, your oath, the one with the Bible and the chief justice and the Jumbotron, is to protect and defend the Constitution of the United States. For the American people are not mere flesh whose greatest hope is to keep our personal greasy molecules intact; we, sir, are a body politic -- with ideals."

title: For gays in Turkey, a slow road to equality
Health Care Begins at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: In a first, IHT prints edition in Moscow
Corrections: For the Record
description: Sunday Business

title: Follow Me
description: That irritating American Express commercial is blaring again during the college basketball telecasts. The scrappy Polish guy from Chicago is standing in front of his bench, his feet firmly planted on the holy hardwood of Duke's Cameron Indoor Stadium, his jaw locked with intensity. For years, Mike Krzyzewski, the legendary Coach K, has been pounding your team, my team and every other damn team in America, but here he is saying that he's not, really, all about basketball. His purpose is a higher one. "I don't look at myself as a basketball coach," he says in the ad. "I look at myself as a leader who just happens to coach basketball."

title: On the League's Longest Whistle-Stop Tour
description: Correction Appended

title: No Plot. No Professional Actors. No Holds Barred.
description: "THE conquest of the final visual taboo -- the realistic, poetic or lyrical portrayal of the sex act -- is the undeniable goal of subversive film artists today," wrote Amos Vogel in his landmark 1974 study, "Film as a Subversive Art."

title: The Last Kindness
description: I HAD always been fascinated by the hevra kadisha, the ritual burial society that prepares the dead before they are placed in their coffins. In Jewish communities, this task -- the taharah, as it is called -- was usually performed by the elders.

title: ECONOMIC CHIEF NAMED
description: Gov. Jon S. Corzine tapped a former colleague from Goldman Sachs last Tuesday to be chairman of the new Office of Economic Growth. The new chairman, Gary D. Rose, 60, a retired partner from the firm's investment banking division, has experience in mergers, acquisitions and finance, and will be asked to come up with a strategic plan to create jobs and expand business opportunities. He joins Bradley I. Abelow, Mr. Corzine's nominee for state treasurer, as former Goldman executives who have been recruited by Mr. Corzine, a former co-chairman.

title: Mixed Messages
description: FREEHOLD - IT is lunchtime, the sun is slanting through the windows of the Main Street Bistro here, and my friends are discussing ways to kill people. It is quite a juxtaposition: an interesting menu, a friendly waiter and death.

title: Other Voices: But What News Goes in That News Hole?; Justin Berry's Story
description: I followed Kurt Eichenwald's reporting on the Justin Berry story both in print and online. Your column and Mr. Eichenwald's articles, as well as television interviews with Mr. Eichenwald, made me distinctly uncomfortable for three reasons: (1) the unilateral praise for Mr. Eichenwald's "good" deeds and the underlying assumption that Mr. Eichenwald's behavior was heroic; (2) the lack of critical analysis of Mr. Berry's responsibility for his own behavior; and (3) the lack of critical analysis of the adult Mr. Berry's decision (with Mr. Eichenwald's assistance) to turn in hundreds of men to the F.B.I.

title: Are You Ready For Some Super Bowl?
description: Michael Lewis the Original Hero and the Changing of the Game; Stephen J. Dubner and Steven D. Levitt Outwitting Your Bookie; Bryan Curtis and Phil Simms How to Watch the Game; Jennifer Allen What It All Means When It's Your Dad Out There

title: For a Life Immersed in Jazz, Honor From the Academy
description: Barry Harris, jazz pianist, composer, educator, Weehawken resident and keeper of the be-bop flame, is being honored this month by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences along with the jazz pianists Hank Jones and Oscar Peterson. The academy is giving each musician its President's Merit Award "for outstanding achievement and lasting contributions to jazz and the music community."

title: The Meat Raffle
description: My 93-year-old grandmother has been feeling poorly recently, so I took a trip out to Minnesota to visit her. Unfortunately, I don't know my Minnesota relatives that well; my mother moved East as a young woman and pretty much stayed East. So I cherished this opportunity to spend time not only with my grandmother but also with my aunts and my passel of predominantly female cousins. And, as always, staying in their homes, I was instilled with such a profound respect for how capably and calmly these women embody their traditional female duties -- knitting, crocheting, gardening, cooking, caretaking, nourishing.. . .

title: Postage Is Due for Companies Sending E-Mail
description: Correction Appended

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Choristers From Dublin

title: Fighting a Little-Known Enemy
description: IF Suzanne Cohen asked you to donate money for TB research and counseling programs, you would almost certainly know what she was talking about. But if she asked you to donate money for E.B. research and counseling programs, you would probably react with a blank stare.

title: Scam Artists, Off to Court
description: To the Editor:

title: This Money Was Not Going to the Dogs
description: You've seen those canisters on the counter at the liquor store or the diner, bearing a picture of a sad-eyed skeletal dog asking for a contribution. And you've probably asked: Am I supposed to believe that my 35 cents is not going into the pocket of some sleazy human?

title: READING FILE
description: Correction Appended

title: As Dust Settles, the Speaker of the House Emerges, Still Standing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 - In the competition to succeed Representative Tom DeLay as the leader of their caucus, House Republicans have railed for weeks against the images of autocracy and corruption that have come to surround their party's control of the chamber.

title: Herbert Schilder, 77, Surgeon Who Refined the Root Canal, Dies
description: Herbert Schilder, a Boston dental surgeon who refined the instruments and techniques used to perform root canals and made the procedure safer and more successful, died on Jan. 25 at his home in Newton, Mass. He was 77.

title: In Poland, mining city faces unsettling change
REALITY IN LITHUANIA
description: To the Editor: I have traveled to Lithuania quite a few times since its independence from the Soviet Union. It was with great dismay that I read your article. I was astounded to read: "Instead of rejecting its Soviet history, Lithuania is embracing it, in a kind of kitschy salute to its Leninist roots."

title: On 'Evolutionism'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Animal Self
description: A tenet of social psychology is that behavior is a function both of who the creature is and of the social/situational contexts in which it finds itself. A poignant example of this might be the "temperamental" behaviors that some of the giant Pacific octopuses exhibited -- tearing up their tanks, ripping apart hoses and even wrapping their tentacles aggressively around intruders. I am not convinced that what they were displaying was "personality," but one thing is certain: they clearly don't want to be caged, socially isolated, stared at, prodded or worse. Humans and animals behave quite differently in cages, tanks and holding pens than they do when they are free.

title: The Way We Eat: Schnitzel on the Brain
description: Fifty-odd years ago, the journalist Joseph Wechsberg introduced many Americans to the pleasures of Austro-Hungarian food, but somehow the cuisine faded in the shadow of French cooking. Such fare may not quite be trendy these days, but it has at last gained a certain gravity and visibility, thanks largely to Kurt Gutenbrunner, the New York City chef and restaurateur. He recently added Blaue Gans, a fifth, more casual restaurant with German leanings, to his collection of Walls, Caf Sabarsky, Caf Fledermaus and Thor. Unlike David Bouley, whose well-regarded Danube plays with certain Austro-Hungarian dishes, Gutenbrunner makes it his mission to introduce fusion-minded customers to such unadulterated classics as kavalierspitz (boiled beef served with apple horseradish, potatoes and creamed spinach). "I cook it the same way every single day," he said. "This is what classical musicians do: they play a classic well, doing it over and over again the right way." The truth is, Americans might not recognize his masterly technique. They need a little tutorial in the Austro-Hungarian culinary canon -- the schnitzels, spaetzles, goulashes and all those astounding pastries. For them, there is still no better English-language guide than Wechsberg.

title: Mastermind of U.S.S. Cole Attack Escapes Jail
description: A man convicted of masterminding the attack on the American destroyer Cole in 2000 escaped a Yemeni jail through a tunnel with 22 other prisoners, the international police organization, Interpol, said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Super Bowl a Temporary Lift

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVERMAN, MORRIS
description: SILVERMAN - Morris. The Beth Israel Medical Center and St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital families join with the leadership of their parent company, Continuum Health Partners, in acknowledging with sadness the passing of our dear benefactor Morris "Marty" Silverman. To our friends Lorin Silverman and Patty Lipshutz, and the entire Silverman family, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Boards of Trustees Continuum, Beth Israel, and St. Luke's-Roosevelt Stanley Brezenoff, President and CEO, Continuum David J. Shulkin, MD President and CEO, Beth Israel Richard F. Daines, MD President and CEO, St. Luke's-Roosevelt

title: Finding the Bottom of a Polluted Field
description: JERSEY CITY - Just past the old municipal incinerator, near the car lots, strip malls and fast-food joints heaped on this city's far west side, a long fence juts into the shoulder of busy Route 440. Most drivers whiz by without knowing that on the other side of the fence lies one of the nation's biggest hazardous waste sites, one that spurred an environmental battle so contentious that it has dragged on for a generation.

title: A Chance to Tune Out the Numbers
description: WALL STREET will have the luxury this week of deliberating over events of the recent past. There will be little in the way of new economic reports or corporate earnings announcements to react to.

title: A Basketball Game Like No Other
description: The annual, seemingly endless iterations of sports video games rarely do more than change the jerseys on players who've switched cities. NBA Ballers: Phenom (Midway, $40) is different. It shows pro basketball for what it really is: a lifestyle. One of the most anticipated games of this season, Ballers, out next month, presents the life in all its diamond-encrusted splendor. You're a pro prospect looking to impress coaches, scouts and Hollywood agents. You try to get drafted, sign a record deal and start a clothing line. There's even a Build-a-Crib feature. But mostly you play ball against N.B.A. stars like Allen Iverson, in games so realistic that the televised ones seem dull by comparison. Seth Schiesel

title: A Heavenly Hint of Chocolate
description: Valentine's Day and chocolates are synonymous. Chocolates and port are also traditional mates, because of port's chocolate and cocoa notes.

title: Spy program breaks law, key Republican charges
In Brewster, a Backlash Against Day Laborers
description: BREWSTER - EVERY morning at the glimmer of dawn, scores of immigrant workers from Mexico and Central America gather along Main Street here, lining up to await their deliverance. It arrives in the form of local contractors and homeowners who drive up looking for an extra hand or two, offering the men construction work at $8 to $10 an hour, and on a good day more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOFFAT, JANE JACOBS
description: MOFFAT--Jane Jacobs, on February 4, 2006. Died peacefully at home at age 93. Loving wife of the late Alexander Moffat. Devoted sister of Harry A. Jacobs Jr. Loving aunt of many nieces and nephews. Graduate of Randolph Macon Women's College, and a Masters from Teachers College. She volunteered for many years at the United Nations. Memorial service Friday, February 10, 11 am, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street.

title: 'My Fundamentalist Education'
description: My first encounter with the Almighty did not go as planned. I was three months old in the fall of 1973 when Mom squeezed me into the same white christening gown she'd dressed my sister, Cathy, in a year earlier. After putting on a white cap-sleeve dress and twisting her dark hair into a stylish twist, she helped Cathy tug on some lace tights and a dress decorated with colored ribbons. Dad donned a polyester maroon suit and smoothed down his sideburns, and the four of us piled into the car for the brief trip to Pasadena Community Church. A local Methodist congregation, the church was well known in St. Petersburg for its lush outdoor "garden sanctuary" filled with fountains, palm trees, hibiscus, and bottlebrush. The minister welcomed random infants for blessing as long as the child's parents, like mine, were presentable and vaguely Protestant.

title: You Must Remember This
description: "YOU know what a 'rainmaker' is?" the event photographer Patrick McMullan asked last weekend, still hoarse from the previous night's merrymaking for Bronson van Wyck's 30th birthday party at Element. "I feel like the kissmaker. I've been taking pictures since the 1970's, and whenever I see people kissing, I'll say, 'You guys look so great kissing, can I take a picture?' I've never had a problem of someone saying no. And I've never had an altercation, knock on wood."

title: On Advertising: Why does Buick sell well in China?
Sweden and U.S. Agree About the Oil Dependency Problem, but for Different Reasons
description: STOCKHOLM, Feb. 4 - After he heard President Bush tell Americans they were "addicted to oil," Prime Minister Goran Persson of Sweden said he was relieved that "at last there's one more who understands the problem."

title: A Real Estate Investment Moves to the Mainstream
description: WALL STREET has embraced real estate investment trusts as an asset family that adds diversification to portfolios, but some financial advisers still regard so-called private, or unlisted, REIT's as a kind of black sheep.

title: Ruy Lopez May Build Slowly, But It Can Prove Devastating
description: One of the most feared openings, the Ruy Lopez, named after a 16th-century Spanish priest, was also one of the earliest modes of play. Lopez gave it its earliest written analysis, but it had been known since at least 1490. Now it is one of the game's most sophisticated openings. The process has been slow, however, and has been accompanied by the decline of other open games, like the Giuoco Piano and the Evans Gambit, their soundness coming into question with the rise of defensive technique.

title: BEST SELLERS: February 5, 2006
'Sandra Day O'Connor'
description: To ready herself for the birth of her first child, Ada Mae Day left her home on an Arizona ranch and her husband of three years. She traveled two hundred miles east, to her mother's place in El Paso, Texas, to be near a city hospital. After baby Sandra was born on March 26, 1930, at the Hotel Dieu Hospital, Harry Day came by train to see Ada Mae and his new daughter. "Although I cannot say that I feel any great parental love for Sandra yet," Harry wrote to his wife upon his return to the Lazy B, "I would like to see her and touch her again."

title: School Worker Accused of Rape
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y., Feb. 4 - A psychologist for a Long Island middle school was charged on Saturday with having sex with a 16-year-old boy who once dated her daughter.

title: In Modern Rarity, Workers Form Union at Small Chain
description: Among the thousands of stores in New York's low-income neighborhoods, labor unions have virtually no presence, except in a few supermarkets. But in a remarkable culmination to a yearlong struggle, 95 workers at a chain of 10 sneaker stores have formed a union.

title: Diabetic Brothers Beat Odds With Grit and Luck
description: When Robert Cleveland was a boy, in place of a birthday cake his mother wrapped an oatmeal box in colored paper and put candles on top. "I never had any sweets as a child," he said. "Never."

title: Hurricanes Get Jump On Trading Deadline
description: The upstart Carolina Hurricanes made the first bold splash among the Stanley Cup contenders Monday by trading for Doug Weight, a playmaking center. The Hurricanes acquired Weight and left wing Erkki Rajamaki from St. Louis for forward Jesse Boulerice, center Mike Zigomanis, the rights to forward Magnus Kahnberg, first- and fourth-round draft picks this year and a fourth-round pick in 2007.

title: Skeleton Coach Fired for Refusing to Stay Away
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 4 - The United States Bobsled and Skeleton Federation, after dealing with sexual harassment accusations against the national skeleton coach Tim Nardiello for the past month, fired him Saturday for insubordination.

title: A Trove of Prints By a Cast of Masters
description: POUGHKEEPSIE - "PRESSES, Pop and Pomade: American Prints Since the Sixties," now at the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center here, is an alluring, complex exhibition that not only presents rare signature works by blue-chip artists but also offers many pieces that have never been displayed before.

title: With a Slouch and a Shrug, a Nantucket Surfer Turns Model
description: BOBBY KING is tall, tan and thinly muscled, with a rugged handsomeness that some might describe as "organic." At least that was the term used by a photo coordinator at Cargo, the men's gear magazine, where Mr. King showed up two weeks ago for a casting call. Dressed casually in baggy jeans and a peasant shirt, his long, messy hair fastened down by a headband, he had the appearance of a surfer dude plunked down in the city.

title: Redrawing the Political Map
description: THE decennial process of Congressional redistricting is fundamental to a functioning democracy. But unfortunately it is often abused for partisan purposes.

title: County Bowed by Storm Long After It Eased Up
description: THE wind started howling late on Jan. 14, heralding a storm that charged toward the metropolitan region. The rain that followed turned into sleet as the night wore on. By daybreak, snow blanketed streets, driveways and rooftops throughout Westchester. Trees had toppled here and there, taking down power lines and leaving 14,000 homes without heat or electricity -- some for hours, some for days.

title: Dark Moment In the Harsh Hollywood Sun
description: LOS ANGELES - DURING her brief lifetime, Elizabeth Short never starred in a single movie. There is no record of her having played so much as a bit part. Yet within popular culture, Short -- who frequently told friends she wanted to break into show business -- has emerged as something of an honorary leading lady whose shadowy life and violent death follow the contours of a classic film noir script.

title: His Morning After
description: TO appreciate fully how complicated Jay McInerney's personal life is these days it helps to know how he began his relationship with the socialite Anne Hearst.

title: A New Stadium: Who Benefits?
description: To the Editor:

title: Deerstalkers
description: The fashion-conscious are jumping online to order three-dimensional camouflage jackets from outdoor outfitters in the Midwest. The 3-D garments, costing about $100, have strips of oak-leaf-pattern fabric stitched over mesh; city folk discard the zip-out scent-blocker linings. Louise Doktor, top left, an executive secretary on Park Avenue, wears her jacket upside down. Jack Edwards, top right, visiting in his from Minneapolis, said someone in Greenwich Village yelled, "You need a rake!" Other takes on camo, some that would only amuse a deer, stalk Fifth Avenue, bottom row. ON THE STREET

title: Corrections
description: An "In the Region" article in Westchester and Connecticut copies last Sunday about a reported shortage of affordable housing in Connecticut misidentified the new hometown of a family that moved to Idaho. It is Idaho Falls, not Idaho Springs.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,242 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Friday:

title: On Sauerkraut Boulevard, Hard Feelings for a New Hotel
description: Kathy Jolowicz, a neighborhood historian born on East 76th Street, is an unapologetically nostalgic booster of Yorkville, the once largely German-speaking neighborhood on the Upper East Side. Ms. Jolowicz, 66, remembers the 1940's and 50's, when East 86th Street was packed with so many German restaurants and dance halls it was known as Sauerkraut Boulevard. She remembers the smell of sauerbraten and the voice of a family friend who sang opera at the Cafe Wienecke.

title: DNA Kits Aim to Link You to the Here and Then
description: THE past comes at a price for Georgia Kinney Bopp. Retired and living in Kailua, Hawaii, Ms. Bopp has spent about $800 on tests to trace her ancestry, using samples of DNA from inside her cheek and from possible relatives.

title: Why Let the I.R.S. See What the S.E.C. Doesn't?
description: IMAGINE a company that makes a practice of keeping two sets of accounts. One version is revealed to the public through periodic Securities and Exchange Commission filings and public announcements. The other is never made public and conveys a markedly different picture.

title: When the Game Means Everything
description: Last fall, as the Indianapolis Colts threatened to match the 1972 Miami Dolphins' feat of an undefeated season, one particular image received maximum play. The picture was taken seconds after the Dolphins beat the Washington Redskins in Super Bowl VII, securing a perfect 17-0 record, when players hoisted Coach Don Shula onto their shoulders and carried him across the field at Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum.

title: Faith Based
description: MY FUNDAMENTALIST EDUCATION

title: Moussaoui Trial Set to Begin
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 A Zacarias Moussaoui and nearly 500 potential jurors are set to gather in a Northern Virginia courtroom on Monday, marking the start of the only trial in the United States of a person charged with direct involvement in the terror attacks on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Meet Our New Name
description: WHAT'S in a name? The new one my husband, Gary (formerly Ruderman), and I (formerly Wilgoren) adopted has three letters from his father's father's father and four letters from my patrilineal ancestors -- or perhaps from the imagination of some anonymous clerk at Ellis Island.

title: Redrawing the Political Map
description: THE decennial process of Congressional redistricting is fundamental to a functioning democracy. But unfortunately it is often abused for partisan purposes.

title: Sister Cities: Winter Olympic Sites From 1976 to 2002
description: 1976: Innsbruck, Austria

title: Short Work | Jan. 29-Feb. 4
description: QUICK VOTE

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: CURRY: A Tale of Cooks and Conquerors. By Lizzie Collingham. (Oxford University, $28.) To the growing list of food microhistories with punchy titles, like "Salt," "Cod" and "Spice," add "Curry," a lively study of Indian cooking from the Mogul Empire of the 1600's to Utsav in 21st-century Manhattan, one of the "new breed" of Indian restaurants. It's a long but tasty journey, made easily digestible by Collingham, who was seduced by Indian food when she drank a "thick, velvety" lassi in Bombay in 1994. Curry, it turns out, is a British classification, a catchall based on a term used by Portuguese colonists, "who described as 'caril' or 'carree' the broths that the Indians 'made with butter, the pulp of Indian nuts . . . and all sorts of spices.' " Indeed, the poor British come in for frequent roastings by Collingham: as gluttons during their colonial rule over India (loading their tables with "turkeys that you could not see over"); culinary philistines ("there was virtually nothing that the British would not stew in curry sauce"); and bigots ("the consumption of large quantities of curry has not necessarily made the British any less racist"). Collingham, a historian by training, builds her book dish by dish, starting with chicken tikka masala. As the cuisine changes with new ingredients like the chili pepper (which arrived in India in the early 1500's from South America) and the importation of foreign eating and cooking habits, you feel selfishly grateful it came to travel the world, yet also fearful of the losses the globalization of food can bring.

title: Building Blocks of Art, Embedded in the Walls
description: Home improvement as art? Well, why not?

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Jan. 22 about remnants of the Soviet era in Lithuania included an out-of-date reference to NATO, a bar in Vilnius. The bar has gone out of business.

title: The Pride of the Ferry Riders Reaches for the Stars
description: She did not wear a Statue of Liberty costume, or a ridiculous Jamaican wig. She failed to moonwalk or break-dance or sing with her mouth closed. When Tyra Juliette Schwartz, a Staten Island native, arrived for her audition on the Fox reality show "American Idol," which ran in January, there were no gimmicks at all. She just sang, and it worked.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   RODBELL, SHELDON
description: RODBELL--Sheldon. Today would have been your birthday. While we wish you were here to see your family grow and change, you're still always in our hearts, minds and thoughts. Your loving family

title: Harlem Renaissance
description: On a cold East Harlem morning in 1966, when I was 15, my new best friend Stinky and I ran inside an old tenement building to shoot up. After scaling six flights, we arrived at the landing that led to the roof. Our day's first stab at ghetto kids' roulette was about to begin. We were gleefully unfolding the pouch containing our heroin and paraphernalia when trouble arrived. The faint sound of footsteps activated our "uh-oh" meter. As the sound grew louder, Stinky and I looked at each other before harmonizing out loud, "The po-lice!"

title: COMINGS & GOINGS
description: Apparently being a television star and a self-proclaimed billionaire isn't enough. Last month, Donald J. Trump started a new travel site -- called, of course, gotrump.com -- powered by Travelocity. But one New York hotel listed, the Mayflower at 15 Central Park West, no longer exists. The Mayflower was demolished at the start of last year, and a condominium building designed by Robert A. M. Stern Architects is going up in its place. The Trump Web site listed the hotel as "sold out" but included a map of its former location and an overview of its amenities. Later, the site was amended to point out that the hotel is "nonexistent." When the listing was brought to the attention of the Web site, "it was removed immediately," said Jim Dowd, a gotrump.com spokesman, who added that the hotel was still listed on competitor sites.. Feeling lucky? The Ritz-Carlton in Key Biscayne, Fla., will randomly place a diamond-and-sapphire necklace worth more than $3,000 under one guest's pillow each month through May to celebrate its new distinction as an AAA Five Diamond resort. Radisson Seven Seas is offering free economy-class air fare on a handful of seven-night sailings from May to September. Prices, including free air fare from 86 North American gateways, start at $3,497 per person. Romance on the cheap: Apple Core Hotels, a group of five budget hotels in midtown Manhattan, is offering about 20 percent off regular prices from Feb. 10 through Feb. 28 with the Big Apple Romance package. The package, which includes Continental breakfasts and two tickets to the observation deck at Rockefeller Center, costs $169 a night, not including tax.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILBERT, SUE
description: GILBERT--Sue. February 3, 2006. Beloved mother and grandmother of Fred, Sheryl, Scott and Alex. Cherished sister of Bea Gilbert. Adored by her nieces, nephews and their families. Predeceased by husband Sol and son Jon. All who knew her were swept into her magic circle of love. We will miss her.

title: In a Change of Plans, Bush Says He Will Attend King's Funeral
description: CRAWFORD, Tex., Feb. 4 - The White House announced here on Saturday that President Bush would attend the funeral of Coretta Scott King in Atlanta on Tuesday, postponing a scheduled trip to New Hampshire.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 5, 2006
Take the Money and Stay
description: Last May, three and a half months before Hurricane Katrina devastated New Orleans, a San Antonio lawyer named Stanley Rosenberg told a local reporter that the New Orleans Saints might be contemplating a move to San Antonio. This was no idle chatter, as the reporter well knew. One of Rosenberg's longtime clients is Tom Benson, who has owned the team since 1985. Although a New Orleans native, Benson has deep roots in San Antonio, where his car dealerships have helped make him wealthy. Benson also owns a ranch, said to be his favorite place in the world, just north of the city.

title: Lottery Numbers
Adding Newsprint to the Fire
description: PARIS - EUROPEANS hoisted the banner of press freedom last week in response to Muslim anger over a dozen Danish cartoons, some of them mocking the Prophet Muhammad. But something deeper and more complex was also at work: The fracas grew out of, and then fed, a war of polemics between Europe's anti-immigrant nationalists and the fundamentalist Muslims among its immigrants.

title: Deliberation Nation
description: The public hearings that the Senate Judiciary Committee is scheduled to begin holding tomorrow are supposed to help determine whether the National Security Agency's domestic spying program broke the law. But this is no ordinary trial. Although lawyers will abound and oaths will be administered, there will be no prosecutors or judges, and there are as yet no defendants, no one charged with a specific legal violation. Instead, a profusion of statutes, case law and constitutional provisions surrounds and obscures the issue. The committee will try to shed light on the question of legality, but it won't be easy. We are in the midst of a once-in-a-decade constitutional weather pattern -- what you might call a fog of law.

title: Paying the Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Fisher Has Gone From Air Force to a Force on Defense for the Seahawks
description: DETROIT, Feb. 4 - Even if he does not lay a hand on Pittsburgh quarterback Ben Roethlisberger on Sunday, Seattle defensive end Bryce Fisher will touch a lot of people during Super Bowl XL: a grieving mother in Lompoc, Calif.; troops in mess halls throughout the Middle East; friends in Colorado Springs.

title: That Which Does Not Kill Me Makes Me Stranger
description: Jure Robic, the Slovene soldier who might be the worldAs best ultra-endurance athlete, lives in a small fifth-floor apartment near the railroad tracks in the town of Koroska Bela. By nature and vocation, Robic is a sober-minded person, but when he appears at his doorway, he is smiling. Not a standard-issue smile, but a wild and fidgety grin, as if he were trying to contain some huge and mysterious secret.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the workplace culture of Pixar Animation Studios misspelled the surname of the director of a Pixar film, "Monsters, Inc." He is Pete Docter, not Doctor.

title: Movies on TV
description: HOTEL RWANDA (2004) Saturday at 9 p.m. on Showtime Wrenching isn't a strong enough word for Terry George's drama about the slaughter of 800,000 human beings over a 100-day period in 1994. The hero of the film is the manager of a luxury hotel. That manager, Paul Rusesabagina (Don Cheadle in the performance of his career so far, and that is high praise), belongs to the Hutu ethnic group. The Hutus are murdering the Tutsis, and Paul's wife, Tatiana (Sophie Okonedo, above, with Mr. Cheadle, right, and Antonio David Lyons), is Tutsi. He manages to save lives by harboring more than a thousand Tutsis at the hotel, but it is never clear exactly who will escape and who will not before the madness ends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HYMAN, FREDRICK
description: HYMAN--Fredrick. February 1. Predeceased by wife Mildred. Beloved father to Steven, Kenneth and Debra, and loving husband to Gail. Founder of Grand Lumber Jersey City, NJ. His memory will be with us forever.

title: Turkey Balks on Widening Rights for Gays
description: ISTANBUL, Feb. 4 A Groups advocating equal rights for gay people in Turkey have long hoped that their countryAs bid for membership in the European Union would bring European-style sexual freedoms. But as Turkey has moved closer to conforming with European legal standards and policies, its movement toward legal parity has been halting.

title: Other Voices: But What News Goes in That News Hole?
description: I am one of those who have questions about the wedding announcements. A short paragraph or two would be appropriate, but some of the announcements have a long narrative about how the couple met, fell in love, whatever. Is this an appropriate allocation? After all, the couple can send e-mail messages to all their friends and relatives giving this breathtaking information without taking up valuable newspaper space.

title: Detroit's 'Organic Energy'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Handling Hamas
description: Q: You were this country's chief peace negotiator in the Middle East for 12 years, until 2001, when the talks broke down and never resumed. Do you think the U.S. is at all responsible for the ascent of Hamas in the Palestinian territories and its landslide election victory last month? I find it incredibly depressing. We had so many opportunities to stop this.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCALEER, EDWARD C.
description: McALEER--Edward C. Of Centerville, MA and Naples, FL, formerly of NYC and Haverhill, MA, on January 31. Retired Professor Emeritus at Hunter College, NYC; formerly Chairman of the Department of English and English Professor at Hunter College. Renowned author of English literature and recipient of numerous literature awards. Former Fulbright Fellow at the University of Rome and founder of The Browning Society. Uncle of Henry A. Lyons of Centerville, MA and Naples, FL and Joseph M. Lyons of Dublin, Ireland; survived by grandnieces and grandnephews. Funeral Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated Tuesday, February 7, at 12 noon in St. James Church, Haverhill, MA. Interment St. James Cemetery. visitation at the C. Frank Linnehan and Son Haverhill Funeral Home, 129 Kenoza Ave. Haverhill, Tuesday 10:30-11:30AM.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WECHSLER, LEWIS S.
description: WECHSLER--Lewis S. Died Friday, February 3, 2006, at the age of 79, after a long and brave battle with heart disease. He leaves behind his wife of 31 years, Joan Kirkendall Wechsler, his children Zachary Wechsler, Hilary Wechsler Gibson. His grandchildren Teddy, Adam and Miranda. His sister Elise Snyder and nieces Margaret Hamilton, Katherine Snyder, Kelly Allen, Allison Kirkendall and Amanda Kirkendall. Services are private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Juvenile Diabiates Research Foundation.

title: Ode to the Bears' Super Shuffle
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Raspberries and Sharp Elbows
description: George and Paul Likitsakos, the father and son who own the Natures Gifts greengrocer on East 86th Street near Second Avenue, are surrounded by rival merchants selling fruit and vegetables. A Food Emporium faces off against them across the street, while just down the block stands a Gristedes supermarket, whose fruit is advertised by a five-foot-tall green pear that hangs like a Magritte on the store's facade.

title: Muslim protests swell in Mideast
More than 1,000 feared dead in Egypt ferry tragedy
Other Voices: But What News Goes in That News Hole?
description: Absent from the excerpts of your interview with John Geddes, the managing editor in charge of the space budget, was attention to what qualifies as "news." Whether advertising and features have displaced some news coverage is one way of looking at the evolution of The Times. What about what I call the "filler," the huge photos, blank spaces, jokes from talk-show hosts and other ephemera that I presume, in your and Mr. Geddes's quantitative analysis, count as "news"?

title: Retirement Fund Used To Cover Deficits
description: The new Democratic administration in Brookhaven said on Wednesday that the Republicans whom they replaced left a mess in the town's retirement system.

title: Being Ben Franklin
description: AN exhibition about Benjamin Franklin (1706-1790) might have been about many things. It could have been a sweet-sour tale of his years as a typesetter, printer, newspaper owner and author. Or the exhibition might just as well have been about his science experiments and inventions. Or, it could have traced his political career, during which he helped draft the Declaration of Independence and served as the American ambassador to France.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOLANTO, DR. GREGORY A.
description: SOLANTO--Dr. Gregory A. Of Rye, La Jolla, CA, Pelham Manor, on February 1, 2006, age 91. A captain during WWII and Bronze Star recipient. A graduate of New York Medical College, he was a dedicated physician and surgeon. Beloved husband of the late Geraldine. Cherished father of Mary V. Solanto, Ph.D., Gregory N. Solanto. Predeceased by a brother, Pasquale Solanto. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10 am, at St. Gregory's Church, Harrison, NY, followed by entombment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Information: Coxe & Graziano, 914-698-5968

title: Protesters in Beirut Set Danish Consulate on Fire
description: BEIRUT, Feb. 5 A Protesters angry over Danish cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad clashed with Lebanese security forces today, setting a building housing the Danish Mission on fire and attacking a nearby church.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Feb. 5 - Feb. 11; TELEVISION
description: It's a colossal television week. There's the SUPER BOWL, in which the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Seattle Seahawks will face each other in Detroit (ABC, Sunday at 6 p.m., with pre-game coverage beginning at 2:30 p.m.). On Wednesday, CBS will broadcast the "48th ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDS" at 8 p.m.: MARIAH CAREY, KANYE WEST and JOHN LEGEND lead the nominees. And then there's the OLYMPICS, which start on Friday (NBC, 8 p.m.): unfortunately, BJORK will not be adding an element of arty weirdness to the opening ceremonies, as she did in Athens 2004.

title: Trans-Atlantic battle of biotech
Survivors Recount Begging Ferry Captain to Turn Back
description: SAFAGA, Egypt, Feb. 4 - Within hours of leaving shore, as smoke began to fill the upper decks of the ferry and the crew tried desperately to calm passengers, it became clear to many on board that something had gone terribly wrong, survivors said on Saturday.

title: Denell Downum and Erik Pitchal
description: Denell Marie Downum and Erik Scott Pitchal were married in Brooklyn last evening at the Picnic House, an event space in Prospect Park. Cantor Daniel Rous officiated at the ceremony which incorporated elements of Lutheran and Jewish wedding traditions.

title: VIEWS OF CAMBODIA
description: To the Editor: Regardless of the fact that one of us is Cambodian-American, we were highly offended by the statement that "Cambodians, it seems to me, just want to be considered human beings," which was part of your article. We are sure the author meant no harm, but to explicitly say what is assumed to be a desire of all people indicates that there is a public view that Cambodians are inferior.

title: Is Ritual Circumcision Religious Expression?
description: Americans pride themselves on their commitment to freedom of religion, but how much religious freedom is too much religious freedom? At the moment, the thorniest dispute over the issue concerns a male-circumcision ritual practiced by some Hasidic Jews in New York. The ritual is called oral suction, or metzitzah b'peh. After removing the foreskin, the mohel, who conducts the circumcision, cleans the wound by sucking blood from it. According to city health officials, the ritual may have caused three infants circumcised by the same mohel in 2003 and 2004 to contract neonatal herpes (one of the infants subsequently died). New York's city health commissioner recently issued a warning about the dangers of oral suction, leading some Orthodox Jewish leaders to complain that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had reneged on promises to let religious authorities handle the issue. Meanwhile, secularists like the writer Christopher Hitchens have attacked the mayor for banning smoking in restaurants while failing to protect helpless children from diseases transmitted by "religious fanatics."

title: Mlange  Trois: Me, Him ... and the Stuff
description: I SENT my boyfriend out for coffee, and he brought back whole beans. I reached for the coffee grinder, and it was gone.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-16

title: In Guadeloupe, French, and Beach, Spoken Here
description: FRANCE once traded hulking Canada for the butterfly-shaped Caribbean island of Guadeloupe, and -- without wishing to ruffle any flannels among the lumberjacks -- in the bleak midwinter, at least, it's easy to see why it might have struck that bargain.

title: Giving Voice to Sacred Prayers
description: Days before his rabbi grandfather died in 1955, a writer of idiosyncratic poetry named Lionel Ziprin gave the old man his word that he would publish the rare Jewish liturgical recordings the rabbi had made at his Lower East Side yeshiva. Now, Mr. Ziprin appears tantalizingly close to fulfilling his promise.

title: Teen suspect in gay bar attack captured
They Are Family: Pirates Pull for Steelers and Aim High
description: THE last time the Steelers won the Super Bowl, after the 1979 season, they made Pittsburgh the city of champions because their 31-19 defeat of the Los Angeles Rams came only 95 days after the Pirates won the World Series.

title: The Courting of Gang Green
description: FLORHAM PARK'S mayor, Frank D. Tinari, used to think of what townspeople call "the Exxon property," a former office park for the oil giant, as a perfect swatch of bucolic green for this otherwise packed suburban town in Morris County.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENBERG, LENORE L.
description: GREENBERG--Lenore L. On Friday February 3, 2006. Wife of Max, mother of Allan and Howard, grandmother of Hannah, Emily, Eric and Joshua. Shiva will be held at 3 Sadore Lane, Apt. 70, Yonkers, on Monday and Tuesday, 2 to 9 pm, and at 11 Oakwood Lane, Westport, CT, on Wednesday and Thursday, 2 to 9 pm, and Friday and Sunday, 10 am to 4 pm.

title: All Units, We've Got Cops Dancing at the Academy
description: LOS ANGELES - IN six years with the Los Angeles Police Department, Officer Mike Fernandez has seen many things. Modern dance, not surprisingly, is not among them. "I've seen guys' arms blown off with AK-47's," he said. "I've seen kids molested to where they can't walk."

title: Peddling an Ounce of Prevention
description: STONY BROOK - HER legs dangling over the edge of the stage, Crystal Igneri whipped her long chestnut hair over her shoulder. "I don't know how to put that out there," she said, her chin jutting forward earnestly. "I have to work on that."

title: Photo as Artifact
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Medium Egos in XL Game
description: Detroit - THE two club owners in Super Bowl XL are so different.

title: Back to the Work Force
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Companies Sending E-Mail May Soon Pay Some Postage Companies may soon have to buy something like an electronic postage stamp if they want to be certain their e-mail is delivered to customers using AOL and Yahoo accounts. The two companies say the change will reduce spam. PAGE 25

title: Dissecting the Line
description: If you are a bookie, legal or otherwise, today is a signal day. People who would never think of wagering on a regular National Football League game suddenly become desperate to bet the Super Bowl. People who do bet the N.F.L. every week (there are millions upon millions of them) can hardly stand by and watch the tourists have all the fun. This makes for a day in which billions of dollars change hands -- as much on this single game as is bet on a full slate of games during an entire month of the regular season.

title: Mastermind of Cole attack escapes Yemeni prison
Will Other Insurers Follow Allstate's Move?
description: ALLSTATE, one of the country's largest providers of homeowners' insurance, reported $4.7 billion in losses during the third quarter of last year from Hurricanes Katrina, Rita, Dennis and Ophelia. Calling that a tenfold increase over any previous quarter, Allstate announced that it would reduce the financial risks it would face in a future catastrophe.

title: The Broadwater Battle
description: Now that the federal government has received an energy company's formal application to anchor a huge natural gas terminal in Long Island Sound, the Battle of Broadwater can be fully engaged. On this side is an array of deeply suspicious local residents, lawmakers and environmental groups infuriated at the thought of turning a fragile estuary into a combustible filling station. On that side are the TransCanada Corporation and Royal Dutch Shell, deep-pocketed multinational corporations that have teamed up in the Broadwater project to better exploit the global market in liquefied natural gas.

title: Free paper now No. 1 in Spain
A Steamy Passage
description: WHEN all you have is a hammer,everything looks like a nail. ToGail Sheehy, America's mosttherapeutic journalist, everythinglooks like a passage. Must we all keeppassing through, forever in the process, alwaysbecoming? Can't we just get somewhere, putour feet up, have a martini and enjoy the view?Apparently not, because, as they say, ''life is ajourney.'' More like a long slog, sometimes.

title: Other Voices: But What News Goes in That News Hole?
description: Re "All the News That Fits the Allocated Space" (Jan. 29):

title: Knit Up the Loopholes
description: All it takes is a quick look at K Street in Washington these days to remember that money affects politics about the same way that salt corrodes a fine old automobile. The erosion of political separation between lobbyist and candidate is steady and real, and, to stretch this analogy near its limits, this is a great time for politicians -- especially those in Albany -- to start heading for the campaign car wash.

title: Medical Centers With Open Doors
description: To the Editor:

title: It Could All Come Down To the Kickers (Gulp)
description: DETROIT, Feb. 4 - As a place-kicker, the Steelers' Jeff Reed does not expect unconditional love.

title: The Professor Who Teaches By Doing
description: JAZZ bassists usually don't rate an entourage. But when Todd Coolman pushed his bulky acoustic bass through the New York Hilton at the International Association of Jazz Education conference a few weeks ago, three of his students from Purchase College's jazz studies program trailed behind him carrying his equipment and bags, causing a stir as conventioneers stopped to see who the man with the posse was.

title: Presumed Innocence
description: THERE isn't much to laugh about in "The Exonerated," Erik Jensen's and Jessica Blank's story of six Americans who found themselves on death row for crimes committed by other people.

description: SOMEWHERE in the wilds of Fresh Kills, within view of a Gold's Gym and a shuttered movie house that sit on service roads to the West Shore Expressway, the trash fears of Staten Island are still alive.

title: The Pleasures of the Text
description: As a single woman, I notice that dating communication these days is often via text. As your writer noted, texting forces you to be haiku-brief, and therefore, to flirt, you must be very clever.

title: Judges and Lawyers Debate Probate System
description: WILL ROGERS once said, "The only difference between death and taxes is that death doesn't get worse every time Congress meets."

description: Detroit - THE weather turned nasty here yesterday as the temperatures began to drop and the rain mixed with snow. But the atmosphere was jubilant inside a building rented out by the sports agent Leigh Steinberg for his 20th Super Bowl party.

description: AFTER some false starts in the last five years, largely because of uncertainties about the strength of the residential rental market, AvalonBay Communities, a Virginia-based real estate investment trust, has broken ground on the second phase of a luxury apartment complex in New Rochelle overlooking Long Island Sound.

description: DID you hear the one about the guy who wheels his toddler into Hooters and asks if they have a diaper-changing table in the men's room?

description: Despite local opposition, Broadwater Energy formally applied to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission on Monday for permission to build a $700 million floating natural-gas plant nine miles off Wading River in Long Island Sound.

title: Terminal 'teething' woes result in missed flights
At Risk
description: When Win went to meet his anonymous caller, he got a threatening note that the man had left, warning him to stay off the Finlay case. Win drove to Lamont's house, planning to tell her that he quit, but when he arrived, he found her in her bedroom, tied to the bedpost, with an armed man hovering over her. In a struggle, Win shot the attacker. Now Lamont and Win are in the hospital, where she and her assailant were taken.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KESSEL, BERTHA
description: KESSEL--Bertha. 92, of Lakewood, NJ, on February 3, 2006. Survived by her loving brother, Bernard Joseph Kessel and nephew Richard Mark Kessel. Graveside services on Monday, February 6, 2006, at 1 pm, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Briefly: Talks over kidnappings produce little result
Torts With a Side of Fries
description: WITH the swearing-in last week of Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. by new Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr., one can only imagine what the jurists' respective law schools, Yale and Harvard, might name in their honor now that they have reached the nation's highest court. The Roberts Reading Room? The Alito Atrium?

title: Bronx Teenager Beaten to Death Hoped to Be a Veterinarian
description: Relatives and friends of a Bronx teenager beaten to death Friday as he walked home from a store struggled yesterday to make sense of the attack, as the police said that a 15-year-old with whom he had had a continuing dispute was in custody.

title: Iran to hold talks with Russia on uranium enrichment plan
Tax talk goes Orwellian
Restaurateurs Push Hanoi Into the Future
description: CA KHO is one of those Vietnamese dishes that is so simple to prepare that it poses a challenge to chefs who want to make it uniquely their own. After all, it's just fish braised in a clay pot. But therein lies the challenge: What kind of fish? How sweet, how salty, how runny should the caramel-and-fish-sauce braising liquid be? How much black pepper is too much? It's a debate that has as many wrong answers as right ones, and that, as far as I'm concerned, rarely yields a dish that could ever be called memorable.

title: First to the Ball
description: It's a small house in a middle-class Washington neighborhood, and inside it feels even smaller -- so small that it strains to contain the plaques and pictures and framed newspaper scraps on its walls. People think Willie Wood must have a lot of money, but he doesn't. Hanging over the slender mantelpiece is a photograph, taken around the time that Wood's football team, the Green Bay Packers, won the first Super Bowl, in 1967. In it he stands alone, at his free safety position, right leg forward, hands on his hips, lips slightly apart, waiting for the snap of the ball. What regularly occurred next on the football field was what inspired the National Football League Hall of Fame, in 1989, to commission the massive bronze bust that sits on the mantel next to the photograph.

title: 1980: Lake Placid, N.Y.
description: This Adirondack village with 3,000 permanent residents bills itself as the last small-town Olympics, and the claim is probably legitimate. The number of athletes (1,071) and nations represented (37) in Lake Placid have more than doubled since the 1980 Games, best remembered for Eric Heiden's five gold medals in speed skating, and the scrappy United States hockey team's semifinal game victory over the formerly omnipotent Russians.

title: At 33, Rose Is Ripe for a New Challenge
description: Jalen Rose will return today to Madison Square Garden, where he is perhaps remembered most for a play that has become part of Knicks lore.

title: Detroit's 'Organic Energy'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Kentucky's Underground Economy
description: Lexington, Ky. - WHEN you fly over the Appalachians of eastern Kentucky, you can see the gray scars on the mountains, pockmarks reaching far to the north and east that are the results of a kind of strip-mining called mountaintop removal. Most Kentuckians never see that part of the state because it is so isolated, and most people across the nation (which burns the premium coal from these mountains) don't know how costly their cheap electricity really is. It could break your heart to know.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Everybody's Business column last Sunday, about executive pay at the UAL Corporation, misstated part of the compensation for the leader of another company in 2004. Lee R. Raymond, then the chief executive of Exxon Mobil, received restricted stock worth $28 million; he did not receive 28 million shares of restricted stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HERKO, ROBERT W.
description: HERKO--Robert W. Of Harrison, NY, died Saturday, February 4, 2006, after a long illness with lung cancer. He is survived by his wife Robin, his two sons, Russell and Randall, his daughter Regina and step-daughters, Royce Abrams and Amy Kean. His seven grandchildren, Collin, Gillian, Shea, Cassidy, Peri, Lee and Nicole. The lights of his life. Bob served in the 11th Airborne as a young man. He went on to become an accountant and an international businessman. The funeral will be held on Sunday, February 5, 2006, at 9:45 am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY. Donations in his memory can be made to the American Lung Association or Calvary Hospital, Bronx, NY. May he rest in peace.

description: EVEN at the time, Lauren Siegel knew that ditching her studio apartment in Midtown Manhattan to move to Brooklyn with her boyfriend was risky.

description: Customers who frequent the Newark outpost of the coffee-and-peanut purveyor T. M. Ward may be surprised at what they find once they walk into its sister location in Chatham. Instead of a bustling store jammed with shelf after shelf of bulk candy, nuts and coffee, the Chatham customer sees: Gift baskets? Pottery? Crackers and gourmet salsa?

title: Here a Planet, There a Planet
description: Astronomers announced last week that they had measured a large ice ball far beyond Pluto, first discovered last year. The object, nicknamed Xena for now, is about 1,900 miles wide, or a third wider than Pluto.

title: Turin
description: WHY GO NOW From Feb. 10 to 26, Turin will play host the 20th Winter Olympic Games, surpassing Rome, Florence and Venice as the place to be in Italy. During that time, organizers expect 2,500 athletes, 10,000 journalists and more than a million spectators to descend upon the city. From March 10 to 19, it will revive its Olympic spirit as the host of the Paralympic Games.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about adult siblings who live together misstated the age of one of the sisters who share a Chelsea apartment. Yael Kohen is 26, not 25.

title: MODEL TODDLER
description: It's Fashion Week in New York, the twice-a-year crunch of competition among designers to grab retailer buyers' attention. How does a designer become noticed? Coaxing celebrities to attend a show is a longtime ploy; so are runway antics. (The most irresistible: the designer Miguel Adrover once sent a live goat to walk the ramp with a model.)

title: The Mayor's Prudent Budget
description: The first look at New York City budgets almost always reveals horrifying, multi-billion-dollar gaps that by law have to be closed. During his first four years in office, Mayor Michael Bloomberg became very adept at telling New Yorkers why and how the city would do more with less. This year he faces a new dilemma. The city is floating in black ink, a surprise surplus of some $3.3 billion.

title: Yes, Towns Can Seize Land, but Aren't There Limits?
description: NEW ROCHELLE - ROBERT AND GLORIA CONNER have run their Royal Child Care Center in a squat commercial building in this city's downtown for nearly a decade. But their time here may be running out.

title: I Said, 'Camera Left!'
description: With a sweater and a scowl, Robert Montgomery Knight has loomed over college basketball for nearly four decades, winning more games than any coach except Dean Smith. The vast majority of Knight's victories came during his 29 seasons at Indiana University, where he won three national championships. In his second act, as head coach of Texas Tech since 2001, Knight has traded his roster of schoolboy all-stars for a spottier collection of second-tier recruits and has molded them into contenders who last year reached the N.C.A.A. tournament's Sweet 16. On Feb. 19, he takes a star turn on "Knight School," on ESPN, in which 16 students submit to his grueling workouts and volatile temper for a shot at a spot on Tech's basketball team next year. We caught up with the coach by phone.

title: 100 Shots, With Props
description: THE Barcelona Bar may be the one place where drinking is good for you -- to a point anyway.

title: Guy Walks Into a Bar
description: Recently my friend Brandon and I walked along Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn looking for a place to watch a football game and to quench our thirst for a cold brew. I pushed open the door and we were headed for a pair of empty stools when we both stopped cold. The bar was packed with under-age patrons.

title: The New Wild and Crazy Guys
description: IT'S 10:30 on a Thursday night, and Andy Samberg and Jason Sudeikis, two new faces on "Saturday Night Live," are speeding downtown in a cab, checking their hair. They had spent the day in wigs, shooting a mock music video. They're headed to meet Seth Meyers, a five-season veteran, and Bill Hader, another rookie, at a favorite post-rehearsal haunt called Dublin, in the West Village at Hudson and 11th Streets.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about Iona College misstated the surname of a spokeswoman for the college. She is Meghan Finn, not Flynn.

title: Costa Rican boom
The Fated Sky
From Pastime to Nap Time
description: Spring training camps open this month with a tough new steroid policy in place and the sport, in a sense, restored to its proper historical balance. We can assume there will be no more seasons with multiple players hitting 60-plus home runs, nor the abomination of a 73-home-run season. Record books may one day even include asterisks for steroid-era feats, and future sluggers could find themselves chasing two distinct sets of numbers: the Ruth-Maris and the McGwire-Bonds standards, with the latter considered as unreachable as some of the track and field marks set by doped athletes in the 1980's and early 90's.

title: OOPS
description: Whole Foods Market limits the cash pay of its chief executive, John P. Mackey, to 14 times the salary of its typical worker -- unless, of course, the boss has forgotten to exercise some stock options. Last year, the company gave Mr. Mackey $460,000 on top of his $356,000 salary and $126,000 bonus, to make up for stock options that "expired unexercised due to a company error," according to the 2006 proxy statement. The company handed over the value of the options on their last day because an employee failed to remind him to exercise them, said Amy H. Schaefer, a spokeswoman.

title: Carson Makes Hall at Last; Party Goes On Without Him
description: DETROIT, Feb. 4 - When the call Harry Carson wanted finally arrived, his phone went unanswered and his voice mailbox was full, presumably with a mix of good wishes and heartfelt congratulations.

description: Golden parachutes are so five minutes ago. Today's executives prefer platinum.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LASKY, ESTELLE AND CHARLES
description: LASKY--Estelle and Charles February 6th On this, your anniversary, we continue to treasure your loving example, as will your nine great-grandchildren. George and Joyce

title: Diabetic Brothers Beat Odds With Grit and Luck
description: When Robert Cleveland was a boy, in place of a birthday cake his mother wrapped an oatmeal box in colored paper and put candles on top. "I never had any sweets as a child," he said. "Never."

title: Follow Me
description: That irritating American Express commercial is blaring again during the college basketball telecasts. The scrappy Polish guy from Chicago is standing in front of his bench, his feet firmly planted on the holy hardwood of Duke's Cameron Indoor Stadium, his jaw locked with intensity. For years, Mike Krzyzewski, the legendary Coach K, has been pounding your team, my team and every other damn team in America, but here he is saying that he's not, really, all about basketball. His purpose is a higher one. "I don't look at myself as a basketball coach," he says in the ad. "I look at myself as a leader who just happens to coach basketball."

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Detroit nightspots misstated the history of a rock club. St. Andrew's Hall was originally a meeting hall, not a Catholic school gymnasium.
