title: Protesters set fire to Danish embassy in Beirut
In Memory of 1906, a City Shakes Like a Bowl Full of Jell-O
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3 - In this centennial year of the great 1906 earthquake, San Francisco has tectonic shifts on the brain. Among the planned commemorations of the event are "Symphony No. 1: The Earthquake," to be played by the Contra Costa Wind Symphony, an "Earthquake Walking Tour of San Francisco" by the Northern California Geological Society and a tour of campus retrofit projects at the University of California, Berkeley.

title: Yet Again, Taurasi An All-Star In College
description: AS if three consecutive national championships and two Naismith Player of the Year awards weren't enough, the former University of Connecticut star Diana Taurasi earned even more validation as one of the greatest players ever in college basketball when she was named to the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 25th Anniversary Team on Tuesday.

title: A Fairer Election System
description: To the Editor:

title: Rome
description: WHY GO NOW With the Winter Olympics in full swing in northern Italy from Feb. 10 to 26, there has never been a better opportunity or excuse to sneak in a side trip to Rome. After all, you didn't come all this way just to see Turin, did you?

title: Luggage Companies Bet That 4 Wheels Are Better Than 2
description: Tired of your wheelie tipping over when you round a corner in the airport? Luggage companies are now pitching upright suitcases with four wheels instead of two.

title: East Sixth Street
description: Just as the city always evolves, so does its restaurant scene. East Sixth Street between First and Second Avenues, for example, was once a unified front of mostly undistinguished Bangladeshi and Indian restaurants, but now it serves up everything from Peruvian to Cajun and Japanese, along with more interesting and authentic Indian fare.

title: A Rosenberg Takes On the Government, This Time Using the Law as a Means of Protest
description: A profile of Rachel Meeropol, the lead lawyer for a group of Muslim immigrants suing the United States government, explains why she went to work for the Center for Constitutional Rights.

title: When the Grass Was Greener
description: Last month, Alexi Lalas, the great American soccer defender who in his playing days wore a goatee in the Hell's Angels style, was shown the new documentary called "Once in a Lifetime." The film's subject, the legendary New York Cosmos, is something of an annoyance to him. Although the Cosmos haven't played in more than 20 years, the club's name still rings in Lalas's ears. Last year, he took the job running the MetroStars, the Major League Soccer team that now inhabits the Cosmos' old pitch, Giants Stadium. Where the Cosmos played to crowds of 70,000, Lalas's club draws an average of about 15,000. And unlike the international cover boys who populated the Cosmos -- Pel, Franz Beckenbauer and Giorgio Chinaglia -- the MetroStars must flip deep into the sports pages to find their 200-word game reports. "I wish a discussion of the present was a bit more prevalent," Lalas moaned, "but the comparisons to the Cosmos are inevitable."

title: The Pleasures of the Text
description: I recently dated an avid texter. Initially, I didn't see this as much of a problem. But the texting was used far more than calling. I liked the sound of this man's voice. I liked getting calls.

title: A Fine Old Conflict
description: I MARRIED MY MOTHER-IN-LAW

title: The Mysterious Trail of a Treasure, Retraced
description: Correction Appended

title: Something Happening Here
description: Correction Appended

title: Pentagon Hones Its Strategy on Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 - The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff has completed a new, classified counterterrorism strategy that for the first time orders the military to focus on nine areas identified as necessary for any terrorist network to operate, senior Pentagon officials say, and warns that ill-conceived military operations could add to terrorists' ranks.

title: Corrections
description: A photo caption on the Evening Hours page last Sunday, with a report about a fund-raiser for the American Academy in Berlin, misidentified a couple. They were David Bowker and Amanda Bowker, not John vanden Heuvel Pierce and Marie-Nolle Pierce, who also attended the event.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUTIN, TRUDE
description: BUTIN--Trude. On February 3, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Sam. Devoted mother of Charles and Sue, and Mitchell. Loving grandmother of Marisa, Scott, Sam, Caroline and Sally. In our hearts forever and a day. Services today, 2:30 pm, Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows; 718-445-0300.

title: Pedal-to-the-Metal 101
description: I was accelerating fast out of a 90-degree corner, heading into a double-S turn that led to the short back straightaway. The bulky Mustang GT's V-8 whined -- R.P.M.'s approaching 8,000 -- and at least two tires were screeching as their edges barely held the tarmac. I was hard on the clutch, hard on the brakes, hard on the motor. And that's how my instructors at the Bob Bondurant School of High-Performance Driving wanted it. Because auto racing, done properly, is brutal on a car. To work as a race mechanic is Sisyphean. Professional teams rebuild their engines nearly every weekend, and Bondurant employs a crew of technicians to constantly replace the parts ruined by hacks like me. You might hesitate to run third gear to the redline in your Volvo, but there's little reason to worry at Bondurant. As one instructor put it, while my class coughed inside a cloud of atomized tire rubber, "You're here to push the limits of the car."

title: Baseball's New World Order
description: The knock against the World Series, at least in name, has always been its provincialism: the champion of all Earth comes from only a handful of American teams. O.K., and one or two Canadian teams. That's hardly a world series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAHN, HELENE
description: HAHN--Helene. Died February 2, 2006 at 100 years of age. An amazing woman and role model. Owner of the former Hahn's Delicatessen. Beloved wife of the late Isidor. Beloved mother of Sanford and the late Carol Glasser. Loving sister of the late Miriam Schloss and the late David Hausman. Cherished grandmother of Barbara, Jonathan, William, Laurie and Daniel. Service Sunday, February 5, 11:30am, Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th St & Madison.

title: Carmakers' Big Idea: Think Small
description: Dundee, Mich. - THE writer E. F. Schumacher would be proud. Across the automobile market in America, there is an evolving realization that small is beautiful.

title: Closing the Hole in Drug Rehab for Youths
description: MENDHAM - SINCE setting up shop on the outskirts of this Morris County town in 1992, Daytop New Jersey, a residential treatment center for youths who abuse drugs and alcohol, has won plaudits from politicians and health care professionals and -- most important -- from parents and the young people themselves.

title: Wife, Widow, Lover
description: GOOD WOMEN

title: A Hot Trend on Campus: Majoring in Health Care
description: Eighteen months after the University of Colorado created a department to prepare undergraduates for a broad range of careers in health care, from medicine to physical therapy to physician assistant, that department already has 1,200 students, making it the second most popular on campus.

title: This Man Really Hates Duke
description: Will Blythe writes that his book was born when an editor observed him curled on the floor, paper clips stuck to his skin, trying through some higher power to alter the course of a Duke-North Carolina basketball game. The editor suggested that maybe Blythe should harness that, er, passion. The result is "To Hate Like This Is to Be Happy Forever" (HarperCollins, $25). The book begs comparisons to Nick Hornby's $(3$)Fever Pitch$(2$) but owes its debt more than anything to maybe the greatest sports novel of all time, Frederick Exley's "A Fan's Notes." Blythe knows a thing or two about bitterness and longing, but tempers these twin emotions with intelligence and humor and even generosity. It goes without saying that if you hate Duke you should read this book. But if you love Duke, or you love basketball, or you just love the kind of sportswriting that comes along so rarely you can count the classics on one hand, you should read this book. Joel Lovell

title: Harsh words for Putin from the U.S. on rights
A New Stadium: Who Benefits?
description: To the Editor:

title: Questions for Daniel C. Dennett
description: Daniel C. Dennett seems to be advocating a reductionist understanding not just of faith and religion but ultimately of what it means to be human (Deborah Solomon, Jan. 22). Can he really explain the beauty of Bach's music as merely the right combination of sound waves tickling his eardrums?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KEAN, MALLORY G. B.
description: KEAN--Mallory G. B. Of Far Hills, NJ, suddenly on January 27, 2006. Friend to many new and old, she gave so much to us all, touching more people than anyone can count. A thoroughly developed appreciation for life in all its forms and of the mysteries of nature for which she had a deep love. It is not the years in our lives, but the life in our years. Mallory was the cherished wife, mentor and partner of Robert W. Kean III. In addition to Roy, she was a loving and engaged role model and friend in so many ways to her stepchildren Bobby, Philip and Nina Kean, who will always have her in their hearts. Mallory's unforgettable electric energy continues with us all. Memorial donations can be made in Mallory's name to The Museum of the City of New York Directors' Council, 1220 Fifth Ave, NYC 10029; and to Memorial Sloane-Kettering Cancer Center at P.O. Box 27106, NYC 10087-7106. Mallory's memorial service will be at Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street, NYC, on Thursday, February 9th, at 4 pm. No flowers please.

title: Sarajevo in peacetime: Ghosts and frantic night life
In Darfur, Tiny Steps Toward Policing a Lawless Land
description: MENAWASHEI, Sudan, Feb. 2 - It is no longer surprising in the heart of Darfur when men on camelback attack defenseless civilians, when the civilians grab what they can and run for their lives or even when people linked to Sudan's security forces are implicated in the violence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOMERFIELD, RALPH MURRAY
description: SOMERFIELD--Ralph Murray died at home January 31 in Floral Park, NY. Ralph was a life long resident of NYC, born of immigrant parents, Benjamin and Sophie, in 1915. His childhood was immersed with the joys of dance, opera, the Yiddish Theater, and a precious friendship with Manny Dichter. He was blessed to find his true love, Elsie, at 16 and spent the next 73 years with her at his side through all life's joys and travails. He had a long creative career as a marketing executive holding senior positions at Bulova, Lucien Piccard, including Vice President and Secretary at Gruen. A talented tennis player since childhood, he competed in many tournaments including winning the Sears Tennis Tournament in his 70's beating competitors 30 years his junior. His love of tennis was only exceeded by his love of chocolate to which he attributed his long life. A Shakespeare enthusiast, he often quoted from his work to make points and entertain friends and family. After his retirement he volunteered at LIJ Hospital where he organized educational conferences and read to seriously ill children. He was appointed by the Governor to the Board of Visitors of Queens Children's Psychiatric Center & was its Secretary. He was a fearless fighter for children against the political powers favoring funding cuts for the disadvantaged. He sponsored dance therapy programs and donated musical equipment through the Ralph and Elsie Somerfield Arts Enrichment Fund. He attended every class conducted by the Ailey dance teachers. He enjoyed lively debates at Temple Beth-El Torah study. He was preceded in death by his beloved wife, Elsie. He is deeply mourned by his daughters, Barbara and Benita; his son in law, John; Joan and Bill; his cousins, Bonnie and Sven and his devoted friend, Clem. "May a flight of angels, sing thee to thy rest." Donations in Ralph Somerfield's memory may be made to: Queens Children's Psychiatric Center, Att. Carol/K. Little, 74-03 Commonwealth Blvd, Bellrose, NY 11426 or National Audubon Society.

title: CALENDAR
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items should be submitted by mail at least three weeks in advance to New Jersey Cultural Calendar, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Excerpt From 'The Feminine Mystique'
description: Following is an excerpt from "The Feminine Mystique," by Betty Friedan.

title: For a General, a Tough Mission: Building the Army
description: FORT KNOX, Ky., Feb. 1 - From his office in the command center here, where dozens of recruiters answer questions about military life via e-mail and chat rooms, Maj. Gen. Thomas P. Bostick is trying to retool the Army's strategy for fighting a war within a war: persuading young people and their families that the military is a good choice, even when combat duty is almost certain.

title: Rebecca Paley and Daniel DiClerico
description: Rebecca Jacqueline Paley and Daniel James DiClerico were married last evening at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in Manhattan. Rabbi Ruth A. Zlotnick officiated.

title: Skiers Hope to Meet Up on Olympic Podium
description: CHAMONIX, France, Feb. 4 - When Julia Mancuso travels to Turin, Italy, on Monday for the Olympic Winter Games, she will have more than just a recent athletic breakthrough putting wind in her sails.

title: Gym Gym Revolution
description: West Virginia took one giant dance step for physical fitness last week when it announced plans to fight obesity in schoolchildren by adding the video game Dance Dance Revolution to its official physical fitness curriculum.

title: In Bush's Budget Plan, Shifting Priorities
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 - President Bush wants to spend more on bird flu and the physical sciences next year, but would freeze the budget of the National Institutes of Health and would slightly cut federal support for research on cancer and heart disease, two of the leading killers of Americans, budget documents show.

title: A Billion-Dollar Bet
description: SECAUCUS - TWENTY FOUR years and six governors ago, a billboard company bought a patch of rail yard next to the New Jersey Turnpike for about $5,000 an acre and began to hatch plans for a new urban center, its hub a train station linking transit lines from all over New Jersey.

title: Has the Trickster Hero Struck Again?
description: The not-for-profit Harlem gallery Triple Candie bills its show dedicated to the notoriously elusive artist David Hammons as an "unauthorized retrospective." After five years of trying to secure his cooperation or that of collectors and dealers, the gallery opted to include no actual works of art; instead the walls are decorated with photocopies and computer printouts of images of his work from catalogs, exhibition brochures and Web sites.

title: The Last of Her Kind
Paid Notice: Deaths   BALK, MADELINE
description: BALK - Madeline. Passed away after a very brief illness February 1st at New York Presbyterian Hospital-Cornell Weill. Caring daughter of the late Ethel and Joseph Balk. Loving sister of Daniel Balk and the late Leon Balk and Pauline Manevitz. Beloved Aunt and second "Mother" to Sheila Manevitz, Alan Manevitz, MD, Larry and Jenny Manevitz, Sharon Lauer and John Wolf, June and Gary Miller, Joyce and Steve Wasserman. Great-Aunt to Craig, Claire, Suzanne, Hillary, Jeffrey, Zevi, Shouli, Miriam, Kehat and Hanania. Funeral Services will be at the Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 E. 51 St (between 2nd & 3rd Ave, Manhattan), Sunday, February 5 at 9 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The National Mental Health Project, 60 Sutton Place So., Suite 1CN, NY, NY 10022

title: Through the Quarterback's Eyes
description: Many National Football League fans share a secret shame. They can fake their way through a Super Bowl party, making intelligent-sounding noises about the major players, but in private moments they admit to themselves that they don't really understand the game's complexities. Trap blocks? Defensive audibles? Zone defense, cover 2, end around -- say what? Phil Simms, the Super Bowl-winning quarterback for the New York Giants who is now a CBS analyst, feels everyone's pain. For about two hours each day, Simms pores over game film at his home in Franklin Lakes, N.J., deciding which subtleties can be conveyed on a telecast. One morning during the playoffs, Simms invited Play to join him at a film-study session and offered a few hints on four plays you might see in the big game.

title: The Gladwell Effect
description: "PEOPLE are experience rich and theory poor," the writer Malcolm Gladwell said recently. "People who are busy doing things -- as opposed to people who are busy sitting around, like me, reading and having coffee in coffee shops -- don't have opportunities to kind of collect and organize their experiences and make sense of them."

title: Yonkers, Unburied
description: Under the skin of downtown Yonkers, under the antique buildings, the weary storefronts, the chipped expanses of desolate brick, the industrial remnants and the blandly pretty new construction, there is a proud and soulful city. There is a river, too: the paved-over Saw Mill, which moseys through downtown darkness for 2,000 feet before emptying into the Hudson.

title: Laugh Lines
description: Jay Leno

title: The Mensch Who Didn't Get Away
description: ROBIN GORMAN NEWMAN describes a mensch as "a decent, responsible person even your mother would love." Ms. Gorman Newman, 45, of Great Neck, has been married to her husband, Marc, for 13 years and likes to think of herself as a "Mrs. Mensch."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZWERLING, RUTH
description: ZWERLING--Ruth. Formerly of Yonkers and Hollywood, FL, wife of the late Eric Zwerling, devoted mother of Susan Wolfe (Robert) and John Zwerling (Pat West), grandmother of Jeffrey Kirschenbaum and Laura Rabishaw, great-grandmother of Elana, Aaron, Jacob and Zoe and sister of Abe Hoffman. Passed away February 1, at age 91, in San Francisco.

title: Preserving a Theater Legacy in Westport
description: THE White Barn Theater in Westport, which last staged a production in 2002 but was once a haven for new writers and independent productions, is being sold. But in an agreement with the theater's owner, the Westport Country Playhouse will preserve and advance its legacy.

title: The King of Reggaetn
description: A long time ago, before he started draping himself in huge diamond medallions, before flocks of teenage girls began trailing him nearly everywhere, before he had a staff of 15 working day and night on the maintenance of his image, Daddy Yankee had a regular name, which was Raymond Ayala. When he is at home in Puerto Rico, his parents still call him Raymond, as does his older brother Nomar, who works as one of his managers, his wife, Mirredys Gonzalez, who is another manager, and his former neighbors at Villa Kennedy, the run-down San Juan public-housing project where he lived until a few years ago. To just about everybody else, he is Daddy Yankee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANK, ELIZABETH POPE
description: FRANK--Elizabeth Pope. 91, longtime women's magazine editor, died January 30, 2006 after a lengthy illness at Meadow Lakes in Hightstown, NJ. The daughter of the late Melville and Belle Oberfelder Welt, she was born December 9, 1914 in Detroit. Mrs. Frank earned her B.A. at Vassar College in 1936. She edited the school paper and was a well-known liberal activist. Her classmates named her "Most Likely to Start a Revolution". Her career began at Look Magazine in Des Moines, IA in 1936. In 1938, she married Vernon Pope, the magazine's founding editor. After the couple moved to New York, she contributed to McCall's, the Ladies Home Journal, Redbook, Reader's Digest and Good Housekeeping. Divorced from Mr. Pope in 1961, she married Morton Frank, the Publisher, President and CEO of the Sunday supplement Family Weekly, in 1963. They were married until his death in 1989. Mr. Pope died in 1995. Known as "Betty", Mrs. Frank served as features editor and articles editor of Good Housekeeping. After retiring in 1977, she served as an editorial consultant to Family Circle magazine. Mrs. Frank won numerous journalism awards, including the National Magazine Award for feature writing and the Penny-Missouri Magazine Award. Survivors include her daughter, Barbara Pope, her son John Pope. Also surviving: three stepchildren: Allan Dodds Frank, Michael Frank and Marilyn Dodds Frank; granddaughters Lindsey Jane Pope, Cara Hall and two step-grandchildren. Mrs. Frank's other child, Anne Elizabeth Pope, died of cancer in 1994. A Memorial service will be held March 10, 2006 at 12:15pm at the Cosmopolitan Club in NY. In her memory, the family requests contributions to Planned Parenthood.

title: The Room Service May Be Great, but What About Those Trans Fats?
description: To the growing list of menu adjustments hotels are making to satisfy diet-conscious guests add: food free of trans fats.

title: The Animal Self
description: Siebert considers the question of whether both human and nonhuman animals possess personalities or whether personality is a distinctively human trait. He might, however, have considered another alternative: perhaps neither has personalities. If by "personality," we mean a suite of emotional and behavioral dispositions, then it seems chauvinistic to deny this of nonhuman animals. If it means something more, something soul-like, then we ought to take seriously the possibility (explored extensively by the philosopher Daniel C. Dennett, interviewed in the same issue) that no such phenomenon exists.

title: Palestinians Set Meeting of Parliament
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 4 - The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, and the Hamas leadership agreed Saturday to convene parliament on Feb. 16 for talks on a new government, which Hamas said it hoped to form before the end of the month.

title: High Noon at the Not-So-O.K. Corral
description: AT the intersection of Pelham Parkway South and Stillwell Avenue, backed by a railroad track and a tangle of power lines, there sits what is surely the saddest stable in the Bronx. The barn at Bronxbuster is scrawled with graffiti, its windows have been blown out and seven or eight mournful horses poke their heads from the tumbledown stalls where customers lodge their animals.

title: And for Perfect Attendance, Johnny Gets... a Car
description: CHELSEA, Mass. - Attendance at Chelsea High School had hovered at a disappointing 90 percent for years, and school officials were determined to turn things around. So, last fall they decided to give students in this poverty-stung city just north of Boston a little extra motivation: students would get $25 for every quarter they had perfect attendance and another $25 if they managed perfect attendance all year.

title: In Europe, newspapers torn over prophet cartoons
Pistons' MilicicIs Pining For Some Playing Time
description: As the Detroit Pistons rush to dispense with the regular season and return to the finals for the third consecutive season, one of their players, Darko Milicic, has been virtually invisible.

title: Evolution Measure Splits State Legislators in Utah

Prayers are commonplace, and lawmakers speak of their relationship with God in ordinary conversation.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 4 - For nearly half of Saturday's game between the Nets and the Miami Heat, Shaquille O'Neal had a front-row seat. And even when he was on the floor, the Nets stood tall.

title: Two Aquariums Swap Sharks
description: The state's two aquariums swapped sharks on Wednesday. The Maritime Aquarium at Norwalk traded two juvenile sand tiger sharks for Veronica, Mystic Aquarium's hulking 9-foot-long, 210-pound sand tiger.

description: SAL OLIVA had a hunch that the woman he knew as Cha would make a great firefighter, even though, at 5-foot-1, she didn't look the part.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WASSERSTEIN, WENDY J.
description: WASSERSTEIN -- Wendy J. On January 30, 2006 loving mother of Lucy Jane, cherished daughter of Lola, beloved sister of Bruce, Georgette, and the late Sandra. Aunt of Tajlei, Jennifer, Melissa, Samantha, Pamela, Oliver, Ben, Scoop, Maxwell, Jack, and Dash. She was a source of laughter, love, and kindness and will be deeply missed. Memorial Service at Lincoln Center Theater in the Vivian Beaumont Theater on March 13, 2006 at 4:00 PM.

title: State Checking Dozens of Sites for Hidden Contaminants
description: WITH satellite photographs all over the Internet, images of Long Island as seen from above are only a few mouse clicks away. Views beneath the Island's surface and a clear picture of what may be seeping up and down are not so easy to come by.

title: The American Jumping Bean
description: When Shawn Marion, the 27-year-old Phoenix Suns forward, entered the National Basketball Association seven years ago, the television commentator Kenny Smith dubbed him the Matrix for his uncanny ability to spring from the court and spar with opponents in midair. That explosiveness is crucial to his unusual rebounding prowess; at 6-foot-7, he's the shortest player among the league's top 10 rebounders. (Last time we looked, he ranked fourth and was second in double-doubles -- shorthand for at least 10 points and 10 rebounds in a game.) "I could see it if I was 6-9," Marion says. "But I'm 6-7, and I'm averaging a double-double. I mean, that's not realistic."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOODMAN, NORMAN H.
description: GOODMAN--Norman H. 83, died peacefully January 24, at his Greenwich Village home, with his wife Barbara at his side. They had been married 60 years. Besides his wife, he is survived by his daughters, Vanina and Chryse, their husbands, six grandchildren, and his brothers, Peter & Thomas and their families. After time in college, military service and art school, Norman joined the family hosiery business. When stretch nylon was introduced to the U.S., he was instrumental in the development of the first Danskin tights. He had a lifelong passion for photography and a keen interest in the arts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WICKBORN, JESSIE (NEE WHYTE)
description: WICKBORN -- Jessie (nee Whyte). Born June 6, 1910, in Brooklyn, NY. Passed away January 31, 2006, at Twining Village, Holland, PA. Wife of the late Arthur I. Wickborn, daughter of the late Alexander and Ella Whyte, and sister of the late Robert M. Whyte. Beloved aunt of Robert M. Whyte Jr. and his wife Carol of Baldwin, NY. Grandaunt of Katherine and Andrew, and great-grandaunt of Samuel, Jack, Douglas and Allison. Corporate officer of Somerset Importers, Ltd., New York, NY, and member of the Women's Association of Allied Beverage Industries for 34 years, the last 25 of which she served as President. Longtime member of the New York Chapter of the Adirondack Mountain Club. Burial private at Mount Olive Cemetery, Middle Village, New York.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the satirical newspaper The Onion misstated the number of published collections of fake newspaper articles from The Onion. Although the term "Volume 16" appears on the cover of the most recent collection, there have been only seven.

description: Some fans of the Pittsburgh Steelers and Seattle Seahawks were willing to pay thousands for a ticket to the Super Bowl.

title: See You in the Food Court
description: Trade shows usually involve travel. Heres one that involves going no farther than your computer: The National Real Estate On-Line Convention & Exposition. I havent quite figured out what it is beyond an amalgam of Web sites, but it seems to include speakers, booths, door prizes and even a food court. And an abundance of exclamation points! Attendance, as it were, is free. See you there!  JOYCE COHEN

description: DETROIT, Feb. 5 - The 12th man? The Seattle Seahawks might argue that in Super Bowl XL, the moniker belonged not to their exuberant fans but to the officiating crew.

title: Katowice Journal; Coal Tells of a Hard History, but the Future Is Here, Too
description: KATOWICE, Poland, Jan. 31 - When you step off the plane at the small airport in this southern Polish city, the first thing you notice is the acrid odor of burning coal, a smell common in Communist countries. But Communism officially ended some 16 years ago, when Poland liberated itself from the twin domination of the Soviet Union and its own Communist Party.

title: Skipping Across the Globe and Through Time
description: Osvaldo Golijov's music makes a powerful case for wandering. Having spent stretches of his life in Argentina and Israel before coming to the United States, he has soaked up the music and poetry of several cultures -- ancient, modern, popular, traditional, formal and improvised -- and given them equal weight in his creative psyche. Composing, for him, seems to be a matter of resequencing the DNA of these styles, balancing their influences differently in each of his works. His pieces may tilt toward his Latin or Jewish roots, or toward influences from other, less predictable directions. Increasingly, they draw on several of these flavors at once, but the mlange they yield is identifiably Mr. Golijov's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SWEENEY, ETHEL
description: SWEENEY--Ethel. 83, died in Brooklyn, NY, on January 25, 2006, with friends and family by her side. Born April 1, 1922, in Scarsdale, NY, she lived most of her life in Brooklyn Heights. Daughter of H. Blanche Sweeney and Edward C. Sweeney, and niece of Ethel L. Armstead. Ethel received a BA from NYU and began her career with the law firm Sullivan & Cromwell. She worked most of her professional life as a publicity writer for Time and Life Inc. Ethel was a member of the New York West Side Tennis Club. She enjoyed skiing and hiking, was a devotee of the New York Philharmonic, frequented theatre, and travelled extensively. Survivors include her sisters, Dorothy B. Brown and Laura E. Sweeney, nephews Robert Brown and Richard Brown, grandnieces Cara Russell, Rebecca Brown, and Kirsten Brown, and great-grandniece Penelope Russell.

Paid Notice: Deaths   ASH, DAVID H.
description: ASH--David H. July 4, 1922-January 24, 2006. David passed with his loved ones at his side. Born in E. Norwalk, Conn., David was preceded in death by parents Bessi and Harry, brothers Jacob and Barney, and sisters Miriam, Nedi and Ruth. His children Jodi, Marc and Robin, his grandson Morgan, and a loving extended family survive him. David was a graduate of Stamford High, Class of 1940. After graduation he served as an officer and fighter pilot in the United States Air Force. His passion for all things cars, especially racecars, led him to a highly accomplished career in the automotive world. He was a regular and distinguished competitor at Sebring, America's premier race. Between 1952 and 1957, David earned the title of "Mr. MG" as the only driver to start and finish five twelve-hour-long endurance races at Sebring in five tries. He also set numerous "land speed" records on the Bonneville Salt Flats in 1957. David later pursued a career in automotive journalism. His pieces appeared in "The New York Times," "Argosy Magazine" and "Esquire Magazine." He also served as publisher and editor of "Sports Car Magazine," and from 1966-1977 authored and published "Automobile Almanac." An avid sports fan, he "Loved the Yankees, and never, ever gave up on the NY Giants." His most cherished times were spent with his children on Fire Island, fishing, swimming and glassing. Family and his many friends will miss his unending quest for knowledge, enthusiasm, energy, and charm. Memorial services are planned for Sunday, February 12th. Family and friends may contact 617.308.6441.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KEAN, MALLORY G. B.
description: KEAN--Mallory G. B. Of Far Hills, NJ, suddenly on January 27, 2006. Friend to many new and old, she gave so much to us all, touching more people than anyone can count. A thoroughly developed appreciation for life in all its forms and of the mysteries of nature for which she had a deep love. It is not the years in our lives, but the life in our years. Mallory was the cherished wife, mentor and partner of Robert W. Kean III. In addition to Roy, she was a loving and engaged role model and friend in so many ways to her stepchildren Bobby, Philip and Nina Kean, who will always have her in their hearts. Mallory's unforgettable electric energy continues with us all. Memorial donations can be made in Mallory's name to The Museum of the City of New York Directors' Council, 1220 Fifth Ave, NYC 10029; and to Memorial Sloane-Kettering Cancer Center at P.O. Box 27106, NYC 10087-7106. Mallory's memorial service will be at Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street, NYC, on Thursday, February 9th, at 4 pm. No flowers please.

title: Arts, Briefly; Henry Roth Remembered
description: By proclamation of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, tomorrow will be Henry Roth Day in New York. This tribute to the author best known for the 1934 novel "Call It Sleep" honors him on the 100th anniversary of his birth. Mr. Roth, who died at 89 in 1995, will also be the subject of "A Hundred Years of Henry Roth" tomorrow in the South Court Auditorium of the New York Public Library, at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street. Free and open to the public, a reception and exhibition at 5:30 p.m. will be followed at 6:45 with readings, a discussion and reminiscences. Participants include the author Cynthia Ozick; Roslyn Targ, Mr. Roth's agent; Hugh Roth, his son; and Steven G. Kellman, whose biography of Mr. Roth was published last year. LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

title: The Defenders Don't Let Up, and It's a Long Way Down
description: Zia Mahmood, the colorful Pakistani who lives primarily in London but has a pied--high-rise in Manhattan, says that if you never double a making contract, you are not doubling often enough. These days opponents bid almost whenever they hold 13 cards, making overcalls that never would have been considered 25 years ago. But if an opponent tries to disrupt your auction, inflicting a heavy penalty will make him think twice next time.

title: Wrong Fix for Foreign Aid
description: Ever since Washington began giving foreign aid, administrations have been coming up with plans to reform it. Now it's Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice's turn. She has put a single official, reporting directly to her, in charge of coordinating the State Department's multiple foreign aid programs. Duplicate efforts are a problem, but they are not the main problem, and Ms. Rice's proposed solution could easily end up cutting programs that fight disease, send children to school or provide clean water.

title: The Antiquities Mess
description: The Euphronios krater, which the Metropolitan Museum bought in 1972, exemplifies the paradox of many antiquities. It is a staggeringly beautiful object, painted some 2,500 years ago, with a decidedly unattractive past. The Italian government claims that it was stolen from an Etruscan tomb. The Metropolitan Museum claims, as museums often do, the narrow legality of having purchased it in good faith.

title: Arts, Briefly; USA Tops on Cable
description: Among advertiser-supported cable channels, USA Network was No. 1 in prime time for January in total viewers, as well as the crucial adult demographics advertisers seek. Its victory in Nielsen's estimates was due in large part to the channel's two most successful hits, which are aesthetic opposites: Tony Shalhoub's fussy detective on "Monk," left, and Vince McMahon's boorish wrestlers on "WWE Monday Night Raw." For the whole day of programming in January, Nickelodeon was the top-ranked channel, as it nearly always is. Its most-watched shows of the month were the "Jimmy/Timmy Power Hour 2" (5.48 million) and three broadcasts of "Drake & Josh Go Hollywood," a movie based on the channel's popular tween series. Last Friday, the first of the February sweeps, CBS placed first among total viewers, but NBC squeaked by CBS among adults 18 to 49. ABC, which was second among viewers and third in the 18-to-49 demographic, had the night's most-watched show, "Dancing With the Stars" (15.94 million). Tia Carrere, the tribe has spoken. KATE AURTHUR

description: POSEN--Carol Abelson. We grieve the untimely passing of Carol, who died tragically on February 4, 2006. She leaves behind her beloved husband Jack, adoring daughter Jenny, devoted parents Fran & Sandy, mother-in-law Celia, brother Kenny, sisters-in-law Bunny & Leslie, stepchildren Julie, Paul, David and Anneliese, niece and nephew, Zoe and Michael, grandchildren Taryn, Jordan, Lindsay, Jimmy and Devin, dog Sunshine, and too many dear friends to name. She will be greatly missed by us all. $(6$)POSEN--Carol Abelson. Carol's sudden and tragic death is hard to comprehend. If anyone were to help soothe such a family trauma, it would have been Carol. Her family's well-being was her life's mission and we will feel her loss daily. She has left a void that cannot filled. We will miss her with all our hearts. David, Anneliese, Jimmy and Devin $(6$)POSEN--Carol. Our beloved daughter, you brought sunshine and happiness into our lives every day. Jack and Jenny are your gifts to us and we treasure them dearly. A fantastic wife and unbelievable mother, unique daughter, loving, kind and caring sister, grandmother and friend, you were beautiful inside and out. May you rest in peace surrounded by the love of all who knew you. We will love you and miss you every day for the rest of our lives. Mom and Dad $(6$)POSEN--Carol. "It's not the years in your life that count, it's the life in your years." Carol, your presence in our lives was truly a special gift, always generously given, happily accepted, and one that will forever be an inspiration for us to find the good and positive in ourselves and others. There could never be a better sister, sister-in-law and aunt. We know you are in a place as beautiful as you are. Kenny, Leslie, Michael & Zoe $(6$)POSEN--Carol. We are devasted by the tragic loss and untimely death of Carol. She was an incredibly special, loving and important part of our lives. Carol was a devoted step-mother to Julie, Paul, David and Anneliese. She was the most adoring grandmother. Our hearts go out to the entire family. We will miss her terribly. She will be in our hearts forever. Bonnie, Marty, Lauren, Russell, Ali, Barry $(6$)POSEN--Carol. The Jewish Community Center of Harrison announces with profound sorrow the loss our esteemed member. We extend deepest sympathy to her husband Jack, her daughter Jennifer, her children David Posen and Julie Brandes, and to the entire family. Aubrey L. Glazer, Rabbi Sarah A. Zemel, Hazzan Robert M. Schack, President Karen Goldstick, Chairman $(6$)POSEN--Carol. Genuinely giving, forever caring, always supportive, immensely sensitive, and certainly beautiful inside and out. You were a gift in our lives that we will forever cherish. Your love, so abundant and expressive, will be missed more than anyone can imagine. The devastation of your loss is immeasurable. We will always love you. Julie, Paul, Taryn, Jordan, and Lindsay $(6$)POSEN--Carol. My shopping, lunching, art-browsing, afternoon-movie buddy and dear family friend. We will miss your smile, your warmth and your wonderful enthusiasm. We will miss you. Susan, Jim, Alex and Elizabeth Dubin $(6$)POSEN--Carol. My mother, my best friend, my biggest fan. Words cannot begin to describe how much I will miss you in my life. You are always everything a mother should be and more. I love you, Mama. Jenzo $(6$)POSEN--Carol. We are so saddened by the tragedy that has taken a beautiful soul. To Jack, Jenny, Fran, Sandy, Kenny and their families, our love and deepest sympathy. Myrna & Ron Ruskin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, ROBERT A.
description: SMITH--Robert A. Loving and devoted husband of Roslyn. Cherished father of Penny Novick, and Howard and Amy Smith. Adored grandfather of Jeffrey and Stephanie Smith, and Brett and Drake Novick. A compassionate man who always put his family first, he could not do enough for family and friends alike. His belief in helping others was evident through his many charitable efforts. He was the recipient of The Torch of Learning Award from The American Friends of the Hebrew University, and received an honorary Doctorate Degree from Long Island University, while serving as a Trustee of both Long Island University and The Arnold and Marie Schwartz College of Pharmacy and Health Sciences. He was incredibly generous and his many philanthropic interest included UJA, North Shore/LIJ Health Care Systems, where he served as an Associate Trustee, St. Francis Hospital, Boca Raton Community Hospital, Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center and The Kravis Center in Palm Beach, Florida. He served his country during World War II in the Navy aboard the USS Hornet. A brilliant businessman and industry leader he was President and CEO of S-P Drug Co. Inc. He was respected by vendors, customers and employees alike, and served on the Board of The National Wholesale Drug Association. An avid golfer, he truly enjoyed his memberships at The Glen Oaks Club, Delaire Country Club and High Ridge Country Club. We will miss his great sense of humor, endless stories and sage advice. A man of integrity, he was the ultimate role model for his children and grandchildren. His memory will remain with his family and friends forever. Donations in his memory may be made to NeuroOncology Research, c/o Jerome B. Posner, M.D., 1275 York Avenue, Room C731, NY, NY 10021. Services Tuesday, February 7th, 10 am, at "Gutterman"s, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI. $(6$)SMITH--Robert A. How lucky we were to have a Grandpa like you. We will miss the many trips to Florida, family vacations and our special Sunday night dinners. We will miss your smile and the hugs and kisses you always gave us. We will always remember your sense of humor and your endless storytelling. And most of all, we miss your kindness, warmth and love. Love always, Jeffrey, Stephanie, Brett and Blake $(6$)SMITH--Robert A. Dad, we were truly blessed to have had a father like you. Your support, understanding and guidance were always evident in all that you did for us. Your unconditional love was never ending. You will be in our hearts and minds forever. We will always miss you and love you. Penny, Howard and Amy $(6$)SMITH--Robert. The Board of Governors and the members of Glen Oaks Club express our deepest sorrow at the passing of Robert, our esteemed member of 24 years and past member of the Board of Governors. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Roslyn, his son Howard, his daughter Penny and his grandchildren Jeffrey, Stephanie, Brett and Blake. Board of Governors Alan Goldberg, President $(6$)SMITH--Robert. The Board of Governors and members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Robert Smith. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Roslyn, and their family. Jack Sussman, President Joseph Lehman, Secretary $(6$)SMITH--Robert. Good friend. Gone, never forgotten. Our condolences to the family. Gladys & Monroe $(6$)SMITH--Robert. We will miss this lifetime friend for his humor and wise counsel. Elaine & Mel Finkelstein $(6$)SMITH -- Robert. A good friend who we will always remember. Joan and Bob Goldberg

title: Next Steps on Energy
description: The early reaction to President Bush's promise to wean the United States from foreign oil was, in some cases, oddly off-key. The Saudi ambassador, for instance, seemed to wonder whether Mr. Bush had some sort of personal grudge against Mideast oil. Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, found it odd that someone would subsidize fuels other than oil. Yet there are some people in Congress who are prepared to take the president at his word, while giving his undernourished proposals the budgetary and regulatory heft they sorely need.

title: A Springboard From a Premiere to the Repertory
description: An ensemble gains prestige from introducing a new piece of music, but there is far less glory in second or third performances. So every year dozens of new works have their premieres with great fanfare and are then promptly consigned to oblivion. Various organizations have tried to address this problem. The latest worthy effort is the Cheswatyr New Music Initiative, a sensible joint project of the Orpheus chamber ensemble, WNYC Radio, the American Music Center, National Public Radio and the Cheswatyr Foundation.

title: Demonstrators throw stones at Austrian Embassy in Tehran
Arts, Briefly; 'Stranger' No. 1 at Box Office as Oscar Films Get a Boost
description: Despite competition from the Super Bowl, a cast of unknowns and a pummeling by critics, "When a Stranger Calls" (Screen Gems), a remake of the 1979 horror film with Camilla Belle, right, opened strongly this weekend with an estimated $22 million in ticket sales. Directed by Simon West ("Lara Croft: Tomb Raider"), the PG-13 film -- about a babysitter who receives mysterious, threatening phone calls -- set a record as the first to exceed $20 million in box office receipts over a Super Bowl weekend, according to a studio executive. (Last year during the same weekend, "Boogeyman," another horror film from Screen Gems, took in $19 million.) "Big Momma's House 2" (Fox), last week's top film, dropped to No. 2 with $13.3 million, and "Nanny McPhee" (Universal), with Emma Thompson, dropped one spot to No. 3 with $9.9 million. "Brokeback Mountain" (Focus Features) rose two spots, to No. 4, with $5.6 million; it expanded to more than 2,000 theaters after receiving eight Oscar nominations last week, and its total gross after nine weeks now stands at nearly $60 million. "Hoodwinked" (Weinstein Company) held at No. 5 with $5.3 million, bringing its total to $44 million. As expected, several Oscar-nominated films had big weekly gains: sales for "Capote" and "Mrs. Henderson Presents" more than tripled, and "Good Night, and Good Luck" had an eightfold increase, with $1.5 million. CATHERINE BILLEY

title: Europe banks look past their borders
Metro Briefing | New York: Con Ed Finds More Than 1,000 Shock Hazards
description: Consolidated Edison workers scanning New York City and Westchester County last year for leaking voltage found more than a thousand shock hazards from items like light poles and manhole covers, according to an annual report filed last month with the State Public Service Commission. Details from the filing were reported by The New York Post. Many items were not owned by the utility, but were the responsibility of the city or private owners, said Michael Clendenin, a Con Edison spokesman. He said the power had been cut in all cases until the leaking voltage was repaired. Con Edison received 428 allegations of shocks last year, down from 576 reports in 2004.

title: The Word of God, as Shaped by Nature
description: The natural world is not given sufficient credit for inspiring human tyranny. A society can manage itself only if it can also, in some way, manage nature, and it can manage nature only by also managing itself: controlling the damage from floods or fires, ensuring that food can be grown or water found, maintaining order in the face of cataclysm and uncertainty. That requires power, over both place and people. Ancient societies that faced regular flooding and required irrigation systems, for example, developed what the scholar Karl A. Wittfogel called "hydraulic societies," with strong central authority and rigid hierarchies.

title: Modifying the AIDS Laws
description: New York City's health commissioner wants to change state laws to facilitate the testing and treatment of people suffering from AIDS or the virus that causes it. His proposals raise concerns about privacy that will need to be evaluated by the Legislature, but they reflect the legitimate desire of health authorities nationwide to gain new tools to rein in the stubbornly persistent AIDS epidemic. Achieving the proper balance is important not just to New York City, which has the highest AIDS case rate in the country, but to other states as well.

title: Chatty Host Who Makes Archaeology Glamorous
description: An Ivy-League educated guy who grew up on the Upper East Side would not necessarily seem to fit the bill to be the next Indiana Jones. But Josh Bernstein, the chatty, photogenic host of "Digging for the Truth" on the History Channel could be the best thing for archaeology's image since Harrison Ford cocked his hat and starred in "Raiders of the Lost Ark." Mr. Bernstein's show is the channel's highest-rated series, bringing younger viewers to a network whose average armchair adventurer is 50-something. Beginning today, there will even be a comic-book promotion for the show featuring Mr. Bernstein as a superhero.

title: Storyteller in the Family: Inspiration and Obligation
description: NOIDA, India - Vikram Seth has a house of his own. He just prefers to live in his parents' house, a few doors down. His father's study is his crash pad. His mother's study, connected by a door, can be invaded at any time. His parents' bedroom, with windows that overlook a small, tidy garden, is in effect the family room, too: before anyone goes on a journey, it is here, on the large square bed, that the family sits and chats. The upstairs quarters belong to Mr. Seth's brother and his wife. Nearly every day, a meal is eaten together, either upstairs or downstairs. What's the point, Mr. Seth asks, of being sequestered in your own house down the road?

title: Sizzling Sales in Arizona
description: MERCEDES-BENZ 300SL -- The original owner brought a pair of SL's to the Barrett-Jackson auction, hoping to sell the low-mileage originals to a single bidder. And if men think about it, the sexual revolution may have brought them their share of chicks, but now, deep into middle age, they find themselves questioning their wives' choice of percale or whether Miuccia Prada's collection was really better than her last one.

description: Of all the ways to get to Brooklyn, rowing a 24-foot boat across the Atlantic Ocean must be among the hardest. Especially when you have to build your own boat. And if you haven't actually practiced on the water since last summer.

title: Looking for Mr. Good ... Plumber?
description: A company that sells itself as handy around the house is making like Mr. Fix-It to redo its advertising.

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
In Indicting Boat's Captain, U.S. Tries to Send a Message
description: WINCHESTER BAY, Ore. - The waves that torment the area where the Umpqua River empties into the Pacific are among the most fierce on the West Coast -- as tall as a two-story building at times, with a punch that can shatter a boat into splinters.

title: Mob attacks ferry offices
Basil Worgul, 58, Biologist, Who Studied Causes of Cataracts, Dies
description: Basil V. Worgul, a biologist at Columbia University who studied radiation's harmful effects on the eye, particularly as a cause of cataracts, and helped lead a long-term international study of thousands of workers exposed to radiation in the Chernobyl disaster in 1986, died on Jan. 19 at his home in Edgewater, N.J. He was 58.

title: A Violetta to Conquer the Scenery
description: The Metropolitan Opera had Angela Gheorghiu in mind when it put together its present production of "La Traviata" eight years ago. Franco Zeffirelli was brought in to do one of his opulent designer jobs on the Verdi favorite, but in rehearsals what operatic diplomats like to call "artistic differences" sent Ms. Gheorghiu on her way. Replacement strategies were visited by bad health and bad luck, and in the end this "Traviata" was sent out into the world resembling (as I wrote at the time) the aftermath of a neutron bomb attack: the gorgeous structures intact but not much human action going on inside them.

title: Connecting Bodies, Apples and DNA Through Dance
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Feb. 3 - It is hard to imagine anyone but Liz Lerman taking on developmental biology as the subject for a dance, as she has in her new "Ferocious Beauty: Genome," a world premiere Friday night here at Wesleyan University's Center for the Arts. Ms. Lerman has been addressing unlikely, increasingly complex themes for 30 years. But she is still at her best when focusing on microcosmic individual stories.

title: INSIDE
description: Iranian Bomb Is Seen As All but Inevitable Behind the frantic international diplomacy around the Iranian nuclear dispute, American officials say the best they can probably do is to delay Tehran's acquisition of a nuclear arsenal. Sooner or later, one official says, it will happen. NEWS ANALYSIS, PAGE A10

title: Toshiba Agrees to Buy Westinghouse for $5.4 Billion
description: LONDON, Feb. 6 A Making a big bet on the future of the nuclear power industry, the Toshiba Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy Westinghouse Electric, a builder of nuclear power plants, from British Nuclear Fuels P.L.C. for $5.4 billion.

title: Eat the Document

Printing Error?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Next Episode of Lost
description: Over at Fox, Roger Friedman puts on the miners helmet and goes looking for the career of Elizabeth Shue.

title: Kudofest, Kudofest, Kudofest
description: The Bagger loves typing that word. And for those who are looking for an NYC angle on the Oscars, the site of this years East Coast party has been set. The Bagger has historically taken up a seat at Entertainment Weeklys party at Elaines  they always invite him in lieu of a donation to a worthy charity. This year he will be at the Kodak Theatre in LA, although likely in a location that is tougher to find than the vice president during a major national crisis.

title: Blogged Down
description: Turns out the various entertainment-oriented blogs, which the Bagger has always seen as a source of unalloyed truth and justice, are a huge pain in the backside of people who are trying to control and commoditize information. Who could have ever guessed?

title: Chunky but Funky
description: A year after winning a best actor Oscar, Jamie Foxx has it all going for him  roles, Rolls and Rolex  but hes short on one thing: Some human jewelry for the Oscars. Hes still looking, but no fey little model girl need apply. Yes. Just a little girth. Something to keep me warm in the winter, he told MSNBC.

title: EWWWWWWWWWWW
description: The Bagger was checking his AOL account  he is one of four people remaining in the U.S. who still has one  and noticed a link to Entertainment Weeklys cavalcade of Oscar dudes and dude-ettes. It is breathtaking in its comprehensiveness, which means that you will need to have some serious time on your hands, but the Bagger reads so you dont have to. Among the revelations, Jake Gyllenhaal said Brokeback Mountain wasnt really about sex between two guys  it was about love between two human beings. Who just happened to be guys  get it? Dan Futterman, the writer of Capote who warmed up by reading Janet Malcolms The Journalist and the Murderer and Gerald Clarkes exquisite biography of Capote, comes straight at the truth of the movie (and perhaps why it resonates so much with people in showbiz and media): Anybody in this kind of business  whether acting, writing, or directing  who denies that ambition, public recognition, and respect drive them is lying to themselves. The Bagger makes no such claim  still, he sees no reason to type unless his name is at the top  and wrote, way back when, about the cravenness that lies at the heart of Capote. On the acting front, one noted film observer points out that in playing Transamericas Bree, Felicity Huffman acts the bejeezus out of this. O.K., so its William H. Macy, who happens to be married to her, but the Bagger watched the movie again this weekend  nothing like a little transsexual drama to leaven Super Bowl weekend, right?  and hes right. Keira Knightly looks like an angel and swears like a sailor in describing her turn as Elizabeth in Pride & Prejudice. Philip Seymour Hoffman, who is just about talked out after all his trips to the podium, offers up aphoristic majesty. The older you get, its not the competition that matters. Its the challenge. The Bagger thinks he remembers hearing that on the Super Bowl post-game show. For Oscar completists, EWs tour de Oscar is a must-click.

title: Cartoon Catfight
description: Not much in the way of linkage or sourcing here, but there seem to be some bad feelings afoot out in the goofy, lucrative funhouse of animation. Jeffrey Katzenberg is campaigning madly for another animated Oscar with the clay-animation feature Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit from Dreamworks. The movie gained a bit of momentum this weekend when it took top honors from the International Animated Film Society. But some people on the other end of the hard sell are getting their backs up, finding Tim Burtons Corpse Bride more soulful and less commercial  or else finding that Howls Moving Castle is a far more magical example of the art form. It is ironic  the Bagger is never quite sure exactly what the word means, but he will ask Graydon Carter sometime  that at a time when billions are changing hands over Pixar, there is no film of computer-generated imagery deemed Oscar-worthy this year.

title: The Rugrats Know More than We Do
description: If youre looking for actual wisdom, you could do a lot worse than skipping the Baggers post on Friday and getting into the comments section, where many people who actually know what they are talking about weighed in with some rather impressive Oscar historical deconstruction. Steve4992 points out that the correlate between editing and best picture breaks down when it comes to a film actually winning best picture, and offers a nice little bit of algebra instead: DGA plus Golden Globe for best pic drama or musical/comedy plus most Oscar noms or tied for most Oscar noms equals victory, always. He concludes Brokeback Mountain is a shoe-in because it meets all these various and sundry criteria. Another rugrat, if the Bagger may be so bold, pointed out that BBMs eight nominations is a pretty small number in the context of Oscar history. In the modern era, Hugo points out, only three films, The Greatest Show on Earth, (five noms) Annie Hall (five noms), and Ordinary People (five noms), have won the big magilla after receiving fewer than seven nominations, which is a hurdle BBM got over, but not by much. The Bagger obviously needs all the help he can get and is beginning to see the comments section as a large network of serially linked computers, with a reigning deity named Zimmergirl, See for yourself. (Although one industry maven, whose predictions the Bagger has come to rely on but cant cite by name, has suggested that there is a real, actual fight for best picture between BBM and Crash, with BBM ahead by a nose for the time being.)

title: Spun and Nicely Done
description: Last Friday, the Bagger was spun like a prop on a C-130. He thought he had discovered cold fusion, but was merely exploited by forces behind Crash. (That is, technical guilds are made nervous by Brokeback Mountain but have a crush on Crash.) By the time he published this chestnut, it was as common on the web as an online banking scam. The Bagger realizes now that he was merely in receipt of conventional wisdom with a side of propaganda and vows in the future more chase when marketing stuff that plops in over the transom. Now: the new Bagger, less credulous, less windy, more links.

title: Meet the Mountain Owlet-Nightjar
description: A trip to New Guinea yielded a spectacular array of new species.

New York Collections
description: Men's and women's wear from New York's fall 2006 Fashion Week.

title: Rolling Thunder
description: Hollywood, a town whose collective conscience is generally troubled for a reason, is wondering just whether Anthony Pellicano, P.I. to the stars, is rolling on some of his former clients. Mr. Pellicano has always been known as a stand-up guy, but then, hes never been buried in federal indictments. Everyone is talking about what Mr. Pellicano might be talking about. It should be good for the legal business in Los Angeles: A-List lawyers who have worked with Mr. Pellicano are hiring criminal attorneys to make sure when and if the feds come knocking, they are all lawyered up.

title: The Cafeteria of Human Existence
description: Brad Grey, the head of Paramount, has had a lovely ride through the entertainment business, but his ascension to the front ranks as a studio head has not been met with, ahem, universal acclaim. First Variety got a bite of Mr. Grey, suggesting trouble in his attempt to blend in his new acquisition, the live action division of DreamWorks. And now the Baggers colleague Laura Holson quotes a DreamWorks executive who compares his personnel management to a human bake sale. The Bagger has been on the wrong side of the oven door during a few bake-offs and he knows that someone always ends up burned to a crisp.

title: Supporting No Child, Israel in NATO and More

description: Citing Roger Ebert and other critics who have proclaimed Brokeback Mountain to be a universal love story, Daniel Mendelsohn writes in the New York Review of Books that such critics are well-meaning but seriously misguided when they ignore the movies status as a specifically gay tragedy. He writes:

title: Coretta Scott King, National Widow
description: The death of Coretta Scott King brings a certain aspect of the 1960s to near-closure. There were four widows of assassinated public figures of major renown at that time: Jacqueline Kennedy, wife of President John Kennedy; Betty Shabazz, wife of Nation of Islam minister Malcolm X; Ethel Kennedy, wife of slain senator Robert Kennedy; and of course Mrs. King, wife of Martin Luther King, Jr. Only Ethel Kennedy is still alive, and she is not a significant public presence. Of all these women, only Mrs. King worked tirelessly to advance her husbands name and his cause. Indeed, of all of them, Mrs. King became the national widow, a woman who could not have remarried if she wanted the public standing to do what she proceeded to do.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FAZIO, CHARLES R.
description: FAZIO--Charles R. A prominent international consultant, died suddenly on February 3, 2006. Born in Brooklyn, NY in 1936, son of George and Helen (Mulcahy) Fazio. Survived by his wife Carolyn; his children Carla Fazio, Teresa Fazio Hoffman and Steve Hoffman, Charles and Nanette Fazio, Victoria Fazio Capeletti and Clayton Capeletti, and Francesca Fazio; grandchildren Darius Radmanesh, Alexis Hoffman, Charles Fazio, William Fazio and Tyler Capeletti; and numerous cousins in New York, Ireland and Italy. Fazio graduated from Georgetown University in 1957. Following military service, Fazio's entire career was dedicated to serving non-profit organizations worldwide. He was cofounder and President of Fazio International Ltd., headquartered in Boca Raton, FL. Fazio held key volunteer positions with many non-profit organizations, notably serving as President of the Georgetown University Alumni Association and as Chairman of the Fellows, American Society of Association Executives. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC, on Thursday, February 9 from 2-5 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. Mass will be celebrated on Friday, February 10 at 10:30 a.m.; St. Ignatius Loyola Catholic Church, NYC. Memorial services are also planned in Boca Raton and in Washington, DC. In lieu of flowers the family requests that contributions be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Far Rockaway: Gunfight Leaves One Dead
description: One man was fatally shot and another wounded yesterday in a dispute over a woman, the police said. Keith Thompson, 19, of West Hempstead, on Long Island, was shot in the chest shortly after 11 a.m., and taken to St. John's Queens Hospital in Elmhurst, where he was pronounced dead, the authorities said. The other man, 22, who the police said fired at Mr. Thompson, was shot in the arm and taken to Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica in stable condition. The surviving man and the woman live in a basement apartment on Brunswick Avenue. Patrick Meola, a neighbor of the couple's, said that Mr. Thompson had had a child with the woman in a previous relationship. Several months ago, Mr. Thompson beat the other man and broke the windows on his car, Mr. Meola said. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)

title: A Global Alternative to Spring Training
description: NEXT month, baseball fans will face a difficult choice: either travel to Florida and Arizona for spring training or attend the first World Baseball Classic, an international tournament played largely on American soil that will attempt to become a real world series. If you choose the latter, then move fast. Tickets for the event, which has generated a surge of publicity, are going fast.

A leading philanthropist and longtime friend of JTS, Bernie was highly respected in the business and Jewish community for his integrity and warmth. He was honored by JTS in 2004 with the Chancellor's Medal in appreciation of his unswerving support and generosity, which enabled the institution to further its mission of enhancing Jewish life in America, Israel, and beyond. title: Primping for the Cameras in the Name of Research
description: PARIS, Feb. 6 - The quest for the holy grail of beauty begins in a stark white bathroom, where a middle-aged strawberry blonde primps her freshly washed and blown hair under the relentless gaze of two overhead cameras. Steps away, a researcher checks a flickering computer screen, toggling controls to zoom in on the woman, who has just sampled unmarked bottles of shampoo and conditioner.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Chvez Warning On Refineries
description: President Hugo Chvez said in a speech to supporters that he would shut Venezuela's refineries in the United States if Washington cuts off ties with the South American nation or attempts to invade the country. "It wouldn't cost me anything to shut our refineries in the U.S.," Mr. Chvez said Saturday, according to a transcript. The warning came amid growing tensions between the nations. On Thursday, Venezuela expelled the naval attach at the United States Embassy, accusing him of passing secret information from Venezuelan military officers to the Pentagon. Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld than likened Mr. Chvez to Hitler as a legally elected dictator, and the State Department expelled Jeny Figueredo Fras, who was chief of staff to the Venezuelan ambassador. Mr. Chvez has repeatedly said that he would halt oil exports to the United States if the Bush administration tries to invade Venezuela; the United States has said it has no plans for such action.

Advanced Placement Program Gains Visibility in High Schools
description: The College Board's Advanced Placement program is gaining visibility in efforts to ratchet up the rigor of American high school education, finding a place in President Bush's State of the Union Message as well as in individual state initiatives. According to the second annual report from the College Board, the New York-based nonprofit group that administers the program, about 60 percent of American high schools A almost 15,000 schools A now offer Advanced Placement courses, and high schools on average offer a choice of eight such courses.

title: Record Sales of Sleeping Pills Are Causing Worries
description: Americans are taking sleeping pills like never before, fueled by frenetic workdays that do not go gently into a great night's sleep, and lulled by a surge of consumer advertising that promises safe slumber with minimal side effects.

title: Durst Cuts Ties to Family in Return for $65 Million
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 6 - Robert A. Durst, the real estate scion acquitted of murder in Texas despite admitting that he carved up his 71-year-old neighbor, cut the last ties to his family and 10 Manhattan skyscrapers on Monday in return for a payout of about $65 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Totowa: Cleanup Of Oil Spill
description: Environmental crews spent yesterday containing and cleaning up heating oil that spilled into the Passaic River during the weekend from an asphalt-manufacturing plant in Totowa, state officials said. The oil did not pose a threat to drinking water, said Elaine Makatura, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection. JOHN HOLL (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Treatment Of Mentally Ill Prompts Suit
description: A lawsuit charged the state yesterday with violating the Americans with Disabilities Act by isolating more than 200 people with mental illness in three nursing homes. The suit, filed in federal court by the state-financed Office of Protection and Advocacy for Persons with Disabilities and the private Bazelon Center for Mental Health Law, based in Washington, contended that mentally ill people "are left to languish in these facilities while equally affordable and more integrated community-based settings exist or could be made available." A spokesman for the state's Department of Mental Health and Addiction Services, Wayne F. Dailey, said the state was studying whether Medicaid would help pay for community-based services. He called the suit's timing unfortunate, saying, "There's some real progress that's been made in this area." WILLIAM YARDLEY (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: New Leader Steps In
description: Stephen Harper, left, was sworn in as Canada's 22nd prime minister, taking over from Paul Martin two weeks after the Conservative Party won a narrow victory against Mr. Martin and his long-governing Liberal Party. Mr. Harper's cabinet choices include Peter MacKay of Nova Scotia, who was the deputy Conservative leader in opposition, as the new foreign minister, and Gordon O'Connor of Ontario, a retired brigadier general, as defense minister. CLIFFORD KRAUSS (NYT)

title: Mississippi's 'Heart Man' Examines Links Between Race and Disease
description: JACKSON, Miss. - When Dr. Herman A. Taylor Jr. goes for breakfast in this city of 180,000, he orders carefully: granola, fresh fruit. "People look at what I put on my tray," he said on a recent morning at the Broad Street Bakery, a local cafe. "They wonder if I practice what I preach."

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Ryanair Profit Declines
description: Ryanair Holdings, Europe's largest discount airline, reported an unexpected decline in third-quarter profit on soaring fuel costs and predicted that fares would drop. Net income at the Dublin-based Ryanair fell 21 percent, to 36.8 million euros ($44.2 million) in the three months ended Dec. 31, from a restated 46.7 million euros a year earlier. The result missed the median estimate of 39.5 million euros among analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News. Fuel costs in the third quarter climbed 59 percent, to 114.9 million euros, higher than analysts estimated. The airline has futures contracts protecting against high fuel costs only through the fourth quarter. Ryanair is able to absorb higher fuel costs, without hedging, because other expenses are being reduced, the chief executive, Michael O'Leary, left, said on a conference call. Shares of Ryanair fell 20 cents, or 2.6 percent, to 7.52 euros in Dublin.

title: Read the Book, See the Commercial
description: In yet another test of how books will survive in a digital world, HarperCollins said yesterday that it had made the entire text of one of its recently published books available online accompanied by advertisements, the first time it has done so. The book, titled "Go It Alone! The Secret to Building a Successful Business On Your Own," by Bruce Judson, a senior faculty fellow at the Yale School of Management whose expertise is in using the Internet for business, is available at the author's Web site, www.brucejudson.com, where it can be searched and printed page by page. The text of the book will be indexed for search engines and accompanied by contextual ads served by the major search companies. The site also provides links to buy the book. "Go It Alone!" was originally published in hardcover in November 2004 and in paperback in December 2005. The paperback sells on Amazon.com for $10.17, although a discounted new copy of the hardcover can also be bought there for $5.99, indicating that the publisher has plenty of unsold copies. EDWARD WYATT

title: Germany Frees Moroccan Linked to 9/11, Pending Appeal

title: A Trillion Little Pieces
description: President Bush's $2.77 trillion budget is fiction masquerading as fact, a governmental version of the made-up memoirs that have been denounced up and down the continent lately. The spending proposal is built around the pretense that the same House and Senate that are set to consider a record deficit of $423 billion will now impose a virtual freeze on everything other than Pentagon and homeland security outlays. The budget writers even fantasized an end to Social Security's lump-sum death benefit -- a whopping $255 per recipient -- as if Congress would dare to do something so heartless and easy to exploit in an election year.

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Suspect Sought In Harlem Killing
description: The police said yesterday that a suspect was being sought in the killing of the manager of a Dunkin' Donuts during an attempted robbery on Sunday. The police said the manager, Sanjoy Kar, 25, of Woodside, Queens, was shot after refusing a gunman's demand for cash at the shop, on 145th Street near Lenox Avenue in Harlem. The suspect was identified as Otis Cain, 42, whose last known address was 540 Gates Avenue in Brooklyn. The police said Mr. Cain had been arrested six times, but they would not immediately elaborate on what the charges were or on whether he was ever convicted.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Assembly Overrides Veto On Prescriptions
description: The Democratic-controlled State Assembly voted unanimously yesterday to override a veto by Gov. George E. Pataki of a bill to pay for eligible elderly people to fill prescriptions if they were denied coverage under the new federal Medicare prescription drug benefit. Voting 141 to 0, the Assembly approved reinstating emergency legislation to permit those eligible for Medicare and Medicaid to receive their medications until problems with changes in the federal Medicare program are resolved. Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader of the Republican-controlled State Senate, said he would recommend that his conference also vote to override the veto. Kevin Quinn, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki, called the legislation an "expensive election-year placebo that doesn't offer any new relief to our seniors and ultimately lets the federal government off the hook." JENNIFER MEDINA (NYT)

title: Figure in JT Leroy Case Says Partner Is Culprit
description: A central figure in the case of the mysterious writer JT Leroy has come forward to say that no one named JT Leroy exists, and that the books published under that name were actually written by a San Francisco woman named Laura Albert.

The officer, Jim Sell, was 63, not 56.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Public Workers Strike Over Hours
description: The country's first open-ended public sector strike in 14 years got under way as thousands of civil servants in the southwestern state of Baden-Wrttemberg stayed off their jobs, affecting garbage collections, hospitals, kindergartens and municipal offices. The service sector union Ver.di, which represents 2.4 million workers nationwide, opposes plans by municipalities across the country to raise working time to 40 hours a week from 38.5 without extra pay. The strike may spread across Germany as workers in other states begin voting on whether to join the protest. VICTOR HOMOLA (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LENGEMANN, GEORGE L.
description: LENGEMANN--George L. On February 5, 2006 at the age of 78. Beloved husband of Ruth C. Haupert-Lengemann. Loving brother of Dorothy Lengemann Walker and caring uncle of Wendy L. Walker, both of Virginia, and Dr. William H. Walker of Pittsburgh. George waged a valiant battle against cancer for over two years with his characteristic dignity, wry sense of humor and indomitable work ethic. A dedicated life-long New York Giants football fan, he would consider it ironic that Super Bowl Sunday was his last day on earth. George had a distinguished career in investment management and security analysis spanning more than 50 years. For the past 34 years, he had been Vice President of S.W. Childs Management Corporation. He was also Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Lengemann Capital Management Assoc., Inc. Earlier, he had been affiliated with Peoples Trust Company of New Jersey, Guaranty Trust Company, a predecessor of Morgan-Guaranty and F.H. Vahesing. A 1951 graduate of Hofstra University, he earned an M.B.A. from N.Y.U.'s Stern Graduate School of Business in 1959. His service in the United States Army as a military photographer in Europe fortified a life-long love of photography. A past Vice President and Treasurer of the N.Y.U. Club of New York, he also served as Treasurer of the Touchdown Club of America and was a Member of the Princeton Club in New York and the Sun and Surf Beach Club in Atlantic Beach, NY. Family will receive friends on Wednesday, 7-9pm and Thursday 2-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave (81 St). Funeral services Friday, 9:30am at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, the family would be grateful for donations to St. John's Lutheran Church, PO Box 72, Brooklyn NY 11222; St. Luke's Lutheran Church, 308 W. 46 St, NY NY 10036; New York University Stern School of Business, 44 W. 4 St, NY NY 10012.

title: For a Period Film, a Serving of Lean, Smoky Jazz
description: It should come as news to no one that the front-runner for best jazz vocal album in this year's Grammy Awards is an intimate standards session that evokes the sound of the 1950's. Isn't that often the case? What's interesting about the current favorite is that it comes with a period picture attached, the George Clooney film "Good Night, and Good Luck." The soundtrack is the latest effort from Dianne Reeves, a singer who has been unbeatable in recent awards seasons.

Former Administrator of Volunteers and one-time Acting Executive Director, Ms. Tombelaine was devoted to the Society and its Library. She organized hundreds of volunteers for the New York Flower Show and helped found an association for administrators of volunteer programs in NYC cultural institutions. She is remembered fondly by her many colleagues and friends.

Once one of the most feared men in the country, he was an architect of the modern black power movement and symbolized a century-long debate among blacks about the need to meet violence with violence.
