Ekaterina Mechetina won the World Piano Competition of Cincinnati in 2004, and her recital at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday evening was evidently one of her rewards. Ms. Mechetina is another in a long and impressive line of racehorse Russian pianists; their outsize physical ability leaves them straining in their reins, and they are never so happy as when the course is tough and the hurdles are high.

description: Marxist guerrillas killed seven policemen providing protection for peasants hired by the government to uproot coca plants manually from Macarena National Park in the south. He vowed to continue the manual cull in the park, which has been a haven for the drug runners of the guerrilla group Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, because conservation rules bar spraying in national parks. title: How the FISA Process Works
description: Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales has argued that the process to obtain a warrant under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA, passed in 1978) is cumbersome and does not provide the "speed and the agility" necessary to fight terrorist threats today. The Sept. 11 commission and subsequent Congressional reports have blamed the workings of the F.B.I. and the Justice Department for many of the "bottlenecks." In June 2004, John Ashcroft, then the attorney general, testified in Congress that the agencies were working on streamlining the process.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Costa Rica: Presidential Cliffhanger
description: The presidential election on Sunday was too close to call, and the country's main election authority said it would recount the ballots by hand, ensuring a delay of at least two weeks. With 87.3 percent of the ballots from Sunday counted, scar Arias, the centrist former president and winner of the 1987 Nobel Peace Prize who had been expected to win, had 40.5 percent of the vote. His main rival, the center-left candidate, Ottn Sols, an economist, had 40.3 percent and trailed by just 3,648 votes. JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. (NYT)

title: Haiti's Orphan Democracy
description: Los Angeles - TWENTY years ago today, in the elegant but down-at-the-heels central square of Port-au-Prince, the Haitian people celebrated the departure of a dictator and the end of nearly three decades of a nightmare dynasty. In the smallest hours of Feb. 7, 1986, Jean-Claude Duvalier, his chain-smoking wife at his side, drove his Mercedes sedan right up to the open door of a United States Air Force jet and fled the country for the South of France. Along with about 50 members of the foreign press corps, I was there at Franois Duvalier International Airport, named for the fleeing man's father, who had visited disaster after disaster on his native land.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, ROBERT A.
description: SMITH--Robert A. Loving and devoted husband of Roslyn. Cherished father of Penny Novick & Howard and Amy Smith. Adored grandfather of Jeffrey & Stephanie Smith, and Brett and Blake Novick. A compassionate man who always put his family first, he could not do enough for family and friends alike. His belief in helping others was evident through his many charitable efforts. He was the recipient of The Torch of Learning Award from The American Friends of the Hebrew University, and received an honorary Doctorate Degree from Long Island University, while serving as a Trustee of both Long Island University and The Arnold and Marie Schwartz College of Pharmacy and Health Sciences. He was incredibly generous and his many philanthropic interests included UJA, North Shore/LIJ Health Care Systems, where he served as an Associate Trustee, St. Francis Hospital, Boca Raton Community Hospital, Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center and The Kravis Center in Palm Beach, Florida. He served his country during World War II in the Navy aboard the USS Hornet. A brilliant businessman and industry leader he was President and CEO of S-P Drug Co. Inc. He was respected by vendors, customers and employees alike, and served on the Board of The National Wholesale Drug Association. An avid golfer, he truly enjoyed his memberships at The Glen Oaks Club, Delaire Country Club and High Ridge Country Club. We will miss his great sense of humor, endless stories and sage advice. A man of integrity, he was the ultimate role model for his children & grandchildren. His memory will remain with his family and friends forever. Donations in his memory may be made to NeuroOncology Research, C/O Jerome B. Posner, M.D., 1275 York Avenue, Room C731, NY, NY 10021. Services today 10AM at "Gutterman"s, 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, LI.

title: A bourgeois 'Figaro' in London
Paid Notice: Deaths   EHRLICH, HARVEY B.
description: EHRLICH--Harvey B. Died peacefully at age 98 after a brief illness. Beloved husband of the late Belle "Bubbles"; father of Barbara and Jules Reich, and Jerrold and Vivian (Fenster) Ehrlich; grandfather of Mark and Insuk, Bruce and Lisa (Mirowitz), Alan and June, Randi and Alan Kahn, Philip, Jeffrey and Barbara Reich, Laurie and Keith Emmer, and Joshua. Great grandfather of Leanna, Madison, Mariel, Jason, Rebecca, Matthew, Stephanie and Justin. Harvey, an attorney since 1929, devoted his life to the service of the people. He was one of the founders of the New York State Liberal Party and served as Party Secretary for Queens County and Staff Director for the New York City Council. As one of New York's leading attorneys, he served as: Deputy Chief Assistant DA for Queens County; Head of Special Investigations Unit and Chief of the Settlement Bureau of the New York City Comptroller's Office; and Confidential Secretary to a New York State Supreme Court Justice. He worked tirelessly for the Zionist Organization of America and B'nai B'rith. After retirement, he was a founder of the American Society of Retired Attorneys and volunteered as a hearing officer in the courts and schools of Broward County, Florida. He was inducted into the Broward County Senior Volunteer Hall of Fame for his services to the community. He was deeply devoted to his family who celebrate his long and rich life and mourn his loss. Donations may be made to DOROT, 171 West 85 Street, NY NY 10024. Memorial services will be held on Tuesday, February 7 at 11:15 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave at 76 Street. Burial at Mt. Ararat Cemetery in E. Farmingdale, NY. The family will be sitting Shiva at the home of Jerry and Vivian Ehrlich, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, 4-9.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Ivory Coast: U.N. Sends More Troops
description: The Security Council transferred a 200-man Nigerian infantry unit from Liberia to Ivory Coast to help United Nations peacekeepers. They have been under attack there from youths supporting President Laurent Gbagbo and protesting a United Nations-backed decision barring renewal of the expired mandate of the National Assembly, which is dominated by the government party. Secretary General Kofi Annan had asked the Council to send up to more than 800 soldiers, but the United States objected to the higher number. WARREN HOGE (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Owner In Bus Fire Pleads Not Guilty
description: The owner of a bus that caught fire last September near Dallas and killed 23 people pleaded not guilty to a federal indictment accusing him of failing to ensure the safety of the vehicle and falsifying driver records. The man's company, Global Limo, a co-defendant, was closed by federal safety officials after the accident, which occurred on Sept. 23. The owner, James H. Maples, 65, was released pending trial after posting a $75,000 bond. He could be fined $400,000 and sentenced to seven years in prison if convicted of all counts in the indictment. The bus was evacuating nursing home patients from the Houston area as Hurricane Rita approached the Texas coast. STEVE BARNES (NYT)

Doctor of Psychology in private practice. Beloved husband of Ann HarringtonFoley. Loving father of Brendan Foley. Dear brother of Red Foley. Also survived by many caring nieces & nephews. Family will receive friends at Hungerford & Clark Inc., Funeral Home, 110 Pine Street (Cor. So. Ocean Ave) Freeport. Funeral MassThursday 10AM at St. Thomas More R.C. Church at St. Johns University. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing. Visiting Wednesday 2-4, 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions to Regis High School, 55 E. 84th St., NY, NY 10028, would be appreciated.

Canada to Shield 5 Million Forest Acres
description: HARTLEY BAY, British Columbia, Feb. 4 - In this sodden land of glacier-cut fjords and giant moss-draped cedars, a myth is told by the Gitga'at people to explain the presence of black bears with a rare recessive gene that makes them white as snow.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: White House Budget Includes More Spending On Military and Cuts in Domestic Programs President Bush proposed a $2.77 trillion budget that would increase spending on the military and homeland security, while calling for substantial cutbacks in domestic programs, ranging from education to farm subsidies to the national parks. Mr. Bush is also proposing to limit the growth in Medicare spending, at a savings of $36 billion over five years. [Page A1.]

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENJAMIN, MIRIAM
description: BENJAMIN--Miriam. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) are deeply saddened by the loss of Miriam Benjamin of Sarasota, Florida. Mrs. Benjamin was a founder of our Sarasota/Gulf Coast Chapter and prior to moving to Florida, was a National Vice President of the ATS Women's Division. She was a Life Trustee of the ATS Board of Regents and an Honorary Life Member of the Technion International Board of Governors. Mrs. Benjamin and her late husband Louis were both Technion Guardians, demonstrating the highest level of commitment to Israel and the Technion. The Louis and Miriam Benjamin Chair in Computers and Communication Networks, The Louis and Miriam Benjamin Signal Processing Laboratory and The Louis and Miriam Benjamin/Sarasota Chapter Auditorium are but a part of the Benjamins' legacy that will help generations of students become Israel's leaders in the high-tech fields that are the foundation of Israel's future. Revered as unequaled in their outstanding generosity and steadfast dedication to the Technion, Miriam and Louis were both awarded Technion Honorary Fellowships as well as Honorary Doctorates. They are the only couple in the Technion's history to be so recognized. Our hearts go out to Mrs. Benjamin's daughter, Carol B. Epstein, ATS Washington, D.C. Chapter president, and the entire Benjamin family. Stephen A. Laser, President Evelyn Berger, Chairman, Board of Directors Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Gary G. Folz, President, Sarasota/Gulf Coast Chapter Betty Lustig, Director Southern Region

title: Company Tells Panel It Didn't Ship Wheat
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 6 - The Jordanian company Alia for Transportation and General Trade, which is at the center of a scheme through which $200 million was channeled from an Australian wheat company, AWB Ltd., to the Iraqi government in violation of United Nations sanctions, said Monday that it had not transported any wheat for AWB.

title: Bertuzzi's Opportunity to Show He Belongs
description: As Olympic darlings go, figure skating has Michelle Kwan, freestyle skiing has Jeremy Bloom and hockey has Todd Bertuzzi.

title: Muslim Protests Against Cartoons Spread
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, Feb. 6 - Muslim anger over Danish cartoons that satirized the Prophet Muhammad continued to swell across the Middle East and elsewhere in the world on Monday, turning violent in Afghanistan, where at least five protesters died and more than a dozen police officers and protesters were wounded.

title: In Europe, Banks Look at More Deals Over Borders
description: PARIS, Feb. 6 - A bid by BNP Paribas, the French banking giant, for Banca Nazionale del Lavoro of Italy appears to be the latest sign that European lenders are jostling to win new clients beyond their national borders and taking advantage of changes in the regulatory climate.

title: Works in a Program Ideal for Making Girls Love Dance
description: On Saturday afternoon, New York City Ballet went into family-dance overdrive, with a program intended to sweep little girls right out of their Mary Janes (or in a dozen years, to the box office). After Jerome Robbins's "Mother Goose" -- a strange ballet almost too subtle for child consumption -- came George Balanchine's "Duo Concertant," Sean Lavery's "Romeo and Juliet" and Christopher Wheeldon's "American in Paris." It all seemed a bit desperate.

title: Ferry Victims' Kin Storm Owner's Offices
description: SAFAGA, Egypt, Feb. 6 - Frustrated relatives of passengers aboard an Egyptian ferry that sank Friday in the Red Sea stormed into the office of the ship's owners here early Monday, looting it and demanding that the company and the government provide information about those lost.

title: Those Danish Cartoons
description: Cartoons making fun of the prophet Muhammad that were published in a Danish newspaper last September are suddenly one of the hottest issues in international politics. Muslims in Europe and across the Middle East have been holding protests with growing levels of violence and now loss of life.

description: After the judging scandal at the 2002 Winter Olympics, the International Skating Union devised a new scoring system to replace the familiar 6.0 scale.

title: Nassau Executive Offers Plan With Alternatives to Abortion
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Feb. 6 - In a move with potential implications for the Democratic race for governor, Nassau County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi plans to announce on Tuesday a $3 million proposal to reduce abortions with a program intended to appeal to both sides of the divisive issue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KEAN, MALLORY G. B.
description: KEAN--Mallory G. B. Of Far Hills, NJ, suddenly on January 27, 2006. Friend to many new and old, she gave so much to us all, touching more people than anyone can count. A thoroughly developed appreciation for life in all its forms and of the mysteries of nature for which she had a deep love. It is not the years in our lives, but the life in our years. Mallory was the cherished wife, mentor and partner of Robert W. Kean III. In addition to Roy, she was a loving and engaged role model and friend in so many ways to her stepchildren Bobby, Philip and Nina Kean, who will always have her in their hearts. Mallory's unforgettable electric energy continues with us all. Memorial donations can be made in Mallory's name to The Museum of the City of New York Directors' Council, 1220 Fifth Ave, NYC 10029; and to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center at P.O. Box 27106, NYC 10087-7106. Mallory's memorial service will be at Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street, NYC, on Thursday, February 9th, at 4 PM. No flowers please.

No More Favors, Judge Tells Man Accused in Court Mayhem
description: James Koenig and John B. Stella almost got fired yesterday. It could have been worse.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 27 about New York City's efforts to remove children from abusive homes or to place them under court supervision in response to the death of a 7-year-old Brooklyn girl, Nixzmary Brown, referred imprecisely to a 2004 report on the city's child welfare agency by the Vera Institute of Justice. In finding that the authorities in Brooklyn made arrests or removed children from homes at a lower rate than did their counterparts in the rest of the city, the report referred only to special teams of child welfare workers and police detectives, known as instant-response teams, that act after complaints of serious child abuse, not to caseworkers in general.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Rell Aide Cleared In Inquiry
description: M. Lisa Moody, chief of staff to Gov. M. Jodi Rell, committed no crime when on state time she distributed campaign fund-raising invitations in December on behalf of the governor to the heads of several state agencies, Christopher L. Morano, chief state's attorney, said yesterday. After Ms. Moody acknowledged that she had violated the governor's policy by distributing the invitations, Mrs. Rell suspended her for two weeks without pay. But neither Ms. Moody nor agency officials who had accepted the invitations committed a crime, since "the mere act of passing an envelope is insufficient to constitute a knowing and willful violation of the law," Mr. Morano's office said. The agency officials remain under civil investigation by the state's Elections Enforcement Commission, said Jeffrey B. Garfield, its executive director. STACEY STOWE (NYT)

title: The Top Travel Worries
description: THE TOP TRAVEL WORRIES -- In a survey, more business travelers cited theft (37 percent) than terrorism (27 percent) as the biggest potential risk on the road. The survey of 1,717 business travelers was commissioned by the travel management company Ultramar Travel Bureau. Of those surveyed, 56 percent said their company had an emergency preparedness plan for corporate travelers.

title: Bronx Elephants Could Live Many More Years
description: If an elephant never forgets, then it must pile up an awful lot of information in its thick skull because elephants live a long time. Not quite as long as humans or bowhead whales (150 to 200 years), perhaps, but they live longer than cats or dogs.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Australia: Police Seek Manslaughter Charges For Surgeon
description: The police in Queensland State have recommended that Dr. Jayant Patel, the American-trained surgeon who worked in a rural hospital there, be charged with 4 counts of manslaughter, 6 counts of inflicting grievous bodily harm and 16 counts of fraud. The charges arise from his work as chief surgeon at the municipal hospital in Bundaberg, where he was hired in 2003 on the basis of a rsum that neglected to say that he had been disciplined by medical authorities in New York and Oregon. Dr. Patel left Australia for Portland, Ore., in April 2005. The Queensland prosecutor will now decide whether to act on the police recommendations. Dr. Patel's lawyer in Portland has said that Dr. Patel is innocent and will fight any extradition attempt. RAYMOND BONNER (NYT)

title: New Google Service to Blend the Gmail and Chat Features
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6 - Google, the search-engine giant, is expected on Tuesday to disclose that it will join its instant-messaging service with its popular Gmail program, the latest indication that the company has set its sights on the broader communications industry.

title: Senate Seat From Harlem Is Drawing a Lot of Interest
description: Two weeks ago, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer chose David A. Paterson, a state senator from Harlem, to be his running mate in the 2006 governor's race. And within hours, some notable candidates began to emerge with aspirations of filling Mr. Paterson's seat in Harlem and Upper Manhattan.

One of Everything Oscars hobby horses: the stiffing of Ralph Fiennes in the best actor category, a sentiment the Bagger could get behind if he could ever figure out how to say the actors name.

title: Sizzling Sales in Arizona
Jake Gyllenhaal, Superhero
description: Jake Gyllenhaal, who looked for a minute like he might end up as Spiderman before Tobey Maguire came to his senses, might just cop a role as the district attorney in the next Batman movie. Mr. Gyllenhaal, who is up for best supporting actor this year  he landed in the supporting category to make way for co-star Heath Ledger in the best actor tussle  was also thought at one time to be the next Green Hornet, but that never came to pass.

title: Secret Agent Man
description: Wire-tapping, black ops, and death threats would all seem to be part of a story about a government gone wrong, but its actually just a day in the life of sunny Hollywood. Anthony Pellicano, friend to the elites, was charged with 110 counts of wire-tapping and conspiracy yesterday. Of course, many of the people who hired him will be asked to testify, and the Bagger is just guessing here, but many of them will say that they had no idea how the private investigator happened to know all about the private telephone conversations of their competitors and foes. Pellicano is not talking, so far, and pleaded not guilty to all charges in United States District Court as he was ordered held without bond. He was arrested a day before he was to complete a 30-month prison term for the explosives and weapons found in his office four years ago, so this has been a tough few days for the tough-talking former detective. So far he is not talking about his ongoing caper, which was said to involve a number of law enforcement officials. United States Attorney George Cardona is not messing around:

title: Dargis Digs In
description: My colleague and film savant Manohla Dargis weighs in on all matters Oscar-ish, including some of the reasons behind the durable appeal of Crash:

title: Will Oscar Switch Teams?
description: The Bagger has always had his speculations about Oscars dating life. The golden guy does not set off the Baggers gaydar in a huge way  unlike The Actor, which is given out by the Screen Actors Guild and is TOTALLY gay  but then there are some facts that are tough to get past. For example, what straight male do you know who would consider being clad head-to-toe in gold to be proper evening wear? And even though Oscar is 78 years old or so, he is incredibly buff, a tribute either to a moderate lifestyle or endless trips to the gym. Factor in the fact that Oscar spends his time adjacent to big stars, a constant familiar who is petted and stroked, and there are reasons to think that Oscar, if not an avowed homosexual, certainly has his moments, and may be more flexible than he appears to be.

title: The Spying Georges: Washington and Bush
description: The Los Angeles Times editorial page isnt pleased with Attorney General Alberto Gonzaless testimony in front of the Senate Judiciary Committee during Mondays hearings on the Bush administrations domestic surveillance program: Its hard to say whats more disturbing: the attorney generals unsound legal reasoning or his transparent efforts to avoid a legal conversation altogether in favor of emotional appeals aimed squarely at the court of public opinion. As several senators reminded him, the hearings are not a contest to see who hates Al Qaeda more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PEABODY, JOHN DAMON JR.
description: PEABODY--John Damon Jr. Died January 23, 2006 at his home in Hancock, New Hampshire. He served in the Naval Air Corps in World War II. He married Virginia Boyd who died in 1983. He worked in the US State Department in the Agency for International Development in Turkey, Brazil and Honduras. He married Bettina Wall in 1986. He is survived by his present wife Bettina Wall, three sons John, Alexander and James and four grandchildren.

title: New York Health Care Industry Says It Faces $1.2 Billion in Cutbacks Under Bush Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 - The Medicare cutbacks that President Bush proposed this week would eventually wring $1.2 billion a year from New York's troubled health care industry, cuts that would come as the state is already losing hospitals to wrenching changes in health care, industry officials said on Tuesday.

title: As a Free Spirit, Miller Is Not as Advertised
description: TURIN, Italy - ONE American free spirit is a sassy talent who arrived at the Olympic Village with his sequins in a comic twist after viewing the vintage summer-camp dcor of his accommodations.

title: Rose's Gaffe Brings Back Memories of Fab Five
description: Jalen Rose had the ball in his hands and, for the second straight game in his brief Knicks career, held the fate of his new team as well. But the game ended with only confusion and slumped shoulders -- as games so often do for the Knicks, and as Rose is quickly learning.

title: Barefoot in the Caribbean? Not on These Hikes
description: THERE is more to a Caribbean vacation than lounging on the beach with a cool colada in hand. Some of the world's best rain forest and volcanic hiking can be found within the lush canopied Caribbean trail systems. Chock-full of waterfalls and hot springs, bright-colored birds and howling monkeys, flora-lined trails cut through thick, fragrant forests and up cloud-covered mountains. Hard-packed paths wend past tropical gardens, and steep, rocky routes climb through multiple ecosystems revealing stunning island views at the top. Here are six terrific hiking destinations with something to please everyone from the casual to the serious hiker.

title: Germany Frees Man in Qaeda Cell Linked to 9/11 Terrorists
description: FRANKFURT, Feb. 7 - Germany's highest court on Tuesday released a Moroccan man who had been convicted of belonging to a cell of Al Qaeda whose members included the Sept. 11 hijackers, pending an appeal of his case.

title: Japanese Princess Expects, and Many Hope (for a Boy)
description: TOKYO, Feb. 7 - Japanese officials said Tuesday that Princess Kiko, the wife of Emperor Akihito's second son, Prince Akishino, is pregnant, raising hopes for a long-awaited male heir to one of the world's oldest hereditary monarchies and throwing into doubt imperial law revisions that would allow a female line to hold the throne.

title: No More Mr. Tough Guy
description: I've always thought Dick Cheney took national security seriously. I don't anymore. It seems that Mr. Cheney is so convinced that we have no choice but to be dependent on crude oil, so convinced that conservation is just some silly liberal hobby, that he will never seriously summon the country to kick its oil habit, never summon it to do anything great.

title: The Rev. William A. Jones, Civil Rights Activist, Dies at 71
description: The Rev. William A. Jones, who marshaled his golden voice and forceful personality to exert influence far beyond his Brooklyn pulpit in support of local and national civil rights causes, died on Feb. 4 at his home in Brooklyn. He was 71.

title: Olmert Says Israel Will Keep 3 Large West Bank Settlement Blocs
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 7 - Acting Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said in a television interview broadcast on Tuesday that he wanted to set the country's permanent borders, with Israel giving up significant parts of the West Bank but keeping the largest Jewish settlement blocs.

title: At Mavericks, Thousands See the Best Wipe Out
description: HALF MOON BAY, Calif., Feb. 7 - It used to be that the most well-publicized surf contests were held at places where the size of the parking lot mattered more than the size of the surf. Not anymore.

title: Compromise in Connecticut Property Seizure Case
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 7 - A handful of property owners in New London, Conn., who have resisted having their property taken by eminent domain even after the United States Supreme Court ruled last year that the taking was legal, could be allowed to stay on their land -- or at least very close to it -- under a plan approved by the City Council.

description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 7 - As his career nears an end, Daron Rahlves, the most successful United States downhill ski racer ever, is becoming antsy about life after skiing.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday and in some copies on Sunday about Betty Friedan, the pioneering feminist who wrote "The Feminine Mystique," misstated the residence of her sister, Amy Adams. It is Chapel Hill, N.C., not New York City.

title: If Food Be the Music of Love, Make a Reservation
description: IS there a day a man faces that has more romantic minefields, more opportunities to ruin a relationship -- if not his entire life -- than Valentine's Day? Consider the long-married man who goes home empty-handed because the relationship is so beyond that. The out-of-town lover who sends his Cond Nast sweetheart an FTD bouquet. The guy who waits until he is reading this to try to book a restaurant. GOOD LUCK, SUCKER! Uh, that is to say it's challenging, but if anyone can do it, it's you! JOYCE WADLER

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a plan by America Online and Yahoo to charge companies for delivery of some e-mail to their customers misstated the background of a business that will process the messages. That company, Goodmail, was founded on the premise of charging postage for high-volume e-mail, not for all e-mail; it has narrowed its focus to companies and organizations that get permission from users to send them mail. The article also misstated the progress of Goodmail's relationship with two clients, the American Red Cross and The New York Times Company. While both have announced that they will use the Goodmail system, they have not yet taken part in testing it.

title: Thanks, Iran, for the reminder

description: FORT MYERS, Fla., Feb. 5 - As the stepchild to its more beautiful sisters in southwest Florida, Naples and Sarasota, this city has struggled for decades to revitalize its picturesque downtown and attract snowbirds and tourists.

title: 3 Convicted in Smuggling Scheme That Killed 19 in Truck Trailer
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 8 A Overcoming an initial deadlock, a federal jury here today convicted three South Texans in a botched human-trafficking scheme that killed 19 illegal immigrants sealed in a trailer bound north from the Mexican border in 2003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BALICH, MARIE (ZULYEVITS)
description: BALICH--Marie (Zulyevits). 101, died Saturday in Ghent, N.Y. She taught French, primarily at Christopher Columbus H.S. in the Bronx, for 35 years. Memorials may be made to the Hunter College Foundation.

title: The Quest
description: The 64 skaters who make up the four teams in the Gotham Girls Roller Derby League practice at the Skate Key in Mott Haven, the Bronx. Two teams compete at a time, flying around the flat track. The reigning champions are the Queens of Pain. For the skaters, the goals -- their quests -- are both obvious and not so. "Have you ever wanted to push someone into a desk? Well, here you can," says Kat Vecchio, a 23-year-old theater director, as she waits her turn. "Roller derby keeps you sane. I live in New York City.It's very cramped. You spend your days being very nice to people on the phone, in the office and in person. But you come here,and you can push the boundaries." An audio interview with players from the Gotham Girls Roller Derby: nytimes.com/nyregion. LENS

description: HARTFORD, Feb. 7 - A juror was dismissed on Tuesday on the 26th day of deliberations in the second fraud trial of Walter A. Forbes, the former chairman of Cendant.

description: OTTAWA, Feb. 8 A Nortel Networks, North America's largest telecommunications equipment maker, said today that it had reached a tentative agreement to pay about $2.4 billion in cash and stock to settle two class-action shareholder lawsuits that stemmed from the company's accounting scandal.

Cookware From the Minds Of Chefs
description: The Culinary Institute of America has introduced a line of professional quality cookware and utensils for home cooks. Called the Masters Collection, it was designed by chefs and includes more than 80 items. I liked the big kitchen peppermill ($50) and the set of stainless steel mixing bowls ($99.99) with measurements etched inside. The pots and pans ($89.99 to $370) are seven-ply with a copper core and a stainless steel finish. The equipment is made by Robinson Home Products of Buffalo; the institute is donating its licensing fees from Robinson to scholarships. It's available at ciacook.com, at the institute's gift shop in St. Helena, Calif., and in New York at the Kitchen Drawer in Hyde Park and Chef Central in Hartsdale. FOOD STUFF

description: STORRS, Conn., Feb. 7 - When Barbara Turner hit two free throws for Connecticut with 4 minutes 12 seconds left, a once-commanding Rutgers lead of 14 points had been whittled to 2. It seemed as if a familiar pattern was about to unfold once again. Doesn't Connecticut always find a way to defeat Rutgers on its home court?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KARETSKY, SARA
description: KARETSKY--Sara, 94. Passed away peacefully on February 6, 2006 at The Hebrew Home for the Aged. Loving and beloved wife of the late John (Jacob). Loving mother of Alfred, the late David & Samuel & daughtersin-law Bernice, Geraldine and Nancy. Proud grandmother of seven and great grandmother of thirteen. She lived her life for her family and took great pride in every child she taught to read at PS 187. Graveside services Wednesday, February 8, 2006 at 11 AM at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery 80 Commerce Street, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale, 5901 Palisade Ave, Bronx, NY 10471.

description: TOKYO, Feb. 7 - Toyota posted a record quarterly profit for the end of December, an increase of 34.1 percent over the previous year, placing Japan's largest automaker within striking distance of overtaking General Motors this year for the title of world's largest automaker.

title: Bombings Across Iraq Kill 5 Iraqis and 4 Marines
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 7 - Two bombs exploded minutes apart in a crowded Baghdad market on Tuesday morning, in one of two attacks that killed five Iraqis and appeared to be aimed at Shiites celebrating the religious festival of Ashura.

title: Classics on the Internet: A Promising Prognosis
description: In March 2001, toward the end of the dot-com boom, Alain Coblence, a wealthy French businessman, decided to finance Andante.com, a multifaceted classical music magazine on the Internet. In addition to offering a steady diet of reviews, commentary and news, Andante was going to offer a "virtual music library," with streaming of concerts, both live and taped. It was also a record label, dedicated to classy reissues of rare historic recordings.

title: Judge Is Urged to Intervene for Detainee Held in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 - Lawyers for a 44-year-old naturalized American citizen have been pressing a federal district judge to intervene in their client's case, saying that he had been arrested and held in Iraq for more than a year without being charged or given access to a lawyer.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: L.I. Man Accused Of Kidnapping And Sexual Attack
description: A 41-year-old Long Island man was arrested and charged with kidnapping and sexually abusing a 24-year-old woman on Monday morning, the police said. The man, Richard Padilla of Huntington Station, is accused of forcing the woman into a car at gunpoint at Second Avenue and East 12th Street about 6 a.m. Mr. Padilla then sexually assaulted her, the police said. Police officers on patrol said they stopped the car in Harlem after they saw Mr. Padilla commit a traffic violation. The officers had the woman step out of the car, and she told them that she had been abducted and sexually assaulted, the police said. The woman was taken to a hospital in stable condition. Mr. Padilla was also charged with committing a criminal sexual act and criminal possession of marijuana. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)

Arts, Briefly; CBS Wins in Sweeps
description: Despite the challenge posed by Fox's "24," CBS's solid Monday lineup was No. 1 in Nielsen's estimates. In the 9 p.m. hour, "24" managed to win the slot among adults 18 to 49, and at 9:30 p.m. it even beat CBS's "Courting Alex" (13.24 million) in total viewers, drawing an average audience of 13.6 million. But CBS's "Two and a Half Men" (16.44 million) and "CSI: Miami" (18.13 million) were the top two shows of the night among viewers, and they gave the network a victory for the first Monday of sweeps. Fox placed second, as its other offering, "Skating With Celebrities," featuring the ouster of the arrogant Dave Coulier and Nancy Kerrigan, delivered 10.33 million viewers. NBC ranked third among viewers and fourth in the 18-to-49 demographic. The season finale of its sea creature drama, "Surface," ended vividly, as a tsunami took the creatures onto land: 9.49 million viewers watched what is likely the last to be seen of "Surface." KATE AURTHUR

title: A Long Island City Awakening
description: Midtown Manhattan is closer to Long Island City than it is to downtown Manhattan, and the transportation links are excellent. All this has made the area particularly attractive to deep-pocketed developers of residential projects, like Rockrose and AvalonBay, and they and other builders have a number of projects under way to house people who cannot afford Manhattan prices or decline to pay them.

title: Who Cares About Grammys? He'll Take the Hit Records
description: ATLANTA - Having produced a handful of chart-topping songs on Mariah Carey's latest album, "The Emancipation of Mimi," including "Shake It Off," "Don't Forget About Us" and the huge hit "We Belong Together," the veteran producer Jermaine Dupri is widely regarded as the man behind Ms. Carey's phenomenal comeback. So it came as a surprise to many in the music industry that he was not nominated as producer of the year at the Grammy Awards, being presented tonight.

World Briefing | Asia: China: 6,000 Fires From Fireworks
description: Fireworks were linked to more than 6,000 fires over the Lunar New Year, a sharp increase that came after cities including Beijing lifted bans on fireworks, the Ministry of Public Security said. The fireworks-related fires tripled from last year and accounted for nearly half of the 13,904 fires nationwide during the Jan. 28-Feb. 4 holiday. The ministry said 63 people had died in the fires, a 41 percent drop from last year.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 48TH ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDS John Legend (left), Kanye West and Mariah Carey are the superstars this year, with eight nominations each. They'll be performing live from Los Angeles tonight, as will a bevy of other nominees, including Bruce Springsteen, Coldplay, U2, Sugarland and Faith Hill. Viewers can also expect to see Madonna, Christina Aguilera, Herbie Hancock, Jay-Z, Linkin Park, a tribute to Sly and the Family Stone, and Paul McCartney's first Grammys performance ever. It's still the most prestigious pop-music award around.

title: Principal Named at Brooklyn Tech
description: Randy J. Asher, the highly regarded founding principal of a small high school in Upper Manhattan, has been appointed interim acting principal of Brooklyn Technical High School, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said yesterday.

title: World Trade Agency Rules for U.S. in Biotech Dispute
description: The United States won a closely watched trade dispute yesterday when the World Trade Organization ruled that the European Union breached international rules by restricting imports of genetically modified crops and food made from them.

title: 3 Afghan Demonstrators Die in Clash With NATO Troops
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 7 - NATO troops fired on demonstrators in northern Afghanistan on Tuesday in a second day of deadly protests here against the publication of satirical cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad in European newspapers.

title: Chechnya Expels Danish Aid Agency
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 7 - The Danish Refugee Council, one of the largest aid organizations working in war-racked Chechnya and its neighboring republics, was expelled from Chechen territory on Tuesday, as anger spread yet further over Danish cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad.

description: MILLER--William. Of Boca Raton FL, formerly of Great Neck NY died February 7 after a valiant struggle. Beloved husband for 63 years of Ida. Devoted father of son, Robert and daughter-in-law Susan; daughter Janet Mait & son-in-law the late Harold Mait; and son, Gary Miller. Cherished grandfather of Josh, Kira, Jennifer, David, Emily and Jonathan. Dear brother of Irving Miller. Services Thursday February 9, 11 AM at "Riverside-Nassau North Chapels," 55 North Station Plaza (opposite the LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Taipei
description: WHY GO NOW In the last few years, Taipei A the sprawling metropolis of 2.6 million that is the capital of Taiwan A has leapt into modernity with a panache that puts the casino moguls of Macao and the skyscraper-erectors of Shanghai to shame.

title: Haitians Flock to Vote, on a Day of Anger and Hope
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 7 - After more than a year of planning, the long-awaited presidential elections began here on Tuesday with signs of the same tensions and disorder that have kept this poor, troubled nation at the brink of chaos for the last two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVY, SENATOR NORMAN J.
description: LEVY--Senator Norman J. 02/07/98. Eighth anniversary in heaven. To my beloved Norman on the anniversary of your passing, you are always remembered and forever in my thoughts and in my heart. Your legacy is being fulfilled and preserved through all who loved and respected you. I miss you, and will love you forever. Love, Joy

title: Europe Defends Stance on Genetically Altered Foods
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 8 - The European Commission defended its current practices on screening genetically altered foods in the wake of a report from the World Trade Organization that criticized its past action in restricting the entry of modified products into the European Union.

title: Bruno Reacts to a Threat by Bloomberg
description: ALBANY, Feb. 7 - For the last few days, two of the most powerful Republicans in the state, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, have kept their growing feud below the surface, with neither saying unkind words about the other.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORENTLICHER, DR. WILLIAM A.
description: ORENTLICHER--Dr. William A. Revered rabbi of the Bayside Jewish Center for 50 years. Accomplished Jewish scholar and university professor. Beloved and loving husband of Jeanne, devoted and adored father of Allen, Harriet, Gary, Paul and Rona, and doting grandfather of 11 grandchildren. He was a blessing to us all and we now bless his memory with our deepest love and respect. Contributions may be made to the Rabbi William Orentlicher Scholarship Fund at Yeshiva University.

title: Buy a Hybrid, and Save a Guzzler
description: SOME of my favorite people drive a Prius. They bought the car, obviously, because they were worried about the planet. But the fringe benefits are pretty nice, too.

title: New Artistic Underground in Belarus Is Theater Group
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 7 A The Free Theater of Belarus, not yet a year old, has no home, no permanent troupe and, for now, only three short plays in its repertory. It staged them for a while in a cramped bar called Graffiti in an industrial neighborhood of Minsk, the Belarussian capital, but the authorities warned the bar's owner to stop.

title: Republican Who Oversees N.S.A. Calls for Wiretap Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 - A House Republican whose subcommittee oversees the National Security Agency broke ranks with the White House on Tuesday and called for a full Congressional inquiry into the Bush administration's domestic eavesdropping program.

title: Vonage Plans to Go Public in $250 Million Offering
description: The Vonage Holdings Corporation, a provider of Internet-based telephone service, filed an initial public offering today with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell up to $250 million in common stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LENGEMANN, GEORGE L.
description: LENGEMANN--George L. On February 5, 2006 at the age of 78. Beloved husband of Ruth C. Haupert-Lengemann. Loving brother of Dorothy Lengemann Walker and caring uncle of Wendy L. Walker, both of Virginia, and Dr. William H. Walker of Pittsburgh. George waged a valiant battle against cancer for over two years with his characteristic dignity, wry sense of humor and indomitable work ethic. A dedicated life-long New York Giants football fan, he would consider it ironic that Super Bowl Sunday was his last day on earth. George had a distinguished career in investment management and security analysis spanning more than 50 years. For the past 34 years, he had been Vice President of S.W. Childs Management Corporation. He was also Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Lengemann Capital Management Assoc., Inc. Earlier, he had been affiliated with Peoples Trust Company of New Jersey, Guaranty Trust Company, a predecessor of Morgan-Guaranty and F.H. Vahesing. A 1951 graduate of Hofstra University, he earned an M.B.A. from N.Y.U.'s Stern Graduate School of Business in 1959. His service in the United States Army as a military photographer in Europe fortified a life-long love of photography. A past Vice President and Treasurer of the N.Y.U. Club of New York, he also served as Treasurer of the Touchdown Club of America and was a Member of the Princeton Club in New York and the Sun and Surf Beach Club in Atlantic Beach, NY. Family will receive friends on Wednesday, 7-9pm and Thursday 2-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave (81 St). Funeral services Friday, 9:30am at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, the family would be grateful for donations to St. John's Lutheran Church, PO Box 72, Brooklyn NY 11222; St. Luke's Lutheran Church, 308 W. 46 St, NY NY 10036; New York University Stern School of Business, 44 W. 4 St, NY NY 10012.

title: A Radical on the Run as a Novelist's Muse
description: CHERRY VALLEY, N.Y. - Dana Spiotta understands the idea of a secret life, holed up here in a remote part of New York State, running a restaurant with her husband, working as a waitress, and then, in her free time, sitting up in her study, writing novels. And a secret life forms the basis of Ms. Spiotta's second book, "Eat the Document," about fugitive radicals from the early 1970's still in hiding and living a counterfeit existence while they avoid prosecution for crimes committed in the name of social justice.

description: ALBANY, Feb. 7 - In a nod to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, Gov. George E. Pataki on Tuesday proposed increasing New York City's share of the governor's new cigarette tax plan by 50 cents a pack, which would raise the total tax on cigarettes sold in the city to $3.50 from $3.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the high rate of AIDS infection among black New Yorkers referred incorrectly to one statistic. According to the city health department, one in five black men ages 40 to 49 in Manhattan -- not in the entire city -- has H.I.V. or AIDS. (The citywide figure is just under 1 in 10 black men.)

title: A Leader Is Chosen for the 9/11 Museum
description: Seeking a leader to guide a much-disputed 9/11 museum into existence at ground zero, officials announced yesterday that they had settled on Alice M. Greenwald, an associate director for museum programs at the Holocaust Museum in Washington.

title: HoHo? WeVar? Wherever, It's There
description: IT seems that no one knows what to call the neighborhood that Giorgione 508 calls home. Jorge Neves, a partner in the two-month-old spot, its older sibling Giorgione around the corner and the Portuguese restaurant Po up the block -- someone who should by all accounts have a name for where he goes to work every day -- gave what amounted to a verbal shrug when I put the question to him.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Donovan Will Not Run For Attorney General
description: Daniel M. Donovan Jr., the Staten Island district attorney, said yesterday that he would not seek the Republican nomination for attorney general. Mr. Donovan, in his first term as district attorney, had been urged to challenge Jeanine F. Pirro, the former Westchester County district attorney, for the nomination. In a statement, Mr. Donovan said he did not have enough time to form the kind of campaign he would have liked before the September primary. "It is my belief that the advanced date of the political calendar would not allow me to put together the type of campaign I believe my supporters deserve, through a divisive primary and general election," he said. JONATHAN P. HICKS (NYT)

description: MILLER--Pamela.69, Of Hartsdale died February 5, 2006 after a brief illness. Beloved wife of Dr. Irwin; loving mother of Eric (and Andrea) of Marlboro, NJ and Larry (and Suzy) of Niskayuna, NY; adored grandmother of Shelby, Nathan & Rebecca, sister of Gene Schaffer, Susan Hertzberg, Linda Lee & Bonnie Kamen. She also adored and will be missed by her beloved pets. Funeral service 10 AM Wednesday Woodlands Community Temple, 50 Worthington Road, White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Woodlands Community Temple or the Baker Institute for Animal Health at Cornell University.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Borough President's Grandson Is Charged
description: Three teenagers, including the grandson of the Staten Island borough president, James P. Molinaro, were arrested on Monday night and charged with stabbing and beating another youth in a Staten Island schoolyard, the police said. Steven Molinaro, 17, the borough president's grandson, and two friends, Charles Sarnelli, 18, and William Guash, 16, were charged with attempted murder, assault and criminal possession of a weapon in the attack, which took place about 10:30 p.m. on Saturday outside Public School 52, the police said. The victim, Richard Orloski, was stabbed five times, beaten with a stick and punched and kicked repeatedly, according to the Staten Island district attorney's office. Mr. Orloski, whose age was not released, was left with a punctured lung and bruises,. A spokesman for the borough president declined to comment. ANDREW JACOBS (NYT)

World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Donation by Executive
description: The Samsung Group, under fire last year for its suspected role in the bribing of politicians and illicit transfers of stock, said that its chairman, Lee Kun Hee, left, and his children would donate 590 billion won ($621 million) to charity. Samsung also said that it would withdraw from its disputes with the government over tax penalties and its fight with the Fair Trade Commission over rules governing holding companies. The announcement comes less than a week after Mr. Lee apologized for various controversies linked to him. Last year, prosecutors investigated whether Mr. Lee wrongfully used corporate money to bribe presidential candidates; he was ultimately cleared of those suspicions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FAZIO, CHARLES R.
description: FAZIO--Charles R. A prominent international consultant, died suddenly on February 3, 2006. Born in Brooklyn, NY in 1936, son of George and Helen (Mulcahy) Fazio. Survived by his wife Carolyn; his children Carla Fazio, Teresa Fazio Hoffman and Steve Hoffman, Charles and Nanette Fazio, Victoria Fazio Capeletti and Clayton Capeletti, and Francesca Fazio; grandchildren Darius Radmanesh, Alexis Hoffman, Charles Fazio, William Fazio and Tyler Capeletti; and numerous cousins in New York, Ireland and Italy. Fazio graduated from Georgetown University in 1957. Following military service, Fazio's entire career was dedicated to serving non-profit organizations worldwide. He was cofounder and President of Fazio International Ltd., headquartered in Boca Raton, FL. Fazio held key volunteer positions with many non-profit organizations, notably serving as President of the Georgetown University Alumni Association and as Chairman of the Fellows, American Society of Association Executives. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC, on Thursday, February 9 from 2-5 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. Mass will be celebrated on Friday, February 10 at 10:30 a.m.; St. Ignatius Loyola Catholic Church, NYC. Memorial services are also planned in Boca Raton and in Washington, DC. In lieu of flowers the family requests that contributions be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WELLS, PATRICIA KEEVER
description: WELLS--Patricia Keever. On February 6, 2006, in Long Beach, NY, her favorite place on Earth. Loving daughter of the late Katherine (nee Holm) and Christopher Keever. Devoted sister of the late Frank Keever. Dear friend and companion of the late Edward G. Condon. Loving cousin and dedicated friend to many. Pat will always have a special place in the hearts of the Condon and Rafferty families. Reposing at the Macken Mortuary, Rockville Centre Chapel, 52 Clinton Avenue, Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass 10 AM, Friday St. Ignatius Martyr RC Church, Long Beach. Cremation private.

title: A theater enters from the underground
Paid Notice: Deaths   POSEN, CAROL
description: POSEN--Carol. Our beloved daughter, you brought sunshine and happiness into our lives every day. Jack and Jenny are your gifts to us and we treasure them dearly. A fantastic wife and unbelievable mother, unique daughter, loving, kind and caring sister, grandmother and friend, you were beautiful inside and out. May you rest in peace surrounded by the love of all who knew you. We will love you and miss you every day for the rest of our lives. Mom and Dad

description: The big sound of Philip Glass, a set worthy of Lincoln Center, clothes so clear in their imagination they conveyed the designer's vision at a glance: could Marc Jacobs have offered a more optimistic expression of American style?

title: Hollywood's broody mood is in full spread
World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Gunmen Storm Border Newspaper
description: Two heavily armed men burst into the Nuevo Laredo offices of the border city's largest newspaper, El Maana, on Monday night, threw a hand grenade and sprayed bullets at more than 20 reporters and editors. One reporter, Jaime Orozco, was shot and seriously wounded. Several others were injured by flying glass. The gunmen escaped, their motive unknown. Officials at the newspaper said the use of heavy weapons suggested that the attack had been ordered by drug dealers. President Vicente Fox condemned the assault and ordered his attorney general to investigate. "To organized criminals, I say again, you will not defeat the people of Mexico," he said.

title: TechBrief: EU seeks lower charges for mobile calls abroad
Clinton Shifts Party to New Club, Citing Size (Not Those Rumors)
description: Bikini-clad dancers discoing inside glass-walled showers. Beautiful people carousing on the dance floors and canoodling in the V.V.I.P. room. Murmurs about drugs and sex in other rooms.

title: Michaels Leaving 'Monday Night Football'
description: ESPN has shed a discontented Al Michaels from his contract to call "Monday Night Football" for the next eight years and named Mike Tirico the play-by-play voice of the series for the foreseeable future.

title: The President, Spying and the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Settlement Would Protect Prospective Tenants
description: Thousands of New York City tenants would get some new protection against inaccurate and outdated Housing Court data that is often used by landlords seeking to screen out undesirable tenants, under a tentative settlement with the largest tenant agency in the country. "It is a very big deal, but there are a lot of other issues remaining," said Michael McKee, who runs a tenant political action committee. "People are constantly saying, 'but if I take the landlord to court, I might end up on the black list.' It has had a tremendous chilling effect." In the past, the screening agency, now known as First Advantage SafeRent, simply reported the filing of suits for eviction or nonpayment of rent and not the final disposition of cases. The draft agreement, which must be approved by a judge, requires the screening agency to update its files regularly with information on the outcome of cases, and to expunge records of suits when tenants show that the court found a case to be without merit or filed in error. A spokesman for First Advantage declined to comment on the agreement before the judge's hearing. JOSH BARBANEL (NYT)

title: Lou Jones, 74, Sprinting Star, Dies
description: Lou Jones, a former world-record holder in the 400 meters and a member of the United States 4x400-meter relay squad that won a gold medal at the 1956 Melbourne Olympics, died Friday at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 74 and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Gadgets of the Week: Player with plenty for road or home
Some Democrats Are Sensing Missed Opportunities
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 - Democrats are heading into this year's elections in a position weaker than they had hoped for, party leaders say, stirring concern that they are letting pass an opportunity to exploit what they see as widespread Republican vulnerabilities.

title: Pataki Plan Would Allow City to Create Charter Schools
description: ALBANY, Feb. 7 - A new proposal by Gov. George E. Pataki would allow New York City to approve up to 50 of its own charter schools. If the plan is approved by the Legislature, it would give the city broad authority to decide who could operate the privately run but publicly financed schools.

title: In the Mood for Malpeques
description: Oysters are a must-have for a Valentine's Day menu. Most fish markets sell one or two kinds at this time of year. But the Lobster Place in the Chelsea Market, 75 Ninth Avenue (15th Street), (212) 255-5672, always has at least six varieties, including Diamond Points from Delaware Bay, Moonstones from Rhode Island, Malpeques or Caraquets from Canada and Kumamotos from Washington. The branch at 252 Bleecker Street (Leroy Street), (212) 352-8063, carries a more limited selection. The oysters are 89 cents to $1.10 each, with a charge of 20 cents apiece for opening them. FOOD STUFF

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a memorial service for Coretta Scott King misstated the day of her death. It was last Monday, Jan. 30, not Tuesday.

title: Pfizer to Explore Sale or Spinoff of a Division
description: Pfizer said yesterday that it would explore spinning off or selling its consumer health care division, a unit that had $3.9 billion in sales last year and whose brands include Listerine mouthwash and Benadryl allergy medicine.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Sunday, about Chicago's economy, misstated the location of the Cabrini Green housing project. It is on Chicago's Near North Side, not the South Side.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Reuven Frank, former president of NBC News and a pioneering producer, referred incorrectly to his surviving grandchildren. They are a grandson and a granddaughter, not two grandsons.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article in Weekend on Friday about Wendy Wasserstein's work for television referred incorrectly to her surviving brother Bruce. He is chairman and chief executive of the Lazard investment bank, not a hedge fund titan.

title: The Telegram
description: I've received exactly one telegram in my life. It arrived on New Year's Eve a couple of decades ago. The message was congratulatory -- it quoted J. D. Salinger -- and so was the medium, which had a sort of "all the ships at sea" feeling about it. In fact, the telegram was just a piece of paper that looked a little down at the heels, as if it had been a ragged night for the telegraphers. But it arrived with a sense of its own occasion, which went a long way toward enhancing the occasion it had been sent to celebrate: a wedding.

title: Weld Attacks Spitzer on Property Tax Plans
description: ROCHESTER, Feb. 7 - William F. Weld, campaigning for the Republican nomination for governor, intensified his attacks on Eliot Spitzer on Tuesday, criticizing the Democratic candidate for his positions on taxation.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Strip Club Workers Charged
description: An owner, a manager and a bookkeeper at the Scores strip club company have been indicted on charges of evading about $200,000 in state taxes on $3.1 million in income, the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday. According to the charges, Richard K. Goldring, chief executive of Scores Holding Company, which is publicly traded; Harvey B. Osher, manager of Scores Showroom; Cheryl Osher, his niece and a Scores bookkeeper; and five corporations associated with Scores are accused of funneling revenue from the club into dummy corporations, which Mr. Osher and Mr. Goldring used to pay personal expenses. Mr. Morgenthau said the investigation began after customers, including a St. Louis businessman who spent $241,000 in one night last fall, complained about overcharges to their credit cards. But no charges have been brought related to overcharges. The defendants pleaded not guilty yesterday and were released. Mr. Osher, who had a prior federal conviction for money laundering, posted $10,000 cash bail. ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS (NYT)

title: A Musical for Tweens Captures Its Audience
description: The executives at Disney are quite clear: they are not surprised at all by the runaway success of "High School Musical," the new break-into-song television movie that has quickly established itself as a "Grease" for the tween set.

title: Redick Leads Way as Duke Holds Off North Carolina
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Feb. 7 - Duke and North Carolina will forever be celebrated for the championship banners they hang, and for the all-American players and N.B.A. stars their basketball programs produce.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Harriman: 4 Die In Thruway Collision
description: Four people, including a 3-year-old boy, were killed yesterday afternoon after a driver heading south lost control of his tractor-trailer on the New York State Thruway in Orange County, veered into the northbound lanes and crashed head-on into a Range Rover, the authorities said. The boy, Amir Magomedov, and his parents, Nabi Magomedov, 35, and Natalia Shcherbina, 33, who were in the Range Rover, were pronounced dead at the scene. The truck driver, Andrew McKiver, 63, of Roosevelt, N.Y., was airlifted to Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y., where he later died. The family lived in Rochester, but was originally from Russia, the state police said. The crash occurred at 12:45 p.m. about 45 miles north of New York City, near the Woodbury Common shopping mall. Northbound traffic was tied up for hours afterward. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALVAREZ, ERNESTO
description: ALVAREZ--Ernesto. Died on February 1 in Palm Beach of a thoracic aneurism. Coffee grower, entrepreneur, patron of the arts, and philanthropist, he was born in El Salvador. He graduated from the Hackley School and from Yale University. He served as a trustee of Casita Maria, Inc., and of the International Rescue Committee. He was a founder of the Museo de Arte Moderno in San Salvador, as well as founding president of Amigos del Volcan and Friends for El Salvador. As the youngest Minister of Tourism for El Salvador, he started the International Music Festival which attracted Pablo Casals, Margot Fonteyn and Isaac Stern among many other internationally known performers. He leaves behind his beloved partner of 27 years, Michel Langlais, his sister Carmen Elena Alvarez de Avila, six nieces and nephews and 13 grand-nieces and nephews. A Funeral Mass will be held in the Capilla de Montelena in San Salvador, with a Memorial Service planned for April in New York, exact date to be announced. Donations may be made in his memory to Friends for El Salvador, attn: Carol Dauber, 225 East 73rd Street, NYC 10021. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Suspect In Killing Of Police Sergeant Is Arrested
description: Federal authorities in Brooklyn arrested a man yesterday on charges that he shot and killed an off-duty police sergeant in the Dominican Republic in 2004 after the officer scolded him for urinating in the street. Federal marshals and F.B.I. agents arrested the man, Jeffry Alejandro Pea Bencosme, 22, based on an extradition request filed on Oct. 25, 2004, in connection with the killing of the sergeant, Fortuna Sanchez, in Santiago. Court papers said that Mr. Pea Bencosme shot Sergeant Sanchez in the chest after the reprimand and an argument. Mr. Pea Bencosme, who the federal authorities said was a United States citizen, was put under house arrest after the killing and then fled to New York. Magistrate Judge Steven M. Gold in federal court in Brooklyn ordered Mr. Pea Bencosme held pending a hearing in March. WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM (NYT)

The menu features elaborate food like ballotine of chicken and foie gras, truffle-roasted sweetbreads and roast duck with turnips for two. Doug Psaltis is the chef de cuisine: 90 Madison Avenue (29th Street), (212) 889-7100.

title: A Cemetery of Poets Is in Crisis in Rome
description: ROME - This city's tiny Non-Catholic Cemetery possibly contains the highest density of famous and important bones anywhere in the world: the cramped final resting place of the poets Keats and Shelley, dozens of diplomats, the Bulgari family, Goethe's only son and Antonio Gramsci, a founding father of European Communism, to name a few. The cemetery (in Italian, Cimitero acattolico), also widely known as the Protestant Cemetery, although it contains the graves of Jews and other non-Christians, is the oldest burial ground in continuous use in Europe, conservationists say.

title: Ordinary Killers: A Theme of the Movie Moment
description: It's one of the tritest sound bites on local television news. "He was such a nice, quiet man; I never would have expected it," some befuddled person says about a neighbor who seemed perfectly normal until he grabbed an Uzi and went on a killing spree. The variations are endless and seem ludicrous to those watching at home. Weren't there any signs of the nice neighbor's lethal instincts?

Seaman; Joseph Dickey Jr.

Two of the men, Charles Bl Goudand Eugne Dju, led young supporters of President Laurent Gbagbo in four days of attacks last month on the bases of United Nations peacekeepers. The third, Fofie Kouakou, is a commander of antigovernment rebel forces.

title: The Art of Saying Nothing
description: We thought President Bush's two recent Supreme Court nominees set new lows when it came to giving vague and meaningless answers to legitimate questions, but Attorney General Alberto Gonzales made them look like models of openness when he testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Monday about domestic spying. Mr. Gonzales seems to have forgotten the promise he made to the same panel last year when it voted to promote him from White House counsel to attorney general: that he would serve the public interest and stop acting like a hired gun helping a client figure out how to evade the law.

title: Arts, Briefly; Getty Foundation to Aid Arts in New Orleans
description: The Getty Foundation has established a $2 million fund to aid New Orleans's visual arts organizations as they recover from Hurricane Katrina, the foundation is to announce today. The Getty's Fund for New Orleans will allow nonprofit arts groups to apply for two types of assistance: conservation grants to care for their art collections, archives, historic buildings and landscapes, and transition planning grants, to strengthen institutions as they regain their footing. "It isn't just a question of needing money to rehire their staffs, but in a totally changed city, how do you go about your business?" said Deborah Marrow, director of the Getty Foundation, which supports the visual arts. The number of arts organizations that will benefit remains to be seen. Guidelines for applicants will be posted on the foundation's Web site, www.getty.edu/foundation. Typically, the foundation's gifts range from $5,000 to $250,000, Ms. Marrow said. "It's a first step," she added. "I hope what will come out of it is a road map for the future and that it will be a catalyst for other funding." The grant is the foundation's second contribution to the hurricane recovery; it donated $100,000 toward the National Trust for Historic Preservation's efforts to assess damage to historic buildings and districts. ROBIN POGREBIN

title: A Radical on the Run as a Novelist's Muse
description: CHERRY VALLEY, N.Y.  Dana Spiotta understands the idea of a secret life, holed up here in a remote part of New York State, running a restaurant with her husband, working as a waitress, and then, in her free time, sitting up in her study, writing novels. And a secret life forms the basis of Ms. Spiotta's second book, "Eat the Document," about fugitive radicals from the early 1970's still in hiding and living a counterfeit existence while they avoid prosecution for crimes committed in the name of social justice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, LEWIS H.
description: MILLER--Lewis H. Peacefully on February 6. Beloved husband of Joanne. Loving father of Harry (Nancy) and Dawn (Richard). Adoring grandfather of Ari, Noah, Kyla, Amy, Nina and Rachel. Cherished brother to Caryl Bank. Graduate of Lowell Tech 1957 and resident of Roslyn for over 40 years. CoFounder of the Bank-Miller Co. in N.Y.C. C.E.O. of Growing Tree North Nursery School in Roslyn. Current member of Temple Judea of Manhasset. Services will be at "Gutterman's", 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Wednesday 11 AM.

title: Arts, Briefly; White House Cuts Money for Public Broadcasting
description: The White House budget has proposed cutting support for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting by more than 25 percent, or more than $100 million. If adopted by Congress, the budget would be a sharp blow to the corporation, which provides money for public radio and television and has been instituting a variety of changes after a tumultuous year. The corporation underwent a management shakeup late last year, and its former chairman, Kenneth W. Tomlinson, was forced to resign from the board in November after investigators found evidence that he had violated a law intended to insulate programming decisions from politics. But the public television and radio stations have powerful allies in Congress, and previous efforts to cut back the corporation's budgets extensively have failed in recent years. STEPHEN LABATON

title: Smiling in Toronto, Davis Wags a Finger at the Knicks
description: TORONTO, Feb. 7 - After Antonio Davis finished his first practice as a Raptor on Tuesday, he had some parting words for those who run his former team, the Knicks.

title: Excavating Roman Tilework, From the Ancient 70's
description: Some people might remember 57 West 48th Street as the address for several Indian restaurants, most recently Shaan. But back in 1957 it was home to one of the city's most grandiose restaurants, the Forum of the 12 Caesars, created by Joseph Baum for Restaurant Associates. Along with the gladiators' helmets as wine buckets and waiters in togas it had a floor-to-ceiling mosaic mural in the bar. That mural, all 12 by 15 feet of it, was covered with wallboard and plaster after the restaurant closed in 1975. But two weeks ago it was revealed during the renovations for A. J. Maxwells, a steakhouse and Continental restaurant that is to open on March 13. The owners, Lenny Passarelli and his partners, hired Susan Brown of Serpentile, who has done mosaic work for the city's subway stations, to restore it. "It doesn't need much," Ms. Brown said. "It's in fabulous condition." FOOD STUFF

Services are on Wednesday 11:30AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck. title: The Parent Trap

We read it not in women's studies, but in a class on intellectual history; and indeed, from the vantage point of a young woman coming of age in the mid-1980's, the world that Betty Friedan depicted -- a world in which a married woman couldn't get a job without her husband's permission, couldn't open a checking account and couldn't get credit in her own name -- seemed like ancient history.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Guilty Plea In Fatal Concert Fire
description: Under a plea agreement announced last week, Daniel M. Biechele, a band tour manager who set off a pyrotechnic display that ignited a fire that killed 100 people, pleaded guilty to 100 counts of involuntary manslaughter. Mr. Biechele, 29, left, who was the tour manager for Great White, entered the plea before Associate Justice Francis J. Darigan Jr. of Superior Court in Providence. He faces up to 10 years in prison and will be sentenced May 8. More than 200 people were injured in the fire, which happened at the Station nightclub in West Warwick on Feb. 20, 2003. The club's owners, Michael and Jeffrey Derderian, were also indicted; their trial is pending.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 - Corruption scandals and new scrutiny on lobbying practices are providing powerful ammunition to critics of earmarks -- the popular legislative practice of steering federal dollars to home state projects or the causes of well-connected lobbyists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARCUS, SAMUEL
description: MARCUS--Samuel. On February 5, 2006 at home with Sylvia, his beloved wife of over 50 years. Cherished father of Andrew & Rhonda, adored grandfather of Sydney, friend of Carolyn. He will be deeply missed and never forgotten. Love for children and nature but most of all his family made him the special person he was. Devotion to his business and all people concerned made Sam a role model. His granddaughter Sydney was the light of his life as he was for many. Services will be at RiversideNassau North Chapel, 55 North Shore Rd, Great Neck Thursday, February 9 at 12:30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CATTON, SAM E.
description: CATTON--Sam E. The Magen David Yeshivah Family mourn the passing of our much loved and highly respected friend, founder and patriarch Sam Catton. His knowledge of Sephardic tradition, history and literature is unsurpassed. As a founder of the Sephardic Heritage Foundation and author of our daily and holiday prayer books, his legacy will live on through the many lives he touched with his teachings, wisdom, kindness and keen wit. We extend our deepest sympathy to his children Harry and Diane, Mrs. Frieda Catton, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Our prayers are with them at this most difficult time. Eddie J. Esses, President And the entire Magen David Yeshivah Family

title: Lennon's music: They love it, yeah, yeah, yeah
Barrier Could Have Prevented Accident, Safety Board Says
description: An investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board has concluded that a two-car collision in New Jersey that killed six people on May 1, 2003, could have been avoided if there had been a concrete median barrier in place, as there was along the rest of the highway in the area.

title: Giambi Hoping to Build on His Feel-Good Story
description: Two news conferences, almost precisely a year apart, offered strikingly different images of Jason Giambi.

title: Chinese Editor Dies After Beating by the Police
description: BEIJING, Feb. 7 - A Chinese newspaper editor who was severely beaten by the police after he published an article that alleged petty abuses of power in their ranks died of the wounds he suffered in the attack, a New York-based media watchdog group said Tuesday.

title: Letter from Shanghai: Genie of free speech dodges China's censors
In Bronx, a Possible Case of High School Cheating, but Not by Students
description: FOR 34 years, Morris Schulgasser was a high school English teacher and administrator. He has a doctorate from Columbia, was head of the English department at John F. Kennedy High in the Bronx for seven years, and in 2002 was named a Bronx high school supervisor of the year.

title: Barefoot in the Caribbean? Not on These Hikes
description: THERE is more to a Caribbean vacation than lounging on the beach with a cool colada in hand. Some of the world's best rain forest and volcanic hiking can be found within the lush canopied Caribbean trail systems. Chock-full of waterfalls and hot springs, bright-colored birds and howling monkeys, flora-lined trails cut through thick, fragrant forests and up cloud-covered mountains. Hard-packed paths wend past tropical gardens, and steep, rocky routes climb through multiple ecosystems revealing stunning island views at the top. Here are six terrific hiking destinations with something to please everyone from the casual to the serious hiker.

title: Chocolate That Flashes Its Passport
description: HIS name was Conrad Miller, and he would be our chocolate sommelier for the afternoon.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: G.M. Cuts Executive Pay, Halves Dividend And Changes Benefit Plans for Retirees General Motors, under pressure to show its blue collar workers that investors and executives will also sacrifice to help overcome its deepest losses in more than a decade, said that it would cut pay for top officials and cut its stock dividend by half. G.M., still clinging to its status as the world's largest auto company, also announced changes in the pension and health care plans for its retired salaried workers. [Page A1.]

title: Fragrant and Flavorful, and Inspired by a Street Snack
description: THE robust, earthy but fairly one-dimensional flavors of most of the malbecs we tasted, whether from Argentina or Cahors in France, demand food that is also robust and earthy. But the wines offer an inky garnet canvas on which colorful spices can be pinned.
