title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Growth Estimate Is 8.1%
description: India forecast that economic growth would be 8.1 percent in the fiscal year that ends in March, exceeding the expectations of analysts. The government attributed the gain to robust growth in manufacturing and services and higher productivity in farming after abundant rainfall. The government's estimate makes India the second-fastest growing economy in the world, after China. The government said in the forecast that manufacturing is estimated to grow 9.4 percent for the year after rising 8.1 percent in the previous year. Both manufacturing and services have shown strong growth while a rise in farming income has created demand for goods and services. India's economy grew 7.5 percent last year.

title: Dissident Is Killed in Nepal's First Election in 7 Years
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 8 A There was violence in Nepal today as the country held its first elections in 7 years. The military shot and killed a political dissident who was protesting the elections, while suspected Maoist guerrillas lobbed bombs at government buildings.

title: Review: A box for groovin' in every room
A Sip, a Tango: Malbec Old and New
description: MALBEC is a grape with a history that stretches back centuries in southwestern France, but the French get little credit for any of malbec's current renown. No, today, when consumers think of malbec, only one country comes to mind: Argentina.

title: Trying to keep the lid on in France
Nassau's Executive Unveils Plan to Reduce the Number of Abortions
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Feb. 7 - Nassau County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi announced a plan on Tuesday intended to reduce abortions, calling the proposal a "politically risky" step as he contemplates running for governor this year. Even as he was speaking, an abortion rights group issued a statement criticizing the plan.

title: Berlin Journal; Finally Filling a Vacant Lot Ravaged by Tides of Terror
description: BERLIN - For decades, even as a renewed Berlin grew up around it, one large lot that might otherwise have been prime territory for development has lain vacant, and not surprisingly.

title: Bush Takes His Budget Message to New Hampshire
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 A President Bush made a sales trip on behalf of his budget today to New Hampshire, a state whose traditional antipathy to taxes made it a friendly setting.

title: Tapes of Hussein to Be Analyzed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 - The chairman of the House Intelligence Committee has turned over to intelligence agencies 12 hours of audio recordings of Saddam Hussein meeting with top advisers, an aide to the chairman, Representative Peter Hoekstra, Republican of Michigan, said Tuesday.

title: Iran deadlock
To Drink, to Learn: A Rent-a-Sommelier
description: Wine tastings at home are becoming increasingly popular. Instead of scurrying around for the wines, buying food to go with them and organizing the glassware, you can have Paul Lang, left, a former sommelier at Babbo, take care of it. His enterprise, A Casa, will do it all for a fee starting at $75 a person for a wine and cheese tasting, and $125 a person for a dinner. He will also talk about the wines in as much detail as you like. Mr. Lang provides each guest with a written description of the wines and a map of their region, as he did at an Italian dinner he prepared and explained for a party of 10, including Timothy Huang and Diane Chang, in an uptown Manhattan apartment last week. Information: (646) 851-8166 or acasanyc.com. FOOD STUFF

title: The End User: Cashing in on cachet

description: In a display of grand corporate theater, Bruce Wasserstein and Carl C. Icahn shared a podium yesterday to step up their indictment of the management of Time Warner Inc. and argue their rationale for breaking the company into four separately traded public companies.

title: Peter Ladefoged, 80, Linguist Who Was Immersed in Speech, Is Dead
description: Peter Ladefoged, an internationally renowned linguist who spent his life blissfully awash in the whistles, murmurs, pops, clicks and trills that make up the world's spoken languages, died on Jan. 24 in London. Professor Ladefoged, who was returning to his home in Aliso Viejo, Calif., from fieldwork in India, was 80.

title: Evangelical Leaders JoinGlobal Warming Initiative
description: Despite opposition from some of their colleagues, 86 evangelical Christian leaders have decided to back a major initiative to fight global warming, saying "millions of people could die in this century because of climate change, most of them our poorest global neighbors."

title: Excavating Roman Tilework, From the Ancient 70's
description: Some people might remember 57 West 48th Street as the address for several Indian restaurants, most recently Shaan. But back in 1957 it was home to one of the city's most grandiose restaurants, the Forum of the 12 Caesars, created by Joseph Baum for Restaurant Associates. Along with the gladiators' helmets as wine buckets and waiters in togas it had a floor-to-ceiling mosaic mural in the bar. That mural, all 12 by 15 feet of it, was covered with wallboard and plaster after the restaurant closed in 1975. But two weeks ago it was revealed during the renovations for A. J. Maxwells, a steakhouse and Continental restaurant that is to open on March 13. The owners, Lenny Passarelli and his partners, hired Susan Brown of Serpentile, who has done mosaic work for the city's subway stations, to restore it. "It doesn't need much," Ms. Brown said. "It's in fabulous condition."

title: A Tale of Intrigue You Won't Hear on the Met's Headsets
description: AT the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday morning, tour guides softly paid compliments to items encased in glass. Herds of schoolchildren followed their teacher shepherds, giggling and whispering. Patrons listened on headsets as narrators urged them to notice the transcendent, made from metal, or paint, or clay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUSKIN, PAMELA E.
description: BUSKIN--Pamela E. Boslet. Of Montclair, New Jersey, 60, on February 4, 2006. Beloved wife of John Buskin. Cherished mother of Oliver and Roxanne Buskin, all of Montclair. Caring sister of Robert Boslet of Uniondale, NY. Memorial 2PM Saturday, February 11, First Congregational Church, 40 South Fullerton, Montclair, NJ.

description: Stocks fell yesterday after Toll Brothers, the nation's largest builder of luxury homes, said 2006 sales would be less than its most recent forecast.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the television actor Al Lewis by The Associated Press on Sunday misstated his age. His son Ted Lewis says he was 82, not 95. A picture credit misstated the photographer's given name. He was Henny Ray Abrams, not Henry.

title: Nebraska Man Sentenced for Having Sex With Girl, 13
description: A 23-year-old Nebraska man who pleaded guilty to first-degree sexual assault last year for having sex with his 13-year-old girlfriend, whom he impregnated and later married, was sentenced to 18 to 30 months in prison yesterday.

description: An Op-Ed article on Sunday, about Chicago's economy, misstated the location of the Cabrini Green housing project. It is on Chicago's Near North Side, not the South Side.

title: 'Made in China' labels don't tell whole story
A Cemetery of Poets Is in Crisis in Rome
description: ROME  This city's tiny Non-Catholic Cemetery possibly contains the highest density of famous and important bones anywhere in the world: the cramped final resting place of the poets Keats and Shelley, dozens of diplomats, the Bulgari family, Goethe's only son and Antonio Gramsci, a founding father of European Communism, to name a few. The cemetery (in Italian, Cimitero acattolico), also widely known as the Protestant Cemetery, although it contains the graves of Jews and other non-Christians, is the oldest burial ground in continuous use in Europe, conservationists say.

title: A Startling New Lesson in the Power of Imagery
Jets Continue Remodeling: Bradway Is Replaced
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Feb. 7 - Three weeks after naming a new coach, the Jets went a step further Tuesday and named a new general manager. In a move that was not expected, Terry Bradway was pushed aside and replaced by Mike Tannenbaum, who has been with the team since 1997 and is best known as an expert on the salary cap.

title: Designers Forsake Simplicity for Her Sequined Sister
description: Was it just a season ago that fashion designers were declaring that now is the time to clear the closets of embellishment and make way for the new minimalism? Well, gotcha.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about women who lead American Indian tribes misstated the name of an organization that provided data on the number of such women. It is the National Congress of American Indians, not the National Congress of Indians.

title: Four killed in cartoon protests in Afghanistan
Senate Votes to Debate Bill for Asbestos Victims' Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 - Backers of legislation to create a $140 billion trust fund for victims of asbestos exposure won an important victory on Tuesday evening, when the Senate voted to begin debate on the measure. The vote was 98 to 1, and came after critics dropped their opposition when they realized that they did not have enough votes to block the debate.

title: Solzhenitsyn returns, on Russian TV
Keepers of the Culture
description: Keith Calhoun and Chandra McCormick's portraits of a vanishing Louisiana.

title: Fabric Painting
Gear Test With Nate Carey, Ski Instructor
description: Good ski goggles are multitaskers. The right pair will protect eyes from sun and wind, enhance vision, reduce glare and, ideally, look cool.

title: New York Collections
description: The fall fashions throw 80's raunchy chic in the face of a conformist era. Americans are regaining their interest in cultural flux.

title: The Parent Trap
description: Judith Warner has written an Op-Ed for the Times on Betty Friedan; it appears in the paper today. Read the rest of Warners Op-Ed, then post a comment about it below.  The Editors

title: Distant Farms
description: Selborne Journal: Sunday, 8 February 1784: 29 1/10; 33; NW. Severe frost, sun, sharp wind, bright, frost. Snow covers the ground.

title: Red Carpet
Less Than Super Mario
description: As if a lone indie blogger doesnt have enough to worry about, Paramount keeps sending The Reeler tax info for Mario Van Peebles. The Reeler and the Bagger are sworn enemies  The Reeler christened his blog in part because he was deeply offended by the Baggers feckless take on the New York film industry  but have reached a kind of dtente. The Bagger actually reads The Reeler, and has nothing to do with the erroneous shipping of earnings statements to its proprietor.

title: Vanity, Nudity, Pruditry
description: Yesterday the Bagger exercised rare restraint in not linking to the nude picture of Scarlett Johansson and Keira Knightley. It was not just because he spilled his coffee when he opened up the New York Post and saw the Vanity Fair picture of the pair with some homeless guy who apparently wandered into the shoot. And it wasnt even that Ms. Johansson was selling crack, visually, in one of those magazine covers that will live in infamy. Its just that the Bagger did not want to participate in the objectification of two of the more promising young actors of our time  hes got three daughters to think about, after all. But last night he found a much more chaste link  Reuters via Yahoo  with a postage-size picture that renders its more naughty bits in miniature. Turns out Rachel McAdams decided not to go there at the last minute and bowed out, and that the issue includes George Clooney as well, although he kept his clothes on, perhaps because he didnt want to reveal some of the stretch marks he picked up by beefing up for his role in Syriana.

title: The Sensitive-Artist Type
description: The Bagger has been neglecting his bookmarks of late and they have been neglecting hm him back. One of the nicer bits he missed was the Hollywood Reporters roundtable with the writers nominated for the Writers Guild of America awards. (Crash and Brokeback Mountain won for original and scripted screenplay, respectively.) Everybody in the gang chat did their bit and played to type, with writer-director Stephen Gaghan making sure he put across the undue burden of not only writing a film, but directing it as well. Directors, he explained, are called on to make 10,000 decisions a day, any one of which could change the movie irrevocably. Thats anxiety. The writer of The 40-Year-Old Virgin, Judd Apatow, suggested they had the bong-wielding contingent of writers locked up. Its nice to know that writers still smoke reefer, he said, by way of explaining how the comedy he wrote got some play from the writers guild while it was ignored everywhere else during the award season. And Diana Ossana opened up a vein on those things that troubled her sleep: The tagline gay cowboy movie really annoyed us. Gosh, shes right  that is SO unfair. Paul Haggis, who wrote, directed, produced  and for all we know, worked in craft services on  Crash, said hes all for someone abjectly loving or loathing his film. Id much rather have that than have someone say, Nice film, man. Thats a stake through your heart. Yeah, and thats mighty ugly to contemplate as well. As Mr. Rather would say, Courage.

title: Spoof-o-rama
description: If youre the kind of worker who likes to spend your employers time and bandwidth surfing in search of the next diverting thing, the O Factor at USA Today has  some links for you. Brokeback, which has been catnip so far to awards voters, seems to be attracting its share of parodies as well.

title: A Paramount Concern
description: The Bagger doesnt do blind items, but he will give somewhat opaque ones a try. With the Anthony Pellicano investigation in full cry  what did the clients of the private investigator know and when did they know it?  there are people at Paramount who wonder if the chips may fall in such a way as to put some dents in their leadership. Over at Fox411, Roger Friedman speculates that when the feds get to the bottom of the intrigue and double-cross, they might find someone who looks a lot like Michael Ovitz. All of the speculation, which has hit DefCom 4, actually threatens to overtake the Oscars as Hollywoods chief preoccupation. And that just doesnt seem right.

title: Splitsville
description: The Bagger stopped by the Bruce Wasserstein/Carl Icahn investor road show at the St. Regis yesterday. Mr. Wasserstein spent 30 minutes explaining why breaking Time Warner into a million little pieces  well, at least four  makes inescapable business sense. Not your great Oscar story, but pickings are slim this time of the season, and the Bagger will do what he can with what hes got. In this instance, if the pressure from Icahn were to force a de-merger, Warner Brothers, one of Hollywoods most reliable producers of tentpoles, would end up as its own darn thing, more or less. If things go that way, Warner might think about commissioning a movie called, It Came from Another Part of the Boardroom, a thinly veiled biopic of Mr. Icahn, who managed to mangle Shakespeare and misidentify his would-be compatriot Mr. Wasserstein as Ken. Mr. Wasserstein expressed significant admiration for News Corporation and Rupert Murdoch, but the gooey feeling is far from mutual. In an interview, Mr. Murdoch pointed out that Viacom Inc., another major media conglomerate, has so far achieved little or nothing for its shareholders in deciding to break up into two entities at the beginning of this year.

title: New York Collections
description: Narciso Rodriguez's sophisticated clothes evoked a primal heat. The collection was not only different, it was right.

title: A Digital Army of One
description: The Bagger is up late, having attended one of those dinner parties on the Upper West Side of Manhattan that he has come to dread. Hollywood has its rituals  the breakfast meeting being one of the more foul and unholy expressions of SoCal culture he finds inhumane  but in Manhattan, people frequently attend dinner parties out of a sense of duty, or fear that they will be left out the next time and actually get to do what they want instead. A frequent motif is dinner guests pretending to listen to each other but actually just rehearsing to come up with a sassy bit to top the person sitting to their left. But the Baggers fears were misplaced. Dinner was lovely, the company was rocking, and he got a chance to talk a great deal about his favorite topic.

title: Winners, Presenters and Performers
description: U2 dominated the Grammys with wins in five categories, while Mariah Carey picked up three awards, including best R&B album.

title: The Moderate Friedan, Defending Evolution and More
Voting Bloc
description: Everyone knows that each member of the Academy, to a person, carefully views each movie and then heads up to his or her own private mountaintop to carefully consider the best. And everyone knows thats a bunch of malarkey. According to Page Six, Samuel L. Jackson told Foxs Bill McCuddy that come Oscar time, everybody from the maid to his assistant weighs in on his ballot. But Jackson eventually punches in at the end: I generally go down the ballot and look and see if any of my friends are nominated and I vote for them.

title: Currents
description: Cards for relationships not suited to Hallmark sentiments, a zen garden for an Iron Chef, souvenirs for Bobby Short fans and more.

title: Graphic Equation
description: Spring is about paring down and loosening up. A black-and-white palette accessorized with a casual attitude.

title: Personal Shopper
description: At the Maison et Objet trade show in Paris last week, new designs revealed a longing for the past, with playful homages to Louis Whoever chairs and African textiles.

title: Is Bush Modeling Lincoln on War Powers?
description: Senator Russ Feingold, a Democrat from Wisconsin, has taken to saying that President Bushs position on domestic surveillance derives from his pre-1776 worldview. But Jeffrey L. Pasley, a history professor at the University of Missouri, writes at Common-Place that the debate over the National Security Agency domestic spying program is decidedly post-1776: The recent conflict over President Bushs domestic surveillance program reflects one of the oldest recurring divisions in American politics, dating all the way to the 1790s and that decades debates between the Jeffersonian Republicans and the Hamiltonian Federalists. Jefferson and his allies believed the governments powers to be limited by the values and rules embedded in our founding documents, while Hamilton and friends believed that the inherent nature of government gave it essentially unlimited powers.

title: Today Is Z Day
Phoenix Is Swamped
description: The desert city is awash in home inventory. Bubble Tracking Blog, which, as you might surmise, tracks the inventory of unsold homes in a number of major cities, notes that Phoenix now has 33,550 homes in inventory.

title: Prices Grow in Brooklyn
description: What do you do when even the mayor of your city points out the obvious  that real estate prices have peaked? You tout a report that says prices in the previous year skyrocketed.

title: OReilly Fires Back
description: Bill OReilly writes on his website: This week Mr. Kristof posted another column entitled Helping Bill OReilly, in which he asks his readers to send money so I can travel to Africa. This is strictly a gimmick and I dont mind, but Kristof is making a big mistake in his analysis. He continues to lay the Darfur situation at Americas doorstep when the United Nations is where his anger should be directed. Of course that great African Kofi Annan could make Darfur a huge issue at the UN, but has chosen not to do so. Thats where Mr. Kristof should be directing his ire, and also at his own newspaper, which continues to ignore the child predator situation in the USA. We invited Mr. Kristof to make his case, but so far hes been too busy.

title: Goodbye, and Thanks

In answer to audience questions, she spoke about aging, about being Jewish (It gave me some brains) and about the changes in womens lives since the 1950s, when she began work on The Feminine Mystique.

description: SCHUKIN--Harvey, 64. On February 5. Retired Local 3 IBEW, volunteer fireman, and avid Rangers fan. Simply the Best. Donations to Project ALS.

description: GAITHERSBURG, Md., Feb. 9 A Stimulants like Ritalin could have dangerous effects on the heart, and federal drug regulators should require manufacturers to provide written guides to patients and place prominent warnings on drug labels describing these risks, a federal drug advisory panel voted today.

I could think of only two things: flowers -- and what flower's name begins with those letters? -- or chocolate. All I could come up with was "Linzer torte."

description: RUNCH--Daniel. Born on June 16, 1911 on the Lower East Side of Manhattan; died in Margate, Fla., on February 7, 2006. Danny says goodbye to his beloved New York. The family may be contacted thru Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, 6701 W. Commercial Blvd, Tamarac, FL.

title: Service law fails to still opposition
Metro Briefing | New York: Mount Vernon: Not-Guilty Plea In Killing
description: A 30-year-old Mount Vernon man accused of murder in what was believed to be a revenge killing in October pleaded not guilty yesterday in Westchester County Court. The man, Shamei Brown, was arraigned on charges of second-degree murder and attempted murder for the shooting death of Raymond Harris, 25, in New Rochelle on Halloween night. A second man, who was shot in the face, survived. The authorities say that Mr. Brown was seeking revenge for the killing of his brother, Dacheau, two weeks earlier, but that he shot at the wrong people. The man who has been charged with killing the brother, Rodney Alston, 18, was arrested in Georgia on Tuesday, said Janet DiFiore, the Westchester County district attorney. Mr. Brown's lawyer, Murray Richman, did not immediately respond to a telephone call seeking comment. ANAHAD O'CONNOR (NYT)

title: Undercover Agent in Fur Snares a Fake Veterinarian
description: The place was New York City. Crime was the dish of the day, and the main course was injury to an animal with a side of petty larceny. The victim was Burt. Burt was a Boston terrier. He was about to find a friend who looked more like a foe.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Guantnamo Detainees' Suit Dismissed
description: A federal judge in Washington has dismissed the main part of a lawsuit brought by four former Guantnamo detainees who were seeking damages from Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and other military officials who the suit said were responsible for their mistreatment and wrongful imprisonment. The four former detainees, all British citizens picked up in Pakistan and Afghanistan, charged in their October lawsuit that they had faced repeated beatings, death threats, interrogation at gunpoint, forced nakedness and menacing with unmuzzled dogs. Judge Ricardo M. Urbina on Monday ruled that the defendants had acted in their official government capacity and thus a longstanding legal doctrine made them immune from such a lawsuit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SZUMLAK, ESTERA
description: SZUMLAK--Estera. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Gail Weisbrod, Akiva (Kenneth), Lana Chudkosky, Sister of Mikhail Yelin. loving grandmother of Yehuda, Sabrina, Lora and Christopher. Great-grandmother of Yair. Services Thursday 11:45AM "The Riverside," 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production malfunction, an article on Tuesday about a protest outside the office of The Philadelphia Inquirer over its publication of caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad omitted a response from Seth Lipsky, publisher of The New York Sun, who was asked why his newspaper had printed two of the caricatures. While Mr. Lipsky hung up on a reporter when first telephoned for comment, he later said by e-mail: "We published the two images last week not to make a political statement but to illustrate a dispatch by The Associated Press. We sought to respect the sensitivities by running the story and pictures in a modest position inside the paper." (Go to Article)

title: Bush Budget Would Cut Military Aid to Bolivia by 96 Percent
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 - Less than a month after an assertively anti-American president took office in Bolivia, the Bush administration is planning to cut military aid to the country by 96 percent.

title: Toyota pickup challenges Detroit
Paid Notice: Memorials   REITMAN, EDWARD
description: REITMAN--Edward. On this your anniversary we continue to treasure your loving example as will your greatgrandson. Your loving family

title: Highway Memorials
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Aerialist's Trajectory: 5 Twists and 3 Flips
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 8 - The first time Jeret Peterson tried the jump he has since named the Hurricane, he landed face-first in the snow.

title: For the Olympics, Commercials for Screens of All Sizes
description: BRACE yourself, Olympic fans, for $1 billion in advertising that will begin inundating you in 24 hours on screens in four sizes: small, on cellphones; medium, on computers and airplanes; large, on television sets; and extra large, in movie theaters.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SAVAGE, MARILYN
description: SAVAGE--Marilyn. 10/29/45-2/ 9/94. Still wish I could talk to you everyday. Miss you so much. Love, Vicki

title: Techbrief: BT profit falls, but growth in revenue accelerates
3 More Convicted in Deaths of Immigrants in a Trailer
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 8 - Overcoming an initial deadlock, a federal jury here on Wednesday convicted three South Texans in a botched human-trafficking scheme that killed 19 illegal immigrants sealed in a trailer bound north from the Mexican border in 2003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LENGEMANN, GEORGE L.
description: LENGEMANN--George L. On February 5, 2006 at the age of 78. Beloved husband of Ruth C. Haupert-Lengemann. Loving brother of Dorothy Lengemann Walker and caring uncle of Wendy L. Walker, both of Virginia, and Dr. William H. Walker of Pittsburgh. George waged a valiant battle against cancer for over two years with his characteristic dignity, wry sense of humor and indomitable work ethic. A dedicated life-long New York Giants football fan, he would consider it ironic that Super Bowl Sunday was his last day on earth. George had a distinguished career in investment management and security analysis spanning more than 50 years. For the past 34 years, he had been Vice President of S.W. Childs Management Corporation. He was also Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Lengemann Capital Management Assoc., Inc. Earlier, he had been affiliated with Peoples Trust Company of New Jersey, Guaranty Trust Company, a predecessor of Morgan-Guaranty and F.H. Vahesing. A 1951 graduate of Hofstra University, he earned an M.B.A. from N.Y.U.'s Stern Graduate School of Business in 1959. His service in the United States Army as a military photographer in Europe fortified a life-long love of photography. A past Vice President and Treasurer of the N.Y.U. Club of New York, he also served as Treasurer of the Touchdown Club of America and was a Member of the Princeton Club in New York and the Sun and Surf Beach Club in Atlantic Beach, NY. Family will receive friends on Wednesday, 7-9pm and Thursday 2-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave (81 St). Funeral services Friday, 9:30am at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, the family would be grateful for donations to St. John's Lutheran Church, PO Box 72, Brooklyn NY 11222; St. Luke's Lutheran Church, 308 W. 46 St, NY NY 10036; New York University Stern School of Business, 44 W. 4 St, NY NY 10012.

title: Differences Emerge Over Efforts to Restrict Lobbying
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 - The election-year push to impose new limits on lobbying and the pet projects known as earmarks is running into roadblocks on Capitol Hill, as lawmakers clash on such pivotal issues as whether to ban gifts and corporate travel, and whether ethics investigations should be conducted by outside watchdogs or members of Congress.

title: For Relationships Not Suited to Hallmark Sentiments
description: Valentine sentiments don't have to be cloying, judging from a new gift book, "Valentines: Vintage Holiday Graphics" (Taschen, $9.99), edited by Jim Heimann. Indeed, through the years some of the most notable cards (a sampling is above) have had an edge -- even, to modern eyes, a slightly twisted quality. Mr. Heimann, a writer, editor and collector in Los Angeles, scoured the Rose Bowl Flea Market and Swap Meet in Pasadena, Calif., for the cards. Blatantly cute ones, or what he calls "bottom feeders," sell for about $1, he said, while "the satiric ones with monkeys and little old maids -- the ones you don't want to get if you're a diehard romantic -- will hover around $30."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DATTELBAUM, MERVIN
description: DATTELBAUM--Mervin, 86 year old avid tennis player, loving husband of Harriet, devoted father of Marlene (Gross), Carole (DeRoberts) and Jeff Dattelbaum, adored grandfather of Randi, Peter, Royce and Kyle, great-grandfather of Ethan and Dylan, brother of Paul and late Arthur. He'll be deeply missed.

title: Earmarked Men
description: Washington - BACK on the F-Bar Ranch, when I was too young to load the chute, de-horn, vaccinate, hold a hot iron or otherwise make myself useful as my father and older brothers branded calves, I would spend my time collecting "earmarks" -- V-shaped pieces of a calf's left ear detached with two swift strokes of a pocketknife. I would stack these earmarks on the fence surrounding the corral as an unofficial tally of our progress.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on the Spotlight page on Sunday about Dick Bavetta, a longtime referee in the National Basketball Association, misstated the number he was approaching to set the record for regular-season games worked. It is 2,135, not 2,035.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Orthodox Jew Sentenced In Stabbings
description: An ultra-Orthodox Jew who stabbed and wounded three people at a gay pride parade in Jerusalem last June was sentenced to 12 years in prison and to pay his victims a total of $30,000 restitution. The man, Yishai Schlussel, 30, was convicted of attempted murder after judges rejected his claim of temporary insanity. The judges said that "the accused showed excessive fanaticism." Some religious authorities in Israel had condemned the march and tried to get the police to deny a permit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RABHAN, DR. NATHAN
description: RABHAN--Dr. Nathan. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed member and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Yaakov Y. Kermaier, Rabbi Ira Leon Rennert, Chairman J. Ezra Merkin, President

title: A Zen Garden For an Iron Chef
description: The celebrated Japanese architect Tadao Ando has completed his first project in New York: Morimoto restaurant at 88 10th Avenue (16th Street). Named after its chef, Masaharu Morimoto (a k a the Iron Chef), the $12 million restaurant features, above, ceilings draped in undulating fiberglass-reinforced canvas, evoking the raked gravel of Zen rock gardens; furniture by Ross Lovegrove; a traditional noren curtain and Mr. Ando's signature use of concrete. The lighting, including a wall of L.E.D.-illuminated water bottles, inset, is by Arnold Chan. "Mr. Ando wanted something serene," said Stephanie Goto of Goto Design Group in New York, which collaborated on the project, "a Japanese sensibility without being overtly Japanese."

title: Unify Flood Protection
description: Natural disasters leave destruction in their wake, but they can also remove entrenched barriers to change. Hurricane Katrina's devastation of New Orleans has provided a rare opportunity to dissolve the levee boards, which fragment and decentralize storm protection for southern Louisiana, and replace them with one unified board.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: West Virginia: State Mine Safety Director To Resign
description: The state director of mine safety will resign within the next several weeks, state officials said. The announcement comes less than a week after two mining accidents left two coal miners dead, bringing the year's total mining fatalities in West Virginia to 16. Lara Ramsburg, a spokeswoman for Gov. Joe Manchin III, said the director, Doug Conaway, had discussed his intention to resign with the governor in December. His departure was postponed, Ms. Ramsburg said, so the governor could focus on the Jan. 2 mining disaster in Sago which killed 12 miners. Governor Manchin praised Mr. Conaway for his handling of the accidents.

title: Illegal and Inept
description: While testifying about the Bush administration's warrantless eavesdropping program, Attorney General Alberto Gonzales was asked to explain how the program had been damaged by the disclosure of its existence in the press.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Accountant Admits Fraud
description: A man who worked as an accountant and financial adviser pleaded guilty yesterday to stealing more than $750,000 from eight clients, the Westchester County district attorney, Janet DiFiore, left, announced yesterday. The accountant, Alan Russo, pleaded guilty to second-degree grand larceny and scheme to defraud, Ms. DiFiore said in a statement. Mr. Russo, who worked in Mamaroneck and Harrison, promised to invest his clients' money but put it into his own bank account, Ms. DiFiore said. Mr. Russo, who is already serving a five-year prison sentence, is scheduled to be sentenced next month. He faces 1 1/2 to 4 1/2 years in prison, prosecutors said.

title: Letting you drawyour own conclusions
British Man Charged With Killing Wife and Baby in U.S.
description: A British man was arrested today in London on murder charges stemming from the shooting deaths of his wife and infant daughter in their rental home in Massachusetts last month, according to the Middlesex County, Mass., district attorney.

title: Racing Promoters Look for Life After Armstrong
description: Seven months after the retirement of Lance Armstrong, two California entrepreneurs are making multimillion-dollar bets on the continued popularity of professional bicycle racing in the United States, seeking to prove that the sport can continue to grow without the presence of the most famous American cyclist ever.

title: Arts, Briefly; Manilow Back at No. 1
description: Barry Manilow has scored his first No. 1 album in 29 years with "The Greatest Songs of the 50's" (Arista) -- featuring tunes like "Unchained Melody" and "Love Is a Many-Splendored Thing" -- which sold 156,000 copies in its first week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. His last album to reach the peak position on the Billboard chart was "Live" in 1977. It was a big week for sentimental vocal albums, as Andrea Bocelli opened at No. 3 with "Amore" (Decca) and the Broadway star Heather Headley's new "In My Mind" (RCA, 95,000) reached No. 5. The rock band Train, never accused of a lack of sentimentality, is at No. 10 with its new album "For Me, It's You" (Sony BMG). Other top spots on this week's chart are filled by holdovers: Mary J. Blige (No. 2) and Jamie Foxx (No. 4). BEN SISARIO

title: Can Saddam's trial be salvaged?
I Got My Fingers Dirty in Pursuit of Beauty
description: BACKSTAGE at the Tracy Reese show on Sunday morning, Anastasia Pavlenko, a model from Kiev, Ukraine, perched on a makeup chair and eyed me suspiciously.

title: Living at Cool, Not Just Visiting
description: BOND. Forty Bond. That's the address of the latest downtown luxury condominium being whipped into shape by Ian Schrager in league with the high-brow Swiss architectural team of Herzog & de Meuron. The name brings to mind the spy who never came in from the Cool.

title: Doritos and DirecTV Out, But Dell Is In at BBDO
description: It was a hectic day yesterday for BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, as the agency lost two assignments but gained one that was larger.

title: Censoring Truth
description: The Bush administration long ago secured a special place in history for the audacity with which it manipulates science to suit its political ends. But it set a new standard of cynicism when it allowed NASA's leading authority on global warming to be mugged by a 24-year-old presidential appointee who, quite apart from having no training on that issue, had inflated his rsum.

title: Director of Getty Trust Quits
description: The director of the J. Paul Getty Trust in Los Angeles, one of the world's richest art institutions, resigned under pressure today. The trust said the director, Barry Munitz, whose lavish expense spending is under investigation by the California attorney general's office, would be required to repay the trust $250,000 for undisclosed reasons and would not be given a severance package.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Blast Kills 13 Soldiers In Chechnya
description: An explosion at a Russian military barracks in Chechnya late Tuesday killed at least 13 soldiers and wounded 20 others, officials cited by news agencies reported. The blast destroyed a two-story building housing soldiers from the Vostok Battalion, a unit formed by former Chechen rebels and now under the command of the Ministry of Defense. Officials said the blast might have been caused by canisters of gas stored in the building's kitchen, but did not rule out the possibility of an attack. The Vostok Battalion has been accused of committing abuses against Chechen citizens, including a raid in a border village last summer in which an elderly man was killed and 11 others disappeared.

title: Briefly: Stark set to get post on ECB executive board
Paid Notice: Deaths   MALOOF, HARDING
description: MALOOF--Harding. Award winning photographer, collector and fisherman, died in his home February 7, 2006. He is survived by his sisters Lourice, Alice, Renee and Camille. Funeral services will be held Friday, 10AM at Ortiz Funeral Home and St. Elizabeth Church.

title: Jurassic Pork
description: Washington - THE military budget for the 2007 fiscal year clocks in at $439.3 billion. And that doesn't include the $120 billion that reflects the real cost of the war. We have a behemoth defense budget that inadequately addresses the top national security threats.

title: Shot in Case of Mistaken Identity, Officer Dies After 11-Day Ordeal
description: It is a hard-to-fathom chain of events: a rookie police officer, assaulted at a White Castle restaurant in the Bronx, is shot three times by a fellow officer responding to a 911 call. Given little chance of surviving, the young officer defies the odds and keeps living.

title: Rasmussen calls Danes embittered on support
Danish Leader Assails Firms for Lack of Support
description: COPENHAGEN, Feb. 9 A Prime Minister Anders Fogh Rasmussen said today that attempts by European companies in the Middle East to disassociate themselves from Denmark or Danish products was considered by Danes to be "disgraceful."

title: Oprah Signs Deal With XM Satellite Radio
description: The television talk show host Oprah Winfrey has signed a three-year, $55 million agreement with XM Satellite Radio Holdings to establish a new radio channel in September, the company announced today.

title: For Your Valentine
description: For Your Valentine

title: AIG to pay $1.6 billion in settlement of fraud charges
Provocative Images And Bitter Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Other Views: The Independent, Gulf Times, Christian ScienceMonitor
Hamas Leader Tells Abbas Not to Act on His Own
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 8 - A senior Hamas leader warned the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, on Wednesday not to revamp the Palestinian Authority or make cabinet appointments without Hamas's approval. The Hamas leader, Khaled Meshal, spoke at a news conference in Cairo, where he and other exiled Hamas officials have been conferring with Hamas leaders from Gaza and the West Bank. After sweeping the Palestinian parliamentary elections two weeks ago, Hamas is preparing to put together the new government, though Mr. Abbas, known as Abu Mazen, will remain president of the Palestinian Authority.

title: Arts, Briefly; Actors and Writers Guilds Protest Product Placement
description: Elliot Gould and Connie Stevens, above right, were among members of the Screen Actors Guild and the Writers Guild of America, West, who picketed the Beverly Hills Hotel in Los Angeles yesterday morning to protest a conference on product integration being held there by the trade magazine Advertising Age. The unions said they were denied a chance to be included in the conference, about the growing practice of weaving products into television, film, video games and cellphones in an age of changing consumer entertainment choices. The unions have been asking the industry to adopt a "code of conduct" about product integration, which they say deceives television viewers and takes advantage of actors and writers without compensating them. "As people speed though commercials with their DVR's, new advertising models are being developed, and this affects the performers' bottom line," said Patric M. Verrone, president of the writers guild. "We think the creative community should have a voice." Scott Donaton, editor of Advertising Age, said the guilds made their request only days ago and had disrupted a conference in September when they bought a ticket. "They want to focus on an issue that is not the focus of this conference," he said. SHARON WAXMAN

title: Despite Web Crackdown, Prevailing Winds Are Free
description: SHANGHAI, Feb. 7 - For months now, the news about the news in China has been awful. Carrying out its vow to tighten controls over what it calls "propaganda," the government of President Hu Jintao has busied itself closing publications, firing editorial staffs and jailing reporters.

title: Applications to Law Schools Are Declining
description: Has law school lost its appeal?

title: When the Lower Ninth Posed Proudly
description: NEW ORLEANS - On a hazy summer afternoon several years before Hurricane Katrina, Chandra McCormick spied a juke joint with an open door in the Lower Ninth Ward. She nudged her husband, Keith Calhoun, and they stopped their car.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Fuel Cell To Power New Subway Shop
description: The New York Power Authority and New York City Transit said yesterday that they would equip a subway maintenance shop under construction in Corona with a 200-kilowatt fuel cell, capable of powering maintenance and cleaning equipment and saving the equivalent of 2,800 barrels of oil a year that would otherwise be used to generate electricity. The new shop, serving the No. 7 subway line, is next to the Casey Stengel Bus Depot. Brian Warner, a spokesman for the Power Authority, said the authority would install the fuel cell by summer at a cost of $2 million, and would be reimbursed by New York City Transit. THOMAS J. LUECK (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POLLOCK, BERNICE
description: POLLOCK -- Bernice. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Bernice Pollock, beloved mother of our devoted members, Cary and Elyse Pollock, grandmother of Will and Michelle. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Lottery Numbers
Matchmaker Pairs Computer and Stereo
description: THOSE crazy kids today! Their home music systems often wind up split in two. In this corner: the computer, stuffed with music files copied from CD's or downloaded from the Internet. In that corner: the stereo system or home theater.

title: Rich Guys Over Here
description: This just in for the snaking lines of air passengers waiting in their socks to pass through airport security: homeland security officials have proudly approved the diversion of 16 screeners from Kennedy International Airport to a private heliport entrepreneur so Wall Street executives can purchase speedy velvet-rope clearance and chopper right to their planes for $150 or so.

title: Toyota Vies for One of Detroit's Last Strongholds
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 9 A Toyota has been selling pickup trucks in the United States since 1964. But none have been more important than the one it unveiled here today A either to Toyota or to Detroit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FAUSER, JOSEPH E.
description: FAUSER--Joseph E. Beloved husband of Helen. Devoted father of Robert and Arlene Fauser, Jill and Richard Israel, dear brother of Doris Brisbane, loving grandfather of Chad and Scott, and greatgrandfather of Darian and Devon. Services Friday, 11:15AM, "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Suicide attack hits Shiite procession in Pakistan
Work vs. Family, Complicated by Race
description: Correction Appended

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: 3 Russian Officers Detained
description: Tensions heightened in the separatist enclave of South Ossetia in the Caucasus Mountains after Georgia detained three Russian military officers for entering its territory without visas. Russia in turn accused Georgia of exceeding its troop allotment in the region under a 1992 peacekeeping agreement. About 250 Georgian soldiers arrived in trucks at the village of Eredvi, Vyacheslav N. Sedov, the chief spokesman for the Russian military, said. A Georgian official, meanwhile, denied any Georgian troops were in the village, Russian news media reported. Georgian troops and pro-Russian separatists occasionally skirmish in the region, which has had de facto independence since the breakup of the Soviet Union.

title: A Makeover of a Romance
description: Correction Appended

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Thursday with the Physical Culture column, about athletic clothing, misstated the name and price of the white long-sleeve shirt from Isis. It was the Essential T-shirt, which sells for $45, not the Activitee, which costs $32.

title: Arrest of Chicago Priest Raises Questions About Reform
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 8 - Last August, a young boy told the police that a Roman Catholic priest had groped him after Mass at St. Agatha Catholic Church, a West Side parish.

title: Univision Confirms It May Be for Sale
description: Univision Communications, the Spanish-language media company, confirmed yesterday that it would put itself up for sale, igniting speculation about which media giant would jump into the auction and how high a price the company would fetch.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production malfunction, an article on Tuesday about a protest outside the office of The Philadelphia Inquirer over its publication of caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad omitted a response from Seth Lipsky, publisher of The New York Sun, who was asked why his newspaper had printed two of the caricatures. While Mr. Lipsky hung up on a reporter when first telephoned for comment, he later said by e-mail: "We published the two images last week not to make a political statement but to illustrate a dispatch by The Associated Press. We sought to respect the sensitivities by running the story and pictures in a modest position inside the paper."

title: Rosier Technology Outlook Fuels Broad Market Gains
description: Stocks gained yesterday after a sales forecast from Cisco Systems suggested that the profit outlook for technology companies might be improving.

title: People: Warren Buffett, Ralph Fiennes, Bob Marley
Rell Calls for End to Car Tax, but Also for Repeal of a Tax Credit
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 8 - Flush with a $500 million surplus and facing a November election, Gov. M. Jodi Rell on Wednesday proposed almost $300 million in tax cuts on automobiles, utility bills, estates and corporations. She also promised to create jobs by reorganizing economic development efforts and creating a commuter rail service that would run north-south through the center of the state.

title: Readers react to the cartoon controversy
Next Step by Weekly in Paris May Be to Mock the Holocaust
description: PARIS, Feb. 8 - President Jacques Chirac on Wednesday condemned a French weekly's decision to print the Danish cartoons that have inflamed passions across the Muslim world. The paper said it would also publish Iranian-sponsored lampoons of the Holocaust.

title: Bank of Korea lifts rate as inflation jitters mount
Japan's history lesson
A Troupe Is a Potent Force in Belarus's Underground
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 8 - The Free Theater of Belarus, not yet a year old, has no home, no permanent troupe and, for now, only three short plays in its repertory. It staged them for a while in a cramped bar called Graffiti in an industrial neighborhood of Minsk, the Belarussian capital, but the authorities warned the bar's owner to stop.

title: BlackBerry is prepared for worst
In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
Bruckner's Seventh and Painterly Tableaus in Song
description: Having just spent the better part of a week at Carnegie Hall with his own orchestra, the Berlin Philharmonic, Simon Rattle was back at Carnegie on Tuesday evening with the Philadelphia Orchestra, with which he has had a long, fruitful relationship. And having spent much of his stage time with his Berlin players celebrating the 250th anniversary of Mozart's birth, he moved decidedly forward with the Philadelphians, into the late 19th and mid-20th centuries.

title: Cashman Visits Restaurant, and Clemens Is on Menu
description: Brian Cashman maneuvered through the cramped, chaotic El Nuevo Caridad in Washington Heights like a local baseball coach selling raffle tickets. He let patrons try on his World Series ring, he spoke to one youngster about becoming a batboy and he helped distribute free gloves and baseballs.

title: He Says Lingerie, I Say Underwear
description: SOME years ago, four men who worked in an office together went to Victoria's Secret at lunch to buy their wives lingerie for Valentine's Day. Three returned with shopping bags that contained lots of elastic, snaps and lace fashioned into uncomfortable garments that a normal person would not fit into without aid of a winch.

title: Provocative Images And Bitter Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Full House Committee Gets Briefing on Eavesdropping
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 - Under pressure from some Congressional Republicans as well as Democrats, the White House abruptly changed its position on Wednesday and provided a closed-door briefing on the National Security Agency's domestic surveillance program to the full House Intelligence Committee.

title: Physical Culture: GEAR TEST WITH | Nate Carey, Ski Instructor; Goggles With an Eye on Technology
description: Correction Appended

title: Low-Fat Diets Flub a Test
description: The more we learn about nutrition, the less we seem to know. That is the clearest lesson to emerge from a large study of low-fat diets that has left diet aficionados thoroughly confused.

title: Egypt's Valley of Kings yields a major new burial site
AIG to pay $1.6 billion in settlement of fraud charges
A brain drain threatens Afghanistan's future
The Man Who Keeps Babar's Young Subjects Loyal
description: BABAR the elephant is 75 years old and, from the looks of him, immortal. Not a single wrinkle in that hardy gray skin. Maybe it's the yoga. "Babar's Yoga for Elephants" hit the children's book list in 2002.

title: In a Battle of Young Players, a Lot Rides on the Club King
description: There are few young players coming into bridge in the United States. The reasons are debated regularly, with no firm conclusions being drawn. Everyone has an opinion. But there is no doubt that the United States is producing some top juniors, as highlighted by the victory last August at the World Youth Team Championship in Sydney, Australia. One member of that team was Justin Lall of Dallas.

title: First Elections in Nepal in 7 Years Turn Violent
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 8 - Violence erupted in Nepal on Wednesday as the country held its first elections in seven years. The military shot and killed a political dissident who was protesting the elections, while suspected Maoist guerrillas lobbed bombs at government buildings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JABLONSKY, BEBE (BONNIE) G.
description: JABLONSKY--Bebe (Bonnie) G. On February 6, 2006, our beloved "Bubbie" and Mother. Memorial service Friday, February 10, 11:30AM, I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn. Shiva call Friday 47PM and also Saturday, February 11, 2-7PM, 876 East 21 St., Brooklyn. Flowers accepted. Accepting donations for Brooklyn Parents for Peace sent to: B.G. Jablonsky Peace Fund, c/o R. Munksgaard, 82 Court St., Bangor ME 04401.

title: Rodriguez Dirties Up Sex; Kors Rhymes Moon With June
description: Anytime a designer is excessively happy a week before his show and he has only a few clothes finished, that's usually a problem. It either means (a) he has a bad collection and he knows it and is trying to cover up, or (b) he's out of his mind. Narciso Rodriguez was happy, and it was no problem.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 8 about the Cambodian government's contracts with nonprofit groups to manage public health districts referred incorrectly to remarks by a former official who said corruption consumed much of the money budgeted for health care. The former official, Sao Chhorn, has notified the writer that he was referring to developments before nonprofit groups took over, not after.

title: Drug Samples to Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: What Should the Democrats Do?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAYLOR, HUNT
description: TAYLOR--Hunt. The Stern Family and staff of Hartz Trading are deeply saddened at the loss of Hunt Taylor, who we were lucky to work with for a period of six years. His insight, openness, honesty & creativity set an example for all of us. We send our love & deepest condolensces to Martha, Julia, Davis, and the entire Taylor family.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10 P.M. (CBS) WITHOUT A TRACE -- Leah Robinson (Meeghan Holaway) is justa sweet,church going suburban stay at-home mom, her husband and her minister say. So what was she doing at a Manhattan gallery opening with another man? Investigating her disappearance, Jack and Anne (Anthony LaPaglia and Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio, above) learn about a disgruntled client and Leah's husband's socalled hunting trip, which involved a waitress.

title: Protecting Your MP3 Player, and What to Do When You Don't
description: Compressed audio formats like MP3 files, and the devices that play them, allow people to take huge music collections virtually anywhere. But the very portability of an MP3 player can be its undoing -- too often, the pocket-size gadgets are dropped, scratched, drowned, or exposed to extreme temperatures.

title: Spoils of War Add Up to 56% Profit Gain for Lazard
description: As Bruce Wasserstein left the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan on Tuesday afternoon after presenting Lazard's plan to break up Time Warner, he wore a mischievous smile on his face. He had good reason: He knew Lazard, his investment bank, would report fourth-quarter earnings that would again beat Wall Street's estimates by a wide margin.

title: British Man Charged With Killing Wife and Baby
description: A British man was arrested today in London on murder charges stemming from the shooting deaths of his wife and infant daughter in their rental home in Massachusetts last month, according to the Middlesex County, Mass., district attorney.

title: Why I Watch the Oscars
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POSEN, CAROL
description: POSEN--Carol. Carol, my sweet friend, I will miss you forever and remember you always. You were the best of the best, there could be no better: daughter, wife, mother, grandmother and friend to so many. You will always hold a very special place in my heart as you were a friend that comes once in a lifetime. From my family to your wonderful family, Jack, Jenny, the Abelsons and Posens, we send our love and sincerest sympathy. Lynn, Steve, Alyse and Jay Solomon

title: 7 Afghans Released from Guantnamo  Say They Saw Abuse
description: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan, Feb. 9 A Seven Afghans have been released from American detention in GuantAnamo Bay, Cuba, and were freed in Kabul today, where they spoke to reporters, contending that they had witnessed abuse and desecration of the Koran.

title: Corrections

All of those activities are still offered; they have not been stopped for fear of religious-based terrorism.

title: Analyst Is Fined in Conflict-of-Interest Case
description: A prominent Wall Street analyst has been fined $220,000, and his firm, $350,000, accused of violating NASD rules that were put into place after a scandal that highlighted analysts' publicly promoting stocks they privately derided.

description: I.B.M. is betting on video game technology to bring supercomputer-caliber visualization tools to its mainstream corporate market and to reduce the computing costs of daunting tasks like hunting for oil, discovering new drugs and exploring the human body.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a decision by General Motors to cut its dividend and the pay of some executives misstated the makeup of compensation for directors. They will forgo cash compensation and receive $100,000 in restricted stock -- not $30,000 in cash and $70,000 in stock.

title: Sheik Among 10 Iraqis Killed in Raids by Militants
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 8 - At least 10 Iraqis were killed in attacks by militants on Wednesday, including a prominent Sunni Arab sheik from the northern city of Kirkuk.

title: Extraordinary Medical Effort Can't Stop the Deadly Work of 3 Bullets
description: By any measure, it was an extraordinary effort to save the life of Officer Eric Hernandez.

title: Schools Chancellor Reaches Out to Principals Under Siege
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein moved yesterday to stem rising anger among public school principals over protracted contract negotiations even as the principals had to carry out this week's complicated schedule changes and adopt a new tutoring program required by a new teachers' contract.

title: With Little Effort, the Lazy Ponytail Can Be a Symbol of Glam
description: THE ponytail, the default hairstyle of lazy people, is making a play for the red carpet. No longer emblematic of a paparazzi shame payday (imagine Melanie Griffith circa 1986, when jeans and a ponytail meant a presumed trip to the gastroenterologist), ponytails, like jeans, can now be paired with diamonds. They can be paired with bronze satin.

title: Restoring an Icon of Optimism
description: BRUSSELS - LIKE the Eiffel Tower, the Atomium -- an oversize replica of an iron molecule with nine aluminum-clad spheres -- was once a World's Fair centerpiece. After it went up in 1958, as an emblem of Belgium's postwar industrial boom and its optimism about nuclear energy, visitors could travel the tubes linking the spheres to see an exhibition called Atom Equals Hope and to grab a bite in a snack bar at the topmost point.

title: Dozens killed in holy day violence
On The Street: Then
description: CERTAIN fashion staples survive season after season, brave fixtures in a woman's arsenal of style. One evergreen, the military jacket, stepped out smartly in the winter of 1991, flaunting gold braid, epaulets, costume jewelry medals and rows of brass buttons, details that rendered them chic enough for a day on the town. Alert to its versatility, designers like Marc Jacobs and Anna Sui resurrected the surplus look this week on the Bryant Park runways, signaling that military jackets will return in force for fall.

title: A New Look for Louis and Friends
description: Paris - AT the Maison et Objet trade show here last week, new designs revealed a longing for the past, or what Vincent Grgoire, a director at Nelly Rodi, a trend-forecasting agency, called newstalgia, the current tendency to use old forms as inspiration for new creations. Look for playful homage to Louis Whoever chairs, and textiles from Africa in new patterns.

title: Deaths Cited in Reports on Stimulant Drugs, but Their Cause Is Uncertain
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 - Twenty-five people died suddenly and 54 others suffered serious unexplained heart problems while taking stimulant drugs like Ritalin from 1999 through 2003, according to reports sent to federal drug regulators.

title: Money Shift Possibly Known Outside Enron, Witness Says
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 8 - The former head of investor relations at Enron testified Wednesday at the fraud trial of two former executives that hundreds of millions in losses that were shifted from one company unit to another, supposedly to mislead investors, might not have been entirely secret outside the company.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,254 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Tough U.S. Steps in Hunger Strike at Camp in Cuba
description: United States military authorities have taken tougher measures to force-feed detainees engaged in hunger strikes at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, after concluding that some were determined to commit suicide to protest their indefinite confinement, military officials have said.

title: At Mecca Meeting, Cartoon Outrage Crystalized
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 8 - As leaders of the world's 57 Muslim nations gathered for a summit meeting in Mecca in December, issues like religious extremism dominated the official agenda. But much of the talk in the hallways was of a wholly different issue: Danish cartoons satirizing the Prophet Muhammad.

title: Arts, Briefly; Getty Goddess Conflict
description: The illustration of a larger-than-life limestone-and-marble statue on the Web site of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles is captioned, "Who is this colossal goddess?" The question asked in a Rome courtroom yesterday was, "Where does she come from?" The fifth-century-B.C. statue, believed to be of Aphrodite, the Greek goddess of love, may be the most important ancient artifact at the core of the trial of Marion True, the Getty's former curator of antiquities, who is accused of acquiring objects illegally excavated from Italian soil. The Getty bought the statue in 1988 for a reported $18 million from the London-based dealer Robin Symes. Salvatore Morando, an investigator testifying at yesterday's hearing, asserted that it came from an illegal excavation at Morgantina in central Sicily. Mr. Morando said tests on the statue and on fragments found at Morgantina indicated that "they came from the same archaeological site." Italian officials have asked for more tests, but Maurizio Fiorilli, a lawyer for the state, charged in court that the Getty Museum was uncooperative. Lawyers for Mrs. True countered that many experts, including Malcolm Bell, a director of the excavations at the Sicilian site, say that no proof of the statue's origins is known. Italian officials have contended since 1988 that it was illegally taken from Sicily. ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PETTOLINA, ANTHONY MI CHAEL
description: PETTOLINA -- Anthony Mi chael. On February 6, 2006 in his 34th year. Beloved son of Megan and Paul Tourlis, and the late Anthony. Cherished grandson of Mr. and Mrs. Walter G. Hooke. Dear brother of Timothy C. Also survived by many loving aunts, uncles and cousins. Reposing Thursday 2-5 and 7-9PM at Lloyd Funeral Home, 39th Ave. at 215th St., Bayside. Mass of Christian burial on Friday, 10AM at Our Lady of Fatima R.C. Church, Jackson Heights. Interment St. John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to Fountain House, 425 W. 47th St., NY, NY 10036.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Vonage, an Internet Phone Provider, Files for an Initial Public Offering Vonage Holdings, a provider of Internet-based telephone service, filed for an initial public offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell up to $250 million in stock. The move to go public is the first for an Internet phone provider and a sign of a new level of prominence for a technology that has become a serious threat to traditional phone companies. [Page C1.]

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOENIGMANN, JOHN S.
description: HOENIGMANN--John S. Tragically on February 6, 2006. Beloved husband of Cynthia (nee Maggio). Loving father of Stephen. Corporate specialist for over thirty years. Served on the board of Highland Elementary School, Fresh Meadows. Avid chess and handball player. Family will receive friends Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at "Leo F. Kearns", 61-40 Woodhaven Blvd., Rego Park, NY. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:45 AM at Resurrection Ascension Church, Middle Village, NY. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. Donations may be made to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, 1-800-822-6344.

title: France to favor skilled immigration
Putting Some Kick in the Jumper
description: Few trends so artfully fuse images of the naif and the vamp as the jumper. Last season they resurfaced on the runway at Miu Miu, where Miuccia Prada riffed charmingly on a popular street style by mating bonbon-colored jumpers with immaculate white tees. Marc Jacobs, in contrast, showed a starchy schoolgirl version that Sister Mary Ignatius would surely have approved. Now tarted-up interpretations of the oh-so-proper 1950's look are being resurrected for fall.

title: Nigeria Has Africa's First Case of Bird Flu
description: The bird flu virus has been confirmed for the first time in Africa, a continent that is ill prepared to contain its spread, international health authorities said yesterday.

title: Chatting Is the Least of It With This Multitask Phone
description: If you have a short attention span, LG Mobile has the phone for you. The CU320 handset, to be available in early March, has a multitask button so that voice and data features can be used at the same time. Users can chat while text-messaging, looking up sports scores or browsing the Web.

description: BOSTON - ALONE in his row house on Beacon Hill, with four precipitous flights of stairs and icy cobblestones outside the front door, John Sears, 75, still managed to look after himself after he was hit by a taxicab and left with a broken knee.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Totowa: A Call From Murder Victim's Family
description: The family of Geetha Angara, 43, a senior chemist who was murdered a year ago at the local water treatment plant, has called on Gov. Jon S. Corzine, Attorney General Zulima V. Farber and United States Attorney Christopher J. Christie to jump-start the stalled investigation into her death. About 150 people gathered outside the plant yesterday to mark the anniversary of her killing. The family's lawyer said that he was inviting the governor and other officials to a meeting about how the state could help the investigation, and that he had contacted the Federal Bureau of Investigation for help. Local and county police said that they had exhausted their leads but had narrowed their investigation to three workers at the plant. TINA KELLEY (NYT)

description: On a flight this week, I heard both the pilot and the flight attendant repeatedly use a peculiar English syntax that seems to be unique to the airline industry: the superfluous insertion of the word "do."

title: Music System Taps Wires in Your Walls to Pipe the Sound
description: A big problem with having a central system that pipes music to different rooms is having to run yards of speaker wire through the house. The DAvED (Digital Audio via Electrical Distribution) music system from Marantz solves that problem by using electrical wires that are already in place.

title: 40 Years of Black Male History in 2 Hours
description: How to tell the history of the black man in America on the stage? It took August Wilson 10 plays for one century of the African-American experience; what can be said in two and a half hours? Much, it turns out, if you think of history as an impressionistic collection of events and images and use eight male performers to speak and sing during short scenes that sometimes involve characters who know one another.

title: Souvenirs for Bobby Short Fans
description: Bobby Short, the beloved Cafe Carlyle cabaret singer, died a year ago, and nowhis fans have a chance to own a bit of his past. Christie's will auction his possessions on Feb. 16. Mr. Short, who could channel Cole Porter, had an Art Deco cocktail shaker and a monogrammed Cartier ice bucket, right, valued at $2,000 to $3,000. He collected walking sticks, African stools, Louis Vuitton suitcases and a sobering array of race-based Americana like Uncle Tom figurines. But you may be more interested in his Bechstein grand, estimated at $30,000 to $40,000; (212) 636-2399 or www.christies.com.

Consider that New York has just gotten past John Eliot Gardiner and his Orchestre Rvolutionnaire et Romantique playing Mozart's last three symphonies at Alice Tully Hall and looks ahead to Daniel Barenboim and the Berlin Staatskapelle playing Mozart's last three symphonies over two concerts at Carnegie Hall on Saturday and Sunday.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Jan. 26 about China's reduction of its estimate of the number of its H.I.V. and AIDS cases referred incompletely to the ways that mothers transmit the virus to their infants. While the study listed "infants in the womb by H.I.V.-positive mothers" as one of six categories of infected people, studies show that a majority of cases in which infants are infected by their mothers occur either during labor and delivery or later during breast feeding.

title: Rodriguez Dirties Up Sex; Kors Rhymes Moon With June
description: Anytime a designer is excessively happy a week before his show and he has only a few clothes finished, that's usually a problem. It either means (a) he has a bad collection and he knows it and is trying to cover up, or (b) he's out of his mind. Narciso Rodriguez was happy, and it was no problem.

title: Unyielding stances on biotech
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Rector For St. Patrick's
description: The Rev. Robert T. Ritchie, a pastor from the Bronx, was appointed rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. The appointment by Cardinal Edward M. Egan is to take effect next week, filling a post that has been empty since August, when the former rector, Msgr. Eugene V. Clark, 79, resigned amid accusations that he was having an affair with his longtime personal secretary. Monsignor Clark was not suspended, but voluntarily agreed not to say Mass or celebrate the sacraments in public. Father Ritchie, 60, has been the pastor of Our Lady of Angels Church, in a heavily Hispanic parish, since 2002. He also was the regional vicar of the Northwest Bronx. Before going to the Bronx, he was the pastor of St. Catherine of Genoa in Manhattan. MICHAEL LUO (NYT)

description: John J. Mack named two top executives to be co-presidents of Morgan Stanley yesterday in a long-awaited move aimed at clarifying what had been a murky operating environment at the investment bank.

title: Disabled, and Shut Out at the Gym
description: ALTHOUGH Libby Gratton lost her vision two decades ago, she never wanted that to hinder her ability to stay fit. But at five health clubs she visited, she was told she would have to hire a personal trainer to guide her around the equipment. Ms. Gratton couldn't afford a trainer, so except for an occasional walk with her husband she didn't work out. "I was discouraged but I understood they had a bottom line to worry about," she said. "I'm not one to make waves."

description: Because of a production malfunction, an article on Tuesday about a protest outside the office of The Philadelphia Inquirer over its publication of caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad omitted a response from Seth Lipsky, publisher of The New York Sun, who was asked why his newspaper had printed two of the caricatures. While Mr. Lipsky hung up on a reporter when first telephoned for comment, he later said by e-mail: "We published the two images last week not to make a political statement but to illustrate a dispatch by The Associated Press. We sought to respect the sensitivities by running the story and pictures in a modest position inside the paper." (Go to Article)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHEBITZ, GEORGE
description: SHEBITZ--George. The law firm of Shebitz Berman & Cohen, P.C. is sad to announce the passing of its founding senior partner and visionary leader, George Shebitz, on February 8, 2006. He was 58. George was nationally recognized as a leading expert on education law. He began his public service as counsel and Deputy Director of the Office of Legal Services for the NYC Board of Education with then, Chancellor Frank Macchiorola. He worked tirelessly, selflessly and compassionately to protect the rights of children, persons with disabilities and the mistreated everywhere. George was admitted to the NY Bar in 1975. He was a frequent presenter at law and education seminars, as well as a lecturer at Bank Street College of Education and Fordham University. He served as a member of Governor Cuomo's Task Force on Youth and Criminal Justice. George's good work touched many lives. There was a special place in his heart, both in his legal and philanthropic work, for children with special needs and programs designed to help meet their educational goals, in recognition that everyone was entitled to a free and appropriate education. George and his wife Randi have been the recipients of numerous honors and awards. For the purpose of brevity only four are highlighted: Humanitarian of the Year by the Rockland Jewish Family Services; Humanitarian Award by the Association for the Advancement of the Blind and Retarded; Humanitarian of the Year and Board of Trustees Emeritus of the Rockland Country Day School; and Individual of the Year by P'Tach, a nationwide special education program. George sat on numerous boards of not-for-profit corporations including educational institutions ranging from early childhood programs to degree granting colleges, entertainment boards providing opportunities to young men and women, and entities serving the adult mentally retarded populations. George is survived by his loving wife Randi, his adoring children Daniela and Adam and son-in-law Sergio Capozzi, his precious grandson Jonah, his beloved sister Miriam Rappaport, his niece Elyse and nephews Jonathan and Andrew, and his brotherin-law, Nat Dembin. The funeral will take place on Thursday, February 9th, at 1:15 PM, at Riverside Chapel, W. 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., Manhattan. Burial will be following the service at New Montefiore Cemetery in Farmingdale, LI.
