Memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association or the North Shore Animal League America. Mannie's song remains in our hearts.

title: Cutting Hair, but the Real Business Is Cutting Each Other Up
description: Every workplace that prides itself on banter or turmoil imagines it could become a television series. Most places couldn't. But whatever barber first laid down his scissors and said, "You know, we could do a show right here"  he, at least, was onto something.

title: Train Announcements Are Clearer (Squonk Mumble Brzzt), They Say
description: Among pesky subway annoyances, those crackly, inaudible and often nonexistent announcements may take the cake. "They're horrendous," said Hassan Adams, a Manhattan metal worker, after the speakers on his downtown W train emitted something yesterday that may have been a human voice, but it was hard to tell.

title: Looking Good, Even While Sleeping
description: Q. I've always liked bunk beds. Are there versions that save space?

title: Computer Analysis Suggests Paintings Are Not Pollocks
description: A physicist who is broadly experienced in using computers to identify consistent patterns in the drip paintings of Jackson Pollock has determined that half a dozen small paintings recently discovered and claimed by their owner to be original Pollocks do not exhibit the same patterns.

title: Challenging Rival, Spitzer Strongly Defends Abortion Rights
description: Challenging a political rival over the right to abortion, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, the leading Democratic candidate for governor of New York, vowed today to ensure statewide access to the procedure and to support late-term abortions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARCUS, SAMUEL
description: MARCUS--Samuel. On February 5, 2006 at home with Sylvia, his beloved wife of over 50 years. Cherished father of Andrew & Rhonda, adored grandfather of Sydney, friend of Carolyn. He will be deeply missed and never forgotten. Love for children and nature but most of all his family made him the special person he was. Devotion to his business and all people concerned made Sam a role model. His granddaughter Sydney was the light of his life as he was for many. Services will be at RiversideNassau North Chapel, 55 North Shore Rd, Great Neck Thursday, February 9 at 12:30.

title: Don't yield to extremists
F.C.C. Supports  la Carte Cable Option
description: It has been a given of American living rooms for decades: Every year, the cable television bill goes up and consumers get more channels they do not want or cannot find the time to watch.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Two Charged With Endangering Child
description: A woman and her companion were arrested yesterday because they had sought no medical attention after the woman's 2-year-old daughter fell into a bathtub of hot water on Sunday and was burned, the police said. Workers for the city's Administration for Children's Services contacted the police at 1 a.m. for assistance at 2030 Cross Bronx Expressway, according to the police. The girl, who had burns on her back, arm and leg, was taken to a hospital, where she was reported in stable condition. The mother, Yolanda Rodriguez, 31, and Francis Viera, 45, were charged with endangering the welfare of a child, the police said. Sheila Stainback, a spokeswoman for children's services, said that the agency had received a complaint about Ms. Rodriguez earlier in the day. COLIN MOYNIHAN (NYT)

title: Housekeeper to the Stars Admits Stealing From Her Least Favorites
description: Robert De Niro's ex-housekeeper, tears rolling down her cheeks, admitted in a Manhattan courtroom yesterday that she had stolen a $95,500 pair of diamond-drop earrings belonging to his wife, Grace Hightower.

title: French Activist Denied Entry to United States, Cornell Says
description: A leading French antiglobalism activist, scheduled to speak at a conference co-sponsored by Cornell University, was denied entry into the United States at Kennedy International Airport yesterday, Cornell officials said.

title: A Tremor of Rebellion
description: Correction Appended

title: Crossing a Line Drawn in Greenwich's Fine Sand
description: GREENWICH, Conn. - For Sheila Foster, Migdalia Bonilla and Claudette Rothman, it is what some of their fellow Greenwich residents have had to say in the morning paper that stings the most.

title: Letter from Britain: Who should decide when life should end?
Corrections
description: A rock review on Tuesday about Jenny Lewis referred incorrectly to the Angel Orensanz Center on the Lower East Side, where she performed. It is a converted synagogue, not church.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Settlement In Nightclub Stampede
description: Lawyers representing the families of 21 people killed and dozens injured in a Chicago nightclub stampede three years ago announced they had reached a settlement with the club in a civil lawsuit. Under the proposal, which must be approved by a judge, the nightclub, E2, would pay $1.5 million to 116 plaintiffs. Robert Phillips, a lawyer for some of the plaintiffs, said the settlement was not meaningful compensation but was the full extent of the club's insurance coverage. The company that owned the club filed for bankruptcy more than a year ago. Hundreds of people tried to flee through one exit at the club after pepper spray was used to break up a fight in February 2003.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a memorial service for the bandleader Skitch Henderson misspelled the surname of the mezzo-soprano who was a speaker. She is Marilyn Horne, not Horn.

title: Federal Judge Holds Off Approval of KPMG Tax Shelter Deal
description: A federal judge postponed approval yesterday of a proposed $195 million settlement between the accounting firm KPMG and tax shelter investors, giving the two sides time to renegotiate the deal.

title: Evil deeds in Iran? British are suspects No. 1
Benefits Go the Way of Pensions
description: For years, the benefit packages of General Motors were considered to be so good that the company was known among workers and retirees as Generous Motors.

title: Dip in Cancer Deaths Is Reported In First U.S. Decline in 70 Years
description: The number of cancer deaths in the United States has dropped slightly, the first decline in more than 70 years, the American Cancer Society is reporting today.

title: For celebrated Mr. Fix-It, a big challenge in France
Frank Goodman, 89, Handler of Press and Broadway Stars, Dies
description: Frank Goodman, one of the last of the old-time Broadway press agents, a star handler and headline hustler, died on Friday at the Tisch Hospital of the New York University Medical Center. He was 89 and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about lead poisoning among displaced Gypsies, or Roma, living in Kosovo refugee camps misstated the full name of a German physician who conducted tests on camp residents last October. He is Klaus-Dietrich Runow, not Klaus Dietrich-Runow.

title: INSIDE
description: Iraq Utilities Fall Short Of Prewar Performance Virtually every measure of the performance of Iraq's oil, electricity, water and sewerage sectors has fallen below preinvasion levels even though $16 billion of American taxpayer money has already been disbursed in the reconstruction program, witnesses said at a Senate committee hearing.

title: Fed Plans 2-Day Meeting
description: The Federal Reserve said the next meeting of its interest-rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee will last two days, March 27 and 28, to allow more time for the new Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, to confer with the panel.

title: N.Y.U. Plans Mental Health Center for Children
description: New York University plans to build what it says will be the nation's largest pediatric mental health center to treat thousands of children and train thousands of doctors, and Gov. George E. Pataki has pledged more than $65 million in state funds for the project, which will help address a pressing need.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Juggernaut Rolls On
description: Fox slaughtered everything in its path on Tuesday in Nielsen's estimates. The network's "American Idol" delivered an audience of 30.91 million and continued to outpace its ratings from last season. Compared with its 2005 totals during the same weeks, the talent competition has grown in double digits in both its 18-to-49 ratings and among total viewers. And as it did last winter, "Idol" lifted "House," which returned from a hiatus to its best ratings ever. An audience of 22.19 million watched Dr. House (Hugh Laurie) turn away the love of his life, Stacy (Sela Ward), because he prefers to be miserable. "House" beat everything in its time slot at 9 p.m. in all key demographics. KATE AURTHUR

description: BUSKIN--Pamela E. Boslet. Of Montclair, New Jersey, 60, on February 4, 2006. Beloved wife of John Buskin. Cherished mother of Oliver and Roxanne Buskin, all of Montclair. Caring sister of Robert Boslet of Uniondale, NY. Memorial 2PM Saturday, February 11, First Congregational Church, 40 South Fullerton, Montclair, NJ.

Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Driver Charged In Fatal Crash
description: A 17-year-old boy was killed and a 23-year-old man was critically injured when their Nissan sedan hit a light pole on North Conduit Avenue near Sutter Avenue in City Line about 1 a.m. yesterday, the police said. The driver of the car, Ramchand Hansraj, 35, fled the scene of the accident and was later charged with vehicular manslaughter, assault and driving while intoxicated, according to the authorities. The names of the victims had not been released last night. The 23-year-old was in critical condition at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center. The police said that with the help of a computer, Mr. Hansraj was found at an address in Brooklyn. He had been arrested on Jan. 29 for driving with a suspended license, they said. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)

title: Congress pushes for change on U.S. trade
Web-only guide: Lennon lore and more
Jets' Tannenbaum Has the Law on His Side
description: Before Mike Tannenbaum landed a career in the National Football League, he spent a childhood bumping up against the disappointment and the triumph of growing up a sports fan in the Boston suburb of Needham, Mass.

title: Putin Considers Inviting Hamas Leaders to Moscow
description: MADRID, Feb. 9 A President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said today that he was considering inviting leaders of the radical Palestinian Islamic group Hamas to Moscow to discuss solutions to the conflict in the Middle East.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 23 at Shiite Event in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 9  A suicide bomber killed at least 23 people taking part in a Shiite religious procession in Pakistan today, according to Interior Department officials.

title: After Tense Election, a Smooth Count in Haiti
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 8 - United Nations troops began hauling ballots on Wednesday from remote voting centers across the country, as a politically polarized population braced nervously for results from Tuesday's presidential election.

title: 30-Year Treasury Bond Returns and Demand Is Strong
description: The first auction of 30-year Treasury bonds in more than four years attracted surprisingly strong demand this afternoon, allowing the federal government to borrow $14 billion at a yield of up to 4.53 percent, almost a percentage point lower than it paid at the previous auction in 2001.

title: The Nation's Dual Political Dynasties Are Growing Closer Than Arm's Length
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 - When the Bushes and Clintons held hands before 15,000 mourners at Coretta Scott King's funeral on Tuesday, it looked like a prayerful moment in the life of the nation. But as almost anyone watching America's two leading political families knew, underneath the tranquil image was a drama of ambition, rivalry, love and alliance that could shape the 2008 presidential election.

title: Solar Energy Is Gaining Powerful Friends
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 - It was not so many years ago that solar power was a niche concept for electricity generation, an idea embraced mostly by the green-minded who were eager to do their part for energy conservation.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Pipe Maker Pleads Guilty
description: McWane Inc., a major pipe manufacturer with foundries in several states, pleaded guilty in Utah to federal environmental crimes, the fourth guilty verdict against McWane in the last year. The company admitted submitting false results from emissions tests at its Provo plant, Pacific States Cast Iron Pipe. McWane was ordered to pay $3 million in fines. Prosecutors described that as the largest criminal environmental fine in Utah. The former top executive at Pacific States, Charles Matlock, also pleaded guilty. His sentencing was scheduled for May. McWane, the target of an continuing investigation by the Justice Department, has faced prosecution at five foundries in four states, including Alabama, where the company is based. With the new guilty plea, McWane has been ordered to pay a total of $19 million in fines and restitution.

description: In percent

title: Blending and Distilling Themes of Spirit and Soul
description: Ronald K. Brown has emerged in recent years as one of the strongest, most distinctive choreographers around. There are those who worry that to identify anything today as "black dance" is restrictive, even racist, and of course it is true that in many cases race is no longer an issue.

title: Antidepressants May Harm Infants' Lungs, Report Says
description: Expectant mothers who took antidepressants like Prozac late in their pregnancy were significantly more likely to give birth to an infant with a rare but serious breathing problem, doctors are reporting today.

title: Back at Campaign Site, Bush Sells Budget
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 8 - President Bush returned to this city where he campaigned for the Republican nomination six years ago on a platform of tax cutting and fiscal restraint, arguing that the budget that he sent to Congress on Monday fulfilled that promise.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Body In Suitcase Is Identified
description: A body discovered in a suitcase on Sunday morning has been identified as that of Mario Hidalgo, 28, of 230 Seaman Avenue in the Inwood section of Manhattan, the police said. The suitcase was found in front of 69 West 225th Street in Kingsbridge. The police said Mr. Hildago had been stabbed several times. Relatives came forward to identify the body after seeing a sketch released by the police. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)

title: Report Says Number of Attacks by Insurgents in Iraq Increases
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 - Sweeping statistics on insurgent violence in Iraq that were declassified for a Senate hearing on Wednesday appear to portray a rebellion whose ability to mount attacks has steadily grown in the nearly three years since the invasion.

title: Fancy Camping, With Sunshine Inside
description: A small yellow plywood cube by Elizabeth Leriche, a Paris trend spotter, contains a bed, sink, shower and cooking area. Unveiled last week as a concept piece about contemporary nomadic living at the Maison & Objet furnishings fair in Paris, it echoes a similar (though unpainted) plywood dwelling on display at a retrospective of the midcentury interior architect Charlotte Perriand at the Centre Pompidou in Paris (through March 27).

title: Few Big Surprises, Except One: The Music Dominated
description: With no host, a minimum of banter and some two dozen performances, the 48th Annual Grammy Awards worked like an arena concert -- a smart move for a show that has often diluted its best resource, the music. Finally, the Grammys have realized they are not like the Academy Awards. What matters most is not the celebrities, or even who gets the awards, but the music.

title: Gaza Gunmen Kidnap Egyptian Envoy; Israel Kills 3
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 9 A Chaos erupted in the Gaza Strip today as Palestinian gunmen kidnapped an Egyptian diplomat, while three armed Palestinians were killed during two separate attacks along Gaza's northern border with Israel.

description: MOSCOW, Feb. 8 - A grandfatherly figure, his bearded face wrinkled into a smile, peers down from billboards around town.

title: U.S.O.C. HIRES SPECIALIST
description: The United States Olympic Committee announced the hiring Wednesday of Robert Fasulo as its director of international relations. Fasulo, who has been director of the Association of Summer Olympic International Federations since 2000, said he would try to improve the committee's standing in the international sports community, which is expected to benefit future Olympic bid cities.

description: Stephen M. Ross, the city's most active and politically connected developer, suffered a rare defeat yesterday when city officials barred him from getting a valuable special bonus for bringing Cirque du Soleil to West 42nd Street.

description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 8 - Rupert Day, a self-described "frequent floater" who commutes by ferry between here and Port Jefferson, on Long Island, each day, has one word to describe the new $1 surcharge on his ticket.

title: Prim on the Outside, but a Funhouse Within
description: LONDON - WITH a children's slide shooting down from the attic, a pair of beds that look like space pods, blue rubber floors and pink walls -- not to mention a museum's worth of contemporary art and design -- one could easily mistake the London home of Kenny Schachter and Ilona Rich for an avant-garde playground.

title: 160 Hours of Video Ready to Hit the Road or Anywhere Else
description: With its seven-inch screen, which is fairly large as personal media players go, the DMP740 dockable media player from Directed Electronics can be used as a stand-alone device. But when docked to a mobile monitor in a car, it can show images on a screen as large as 17 inches.

title: Putting Some Kick in the Jumper
description: Few trends so artfully fuse images of the naif and the vamp as the jumper. Last season they resurfaced on the runway at Miu Miu, where Miuccia Prada riffed charmingly on a popular street style by mating bonbon-colored jumpers with immaculate white tees. Marc Jacobs, in contrast, showed a starchy schoolgirl version that Sister Mary Ignatius would surely have approved. Now tarted-up interpretations of the oh-so-proper 1950's look are being resurrected for fall.

title: 30-year U.S. bond is back in big way
This Could Be the Beginning of a Brazilian Friendship
description: The Brazilian film "Cinema, Aspirins and Vultures" is, as might be expected from its quixotic title, a story of moving pictures, analgesics and scavengers. But this road movie about two men traveling the dusty byways of the largest country in Latin America is also about how a little imagination and a quality cinematographer can triumph over a poverty of means.

You in the Arab European League published a cartoon of Hitler in bed with Anne Frank so we in the West would understand how offended you were by those Danish cartoons. You at the Iranian newspaper Hamshahri are holding a Holocaust cartoon contest so we'll also know how you feel.

title: Bush Urges Nations to End Violence; Rice Accuses Syria and Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 - President Bush called on governments around the world on Wednesday to halt the violence that has followed the publication of cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad, while Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice accused Iran and Syria of fueling the protests for political gain.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Hotel Locks Out Evacuee
description: The owners of a Radisson Hotel in Jamaica briefly locked out a Katrina evacuee yesterday, prompting lawyers for the Legal Aid Society to seek a court order reinstating the man, John Buttitta. A Housing Court judge granted the order, said Judith Goldiner, a Legal Aid lawyer. Mr. Buttitta, who could not be reached for comment, is among dozens of evacuees living at hotels in New York City who have been denied housing extensions by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, according to a representative of the evacuees. On Tuesday, the agency stopped issuing housing subsidies for thousands of evacuees across the country. Marc Leffman, the chief executive of the company that owns the Radisson, said yesterday that the hotel managers had locked out Mr. Buttitta because he refused to seek a FEMA extension. Mr. Leffman added that the hotel let Mr. Buttitta back into his room before the court order was received. NICHOLAS CONFESSORE (NYT)

title: Spanish Architecture
description: The Museum of Modern Art's contemporary Spanish architecture feels undercooked, but there is much to see.

title: The Squeezebox 3
description: David Pogue enthusiastically reviews a wireless receiver that provides a window onto your computer's music collection elsewhere in the house.

title: Scheduled Irrelevance
description: Most all of the foreign film nominee screenings for New York members of the Academy are scheduled over Presidents Day weekend, a time when it is really easy to get a great table in New York restaurants, but not so great for finding people who are eligible to vote.

title: New York Collections
description: Women's and men's wear from the fall 2006 New York Fashion Week.

title: The Gary Shandling Show?
description: People who have wondered what Paramount chief Brad Grey has to worry about in the Anthony Pellicano investigation might recall that Mr. Grey was in a long and nasty fight with Gary Shandling. Mr. Pellicano, a private investigator, was reportedly indicted for wiretapping a number of people, including Mr. Shandling. A plus B does not always add up to C, but the math is worth considering.

title: Swagged and Bagged
description: If you are a member of the Academy  the only thing that the Bagger belongs to is a street gang named the Insane Unknowns  you are likely in receipt of a lovely little bound script book for Brokeback Mountain. And even if you are not among the few, the proud, the gifted, subscribers to the print version of Variety received a look-book about Brokeback, including those rarely seen two-shots of Heath and Jake. It may not be Scarlett and Keira, but the boys look good together.

title: Munich, Reconsidered and Repackaged
description: By now, the Bagger thinks we can all agree that Munich was rolled out with all the grace and beauty of a ship that started to sink after it was christened with a bottle of champagne. Bad P.R., bad ads, and bad vibe, all rolled into one. And yet, and yet, it was nominated as one of the five best pictures of the year. So, the folks behind the film, having been granted some oxygen by the nomination, are going to give selling Steven Spielbergs movie another whack. There are new print ads that could not help but be an improvement over the original ad, left: The silhouette of a lone figure certainly brought a lot of mood to bear, a mood that suggests the guy might be about to cut his own wrists. As Rachel Abramowitz of the Los Angeles Times pointed out, marketing the movie as a SERIOUS, IMPORTANT FILM probably wounded its prospects a lot more than the ack-ack it picked up from people on either side of the Middle East debate. The new ads show some beefy, trained-to-maim dudes that would not be out of place in, ah, an action-packed thriller. The marketplace, and by proxy, Hollywood, is a place where do-overs arent usually handed out, but Munichs substantial appeal with members of the Academy  whether it is mostly homage to Mr. Spielbergs storied career or not  has given this movie another shot.

title: Greer on Friedan, Flip-Flop in Pittsburgh and More

description: Selborne Journal: Monday, 9 February 1784: 29 1/10; 33; W, SW, S. Hard frost, dark, thaw, snow, snow, snow.

title: Black and White and Pasted All Over
description: Mebbe it is just the Bagger, but do the ads for this years Oscar contain a semiotic pitch for Good Night, and Good Luck? Look at the male version of the ad, which can be seen on billboards around L.A. right now. You have a suited male, face unseen, rendered in black and white. The only color in the picture comes from the golden guy himself. You dont have to squint your eyes too much to start thinking the classically attired male torso might be that of David Strathairn, George Clooney, or even Edward R. Murrow. Perhaps the Baggers blood sugar is running a bit high and muddling his thinking, but now that he has put that little thought in your head, see if you ever look at the ad the same way again.

title: Credit Score
description: Sometimes when things slow down, the Bagger does his best thinking. Not that he is going to go all Mensa on you, but you know what they say about idle hands. Fer instance, a while back we did a story about the scrum over credits, and now that the ballots are shipping, its worth revisiting. On one level, the fight over who gets credit for Crash is all of the worst of Hollywood  pettiness, ego, avarice  in one untidy multi-car pileup. On another, very real issues are at stake. On one side is the Producers Guild of Anerica and, by proxy, the Academy, seeking to control credit creep, in which everybody and his brother can say they produced a film. On the other, you have people like Bob Yari and Mark Harris, two of the guys who got stiffed in the new process of determining who gets actual credit come Oscar time, wondering who appointed these guys as arbiters of all that is good and holy in the production process. As indie productions grow and become a mainstay of the both the business and the aesthetic of the industry, movies are going to continue to come together in a complicated way. Mr. Yari has already sued one of his former production partners on Crash, not just over the credit issue, but that certainly is one of the salient issues. Mr. Yari has made noises about actually going ahead and suing the Producers Guild, but that brings up a rather delicate issue. Mr. Yari continues to be financially staked in Crash, and will benefit significantly if the movie ends up sneaking in as best picture. So, with that broader objective in mind, he and anybody else involved in Crash wants to get the Academys attention. And suing the hand that feeds them, while it will accomplish that goal, will not endear the membership when Crash needs all the friends it can get.

title: Moment of Truth
description: With ballots beginning to land all over town, members of the Academy are looking over the list and realizing just how many movies they have to actually see to credibly vote in all of the categories. And if they are being the least bit honest with themselves, they will look in the mirror and say, That isnt going to happen. They will make a valiant effort, churning their way through several films, but eventually, they will succumb to reality and pull the trigger in some categories they know very little about. The Bagger has always said that democracy  especially as practiced by elites  is a very blunt technology.

title: Secret Agents
description: Gail Berman, the president of Paramount, has complained that she is getting mau-maued by a bunch of underinformed bloggers, but more than the blogosphere is chattering about how fleeting her hold on the job might be. Brad Grey, head of Paramount, offered a remarkably wan defense in Laura Holsons piece in The Times this week. Mr. Grey said Ms. Berman had his support so far. Shes working hard and its early, he said. Some have suggested that Ari Emmanuel of the Endeavor agency will be brought in to help run the place in Ms. Bermans stead. That would mean that the Dreamworks guys have managed to reverse the polarity on the sale of Dreamworks live-action unit to Paramount, with Jeffrey Katzenberg and Co. dictating what the new team will look like.

title: Much Ado About Nothing at King Funeral
description: Not every conservative is outraged that a few political statements were directed toward President Bush, who was in attendance, during Coretta Scott Kings funeral on Tuesday. (In case youve missed this dust-up, former president Jimmy Carter alluded to Bushs domestic surveillance program by mentioning government wiretapping of Martin Luther King, Jr., while The Rev. Joseph Lowery, former leader of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, criticized the war in Iraq.)

title: Gaming the Next Moves in the Spying Fight
description: Now that Attorney General Alberto Gonzales has finished his testimony to the Senate Judiciary Committee, opponents of domestic spying by the National Security Agency are wondering what they should do next. First Amendment lawyer turned influential N.S.A. scandal blogger Glenn Greenwald concedes that Gonzales articulated a clear and coherent legal theory to defend Bushs violations of the law. Greenwald, however, also argues that the administrations legal position is so radical, so dangerous, and so contrary to our most basic political values, that the first priority, in my view, is to make Americans aware of exactly what powers the administration claims it has the right to use  not just against Al Qaeda, but against American citizens, within the United States.

title: Trash Talking Funeral Talk
description: President Bush had to know what was in store for him. I wonder if he ever thought of not attending Coretta Scott Kings funeral. I suppose, if it ever crossed his mind, it was not a realistic option. He knew three former presidents and one presidential candidate (Hillary Clinton) would be there. He also knew he didnt want more criticism about being racist and insensitive, after the raking over the coals he got for the Hurricane Katrina disaster. But after his experience at Mrs. Kings funeral, I am sure he would rather have been somewhere else.

title: Can Computerized Agents Add?
description: This e-mail from a University of Washington computer science professor is being passed around and it is pretty funny. One of them played around with the Zillow.com computerized home price estimator, branded as the Zestimator. (I had some problems with it and so did a number of others, I understand.)

title: Alleged Mortgage Grifting

title: BIIIIIIIGGGGG Bathroom
description: In touring a lot of McMansions and luxury condominiums, I have seen some pretty large bathrooms in my time  you know, the ones with his and her vanities, a shower big enough to accommodate four people at once, a jacuzzi bathtub and plenty of marble  but the one in this TriBeCa apartmentsurely takes the cake. (You will have to click on the icon for view floorplan.)

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "Elliot, a Soldier's Fugue" and "December Fools."

title: Stay at Home
description: Any time people approaching or over retirement age (that moving target) are asked how long they want to stay in their current home, something like 80 percent of them say as long as possible (in so many words).

title: 'The Pink Panther'
description: Stephen Holden reviews the new version of "The Pink Panther," starring Steve Martin as Inspector Clouseau.

title: Squint to Find Senior Housing
description: Web design too often overdoses on the fancy stuff and neglects the basics. The National Association of Home Builders recently gave awards for the best Web sites for senior housing. The big winner was Village on the Green in Rancho Cucamonga, Calif.

title: 'The Tenants'
description: Stephen Holden reviews "The Tenants," starring Dylan McDermott and Snoop Dogg.

title: Top of the Rock
description: Glenn Collins discusses the recently re-opened observation deck at the top of 30 Rockefeller Center. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

title: Who Will Win Best Actor?
description: David Carr (a k a The Carpetbagger) combs Times Square for opinions as to who will win this year's Oscar for Best Actor. (Producer: Brent McDonald)

title: Dollars for OReilly
description: Winter Miller, my poor researcher, whose human rights I had not fully taken into account when I invited readers to send in their pledges to cover Bill OReillys trip to Darfur, has now plodded through one-quarter of the 6,000 pledges that have come in. The total is now $181,207.

title: Anna Sui Fall 2006
description: Eric Wilson interviews Anna Sui about her fall fashion line. (Producer: Shayla Harris)

title: A Film Series That Celebrates the Truly, Deeply French
description: How French is it? The "it" in this case is the Prix Jean Vigo, an annual award bestowed almost without interruption since 1951 on a French filmmaker notable for his or (less frequently) her "independence of spirit and originality of style." And it is very French. Among the prize beneficiaries are filmmakers who, much as Vigo did in the first half of the 20th century, have helped define modern French cinema since, including Claude Chabrol, Jean-Luc Godard, Alain Resnais, Chris Marker, Maurice Pialat, Philippe Garrel, Arnaud Desplechin and Olivier Assayas.

title: A Quick End to the Cult Series That Lived Up to Its Name
description: There are things that should have been popular but were not: the Allende government, geothermal home heating and "Arrested Development."

title: Parker Gets All-Star Nod and Needed Validation
description: Tony Parker worked the red carpet two weeks ago and appeared on "Oprah" this week with his companion, the actress Eva Longoria. He is a budding rapper in France, his home country, and has won two N.B.A. championships in his first four seasons as the San Antonio Spurs' point guard.

title: Death Penalty Asked for Beslan Raider, Reviving a Debate
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 9 - A senior prosecutor on Thursday asked a court in southern Russia to sentence to death the only attacker known to have survived the siege of Middle School No. 1 in Beslan in September 2004. The request rekindles a contentious debate in Russia over capital punishment.

title: Memoirs of a 'Great and Good' European
A Survey of Spain, Architects' Playground
description: IS there any show more overdue than a major one about contemporary Spanish architecture?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOFFMANN, WILLIAM J. JR.
description: HOFFMANN--William J. Jr. Long associated with broadcasting, advertising and musical circles, died on February 3, 2006. He was 91 years old and lived in Larchmont, New York. He is survived by his beloved wife Judith Telep-Ehrlich, son William J. Hoffmann III and daughter Elizabeth Patricia Hoffmann, and George S. Hoffmann, brother, of Winter Harbor, Maine.

title: The Tin Men of Hollywood
description: If there's a director on earth who knows about marketing, it's probably someone who used to run a studio. Joe Roth directed the Samuel L. Jackson-Julianne Moore crime drama "Freedomland" (opening February 17th) and some forgettable movies like "Christmas with the Kranks," but he's better known as a successful executive at Disney and Fox and the creator of Revolution Studios.

title: Soldier Girls, Molls and Femmes Fatales
description: When Donald Brooks and Chester Weinberg designed military jackets in the late 1960's, the look was more in line with Sgt. Pepper than the battlefields of Vietnam. Fashion tends to reflect times of war through a prism of pop culture; the picture is more interesting when it is not so literal.

title: A Norwegian robbery so frustrating you could scream
Head of Construction Company Is Acquitted of Bribing Union
description: The president of a New York construction company, who was accused of doing a "corrupt dance" with greedy union bosses, was acquitted yesterday in New York federal court of paying bribes to union officials.

title: Arts Guide
Voting Rights Under Siege
description: American laws that strip convicted felons of the right to vote, barring nearly five million from the polls in the last election, are the most punitive and regressive laws of their kind in the democratic world. Several states have recently softened or eliminated the voting bans, and many others are considering laws that could eventually establish voting as a basic American right that should never be curtailed in a way that bars a whole class of people from the polls.

title: Around the Markets: Japan machine data lift yen versus dollar
Spare Times
description: Attractions

description: Opens today in Manhattan Directed by Anah Berneri In Spanish with English subtitles Unrated, 95 minutes

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RABHAN, DR. NATHAN BENAMI
description: RABHAN--Dr. Nathan Benami, 67. On February 7, 2006. Beloved husband of Jane Sonnenschein Rabhan for 43 years. Adored father of Rabbi David, Laura, and Rachel. Loving grandfather to six. Dear brother to Debora Hynda of Tel Aviv, Israel and Charlotte, N.C. Revered brother-in-law to Marc Sonnenschein and Edward Pizer. For 45 years he was devoted to the care and well-being of his patients who will never forget his dedication. Shiva is being observed at 115 Central Park West until Tuesday.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Move Against Hotel Over Cubans' Expulsion
description: Mexico City officials moved to close the Sheraton Maria Isabel, which ordered a group of Cuban officials to leave last week at the request of the United States. Virginia Jaramillo Flores, a city official, said inspectors had found that the hotel lacked liquor licenses for its bars, did not have enough parking spaces and had more floor space than its occupancy license allows. JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. (NYT)

title: In Storm's Aftermath, Catholics Close Parishes
description: Sandra J. Gordon was confirmed in the Catholic Church at St. Augustine in the Treme neighborhood of New Orleans. She was married there, her children were baptized there, her mother and grandmother were buried from there, and she volunteers there most days of the week.

title: Lurid Numbers on Glossy Pages! (Magazines Exploit What Sells)
description: A trip to the newsstand these days can be a dizzying descent into a blizzard of numbers. The March issue of Elle Girl promises readers "375 excuses to shop." Harper's Bazaar offers "783 new ideas to flatter you." Marie Claire trumpets not only "71 easy hair and makeup how-tos" but a mind-blowing "1,157 hot looks (all shapes, all sizes, all prices)."

title: A Quick End to the Cult Series That Lived Up to Its Name
description: There are things that should have been popular but were not: the Allende government, geothermal home heating and "Arrested Development."

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: City Chief Gets Life In Land Clash
description: The Communist Party chief of Dingzhou, a city in northern Hebei Province, was sentenced to life in prison for his role in one the bloodiest rural clashes in recent years, family members of the victims said. The official, He Feng, was convicted of hiring thugs to attack villagers protesting the seizure of land for a power plant. Six people were killed and dozens injured. The conflict, which received brief but widespread attention in the Chinese news media, was unusual because the authorities had acted swiftly to hold local officials accountable. JOSEPH KAHN (NYT)

title: Male Bonding and Other Late Night Activities
description: Opens today in Manhattan Directed by Hunter Richards 92 minutes

title: Rich guys over here
On-Time High School Graduation Rate Fell in 2005
description: The percentage of New York City high school students graduating on time dropped last year, according to new figures released yesterday, to 53.2 percent in 2005 from 54.3 percent in 2004.

description: Opens today in New York and Los Angeles Directed by Jonathan Hock Unrated, 103 minutes

description: To the Editor:

title: Passenger Check May Be Vulnerable
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 - The newest version of the Transportation Security Administration's proposed system to check the names of airline passengers against terrorist watch lists could be vulnerable to hackers, the agency said on Thursday.

title: Other Views: Daily Telegraph, Miami Herald, JoongAng Daily
Ex-FEMA Chief, in Reversal, to Answer Questions on Storm
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 - For months, Michael D. Brown, former director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, has declined to answer questions from Congress about his conversations during Hurricane Katrina with top Bush administration officials. But in an interview on Thursday, he said that his position had changed.

title: BlackBerry Maker Promises to Offer Backup Gear Soon
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 9 - Research in Motion said Thursday that it would soon release backup software that would keep its BlackBerry wireless e-mail service working even if a federal court shuts down the current system.

title: Corrections
description: The Religion Journal column on Saturday, about efforts by the Reform movement of American Judaism to encourage participation by young men, misstated the origin of a program called "Rosh Hodesh: It's a Girl Thing," which promotes self-esteem and Jewish identity among teenage girls. It was founded by Kolot, the Center for Jewish Women's and Gender Studies at the Reconstructionist Rabbinical College, and spun off to the independent feminist organization Moving Traditions. It was not started by Moving Traditions.

title: F.C.C. Sees Cable Savings in  la Carte
description: It has been a trend in American living rooms for decades: every year, the cable television bill goes up as consumers receive ever more channels they do not want or cannot find the time to watch.

title: A War in Mexico: Drug Runners Gun Down Journalists
description: NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico, Feb. 8 - Ren Martnez had just sat down to edit a batch of articles at 7:50 Monday evening when he heard the heavy tread of military boots just outside the newsroom and then, suddenly, like a scream on a quiet night, blasts of machine-gun fire.

title: White House Knew of Levee's Failure on Night of Storm
description: Correction Appended

title: Young and Craving the Salvation That Only Romance Can Provide
description: MATT, the love-starved then love-struck hero of the new play "Red Light Winter," is the kind of guy who has somehow skidded through his 20's with all of his adolescent awkwardness rigidly in place.

title: Ex-Cheney Aide Testified Leak Was Ordered, Prosecutor Says
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 - I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney, told a grand jury that he was authorized by his "superiors" to disclose classified information to reporters about Iraq's weapons capability in June and July 2003, according to a document filed by a federal prosecutor.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Herta Glaz, 95, Mezzo at the Met, Dies
description: Herta Glaz, a mezzo-soprano who performed regularly at the Metropolitan Opera during the 1940's and 50's and later taught at the Manhattan School of Music, died on Jan. 28 in Hamden, Conn. She was 95.

title: Dubai set to win port operator, and status as giant
Paid Notice: Deaths   FAUSER, JOSEPH E.
description: FAUSER--Joseph E., 88. On February 8, 2006. Known as Buddy. He was the beloved husband of Helen. For 62 years no day passed without Helen and Buddy expressing their love for each other. Also, the proud father of Robert and Arlene Fauser, Jill and Richard Israel, dear brother of Doris Brisbane and the late Charles Fauser. Devoted grandfather to Chad and Patti Fauser and Scott Alessandro and delighted great-grandfather to Darian and Devan. Bud was unique. He lived a full and honorable life. He served in the military during WWII and played football at Brooklyn Polyprep LIU and and semi-professionally. His memory will be a blessing and a source of strength and inspiration to his family and all who knew him. We will miss him. Services Friday February 10, 11:15 at Riverside Chapel. The family will welcome guests at the home of Robert Fauser Friday, February 10 at 3 PM and Sunday Februay 12 from 1-5 PM.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Man Arrested In Killings Of Wife And Daughter
description: A man has been arrested in London and charged with killing his wife and infant daughter in their Hopkinton, Mass., home last month, the authorities said. Martha Coakley, the Middlesex district attorney, said the man, Neil Entwistle, 27, shot his wife, Rachel Souza Entwistle, and 9-month-old daughter, Lillian, on Jan. 20. Mr. Entwistle then fled to London, Ms. Coakley said. He was ordered held in custody, a spokeswoman for Scotland Yard said, and will appear in court today for an extradition hearing. Ms. Coakley said the killings may be a murder-suicide that Mr. Entwistle planned because of financial problems but then backed out of. KATIE ZEZIMA (NYT)

title: Fears and Precautions Spread After Alabama Church Fires
description: ASHBY, Ala., Feb. 9 - Larry Crocker leaned on his cane in the hard clay beside the ruins of Ashby Baptist Church, listening for the distant rumble of the truck that was to bring the mobile sanctuary that would be the church's temporary new home.

title: Spotlight: France's chief saleswoman takes on the skeptics
William Pfaff: A 'long war' designed to perpetuate itself
Sectarian Strife Kills 31 in Pakistan and 6 in Afghanistan
description: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan, Feb. 9 - Violence exploded in Pakistan and Afghanistan on Thursday during processions by Shiite Muslim worshipers observing the holy day of Ashura. A suicide bombing in northwestern Pakistan killed 23 people and wounded dozens more.

description: To the Editor:

description: Correction Appended

title: Pressured, Director of Getty Trust Steps Down
description: The president of the J. Paul Getty Trust in Los Angeles, one of the world's richest art institutions, resigned under pressure yesterday amid growing questions about his improper use of the trust's money.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Thursday Styles yesterday about the response of black professional women to questions of family vs. career misstated the title of the 1963 book by Betty Friedan that considered the issue. It is "The Feminine Mystique," not "The Feminist Mystique."

title: Warning Urged on Stimulants Like Ritalin
description: GAITHERSBURG, Md., Feb. 9 - Stimulants like Ritalin could have dangerous effects on the heart, and federal regulators should require manufacturers to provide written guides to patients and place prominent warnings on drug labels describing these risks, a federal advisory panel voted on Thursday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man's Bludgeoned Body Found In Home
description: A man was found bludgeoned to death yesterday evening in his Barclay Avenue apartment in Flushing, the police said. The man, Yongbae Cha, 61, appeared to have been strangled and hit in the head by a hatchet about 12 to 24 hours before his body was discovered by his son about 6 p.m. The police believe that Mr. Cha let his killer into the apartment and struggled with him before his death. An investigator said that a 41-year-old man who may have rented space from Mr. Cha is being sought for questioning. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROSENBERG, RUTH
description: ROSENBERG--Ruth. February 10, 1911-February 18, 2004. Dearest Mother, missing you today on your birthday, and every day. Carla

title: Candidate of Haiti's Poor Leads in Early Tally With 61% of Vote
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 9 - Unofficial electoral results that had been carried in by mules, trucks and helicopters from polling centers across the country appeared Thursday to give an early lead to Ren Prval, a former president considered a champion of the poor masses and a thorn in the side of the elite.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 2 Policemen Killed In Southern Skirmish
description: At least two Russian security officers died in a clash with armed militants in a village in the Stavropol region, not far from Chechnya, according to officials cited by Russian news reports. The fighting -- involving armored vehicles and other heavy weaponry, including grenade launchers -- erupted not far from Neftekumsk in Stavropol, a region that has largely escaped the conflict in Chechnya. There were conflicting reports of the number of militants killed in the clash. STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)

title: A Cartoon Monkey With No Aspirations to Cultural Commentary
description: In a refreshing departure from the animal heroes of most recent children's movies, Curious George -- or "the monkey," as he's called for the first two-thirds of this new animated film -- doesn't rap, punch out bad guys or emit rapid-fire commentary on pop culture.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about an admission by the New York City Department of Environmental Protection that maintenance lapses at two sewage treatment plants led to the illegal discharge of untreated human waste during the 2003 blackout misidentified the neighborhood of one plant. (The error also appeared in articles on Aug. 18, 2003; Dec. 27, 1989; and Aug. 23, 1987.) Although it is known as the Red Hook sewage treatment plant, it is actually at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

description: Bec Stupak/Honeygun Labs: Radical Earth Magic FlowerDeitch Projects76 Grand Street, SoHoThrough Feb. 25

title: Around the Markets: Commodity outlook weakens Wall Street
Strikes setto escalate throughout Germany
Loose Lips Sink Spies
description: Washington - AT the Central Intelligence Agency, we are more than holding our own in the global war on terrorism, but we are at risk of losing a key battle: the battle to protect our classified information.

title: An Appetite for Fast Gains From Restaurant Chains
description: AMERICANS' obsession with food is only slightly outdone by its passion for real estate. Hedge fund activists seem to share the sentiment, redirecting their recent interest in fast food to casual dining, and focusing beyond high margins in the kitchen to finding value in the land beneath it.

title: Stiegler: No Fear in U.S. Skiers
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 9 - The question was posed to nobody in particular, directed at any of the 10 members of the United States women's ski team during a news conference yesterday at the main press center. The reporter wanted to know: Why do American skiers tend to perform better at the Olympics than on the World Cup circuit?

title: Bush Meets With G.O.P. Lawmakers as They Regroup
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 A House Republicans convened with their new leadership today and heard a pep talk from President Bush, who told them he was eager to work with them on an ambitious agenda.

description: Radical Earth Magic Flower Deitch Projects 76 Grand Street, SoHo Through Feb. 25

title: Debate on Abortion Pill in Australia Becomes Personal
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 9 - The continuing debate here over the so-called abortion pill RU-486 -- the Senate voted Thursday to make it more easily available -- has revealed many of the same fierce emotions as abortion debates do in the United States.

title: Chief Rival for Rahlves Is the Face in the Mirror
description: SESTRIERE, Italy, Feb. 9 - Training runs on the days before the Olympic downhill offer the top racers a conundrum. They want to ski fast to test themselves on what is largely an unfamiliar racecourse. But customarily, they try not to ski too fast because it alerts the field, identifying a clear leader whose on-course decisions and tactics will then be closely studied.

title: Chappelle the Shape-Shifter Sits Still Long Enough to Chat
description: Dave Chappelle's comeback tour has so far included two enigmatic television interviews. The first was that awkward and poetic interview Feb. 3 on "The Oprah Winfrey Show," in which he told Ms. Winfrey that the creepy laugh of a white person contributed to his decision to quit "Chappelle's Show," walk away from his $50 million television deal and flee to Africa in May 2005.

title: Davis Cup Tennis: Croatia hopes to avoid champion's curse
Jury in retrial can't agree on Walter Forbes verdict
description: NEW YORK  Walter Forbes was paid more than $100 million as chairman and chief executive of CUC. To hear him tell it, he did not do much to earn the money.

title: High-Profile Doctor to Leave Position at Cleveland Clinic
description: The public face of the Cleveland Clinic, its outspoken cardiology chairman, Dr. Eric J. Topol, is leaving for academia after a divisive yearlong dispute with the clinic's chief executive, Dr. Delos M. Cosgrove.

title: Election tally triggers Iraq choices
Transit Union and M.T.A. Resume Talks Over Contract
description: The transit workers union and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority have begun new talks in hopes of modifying the contract proposal that the union's rank and file rejected last month, authority and union officials said yesterday.

title: Bowing to Styne's Magic and Delivering the Ballads Smoothly
description: Among the many revealing anecdotes the singer and pianist Eric Comstock scattered through his Jule Styne tribute, "The Music That Makes Me Dance," on Wednesday at the Allen Room, one of the most endearing told of the composer's reluctance during his Hollywood years to write songs specifically for stars. It induced artistic claustrophobia in a songwriter who insisted he wrote "for everybody," Mr. Comstock said.

title: Bird flu outbreak puzzles Chinese officials
Don't Let Your Babies Grow Up to Be Ex-Gay Cowboys
description: Seattle - FIRST, a little of that full disclosure stuff: I have not actually seen "Brokeback Mountain" or "End of the Spear," both of which I'm going to discuss here.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Yushchenko Seeks Constitution Changes
description: In a televised address to Parliament, President Viktor A. Yushchenko called for changes to the Constitution that would return to the presidency powers transferred to Parliament at the start of the year, notably the authority to dissolve Parliament and to appoint temporary governments. ALEXANDER NURNBERG (NYT)

title: A Distinctive Shape, and an Inviting Target
description: Correction Appended

title: Principal of Hampton Bays High School Is Accused of Making Lewd Calls
description: HAMPTON BAYS, N.Y., Feb. 9 - At the start of the academic year, Frank Vetro, the new principal of the high school, posted a letter to parents and students on the school's Web site. It ended with an upbeat prediction: "Together we will have a year of successes, triumphs and wonderful memories."

Paid Notice: Deaths   FAGAN, MSGR. JOHN T.
description: FAGAN--Msgr. John T. A priest of the diocese of Brooklyn for more than 50 years died peacefully on February 9 at Little Flower Children and Family Services in Wading River, NY. Beloved brother of Msgr. Robert Emmet Fagan, Jane Fucigna, Helen Marie Murphy and Kathleen Fagan RSHM and brother-in-law to John Fucigna and James Murphy. He was a devoted uncle of JT Fucigna, Robert Fucigna, Brian Fucigna, Michael Fucigna, JaneEllen Logler, Kathleen Murphy, Elizabeth Cooke, Helen Marie Sweeney, Kristin Hubschman, James Murphy 1V (deceased), and numerous grandnieces and grandnephews. Ordained in 1952 he served in Resurrection Ascension parish in Rego Park before being assigned to Little Flower Children and Family Services in 1959. Putting the needs of children first in all decision making, he was a champion on behalf of children and families for his entire life. The oldest in a loving family, he was deeply sensitive to the importance of family for every child. A lover of people and life he shared his humor and kindness with everyone. His respect, reverence, and delight in each person made him loved by all. Visiting hours at Little Flower Chapel, Wading River, from 2PM to 5PM on Friday, February 10. Mass of Transferral, St. Mark's Church, Shoreham, 8PM on Friday, February 10, preceded by viewing from 7PM to 8PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday, February 11, at 10AM at the Immaculate Conception Center, Douglaston, NY. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY In Lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the "Fr. Fagan Angel Fund" at Little Flower Children and Family Services, 2450 North Wading River Road, Wading River, NY 11972. For information: Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home.

title: Not This Time, the City Says Taking Back a Tax Cut
description: Two weeks ago, the City Department of Finance, to the cheers of many apartment owners, announced the improbable: a rule change that would significantly cut property taxes on many small co-op, condominium and rental buildings, even as market values continued to soar.

description: NEW YORK

title: In the Cendant Trial, Ignorance Was an Excuse
description: Walter A. Forbes was paid more than $100 million as chairman and chief executive of the CUC Corporation. To hear him tell it, he did not do very much to earn the money.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Feb. 1 about President Bush's State of the Union address referred incorrectly in some copies to his proposal to help illegal immigrants get temporary jobs. He endorsed a "humane guest-worker program that rejects amnesty" -- not a plan based on amnesty.

title: A Trio Feeling Its Way Through Territory Where Tatum Roamed
description: Few jazz musicians are more forthright about their influences than Adam Makowicz. As a pianist, he has always pledged allegiance to the fearsome style of Art Tatum, a whorl of dazzling runs, stride syncopations and impossibly fleet arpeggios. This caused a sort of sensation when Mr. Makowicz first came to New York from his native Poland nearly 30 years ago: the producer John Hammond, who sponsored the trip, signed him to Columbia Records, and the impresario Barney Josephson presented him at the Cookery, to a succession of rapturous crowds.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Thinking About the Way We Eat

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (Fox) ARRESTED DEVELOPMENT -- The Bluths are busy bees in the two-hour season finale. George Sr. (Jeffrey Tambor) hires a new lawyer, who sets up a mock trial so the family can practice testifying. Judge Reinhold plays himself playing the judge. Michael (Jason Bateman) finds his long-lost sister (Justine Bateman, his real-life sister, above, with Mr. Bateman) and hires her as a consultant. Michael, Gob (Will Arnett) and Buster (Tony Hale) fly to Iraq. Lucille (Jessica Walter) gives a yacht party on the Queen Mary II.

title: He's Taking Aeschylus Hip-Hop
description: THAT lanky young man sitting on a sunny park bench and muttering into a portable cassette as he scribbles in a notebook may not be the amiable neighborhood madman. He could very well be Will Power, the rap actor and playwright whose "Flow" was a hit of the 2003 New York City Hip-Hop Festival. Now Mr. Power, who likes to write outdoors, has returned with "The Seven," a hip-hop adaptation of Aeschylus' "Seven Against Thebes," which opens on Sunday at the New York Theater Workshop.

title: Child's Opera According to Sendak: Send In the Bullies and Milk
description: If the life of Maurice Sendak were a Maurice Sendak picture book, it would open with a busy two-page spread, done in the dark, crosshatched style he has sometimes used, of a sickly, unhappy Brooklyn childhood: brooding parents, a World War II recruiting poster, a scary image of Hitler and, over in the corner, a pair of burglars scuttling away with the Lindbergh baby  an image that haunted Mr. Sendak in his early years. In Disney style, which the very young Sendak used to imitate, the kidnappers wear great big shoes with little white squares to indicate a shine.

title: Briefs: EU reviewing complaints on new Microsoft system
Putin Considers Inviting Hamas Leaders to Moscow
description: MADRID, Feb. 9 - Pulling away from an agreed American and European policy, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said Thursday that he was considering inviting the newly victorious leaders of the radical Palestinian Islamic group Hamas to Moscow to discuss solutions to the conflict in the Middle East.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COOPER, DOROTHY M.
description: COOPER--Dorothy M. of Elizabeth, on Wednesday, February 8, 2006 at her residence. Beloved wife of the late David Cooper in 1967. Devoted mother and mother-inlaw of Betsy Cooper, MD, and devoted son-in-law Barton Penn and Barbara Cooper Mandell. Loving grandmother of David and Iris Mandell, and Holly and Harris Penn. Information call Bernheim-Apter - Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel @ 800938-6372. Memorial contributions to Emily's List.

description: Vintage Work Hasted Hunt 529 West 20th Street, Chelsea Through Feb. 18

title: Ex-Press Aide For NASA Offers Defense
description: George C. Deutsch, the young NASA press aide who resigned on Tuesday amid claims that he had tried to keep the agency's top climate scientist from speaking publicly about global warming, defended himself publicly yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHULBACK, JULES
description: SCHULBACK - Jules. Died peacefully on February 8 at 93 years of age. Devoted husband to Edith for 59 years. Loving father to daughters Eve Schulback and Helen Siegler and son-in-law Steve. Adoring grandfather to Rayna, Bonnie and Nomi Joy and great grandchildren Arin, Buster and Oscar. He was a blessing in our lives. Funeral Friday, 12 noon at Plaza Funeral Home, 630 Amsterdam Ave at 91st St, NYC. Donations may be sent to American Committee for Shaare Zedek Hospital, 49 W. 45th St, Suite 1100, NYC, 10036.

title: Police warn tourists in a pay wage dispute
National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Former Official Convicted
description: Carroll Fisher, the former state insurance commissioner, was convicted by a state court jury in Oklahoma City of embezzlement and perjury. Mr. Fisher, 66, was found guilty of converting to his personal use a $1,000 campaign contribution that he did not report on state ethics forms. The jury recommended a three-year prison sentence and $20,000 in fines for Mr. Fisher, who resigned in 2004 after his indictment and subsequent impeachment by the Oklahoma House. STEVE BARNES (NYT)

title: A Weathered Rocker but Still Unbowed
Art in Review; Jo Smail
description: Axis Gallery 453 West 17th Street, Chelsea Through March 4

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Hit All-Time High in 2005
description: The United States trade deficit jumped nearly 18 percent in 2005, the government reported today, hitting its fourth consecutive record as consumer demand for imports increased and energy prices soared.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Eni Sees Gas Crisis If Cold Weather Continues
description: Italy's gas shortages will reach crisis levels if cold temperatures persist, reducing strategic reserves to historically low levels, the head of Italy's biggest gas and oil company, Eni, said. Another 15 days of cold weather will turn Italy's gas situation into a "red alert," Eni's chief executive, Paolo Scaroni, told journalists from Il Messaggero, which published his comments yesterday. Gianni di Giovanni, a company spokesman, confirmed the remarks. Eni, based in Rome, said almost 4 percent of the gas it requested in January from Gazprom of Russia was not delivered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HANDELL, ADA WINN

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Ruling In Satmar Leadership Case
description: A state judge intervened in the power struggle between two brothers who seek to lead one of the largest Hasidic groups in New York, ruling yesterday that supporters of the older brother have a legitimate claim to control the group's business affairs. At stake is the political leadership of the Satmar Hasidim -- a voting bloc of more than 50,000 -- and control of a vast network of real estate and social services. The ruling, by Acting Justice Stewart A. Rosenwasser of State Supreme Court in Orange County, addressed a question of access to a cemetery in Monroe. But to decide the issue, he wrote that he must first resolve the question of which faction rightfully controls corporate decision-making. He ruled that a close supporter of the older brother, Aaron Teitelbaum, was the legitimate president of the religious corporation. MICHAEL BRICK (NYT)

title: The Hotel Man Who's Expanding the Javits Center
description: NATURALLY, the Hotel Association of New York City resides at a ritzy address, 320 Park Avenue, just opposite the turrets of St. Bartholomew's and cater-cornered from the gilt-embossed Waldorf-Astoria. Great curb appeal. Announce one's ultimate destination -- the wood-paneled sanctum of Joseph E. Spinnato -- to the security guard in the imposing lobby, and he gives a knowing nod: "Hmm, you're going to see the big dog."

title: Two Moguls Hopefuls: One Steely, One Sparky
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 9 - Looking steely and serious, Hannah Kearney leaned toward her microphone at the first news conference for the United States Olympic moguls team here and explained how it felt to win the Olympic trials two months ago.

title: Official Resigns Public TV Post
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 - The top television executive at the Corporation for Public Broadcasting announced on Thursday that he would be stepping down. This is the latest in a string of departures of officials and consultants who played central roles in an effort by conservatives to bring what they viewed as more balance to public television and radio.

title: South Koreans Visit Intel With Questions
description: South Korean regulators have questioned some of Intel's employees as part of an investigation of its marketing and rebate programs, the company said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Charged With Promoting Under-Age Prostitution
description: A man who prosecutors say is a member of the Bloods street gang was charged yesterday with kidnapping a 15-year-old runaway and forcing her into prostitution, according to Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. The man, Troy Siddons, 20, of South Jamaica, was charged with first-degree kidnapping and other offenses. Mr. Brown said that Mr. Siddons, known as Drip, threatened the girl, a runaway from the Bronx, with a pistol, choked her and beat her to force her into prostitution at local hotels and a street corner frequented by prostitutes. He said the police seized a gun and ammunition from Mr. Siddons's apartment. Mr. Brown said the problem of child prostitution is growing in the city; last year, 150 girls under 17 were arrested for it.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Weapons Found In City Worker's Van
description: A city transportation worker who crashed his minivan into a pole on Staten Island late Wednesday night had an arsenal of weapons as well as cocaine in his car, the authorities said. The man, Glenn Kittel, 45, who works as a traffic device maintainer, was taken to Staten Island North Hospital for treatment of his injuries. When looking through his car, the police found two loaded handguns, three assault rifles, six other firearms, 40 assorted knives, including a samurai sword, and cocaine and prescription drugs, said the Staten Island district attorney, Daniel M. Donovan Jr. Investigators are seeking a warrant to search Mr. Kittel's Staten Island home, and he is expected to be arraigned in the hospital when he recovers from his injuries, the authorities said. KAREEM FAHIM (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Central Bank Governor Sees Price Gains
description: Toshihiko Fukui, the head of Japan's central bank, said core consumer prices would show clear gains in January and after, signaling that the bank is getting closer to ending its policy of pumping cash into the economy and holding rates near zero. Mr. Fukui made his remarks to reporters in Tokyo. The bank's board decided earlier to keep the target for reserves made available to lenders at 30 trillion yen ($252 billion) to 35 trillion yen, six times the level in March 2001.

title: Ex-Bush aide disputes late Katrina warning

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Support For Plan To Ordain Women As Bishops
description: The Most Rev. Rowan Williams, the archbishop of Canterbury, secured strong support within the fractious Church of England for a plan that could lead to the ordination of women as bishops. The plan, which could take several years to put into effect, was backed by the General Synod, the Church of England's governing body, in a compromise that would allow dissenting parishes to retain male-only bishops. He was handcuffed at the Philadelphia airport, strip-searched, jailed overnight and sent back to Europe to correct an omission in his travel papers.

title: 36 Hours in Grand Forks, N.D.
description: NORTH DAKOTA in the winter -- cold, you betcha. But in Grand Forks, a town of about 50,000 closer to Winnipeg than it is to Minneapolis, winter is not a forbidding season. There's plenty to do outdoors if you're up for it, but because Grand Forks is home to the University of North Dakota and its more than 13,000 students, there's a surprising number of things to do indoors as well. The people are remarkably friendly, perhaps the result of working together to hold back the Red River of the North, which last flooded in 1997 and would have destroyed the city were it not for the legions of hyperorganized volunteer sandbaggers. And while a majority of the inhabitants trace their ancestry to Norway or Germany, the Forks has grown more diverse with the increasing number of university students from overseas. Finally, consider the joke that Grand Forks played on Dave Barry when he ridiculed the city's efforts to promote tourism. Lured to the Forks by a postcard-writing campaign, he was the guest of honor at an official ceremony in 2002-- in which a municipal sewage pump station was named after him. The plaque at the site reads "Dave Barry Lift Station No. 16." NEAL KARLEN

title: Death Is Not Taking a Holiday (He Is a Dedicated Workaholic)
description: From "Rebel Without a Cause" to "Donnie Darko," American cinema loves killing teenagers, and no one has had more fun with the motif than the brains, so to speak, behind the "Final Destination" franchise. These enjoyably ridiculous movies are premised on a lunatic determinism: having survived a spectacular accident thanks to the intervention of a precognitive hottie, the characters find themselves hunted down by Death. This death force is evidently a major control freak who doesn't care to have his "design" messed with. Judging from the preposterously complex accidents he devises to finish his work, the guy would seem to be a fan of Rube Goldberg and the chain-reaction classic "The Way Things Go," or maybe just bored.

title: The Listings: Feb. 10 - Feb. 16; 'PITTSBURGH: FROM THE HEART OF STEELTOWN'
description: It's a happy accident that this Jazz at Lincoln Center minifestival arrives in the lingering afterglow of Super Bowl XL, which yielded the first Pittsburgh Steelers championship since their glory days a quarter-century ago. "Pittsburgh: From the Heart of Steeltown" is the latest in a series of concert events celebrating the jazz legacy of American cities, by way of Wynton Marsalis, the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra and a handful of special guests. It's a simple and effective premise for the kind of repertory work that the Lincoln Center orchestra does best; performing at the Rose Theater, it will tackle crisp, serious arrangements united by theme rather than style. The evening's Pittsburgh-reared guest stars will be Steve Nelson, a patiently exploratory vibraphonist, and Jeff Watts, known as Tain, a brilliantly locomotive drummer. Some of the Steel City's more famous jazz heroes, like the pianist Earl Hines, nicknamed Fatha, and the composer and pianist Billy Strayhorn, will be represented in the program's repertory. (The absence of living legends like the guitarist George Benson and the pianist Ahmad Jamal is a shortcoming that Mr. Marsalis, in his capacity as M.C., should manage to overcome.) A smaller and more single-minded tribute, in memory of another Pittsburgh native, the tenor saxophonist Stanley Turrentine (above), who died in 2000, will run simultaneously in the Allen Room. Eric Alexander and Robert Stewart will handle tenor saxophone duties, and the rhythm section will consist of Gene Ludwig on Hammond B3 organ, Dave Stryker on guitar and Grady Tate on drums. Appropriately, the music will recall a time just before the Steelers reigned supreme. (Thursday through Feb. 18 at 8 p.m., Frederick P. Rose Hall, Jazz at Lincoln Center, 60th Street and Broadway, (212) 721-6500, www.jalc.org; $30 to $130.)

title: The Listings: Feb. 10 - Feb. 16; MARISS JANSONS
description: He may look like the corporate guy next door, and he has no patience for showy theatrics on the podium, but this probing Latvian-born conductor has quietly risen to the top rungs of his profession. After stints in Pittsburgh and Oslo (the latter for a rare 21 years), Mr. Jansons, above, now leads the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra, as well as the prized Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra in Amsterdam, which he will take to Carnegie Hall next week for the first time since assuming his post in the fall of 2004. On Tuesday, he leads Shostakovich's fabled Seventh Symphony, written for a Nazi-besieged Leningrad during World War II. Mr. Jansons can be counted on for insight and authority in this repertory, as he worked for almost two decades with the Leningrad (St. Petersburg) Philharmonic and has recently finished recording a complete cycle of Shostakovich's 15 symphonies. (The last installment is due out in October on EMI.) On Wednesday, the orchestra will switch gears to tackle Strauss's celebrate-myself tone poem "Ein Heldenleben" and Haydn's "Surprise" Symphony. (Tuesday and Wednesday at 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800; $32 to $110.)

title: Corrections

title: Extolling Newark's Successes, With Few Hints About Future

title: 'The Fallen Idol'
description: Graham Greene liked to say that he preferred "The Fallen Idol" (1948) to the more famous "The Third Man" (1949) because it was more a writer's film than a director's. It's hard not to wonder if he actually favored "The Fallen Idol," which he adapted from his story "The Basement Room" and was, like "The Third Man," directed by Carol Reed, because Orson Welles wasn't on hand, grabbing the spotlight. Whatever the case, while Greene is probably in a minority in preferring "The Fallen Idol," this eccentric curio certainly has its appeal. The streamlined plot involves a young boy, his family's butler and the butler's secrets, and follows the original story in outline, deviating in detail (the boy in the film has a pet snake), if not dark tone. Ralph Richardson plays Baines, a butler for an embassy family in London who works alongside his wife (the ferocious Sonia Dresdel), but loves another (Michle Morgan). The film opens just as the ambassador departs on a short trip, leaving his only son, Phillipe (Bobby Henrey, above), alone with the Baineses and their violently unhappy marriage. Beautifully shot by the French cinematographer Georges Prinal (whose credits include Cocteau's "Blood of a Poet"), the film soon evolves from a claustrophobic domestic affair into a mordantly discomfiting look at the betrayal of innocence. In his story, Greene writes that the boy "didn't understand a thing; he was caught up in other people's darkness." Reed captures both the writer's intentions and the child's panicked isolation in a scene that finds Phillipe fleeing through city streets as steeped in shadow and dread as those in the noirs of Anthony Mann. As the film's putatively happy (and strange) windup makes it clear, when childhood ends, there really is no place left to run. ("The Fallen Idol" runs today through Feb. 23 at Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, west of Avenue of the Americas, South Village, (212) 727-8110.)

description: At 7:58 p.m. on Tuesday, John Faso, a Republican candidate for governor of New York, will appear live on every television market in the state for 90 seconds to declare his candidacy and discuss his agenda: to cut taxes and state spending. The action is costing $104,000, more than 10 percent of the money that Mr. Faso has on hand. The candidate, a former assemblyman who is trying to attract more news media attention and donations, said he was buying the time "because we really need to revitalize grass-roots politics in New York." Timing the broadcast for Valentine's Day was a coincidence, he said, and a plus. "I hope that this will be a vibrant topic of conversations for sweethearts all across New York," he said. PATRICK D. title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: 7 Afghans Freed From Guantnamo
description: Seven Afghans released from American detention in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, were freed on their arrival in Kabul. The men, who had been held for three years or more, said they were aware of a widespread hunger strike among detainees at the base but they said they had not taken part. One, Sharbat Khan, 36, said American guards "insulted the Holy Koran and all of us prisoners started a demonstration and they used a kind of gas to make us calm down." Another prisoner, Khudaidad, said his guards would withhold medicines at times and would sometimes serve bad food as a punishment. CARLOTTA GALL (NYT)

title: Co-op Boards and Back Elevators of the Soul
description: Good satire requires great teeth. It is the art form made for nipping, biting and gnawing on corruption and self-importance. And when the subject offers such promising raw meat as internecine warfare among the members of the co-op board of a Fifth Avenue apartment building, theatergoers have every right to expect a banquet of happy and carnivorous chewing.

title: PSA quits bidding war for P&O
The Doctor Won't See You Now, and an Era Will Be Gone
description: A PRESCRIPTION pad nestled in a side pocket of his jacket. A pen poked out from the breast pocket. As ever, Dr. Charles P. Vialotti was dressed for work. That was a couple of days ago. A career ago.

title: As host to G-8, Russia's qualifications are in doubt
Wieden & Kennedy Awarded Old Spice Line of Products
description: The Procter & Gamble Company has expanded its relationship with Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., awarding the agency its largest assignment to date, the worldwide creative duties for the Old Spice line of men's products. Spending was estimated at more than $100 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAW, ESTHER
description: SHAW--Esther, 84. On February 9, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Risa Silverglate, Karen Shaw, and Deborah Shindell. title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Study On Warming
description: The increase in temperatures in the 20th century was the greatest and most widespread warming in the past 1,200 years, according to a study in the journal Science. The researchers, at the University of East Anglia in England drew that conclusion by analyzing climate data from sources like tree rings, fossil shells and ice core records at 14 locations around the world.

description: In a land of great divides, none are so graphic as the Rio Grande. Its waters demarcate need and desire. Dreams are born or die at the river's edge. Mexicans risk everything sacred to them, from proximity to families to their lives, for the opportunity to cross north.

He is Jim Silver. (Chris Byrne is a different toy-industry analyst.)
