description: CAIRO, Feb. 10 A The first intact tomb discovered in 84 years at the Valley of the Kings near Luxor, Egypt, was formally opened today. It was discovered by a team of American archaeologists a few days ago and is just 16 feet from King Tutankhamen's tomb.

In this age of wondrous electronic entertainment, it remains as popular as ever, and now it is being taken seriously by the sorts of people who were once concerned exclusively with the higher reaches of artistic culture. Witness R. Crumb's inclusion in last year's Carnegie International.

It is the dividing line between the post-cold-war world, which we have known since 1989 -- one of expanding democracy and free markets -- and a post-post-cold-war world, which is unknown but almost certain to be a much less stable, prosperous and benign place.

A tiny Web camera sat atop the computer, beaming live images of him to Nour's home screen across Baghdad.

title: A new generation shows elegance and sophistication
Table XII
description: Is it really possible? Do my eyes deceive me? I scan the menu at Table XII, a relatively new Italian restaurant in Midtown Manhattan, and I don't see a single crudo dish. I don't see a salumi platter of any kind. It's as if a whole chapter of trendy dining never happened. And there, in the realm of desserts, I spy something that makes me wonder anew if I'm hallucinating. Tiramisu? Here and now? It's a blast from the past, when it loomed as large on the city's sweetscape as the molten chocolate cake does today.

Her watercolors and oils are still the subject of traveling shows, and a leading American art historian, William H. Gerdts, wrote a book about her in 2001.

Grandfather of Dr. Grant and Tia and Dr. Evan Disick and Paul Schaffer. Great grandfather of Noah Disick. Brother of Monroe, Gladys and the late Horace. Loved by his step family, Greg, Mindy, Andrew and Jessica White. Predeceased by his dear wife Beverly. A man who did it all and loved everything he did. He leaves a part of himself in all whose heart he touched. Funeral service will be held Friday February 10, at 12:30 pm at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY.

The United States has been dubbed the World Oppressor, and Israel has always been at the top of the enemies list.

description: COPENHAGEN, Feb. 10 A Flemming Rose, the Danish editor whose decision to publish cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad helped provoke weeks of fury in the Muslim world, said in an interview today that he was leaving his newspaper on indefinite vacation following a series of recent mistakes.

title: The Listings: Feb. 10 - Feb. 16; 'FRIANDISES'
description: Choreographers are often drawn to the same pieces of music -- the Bach solo cello suites and Stravinsky's "Sacre du Printemps" are just two examples among many -- but it's hard to think of a musical commission that has been specifically made to be used by more than one choreographer. That's the case with a new composition, "Friandises," (French for sweets) by Christopher Rouse, commissioned by the Juilliard School and the New York City Ballet, which will perform Peter Martins's ballet -- named after the score -- for the first time tonight. (Adam Houghland's "Watershed," to the same score, will be performed by the Juilliard Dance Ensemble, beginning on Feb. 22.) "I think it was cheaper for everyone that way," said Mr. Rouse (above right, with Mr. Martins), an acclaimed composer who also teaches at Juilliard. Mr. Rouse had long wanted to write a piece of music specifically for dance, after seeing a number of his works used by choreographers. He knew Mr. Martins, who had made a powerful duo, "The Infernal Machine," to his score of the same title, in 2002, and they began to talk about the possibility just as Juilliard raised the idea of a commission for its centenary celebration. "We agreed that it would be interesting to have a co-commission," Mr. Martins said. "Although quite frankly, I wasn't thrilled at the idea of having Adam and myself doing pieces at the same time, because it makes it competitive. But then I decided not to worry about it." Although Mr. Rouse has subsequently seen rehearsals, he had little contact with the choreographers while creating the score; he simply told them that it would contain five movements of around five minutes each. City Ballet's musical director, Andrea Quinn, is conducting both the City Ballet and Juilliard performances, and Mr. Rouse is leaving issues of tempo up to her. "I'm staying out of it," he said. "I did my thing, and now they will do theirs." (Tonight at 8, Wednesday at 7.30 p.m., Feb. 23 at 8 p.m., and Feb. 25 at 2p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 870-5570 or www.nycballet.com; $30 to $86.)

title: Home, Home in the Million-Dollar Range
description: WHERE cows grazed and grizzlies wandered in the timber-draped mountains in southwestern Montana, next door to Yellowstone National Park, Chet Huntley, the NBC News anchor, envisioned schussing skiers. In 1973, he broke ground for a ski resort called Big Sky, a name inspired by "The Big Sky" by A. B. Guthrie Jr., a novel whose title had become the nickname of Montana.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Judge Criticizes State Over Confinement Rules
description: A judge rebuked the State Legislature yesterday for being slow to pass a law that would allow the confinement in mental institutions of mentally ill sex offenders who posed a threat to society. The scolding came as the judge, Jacqueline W. Silbermann of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, ordered individual hearings to determine whether to release 10 more sex offenders who had been transferred from various prisons to Kirby Forensic Psychiatric Center after completing their sentences. As in a previous decision, now stayed by appeal, in which 12 other inmates were released in November, she said that the sex offenders had been denied their constitutional right of notice and to be heard. "In the absence of legislation enacted to address the situation," she said, "this court again is put in the untenable position of attempting to 'do justice' by applying existing statutes to fact patterns clearly not anticipated" by current law. ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS (NYT)

description: The following is a transcript of Michael D. Brown's opening statement during a senate hearing today on the government's response to Hurricane Katrina.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COVER, FRANKLIN
description: COVER--Franklin. 77, died peacefully at the Actors Fund Home on February 3rd 2006. An actor whose career spanned six decades, he created countless roles in regional theatre, Broadway, television and film and is best known for playing Tom Willis on The Jeffersons. His talent, infectious humor and his generous loving spirit will linger in our memories and our hearts. He is survived by his wife Mary, his children Bradford & Susan and his grandson Maxwell. Services will be held Tuesday, February 14th at 11AM at The Church of the Resurrection, 115 E. 74 St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Actors Fund of America.

title: Child's Opera According to Sendak: Send In the Bullies and Milk
description: IF the life of Maurice Sendak were a Maurice Sendak picture book, it would open with a busy two-page spread, done in the dark, crosshatched style he has sometimes used, of a sickly, unhappy Brooklyn childhood: brooding parents, a World War II recruiting poster, a scary image of Hitler and, over in the corner, a pair of burglars scuttling away with the Lindbergh baby -- an image that haunted Mr. Sendak in his early years. In Disney style, which the very young Sendak used to imitate, the kidnappers wear great big shoes with little white squares to indicate a shine.

description: BOULOGNE-BILLANCOURT, France, Feb. 9 - Carlos Ghosn became perhaps the auto industry's most celebrated Mr. Fix-It with his remarkable turnaround of Nissan Motor of Japan.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 - The disgraced lobbyist Jack Abramoff told a magazine editor in recent days that he had met with President Bush many times and was invited to the president's Texas ranch for a gathering of campaign contributors in 2003, the editor said Thursday.

title: Amid the Cocktail-Party Banter, a Spiritual Crisis
description: For soft-spoken, troubled Robbie (Brandon Wolcott), just speaking appears to require a Herculean effort. Ask him a question and he tenses up; his face, filled with anxiety, turns toward his navel. He stammers, evades, but most of all he says, "I don't know." The lead character of David Foley's "Paradise," an articulate drama about an inarticulate young man, Robbie seems ready to snap for so long that when he does, it's almost something of a relief.

The moves possibly clear the way for passage of the legislation, which has been bottled up in a dispute over civil liberties.

description: A drawn and weary Wayne Gretzky, hockey's Great One and now the coach of the Phoenix Coyotes, said last night that he did not participate in a betting ring that New Jersey authorities said was financed by his friend and assistant, Rick Tocchet.

description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 9 - The scandal's hard edges have faded in time, the details etched into Olympic lore under the phrase "French judge." But the figure-skating scandal that sidetracked the Salt Lake Olympics four years ago will reverberate here Friday, when a new Winter Games begin.

Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENE, ELIZABETH IVORY
description: GREENE -- Elizabeth Ivory. Born in New York on January 17, 1929, Liz died on January 30. She was the daughter of the illustrator P.V.E. Ivory and Elizabeth Post Price. Liz was a life-long downtown New Yorker who in later years frequently declared that she got a nosebleed if she ventured north of 14th street. She attended City and Country School and Washington Irving High School and graduated from Bennington College. After college she worked as a commercial sculptor and was actively involved in real estate and local politics. She later worked for the Manhattan office of the Board of Elections. Her husband, James Benno Greene, Jr, an executive vice president at Chase Manhattan, died in 1968. She leaves behind a daughter, Elizabeth, and son-in-law, John, of Woodstock, CT; a son, James and his wife Christine, of Houston, Texas; a son, Edgar and his wife Pilar, of Manhattan; four grand-daughters and a grandson. A private memorial party will be held at the Salmagundi Club. She was an enthusiastic supporter of protecting the street trees of the city and donations in her name to Trees New York, 51 Church Street, Suite 1412A NY, NY 10007 are most warmly welcomed.

title: Investing: Crazy? Like a fox

Arts, Briefly; Grammys? What Grammys? 'American Idol' Rolls
description: If Kelly Clarkson's "American Idol" luster had rubbed off on the Grammy Awards, she might have prevented the ceremony's broadcast from achieving its second-lowest ratings ever. The telecast, during which Ms. Clarkson, below, the first "American Idol" winner, won two Grammy Awards, drew an estimated 17.56 million viewers in prime time, down from last year's low-rated telecast. According to Nielsen's estimates, those ratings for CBS were good enough for only a second-place finish, behind Fox, in total viewers and adults 18 to 49. "American Idol," which delivered an estimated 28.29 million viewers, fueled Fox's victory. During the 8 p.m. time period, "Idol" beat the Grammys' first hour by more than 13 million viewers. And at 9 p.m., the awards ceremony was challenged by ABC's "Lost" (18.78 million). The island mystery featured a power play by Sawyer (Josh Holloway), who turned the testosterone tables on Jack (Matthew Fox) and Locke (Terry O'Quinn). With CBS's usual broadcast of "CSI: New York" out of the mix, NBC's "Law & Order" was able to bring in its best ratings since the end of September, with an audience of 14.56 million at 10 p.m.

A beautiful woman whose legacy will live on through the many lives she touched. Wake at Montera Funeral Home, 1848 Westchester Ave., Bronx, N.Y., Sat & Sun.2-6PM. Memorial service at St. Peter's Church, 2500 Westchester Ave, Bronx, N.Y. at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Edith Del Valle Fund, Alumni & Friends of La Guardia H.S., POB 231485, NY, NY 10023.

title: ViewPoints: Are you going to eat that?
They Chose to Go Crazy for Enlightenment
description: If you're rich, you're eccentric; if you're poor, you're crazy. That's the unspoken view of unconventional behavior in our society, though it wasn't the one held by other people at other times. In ancient India and Tibet, kings and paupers had craziness in common and acted crazy in similar ways.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "People know that I don't like to speak of myself. But I think the first thing that people appreciate about me is that Prval has not stolen. Prval is not an assassin. Prval respects freedom. Prval is frank and honest."

title: 36 Hours in Grand Forks, N.D.
description: NORTH DAKOTA in the winter  cold, you betcha. But in Grand Forks, a town of about 50,000 closer to Winnipeg than it is to Minneapolis, winter is not a forbidding season. There's plenty to do outdoors if you're up for it, but because Grand Forks is home to the University of North Dakota and its more than 13,000 students, there's a surprising number of things to do indoors as well. The people are remarkably friendly, perhaps the result of working together to hold back the Red River of the North, which last flooded in 1997 and would have destroyed the city were it not for the legions of hyperorganized volunteer sandbaggers. And while a majority of the inhabitants trace their ancestry to Norway or Germany, the Forks has grown more diverse with the increasing number of university students from overseas. Finally, consider the joke that Grand Forks played on Dave Barry when he ridiculed the city's efforts to promote tourism. Lured to the Forks by a postcard-writing campaign, he was the guest of honor at an official ceremony in 2002 in which a municipal sewage pump station was named after him. The plaque at the site reads "Dave Barry Lift Station No. 16."

title: The Cleanup Continues
description: It's not about the money. After the settlement yesterday between regulators and the insurance giant American International Group, a lot of attention focused on the dollars: $1.6 billion. It is an impressive figure. But the money should not obscure the higher goal of an honest corporate environment.

title: The Davis Cup Is the Prize, but the Persona Is Roddick
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Feb. 9  It doesn't seem to matter whether Andy Roddick is winning or losing because wherever he goes, he tends to be a crowd favorite.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Istanbul Bomb Kills One And Wounds 16
description: An explosion believed to have been caused by a bomb tore through at an Internet cafe in Istanbul, killing a 21-year-old man and injuring 16 other people, including 6 policemen, the Anatolian News Agency reported. Officers from a police station a block way frequent the cafe, in the Bayrampasa district, in their free time, the Istanbul police chief, Celalettin Cerrah, said. A group calling itself the Kurdistan Liberation Hawks and believed to have links to outlawed separatist Kurdish groups claimed responsibility. SEBNEM ARSU (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST

Agrees to $1.64 Billion Settlement With Regulators Over Insurance Practices Apologizing for deceptive business practices extending as far back as two decades ago, American International Group, the global insurance giant, reached a $1.64 billion settlement with federal and state securities and insurance regulators. The company also agreed to changes that will soften its historically combative approach to business, a trademark of its ousted chief executive, Maurice R. Greenberg. [Page C1.]

title: By George, We Think Hes Got It
description: Those of you who were worried that George Clooney, poor lonely soul that he is, was going to show solo for the Oscars, can relax. Although St. George has been looking a bit rugged of late, apparently a former girlfriend has taken pity on his inability to find a date and agreed to serve as a beard on his feckless night life. And while were at it, it should be mentioned that his publicist debunked rumors that he has been dating someone who shows up at awards shows in her underwear.

title: Munich Busts a Move
description: The Bagger noted that Munich was changing up its pitch in ads and now OscarWatch notes that its promoters appear to be playing for all the marbles:

title: New Yorks Secret Oscar Fetish
description: The Oscars are one of the few times of the year when New Yorkers sense of smug self-regard can be challenged a bit. They respond by making fun of the event and those involved, of course, suggesting that it is a trivial event attended by vacuous people, which of course defines most of the nightlife in New York, but lets not go there. The only way New Yorkers can possibly survive not being at the absolute epicenter of the universe for a week is to maintain a claim on the homies who are there. In this funhouse world, both Ang Lee and Heath Ledger are New Yorkers to the core. If they are, lets hear em give a shoutout to Queens instead of their entertainment lawyers.

title: The Latest Count on the Pledge Drive
description: With one-third of the pledges for Bill OReilly counted, the total stands at $215,003. Bill, all I can say is, people really want to see you out of your studio and reporting real atrocities.

title: Greetings from the Red Carpet
description: When stars step out of their limos and tug on their frocks to make sure that everything is covered, they will see a new face smiling in greeting. Army Archerd of Variety has stepped aside and the honor/burden will now fall to Robert Osborne, the author of The Rambling Reporter column and a host on Turner Classic Movies. All hail the new greeter, but lets not forget the Bagger is a bigtime TV host, except his show is strictly available on the web and has the ratings of a night lite. And that he has a newspaper voice and a radio face. And that when he greets people, they generally mistake him for a homeless man in pursuit of spare change.

title: Into the Long Dark Part of the Night
description: Speaking of Oscar analogs, did you notice that the Grammys offered a few cautionary lessons of their own? No. 1, the biggest news of the night seemed to be that one of the attendees showed up in her underwear. It is also worth noting that contests may be trumping awards in the minds of the American viewer. When a game show full of no-name performers (American Idol) doubles up the audience on the recording industrys night of stars, glamour and hardware, the Bagger has to wonder if people are just plain turned off by the routine. Maybe its good that the Academy is switching it up this year because the same old, same old does not appear to be cutting it. And as the night wore on, the Grammys offered an object lesson in the illusion of momentum, something that is breathlessly invoked come Oscar time. Early in the night, it was all Mariah and Mimi, making it appear as if the divas comeback would include a sweep of the Grammys. But by the end of the night, the smoke had cleared and it was U2 hauling away the most hardware. It is a reminder, one the Bagger will tuck under his pillow and sleep on for the next few weeks, that the story can change, even in the course of a single evening.

title: Courage
description: This week, hundreds of beautifully attired strivers fought for the limelight and their share of attention in one of the most brutally competitive non-contact events there is. But were not talking the Oscars, and were not even talking about the Grammys. Naw, its Fashion Week in New York. Any number of boldface names are pretending that the clothes people are wearing might actually be an important cultural indicator. Earlier in the week, the Bagger went to a Fashion Week party and he was so traumatized he has been sitting in his basement since, wearing sackcloth and speaking only through e-mail. A few years ago, the Bagger had the opportunity to go to Fashion Week trailing Anna Wintour, which is a little like going to the Oscars with Julia Roberts, except Ms. Wintour doesnt do that fake smile thing. He felt as if he had landed on the surface of the moon, surrounded as he was by silly model walks, madly vogue-ing wannabes, and some nasty asides from the carefully attired peanut gallery. Not a long walk from the red carpet at the Kodak, if you catch my drift, including the constant discussion of how courageous this or that designer is.

title: Former C.I.A. Official: The Misuse of Intelligence
description: In the forthcoming March/April issue of Foreign Affairs, Paul R. Pillar  the C.I.A.s senior analyst for the Middle East from 2000 to 2005  writes that the failures and mistakes of the intelligence community did not lead the nation to war with Iraq. The Bush administrations rationale for war, Pillar writes, was based not on weapons of mass destruction but by the desire to shake up the sclerotic power structures of the Middle East and hasten the spread of more liberal politics and economics in the region. Therefore, focusing on the intelligence communitys mistaken belief that Saddam Hussein possessed W.M.D. misses the point, because the intelligence of Iraqi weapons programs did not drive [the administrations] decision to go to war.

Its predicting that new-home sales will slip 8.5 percent to 1.17 million from a record 1.28 million in 2005.

title: A No-Fuss Laptop Cover

It looks for all the world like a leather binder or portfolio, but instead of papers and pads inside, it holds the laptop. You open the portfolio and the laptop lid simultaneously. (Four small round Velcro tabs hold the cover onto the bottom of the laptop, and also make it easy to remove.) You can see what the thing looks like at hardcovercase.com.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Thursday with an article about declines in Iraq's public services and power generation, since the American-led invasion, referred imprecisely in some copies to two categories. They were daily crude oil production (not daily oil production) and daily heating oil production (not daily petroleum production). In some copies the chart also carried an erroneous label for the category of daily crude oil production. The amounts shown were in millions of barrels, not billions.

title: A Long-Buried Tomb Is Opened in Egypt
description: CAIRO, Feb. 10 - The first intact tomb discovered in 84 years at the Valley of the Kings near Luxor, Egypt, was formally opened Friday. The tomb, discovered by a team of American archaeologists a few days ago, is just a few feet from King Tutankhamen's tomb.

description: As digital electronics have invaded Toyland, putting video projectors and cellphones into the hands of 7- year-olds, companies that cater to preschoolers have deliberately sat on the sidelines, determined to hold up the wall between adult technology and children's play.

description: A survey released yesterday by city housing officials supplied factual backing for what many renters already know: even as the household income of average New Yorkers has fallen, it has become harder to find an affordable apartment in the city.

title: Awkward Start for Canada's New Leader
description: TORONTO, Feb. 10 - Prime Minister Stephen Harper has gotten off to a shaky start in his first week in office, facing a rash of criticism for three cabinet appointments that appeared to compromise his past positions on making government more democratic and ethical.

title: U.S. Cites Rise in Violence Along Border With Mexico
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 - Mexican criminal syndicates are stepping up their attacks on American agents patrolling the border as officials of the Homeland Security Department intensify efforts to stem the flow of immigrants and drugs into the United States, American officials said this week.

title: 18 Killed as Militants Fight Russian Force in Town
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 10 - A clash between armed militants and security officers in a village in the Stavropol region of southwestern Russia ended Friday evening after more than 24 hours of sporadic fighting, with 12 militants and at least 6 security officers dead.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Official Says Iraq Data Was Distorted
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 - A C.I.A. veteran who oversaw intelligence assessments about the Middle East from 2000 to 2005 on Friday accused the Bush administration of ignoring or distorting the prewar evidence on a broad range of issues related to Iraq in its effort to justify the American invasion of 2003.

title: Norman E. Shumway, 83, Who Made the Heart Transplant a Standard Operation, Dies
description: Dr. Norman E. Shumway, the Stanford cardiac surgeon who in 1968 performed the United States' first successful human heart transplant and later made the operation a standard procedure after virtually all other surgeons had abandoned it, died yesterday at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 83.

description: And on the eighth day, God said, Let there be a thermostat for the heavens and the earth, and God saw that it was good. And God said, Let no man adjust it more than 2 degrees Fahrenheit, or 1 degree Celsius, until the end of time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINSTEIN, SOLOMON, JD, LLM
description: WEINSTEIN--Solomon, JD, LLM, 90. Of Haworth, NJ, passed away on Thursday, February 9, 2006. Loving husband of the late Selma of 62 years. Devoted father of Neal (Mildy) and Marci. Beloved grandpa of Jillian and Russell. Dear brother of Lou and Herb. A graduate of NYU and NYU Law School, he was a practicing attorney for 66 years, right up to the time of his death. A member of the NY and NJ Bars and several Federal courts, including the Supreme Court of the US. A born leader, he was the second president of Temple Beth El of Northern Valley and later, four-term president of the then Jewish Welfare Council (Federation). A founding and longtime member of the Board of Directors of The Frisch School, Paramus. A veteran of WW II, was a 1st Lt. in AAF in Europe. He quietly and with great dignity and humor enriched the lives of all who knew him. He will be missed by his loving family, associates and friends. Services at Temple Beth El, 221 Schraalenburgh Road, Closter, on Sunday, 1PM. Shiva will be observed at the family home, 7-10PM through Tuesday. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Temple Beth El Library Fund, or the American Heart Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOWELL, TRACY
description: HOWELL--Tracy. The Bachmann-Strauss Dystonia & Parkinson Foundation is deeply saddened by the passing of Tracy Howell, wife of Dr. Michele Tagliati, mother of Isabella and Luca. In addition to her own professional career she was a strong supporter of her husband's work in movement disorders and his association with our Foundation. Bonnie Strauss President Helen Miller Executive Director

In his yellow shorts, white golf shirt and prescription aviator-style sunglasses, he looked like a cross between Daffy Duck and Mister Magoo.

title: General Says Training of Iraqi Troops Suffered From Poor Planning and Staffing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 - The American general in charge of training the new Iraqi military after Baghdad fell says the Bush administration's strategy to use those forces to replace departing American troops was hobbled from its belated start by poor prewar planning and insufficient staffing and equipment.

title: Calhoun Is Having Trouble Beating This Press
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 10 - At 63, recently inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame, Jim Calhoun has produced two national championships at Connecticut and may shortly deliver a third. Yet he remains a popular and a polarizing figure, and another potential valedictory season has also become in the Connecticut news media a referendum on his character.

title: Power Plant Would Reuse Carbon Dioxide
description: Subsidiaries of BP and Edison International said yesterday that they were planning to build a power plant that would run on oil residues, and that 90 percent of the carbon dioxide would be captured and pumped into an oil field, where it would help push more oil to the surface.

title: Movement That Gets Its Cue From Heady Matters
description: The notes for Todd Williams's latest program, seen Wednesday at the Ailey Citigroup Theater, were an indication that his dances wouldn't exactly make for a carefree night at the theater: Hinduism, Surrealism, Jung, oh my! For Mr. Williams, a silky, remarkable dancer -- his performance history includes more than a decade with New York City Ballet and the Stephen Petronio Company -- choreography is a fairly cerebral affair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KARGER, STEWART J.
description: KARGER--Stewart J. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Scarsdale, NY on February 10, 2006, peacefully at home. He is survived by his beloved wife, Joyce, daughter, Lanny Alexander, grandchildren, Nicole Schlesinger, Dori and Rick Acampora, and great-granddaughter, Francesca.

title: University Panel Faults Cloning Co-Author
description: Dr. Gerald P. Schatten, a biologist at the University of Pittsburgh who was involved with Dr. Hwang Woo Suk and his discredited claim to have cloned human cells, was accused yesterday of "research misbehavior" by an investigative panel appointed by the university.

title: France Backs Putin on Speaking to Hamas
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 - France on Friday endorsed Russia's decision to hold talks on the Middle East conflict with Hamas, the radical Islamist Palestinian group, saying the discussion "can contribute to advancing our positions."

title: National Briefing | West: California: Officer Who Made Videos Files A Suit
description: The San Francisco police officer who produced controversial videos that the mayor and the police chief called racist and sexist has sued the Police Department, its chief and the City and County of San Francisco for wages lost during his eight-day suspension in December. The officer, Andrew Cohen, left, and 23 other officers were suspended for their parts in a video. One of Mr. Cohen's lawyers, Michael Rains, said the suit sought back pay, legal fees and a favorable court declaration. CAROLYN MARSHALL (NYT)

title: Auditors Find Huge Fraud in FEMA Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 - Thousands of applicants for federal emergency relief money after Hurricanes Katrina and Rita used duplicate or invalid Social Security numbers or bogus addresses, suggesting that the $2.3 billion program was a victim of extensive fraud, a Congressional auditor will report Monday.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about Toyota's introduction of the Tundra pickup mislabeled the scales reflecting company sales and sales of all pickups in the United States. The sales for Toyota's Tundra, Tacoma and T100 were in thousands of pickups, not millions of dollars. The sales of Toyota's cars and trucks, and of total pickup trucks in the United States were in millions of pickups, not billions of dollars.

title: Mets Hire Henderson As a Tutor For Reyes
description: Rickey Henderson's legs no longer speed around the basepaths, and his batting eye is not as keen.

title: A Wink and a Nod for Lobbying Reform
description: A long string of scandals has raised questions about whether Capitol Hill is really run by the lawmakers or the lobbyists. The public has a right to expect reform, but so far the only sign of change is a new House majority leader -- John Boehner of Ohio, a polished veteran of the big-money nexus who even pays his D.C. rent to a lobbyist-landlord.

title: Photograph Shows Lobbyist at Bush Meeting With Legislators
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 A After weeks in which the White House has declined to release pictures of President Bush with Jack Abramoff, the disgraced lobbyist, the first photograph to be published of the two men shows a small, partly obscured image of Mr. Abramoff looking on from the background as Mr. Bush greets a Texas Indian chief in May 2001.

title: Another Cave-In on the Patriot Act
description: The Patriot Act has been one of the few issues on which Congress has shown backbone lately. Last year, it refused to renew expiring parts of the act until greater civil liberties protections were added. But key members of the Senate have now caved, agreeing to renew these provisions in exchange for only minimal improvements. At a time when the public is growing increasingly concerned about the lawlessness of the Bush administration's domestic spying, the Senate should insist that any reauthorization agreement do more to protect Americans against improper secret searches.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: 2 Killed In Balloon Crash
description: A hot-air balloon carrying 12 passengers on an early morning safari over the Masai Mara National Reserve encountered unexpected strong winds and crashed, killing the British pilot and a Belgian passenger, officials said. Other passengers, from Canada and Belgium, were injured and airlifted to Nairobi Hospital. MARC LACEY (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Data on Iraq Was Distorted, Ex-C.I.A. Official Says Paul R. Pillar, a former C.I.A. official in charge of Middle East intelligence assessments, said the Bush administration had distorted prewar intelligence on Iraq to justify decisions officials had already made. He said that under pressure, analysts had begun to "sugarcoat" their conclusions. PAGE A6

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Prisons Chief Ousted
description: Gov. Jeb Bush dismissed the head of the state prison system, more than a year after federal and state investigators began a corruption inquiry into the agency. Mr. Bush would not explain why he asked for the resignation of the Department of Corrections secretary, James V. Crosby, left. Several employees of the agency have been arrested in the inquiry. And last year, state investigators seized property owned by Mr. Crosby and other agency officials after accusations that inmates had illegally performed work for them. Mr. Bush named James R. McDonough, the director of the Governor's Office of Drug Control, as interim secretary. JOE FOLLICK (NYT)

title: Mozart's Mystery Symphonies
description: Depending on how often you go to concerts, Mozart's last three symphonies at this week's New York Philharmonic subscription concerts might seem too much of a very good thing. Consider that New York has just gotten past John Eliot Gardiner and his Orchestre Rvolutionnaire et Romantique playing Mozart's last three symphonies at Alice Tully Hall and looks ahead to Daniel Barenboim and the Berlin Staatskapelle playing Mozart's last three symphonies over two concerts at Carnegie Hall tonight and tomorrow.

Loved by friends, family, teachers, students and staff. Died at home with his family living independently on his own terms. Memorial donations: Rose Varga Discretionary Fund, PO Box 2072, Ridgecrest, CA 93556. 760-371-9893.

title: Arts, Briefly; Viewers Find Grisly 'CSI' Just Yummy
description: "CSI" issued a warning to viewers on Thursday about the show's mature content. Was it meant to caution them about the image of a disembodied eyeball? Or the autopsied internal organs infected by flesh-eating bacteria? Maybe it was the flashback of a woman gnawing at her own hand to free herself from chains? Hard to say, really. But "CSI" was Thursday's most-watched show, as it nearly always is, with 27.08 million viewers, according to Nielsen estimates. Though ABC's "Dancing With the Stars" edged out CBS's "Survivor" among total viewers at 8 p.m. (19.1 million versus 18.87 million), CBS won this sweeps Thursday over all. Noah Wyle's brief, practically minuscule, appearance on "E.R." (14.15 million) helped NBC place second among 18-to-49-year-olds. Also of note was Fox's "O.C." at 9 p.m., which drew a meager 5.26 million viewers and finished fourth among adults 18 to 49. Is it a given that this former smash hit will return for a fourth season?

title: Pilots Demand $1 Billion if Delta Ends Pensions
description: Pilots at Delta Air Lines, the nation's third-largest airline, are demanding a $1 billion payment should the airline scrap employee pension plans as part of its bankruptcy reorganization.

title: Siblings No Longer Hanging With Father Who Trained Them
description: BARDONECCHIA, Italy, Feb. 10 - Domu and Mero Narita, as they used to be known, were a brother-sister act practically born in midair.

title: 95 Pounds Heavier, Angry Son Faces Mother Who Starved Him
description: CAMDEN, Feb. 10 - Bruce Jackson rose in a packed courtroom here on Friday, 95 pounds heavier and 15 inches taller than he was 27 months ago when he was found rummaging through a neighbor's garbage can looking for food.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side parking regulations in New York City will be suspended on Monday in observance of Lincoln's Birthday, which is tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect. Most courts will be closed, but most government offices will be open. No trash or recyclables will be collected, but trash may be placed outside after 5 p.m. In New Jersey and Connecticut, courts and state offices will be closed.

title: Ariel Sharon Undergoes Emergency Surgery
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 11 - Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, underwent emergency surgery on Saturday after doctors discovered severe damage to his digestive system, and the Hadassah Ein Kerem Hospital said his life was in danger.

title: High School Student Charged in Death of Newborn Daughter
description: PORT JEFFERSON, N.Y., Feb. 10 - An 18-year-old high school senior who handed hospital workers a knapsack containing her dead newborn was charged on Thursday with second-degree manslaughter, the police said.

title: US general charged in My Lai massacre dies at 86
Views of a Sardonic Tortoise, Abroad and in Her Garden
description: Correction Appended

title: A Rant. All 406 Pages of It.
description: A NEW e-book tells a "sordid story" of business fraud, according to one reviewer. The book's author says it is "the largest fraud case in American history."

title: Excerpts From Senate Hearing on Response to Flooding
description: Following are excerpts from the hearing of the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee yesterday on the response to Hurricane Katrina, as provided by the Federal News Service Inc. Among the speakers were Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine; Michael D. Brown, the former director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency; and Senator Norm Coleman, Republican of Minnesota. A complete transcript is at nytimes.com/national.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Ivory Coast: Annan Sends A $3.6 Million Bill For Riots
description: The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, sent President Laurent Gbagbo a letter listing the buildings, equipment and vehicles of the United Nations peacekeeping force in Ivory Coast that were vandalized or destroyed by supporters of Mr. Gbagbo in four days of riots last month and attached an itemized bill for $3.6 million for it all. Mr. Annan said that the rioters were motivated by hate messages broadcast by state radio and that he was "particularly troubled" by the failure of security forces to protect United Nations property and personnel. WARREN HOGE (NYT)

title: Taking a Long Look at a Latino Gang Named for Fire Ants
description: Lisa Ling is an unlikely kidnapping target for the MS-13, the Latino street gang with a worrisome global reach, but as the host of "Explorer" on the National Geographic Channel, she learns that the outlaws she's tracking in El Salvador have plans to take her hostage.

title: Volkswagen to Eliminate 20,000 Jobs
description: FRANKFURT, Feb. 10 - Job losses continue to ripple through the German auto industry, as Volkswagen announced Friday that it planned to eliminate up to 20,000 jobs in the next three years.

title: Want to Rally the Troops? Try Candor
description: INC. magazine's cover article this month is an excerpt from a new book by its best-known writer, Bo Burlingham. The book is entitled "Small Giants: Companies That Choose to Be Great Instead of Big," and it aims to do for small private companies what "In Search of Excellence" did two decades ago for big public companies: shine a light on a handful of business practices the author admires, and which he believes are the reason some companies consistently do better than others.

title: Evolution on the Runway: Room to Grow
description: What does a critic look for in a new collection? Certainly a visual understanding of the times is important, but since designers occupy different planes of influence -- Miuccia Prada is a hit maker, Michael Kors a reliable distiller of trends -- and other designers are only concerned with keeping their customers up-to-date, you can find yourself praising a shirtdress for the same reason you do a skirt that appears be sprouting three sleeves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FAUSER, JOSEPH E.
description: FAUSER--Joseph E., 88. On February 8, 2006. Known as Buddy. He was the beloved husband of Helen. For 62 years no day passed without Helen and Buddy expressing their love for each other. Also, the proud father of Robert and Arlene Fauser, Jill and Richard Israel, dear brother of Doris Brisbane and the late Charles Fauser. Devoted grandfather to Chad and Patti Fauser and Scott Alessandro and delighted great-grandfather to Darian and Devan. Bud was unique. He lived a full and honorable life. He served in the military during WWII and played football at Brooklyn Polyprep LIU and and semi-professionally. His memory will be a blessing and a source of strength and inspiration to his family and all who knew him. We will miss him. Services Friday February 10, 11:15 at Riverside Chapel. The family will welcome guests at the home of Robert Fauser Friday, February 10 at 3 PM and Sunday Februay 12 from 1-5 PM.

FDNY (Ladder 50) and Retired Lt. Col. US Air Force. Humanitarian, patriot and gentle heart. He will truly be missed. Services from Gutterman Inc. (in the Parkside building), 98-60 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, 12 noon Sunday, February 12.

description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 10 - Zach Lund, the United States' top male skeleton athlete, was barred from the Olympics on Friday for testing positive in November for finasteride, an antibaldness drug known as Propecia that can also be used as a steroid masking agent.

description: FULTON, Mo. - When Wendy DeVore, the drama teacher at Fulton High here, staged the musical "Grease," about high school students in the 1950's, she carefully changed the script to avoid causing offense in this small town.

title: Icelandic Siren Tones and an Earthly Oom-Pah-Pah
description: It's no fun being ethereal all the time. Sigur Ros, the Icelandic band renowned for its majestic, other-worldly anthems, also touched down regularly in the earthly realms of beats and hooks when it performed on Thursday night at the Theater at Madison Square Garden. It even played a fast song. At certain moments in the concert, Sigur Ros's music could be mistaken for Coldplay's piano arpeggios or Pink Floyd's rock marches, but not for long. Sigur Ros alighted just long enough to ascend again.

title: Finance Ministers Meet Warily in Russia
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 10 - Finance ministers from the Group of 8 industrialized nations arrived Friday on a frosty, sunny day for a weekend meeting that is sure to revive doubts on Russia's membership in the club.

title: The Hidden Tests on the Men's Downhill
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 10 - The men's course in Sestriere Borgata has a series of difficult elements in store for the skiers in tomorrow's downhill. During Thursday's training run, Daron Rahlves of the United States had the fastest time. Here is a look at Rahlves negotiating some of the tricky spots near the top portion of the run. JOE WARD

title: America's Leading Men Play Contrasting Roles
description: SESTRIERE, Italy, Feb. 10 - One of the first things Bode Miller does after finishing a race is rush over to a coach's radio and send a report up to Daron Rahlves. Miller tells his United States teammate if the snow surface is breaking up, or where shade patterns have obscured a challenging piece of terrain.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A chart on Thursday with an article about declines in Iraq's public services and power generation, since the American-led invasion, referred imprecisely in some copies to two categories. They were daily crude oil production (not daily oil production) and daily heating oil production (not daily petroleum production). In some copies the chart also carried an erroneous label for the category of daily crude oil production. The amounts shown were in millions of barrels, not billions. (Go to Article)

description: SARASOHN--Ira, 88, of Bocaire Country Club, Boca Raton, FL, formerly of South Orange, NJ, passed away suddenly on Friday, February 10th. He was the loving husband and best friend for 31 years to Helen, devoted father to Ellen, Wendy, Stephen, Meta and JoAnn, doting Papa to Elizabeth, Jamie, Mollie, Nathan, Bernard, Michael, Julie, Vince, Jackie, Bobby and Jason and beloved brother of Roy and Miriam. Loved by all who knew him, he will be deeply missed. Services Sunday, 1:30 PM, Temple Beth El, Boca Raton.

title: Political Skeletons, Cut and Pasted
description: Staff members for a Republican congressman, carefully perusing his biography on Wikipedia -- the free-form, online encyclopedia -- recently happened upon the insertion that "he likes to beat his wife and children." The Web's collective form of fact-gathering tends to invite such sliming. But now, a more tricky problem is emerging: the editing of legislative biographies by staff members and loyalists devoted to gilding the incumbent.

title: J. P. Donleavy Approaches 80, Anything but Gingerly
description: MULLINGAR, Ireland, Feb. 6 - A crumbling mansion, centuries old, sits amid rolling fields on the outskirts of this market town. It looks uninhabited, its windows blank behind heavy wooden shutters. But inside, a sprightly old man lives alone, tending overgrown gardens, playing the piano and occasionally casting an eye over the cows that roam his wild estate's 180 acres.

description: BIG companies were in big trouble with many of their shareholders this week, whether because they were too slow in cutting some things, like their payroll or their dividends, or too quick to count other things, like their sales.

title: Arts, Briefly; Some Happy News for ABC
description: In a span of less than a year, "World News Tonight" on ABC has had to cope with the death of one anchor (Peter Jennings) and the serious wounds sustained by another (Bob Woodruff) in Iraq. But yesterday, the program made an announcement that David Westin, the president of ABC News, characterized as "life affirming": Elizabeth Vargas, right, Mr. Woodruff's co-anchor since Jan. 3, is expecting her second child. The network said in a statement that Ms. Vargas, 43, and her husband, the singer Marc Cohn, 46, were expecting a baby in late summer. They also have a son, and Mr. Cohn has two children from a previous marriage. ABC said Ms. Vargas would continue to serve as a co-anchor of "World News Tonight" and the prime-time magazine "20/20" for the duration of her pregnancy. Her pregnancy and expected maternity leave have become yet another variable that the network will have to consider as it makes interim anchor assignments in Mr. Woodruff's absence. At least through the end of this month, Ms. Vargas will be joined as anchor most nights by Charles Gibson or Diane Sawyer. "When the timetable for Woodruff's recovery becomes clearer in the coming weeks," the network said yesterday, "ABC News will announce further interim plans for substitution on the broadcast." Mr. Woodruff, who suffered serious head injuries and other wounds in a bomb attack in Iraq last month, remains hospitalized at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md. In a statement earlier this week, ABC said he was being "sedated for now to help with the healing of his various injuries."

title: At the End of the World, the Fish Stories Are True
description: RIO GRANDE, Argentina - Although it holds the world's biggest population of large trout, the Rio Grande in Tierra del Fuego was rarely fished as recently as 40 years ago. Sea trout, the descendants of brown trout placed in the river in the 1930's, thrived in the Antarctic Sea and returned to the Rio Grande every year in ever-increasing numbers and sizes. Ten pounds was the average, and tales of 20-pounders raised eyebrows at first, but the photographic evidence of anglers holding impressive trout could not be dismissed in that pre-Photoshop era.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSS, CARMEL EBAN
description: ROSS--Carmel Eban, 83, NYC, January 29, 2006. Londonborn actress and sister of Abba Eban, Raphael Eban and Ruth Lynn; widow of David Ross. With Ross she founded Theatre Four in NYC. Survived by Raphael Eban of London, Suzy Eban of Tel Aviv, and cousin Oliver Sacks, NYC.

title: The Grass Station
description: THOSE of us who labor in the garden got an unexpected thrill listening to the State of the Union last week when President Bush touted a plant, switch grass to be exact, as a way to "make our dependence on Middle Eastern oil a thing of the past."

title: From Broadway to Runway
description: JOHN MALKOVICH, 52, the Obie winner and Oscar-nominated actor, director and producer, was in New York recently to show his Uncle Kimono clothing line to buyers at the Project New York show held at the Javits Center. The line, formulated with his partner, Francesco Rulli, features tailored suits, sweaters, striped ties and hats for men and just a few items for women, including berets and T-shirts with drawings done by Mr. Malkovich. Examples can be found at www.johnmalkovich.org.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Sets Record, With China and Oil the Causes
description: The United States trade deficit widened to a record $726 billion in 2005, the government reported yesterday, adding more fuel to the increasingly partisan debate between advocates of further globalization and those who contend that free trade is causing the loss of too many American manufacturing jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHAFFER, STANLEY J.
description: SCHAFFER--Stanley J. Your presence in our lives was truly a special gift. Our condolences to Caryl and family. Billie and Fred

title: Terror Case in Buffalo Awaits Word on Wiretaps
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 10 - A man accused of illegally wiring money to Yemen has asked a judge to determine whether any of the evidence against him was gathered secretly and without a warrant as part of the Bush administration's domestic surveillance program.

title: Iraqis Certify Election Results on a Day of More Violence
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 10 - Iraqi officials certified the results of parliamentary elections on Friday, setting the country on a timeline for forming a new, permanent government, while the kidnappers of an American journalist issued a new deadline for killing her if their demands were not met.

title: Gretzky's Presence Will Be a Distraction
description: TURIN, Italy - JUST when the 2006 Winter Olympics seemed likely to be swallowed whole by this greater metropolitan area of almost two million, along came confirmation that Wayne Gretzky will ride a mighty tailwind of fresh gambling scandal here, setting the stage for the follow-up spectacle to the spirited pageantry of the opening ceremony last night.

title: OLYMPICS
Going to the Heart of the Matter

title: Custodian Charged in Internet Sex Sting
description: A school custodian in Brooklyn was arrested yesterday and accused of sending sexual images of himself to a police officer posing online as a 12-year-old girl, the police said.

title: Genocide and a Lawyer's Afterlife Lemkin's House
description: Words are no match for action, and neither are mere laws. Raphael Lemkin, a real-life lawyer who died in 1959, learns this in his imagined afterlife in "Lemkin's House," a compelling, well-acted play by Catherine Filloux at the 78th Street Theater Lab.

title: Government Calls Conference to Study 2 Deadly Infections
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 - The federal government has called an unusual scientific conference to look into two related bacterial infections, one that killed four California women who took an abortion pill and the other that has caused outbreaks of diarrhea and colitis in hospitals and nursing homes across the nation.

title: Low - cost airline pioneer Laker dies
National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Boy Sues Cardinal And Archdiocese
description: A lawsuit has been filed against Cardinal Francis George and the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago on behalf of an 11-year-old boy who has accused a priest of molesting him. The lawsuit accuses the defendants of negligence in failing to act on abuse accusations that were known as early as 2000 and in not removing or supervising the accused priest. The suit, which was filed in Cook County Circuit Court on Thursday, seeks more than $100,000 in damages. The priest, the Rev. Daniel McCormack, 37, a former priest at St. Agatha Catholic Church in Chicago, has been charged with aggravated criminal sexual abuse and accused of fondling three boys. The archdiocese did not respond to a phone message seeking comment. GRETCHEN RUETHLING (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GIUNTA, ARTHUR
description: GIUNTA--Arthur. On February 8, 2006. Founder and owner of Arturo's of Greenwich Village. Beloved husband of Elizabeth. Devoted father of Scott and Lisa, father-in-law of Carol. Dear grandfather of Nico and Sofia. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, 9:30 AM, St. Anthony of Padua Church. Entombment Trinity Church Cemetery. Friends may call Saturday & Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Seeking to Block Demolition of Church
description: As a stained-glass artist, Patti Kelly has a passion for old buildings. She has admired St. Brigid's, built 158 years ago to tend to refugees from the Irish potato famine, for years while walking to her East Village studio.

title: Roddick Loses in Davis Cup
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Feb. 10 - Luck does not seem to be with Andy Roddick lately, and his first Davis Cup match of 2006 Friday was another example.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 - Michael D. Brown, the former federal emergency management chief who became a ridiculed symbol of the Bush administration's flawed response to Hurricane Katrina, returned in anger to Capitol Hill on Friday and lashed back at his former superiors.

description: To the Editor:

title: Congress's Duty on Energy
description: Senator Pete Domenici told a recent gathering of experts that if Congress is going to do anything useful this year about the two big energy-related questions of our time -- oil dependency and global warming -- it will have to focus on "four or five big things" instead of the usual laundry list of tax breaks, subsidies and modest research programs.

title: Limbo, Still, for Catholic Churches Awaiting an Overhaul
description: The faithful at dozens of Roman Catholic churches and schools across the Archdiocese of New York have been stuck for months in an awkward holding pattern as they await word of whether they will be forced to close as part of the largest reorganization in the more than 150-year history of the archdiocese.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 - When Representative Heather A. Wilson broke ranks with President Bush on Tuesday to declare her "serious concerns" about domestic eavesdropping, she gave voice to what some fellow Republicans were thinking, if not saying.

title: Center Is Woods's Way of Giving Back
description: In his first decade on the PGA Tour, Tiger Woods carted away 10 major championships, helped usher in the era of the long ball and changed the view of golf to athletic hip from its polyester past.

title: Along Came a Spider Fanatic
description: Martin Nicholas likes to talk about Spider-Man. In "True Adventures of the Ultimate Spider-Hunter," which has its premiere on PBS's "Nature" series on Sunday, he even interviews Stan Lee, a creator of the Marvel Comics superhero, who says he also considered doing Mosquito-Man or Fly-Man instead. The name just didn't have the same ring.

title: Arts, Briefly; Promotion at NPR
description: William K. Marimow, a former editor of The Baltimore Sun who had been managing editor of National Public Radio news since May 2004, has been promoted to vice president for news. The appointment of Mr. Marimow, right, was announced on Wednesday by Jay Kernis, NPR's senior vice president for programming. Mr. Marimow, previously responsible for NPR's national news desk and investigative reporting staff, will now oversee the entire NPR news division, which includes 350 journalists and technicians at its Washington headquarters and 36 bureaus.

title: Shadow Shogun Steps Into Light, to Change Japan
description: TOKYO - AT day's end, it was perhaps one of the few things over which he held no sway, the relentless logic of aging, that made Tsuneo Watanabe, Japan's most powerful media baron, decide to step out of the shadows.

title: Hey, Whose Grandpa Didn't Tell Some Tales?
description: NEWSPAPERS across the country, including this one, published a small correction a few days ago. Al Lewis, the actor who played Grandpa in "The Munsters," died on Roosevelt Island last week at the age of 82. He was not, repeat, not 95.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about documents showing when the White House learned of the levee breaches in New Orleans referred imprecisely to President Bush's whereabouts on the morning of Tuesday, Aug. 30, the day the public learned that New Orleans had flooded. He was in San Diego that morning, giving a speech and meeting with soldiers, and returned that afternoon to his ranch in Crawford, Tex. He was not vacationing in Texas that morning.

title: CLEMENS MORE LIKELY TO RETIRE
description: The agent for Roger Clemens said yesterday that Clemens was more likely to retire than continue pitching after the World Baseball Classic next month.

title: Tricks to Titles and Concepts in Mixed Program
description: Tricked-up titles, cute program notes and gimmicky concepts tend to be a sure sign of impending disaster in dance. That held true for a joint program presented on Wednesday night by the choreographers Heather Kravas and Antonija Livingstone and a Moscow-based choreographic collective called PO.V.S. Tanze.

title: The White House and the Hurricane
description: To the Editor:

title: War and Rock Video Games Win Awards
description: LAS VEGAS, Feb. 10 - God of War, a classic big-budget action game, shared the spotlight with Guitar Hero, the quirky, infectious rock 'n' roll dream maker, on Thursday night as the Academy of Interactive Arts and Sciences announced the winners of its 2005 video game awards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAYLOR, HUNT
description: TAYLOR--Hunt. Beloved husband of Martha & father of Julia (17) and Davis (13) died in a motorcycle accident while on vacation in Arizona on February 5, 2006. Hunt Taylor lived his life and loved his family "with all his might," which were his last words to a close family friend. His love of life and his intelligence, kindness and humor are a small part of the legacy he leaves behind for his hundreds of friends. He was a valued member of the hedge fund industry and a brilliant musician. He will be sorely missed by many. A private service will be held for the family and closest friends on Sunday, February 12, 2006 at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Post Road, Rye, NY. (914) 967-0129. Visitation will be from 11AM until 2 PM. The service will be held at 2 PM. There will be a celebration of the life that he lived to the fullest to be held at a date yet to be announced.

title: Of Sailors, Chopin and Love
description: At its annual luncheon benefit this month, New York City Ballet honored a founding choreographer with "The World of Jerome Robbins," a program featuring excerpts of his work. On Thursday, the company presented "All Robbins," an evening with three dances spanning 26 years, from the 1944 classic "Fancy Free" to "In the Night," from 1970. Balanchine? Never heard of him.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo: Parliament Picks A New President
description: The Kosovo Parliament voted to make Fatmir Sejdiu, a 54-year-old law professor and member of Parliament from the governing party, the new president of the mostly Albanian southern province of Serbia. He replaces President Ibrahim Rugova, the pro-independence leader who died last month, and is expected to lead the ethnic Albanian negotiating team in United Nations-sponsored talks to decide whether Kosovo, which has been run by the United Nations since 1999, gains its independence or remains part of Serbia. NICHOLAS WOOD (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about the funeral service for Coretta Scott King misidentified a relative of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. who, like him, had preached at Ebenezer Baptist Church. It was Dr. King's maternal grandfather, not maternal grandmother.

title: Dubai Wins Bidding Battle for P.& O.
description: LONDON, Feb. 10 - Dubai appears to have won a bidding battle for control of Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation, the British shipping company, completing the emirate's rapid transformation from a local port operator to one of the world's giants.

title: SEEKING MORE THAN AN AUTOGRAPH
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 10 - Earlier this week, the Austrian skiing legend Hermann Maier was visited by doping-control agents who initially identified themselves to Austrian team officials as fans requesting an autograph.

title: Seeing a Jungle in Congress, a Lion of the Nixon Era Runs Again
description: RUMSEY, Calif., Feb. 6 - As he shambles through his organic orange and olive groves here, Pete McCloskey hardly resembles the liberal lion he once was in Congress, the scourge of the Nixon White House and a father of the environmental movement. He wears beat-up denim clothes and high rubber boots as he imagines mucking out Congress as he does the stables of his prized Arabian horses.

title: It's Not Cool to Love America at the Games
description: SESTRIERE, Italy - THERE is a last bend in the zigzagging roads up to this hard-core skiers' retreat before a village emerges that has gone D.I.Y. in decorating for the Winter Olympics.

title: A Festive Parade Is Politicized Over Exclusion of Falun Gong
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10 - Every year, throngs of revelers and television viewers here marvel at the glittering floats and writhing dragons in the largest and oldest Chinese New Year Parade in the country, the finale to a two-week festival that celebrates the unity and ancestry of Asians.

title: Victims of Church Fires Lose the Center of a Rural Life
description: PANOLA, Ala., Feb. 10 - The little rural churches of Alabama are like anchors for their small, often struggling towns, but nowhere more so than in this sparsely populated and predominantly black swath of the state's far western edge, home to four of the nine Baptist churches that arsonists have destroyed or damaged in Alabama during the last week.

title: Sharon stable but remains in coma after surgery
WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9 P.M. (Showtime) HOTEL RWANDA (2004). Don Cheadle stars in this devastating, multi-Oscar-nominated film about the 1994 slaughter of hundreds of thousands of Tutsis by the Hutus, their fellow Rwandans. Mr. Cheadle plays the Hutu manager of a luxury hotel, where he bravely houses people in danger and saves more than a thousand lives. Sophie Okonedo (above, with Mr. Cheadle, right, and Antonio David Lyons) plays his wife, who is Tutsi.

title: Italy and Greece report bird flu cases in swans
Gen. S.W. Koster, 86, Who Was Demoted After My Lai, Dies
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 - Samuel W. Koster, who was an Army major general in 1968 and became the highest military officer to be charged in the massacre of South Vietnamese civilians at the village of My Lai, died on Jan. 23 at his home in Annapolis, Md. He was 86.

title: Bail Denied for Brooklyn Bookseller Accused of Financing Terrorism
description: A federal judge denied bail yesterday to a Muslim bookseller from Brooklyn accused of plotting to buy arms for Islamic fighters in Afghanistan, saying the government appeared to have "very strong evidence" for the terror charges against him.

title: Baritone Sings to His Strong Suit of English Art Songs
description: When the baritone Thomas Meglioranza made his Weill Recital Hall debut in 2003, he gave fine performances of Schumann and Debussy, but the works that best conveyed his strengths were the English-language songs by Jorge Martn and Marc Blitzstein. Mr. Meglioranza sang these pieces not only with a warm and clear tone, but also with a crystalline diction that afforded the listener a rare directness of contact with the chosen poems and lyrics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FAGAN, MSGR. JOHN T.
description: FAGAN--Msgr. John T. A priest of the diocese of Brooklyn for more than 50 years died peacefully on February 9 at Little Flower Children and Family Services in Wading River, NY. Beloved brother of Msgr. Robert Emmet Fagan, Jane Fucigna, Helen Marie Murphy and Kathleen Fagan RSHM and brother-in-law to John Fucigna and James Murphy. He was a devoted uncle of JT Fucigna, Robert Fucigna, Brian Fucigna, Michael Fucigna, JaneEllen Logler, Kathleen Murphy, Elizabeth Cooke, Helen Marie Sweeney, Kristin Hubschman, James Murphy 1V (deceased), and numerous grandnieces and grandnephews. Ordained in 1952 he served in Resurrection Ascension parish in Rego Park before being assigned to Little Flower Children and Family Services in 1959. Putting the needs of children first in all decision making, he was a champion on behalf of children and families for his entire life. The oldest in a loving family, he was deeply sensitive to the importance of family for every child. A lover of people and life he shared his humor and kindness with everyone. His respect, reverence, and delight in each person made him loved by all. Visiting hours at Little Flower Chapel, Wading River, from 2PM to 5PM on Friday, February 10. Mass of Transferral, St. Mark's Church, Shoreham, 8PM on Friday, February 10, preceded by viewing from 7PM to 8PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday, February 11, at 10AM at the Immaculate Conception Center, Douglaston, NY. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY In Lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the "Fr. Fagan Angel Fund" at Little Flower Children and Family Services, 2450 North Wading River Road, Wading River, NY 11972. For information: Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERNICE, VINCENT T.
description: PERNICE--Vincent T. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Vincent T. Pernice, associated with The Times from November 1959 until retiring in September 2001.

title: Rival Returns in Newark, Making a Rematch Possible
description: NEWARK, Feb. 10 - Cory Booker will officially announce his candidacy for mayor on Saturday, kick-starting a campaign that may yet become as ferocious as the race four years ago between him and the incumbent mayor, Sharpe James, who won a fifth term.

title: Corrections
description: The Books of The Times review in Weekend yesterday, about "The Judgment of Paris," misstated the author's surname at several points. He is Ross King, not Ross.

title: A Mortgage in Reverse: Debtor Beware
description: FINANCIAL planning may not be a sexy field, but every now and then a product stops traffic and turns a lot of heads.

title: Police Chief Places Blame for Deaths of Two Officers
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 10 - The chief of the Jersey City Police Department blamed state transportation officials on Friday for the deaths of two officers who drove off an open vertical lift bridge, saying that the bridge was in chronic disrepair and that the operators compounded the danger by failing to tell the officers exactly when the deck was going to be raised.

title: In a Sloppy Game, the Spurs End Another Nets Streak
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 10 - The Nets were bursting with confidence the last time they faced the Spurs, exactly one month ago in San Antonio. But the Spurs proved to be ungracious hosts, beating the Nets to end their 10-game winning streak.

title: The Form 1040: A Step-by-Step Guide, Right Down to the Alternative Tax
description: CONSIDERING that a tax protest led to the Revolutionary War, Americans have grown docile over the last two and a third centuries. Taxpayers spend long hours sorting through their previous yearAs financial records, as well as the W-2, 1099 and K-1 forms they receive that report their salaries and other income. While some people still prepare their returns by hand, a majority are paying tax professionals handsomely to take their data and do the work for them. But many are spending less money and several more hours to buy software and do it themselves. And they are throwing nary a tea bag into Boston Harbor.

title: Sounds of Prairie Sunsets
description: As Hem, a nine-member country-folk collective from Brooklyn, took the stage of the Allen Room on Thursday evening, Dan Mess, its pianist and focal songwriter, remarked about Manhattan's "wide-open spaces" viewed from the high-ceilinged auditorium whose windows look over Central Park South. Wide-open spaces, or at least a New Yorker's cinematic dream of them, are what Hem is all about. Making music that's categorically neither country nor folk but a flexible citified mix of the two, its songs send one branch toward the hymnal, another into droning soft rock, and a third toward the kind of film music that evokes prairie sunsets.

title: The 29th Annual American Crossword Puzzle Tournament
description: Have you ever wondered how good a crossword solver you are?

title: CHACON AVOIDS ARBITRATION
description: The Yankees avoided an arbitration hearing with the right-hander Shawn Chacon yesterday, signing him to a one-year, $3.6 million contract. The sides had been scheduled for a hearing in St. Petersburg, Fla., on Monday.

title: Rahlves Feels Confident Enough to Skip Second Practice Run
description: SESTRIERE, Italy, Feb. 10 - Weary from pre-Olympic obligations to sponsors and the news media and nursing a sore throat, the downhiller Daron Rahlves of the United States skipped Friday's second day of training on the downhill course here. On Thursday, in the opening training run, Rahlves routed the field, recording a time more than a second faster than his nearest competitor.

title: A Man Fired for Playing With Kings and Queens Has a Name Fit for Royalty
description: In the beginning there was douard-Etienne de Nevers, sieur de Brantigny, later known as douard Boisvert. He immigrated to Quebec from France and in 1654 settled along the St. Lawrence on a prime plot he bought for a cow and two barrels of pickled eel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KEMP, PEARL
description: KEMP--Pearl. The American ORT family mourns the passing of Pearl Kemp, a 25-year supporter. In recognition of her loyalty and dedication, Ms. Kemp received American ORT's 2004 Supporter of the Year Award. She embraced ORT's mission and her longtime generosity and philanthropy have benefited countless students. Our sympathies to the Kemp family. Hope Kessler, Exec. Director Joe Cohen, President Michael Broida, VP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OBERWEGER, TANIA (NEE ZINDEL)
description: OBERWEGER--Tania (nee Zindel). Passed away peacefully on February 10, 2006, at the age of 95. Loving widow of Oscar, beloved mother of Gideon, mother-in-law of Claudia, grandmother of Alexander and Timothy, grandmother-in-law of Caroline and Willow, and greatgrandmother of Naomi Grace. Twentieth Century survivor who brought happiness to all she met and knew. Born in 1910, in Rovno, Poland, on the border of Russia, displaced to Palestine in 1938, the only surviving daughter of David and Bathsheba Zindel, and youngest of 10 children. Present at the creation of Israel, immigrated to the United States in 1951. We will always love and miss you. Services to be held on Sunday, February 13, at Riverside Memorial Chapel. In lieu of flowers, donations to www.mpdfoundation.org.

description: WEST

title: With Gas Prices High, a New Energy Affirmation (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Hearts on Their Sleeves
description: Had some of the models on the runways at Bryant Park this week lifted their arms, they might have been airborne, taking flight on their billowing poet's sleeves. Dimpled at the shoulders and pooled at the wrists, belled sleeves softened the tailoring at Tuleh and Oscar de la Renta, and complemented the luxuriously fluid silhouettes elsewhere on the runways -- harbingers, style seers will tell you, of a buoyantly romantic fall.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Inside Art column in Weekend yesterday about the Yale University Art Gallery's acquisition of the painting "Bibliothque," by Gerald Murphy, misstated the surname of the gallery director. He is Jock Reynolds, not Whitney.

title: Another Fad Hits the Wall
description: A walk down any grocery aisle in America is a study in nutritional fads: low sodium, low sugar, low carb and low cholesterol, but none as enduring and lucrative as low fat.

title: A Pianistic Life, With Grace and Swagger
description: "Thirty-three years," the producer Jack Kleinsinger marveled at the start of his Highlights in Jazz concert on Thursday night. "Two-hundred fifty-nine concerts. Some of you people have been to almost all of them."

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Bombs Kill 8 Afghan Soldiers
description: Eight Afghan soldiers were killed and seven wounded in two roadside bomb attacks in eastern Kunar Province, officials said. Two of the soldiers died when their vehicle hit the first bomb. The other six were killed in the second explosion as they arrived to assist the first vehicle. Gen. Zaher Azimi, a spokesman for the Afghan Army, blamed "enemies of Afghanistan," a phrase used for antigovernment and anti-American insurgents. CARLOTTA GALL (NYT)

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: Visteon Posts a Fourth-Quarter Profit, Helped by the Sale of Assets to Ford The auto parts maker Visteon Corporation posted a quarterly net profit yesterday after recognizing a gain of $1.83 billion on the sale of plants and other facilities to its former parent, the Ford Motor Company. Visteon reported net income of $1.34 billion, or $10.25 a share, for the fourth quarter, in contrast to a net loss of $138 million, or $1.10 a share, a year earlier. Fourth-quarter sales fell to $2.87 billion, from $4.68 billion a year earlier, mainly because of the sale of operations to Ford. Excluding the gain and other one-time items, Visteon reported a loss of $102 million in the quarter. The deal with Ford helped Visteon avoid falling into bankruptcy. Production cuts and price reductions in North America hurt quarterly results for Visteon, which was spun off by Ford in 2000. The Ford bailout is partly financing Visteon's latest three-year restructuring plan. Visteon expects the plan to cost about $650 million, down from its previous estimate of $800 million, the company said in a regulatory filing yesterday. Visteon also raised its 2006 outlook and said it expected the improvement to continue in 2007. (REUTERS)

title: Executive Severance Is a Focus at Getty
description: Amid a broad state inquiry into the finances of the J. Paul Getty Trust in Los Angeles, the nation's third-largest private foundation, questions are being raised about whether excessive severance packages were paid to two senior executives who resigned recently, former Getty officials with knowledge of the trust's finances said yesterday.

title: Pomp and Unsettling Circumstances Open Games
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 10 - Four cross-country skiers were suspended, and one of the world's top skeleton racers, the American Zach Lund, was barred from the Winter Games here on Friday. Hours later, Olympic athletes marched into the opening ceremony to the sounds of disco music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ASH, HELEN (BAKAL)
description: ASH--Helen (Bakal). Peacefully in her sleep on February 9 at her home in Bronxville. Adored and adoring wife of Arthur for almost 60 years; loving and proud mother of Nancy and Jane and son-inlaw Mark Gallant; devoted and doting grandmother of William and Emily; loving sister of Arline Robinson and sister-in-law of Ruth Miller; warm and compassionate, trusted and trustworthy friend of so many; affectionate aunt and cousin. Helen was a gracious woman and a glorious wife. A great void remains where love resided. Services will be held Sunday, February 12, at 11 A.M., Westchester Reform Temple, Mamaroneck Rd, Scarsdale. $(6$)ASH--Helen. An elegant woman and a most wonderful friend who will be sorely missed and never forgotten. Tema and Stan

title: A Corruption Fighter-in-Exile Rocks Kenya From Afar
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 10 - Corruption is not news in Kenya, but a new insider account that reads like a thriller has captivated the people here as never before with accounts of death threats and secret meetings, shell companies and huge, illegal budget outlays, and a cast of characters as colorful as any novelist could create.

title: Truer Than Fact
description: Marblehead, Mass. - MY 5-year-old son loves the Olivia stories. Our favorite is "Olivia Saves the Circus," in which Ian Falconer's beguilingly cheeky heroine tells her class about what she did on her vacation. She relates how she went to the circus and, because all the performers were sidelined with ear infections, conducted the entire show herself: as lion tamer, tightrope walker, tattooed lady, and so forth. "And now I am famous," she concludes. The teacher does not look pleased and asks if the story is true. "Pretty true," says Olivia. "All true?" demands the teacher. Olivia stands firm: "Pretty all true." And though Mr. Falconer cleverly switches scenes at this crucial moment, we know she gets away with it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALVAREZ, ERNESTO
description: ALVAREZ--Ernesto. The Board of Directors of Friends for EL Salvador mourn with profound sadness the loss of our dear friend and President Ernesto Alvarez. His leadership as a founder has strengthened our community and set a standard of commi tment to help the Salvadorian's here and abroad. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his partner Michel Langlais, to his sister Carmen Elena Alvarez de Avila as well as the rest of his family.

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption in some copies on Monday about Hines Ward of the Pittsburgh Steelers, shown with his son and the team's owner, referred incorrectly to the trophy he was lifting. It was the Vince Lombardi Trophy, given to the winning team in the Super Bowl, not his award for most valuable player in the game. The credit also misidentified the photographer. He was Barton Silverman of The New York Times.

description: After more than four months of wrangling over management of their music venture, Sony and Bertelsmann said yesterday that they agreed that the company's chief executive and its chairman would swap jobs.
