description: GENERAL MOTORS, once among the strongest of American companies, this week cut its dividend in half amid fears that it may eventually go bankrupt. It remains the world's largest carmaker, but Toyota may soon catch up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, PAMELA
description: MILLER--Pamela. The Board of Governors and Members of Fenway Golf Club record with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member Pamela Miller and extend to her husband Irwin and the members of her family our sincere condolences. Bruce D. Frank, President Roger Eichel, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOGILNIK, JAKOB
description: MOGILNIK--Jakob. Beloved husband of Ruth. Dear father of Ossie Spector, Nina Mogilnik & Riva Wilkins. Loving grandfather of Daniel, Eric, Sara, Samuel, Noah, Ariel, Danielle, and Justin. Services and interment were held Friday, February 10, 2006. Donations to Hadassah and the Blue Card for Holocaust Survivors.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Koizumi May Shelve Empress Plan
description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi hinted that he was backing away from a proposal to allow a woman to inherit the imperial throne. No male heir has been born since 1965, leading members of Parliament to consider passing legislation that would allow female succession. But conservative opposition has been rising, bolstered by news this week that Princess Kiko, 39, the wife of Emperor Akihito's second son, Prince Akishino, is pregnant. JAMES BROOKE (NYT)

title: After 50 Years, the Return of Bangles, Beads and Kitsch
description: It takes a special wizardry to ride the wild waves of the score of "Kismet." Based on works by the 19th-century Russian composer Alexander Borodin (including his opera "Prince Igor"), the songs of this exotic Broadway curiosity from 1953 swell, swirl, crash and trickle in patterns that your average musical-comedy performer is hardly used to surfing. And do you think it's easy to make light comic and romantic hay from a word like "Rahadlakum" (the title of a second-act lust duet), while dressed like an extra from "Sinbad the Sailor"?

title: La Vie en Rose in Loxford
description: There is an element of cruelty in much -- some would say all -- humor, and Benjamin Britten's 1947 comic opera "Albert Herring" presents a particularly fascinating case. Much is made of the contrast between this work, based on a short story by de Maupassant, and the weightier, more portentous operas for which Britten is better known, but there are also similarities.

description: The first day of competition also featured the first gold medal for the Americans. Speedskater Chad Hedrick won the 5,000 meters.

title: Bolivia's Knot: No to Cocaine, but Yes to Coca
description: VILLA TUNARI, Bolivia - Just weeks ago, Bolivian Army troops swooped down on Seberino Marquina's farm and, one by one, ripped his coca bushes from the ground.

description: HORTON FOOTE begins apologizing almost as soon as he opens the door to his West Village apartment. He has had a bad cold for the past two days and is still a bit hoarse. "If you go out later, be sure and wear your scarf," his daughter Hallie reminds him as she lays out a lunch before rushing off to the theater to perform in the revival of Mr. Foote's "Trip to Bountiful" at the Signature Theater Company. "It's windy out."

title: Davis Cup Tennis: No signs of slowing down for Croatia

description: BOGOT, COLOMBIA, the fourth largest city in South America, with seven million residents, is home to a vibrant restaurant scene, world-class museums and a charming colonial quarter. It is the country's capital and intellectual hub, an enlightened, pedestrian-friendly city with 75 miles of urban arteries turned over to cyclists and walkers every Sunday. And to top it off, the weather is temperate, with highs in the 60's year round.

title: Speaking From the Capital of the Global East Village
description: WHEN Ellen Stewart set up shop in her East Ninth Street basement 45 years ago, her neighbors noticed the procession of handsome white men coming to visit a black woman and called the police. "The people in the building didn't want me there because I was a negress," she said, sitting in her living room, regal and serene, her once-jet-black hair now a halo of white with loose braids at the top. "They kept lodging complaints, then one day a man came to me with a warrant for my arrest for prostitution! I said, 'I'm not a prostitute, I'm running a theater.' "

description: WHEN I graduated from college at the tail end of the Korean War, I applied to all branches of the service. I had never been on a large ship and prepared to go into the Navy. But I took the Coast Guard exam and passed it with flying colors, and I felt I'd get a greater breadth of experience in a smaller outfit.

title: Nothing Doing in Nassau
description: The power struggle that has caused the Nassau County Legislature to spend the year so far doing exactly nothing has left citizens in both parties disgusted, for good reason. Political operas like this one sometimes have redeeming qualities -- as quixotic crusades over high ideals, or farcical diversions for a jaded electorate. But while this fight has been confusing, it has not been diverting and is certainly not funny. It's too petty for that.

title: According to Webster: One Man's Attempt to Define 'America'
description: When Noah Webster published "A Compendious Dictionary of the English Language," purists were horrified. Webster Americanized the British spellings in Samuel Johnson's famous dictionary, turning "defence" and "honour" into "defense" and "honor," and dropping the "k" from "musick." Webster included new American words like "subsidize" and "caucus," and left out hoary Britishisms like "fishefy." John Quincy Adams, the future president, was shocked by the "local vulgarisms," and doubted that Harvard, of which he was a trustee, would ever endorse such a radical "departure from the English language."

title: 'Happy Feet,' by Richard Michelson
description: For more than three decades, "all of Harlem togged out in their finest threads" to swing at the Savoy. Richard Michelson's Happy Feet: The Savoy Ballroom Lindy Hoppers and Me (Gulliver/Harcourt, $16; ages 5 to 8) captures the Savoy's opening night, on March 12, 1926, through stories told by a father to his son. Young readers may need help understanding the jumps in time, from the boy's birth that same night (earning him the nickname "Happy Feet") to his work in his father's shoeshine shop across the street some years later, but they will delight in playful slang like "hep cats" and "jelly on the cuff" (meaning "no charge"). In E. B. Lewis's exuberant watercolors, shop scenes in shades of brown are juxtaposed with the wild, blue-toned dance floor, where dresses and suits swirl and blur. An author's note explains that the Savoy -- which closed in 1958 -- was among the first integrated ballrooms, and brief biographies shed light on famous Lindy Hoppers mentioned in the story, like "Long-Legged George" Grenidge, known for the Long-Legged Charleston, and six-foot-tall Big Bea, who liked to flip her partner, Shorty George. They were the "queen and king of the Savoy" in their day.

title: Mardi Gras All Set to Go, but Officials Want Help
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 11 - City officials here boldly decided last fall to hold the parades of Mardi Gras, even though the city treasury was empty and large swaths of the town still lay in ruins. The price, though, was their demand that the beloved party abandon tradition and seek corporate sponsors.

title: Images of Muhammad, Gone for Good
description: DEEP in the bowels of this newspaper's old morgue  that beloved pre-electronic resource where compulsive clippers and filers stored the records  is a folder with a photograph of a Persian miniature painting depicting the Angel Gabriel appearing to the Prophet Muhammad. It was used to illustrate an article about Islam in 1974.

title: Cave-in on the Patriot Act
Five Years After Death Came to Daytona
description: Wealth, national recognition and a sense of legitimacy came abruptly to Nascar in 2001, the year this mostly Southern fixation with stock-car racing went mainstream with a multibillion-dollar television deal.

title: A Surprising Warning on Stimulants
description: Last week's recommendation by a federal advisory panel that stimulants like Ritalin should carry a strong warning about their dangers was a brave effort to slow the drug promotion juggernaut that frequently drives use beyond reasonable bounds. The panel had simply been asked by the Food and Drug Administration to recommend research into possible cardiovascular risks from the drugs. But the panelists went further and urged regulators to require the strongest possible warning labels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RYBECK, SARAH E.
description: RYBECK--Sarah E. Of Stamford and Greenwich, CT. Wife of 77 years of the late Maurice W. Rybeck, died at the Greenwich Woods Health Care Center on Friday, February 10, 2006. She was 97. Mrs. Rybeck is survived by children, Joan and Norman Suslock of Fairfield, CT; Carole and Sy Haber of White Plains, NY; five grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Services at Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, Stamford, at 12:30 PM, Monday, February 13.

description: FOR sci-fi movie fans, the opening titles of "Alien," Ridley Scott's 1979 voyage through interstellar dread, perfectly evoke the film's ensuing themes. As a series of white rectangles gradually align to form the movie's title, the camera pans across the expanse of an enormous planet floating in the numbing, ominous, infinite void of outer space.

description: FOR such a conceptually simple way to invest -- people pooling their assets for professionals to manage -- mutual funds pose a remarkably complex set of issues for taxpayers.

title: Crowds Are Small, but the Hills Are Alive With Buses
description: SESTRIERE, Italy, Feb. 11 - Logistically, the first day of the 20th Olympic Winter Games seemed to go well. Snarled traffic, bottlenecks at security checkpoints and overwhelmed competition sites in little resort towns did not cause major problems in the mountains west of Turin, though the Saturday events were not the type that generally draw big crowds. For both security and crowd control, the entire area is closed to most traffic, and spectators travel to events by bus.

title: The Coffee Trail
description: OUR guide, Daniel Giraldo, is only 12, but he knows the terrain, all the hazards and turns of this steep, four-foot-wide trail. The horse I am riding has done this before and uncannily finds the best passage along rocky corridors where the footing seems uncertain, or the safest path through the narrow but fast-moving waters of the rivers we cross.

title: The Heartland Dissident
description: With a bluntness that seems habitual -- and more than occasionally strikes fellow Republicans as disloyal -- Senator Chuck Hagel started voicing skepticism about the Bush administration's fixation on Iraq as a place to fight the Global War on Terror more than half a year before the president gave the go-ahead for the assault. What the senator said in public was milder than what he said in private conversations with foreign-policy gurus like Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser in another Bush administration, or his friend Colin Powell, the secretary of state, who thought he still had a chance to steer the administration on a diplomatic course. The Nebraskan wanted to believe Powell but, deep down, felt the White House wasn't going to be diverted from its drive to topple Saddam Hussein. When he rose on the Senate floor that October to explain his vote in favor of the resolution authorizing force -- he'd persuaded himself that his vote might strengthen Powell's hand -- he gave a speech that would have required no editing had he decided to vote against it. What sounded then to the venture's true believers like the scolding of a Cassandra sounds fairly obvious three and a half years later, which is to say that Hagel's words can reasonably be read as prescient: "How many of us really know and understand Iraq, its country, history, people and role in the Arab world?. . .The American people must be told of the long-term commitment, risk and cost of this undertaking. We should not be seduced by the expectations of dancing in the streets." The president had said "precious little" about post-Saddam Iraq, which could prove costly, Hagel warned, "in both American blood and treasure."

title: Bye-Bye, BBC

title: Editors' Note
description: A review on Jan. 15 about "Women Who Make the World Worse: And How Their Radical Feminist Assault Is Ruining Our Families, Military, Schools, and Sports," by Kate O'Beirne, repeated a misattribution, contained in the book, of the quotation "All heterosexual intercourse is rape." The quotation, from "Professing Feminism: Education and Indoctrination in Women's Studies," by Daphne Patai and Noretta Koertge, is part of those authors' characterization of the views of the late Andrea Dworkin, the feminist writer, and Catharine MacKinnon, the law professor and legal theorist; it is not from MacKinnon's own writings.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "We're seeing a very angry population, and they don't go to fists anymore, they go right to guns."

title: Isles' DiPietro Holds On Before Heading to Turin
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 11 - Before his teammates offered congratulations by rubbing his helmet or tapping his helmet with theirs, Islanders goaltender Rick DiPietro stood in his crease and took a big swig from a water bottle.

title: Defense? Schalke prevails amid goal downpour
Brodeur Sets Sights On Another Gold Medal
description: In his 12-plus seasons with the Devils, Martin Brodeur has won three Stanley Cups and the last two Vezina Trophies, awarded to the league's best goaltender. Last month, Brodeur signed a five-year, $31.2 million contract extension, and he will again be the No. 1 goaltender for Canada at the Turin Games.

title: Cheney Accidentally Shoots a Fellow Hunter
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 A Vice President Dick Cheney accidentally shot a prominent Austin lawyer while the two men were on a quail hunting expedition in South Texas on Saturday, firing shotgun pellets at the man while trying to aim for a bird, his spokeswoman confirmed today.

title: Bull Marketing
description: Generally speaking, you could rely on the hands to get to the Gator Bar by midmorning and begin on the whiskey and Cokes forthwith. If they bothered with the breakfast buffet -- and mostly they didn't -- it was only after an hour or two at the bar. Later there would be a contingent that started with beer, but the early hands seemed to prefer whiskey. Which is to say, these were cowboys who knew how to drink. Still, no one ever fell down, and no one got belligerent. Shirts and jeans looked pressed. Hats were clean. Boots were shiny. They had come to Las Vegas to workl. But it was, after all, Las Vegas, where starting early, and staying late, is the law of the land.

title: Bird Flu Detected in Greece, Italy and Bulgaria
description: The lethal A(H5N1) bird flu virus has been detected in wild birds in Italy and Greece, European officials announced yesterday, the first time its presence has been detected in the European Union. It was also detected in Bulgaria.

title: 'American Ally'
description: The result of the 1997 British election had yet to be declared, but in Washington, President Bill Clinton was excited at the prospect of the imminent victory of his young protAgA Tony Blair. With the exit polls suggesting a landslide victory for the New Labour leader, Clinton was pacing the Oval Office wondering when he could telephone his congratulations. The State Department urged caution, pointing out that until the result was officially declared, John Major, the Conservative leader, was still technically Britain's prime minister. Blair, meanwhile, sat in the living room of his house in the northern England constituency of Sedgefield, watching the results on the television with his wife, Cherie.

title: Forsberg Nearing Decision on Olympics
description: Philadelphia center Peter Forsberg may decide today whether he will play for the Swedish Olympic team. Forsberg, 32, who entered yesterday's games tied for fourth in the league with 47 assists, has a nagging groin injury and was expected to miss his eighth consecutive game last night; the Olympic break begins tomorrow. Forsberg is being tugged in opposite directions by the Swedish hockey federation and by the Flyers' brass.

title: And the Anti-Grammy Award Goes to ...
description: The band Clap Your Hands Say Yeah may not have won a Grammy (O.K., so it wasn't even nominated), but it did collect a Plug Award. After years of carping about mainstream award shows because they weren't included, indie rockers have started several competitions meant to honor the undersung. That most of the organizers wind up praising the same bands, and within a few weeks of the Grammys, well, even indie rockers are susceptible to trends.

title: A Rapper for Diddy Finds a Home That's Just Dandy

title: 'World as Laboratory'
description: ALMOST FIVE HUNDRED YEARS have passed since Francis Bacon imagined in The New Atlantis a scientific utopia whose inhabitants-in addition to controlling the wind and tides, turning salt water into fresh, and effecting the spontaneous generation of "frogs, flies, and divers others" out of thin air-perfected a method for turning plants and animals into new forms. Fruit trees were induced to bloom earlier or later, their fruit sweeter or different in size, smell, and shape from the typical. In the island's parks and enclosed pastures, all sorts of beasts and birds resided for purposes more experimental than ornamental: "We make them greater or taller than their kind," stated the great "Father" scientist in charge. "We find means to make commixtures and copulations of different kinds; which have produced many new kinds." Yet despite the marvelous specificity of his vision, Bacon did not offer a date for the actual start of these transformative practices. For when The New Atlantis was published in 1627, a year after Bacon's death, making one plant or animal turn into another was still the stuff of imaginary islands and magically endowed inhabitants.

title: Coupon Clipping, the Old-Fashioned Way

Dressed in bulky layers of clothing, two dancers, Walter Dundervill and Jennifer Kjos, stepped onto a pair of benches. Two others, Chase Granoff and Tasha Taylor, walked onstage brandishing scissors and eyed them like painters facing blank canvases. Then they cut.

title: The Wild Zones
description: The sneaky thing about the suburban landscape is how natural it looks. The trees turn green, then brown and then green again, there are always leaves to blow and grass to mow, and something is keeping all those greedy deer and evil geese alive. It all looks good, but something is not right. All those highways, sidewalks and housing developments, the products of planning decisions that revolve mainly around people and their cars, keep nature off-balance. They pay little heed to the needs of all the other residents of suburbia -- the wild things that live, move, work and play entirely off the grid.

When the first fax machine was installed near my desk in the newsroom (one machine, back then, for hundreds of reporters), I thought, "Don't messenger services deliver clearer copies?" title: The Trouble With Bob
description: Bob Richardson, the infamous fashion photographer from the 60's and 70's? Yeah, sure, we'd heard of him. We had seen some of his black and white photos of Anjelica Huston -- his girlfriend and muse for four years -- sucking on a cigarette, smoke clouds circling her face. And we'd seen his well-known photo of Donna Mitchell, the one with a tear rolling down her cheek. But mostly we knew him as the crazy father of the larger-than-life fashion photographer Terry Richardson. So when Terry asked if the two of us would meet with his dad about a book of his work, we were really curious.

description: GREEN--Norman. On February 3, 2006. Beloved husband of Bernice. Devoted father of Stephen & Halley, Bruce & Nancy, Geoffrey & Heitzi, Sharon and Steve. Cherished grandfather of Rebecca, Sarah, Daniel, Anna, Cipora, Isaac, Perry, Ariella, and Jacob. In our hearts forever. Donations may be made to: Women At Risk, C/O New York Presbyterian Hospital, 601 West 168 Street, #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GIUNTA, ARTHUR
description: GIUNTA--Arthur. On February 8, 2006. Founder and owner of Arturo's of Greenwich Village. Beloved husband of Elizabeth. Devoted father of Scott and Lisa, father-in-law of Carol. Dear grandfather of Nico and Sofia. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, 9:30 AM, St. Anthony of Padua Church. Entombment Trinity Church Cemetery. Friends may call Saturday & Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAYLOR, HUNT
description: TAYLOR--Hunt. Beloved husband of Martha & father of Julia (17) and Davis (13) died in a motorcycle accident while on vacation in Arizona on February 5, 2006. Hunt Taylor lived his life and loved his family "with all his might," which were his last words to a close family friend. His love of life and his intelligence, kindness and humor are a small part of the legacy he leaves behind for his hundreds of friends. He was a valued member of the hedge fund industry and a brilliant musician. He will be sorely missed by many. A private service will be held for the family and closest friends on Sunday, February 12, 2006 at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Post Road, Rye, NY. (914) 967-0129. Visitation will be from 11AM until 2 PM. The service will be held at 2 PM. There will be a celebration of the life that he lived to the fullest to be held at a date yet to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZIMAND, NOEL MANFRE
description: ZIMAND--Noel Manfre. February 10, 2006. Beloved wife of Harvey Folks Zimand. Loving mother of Christopher Francis Manfre III, Mark Anthony Manfre and stepmother of Patricia Folks Carpenter and Stephanie Folks Plexico. Cherished grandmother of Christopher Francis Manfre IV and Scott Anthony Manfre. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PHILLIPS, AUDREY STERN
description: PHILLIPS--Audrey Stern, 76, died Janauary 27, 2006 after a lengthy illness. Beloved mother, grandmother, sister and friend. A woman of valor, an inspiration to all. An ideal of grace, elegance and kindness to her daughters Robin and Eric Hananel, Lindy and Tom Gallagher and Penny and Andrew Needle; grandchildren Andrew, Peter, Julie; James, Graham, Charlie; Jared, Cory and Todd. Loving and devoted wife to Karl Joslow and Lawrence Phillips. Native New Yorker. Attended Syracuse where she was an SDT member. A resident of Boston and NY before retiring to Florida. Fashion executive, professional fundraiser and principal of interior design firm. Longtime resident of Palm Beach. A shining star in her community and tireless philanthropist. Known for impeccable taste in her homes and personal style. Devoted collector of art, avid reader and world traveler. All who knew her were warmed by her friendship. A Memorial Service celebrating her life was held at The Breakers in Palm Beach; burial was private. Donations appreciated to Hospice of Palm Beach County and Jewish Federation of Palm Beach. Her beauty, inside and out, will be missed and she will live on in the hearts of her family. She has left an indelible mark on the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STECKLER, FERNE
description: STECKLER - Ferne. Open minded, tolerant, generous of spirit, you set us on the path of life and continue with us in our hearts. Your children, grandchildren, siblings, nieces, nephews and friends are better for having been loved by you. Family will gather on February 13, 1:30-8, 2627 River Road, Oceanside, NY. Donations may be made to Legal Aid Society, Juvenile Rights Division, NY.

title: For Old Cowhands, How Close Is Too Close?
description: Three people on a yacht; the Bahamas; sexy skullduggery. That's the extent of the pitch for Columbia Pictures' "Nautica," a thriller in development that might bring the stars of "Brokeback Mountain," Heath Ledger and Jake Gyllenhaal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROVINSKY, JUDITH SELMA
description: ROVINSKY -- Judith Selma. Passed away on February 10, 2006, after a three year battle with lung cancer. She is survived by a loving husband, Dr. Joseph, devoted children, Audrey, John, Jill, Michael, Paul and David, and caring grandchildren, Joshua, Lauren, Alexander, Andrew and Max. A memorial service will be announced subsequently. In lieu of other memorials, donations may be sent to the Cancer Support Team, 875 Mamaroneck Avenue, Mamaroneck, NY 10543.

title: BUNDLING UP
description: Correction Appended

title: Can't Get a Plaza Suite? Get the Furniture
description: On the subject of the Plaza Hotel, let us bend a line from Simon and Garfunkel: So long, Frank Lloyd Wright Suite.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCALL, JANET J. (NEE JONES)
description: McCALL -- Janet J. (nee Jones). Wife of Julien L. McCall of Hunting Valley, OH, formerly of Darien, CT, beloved mother of Melissa of Hunting Valley, OH, Alison G. of NYC, NY and Julien L. Jr. (Lash) of London, England. Loving grandmother of Blinn L., Julia L. and Andrew M. Cushman. Those who wish may make contributions in her name to The Old Church of All Saints Church, Waccamaw, 3560 Kings River Rd., Pawleys Island, SC 29585. For additional information log online to www.legacy.com Brown-Forward, 216-752-1200.

title: Making a Pitch For Film Producers
description: A group of state legislators, led by Representative James Amann, the Democratic speaker of the House, wants to offer tax incentives to movie and television producers who agree to shoot their films and programs in Connecticut.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An excerpt in the Reading File column last Sunday from a New Yorker article, "Troublemakers: What Pit Bulls Can Teach Us About Profiling," omitted a reference to the person who compiled a list of signs that Drug Enforcement Administration agents have been instructed to use to spot potential smugglers. He is David Cole, a professor at the Georgetown University Law Center.

title: Corrections
description: A review of the album "Houston for Dummies" in the Playlist column on Jan. 29 omitted a credit. The album was created by JD, as well as DJ Ayres.

title: The Mayor's Lady, Her Own Woman, One and the Same
description: She has been the other half of New York's ultimate power couple. By day, she regulates thousands of institutions in the nation's financial capital while he owns a multibillion-dollar business and runs a world-class city. By night, she is his much-photographed partner in the glittering social swirl. And during crises like a transit strike, she too hunkers down in the city's emergency command center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YOUNG, DR. T. CUYLER
description: YOUNG--Dr. T. Cuyler, Fellow Royal Society of Canada; Director Emeritus, Royal Ontario Museum; died February 7th, in Toronto. Survived by wife Pam, daughters Katherine & Bridget, son Timothy, granddaughter Meredith.

title: QUICK BITE/Verona; A New Dog Show in Town
description: North Jersey is well known for its legendary hot dog havens, and all of them have their champions. For the most part, though, none of the restaurants have tried to break new ground, staying with traditional accouterments to dress the dogs.

title: The Trust Gap
description: We can't think of a president who has gone to the American people more often than George W. Bush has to ask them to forget about things like democracy, judicial process and the balance of powers -- and just trust him. We also can't think of a president who has deserved that trust less.

title: Latino Merchants Fear Having No Place in Westchester Village's Retail Makeover
description: PORT CHESTER, N.Y. - The new big-box mall rises like a beige citadel over this homespun village of mom-and-pop shops and wood-frame houses, a locale distinctive in Westchester County because almost half its residents hail from Latin America.

title: Saving Stereos From a Fate Worse Than Garage Sales
description: PEEKSKILL - WHEN Bart Gravino's television repair shop in Hopewell Junction closed, he found a job at the Soundsmith, a store in Peekskill that restores vintage stereo systems. What he was looking for was work to help pay the bills. What he has gotten in his 11 months on the job is an education.

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
Time to Come Home, Zhivago
description: MOSCOW - OF course, certain things would turn out differently when the Russians put their own version of "Doctor Zhivago" on film, but did the balalaika have to go?

title: Reform Jews Hope to Unmix Mixed Marriages
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y. - In this age of potpourri spirituality, Anique Olivier-Mason, 25, classifies herself generally as a Christian: she grew up Catholic and often attends a Presbyterian church near her home. But on a recent Friday night, she was attending Sabbath services at Larchmont Temple.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOVACH, CAROLE
description: KOVACH--Carole. Age 81, died February 8, after a short illness. Devoted wife of the late John. Loving mother of Gail. Sister of the late Harriet Frohman. Adoring aunt to Ed, Scott and Dara Frohman, Sallee, Faran and Jayme Cohen. A compassionate, generous and loving person who will be sorely missed by all who knew her.

title: Firing On All Cylinders? Prove It
description: CHANGES in tax laws often have a built-in time lag before their effect is felt. A prime example is a revision that effectively cuts the amount that can be deducted for old cars donated to charities.

title: The Call
description: As I started the article, I asked myself what right the parents had to subject their children to those conditions and deprivations in the name of what seems to be their personal fanaticism. But as I read, I was struckby what seemed more like devotion to their beliefs rather than fanaticism. Their children are certainly deprived, but I'm not sure there will be any long-lasting negative effects from this.

title: Why Johnny Can't Get to School
description: IT'S become a painfully familiar Long Island scene: lanes of pavement choked with vehicles, the angry glow of brake lights stretching into the distance, and fuming drivers tossing aside caution, courtesy and the law as they jockey for any opening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, MINNIE H., NEE HAMBURGER
description: HOROWITZ--Minnie H., nee Hamburger, 105, of Fair Lawn, NJ, formerly of New York City, died on February 10, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin Horowitz, loving mother of Elinor Schocket, dear grandmother of Bennett Donalds of Fair Lawn and Beth Donalds and her husband Howard Williams of Ringwood, NJ. She was a bookkeeper for forty years and in her later life became an actress and was a member of the Screen Actors Guild. Services are Monday, 10 AM, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rt.4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: Dublin: Browsing Avoca
description: Now that British and multinational chains dominate retailing in Ireland, Dublin shoppers cling loyally to their few remaining native stores. And no shop has mixed modern consumerism with homegrown Irish identity quite as well as Avoca, a family-run minidepartment store that traces its roots to a 280-year-old woolen mill in the rural hinterland south of Dublin.

title: On Advertising: All Audi, all the time
Brokenhearted
description: Some true and possibly true things about my heart.

title: Hedrick Wins First U.S. Gold, but Four More Will Be Tough
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 11 - It had always been a date tinged with sadness for Chad Hedrick, the anniversary of the death of his grandmother, who was also his No. 1 fan.

title: Marika Lynch and Adrian Villaraos
description: Marika Neale Lynch and Adrian de Jesus Villaraos were married last evening at St. Philip's Episcopal Church in Coral Gables, Fla. The Rev. Eric Kahl performed the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WISNER, LOUIS (LUKIE)
description: WISNER--Louis (Lukie). On February 10, 2006 of Forest Hills, NY. He is survived by his wife Lillian (nee Bernstein). Sister Belle Littenberg and nieces Charlotte Futterman, Abby and Nancy Bloom and their extended families. A graduate of Erasmus Hall High School and The City College of New York. He was also a member of The City College Basketball Hall of Fame.

title: House Republicans Rally for Epic Battle
description: CAMBRIDGE, Md., Feb. 11 - House Republicans descended in force upon this Eastern Shore community for three days to ponder their political and policy future and ended up talking about "the Force."

title: True Imitations of Real McCoys
description: FEW kitchen cupboards are stocked with emulsifiers like polysorbate 60 or soy lecithin, to say nothing of red dye No. 40. As a result, creating a precise facsimile of a Hostess Twinkie, the snack cake, is more or less impossible, as these multisyllabic and numbered ingredients are all vital to the product's look and taste. But with the aid of the Twinkies Brand Bake Set, a budding chef can at least approximate the treat's tubular shape, spongy texture and cream-filled center.

title: Old Neighborhood, New Sounds
description: FIVE years ago, the Glenwood South neighborhood of Raleigh, N.C., a warehouse-wholesale district a half-dozen blocks northwest of the State Capitol, was deserted after 5, its main artery, Glenwood Avenue, merely a quick way to get home or to the airport. The two-story Pine State Creamery stood empty. Dark brick storefronts echoed the mournful sound of passing CSX trains.

title: WORLD HERITAGE MISSION
description: To the Editor: I applaud and appreciate Seth Kugel's in-depth and well-researched feature, "Preservation: Sure, It's a Good Thing, but " (Journeys, Jan. 15), which accurately captured many of the site-level complexities of dealing with tourism in and around World Heritage Sites.

title: Table Scraps from Albany
description: Finally, Mayor Michael Bloomberg has aimed some of his famously controlled temper where it belongs -- at Albany. He advised listeners at a recent event to call a state legislator and say,  la Howard Beale, "We aren't going to take it anymore." The mayor's point, made with increasing emphasis in recent weeks, is that the New York State government is notoriously cheap when it comes to giving New York City its fair share of state funds.

title: A Vivid White for the Table
description: James Christopher Tracy, a former sommelier and a chef, makes charming whites at Channing Daughters in Bridgehampton, on the South Fork of Long Island. His lusciously fruity, appetite-whetting 2005 Scuttlehole chardonnay comes from what the winery calls the "hottest, driest, healthiest vintage our region has seen." He recommends serving with shellfish, poached salmon, grilled lobster, ceviche, lemon-roasted chicken and a platter of charcuterie.

title: Crashing Pins May Give Way to Parking  and Laments
description: Bowling balls clacked and whirred the other morning at Mark Lanes, a 36-lane alley on 88th Street in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, where little other than the modern auto-scoring machines seems to have changed since the place opened in the 1960's. As the Bay Ridge Church Ladies league finished its games, a dozen women with cotton-white hair bemoaned the news that the bowling alley was going to be turned into a parking garage.

title: Corrections
description: A photo caption last Sunday about theater in Chicago misidentified the actors appearing in "After the Quake." Andrew Pang was on the left and Keong Sim was on the right, not the reverse.

title: An Omission but Not a Sin
description: To the Editor:

title: Welcome to the New Jersey 500
description: THE 48th annual Daytona 500 will be held on Feb. 19, with more than 40 powerful stock cars jabbing and jostling around the high banks of Daytona at speeds nearing 200 miles an hour. This year's purse will exceed $18 million.

title: Pelt Appeal
description: It is easy these days to find evidence that consumers are more concerned than ever about ethics: there are constituencies for environmentally friendly products, Fair Trade products, products that support anything from cancer research to Vermont dairy farming. Yet even as the profile of the concerned consumer has risen, so has something else: fur sales. This seems surprising, given that for some years the wearing of fur was arguably the consumer ethics issue. Anti-fur activism had a very high profile, and was presumably one reason that the production of mink skins, for instance, plummeted by more than 50 percent between 1988 and 1993, according to Oslo Fur Auctions Ltd. Last year, mink production was close to 1980's peak levels again. In 2004, a Gallup poll found that 63 percent of respondents pronounced the buying and wearing of clothing made with animal fur "morally acceptable." And it has become routine to see newspaper and television stories asserting that fur is back.

title: Detective's Employer Knew About His Sleuthing Device
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11 - Throughout the three-year federal investigation of Anthony Pellicano, the celebrity detective at the center of a Hollywood wiretapping scandal, the top-tier entertainment lawyer Bert Fields and his firm have insisted that they never knew their go-to investigator was secretly recording his targets' phone calls.

title: The Basics; A Trillion, Triumphant
description: When President Bush proposed a $2.77 trillion budget last week, there was the usual oohing and ahhing over the number. In truth, a trillion can be hard to get a handle on. Saying, "If you stick a trillion dollar bills end to end, they'll reach from here to Toledo" doesn't quite do it. So here's an alternative approach: some numbers that don't measure up. The height of this bar represents one trillion dollars.

title: LoHo? BelDel? Sometimes L.E.S. Really Is More
description: The idea that the Lower East Side should be called LoHo, as in Lower Houston, sprang from the head of Jacob Goldman, a sardonic, smiling, neatly bearded real estate broker who sits behind a knickknack-covered desk at the back of his company's Grand Street office.

title: Charter School Laws Are Already Strong
description: To the Editor:

title: Blow-Dryers, Get Set
description: For women who enjoy but don't have the time for a professional blow-dry, Butterfly Studio in Manhattan will shave valuable minutes off salon hours at almost no extra cost. Butterfly's Blow-dry Express service gives customers an expert double-team blowout, with a pair of stylists simultaneously wielding brushes and combs for glossy results at twice the speed. Even the thickest, most intractable tresses can be tamed in 10 to 15 minutes; simply add $10 to $15 onto the cost of a regular single-stylist blowout (prices are $55 to $75, depending on the stylist, at Butterfly Studio in New York, 149 Fifth Avenue, 212-253-2100). title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAINBRIDGE, JOHN S.
description: BAINBRIDGE--John S. Touro College and the Jacob D. Fuchsberg Law Center communities are saddened by the passing, at age 90, of our beloved friend and former Dean, John S. Bainbridge. Dean Bainbridge was a scion of one of America's most distinguished and historic families. He had a distinguished career in legal education. He was a teacher, scholar and effective administrator, bringing his talents to: Columbia, Pace, Wayne State, Northern Illinois and Delaware. He played a critical role in the founding years of Touro Law School. He was Director of the SAILER Project that established legal education and research in Africa. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his devoted wife, Elizabeth, and son, John. Touro College and the Jacob D. Fuchsberg Law Center Bernard Lander, Pres. Lawrence Raful, Dean Howard Glickstein, Dean Emeritus and the Touro Community

description: FICTION AND POETRY | NONFICTION

title: THERE'S MORE THAN COMFORT
description: To The Editor: It's a depressing commentary on what we've become when well-off baby boomers shuffling between Four Seasons, St. Regis and W hotels are called "world travelers." Denny Lee's "Hotels of the Year: For the World Traveler, What's New in 2006" (Jan. 22) is a thoughtful depiction of a privileged but culturally deprived way of life for those so disposed to luxury they are willing to miss the forest for the trees.

title: After the Fall: Russians Let Loose and Lead
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 11 - When Tatiana Totmianina and Maxim Marinin of Russia spun to the finish of their nearly flawless short program Saturday night, they shared an expression of joy mixed with relief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSNER, NORMAN L.
description: ROSNER--Norman L. February 6, 2006. You are a special person. We will miss you forever.

title: Msgr. John T. Fagan, 79, Leader of Major Social Service Agency, Dies
description: Msgr. John T. Fagan, who retired in 2001 as director of Little Flower Children and Family Services of New York, one of the largest social service agencies in the country, died on Thursday at his home in Wading River, N.Y. He was 79.

title: Germany's Greis Wins the First Gold Medal
description: CESANA SAN SICARIO, Italy, Feb. 11 - The view from the Olympic biathlon site was particularly fine on Saturday, as the brilliant sunlight lit up the peaks and ridges of the natural amphitheater that surrounds this new race course amid the evergreens.

Officer Whose Career Was Ahead of Him Is Mourned
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 11 - They formed a long line down the narrow steps of a funeral home here, standing in pairs, shoulder to shoulder. Police officers in dress blue uniforms and white gloves waited in silence to enter, and behind them stood dozens of other mourners.

title: Bird Flu Spreads to European Union for First Time
description: The H5N1 bird flu virus has been detected in wild birds in Italy and Greece, the first time its presence has been detected in the European Union, European officials have announced.

description: TEHRAN, Feb. 11 - Iran's president warned on Saturday that Iran could withdraw from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty if international pressure increased over its nuclear program.

title: Fielder's Choice
description: Part of pro baseball's charm lies in the simplicity of its gear, its wooden bats and leather gloves, which are innately low-tech. But the latest gloves kick dirt in the face of tradition, introducing exoskeletons and wick-away liners to a piece of equipment that has barely evolved since the Dodgers played in Brooklyn.

title: Inheriting? Don't Forget Your State's Tax Bill
description: EFFECTIVE Jan. 1, Congress eliminated the federal tax on estates worth up to $2 million -- a development that might lead you to think that there were no longer any taxes on inheritances up to that limit.

title: The Great White Way
description: HEALTH officials in New York City are right. The typical bodega in the city's poorer neighborhoods is not brimming with healthy foods, and the residents who rely on these stores suffer for it. The unhappy results are higher rates of obesity, diabetes and heart disease among poor New Yorkers.

title: For Elite, a Method to Their Slowdown
description: SESTRIERE, Italy, Feb. 11 - The last day of downhill training Saturday brought out the best and the worst in the racing elite. They skied the Kandahar Banchetta downhill brilliantly for most of its length. Then, in the final 75 yards, most put on the brakes as they tried to jockey for the right starting positions in Sunday's downhill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CASERTANO, DOLORES
description: CASERTANO - Dolores. Avon, CT, on February 9, 2006. Devoted mother of Drew. Cherished grandmother of Alex, Tyler and Will. She was a warm, giving and loving woman, blessed with extraordinary style and elegance. She will be deeply missed by all those she has touched.

title: Allstate Won't Renew Some Home Policies
description: ALLSTATE has stepped up its retreat from the Long Island market for homeowners' insurance. It announced last Monday that it would not renew policies on some houses that are more likely to be damaged by a powerful storm or whose owners have previously filed multiple claims.

title: Healing, With New Limbs and Fragile Dreams
description: Correction Appended

title: What's So Hot About 50?
description: With apologies to Jane Austen, I would venture that it is a truth universally acknowledged that a single woman of 45 and upward in possession of a good libido must be in want of a partner. Or perhaps it would be more accurate to say that it is a truth rarely spoken aloud in mixed company, but one that is alluded to in the way most unpalatable truths get a hearing: in private, by women murmuring among themselves, when their defenses are down -- over adjoining manicure tables, say, or a second glass of wine.

title: So Many Men, So Few Women
description: THE phrase "All the good ones are taken" is usually ascribed to lovelorn women. But if you're in your 20's, single, straight and looking for love, the statistical odds of finding a full-time partner are better if you're a woman. Unless you're a black woman.

title: Health Care Is Not An Issue to Tinker With
description: Matt Bai (Jan. 29) foresees a future where"businesses will not be forcedto buckle under the soaring costs of what should be an American birthright."First, however,a public debate is necessary regarding those soaring costs.What limits on heroic care and technology will society accept? It is only when the price appears affordable that Americans will get their birthright.

title: Amoebic Names
description: To the Editor:

title: The Call
description: Daniel Bergner's splendid article (Jan. 29) poignantly describes the continuing Christian triumphalism among peoples who are seemingly quite content with their own culture, religious beliefs and lives, without representatives of alien religions coming to them armed with Land Rovers, Bibles, water bottles, aspirin tablets and the trappings of "rescue" -- both material and spiritual. Helping is fine -- witness Doctors Without Borders, whose work in Africa, Asia and other areas of the world is truly making a difference, albeit without evangelical religion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FELD, ALVIN
description: FELD--Alvin. Survived by loving wife Lila, children Scott and Carol, sister Marian and families. Services 10 AM Sunday, February 12, at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre.

title: NORTH SHORE DELIGHTS
description: To The Editor: Having just read "For Surfers, All Waves Lead to Hawaii," I wish to point out that no visit to Oahu's North Shore is complete without partaking of the local specialty, shave ice. Having recently returned from a 10-day vacation there with my family, I can attest that no day could end without a visit to one of the three iconic shave ice purveyors: Matsumoto, H. Miura and Aoki's (all on the main street of Haleiwa).

description: Correction Appended

title: Charles Henry, 78, Housing Police Chief, Dies
description: Charles O. Henry, a former chief of the New York City housing police who commanded some of the city's toughest precincts in troubled times, died at his home in Las Vegas on Feb. 1. He was 78.

title: The Republican game
UConn Rolls Past Seton Hall
description: The top-ranked Huskies brought the Pirates' six-game winning streak to an emphatic end last night with a 99-57 victory. UConn shot almost 53 percent from the field and made 10 of 17 3-point shots.

title: A Hobby That Yields a Harvest
description: PEOPLE are often delighted when their hobbies bring in some income. They sell a painting, say, or some photographs -- or, in recent years, all manner of goods on eBay. Sometimes, they are so delighted that they decide to turn their hobbies into businesses.

title: Love and Other Impossible Pursuits
Goa tries to repair its reputation
What You Get in a Hotel Condo
description: TURNING hotel rooms into condos is not new in New York City, but three of the city's best-known hotels -- the St. Regis, the Plaza and the Essex House -- are now fully embracing the trend.

title: Drama Students Face A Change of Scene
description: HEMPSTEAD - FOR students at the New College of Hofstra University, the curtain is about to close permanently on their drama program.

title: The Honeymoon And the Train Ride
description: Some of the strangest things can happen at the annual gathering of lobbyists, political professionals and elected officials on the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce's trip to Washington, known popularly as the Schmooze Express.

title: In the Land of Discarded Dcor
description: IN a city peppered with famous landmarks that have been analyzed, praised and criticized by millions of people, many New Yorkers take pride in establishing personal landmarks close to their hearts. Stumbling upon hidden parks and quiet hideaways, discovering lesser-known bakeries and unusual curiosity shops can make people feel as if they are, in a sense, writing their own guidebooks.

description: MARY TROY, 71, of New Haven, says she has cut every corner she can think of -- her groceries, new clothing -- just to keep the heat on in her home.

title: Mercedes-Benz CLS500: Curves That Carry You Away
description: HIGH style can make you dizzy, and not just from seeing hemlines rise and fall or watching supermodels change out of madonna and into streetwalker. For instance, you could duck into the back of the haute-couture Mercedes-Benz CLS500 and whump the side of your face on the low-cut roof. As you slump into one of the contoured rear buckets, dazed and confused, you won't notice that there's no place for your head.

Stacey Schreiber and Joshua Cohen
description: Stacey Lauren Schreiber, the daughter of Joan and Paul Schreiber of New York, was married last evening to Joshua Eric Cohen, a son of Ronnee and Stuart Cohen of Valhalla, N.Y. Rabbi David H. Lincoln officiated at the Rainbow Room in New York. Cantor David Lefkowitz took part in the ceremony.

title: Correction
description: A review on Jan. 22 about a book by the philosopher Colin McGinn misstated its title at several points. As noted elsewhere in the review, it is "The Power of Movies," not "The Power of Film."

title: Rift over Falun Gong dampens parade in U.S.

description: HELEN FISHER is a respected anthropologist at Rutgers University who has published four books and given scientific credibility to the idea that brain chemistry undergirds love and romance.

title: Chasing Full Employment
description: FULL employment! The United States has rarely entered that paradise. There was a hint of it in the late 1990's, but for Americans under the age of 50, the experience has been so fleeting that they may not realize full employment was once a hotly pursued goal -- a condition considered so important that many politicians wanted it legislated and not left to chance.

title: Costume Shop Boy Makes Good

title: A Taste of Tranquillity on the Upper East Side

title: Thinning the Milk Does Not Mean Thinning the Child
description: FIRST, New York City schools replaced soft drinks with Snapple. Now they're banning whole milk. In 2000, Los Angeles also banished whole milk from its schools; some states are considering similar proposals. And across the country, there are anguished pleas for more nutrition education, more physical education, more anything to get children to eat less and exercise more.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Feb. 12-Feb.18; ART/ARCHITECTURE
description: Asked to name a hotbed of new architecture, you might not automatically shout "Spain!" But a wealth of innovative architecture has been sprouting across the country ever since Frank Gehry's Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao made a splash in 1997. The Museum of Modern Art highlights 43 of these projects -- 18 completed, the rest under way -- in "ON-SITE: NEW ARCHITECTURE IN SPAIN," which opens on Sunday.

title: Saying 'Keep Out' in Any Language

title: It's Not the Sport, It's the Sportsmanship

A handful of fans were yelling at the officials, using offensive language and continually disrupting the games. The offending students were warned several times, and ultimately banned from attending games for the rest of the season.

title: Trouble-Shooting the 1040
description: CONSIDERING that a tax protest led to the Revolutionary War, Americans have grown docile over the last two and a third centuries. Taxpayers spend long hours sorting through their previous year's financial records, as well as the W-2, 1099 and K-1 forms they receive that report their salaries and other income. While some people still prepare their returns by hand, a majority are paying tax professionals handsomely to take their data and do the work for them. But many are spending less money and several more hours to buy software and do it themselves. And they are throwing nary a tea bag into Boston Harbor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEIN, ESTELLE

title: COMINGS & GOINGS
description: Hello Kitty, the cartoon cat with a cult-like following across much of Asia, has taken to the skies. Taiwanese Eva Airways recently teamed up with the Sanrio Company to offer a Hello Kitty themed Airbus A330-200 that flies from Taipei, Taiwan to Tokyo, Fukuoka and Narita, Japan. Everything from the plane's paint job to boarding passes to uniforms worn by the flight attendants feature the Kitty. Since adding the Hello Kitty plane, the airline says bookings on those routes have jumped as much as 13 percent. Fire sale: The historic Lake Placid Lodge in upstate New York, which had a fire in December at its main lodge, has converted a number of its free-standing cabins for dining and entertainment and is offering discounted accomodations before the summer high season. Prices have been reduced up to 60 percent, with lakeview cabins, formerly $700 a night, now $325. Morocco's national carrier, Royal Air Maroc, is adding four new weekly nonstop flights from John F. Kennedy International Airport to Casablanca this summer for a total of nine nonstop flights a week from New York to Casablanca. Three new flights begin the week of May 14 and run through the week of Oct. 22. Another flight will be added the week of June 18 and run through Sept. 5.

title: Table Scraps From Albany

He advised listeners at a recent event to call a state legislator and say,  la Howard Beale, "We aren't going to take it anymore." The mayor's point, made with increasing emphasis in recent weeks, is that the New York State government is notoriously cheap when it comes to giving New York City its fair share of state funds.

Her spirit and love of life, her sense of humor and kindness will be missed by all whose lives she touched. She will live forever within our hearts and memories. Rest in peace. Services were held.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAWSON, DONALD S. GEN. USAF RET.
description: DAWSON--Donald S. Gen. USAF Ret. Exec. Asst. to Harry S. Truman, attorney, humanitarian, loving husband, father and friend. Died December 25 at age 97 of stroke at his home in Bethesda, MD. surrounded by family & friends. A true American patriot, born in El Dorado Springs, Missouri, graduated Univ. of Missouri 1930 & Law Degree from George Washington Univ. 1938. Instrumental in drafting The Marshall Plan, integration of armed forces, chaired White House Loyalty Review Board, established by Truman. Organized & directed Harry S. Truman whistle-stop campaign train in 1948 which was crucial to Truman victory. Became Sr. Ptr. in law firm of Dawson, Griffin Pickens in 1953 & later Dawson Riddell Holroyd Taylor & Davis. In 1968 went into solo practice. His leadership in national & international organizations included, president of Truman Library. Headed committee to rename State Dept Bldg The Harry S. Truman Building, Inst. of National & International Affairs, Humane Soc. of US, US College of the Virgin Islands, American Friends of Jamaica, The Dwight D. Eisenhower Society of Gettysburg, PA. National Reserve Officers Assoc. Hungarian Freedom Fighters, Arthritis & Rheumatism Foundation & The National Press Club. In lieu of flowers, in his memory, kindly send donations to: National Institute of Neurological Disorders & Stroke (310-496-4927). He is survived by his loving wife Virginia J. Dawson, daughters Diana Coyner Dawson, Virginia Fox, son Robert Fox, and four grandchildren & one great grandson. Interment will be at The Arlington National Cemetery following Memorial Service at The Washington National Cathedral on Thursday, February 16 at 11 A.M.

description: CARMICHAEL--Joel. 90. Writer, editor, linguist, translator and lecturer died at home on January 27th. His 1960 translation of Tolstoy's "Anna Karenina" is widely read. Mr. Carmichael's brothers, Eleazar and David Lipsky, predeceased him. He is survived by his children, Louis David Carmichael (and wife Constance), Isabella Sarah Carmichael, and Deborah Jael Margaret Carmichael, and grandchildren James, Emily, and Felicity. title: Up Front
description: Pankaj Mishra, who was born in 1969, is part of a "globalized" literary generation -- writing an essay on Edmund Wilson on a reporting trip in Ulan Bator, researching Westerners in Tibet on a fellowship in New York -- so it seemed appropriate to track him from his home in London to a remote village on the Indian side of the Himalayas for a conversation about Kiran Desai's new novel, which he reviews on Page 11. Much of "The Inheritance of Loss" takes place in a town near Mount Kanchenjunga that Mishra recognized from his own travels. But Desai's Kalimpong is "much bigger and more diverse" than the village of Mashobra, where Mishra first settled in 1992 and where he has returned every year for long spells of reading and writing and, he confessed, "worrying about writing." In Mashobra, he began the work of memoir, history and philosophy that would become "An End to Suffering: The Buddha in the World" (2004) and worked on his novel, "The Romantics" (2000), about a young Indian's encounters with Westerners studying his country's ancient culture. His next book will be "Temptations of the West: How to Be Modern in India, Pakistan, Tibet, and Beyond." As for the complex view of modernity in Desai's novel, Mishra drew a comparison with the film "Syriana," since both works, although very different, vividly depict what he called "the multilayered interdependent world we live in," a place "where individual lives very far apart in space and time impact upon one another," sometimes with tragic results.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NORTON, JAMES A.
description: NORTON--James A. At home on the morning of February 8, 2006. He will be greatly missed by his wife of 37 years, Femma. Also missed by his mother Kris, sisters Judy (Gene) & Lynn (Gayle). Cherished father of Lesley (Jill), Shauna (Colin), Tom (Norma), Jared and Joshua. Adored "Pop" to grandchildren Hilary, Matthew, Gwen, Keshia and Jonathan. Sadly missed by Millie. Jim was born in Montreal on March 17, 1935 but grew up in New Rochelle, New York where his father Alex was Administrator of New Rochelle Hospital. A 1957 graduate of Williams College, Jim returned to Canada where he was an economist with the Government of Canada, an International Representative for the United Steelworkers and Visiting Assistant Professor of Economics at Brock University. Following his election to North York Council and the Metropolitan Toronto Council, Jim embarked on a consulting career that bridged both sides of the border and spanned over thirty years. A specialist in the field of managed healthcare, Jim left his mark on the industry and those within it, as both a visionary and a friend. Upon retirement, Jim established his own consulting company, aptly titled, Kris Kringle. As candidate, active campaigner and vigilant supporter of The New Democratic Party Jim remained a life-long crusader for social Justice. A rare mix of success and generosity, Jim regularly volunteered at the "Out of the Cold" soup kitchen. Jim Norton was many things to many people: a husband, a father, a grandfather, a teacher, a colleague and a friend. To each of these roles Jim brought his trademark combination of courage, kindness, humour and wit. He will be forever missed. At his own request, Jim has been cremated and there is to be no memorial service. A "Celebration of Jim's Life" is being planned. Please send relevant contact information to jimnortoncelebration@rogers.com and details of the event will be forwarded when available. Donations, if desired, may be made to the Stephen Lewis Foundation.

title: The Heartland Dissident
description: With a bluntness that seems habitual  and more than occasionally strikes fellow Republicans as disloyal  Senator Chuck Hagel started voicing skepticism about the Bush administration's fixation on Iraq as a place to fight the Global War on Terror more than half a year before the president gave the go-ahead for the assault. What the senator said in public was milder than what he said in private conversations with foreign-policy gurus like Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser in another Bush administration, or his friend Colin Powell, the secretary of state, who thought he still had a chance to steer the administration on a diplomatic course. The Nebraskan wanted to believe Powell but, deep down, felt the White House wasn't going to be diverted from its drive to topple Saddam Hussein. When he rose on the Senate floor that October to explain his vote in favor of the resolution authorizing force  he'd persuaded himself that his vote might strengthen Powell's hand  he gave a speech that would have required no editing had he decided to vote against it. What sounded then to the venture's true believers like the scolding of a Cassandra sounds fairly obvious three and a half years later, which is to say that Hagel's words can reasonably be read as prescient: "How many of us really know and understand Iraq, its country, history, people and role in the Arab world?. . .The American people must be told of the long-term commitment, risk and cost of this undertaking. We should not be seduced by the expectations of dancing in the streets." The president had said "precious little" about post-Saddam Iraq, which could prove costly, Hagel warned, "in both American blood and treasure."

title: An Interview With Julian Houston
description: A judge with a long background in the civil rights movement, Julian Houston says he decided years ago that he would like to try writing fiction. But it wasn't until he began working with a teacher in the late 1990's that he started seriously writing. The result is "New Boy," a graceful and moving debut novel that the author hopes will help young readers understand what America was like in the days of segregation. It is based on his experiences in 1959 as one of the first black students to attend the Hotchkiss prep school in Connecticut A called Draper in the novel A and also contains vivid scenes of Harlem night clubs and street life. An edited version of an interview with Houston follows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ASH, HELEN (BAKAL)

Adored and adoring wife of Arthur for almost 60 years; loving and proud mother of Nancy and Jane and son-inlaw Mark Gallant; devoted and doting grandmother of William and Emily; loving sister of Arline Robinson and sister-in-law of Ruth Miller; warm and compassionate, trusted and trustworthy friend of so many; affectionate aunt and cousin. Helen was a gracious woman and a glorious wife. A great void remains where love resided. Services will be held Sunday, February 12, at 11 A.M., Westchester Reform Temple, Mamaroneck Rd, Scarsdale.

If you choose the latter, then move fast. Tickets for the event, which has generated a surge of publicity, are going fast.

title: Paperback Row
description: A GREAT IMPROVISATION: Franklin, France, and the Birth of America, by Stacy Schiff. (Owl/Holt, $16.) In 1776, the 70-year-old Benjamin Franklin was dispatched to secure France's support for the Revolution. Schiff's impressively researched account of Franklin's eight years as a diplomat in Paris shows why he was an ideal choice for the mission. Schiff, a Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer, "skillfully spices up the tale with the colorful spies, stock manipulators, war profiteers and double dealers" who swarmed around Franklin, Walter Isaacson wrote in the Book Review.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LITTLE, ROSE M. (EGITTON)
description: LITTLE--Rose M. (Egitton). Born on June 28, 1912, died February 10, 2006. Of Teaneck, NJ. Formerly of Guttenberg, NJ, NY and MA. Wife of the late William C. Mother of Patricia Friedman (William) and Kathleen Rosen (Gary). Grandma to Virgil, Koko, Molly and Sadie. Daughter of the late Joseph Egitton and Anna Boschett Egitton. Sister of the late James and Nicholas. Aunt, great-Aunt to many nieces and nephews and sister-in-law to the late Anne Bender Moore, Helen Clarke, Mary Gannon Cantwell and Helen N. Egitton. Loving friend to Marcia and Arthur Brody. Graduate of Pinchard High School, MA. Bookkeeper for Scott Photographers, NYC. Artist of various mediums, acrylics, needlepoint and crewel. Member of the St. Helena's Sodality. American Red Cross Volunteer during World War II. Longtime resident of Parkchester, NY, Smithtown, LI and The Galaxy, NJ. Visitation Monday, 2-4 and 6-9 PM, Konopka Funeral Home, 9046 Palisade Ave, North Bergen, NJ (201865-0923). Funeral Mass Tuesday, 11 AM, St. Joseph of the Palisade Church, West New York. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to City Harvest or the American Heart Association. Greeted in Heaven by Vanilla, Jolie and Dexter.

Hidden away on 36th Street off Madison is what started it all: J. Pierpont Morgan's gemlike private library and gallery, built in 1906 all for himself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KASS, ROBERT, ''ROB.''
description: KASS--Robert, "Rob." We deeply mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Rob Kass, and extend our warmest sympathies to his wife Linda Lagos-Kass, his sons Michael and Jason, and daughter-in-law Amy, as well as a wonderful extended family and many friends. We also remember the support and guidance he provided during his eight year tenure at Choice Logistics as our President and COO. He had a passion for his work, and even more so, he loved all of his associates dearly. Choice Logistics is having a Memorial Service for Mr. Kass at the Church Center for the United Nations at 777 United Nations Plaza (44th St and 1st Ave), NY, NY 10017 on Monday, February 13, 2006 at 5 PM.

title: Go For Two?
description: If a national Foot ball League executive wanted to devise a perfect ending to the Super Bowl, it would look like the finale of the Week 10 shootout between the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Washington Redskins. The Buccaneers scored in the final minute and needed only to kick the extra point to tie the game and send it into overtime. But when an offside penalty negated a block kick and nudged his team to the 1-yard line from the 2, head coach Jon Gruden went for the 2-point conversion, a rare move under normal circumstances and almost unheard of late in a game. (Only once before had a N.F.L. game been won by a last-minute 2-point conversion.) Gruden's decision was successful - his team won, 36-35 - and significant for both teams. It kept the Bucs in playoff contention and sent the "Skins into a tailspin: they lost two more games and had to win their last five to make the playoffs (where they exacted revenge on the Bucs in the first round). Some participants and observers break down the play:

THE WEEK AHEAD: Feb. 12-Feb. 18; CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: When it came to writing operas and oratorios HANDEL gave his London public what they wanted. He was hugely popular and financially successful, while also producing works of stunning originality. "HERCULES," though, is neither an opera nor an oratorio but a hybrid that Handel called a musical drama. At its 1745 premiere in King's Theater in London, presented in concert format, the public did not know what to make of it. The first attempts to stage the work date from the 1920's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEIFERT, AUREL MARTIN
description: SEIFERT--Aurel Martin. 5th of February, at his home in Manhattan. Born in Bronx of Hungarian parentage, 15th of December 1924; educated at the High School of Music and Art, Haverford College, and Columbia University; professor of physics at City College; Army Air Corps veteran of World War II; charter member and past president of the Wagner Society of New York. He is loved and will be missed by relatives, friends, and neighbors; contributions in his memory are encouraged to United Spinal Association, 54 Nashua St., Milford, NH 03055-3717; private burial; memorial will be scheduled.

Suddenly her husky voice filled the theater, reciting lines from an elegiac poem by the Spanish poet Luis Cernuda: "I remember a sad town/ And a cold night, / And the lit windows of a train/ And that train departing."

Hikers who reach the top are rewarded with views of Mansfield Hollow Lake and the Town of Scotland's rolling hills about 10 miles away.

Codey announced one of his signature achievements: a deal with the New York Jets and the New York Giants to build a new stadium that would keep them playing in New Jersey for years to come. During his campaign for governor, Mr. Corzine was critical of what he viewed as the overly generous terms of the deal offered by the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOODMAN, FRANK
description: GOODMAN--Frank. 89 year old Broadway legend. Loving husband of Arlene, devoted father of Andrea and Karen, doting grandfather of Adam, Oliver and Allegra died of congestive heart failure February 3. Memorial serivce will be announced.

description: EVER since John Cheever, suburban characters have been shot with starter's pistols when they are not wasting their hollow lives at cocktail or key parties. After six years of actually living a life in the suburbs, I am left with a pair of questions about these apparently very bankable assumptions.

title: The Way We Eat: The Sweet-Tooth Fairy

Do you wear custom-made dresses with pockets in the front so you can nibble during meetings? Did Pierre Herm name five cocoa-based confections after you? Then sorry, you've got nothing on Chlo Doutre-Roussel.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Feb. 12-Feb. 18; DANCE
description: REGGIE WILSON and his FIST & HEEL PERFORMANCE GROUP bring the cool eyes of postmodernists to earthy black diaspora dance theater. His new work, "THE TALE: NPINPEE NCKUTCHIE AND THE TAIL OF THE GOLDEN DEK," which will be performed Wednesday through Saturday and Feb. 22 to 25 at Dance Theater Workshop, draws on the black American folk tradition of stepping as well as contemporary popular music, 1930's jazz and traditional songs from Senegal and Trinidad. 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077 or www.dtw.org; $25, $15 for students and 65+.

title: Most of Northeast Braces for Year's First Big Snowstorm
description: Nearly two months into a winter without a howling northeaster that closed airports and brought out children on toboggans, the New York metropolitan region and most of the Northeast yesterday braced for what the National Weather Service called "a major snowstorm" with winds of up to 50 miles per hour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHULBACK, JULES
description: SCHULBACK - Jules. Died peacefully on February 8 at 93 years of age. Devoted husband to Edith for 59 years. Loving father to daughters Eve Schulback and Helen Siegler and son-in-law Steve. Adoring grandfather to Rayna, Bonnie and Nomi Joy and great grandchildren Arin, Buster and Oscar. He was a blessing in our lives. Funeral Friday, 12 noon at Plaza Funeral Home, 630 Amsterdam Ave at 91st St, NYC. Donations may be sent to American Committee for Shaare Zedek Hospital, 49 W. 45th St, Suite 1100, NYC, 10036.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BALKIND, BENJAMIN LEE
description: BALKIND -- Benjamin Lee died February 8, 2006. Beloved son of Mary Jo & Benjamin Balkind; dearest brother of Sarah Balkind Adler & Jonathan Buck Balkind; fond uncle of Max & Sam Adler, Karey Jo & Teddy Balkind. We will never be the same without him.

title: The Islam the Riots Drowned Out
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. - IN a world of wrenching change, the Danish cartoon affair has widened a growing fissure between Islam and the West. The controversy comes at a time when many in the Islamic world view the war on terrorism as a war on Islam. They draw on memories of colonization and of the Crusades, when Western invaders ridiculed the Prophet Muhammad as an imposter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERRY, HAROLD J.
description: BERRY--Harold J. Died on February 7, 2006, in Jackson, WY after a brief illness. Born April 12, 1913 in Westwood, NJ. Graduated Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania in 1935 and joined Brown Brothers Harriman & Co. He served in the Navy 1941-1945, attaining the rank of Lt. Commander. After the war he returned to Harriman Ripley. In the 1950's he was made Executive Vice President and in 1963 President. In 1966 he became Chairman of Drexel Harriman Ripley. In 1970, he joined Merrill Lynch, where he was Chairman of the Investment Banking Committee, a Director of Merrill Lynch, and Vice Chairman of the Board. He served on the boards of many leading companies. He is survived by Anne, his wife of 45 years, four children and five grandsons. He will be long remembered and deeply missed. Contributions in his memory may be made to St. John's Hospital, Jackson, WY or the charity of your choice.

title: Sideshows
description: The spectacle of last week's New York fall fashion collections was a kaleidoscope of style on the runway and among audience members who passed a series of gently spoofing advertising posters along the Avenue of the Americas outside the Bryant Park tents. Shown here are a few of the fashion trends and eye-catching individual styles of dress of some in the audience. Out of the fray were three women in identical fox-trimmed coats from Balenciaga, left and right. Other women wore the same coat, minus the fur. Also, the cinched waist marked by a wide belt made a surprise return. One woman wore her husband's black cummerbund to accent the waistline of her ivory-color coat, second from right. The male peacock revolution of the 1960's made an appearance, and the extravaganza proved that fashion is as fascinating as ever. ON THE STREET

title: British Investigate After Paper Shows Soldiers Abusing Iraqi Teens
description: LONDON, Feb. 12 A The British government said today that it was investigating allegations that British soldiers viciously kicked, butted and beat Iraqi teenagers in custody at an army compound in Basra in 2004.

title: School, Sleepovers, Red Carpet Dreams
description: WHEN Addison Timlin was 8 years old, she persuaded her parents to take her to Manhattan from their home in Quakertown, Pa., for an audition for "Annie." Her parents did their best to make it a low-pressure event.

title: You Hate Me, You Really Hate Me
description: I've never had trouble understanding the appeal of book clubs. Though of course some are coed or all-male, most have a distinctly female tone that seamlessly blends the quotidian and the literary; they're one of the few places where you might hear cellulite and Tolstoy mentioned in the same conversation. Also, they often involve the consumption of white wine. As far as I'm concerned, these are all selling points. And yet when I began visiting book clubs after my first novel, "Prep," was published, I found that my experiences were not the estrogen-suffused love fests I'd envisioned.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Feb. 12-Feb. 18; FILM
description: There is conventional cinma vrit, and there is the kind that plunges headlong into the thick of things so that the images punch you in the face, clobber you over the head, and knock you to the ground. To the latter category belongs the hurly-burly of "STRANDED IN CANTON," the noted still photographer WILLIAM EGGLESTON's experiments in cinematic immersion, which will be screened on Wednesday evening at the Walter Reade Theater, with Mr. Eggleston in attendance. The movie, gleaned from 30 hours of material, is a compendium of shorts he shot in and around Memphis between 1973 and 1975 with a Sony Portapak, an early black-and-white video recorder. Some of it was shot with an infra-red camera that allowed him to record in dark saloons and outdoors at night.

title: Girardi Can't Tell Players With Scorecard

title: Movies on TV
description: SAHARA (1943) Thursday at 8 p.m. on TCM Zoltan Korda's drama about World War II Allied soldiers alone in a tank in the desert follows all the rules for old-fashioned war movies. The hero has a strong name: Sgt. Joe Gunn (Humphrey Bogart). At least one American soldier is nicknamed for his home state or city (Bruce Bennett as Waco Hoyt). The man from France is called Frenchie (Louis Mercier). A European character is played by an American actor of a completely different ethnic background (J. Carrol Naish as Giuseppe). And there's real, heartfelt drama. This film manages to wring suspense out of the "three swallows" rule that applies to their very limited water supply.
