title: Corrections
description: A brief report about the writer Stephen King in the Inside the List column on Page 22 of the Book Review today refers incorrectly to the history of his first two novels, "Carrie" and " 'Salem's Lot." Both were published initially in hardcover editions, by Doubleday; they did not appear first in paperback.

title: What Carried the Girls Away
description: In a deeply disturbing essay in The New York Review of Books in 1990, the economist and future Nobel laureate Amartya Sen laid bare some brutal math. Because of biological advantages in fighting disease, women typically outnumbered men in fully developed countries, with about 105 women for every 100 men. And yet in developing countries like China and India, there were only about 94 women for every 100 men. The women seemed to have vanished into thin air. What was happening? As a first step toward unraveling the mystery, Sen decided to compute how many women would have been alive in parts of Asia and North Africa had their countries' sex ratios matched those of the developed West. The math shocked the world: more than 100 million women were missing.

title: The Call
description: I think the missionaries might take some pointers from the Samburu. The Samburu warrior on your cover looks calm and relaxed, while the missionary looks uptight.

title: Big Air and Loud Tunes: In the Halfpipe, a Techno Cavalcade
description: BARDONECCHIA, Italy, Feb. 11 - Only a member of the United States snowboarding team has the technological capacity to flip between songs on his iPod, answer a long-distance call from his agent and order some takeout, all while floating upside down 20 feet in the air.

title: It's All in the Wrist
description: Need something to fiddle with while posing for the paparazzi? Seen in demure profusion on many a famous wrist lately is the seven-bangle semanario bracelet. Spanish in origin, the bracelets are a favorite of celebrities like Angelina Jolie, left, and Lindsay Lohan; each bangle is thought to represent a day of the week and to give the wearer good luck. Ms. Jolie's diamond-studded circles, in 24-karat hammered gold by Gurhan, are $2,700 each at www.neimanmarcus.com. A set in 18-karat gold, above right, is $5,825 at Me&Ro in New York, (917) 237-9215; Oscar & Nancy's gold, copper and silver-plated ovals, above left, are $70 at Wink in New York, (212) 334-3646. If just one lucky bracelet is more your style, Mexgrocer.com's, top, gives the most jingle for your buck, stringing 18 medals, mostly saints, on a single strand, for a mere $25.

Mahon, signed off on a plan to transfer a program that provides short-term care to juvenile offenders and other troubled children from a residential treatment center in Valhalla to the Children's Village, a treatment center across the street from the elementary school here.

title: Old-Fashioned Italian and Lots of It
description: IT probably says something about the competition that on a Saturday night, Madison's, a relatively new Shelton restaurant with ordinary Italian food, was packed. Not just packed, but as we lingered over dinner, we noticed several tables nearby were turned three times. And Madison's isn't a small, intimate place; it seats from 150 to 200 people.

title: Robinson, Stamford's Hometown Hero
description: NOT a single scene of "National Pastime," the play about Jackie Robinson at Stamford Theater Works, takes place in Connecticut. It begins on a train from Georgia to California, ends at the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y., and spends time in Brooklyn. And the playwright, Bryan Harnetiaux, is a Californian who lives in Spokane, Wash. But the director, Steve Karp, sees "National Pastime" as having a very specific, very local message.

title: Trying to Get a Read on Amazon's Books
description: TALK to Wall Street analysts who cover the Internet, and one company stands out as the least forthcoming, most furtive, least transparent and most difficult to work with -- and it isn't Google.

title: Second Try Planned On School Bond Vote
description: After voters in the Southampton school district rejected a $64.85 million bond issue in a referendum on Tuesday, school officials said they planned to modify the proposal and put it before voters again.

title: Sharon Stable but Remains in a Coma After Surgery
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 11 - Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel underwent emergency surgery on his large intestine on Saturday and emerged in stable condition, though he remained in a coma, the Hadassah Ein Kerem Hospital said.

title: Rowland, a Year and a Day Later
description: GUV. That was what other inmates called former Gov. John G. Rowland in prison when Brad Davis, a radio broadcaster, went to visit him last fall. To Mr. Davis, a strong supporter of Mr. Rowland, it showed the ex-governor's continuing ability to earn respect and admiration, no matter the audience.

title: CLEANING UP
description: Executives at Water Pik Technologies, best known for cleaning teeth, stand to clean up themselves once the $380 million acquisition of the company by the Carlyle Group is completed. In a regulatory filing, Water Pik disclosed that its chief executive, Michael Hoopis, will wind up more than $20 million richer. That works out to more than 40 times his annual salary. In addition to $10.88 million in vested options and $4.07 million in restricted stock, Mr. Hoopis stands to get $6.1 million in severance.

title: N.F.L. Needs Full-Time Officials
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Is It Anthropology Or Is It Art?
description: "IT'S more Carlos Castaneda than Margaret Mead," Richard Klein, the curator, told me during the installation of Jennifer Zackin's exhibition at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield, Conn. But what came to mind was "Krippendorf's Tribe," a Richard Dreyfuss movie in which an anthropology professor invents a lost tribe to account for the grant money he squandered.

title: Time Travel
description: The influence of the 1950's has been felt in the past few seasons, but now Barking Irons dips back another century, to the 1850's, with its NY by Gas Lamp T-shirt for men. The wait-listed shirt is made of soft, vintage-feel cotton and is an homage to George G. Foster's novel "New York by Gas-Light," which delved into the underbelly of the emerging city. Originally in a coal color with a high-tech bleach print, the shirt sold out at Barneys New York in weeks. Because of demand, Barking Irons is rereleasing it in three new colors: gray, mauve and red. All are available at Barneys New York or www.barkingirons.com for $59. PULSE

title: Attached to a Pet Opening? Better Learn Some New Tricks
description: The day of opening favorites is fading away. Years ago you could depend on a champion's wearing his heart on his sleeve. Long before he became world champion in 1948, Mikhail Botvinnik had an unshakable love for the French Defense. But after Mikhail Tal made mincemeat of that in the first game of their 1960 championship, Botvinnik gave it up in favor of the Caro-Kann. Forever.

title: Impractical Condos
description: Correction Appended

title: Church's Proposal To Build Is Denied
description: Fairfield's Conservation Commission has voted unanimously to reject the Black Rock Congregational Church's proposal to build a $25 million building, although the decision allows the church to submit a modified plan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JAMES, LUTHER
description: JAMES--Luther. A stellar African American veteran of stage, film and television, died after an extensive illness on Sunday, February 5, 2006. A native of Harlem, NY, Luther James started his career as an actor on the New York stage, and graduated to writing and directed more than 50 stage productions since 1956 including "Sophisticated Ladies" and "The Amen Corner" by James Baldwin. He was one of the first minority studio and network executives to integrate the television industry in the '60's and a successful television writer and director since 1968, with credits on "Courtship of Eddie's Father," "Bill Cosby Show," and "Bewitched." He was producer of the critically acclaimed "On Being Black," anthology series (1968-1970). A retired professor of UC San Diego, Luther is survived by his wife Thelma James, sister Miriam Lucas, brother William Brooks Jr., his son Julian James, daughter Robin Green, son-in-law Osayande Sekani, and granddaughter Jaquita S. Ta'le. Memorial observances will be held at a later date. For more information, please contact nylarobin@prodigy.net.

title: Near South Beach, A Luxury Hotel Caters to Families
description: There's a new alternative for vacationers who want to hit the South Beach party scene but may also want to get some sleep.

title: Nassau and Suffolk Address Housing Bias
description: TEN months after a report found that little had been done on Long Island to enforce anti-bias laws in housing, Nassau and Suffolk Counties are edging closer to an agreement that would toughen local enforcement efforts.

title: What and When to Watch
description: ALPINE SKIING MEN'S DOWNHILL

title: RESPONSE ON LITHUANIA
description: To the Editor: I read Denny Lee's three paragraphs ("Finding a Future in a Soviet Past," Jan. 22)on Lithuania and was greatly disappointed.

title: New Front: Protecting America's Investors
description: IN the tiny room where I am writing this missive, there are four little display cases and a framed diploma, among many other mementos. The diploma is for my father-in-law, Dale Denman Jr. of Arkansas, and it is from the United States Military Academy, dated June 6, 1944 -- a day when quite a lot was happening of military significance in France.

title: Locals Who Will Open Doors and Minds
description: IT was only after eating flaming sausages at Tasca el Corral and fried sardines at La Plata that we got down to the business of nibbling pig's lips at Bar Celta, a brightly lighted, blue-painted wood tapas bar in Barcelona that specializes in Galician cuisine.

title: WHY WE TRAVEL: ISTANBUL
description: TAKING A DIP AT SUNSET, NOV. 20, 2005 - Ynon Harel, 36, a public relations manager from Tel Aviv, at the Ciragan Palace, once home to some of the last Ottoman sultans and now a Kempinski hotel. Mr. Harel was on a business trip. "Volvo's Israel branch took several business and opinion leaders on a 48-hour pleasure and driving event, which included driving several of their cars on the new Formula One race track in Istanbul. After you drive very fast on the track, your adrenaline is still running very fast. So, we went back to the hotel, and we had, for two hours, one of the best spas in Turkey to relax in. Outside the pool it was cold -- almost freezing -- but inside it was pretty warm. With the cold outside and the steam rising from the pool, it almost looked like an apocalyptic vision." As told to Austin Considine

title: Rice Warns Cartoon Protests Could 'Spin Out of Control'
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 A Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said today that protests over cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad could "spin out of control" unless governments moved to keep them in check.

title: Our Faith in Letting It All Hang Out
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla. - IF you want to understand what is and isn't at stake in the Danish cartoon furor, just listen to the man who started it all, Flemming Rose, the culture editor of the newspaper Jyllands-Posten. Mr. Rose told Time magazine that he asked 40 Danish cartoonists to "depict Muhammad as they see him," after he noticed that journalists, historians and even museum directors were wary of presenting the Muslim religion in an unfavorable light, or in any light at all.

title: A Modern Look for Prefab Housing
description: ELLEN ZWALSKY and Martin Schepsman want to build a house with many windows on a lot they are buying in Atlantic Beach, Nassau County, with a breathtaking view of the bay near Reynolds Channel.

title: Armed and Adorable
description: "THERE isn't any bobbed-haired bandit," Mayor John Hylan announced when pressed about the female crime wave of 1924. "That's only a myth."

title: Turning Focus to 1,000, Davis Drops Out of Pursuit
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 11 - After finishing seventh in the 5,000 meters Saturday, the American long-track speedskater Shani Davis said he would not compete in the three-man team pursuit because he wanted to conserve his energy for the 1,000 meters, which will be contested two days later.

title: Bookshelf
description: A WREATH FOR EMMETT TILL. By Marilyn Nelson. Illustrated by Philippe Lardy. Houghton Mifflin. $17. (Ages 12 and up) Illustrated in ghostly tempera on cardboard, Nelson's most recent book takes the form of a heroic crown of sonnets, interlinked poems in which the last line of each becomes the first line of the next. An afterword describes in unadorned language the events of 1955, when 14-year-old Emmett Till was murdered in Mississippi; the eerie and allusive verses ("watch-fob good-luck charms teeth pulled out with pliers") are more about evoking a sense of horror and conscience. The winner of several prizes for 2005, including a Printz Honor.

title: White Trash?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WARRINER, LENDALL PITTS
description: WARRINER -- Lendall Pitts, 93, February 10, 2006, Bedford, MA, St. Michaels, MD and Ardsley-on-Hudson, NY. A mining geologist with a BA from Princeton, 1934; he also graduated from St. Mark's School. An avid birder, golfer and joke-teller, he loved to fish at Pocono Lake Preserve. Survived by his wife of 61 years, Ruth Rutter, 3 daughters, Judy Walke, Tucker Smith, and Ibbits Newhall, their families, and a brother, John S. Warriner. Donations in his name to Massachusetts Audubon Society, 208 S. Great Rd., Lincoln, MA 01773.

title: Friends of Sylvia's
description: THE barroom at Sylvia's in Harlem has pictures of Sylvia and all the people she knows, Sylvia and Smokin' Joe Frazier, Sylvia and Regina Belle, teenage Sylvia unaccompanied and pulchritudinous, hands tucked into her hair.

title: Amitabh Bachchan Has a Cold
description: MUMBAI - THE word spread quickly: Amitabh Bachchan was very ill. At 63, Bollywood's most enduring superstar had been keeping an exhausting schedule. He was the busiest actor in the business, shooting films, endorsements and a successful television show one after another. But on Nov. 28, he checked into the Lilavati Hospital here, complaining of abdominal pain.

title: Don't Sing Me That Song
description: I was enjoying a quiet meal with friends at Bette, an intimate and stylish downtown restaurant, when the sophisticated-looking people at the next table broke into a chorus of "Happy Birthday." I found it cringe-inducing. Then I felt guilty about feeling that way.

title: Jaime Freilich and David Eisenberg
description: Jaime Leigh Freilich and David Abraham Eisenberg were married last evening at the Breakers hotel in Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Anthony Fratello officiated.

title: In Party Central, a Clamor to Keep Tabs on the Tap
description: Between dive bars and multistory megaclubs, the three square blocks of West Chelsea below 29th Street just west of 10th Avenue, can legally accommodate 10,000 partygoers. On certain Saturday nights, it can seem as if all these drinkers have stumbled out onto 10th Avenue, there to hail cabs, scatter trash and shout at their friends.

Paid Notice: Deaths   KORETSKY, JOAN MC GOUGH
description: KORETSKY -- Joan Mc Gough. Died on February 9, 2006. Beloved wife of the late William Koretsky. Devoted mother of William A. Koretsky, of Teaneck, NJ. Loving grandmother of Sarah. Graduate of Newtown High School and Hunter College. Mourned by her sisters, Patricia Meeker and Kathleen Hodge, and her nieces, Nancy Hodge, Kathleen Scherich (Dr. Thomas), Amy Pallazolo (Bennet), Leslie Bismillah (Enver), and her nephews, Jeffrey S. Meeker (Cheryl Markowitz), and Warren J. Meeker (Michelle Adams), and eight grandnieces and nephews. Friends may call on Monday, February 13, 7-9 PM, at the Volk-Lieber Funeral Home, 789 Teaneck Rd, Teaneck, NJ; 201-836-0202. Burial in St. Mary's Catholic Cemetery, Trenton, NJ.

title: Gumby Was Never Like These Guys
description: IN some rock circles, nothing short of landing in the center of a teen magazine with a staple through your skinny, skinny tie signals being a sellout faster. But ask Gerard Way, lead singer of the Belleville-rooted goth-pop outfit My Chemical Romance, what he thinks about being cast as a 5-inch-tall action figure with his four band mates, and you get this reply: "Plenty of artists do it. It's a matter of taste. However, we do not sell panties or other products that we feel degrade certain people."

title: Into Every Series, Some 'Brandenburgs' Must Fall
description: WHEN the cellist David Finckel and the pianist Wu Han agreed to become the new artistic directors of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, they knew the job would require deft balancing between competing agendas. But they didn't anticipate getting embroiled in a dispute over, of all things, Bach's "Brandenburg" Concertos.

title: EDITOR'S NOTE
description: A brief article in the Travel section on Jan. 22 described vestiges of the Soviet era in Lithuania. It told of "nostalgia for pre-perestroika innocence," and described bars in Vilnius, the capital, that had Soviet military and political themes, and a park with statues of Marx and Stalin.

title: The Thing That Curated Los Angeles
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif. - When the exhibition "Dark Places" opened at the Santa Monica Museum of Art last month, it looked as if an alien had landed in the main hall. A white plastic creature with eight long, sinuous arms sat in the center of the gallery. At the end of each arm, a projector flashed a sequence of artwork -- film, video, animation, photographs and the like -- on a screen or wall. In the belly of the beast were two media kiosks with information on the 76 artists in the show. Touch the kiosk, and the creature would light up with pleasure, or perhaps disgust.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KARGER, STEWART J.
description: KARGER--Stewart J. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Scarsdale, NY on February 10, 2006, peacefully at home. He is survived by his beloved wife, Joyce, daughter, Lanny Alexander, grandchildren, Nicole Schlesinger, Dori and Rick Acampora, and great-granddaughter, Francesca.

title: A coming of age for Spain's contemporary art scene
On a Site With a Past, a Battle Goes On
description: WHERE the Gristedes supermarket used to stand on Broadway between 99th and 100th Streets, there is a large hole in the ground, big enough to hold a few dozen workmen, an earth-moving machine and a hulking vehicle with a shiny metal pick in place of a scoop. Heavy trucks pull in and out on a ramp, which sits on the former site of two brownstones.

title: Hmm. Did Jimmy Hoffa Wear a Radium Watch?
description: Brookhaven National Laboratory is trying to find out why, right there at the lab's main entrance off William Floyd Parkway, a stretch of pavement is giving off radiation.

title: King of Jordan As Fashionista?
description: King Abdullah II of Jordan, seeking to attract outside business to his country, has his eye on the American apparel sector. He met for breakfast recently with some of fashion's leading executives at the Four Seasons Hotel in Washington.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 22 about luxury travel destinations in Cambodia misstated the name of a famous archaeological site there. It is the Angkor temple complex; Angkor Wat is one of the temples.

title: Corrections
description: The Armchair Traveler column on Jan. 29 about the adventurer John Ledyard omitted part of the title of a book about him. It is "American Traveler: The Life and Adventures of John Ledyard, the Man Who Dreamed of Walking the World." The column also misstated the given name of the author. He is James Zug, not John.

title: Gretchen Bleiler Eyes Gold Before Body Paint
description: BARDONECCHIA, Italy, Feb. 12 A Should Gretchen Bleiler win the gold medal in the women's halfpipe on Monday, as many expect her to do, she knows there will be more requests for body painting.

description: Joe Johnson is an Atlanta emblem now. He represents both the hope of the Hawks and the deficiencies of a franchise fumbling to make sense of this decade.

title: Armenia and Azerbaijan Remain Stalled in Talks
description: PARIS, Feb. 11 - The leaders of Armenia and Azerbaijan failed to break a longstanding deadlock over the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh enclave on Saturday in talks outside Paris that had been billed as the best chance in years to sketch out a preliminary settlement.

title: Bowling For Company
description: ROCKAWAY - THESE events are always begin a bit awkwardly, with people standing around the lounge, nursing their Yuenglings and Corona Lights, eyeing one another without saying much. But soon enough someone shakes hands with someone else, and the conversational hum begins to build. Then the host, Kellie Berg, arrives to collect the cash and pass out the name tags and make introductions. And then it's time to bowl.

title: So Long, Dalai Lama: Google Adapts to China
description: BEIJING - SO what does the Dalai Lama look like, anyway?

title: A BAN ON HARVESTING CRABS
description: The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection last week banned the harvesting of horseshoe crabs in the state for the next two years. The ban, which is scheduled to take effect in May, is primarily aimed at allowing red knots, birds that migrate through New Jersey between Canada and the Southern Hemisphere, to fatten up on horseshoe crab eggs during their long flight. The red knots are near extinction, and environmentalists think a moratorium on harvesting horseshoe crabs will improve chances for survival. Normally, horseshoe crabs are used for bait or fertilizer and are found primarily along the Delaware Bay and the southern New Jersey shore. The ruling by the D.E.P. allows for horseshoe crabs to be captured for medical uses. Some researchers think that horseshoe crab blood helps keep vaccines and other drugs free of contamination. Since the extraction of the blood does not necessarily kill the crab, the D.E.P. thought it was safe to allow that use.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COVER, FRANKLIN
description: COVER--Franklin. 77, died peacefully at the Actors Fund Home on February 3rd 2006. An actor whose career spanned six decades, he created countless roles in regional theatre, Broadway, television and film and is best known for playing Tom Willis on The Jeffersons. His talent, infectious humor and his generous loving spirit will linger in our memories and our hearts. He is survived by his wife Mary, his children Bradford & Susan and his grandson Maxwell. Services will be held Tuesday, February 14th at 11AM at The Church of the Resurrection, 115 E. 74 St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Actors Fund of America.

Two Scarce 20th-Century Commodities, Beauty and Serenity
description: Steve Reich: 'You Are (Variations)'; 'Cello Counterpoint' Los Angeles Master Chorale, conducted by Grant Gershon; Maya Beiser, cellist. Nonesuch 79891; CD.

title: Derailed on the Mommy Track? There's Help to Get Going Again
description: As the first baby boomers begin to face retirement, some women 10 to 20 years younger are grappling with another problem: returning to the work force after "stepping out" for child-rearing. For women professionals -- including lawyers and holders of M.B.A.'s -- the concern is how to land an executive-level job after years away.

title: Eats Shoots, Leaves and Much of Zoos' Budgets
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 11 - Lun Lun and Yang Yang have needs. They require an expensive all-vegetarian diet -- 84 pounds a day, each. They are attended by a four-person entourage, and both crave privacy. Would-be divas could take notes.

title: Sometimes, Nips and Tucks Can Be Career Moves
description: GINNY CLARK of Manhattan got a face-lift last April. She had several reasons for seeking out the procedure. Ms. Clark, 62, said she "wanted to look 20 years younger." She was socializing with a rather youthful crowd -- dating a man 10 years younger than she was, and often dining out with friends in their 30's and 40's.

title: Did You Hear the One About . . .?
description: FIGURING, conservatively, that the average stand-up comic lands five punch lines per minute, at least 15,000 jokes have been told over the years on "Comedy Central Presents." Hundreds more will be added this season, the show's 10th, which begins Friday night. But this time around, the weekly series, which allows each comic the luxury of a half-hour set, will offer something completely new: repeats.

title: A Feud, a Blog And a Boast (It Must Be Cuban Again)
description: Exactly what the N.B.A. needed before the All-Star Game break -- the revival of a good feud.

title: Starlet Behaving ... Nicely?
description: LOS ANGELES - WHILE it seems that the job description for a Hollywood starlet includes playing bumper cars with paparazzi, doing tequila body shots with Lindsay Lohan and Tara Reid, and checking into a hospital with exhaustion, Camilla Belle proves to be the exception.

title: Purchase Lures Corporate Jet Set
description: BECAUSE of a general belief among frequent business travelers that corporate flights are safer than going commercial, times are flush for companies like Landmark Aviation, which services private jets.

title: When Mother Doesn't Know Best
description: MADISON - WE know that Ozzie and Harriet, the Cleavers and Donna Reed have been replaced by less ideal inhabitants in the home of the American Dream. And some of the least ideal among them are the members of the bitter and broken Bender family in D. W. Gregory's play, "The Good Girl Is Gone," now in its world premiere here at Playwrights Theater.

title: Violent Crime Rising Sharply in Some Cities
description: MILWAUKEE - One woman here killed a friend after they argued over a brown silk dress. A man killed a neighbor whose 10-year-old son had mistakenly used his dish soap. Two men argued over a cellphone, and pulling out their guns, the police say, killed a 13-year-old girl in the crossfire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VAN ORDEN, JOAN F.
description: VAN ORDEN--Joan F. Of Peapack, New Jersey died on Thursday, February 10, 2006 of peritoneal cancer. She was the daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. T. Durland Van Orden. Miss Van Orden was born in New York City and graduated from the Dalton School and Smith College. She had lived in the Somerset Hills, New Jersey area since 1946, but had been residing with her niece in Poughkeepsie, New York since September 2005. Miss Van Orden was a Secretary to Nelson A. Rockefeller and Executive Assistant to Laurance S. Rockefeller. She was a founder of the Fresh Air Fund Council, and a Director of the Fresh Air Fund, New York City. She also worked for Planned Parenthood, The American Cancer Society, The Society of Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center and on numerous political campaigns as well as some environmental preservation committees. She was a member of the Somerset Hills Club, The Humane Society of the United States, the Wildlife Conservation Society, and the Smith College Alumnae Association. She was associated with the Booth Real Estate Agency, Bernardsville, New Jersey. She is survived by her niece, Sarah D. Peacock, and her grandnephew and grandniece Alex and Catie Olsen of Poughkeepsie, New York; her nephew, Bill Peacock, his wife Jo-Anne, and their children Sophie and Willie Peacock of Shaftsbury, Vermont; and her dear fourlegged friend, Maggie. She was predeceased by her sister Judith V.O. Peacock in 2002. At Miss Van Orden's request, there will be no funeral or memorial service. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to Morristown Memorial Health Foundation, Inc., for the Carol G. Simon Cancer Center, 100 Madison Ave., PO Box 1956, Morristown, NJ 07962; or The Dutchess County SPCA, 636 Violet Ave, Hyde Park, NY 12538.

title: Something Rotten In Hell's Kitchen?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bad Girl of 'The L Word' Returns to Form
description: IN last Sunday's "The L Word," Shane, the once and future lady-killer of Showtime's lesbian soap opera, slipped back into her womanizing ways. Specifically, she cheated on her girlfriend, Carmen (Sarah Shahi) with her alluring, wealthy ex, Cherie (Rosanna Arquette). Even more specifically, the episode ended with Shane and Cherie having enthusiastic sex next to a Malibu pool. Katherine Moennig, who plays Shane, grimaced when she recalled watching the scene. "The pool," Ms. Moennig said through clenched teeth, "I fast forwarded."

title: Images of Muhammad, Gone for Good
description: DEEP in the bowels of this newspaper's old morgue -- that beloved pre-electronic resource where compulsive clippers and filers stored the records -- is a folder with a photograph of a Persian miniature painting depicting the Angel Gabriel appearing to the Prophet Muhammad. It was used to illustrate an article about Islam in 1974.

title: In Japan, Justice Is Not Only Blind, It Holds a Stopwatch
description: SAPPORO, Japan - As the clock ticked toward the 15th anniversary of her daughter's murder last year, Sumiko Namai offered a $20,000 reward to find the killer. She appeared on television with a clairvoyant; the police posted the suspect's photo on a popular Web sites; and newspapers carried articles on the countdown.

title: You'll Need a Scorecard for Energy Tax Breaks
description: WHEN Bill H. Adams read last fall that a bigger tax break on hybrid cars would take effect on Jan. 1, he decided that buying a Toyota Prius could wait.

title: Lincoln's Birthday
description: Alternate-side parking regulations in New York City will be suspended tomorrow in observance of Lincoln's Birthday, which is today.Other regulations remain in effect. Most courts will be closed, but most government offices will be open. No trash or recyclables will be collected, but trash may be placed outside after 5 p.m. In New Jersey and Connecticut, courts and state offices will be closed.

title: A Truly Generous Performance
description: When Sara Juli's fianc suggested it was time for the money conversation, that squirm-inducing talk a couple has before combining finances, she wanted to flee. That feeling might have driven someone else to second thoughts about the relationship. But it drove Ms. Juli, a dancer, choreographer and producer, to think she should come to terms with these issues by giving away her savings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOSEPH, MARTIN
description: JOSEPH--Martin. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Martin Joseph, associated with The Times since July 1966.

title: Teenage Angst in Texas
description: Gail Caldwell's teenage emotions have been replicated by teens not only in the other 49 states of her 1960's era but also in the decades before and after (Lives, Jan. 29). They are universal and timeless. Having been raised by parents with a decidedly different perspective (politics, religion, even nutrition) from the parents of most of my friends, I recall trying to "mainstream" myself to fit in. Rather than lie, I usually remained silent. A girl had to get a date somehow. As I matured and gained confidence, I trained (forced) myself to speak honestly on matters of importance -- a scary venture, but worth the effort. And yet, years later, I sometimes still debate whether to risk exposure or remain silent. Some things never change.

title: Taipei
description: WHY GO NOW -- In the last few years, Taipei -- the sprawling metropolis of 2.6 million that is the capital of Taiwan -- has leapt into modernity with a panache that puts the casino moguls of Macao and the skyscraper-erectors of Shanghai to shame.

title: Oh, Joy
description: HAPPINESS

title: In Cuomo Campaign, Shadow of '02 Race
description: Andrew M. Cuomo has established a formidable campaign in his quest to become attorney general. He has collected the largest amount of money, a full $1 million more than his closest rival in the crowded Democratic field. And he has picked up significant endorsements from labor unions, political organizations and public officials.

When Mr. Armato was 11, his father moved the family to Los Angeles to take a job at the University of Southern California. The rest was beach volleyball history.

description: SESTRIERE, Italy, Feb. 12 A The Olympic downhill has historically crowned unknown champions and the 16th edition of the race Sunday followed a typically unpredictable course with another nameless racer stunning the skiing elite. France's Antoine Deneriaz, starting in the unenviable 30th position, raced from behind to win by a wide margin over Austria's Michael Walchhofer, who had seemed poised to win Austria's seventh downhill gold medal.

title: New Medicaid Rules on Home Ownership
description: THE Deficit Reduction Act of 2005, signed by President Bush last Wednesday, makes significant changes in the rules regarding home ownership and its effect on eligibility for Medicaid, which is often used to pay for nursing-home care.

description: Last year about this time, scaffolds framed the walkways of Central Park in preparation for Christo and Jeanne-Claude's urban extravaganza. For 16 short days in February, "The Gates" were a wonderment, pure powerful magic.

title: The Call

He raises a number of provocative questions as he presentsacoupletrying hardto bringan authentic Gospelto the Samburu.My only complaint was with the grim expressions on the faces of Rick and Carrie Maples, giving the wrong impressionof theirbest intentions.

title: A Tree Grows. Yes, in Brooklyn.
description: Q. I own shares in a small co-op in Brooklyn. A large tree in the backyard brushes against a neighbor's building. Is my co-op responsible for trimming our tree, or is it my neighbor's responsibility? Second, the backyard is accessible to only one of the four apartments in our co-op, and the proprietary lease stipulates that the lessee of that apartment is solely responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the backyard.

title: A Worrisome New Front
description: As epidemics go, it was a relatively small outbreak: 40,000 chickens died in mid-January on a commercial poultry farm in Nigeria. No humans, apparently, were infected. But to many experts on avian flu, it was the outbreak they had been dreading for months.

This week, David Cameron, the new leader of Britain's opposition Conservatives, tried to make his statement with a celebrity-studded Black and White Ball, a supposedly hip event awash with velvet suits, open-neck shirts and dcollet dresses to replace the Tories' traditional, tuxedoed Winter Ball.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (USA) WESTMINSTER KENNEL CLUB DOG SHOW -- Over at Madison Square Garden, more than 2,500 outstanding dogs representing 165 breeds are competing hard for the biggest best-in-show title of them all. Tonight's live three-hour entertainment includes the judging of the terriers (representing Airedales to Westies) and the working group (Akitas to standard schnauzers). Tomorrow night, more groups and the big prize. (Last year's winner, above, was Ch Kan Point's VJK Autumn Roses, aka Carlee, a German shorthaired pointer.)

description: GENDEL--Edward, M.D. 93, peacefully at home, February 10, 2006. Survived by loving wife Claudine, stepchildren, Jeffrey and Randi Kapelman, and Jacqueline and Peter Dervan, and by three loving grandchildren, Joshua, Samantha and Elizabeth. Also survived by his brother Milton of Italy. His daughter Cara predeceased him. He had great knowledge and style. He will be missed. Private graveside service.

title: A Storm for the Record Books, and a Response to Match
description: If a giant snowstorm is a kind of invasion, it makes sense that the official response yesterday had the scale -- if not the gravity -- of a military mobilization, with commanders in headquarters deciding tactics and dispatching people and vehicles by the thousands.

title: Rumsfeld confident for North Africa
Fast and Neat, and Full of Promising Young Dancers
description: "Friandises," after the French word for delicacy or morsel, seems a misnomer for Peter Martins's latest ballet and its commissioned score by Christopher Rouse, which received their premieres from the New York City Ballet on Friday night at the New York State Theater. The music, conducted by Andrea Quinn, is big and orchestral, with lots of shimmering strings, gleaming brass and thudding kettle drums. The choreography often sends its 20 dancers across the stage so fast and so forcefully that the general effect is of a blur of fluid but carefully defined movements, rather like Gjon Mili's strobe photography of dance from the 1940's.

title: Nowhere to Call Home
description: The worst natural disaster in modern United States history has turned into our collective national shame. When the most powerful nation on earth cannot find long-term housing for its own hurricane victims in almost six months, there is no other word to describe it.

The Destroyers
description: We've pretty much forgotten about Keith Maupin, an American soldier who was kidnapped near Baghdad in April 2004. He was 20 at the time. His captors released a videotape that showed him in the custody of masked gunmen. Looking nervously into the camera, he said: "My name is Keith Matthew Maupin. I am a soldier from the First Division. I am married with a 10-month-old son."

title: Corrections

Mr. Arneson is to be arraigned on Tuesday and is expected to plead not guilty, his lawyer said; he has not already entered a plea.

title: At This Hotel, Just Bark for Service
description: Outside the Hotel Pennsylvania on Saturday, across the street from Pennsylvania Station and Madison Square Garden, three lanes of Seventh Avenue were clogged with taxis, minivans, limousines and sport utility vehicles. Dodging the traffic police and cart-wielding bellmen, they angled left for a spot near the door. Then they stopped to let out dogs and their belongings, and the people who tend to them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOBEL, ANNE
description: SOBEL--Anne. Died peacefully February 7, 2006 in Tequesta, FL at age 104. She was born in St. Petersburg, Russia and came to the United States at age 2. She was valedictorian of her class at Washington Irving High School, New York City. She was personal secretary to Frank Hardart of Horn and Hardart restaurants. He called her "Lady Anne." She attended Columbia University School of Journalism. Subsequently, she worked with her late husband Jack in the wholesale beverage business. She is survived by her three children, Alice Teirstein, Judith Peck and Ralph Sobel, ten grandchildren, 17 great-grandchildren and two great-great-grandchildren.

description: JOHNSON--Gaylar Winton, of Spokane, Washington, New York City and Salem, Oregon. December 2, 1913-February 7, 2006. Devoted husband of Donna, who passed away on February 14, 2002, beloved brother of Loyal, loving father of Sheron Doll and Martin and Lynne Johnson, grandfather of Kim Rosfeld, Andrew Johnson and Tomas Rua, and great-grandfather of Ben, McKenzie and Lucas. Services Saturday, 5pm in Salem. Contributions may be made to Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research or to First Presbyterian Church, NYC.

title: For Today's Boss Lady, a Polished Toughness
description: The fall collections in New York seemed to offer few options about how women should dress. The choices were either wild punkish looks that recalled the catwalking attitude of the 1980's or ladylike blouses, rich tweeds and fusty tailoring, which also felt aggressive. But it was reassuring, and perhaps a turning point in fashion, to see that many designers are finally equating femininity with strength and assurance: as in Diane Von Furstenberg's "working girl" collection, with her design director, Nathan Jenden, in which the models wore the sleeves of their shirtdresses rolled up.

title: Iraqi Doctors Investigating Possible Cases Of Bird Flu
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 12 - Iraqi doctors are investigating six suspected cases of bird flu in southern Iraq, including one in which a 25-year-old fisherman died after contact with birds he was keeping in his yard, Iraqi and American health officials said Sunday.

description: KORETSKY -- Joan Mc Gough. Died on February 9, 2006. Beloved wife of the late William Koretsky. Devoted mother of William A. Koretsky, of Teaneck, NJ. Loving grandmother of Sarah. Graduate of Newtown High School and Hunter College. Mourned by her sisters, Patricia Meeker and Kathleen Hodge, and her nieces, Nancy Hodge, Kathleen Scherich (Dr. Thomas), Amy Pallazolo (Bennet), Leslie Bismillah (Enver), and her nephews, Jeffrey S. Meeker (Cheryl Markowitz), and Warren J. Meeker (Michelle Adams), and eight grandnieces and nephews. Friends may call on Monday, February 13, 7-9 PM, at the Volk-Lieber Funeral Home, 789 Teaneck Rd, Teaneck, NJ; 201-836-0202. Burial in St. Mary's Catholic Cemetery, Trenton, NJ.

title: Popular Demand
description: Nominees for a Grammy Award, not to mention an Oscar or a Tony, inevitably see a boost in sales, but the exact connection between the two can be unpredictable. Paul McCartney's album "Chaos and Creation in the Backyard" benefited most after the Grammy nominations on Dec. 8. Sales of the eventual winner in the best album category, "How to Dismantle an Atomic Bomb," by U2 (above), changed only slightly after it was nominated.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Pink Panther' No. 1 at Box Office
description: Despite competition from the Olympics, harsh reviews, bad weather throughout the Northeast and three other films opening in wide release, the family-friendly remake of "The Pink Panther" (Sony), starring Steve Martin, left, as the bumbling Inspector Jacques Clouseau, opened at No. 1 over the weekend with $21.7 million in ticket sales, according to studio estimates yesterday. But "Final Destination 3," the latest in New Line's horror franchise, was close behind with $20.1 million, which is twice the opening take for the first "Final Destination" film six years ago. The cartoon version of "Curious George" (Universal), featuring the voices of Will Ferrell and Drew Barrymore, opened at No. 3 with $15.3 million in ticket sales. "Firewall" (Warner Brothers), a hostage thriller starring Harrison Ford, opened at No. 4 with $13.8 million, and last week's top film, the horror remake "When a Stranger Calls" (Screen Gems), was at No. 5 with $10 million, bringing its gross receipts over two weeks to $34.8 million.

When she headlined a sold-out show at Webster Hall on Friday night, her set included an Appalachian ballad, a Bee Gees hit, a bossa nova, a waltz, rowdy country-rock and the upbeat quasi-Caribbean groove of her single, "Mushaboom." She could be a plaintive chanteuse or, with electronic loops, a one-woman church choir.

title: A Composer Uses Color Like New Wallpaper
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 12 - Beethoven's "Consecration of the House" Overture, the first piece in David Robertson's Saturday night concert with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra in Orchestra Hall, speaks a language routine concertgoers know. It starts in a place that feels like home. Call it a home key or a tonic chord or, better, a place of rest. Then the music takes a trip, maybe around the corner, maybe halfway around the world. Along the way it gets sidetracked, meets new people, squabbles with neighbors, makes wrong turns. But at last it returns to where it started. Traditional harmony is forward motion: unrest seeking rest.

title: Iraq-Bound Marine Leaders Cram on Civics and Economics
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Feb. 7 - Maj. Gen. Richard C. Zilmer is busy these days poring over classified intelligence reports on the insurgency in Iraq's restive Anbar Province.

title: At the Met: Big Plans for Living Composers
description: When the appointment of Peter Gelb as the next general manager of the Metropolitan Opera was announced in 2004, die-hard opera buffs who knew of him as a crossover king in the recording industry were predictably dismayed. What would he do at the Met? Commission an opera from James ("Titanic") Horner? Cast Charlotte Church as Lucia di Lammermoor?

title: Bad Medicine for What Ails Time Warner
description: CORPORATE theater are two words that generally do not live in the same sentence, but last Tuesday's event for "The Lazard Report," a document advocating a breakup into four parts of Time Warner, the world's largest media company, went off with amazing fanfare. The only thing missing was a herald of trumpets as Bruce Wasserstein, the head of Lazard, told an overstuffed room of analysts, investors and journalists at the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan that "there is no compelling reason for these businesses to remain together."

title: Corrections
description: The David Pogue column in Business Day on Feb. 2, about new frontiers in digital cameras, referred imprecisely to a business that Kodak and Nikon are abandoning. It is the film-camera business, not the film business. A correction in this space on Feb. 3 misstated Nikon's current plans in the area. While the company has indeed said it is discontinuing five of its seven film cameras, it says the two others are unaffected; it has not said it is phasing those out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCOLNICK, WILLIAM STUART
description: SCOLNICK--William Stuart, died February 11, 2006, at his residence in St. Petersburg, FL. Bill was born in New Haven, CT, spent his youth there and graduated from Yale College in 1939. In 1941 he went overseas as a Lieutenant with the 105 Field Artillery of the 27 Infantry Division. At war's end he was released as a Lt. Col, having served on the staff of the Commanding General of the Mid-Pacific. Bill's significant business career commenced when he joined Van Heusen Corp in 1950 as a trainee. He remained with this company until he retired in 1973. Highlights of his business career were being named Vice President in 1959, a Director in '62, and Executive V.P. of the Van Heusen Co. in '65. He continued serving as Director until '97, when he was named Director Emeritus. During this periond Bill lived with his wife Catherine, whom he married in '58. They were members of the Stuyvesant Yacht Club and, he, of the Yale Club. After his retirement, the Scolnicks moved to "Camelot", their farm in Saugerties, NY. Here they, their dogs, and their horses enjoyed over 25 wonderful years. In '98 they moved to Florida to begin serious retirement. Survived by his wife Catherine, his sister, Lila Liner and several nephews and nieces. Contact Beach Memorial, St. Pete Beach, FL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINE, DR. LEONARD
description: FINE--Dr. Leonard, 86, of Delray Beach, FL, formerly of Lake Success, NY. Loving husband of the late Shirley Forman Fine and husband of Beverly Garelick Fine. Devoted and adored father of Madeline (Wesley) Finch, Ira (Lisa) Fine, and Jan Eisenberg. title: Refined True Grit Reveals Another Side in Concert

title: Left Behind
description: Seattle - MY brother Lt. Col. Kevin Shea was killed by a rocket attack in Falluja on Sept. 14, 2004. He knew the risks when he joined the Marine Corps in 1989. But he also thought that if anything ever happened to him, the United States government would take care of his wife, Amy, and his two children. Sadly, that's not the case.

description: Alternate-side parking regulations in New York City will be suspended today in observance of Lincoln's Birthday, which was yesterday. Other regulations remain in effect. No trash or recyclables will be collected, but trash may be placed outside after 5 p.m. In New Jersey and Connecticut, courts and state offices will be closed.

As the highly groomed dogs prance down the runways of Madison Square Garden -- the floor-length coats of the Afghan hounds swaying, the teased coiffures of the poodles bouncing -- it's hard not to think of a fashion show.

Arts, Briefly; Olympics Draw for NBC
description: The opening ceremonies of the Olympics in Turin, Italy, gave NBC an easy win in Friday's Nielsen estimates, drawing an average of 22.8 million viewers from 8 to 11 p.m. (The Italian skier Deborah Compagnoni carried the Olympic Flame, right.) That was a precipitous drop from the opening pomp at the 2002 winter games in Salt Lake City, which delivered 45.6 million. But the ratings Friday were in line with those of the last international games, the 2004 summer Olympics in Athens, which drew 23 million. ABC's "Dancing With the Stars" was the most-watched entertainment on Friday night, as 14.5 million watched the ouster of George Hamilton. ABC placed second to NBC in total viewers and adults 18 to 49. Less popular was the final four episodes of the critically beloved but practically invisible "Arrested Development" on Fox. From 8 to 10 p.m., an average of only 3.3 million viewers said goodbye to the Bluths. KATE AURTHUR

title: Britain Investigates Video Said to Show Abuse of Iraqi Youths by Troops
description: LONDON, Feb. 12 - The British government said Sunday that it was investigating allegations that British soldiers viciously kicked, butted and beat Iraqi teenagers in custody at an army compound in Basra in 2004.

West opens with a weak two-bid in diamonds, showing a decent six-card suit and some 6-10 high-card points. After North makes a takeout double, East raises defensively to three diamonds; he must respond with the artificial two-no-trump inquiry if he has his sights on a game. You, South, leap to four spades, ending the auction.

But he said the department is moving fast to improve its capabilities, and he denied that natural disasters take second place to terrorism on the agency's agenda.

title: Japan's Offensive Foreign Minister
description: People everywhere wish they could be proud of every bit of their countries' histories. But honest people understand that's impossible, and wise people appreciate the positive value of acknowledging and learning from painful truths about past misdeeds. Then there is Japan's new foreign minister, Taro Aso, who has been neither honest nor wise in the inflammatory statements he has been making about Japan's disastrous era of militarism, colonialism and war crimes that culminated in the Second World War.

description: NEWARK, Feb. 11 - In a recent documentary, Beenie Man did something that top dancehall reggae stars don't usually do. He said vocalists like him play a secondary role. "Dancing was before singing," he said. "Be honest."

How Can You Tell the Good Guys From the Bad? By Colors
description: Camille Saint-Sans was one of those composers able to skate across thin ice without ever falling through. The speed, the agility and the coordination of his various musical enterprises were astonishing, and with so little weight attached to all three, the composer always seemed to arrive untouched. Saint-Sans could do everything musical better than anyone else, and could do it from an early age.

But Continental Arena was roughly 75 percent empty for their game against the Milwaukee Bucks on Sunday, the result of a blizzard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EDMONDS, EDITH REED
description: EDMONDS--Edith Reed. We mourn the passing and send our deepest sympathy and condolence to our friend, John L. Edmonds, upon the loss of his wife of more than 50 years, Dr. Edith C. Reed. Dr. Reed was an outstanding NYC woman, having graduated George Washington High School and Hunter College, and then Mahari Medical School in 1951. In addition to her private practice, Dr. Reed was Chief Resident of Beth El Hospital in Brooklyn and Attending Cardiologist at Jamaica Hospital in Queens. She was a dedicated doctor and friend to all who knew her and served her city well. Phyllis and Robert Seavey Their Children and Grandchildren

title: Corrections
description: The David Pogue column in Business Day on Feb. 2, about new frontiers in digital cameras, referred imprecisely to a business that Kodak and Nikon are abandoning. It is the film-camera business, not the film business. A correction in this space on Feb. 3 misstated Nikon's current plans in the area. While the company has indeed said it is discontinuing five of its seven film cameras, it says the two others are unaffected; it has not said it is phasing those out.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about violence in Afghanistan misstated the rank of James Yonts, chief spokesman for the United States military there. He is a colonel, not a lieutenant colonel.

description: MEHLMAN - Emily. Of Brookline, MA, February 11, 2006. Beloved wife of Rabbi Bernard Mehlman. Devoted mother of Jonathan and his wife Marla, David and his wife Marcy, all of New York. Dear grandmother of Sarah, Jillian, Aliza and Ari. Loving sister of Harriet Steinberg. Services at Temple Israel, Boston, Monday, February 13. Remembrances to the River Way Project at Temple Israel or Dr. Ursula Matulonis/GYN Oncology Fund, Dana Farber Cancer Institute, 44 Binney St, Boston, MA 02215. For information Brezniak-Rodman Funeral Directors, 1-800-554-2199.

title: Corrections

It is the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, not just Independent Colleges.

description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 12 - It was a lighter Apolo Anton Ohno who stepped onto the ice at the Palavela on Sunday to defend his Olympic 1,500-meter title. A strict diet was the tool he used to chisel his body, but in the four years since the Salt Lake Games, Ohno had also shed his bad-boy image and lost his appetite for celebrity.

title: Briefs: 5 more suspects linked by DNA to train attacks
Education for Profit
description: For-profit trade schools and colleges are a useful part of the educational mix. Ethical, well-run institutions provide a valuable service for recent immigrants and other poorly prepared students who don't qualify for traditional schools or colleges. But many others are little more than diploma mills. They pump up the bottom line by enrolling large numbers of woefully unprepared students who wind up saddled with college loans and are shown the door. Unethical sales practices, in which schools misrepresent course offerings and promise more than they can ever give, have become a special area of concern.

Prosper.com, a start-up company based in San Francisco, started operations last week, offering a mixed brew of eBay, Friendster and the local bank.

It's been there since the trust was founded nearly a quarter of a century ago to administer the estate that J. Paul Getty left behind.

title: Editors' Note
description: The On Education column on Wednesday discussed an inquiry into the changing of scores for the January 2005 state Regents exam in English at John F. Kennedy High School in the Bronx, where the grades of at least 16 students were raised to passing. The column named two assistant principals who acknowledged having raised scores. It also quoted the principal, Anthony Rotunno, as saying that a third assistant principal, Terry Ballard, was also involved.

Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, MANNY
description: COHEN - Manny. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia, devoted father of Nancy Druckman and Rick Cohen. Loving grandfather of William and Katherine, dear brother of Grace Jaffe. Visitation Monday at The Riverside, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave, 7-9 pm. Funeral at Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, Tuesday, February 14 at 10:30am.

title: Amid the Cocktail-Party Banter, a Spiritual Crisis Simmers
description: For soft-spoken, troubled Robbie (Brandon Wolcott), just speaking appears to require a Herculean effort. Ask him a question and he tenses up; his face, filled with anxiety, turns toward his navel. He stammers, evades, but most of all he says, "I don't know." The lead character of David Foley's "Paradise," an articulate drama about an inarticulate young man, Robbie seems ready to snap for so long that when he does, it's almost something of a relief.

title: Down to the Wire at Ground Zero
description: Economists and lawyers working for New York City have shown why we should be concerned that Larry Silverstein, the real estate developer who held the lease to the World Trade Center, appears to have so much control over ground zero. These analysts have waded through the agreements between Mr. Silverstein and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the site. They have looked at the insurance payouts to Mr. Silverstein after the buildings he had leased for only a few weeks were destroyed. And their conclusion is grim: if Gov. George Pataki fails to persuade Mr. Silverstein to cede about half of the development rights back to the Port Authority, where they belong, the former World Trade Center site might not be rebuilt for a decade, maybe much longer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KASS, ROBERT, ''ROB.''
description: KASS--Robert, "Rob." We deeply mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Rob Kass, and extend our warmest sympathies to his wife Linda Lagos-Kass, his sons Michael and Jason, and daughter-in-law Amy, as well as a wonderful extended family and many friends. We also remember the support and guidance he provided during his eight year tenure at Choice Logistics as our President and COO. He had a passion for his work, and even more so, he loved all of his associates dearly. Choice Logistics is having a Memorial Service for Mr. Kass at the Church Center for the United Nations at 777 United Nations Plaza (44th St and 1st Ave), NY, NY 10017 on Monday, February 13, 2006 at 5 PM.

title: Rumsfeld's Algeria Agenda: Arms Sales and Closer Ties
description: RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 12 - Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld said Sunday that he discussed possible arms sales to Algeria with the country's president in what other Pentagon officials described as a growing American effort to build a military relationship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VARDY, EDITH E.
description: VARDY--Edith E. 77, died peacefully on February 10. Beloved wife of Moshe, loving mother of Joel, Iris and Michael, proud grandmother of Noah, Alex, Sofia, Andrew and David. Survived ghetto, Auschwitz, death march, slave labor. Fought for Israeli independence. Nurse, artist and speaker on the Holocaust to thousands. We will never forget.

title: A Favored Gonzo Memory
description: The widow of Hunter S. Thompson,the writer and journalist, has athank-you for his fans. Anita Thompsonsaid she had decided she wouldlet them download a rarely seen photo,her favorite, in observance of theanniversary of his death, The AssociatedPress reported. Mr. Thompsonwas 67 when he shot himself on Feb.20 last year inhis home inWoody Creek,Colo. Mrs.Thompson, explainingher decisionto offerthe image ongonzostore.com,said, "I've beensurrounded bywonderful lettersand e-mailsand cards for the entire year." Mrs.Thompson said the photo hadbeen taken at the Chateau Marmontin Los Angeles, where Mr. Thompsonwas visited by friends as he was writinga column. She said: "He has aspecial look in his eye that he hadonce in a while when he was up tosomething but was totally at peace.I've taken thousands of pictures ofhim, but this one is my favorite. Andnobody has seen it." Under the imagewill be one of his favorite quotations,typed by her on his typewriter. Shewould say no more than that the quotationconcerned Bob Dylan.

description: Can we learn anything from the real estate problems of the 1980s? There are some constants, I am sure, like lenders giving away money to people who should not be borrowing, but the economic conditions have changed dramatically.

title: A New, and Dry, Megalopolis
description: Sprawl that stretches out from Los Angeles (population: 17.5 million) and Phoenix (population: 3.9 million) is now hitting the sprawl that is stretching out from Las Vegas (population: 1.6 million) . (Total: 23 million people.) Arizona Republic columnist Jon Talton is thinking about a new development of of 160,000 houses between Kingman, Ariz. and the Arizona-Nevada state linesuburbs, really, to Las Vegas in the Mohave Desert.

title: Clooneys Empty Hands
description: From all outward signs, it would seem as if George Clooney has life by the tail. Riding not one but two movies into the Oscars, he would seem likely to walk away with one of those little guys in his hands, but not according to one handicapper. I dont think were going to win any, Mr. Clooney told reporters Friday at Berlins annual film festival. Theres been a lot of Brokeback Mountain stuff. The Bagger knows that Mr. Clooney is up against some sincere competition both in terms of acting and directing, but he also knows that the Academy would dearly love to get the one superstar of this years Oscar roster up to the microphone. It will be a long night without Mr. Clooneys trademark of sincerity and hijinks.

title: The Guy in Pajamas? My Agent.
description: For some Californians, it feels like every other neighbor is a real estate agent. They wouldnt be too far off.

title: Salt Lake City: Feeling Prosperity
description: The Sacramento Regional Research Institute, a joint venture of California State University Sacramento and the Sacramento Area Commerce and Trade Organization, tried to figure out how Californias state capital measured up against ten other western cities in terms of economic competiveness.

title: No Credit Assignment
description: Speaking of Crash, Bob Yari has lost his bid to be listed as one of the producers of the film. John Horn writes that last Thursday, the Academy rejected an appeal by Mr. Yari, who had claimed that he was unfairly denied credit for his role in making the film. The Academy was following recommendations of the Producers Guild, which has sought to reduce the number of listed producers on various projects. The guild believes that handing out production credits as deal points devalues the contributions of people who actually did the work. Mr. Yari and Mark Harris, who was also denied a credit, believe the Producers Guild has little knowledge of how independent movies actually come together in the modern era of film-making. All of the fuss is an attempt to avoid the kind of traffic jam that occurred when Shakespeare in Love won at the 1999 ceremony, with a total of five producers heading up to the stage to make a grab for the Oscar and the limelight. Mr. Horn points out that Crash was not the only movie in which credits were an issue; under the Producers Guilds more vigorously enforced standards, Colin Wilson was cut as a producer for Munich. The Academy now limits to three the number of listed producers.

title: The Bubble Bursting is a Democrats Dream
description: Im not making that claim, but Michael Mandel, a columnist for Business Week says that if real estate prices tank, it will send the economy into a spin and help the Democrats.

title: Looking for the Counter Trend
description: I am always looking for the counter trend. You knew the market had peaked when every newsmagazine discovered the home price boom and put it on the cover. I did a Nexis search on this back in August and found the peak, judging from headlines,was the previous June.

title: Crash  Slow-Motion Lead-up
description: Crash, is the darling of a certain smart set now, but there was a time when the racial parable had few friends and no backers. Mark Caro of the Chicago Tribune points out that the movie went over hill and dale to get financing, with no one willing to step up to the plate until Don Cheadle finally signed on to star. And even then, the film sparked wildly different critical responses, hardly the sort of vitae youd expect for one of the leading contenders for best film. The story itself is something of a fever dream. Paul Haggis, who wrote and directed, didnt even know it was a film to begin with:

title: Paradise Never?
description: An anonymous online petition is asking members of the Academy to withdraw the nomination of Paradise Lost for best foreign film. The petition says that by humanizing the life of two would-be suicide bombers, the film legitimizes murder:

title: 9/11 Show Trial, Bush Exceeds Authority and More
Oscars Dark Little Secret
description: The Academy doesnt like to talk about it, auctioneers are all hush-hush, and even some of the people who do the buying dont like to brag, but there is in fact an aftermarket for Oscar statues. Josh Evans, a New York auctioneer at Lelands, said peddling an Oscar is tough duty. I dont see how its possible, he said. Its almost like buying the Mona Lisa  no, like that painting The Scream. Theres no or little value, or even underground value. Its too famous. Every time the Bagger looks at an Oscar, the Mona Lisa comes to mind. Both icons share a singularly validating gaze, a look that says, I have peered into your inner soul and noticed you dont have one, but thats O.K.

title: Academy Awards Luncheon
description: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences honored this year's Oscar contenders at its annual nominees' luncheon on Monday.

title: Debating Leaks and Secrecy
description: In response to C.I.A. director Porter Gosss Times op-ed decrying intelligence leaks as the act of criminals rather than whistleblowers, Newsweeks Jonathan Alter says that todays biggest leaker of antiterrorism secrets in Washington [is] President George W. Bush.Alter writes:

title: Digging Out From Under
description: Across New York City, plows and shovels cleared away the drifts of snow that blanketed the city.

title: Bill OReilly Pledges
description: Well, were finally getting down toward the end of those Bill OReilly pledges. With maybe 500 left to be counted, the total pledged is $682,561. Thats easily enough to send Bill to Darfur for a month and buy him a truck full of sat phones.

title: Veggie Burgers
description: Mark Bittman shows how to prepare a homemade veggie burger.

title: 2006 Speaking Schedule
description: 2/16, 3 p.m.: Health Care Aconomics, University of Central Florida (at Holiday Inn Select, Orlando, Fla.)

title: Experiments in Security
description: Joe Sharkey compares Registered Traveler and Secure Flight, two initiatives aimed at improving the flow of airport security. Producer: Jonathan Berman

title: Olympic Magic
description: Joey Cheek, the newest American gold medalist in the Winter Olympics, turns out to be a pretty cool humanitarian as well as an amazing skater. After winning, he announced that he would give his entire $25,000 prize to an aid organization helping kids in Darfur.

title: Can't Be Kept Down
description: Feb. 13 - The Times's Lynn Zinser reports on how the gold and silver medalists in pairs figure skating were able to recover from horrific falls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAPLAN, JEAN RHEA BACKER
description: CAPLAN--Jean Rhea Backer. Died peacefully February 9, 2006, aged 98, at home, in Long Beach, NY. Beloved wife of the late Rabbi Harry Caplan, devoted mother of Neil (Judi) & Marc (Hannah), she was the much cherished "Granny Jean" to grandchildren Hillel (Joann), Baruch (Aliza), Ariel, Luna Leila, and Noe, and great-grandchildren Esther Malka, Gwen, Owen, and Chana Rivka. She will be missed by her brothers Moe and Labon Backer, and her nieces, nephews, and cousins. Burial will be February 15, 2006, Sir Moses Montefiore, Richmond, VA.

title: Trust Is Not a Partisan Issue (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LERMAN, MORRIS (MURRAY)
description: LERMAN--Morris (Murray). Of Lake Worth, FL, formerly of Woodmere, NY on February 10, 2006. Beloved husband of 55 years to Blanche (Useloff) Lerman. Loving father of Roberta and Alan Herman and Andy and Judi Lerman. Proud grandparent of Jaime and Daniel Herman and David and Adam Lerman. Brother of Saul Lerman. Retired Chief Executive of a manufacturing firm, Murray served in the Army during WWII. He delighted in his family and friends, went out of his way to make others happy, and was a terrific golfer and pool player. He will be missed deeply by all who knew him. Services Wednesday, February 15 at Gutterman's in Rockville Centre, 516-764-9400. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINKEL, DR. EUGENE H.
description: FINKEL--Dr. Eugene H., 90. On February 11, 2006 in Stamford, CT, formerly of Belle Harbor, New York. Devoted husband of the late Selma Newberger (Sandy), loving father of Nancy Ross (Dr. Frederick) & Robert (Linda), proud grandfather of Jordan, Jeremy, Bryan, Courtney and Shannon. Graveside services Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, N.Y. on Wednesday, February 15, 2 PM.

Paid Notice: Deaths   ITZLER, RONALD S.
description: ITZLER--Ronald S. Passed February 12, 2006. Loving husband of the late Ronnie Itzler. Adored father of Jane and David Armour & Jason. Cherished Poppy of Ryan, Dylan & Max. Caring brother of Lois and Barbara. Devoted companion of Bonnie, who filled his heart with joy. Services Wednesday, February 15, 11:15 AM, at Riverside, 76th and Amsterdam. Your zest for life will live in our hearts forever.

title: Judge Says U.S. Can't Transfer Detainee in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 - A federal judge ruled on Monday that the Bush administration could not transfer a United States citizen held by the military in Iraq to Iraqi civilian custody.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: NBC Tunes Up a Challenge to 'American Idol'

title: Arts, Briefly; Olympics and 'Grey's Anatomy' Draw Well
description: Though its ratings were down in comparison to previous years, NBC's Olympics coverage brought the network a rare Sunday victory in total viewers and households. The second night of prime-time event coverage, featuring short-track speedskating and snowboarding, drew an average of almost 23 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. ABC's regular entertainment lineup managed to hold on to the 18-to-49 demographic for the sweeps Sunday, but NBC beat ABC's "Desperate Housewives" at 9 p.m. among total viewers (26.27 million versus 23.25 million). Whether it was Olympics time period competition, a lift from its post-Super Bowl exposure last week, "Housewives" fatigue, or a combination of all three, ABC's "Grey's Anatomy" outdrew the women of Wisteria Lane for the first time. Part 2 of the hospital soap's plot in which a patient had an unexploded bazooka shell inside his chest brought in 25.3 million viewers and a higher 18-to-49 rating than "Housewives." "Grey's" also beat NBC during the 10 p.m. hour. KATE AURTHUR

title: China defends Internet censorship
As Monsters Go, This Storm Had a Lighter Tread
description: Correction Appended

title: Grand awakening of Spain's young, elegant architects
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Interior Department Plan Forgoes $7 Billion In Royalties for Domestic Oil Drilling The federal government is on the verge of one of the biggest giveaways of oil and gas in American history, an estimated $7 billion over five years. New projections, buried in the Interior Department's just-published budget plan, anticipate that the government will let companies pump about $65 billion worth of oil and natural gas from federal territory over the next five years without paying any royalties to the government. [Page A1.]

title: Ship's asbestos to be checked
Deportation Case Against Boy Is Dismissed
description: A federal immigration court judge in Manhattan yesterday dismissed the deportation proceedings against Jos Rodas, a 7-year-old whose case was described in a front-page article in The New York Times on Friday about how low-level immigration gatekeepers and prosecutors are using their growing discretionary power over travelers who pose no security risk.

title: At the Pharmacy: Prescription Labels Often Pose Language Barrier
description: Pharmacies are often unable to provide labels in Spanish, even when the pharmacy is a neighborhood where the language is widely spoken, a new study has found.

title: REALLY?
description: THE CLAIM -- High intake of sodas increases the risk of esophageal cancer.

title: Sale Helps Cendant Profit, but Forecast Is Cut
description: The Cendant Corporation, owner of the Orbitz travel Web site and the Avis car rental business, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit rose 50 percent on the sale of a unit. The company also cut its annual profit forecast, sending the shares lower after hours, when it made the announcement.

description: To the Editor:

title: The cartoon affair
New England Resort Businesses Spared From Much-Needed Snow
description: BOSTON, Feb. 13 - While the weekend's record-breaking storm left 12 to 27 inches of snow from Virginia to coastal Maine, it spared Vermont, New Hampshire and western Maine, much to the regret of ski lift operators, snowmobile clubs and businesses already reeling from a warmer-than-normal winter.

title: World Briefing | Australia: 3 Scientists Cite Pressure Over Global Warming
description: Three scientists who have studied climate change for a state science agency said the Australian government had intimidated them over their views, The Sydney Morning Herald and other newspapers reported. Graeme Pearman, left, the former director of atmospheric research at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, Australia's main science agency, said he had been reprimanded after backing a call for action to reduce greenhouse gases. Two other scientists, Barrie Pittock and Barney Foran, said they had been barred from disseminating some scientific information. The agency's deputy chief executive, Ron Sandland, said it prohibited its scientists from commenting on policy. FORD BURKHART (NYT)

title: Discover to Offer a New Debit Card
description: Discover Financial Services, which has more than 50 million cardholders, will for the first time offer a debit card to banks that previously issued only cards from Visa and MasterCard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERKINS, JOAN T.
description: PERKINS--Joan T. Joan Titcomb Perkins, beloved wife of Roswell B. Perkins, mother of Roswell, Jr., of Little Compton, RI, Laura, of Cambridge, MA, and Nancy, of Washington, D.C., grandmother of Renny and Samantha Waldron, James and Christine Perkins, and sister of Elizabeth Blow, of Rhinebeck, NY, died of cancer in her home in Manhattan on February 13, 2006. In addition to her immediate family, Joan leaves nieces, nephews, and a host of friends and godchildren who will miss her enthusiastic, generous spirit and wonderful sense of humor. A memorial service will be held Friday, February 24 at 11 A.M., at All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Ave. (between 79th and 80th Streets). In lieu of flowers, contribution may be sent to either: Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 1250 Broadway, NY, NY 10001-3701, or to Little Compton Community Center, PO Box 926, Little Compton, Rhode Island 02837.

title: Street Lit With Publishing Cred: From Prison to a Four-Book Deal
description: On a recent Saturday night, Dewitt Gilmore, 41, stepped onto an idling bus waiting to make the trip from Columbus Circle in Manhattan to the Groveland Correctional Facility in Sonyea, N.Y., near the Canadian border. Dressed in a flashy warm-up suit, he squeezed down the aisle past women and young children clutching pillows for the overnight trip.

description: To the Editor:

title: Popular Ohio Democrat Drops Out of Race, and Perhaps Politics
description: Paul Hackett, an Iraq war veteran and popular Democratic candidate in Ohio's closely watched Senate contest, said yesterday that he was dropping out of the race and leaving politics altogether as a result of pressure from party leaders.

title: Alternatives: Saw Palmetto for the Prostate? Maybe, Maybe Not
description: The fruit of the saw palmetto plant is widely used in the United States by men who believe that it can relieve swollen prostate glands. In Europe, it is commonly recommended by doctors.

description: A decent snowplow driver reporting to work the day after a major snowstorm must contend not only with snow, but also with plowing guilt.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Eritrea: U.N. Peacekeeping Workers Arrested
description: The United Nations said 13 Eritreans working with its peacekeeping force on the troubled border with Ethiopia had been arrested over the weekend, and 30 others had not reported for work. Marie Okabe, a United Nations spokeswoman, said it was not clear whether they had been detained in the dispute between the United Nations and Eritrea, which wants a 2002 border demarcation enforced, or whether they were being sought by Eritrea for ducking national military service. In November, Eritrea banned United Nations helicopter flights from its airspace and a month later expelled all Westerners from the peacekeeping mission. WARREN HOGE (NYT)

title: Harvard's President Is Again at Odds With His Faculty
description: Correction Appended

title: Ex-officials protest censorship by China
No End to Questions in Cheney Hunting Accident
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 - The White House sought with little success on Monday to quell an uproar over why it took the better part of a day to disclose that Vice President Dick Cheney had accidentally wounded a fellow hunter in Texas on Saturday and why even President Bush initially got an incomplete report on the shooting.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Air Marshals Face Drug Smuggling Charges
description: Two federal air marshals appeared in court facing charges of conspiring to smuggle 33 pounds of cocaine aboard a commercial airliner bound for Las Vegas from Houston. The air marshals, Shawn R. Nguyen and Burlie L. Sholar, were arrested Thursday, and the police said they recovered the cocaine from Mr. Nguyen's residence along with what they described as partial payment of a bribe for the smuggling. The authorities also said that in December, Mr. Nguyen, 38, used his position to circumvent airport security and transport $25,000 in illegal drug proceeds as well as bogus government documents. He and Mr. Sholar, 32, could each be fined $4 million and be sentenced to life prison terms if convicted. STEVE BARNES (NYT)

title: Two killed in Pakistan's worst wave of violence against cartoons
Paid Notice: Deaths   DOLGIN, DR. MARTIN
description: DOLGIN--Dr. Martin, 86. Of Ardsley, NY on February 12, 2006. Loving father of Barbara and Hanna, Debbie and Robert, Stuart and Deborah. Cherished grandfather of Rachel and Sam. Memorial service will be announced at a later date. Donations to the New York University School of Medicine.
