title: Roundup: Collapsed runner dies in Hong Kong
Skepticism and Praise for Change at the Met
description: Peter Gelb's bold effort to remake the Metropolitan Opera drew praise from the opera world yesterday as a necessary jolt to what some see as a stodgy institution. At the same time, the risks quickly became apparent, with some longtime audience members and others sensing betrayal of cherished traditions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RISLEY, WILLIAM S.
description: RISLEY--William S. Educational consultant and longtime resident of Washington, CT. Died February 12 of postoperative complications at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital in New York. Beloved husband of Jane, father of Mandy and Emily, stepfather of John and grandfather of Julia. He is deeply mourned as well by his stepmother, Virginia Risley deCourcy of Washington; brother John; sister Mary; and stepbrothers, Dr. Charles de Sieyes and David de Sieyes and a host of friends in Litchfield County, CT. A memorial service will be conducted Saturday at 11 A.M. in the Washington Club Hall on Route 47 in Washington. The family requests that remembrances be made in the form of contributions to the Steep Rock Association, Inc., the land trust, P.O. Box 279, Washington, CT 06794.

title: High School Graduation Rates Unacceptably Low, State Says
description: More than a third of high school students in the state scheduled to graduate last June failed to do so, State Education Commissioner Richard P. Mills said yesterday, calling the figure "unacceptable."

title: 2 Australians sentenced to die in 'Bali Nine' case
Author Applies Tools of Linguistics to Mend Mother-Daughter Divide
description: Before Deborah Tannen made her mark in her field in the 1980's, academic linguists primarily studied the sound, syntax and history of language. Dr. Tannen saw a bigger picture.

title: Yanks Entering Spring Training With More Pitchers Than Spots
description: Imagine, for a moment, that you are Scott Proctor. You are 29 and you pitched 31 games for the Yankees last season, including two in the playoffs. Your earned-run average was high, but you throw 95 miles an hour and make close to the minimum salary.

title: Marketers, Too, Are Subject to Slip-Ups While Going for Olympic Gold
description: When Michelle Kwan tearfully announced on Sunday that a groin injury would force her to withdraw from the Olympics in Turin, she was acknowledging a painful reality: she would leave her third, and probably final, Olympics without a gold medal.

title: A chance for anyone to be a banker
EU's law on services emerges in weak form
Egypt Pushes 2-Year Delay in Local Vote
description: CAIRO, Feb. 13 - President Hosni Mubarak has moved to postpone for two years local elections that were scheduled for April, turning away from a promise made during his recent presidential race to promote democratic practices, Egyptian analysts and political leaders said Monday. Thousands of local council positions were to be on the ballot.

title: Rowland Home After Serving 10 Months in Corruption Case
description: WEST HARTFORD, Feb. 13 - A thinner, more subdued John G. Rowland, Connecticut's former governor, returned to his home here on Monday afternoon after being released on Friday from a federal prison camp where he served more than 10 months after pleading guilty to corruption charges.

title: Hairspray and Gel Keep Fur From Flying at Westminster
description: Beauty pageants have their not-so-secret secrets of success: Vaseline on the teeth, hemorrhoid medicine under the eyes, tanning cream on the arms, tape on the hidden body parts to help keep everything perfectly aligned.

title: Off Course: Kildow Is Among 4 Skiers in High-Speed Falls
description: SAN SICARIO, Italy, Feb. 13 - Nearly a year ago, Lindsey Kildow, the United States' best downhill racer and one of the ski team's more charismatic figures, joined several European colleagues in a plea for a more challenging Olympic racecourse. Organizers of the Turin Olympics listened and last summer added bumps and enlarged jumps to make the courses for the downhill and super-G events more daunting.

title: Ohio Expected to Rein In Class Linked to Intelligent Design
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 13 - A majority of members on the Board of Education of Ohio, the first state to single out evolution for "critical analysis" in science classes more than three years ago, are expected on Tuesday to challenge a model biology lesson plan they consider an excuse to teach the tenets of the disputed theory of intelligent design.

description: The police fatally shot a 24-year-old Bronx man yesterday after officers burst into an apartment where he slashed and attacked four members of his family, the police said.

It is the CBS Corporation, not Viacom.

title: Taliban said to get aid in Pakistan

description: With his broad mustache and big grin, John Pye was a familiar presence in the Tremont section of the Bronx, where he lived all his life. He ran the hardware store, made a daily appearance at the Cross Town Diner and was active in the Sons of Italy.

title: Recognizing Good Fortune, Cheek Shares Gold Medal
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 13 - Joey Cheek of the United States arrived at the starting line for the first of his two heats in the 500 meters Monday with a strategy, which was unheard of. Most long-track speedskaters will tell you that the shortest race on the Olympic program is over too soon to scheme for anything other than a fast start and a clean trip around the oval.

title: If You Want a Film to Fly, Make Americans the Heavies
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REBHUN, DR. LIONEL EARL
description: REBHUN--Dr. Lionel Earl. Of Boca Raton, FL. formerly of Lake Success, NY passed away February 10 after a long illness. Dr. Rebhun practiced Dentistry in Flushing, NY. He graduated with honors from Columbia University Dental School in 1948. Dr. Rebhun was a member of William Jarvie Society and OKU. Beloved husband of Pearl. Father of Laurence, Kit, Andrew and Dr's Donald and Francine Rebhun. Grandfather of Caroline, Chad, Carl, Nicholas and Coby. Loving brother of Elsa Cohen and Allan. He will be interred at Beth Moses Cemetery on Long Island. Shiva will be at his residence in Florida. Donations can be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: An Elegant Exit
description: Michelle Kwan's gracious departure from the Olympics deserves a salute. She was a last-minute addition to the American figure-skating team in Turin, and was poised to make a dramatic third attempt at a gold medal, which she has never won. But a horrible practice session there and a groin injury convinced Ms. Kwan that she should go home. This clears the way for an understudy, Emily Hughes, to dash over from Great Neck High School to join the Games, whose appetite for melodrama continues, Kwan or no Kwan.

title: Rallying Call From the Siege of Leningrad
description: When the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam last performed in New York, in 2004, it was led by a guest conductor, Herbert Blomstedt, but its spectacular sound provided assurance that its departing music director, Riccardo Chailly, had left it in fine shape. Mariss Jansons took over as director a few months later, and this week he has brought the orchestra to Carnegie Hall for two concerts that are giving New Yorkers a first glimpse of this new collaboration.

title: Why Wait for Nature's Thaw When There's the Diesel-Powered Kind?
description: It is a measure of New York's impatience that the city does not wait for snow to melt. It has machines to do the job -- big, noisy orange machines that warm snow to the consistency of a Sno-Kone or Slurpee that has been around too long.

title: Moussaoui Is Banned From Courtroom
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 A The confessed Al Qaeda plotter Zacarias Moussaoui berated the judge today and was banned from the courtroom during the jury-selection process that will determine whether he lives or dies.

title: City's Day of Delays, Shoveling and School
description: As commuters throughout the New York region returned to work yesterday, the routines of daily life had a hit-or-miss quality. Major city streets were cleared, but officials warned of possible floods from melting snow as meteorologists projected midweek temperatures in the low 50's. The city's public schools were open, though many Catholic schools were closed. On the economic front, companies reported delays in deliveries, but hotels and restaurants said stranded travelers seemed to make up for canceled reservations.

description: When rats pause in running through a maze, they play back their memory of points along their route, but in reverse order.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 - The Energy Department no longer has an estimate of when it can open the nuclear waste repository that it wants to build at Yucca Mountain, 90 miles northwest of Las Vegas, and it may never have an accurate prediction of the cost, the energy secretary said on Monday.

title: INSIDE
description: Hurricane Evacuees Begin Leaving Hotel Rooms For 12,000 families of evacuees from Hurricane Katrina, including 4,400 in New Orleans, it was the last day the government paid for their hotel rooms. In Arkansas, mobile homes worth hundreds of millions of dollars are deteriorating in a muddy field and may never be used to house hurricane victims, federal officials acknowledged. PAGE A18

title: Maybe He's Just Not Into You, Helena
description: Whether the genre is comedy, tragedy or history, it's no secret to regular theatergoers that all often does not go well for Shakespeare, even on stages in New York City, the country's theater capital. If the actress playing the cross-dressing ingnue is lovely and affecting, her paramour may be played by a cardboard charmer with a popular television show on his rsum. Or maybe the clowns hit their marks, but the love-struck youngsters speak verse as if they're reading the list of additives from the back of a cereal box.

Mr. Kibaki announced on national television that Education Minister George Saitoti, left, and Energy Minister Kiraitu Murungi would be leaving their posts to allow for further investigations of their activities. A recent investigation of the decade-old Goldenberg scandal recommended that the attorney general consider filing criminal charges against Mr. Saitoti. Mr. Murungi has been accused of trying to interfere with the investigation of the more recent scandal involving Anglo Leasing and Finance. MARC LACEY (NYT)

title: Fares at Dulles
description: FARES AT DULLES -- Many analysts predicted that the collapse of the discount carrier Independence Air last month would lead to higher airfares at Dulles International Airport near Washington. The airport had some of the highest average fares in the nation before Independence Air began operating there in 2004, forcing competitors to lower ticket prices. Over all, fares have not gone up much since Independence Air closed on Jan. 5, industry analysts say. But on flights in which passengers depart and return on the same day, once a staple of Independence Air's short-haul network, ticket prices have risen significantly, said Terry Trippler, the airfare analyst at Cheapseats.com. When Independence Air folded, he found, the round-trip fare for same-day flights between Dulles and Buffalo on United Airlines was $158. A month later, it had risen to $618. Dulles to Pittsburgh went to $900, from $78, on United and to $900, from $228, on US Airways.

It took the White House nearly 24 hours to share that information with the rest of the nation because Dick Cheney thought it would be better for the ranch's owner to give the story to the local newspaper first. And by the way, it was all the victim's fault.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Saturday about the Arab-American playwright Yussef El Guindi and his new play, "Back of the Throat," erroneously attributed a view about the scarcity of Arab-American playwrights. It was Rabiah Ahmed, a spokeswoman for the Council of American-Islamic relations, not Jamil Khoury, a founder of the Silk Road Theater Project in Chicago, who said that conservatism within Muslim culture might be one reason, and that representations of the human form were frowned on and that dancing or performing by women in front of men was considered reprehensible.

National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Rail Company To Pay City Over Fire
description: CSX Transportation agreed to pay the City of Baltimore $2 million to cover costs of the city's response to a 2001 freight train accident and fire in an underground tunnel downtown. The agreement came in a settlement of a federal lawsuit by the city against CSX. The 60-car train derailed in a tunnel in July 2001, igniting a chemical fire that burned for days. It forced businesses to close, put downtown traffic in gridlock, delayed East Coast freight shipments and canceled Orioles baseball games. The city and CSX also agreed to improve communications about rail shipments and to ask the federal and state authorities to inspect the tunnel. The settlement blames neither the city nor CSX for the accident. GARY GATELY (NYT)

Then Dr. Phil McGraw (above, with Ms. Abdul) watches the tape of it and tells her what she did wrong. After that, Dr. McGraw counsels a 25-year-old womanizing bachelor who says he wants to change.

description: KAUFMAN - Seymour. On February 13th, Seymour Kaufman, 76, died quietly and in peace after a long illness with his family by his side. For more than 50 years he was an educator, as a teacher and principal in New York City, as founder of Kaufman Tutoring, and as the best example of a beloved father and husband. He leaves to mourn him his devoted wife Joan Robin, his children Sharon, Lauren, Dena, and Andy and daughterin-law Debbie Bauman. His grandchildren Evan and Anna Rose will greatly miss their Beepa. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DE GUNZBURG, BARON GUY GEORGES
description: de GUNZBURG--Baron Guy Georges, born in Paris January 1, 1911. With great sorrow, we announce the death of Baron de Gunzburg, January 16, 2006 in Miami. He will be mourned by his wife Baroness Mary de Gunzburg, his sister Madame Giorgio Uzielli; his children Baron JeanLouis de Gunzburg, Madame Eliane de Gunzburg Beckman and Baron Gerard de Gunzburg; his grandchildren Veronique Albersmeier, Jacques Heim, Alexia de Gunzburg, Gregory de Gunzburg and his twin greatgrandchildren Julia and Vanessa Albersmeier and by his stepchildren Robert Malcolm Buxton, Lucy Geppert and Mary Hess. Baron de Gunzburg was schooled in Paris and Switzerland and he survived the evacuation of Dunkerque in 1940 and served in the Free French and British Armies during WWII. Later he became an American citizen. Baron de Gunzburg had three friends who were always there for him personally and professionally: Peter De Gaetano, Joseph Cooper and Steven Thaler. A man of varied talents, he enjoyed sculpting and writing and cultivated a beautiful farm in Virginia. Baron Guy was a benefactor of the Mayo Clinic, Rochester and the Center for Excellence Program for Nurses at Baptist Hospital in Miami. All who knew him will miss him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CURTIS, CHRISTINE WINDISCH VON GOEBEN
description: CURTIS--Christine Windisch von Goeben, granddaughter of the late Frederick and Hedda von Goeben Behr of this city died at the age of 77 at the River Glenn Rehabilitation Center in Southbury, CT on February 11. She is survived by her husband John Robert Curtis, Jr., three sons, Carl Gavin, Allen Richard and Robert Frederick, and one sister, Hedda Windisch von Goeben. Funeral services will be held in the Roxbury, Connecticut Congregational Church on Friday, February 17 at 10:30 A.M. Please, no flowers. If you wish to leave a token in remembrance to her, perhaps you might wish to make a donation in her name to one of your favorite charities or to the Christine Curtis Memorial Scholarship Fund administered by the Connecticut Community Foundation, 43 Field Street, Waterbury, CT 06702. Born in New York City, Christine spent her formative years in Belle Haven, Greenwich. She graduated from the Greenwich and Abbott Academies and Smith College. She and her husband met in Vienna, Austria while both were working there for the Central Intelligence Agency during the Allied occupation of that city after the end of WWII. They were married in Washington, CT in April of 1954 and just missed celebrating their 52nd wedding anniversary this year. Christine will be remembered for her countless good works to aid humanity. In so doing, she followed in the footsteps of her grandfather Behr, founder of the Behr-Manning Corporation of NYC (Now part of Norton Abrasives). Through philanthropy and a willingness to get her hands dirty in projects in various countries to assist the needy, she became known far and wide as a true soldier of charity. She and her husband traveled broadly both with the U.S. Foreign Service and privately. They lived in Spain for twenty years before returning to Connecticut in 1989 to reside in Heritage Village. Immediately she involved in numerous important chores in that large community including the presidency of the Volunteer Ambulance Association for six years.

title: Violence Flares as Top Candidate Slips in Haiti Count
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 13 - Tens of thousands of people paralyzed traffic with flaming barricades here on Monday, charging fraud in the tabulation of votes from the election for president last week, and demanding that Ren Prval be declared Haiti's next president, even though results suggested that he had not won the required majority of votes in the first round.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENCHLEY, PETER
description: BENCHLEY--Peter. On behalf of the trustees and staff of Environmental Defense, it is with great sadness that we note the passing of Environmental Defense supporter Peter Benchley on February 11. Peter was a passionate, powerful, advocate for the Oceans. Generous with his time and an engaging, entertaining speaker, Peter was the ideal ambassador for Environmental Defense's ocean conservation work. We remember with great appreciation his service on the National Council, the public events he headlined, and, more recently, the opinion pieces he co-authored with Environmental Defense calling on America to view her oceans as the national treasure they are, protecting them in the same way we have protected our great treasures on land in National Parks. His dedication, energy and sense humor were an inspiration. We will miss him greatly and extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Wendy, and their children and grandchildren. Fred Krupp, President Environmental Defense N.J. Nicholas, Jr. Chairman of the Board, Environmental Defense

title: An Illegal Drug From Labs That Can't Be Shut Down
description: The active ingredient in methamphetamine is the same substance found in Sudafed: ephedrine or pseudoephedrine. It can be acquired either by "smurfing" -- buying a few packs of cold medicine here and there till you have a hoard -- or more brazenly, by appealing to one of the world's nine major ephedrine factories. From there, you cook it for days, like sauerkraut. Then you bag and sell it.

description: EDMONDS--Edith Reed. We mourn the passing and send our deepest sympathy and condolence to our friend, John L. Edmonds, upon the loss of his wife of more than 50 years, Dr. Edith C. Reed. Dr. Reed was an outstanding NYC woman, having graduated George Washington High School and Hunter College, and then Mahari Medical School in 1951. In addition to her private practice, Dr. Reed was Chief Resident of Beth El Hospital in Brooklyn and Attending Cardiologist at Jamaica Hospital in Queens. title: World Briefing | Australia: Iraq Suspends Purchase Of Australian Wheat
description: Iraq has suspended the purchase of wheat from the Australian wheat export company AWB pending an Australian royal commission investigation into allegations that AWB paid more than $200 million in kickbacks to Saddam Hussein's government from 1999 through 2003, in violation of United Nations sanctions. Iraq's move is certain to please American wheat farmers. U.S. Wheat Associates, a trade association representing American wheat growers, had urged the American-led Coalition Provisional Authority in Iraq to take similar action after Mr. Hussein was toppled in 2003, and has led an effort to have AWB investigated. The Australian trade minister, Mark Vaile, called Iraq's action "regrettable given that Australia has been a reliable supplier of high quality wheat to Iraq for many years." RAYMOND BONNER (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Science Medals Awarded
description: President Bush presented the national medals of science and technology to 10 people and 5 companies, saying the medals were the "highest award a president can bestow for astounding achievement in science and technology." Among those honored were Kenneth J. Arrow of Stanford, for his contributions in the field of economics; Thomas E. Starzl of the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, for his work in organ transplantation and immunosuppressive medication; Dennis P. Sullivan of the City University of New York Graduate Center and State University of New York at Stony Brook, for his work in mathematics; the microelectronics division at I.B.M., for innovation in semiconductor technology; and Motorola, for work in mobile communications. The medal of science award, established by Congress in 1959, is administered by the National Science Foundation; the medal of technology, established by Congress in 1980, is administered by the Commerce Department. JOHN FILES (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Natural Gas Reserves to Be Tapped
description: Italy expects to start tapping strategic natural gas reserves today or tomorrow after the latest dip in supplies from Russia, an industry ministry official said. Exactly when will depend on consumption, the ministry spokesman, Sandro Staffolani, said. "The gas reserves should last long enough to get through the remaining part of winter unless there are further reductions in gas," Mr. Staffolani said. "These could be caused either by periods of great cold or from a reduction in supplies from Russia." Should that happen, an emergency plan outlined Saturday by Industry Minister Claudio Scajola would carried out, Mr. Staffolani said. Under the plan, energy exports would be blocked, energy imports would be stepped up and gas supplies could be cut off to some major customers, he said. Earlier yesterday, the Italian oil and gas company Eni said it expected natural gas supplies to Italy from Russia to be 16.2 percent below requested volumes for the 24-hour period starting that morning. Russia's natural gas monopoly, Gazprom, says the supply reductions to European customers do not violate contracts.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GRETSCH CHARLOTTE SOMMER GRETSCH
description: GRETSCH Charlotte Sommer Gretsch 1880-1928 It is with great respect and loving memories that we honor Charlotte Sommer Gretsch on the anniversary of her 125th birthday. Born on December 16, 1880 in Brooklyn, NY, she entered into eternal rest on May 12, 1928. Charlotte was the only daughter of seven children born to William and Theresa Sommer who later resided in Manhattan. She was the devoted wife of the late Fred Gretsch, president of the Fred Gretsch Mfg Co. in Brooklyn, the world's largest musical instrument factory. Charlotte was a very dedicated mother of 3 boys, Fred Jr., William & Richard. Her love was apparent in every aspect of her faith, family, and friends. She was an esteemed benefactor to many charities and organizations. Those who knew Charlotte Gretsch often referred to her as a "saint." Happy 125th Birthday! The Family of Fred Gretsch Sr.

title: Evolution, Not Revolution, as Schoenberg Might Say
description: In an essay called "How One Becomes Lonely," an embittered Arnold Schoenberg looked back in 1937 and recalled the process of losing his public. Countless listeners wondered why he had not continued writing in the lush intoxicated style of his early masterpiece "Verklrte Nacht" but had instead broken with the past to embrace a harsh atonal language. What his interrogators failed to see, he lamented, was just how much of the old there was in the new. His music was only a logical extension of the preceding trends in music history, he argued, more evolution than revolution.

title: For Miller, a High, Then Another Low
description: SESTRIERE, Italy, Feb. 14 A Bode Miller, leading by nearly a full second after the first of three races in the Olympic men's combined, missed a gate in the second stage of the event Tuesday and was disqualified. Miller, a gold medal favorite in what is his best event, failed to get both skis around one of 56 gates in the first of two slalom races scheduled here. Earlier in the day, in the downhill run that opened the combined competition, Miller had routed the field, taking a lead of 2 minutes and 8 seconds over his chief rival, Austria's Benjamin Raich.

Loving grandfather of Elizabeth, Arthur Jr., Thomas, Lyn, Tamara, Lori and Kristi. Adored by his 13 great-granchildren. Loved brother of Joan Green and Benjamin Jacobson, Jr. Some knew him as the great amateur golf champion that he was. Others knew him as a superb specialist and businessman for over 50 years on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. But first in his life was his family and he will be forever missed because he was such a loving Dad, Grandfather and GreatGrandfather. Services will be held at Frank E. He was elected to the Board of Trustees in 1976. His generosity, good humor and commitment to the welfare of youth will be remembered by us all with deep affection. Jim was appointed Honorary Trustee of The Boys Club of New York in 2005. While his steadfast commitment to BCNYs mission was felt at all levels of the organization, it was his belief that international travel was a critically important aspect of a young person's education that distinguished his term of service. title: L.A. Times: Lets Rub Out Valentines Day
Munich Makes a Move
description: Yesterday word came that subscribers in some of Los Angeles better zip codes opened up their morning paper to find a full-page ad touting Munich for best picture. It could be that Universal is just doing what it should for a film it backed, but there may be a subplot. Focus Features, which has the prohibitive favorite in Brokeback Mountain, is a division of Universal, so it would seem odd for a company to spend money competing with itself. But perhaps studio execs are unimpressed by Brokebacks homestretch and want to hedge a bit. And they may be miffed that so many specialty divisions and indies are ruling what has been a historically a big party of the big guys. The Bagger wonders whether the folks at Universal sense an opening  sure, they would like Brokeback to do well. But if the talk that it may not go all the way is more than that, well, if not BB, then why not Munich? It is an Important Film, by an Important Director  Steven Spielberg  and written by one of the most Important Playwrights of Our Time  Tony Kushner. Mr. Kushner told CNN that when people go to the movie house, they are expecting more than a bag of popcorn: Were living in very fraught, complicated times, and I think that when we live in times like these, that people expect their entertainment, as well as their newspapers, to help them think their way through things, said Mr. Kushner.

title: Shoot First, Talk Much, Much Later
description: Its not every day the vice president shoots a man and then decides not to tell the public about it for almost 24 hours. Simple accident or symbol of a White House culture of secrecy? Count the Washington Post editorial page among those in the latter camp: Saturdays incident required immediate public disclosure  a fact so elementary that the failure to act properly is truly disturbing in its implications. On the Posts op-ed page, columnist Eugene Robinson sees Cheneys hunting accident as a metaphor for the Bush administrations foreign policy as well: The man is out of control. Then again, out-of-control is the way this whole administration operates: Ready, fire, aim. Global war on terrorism, global war on poultry, whats the difference? You see something moving, shoot it. (The Times editorial page says the White House once again demonstrated that it would rather look inept than open.)

description: LEVIN--Alan M., 79. Of Maplewood, NJ, died peacefully in his sleep February 13, 2006. Loving husband of the late Hannah Jane Alexander Levin. Devoted and beloved father of Marc and his wife Ellin, Nicole, Danielle and her husband David and Juliette and her husband James; grandfather of Sara, Daniel, Benjamin, Julia, Sophia, Molly, Lucy and Rebecca; and adored brother of Helen Sacks and Sue Miller. He touched countless lives with his passion for life with boundless optimism. Daddy, we love you forever. Burial services will be private. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: A Dancing British Brood in a Feast of Fancies
description: LEEDS, England, Feb. 12 - To a friend, the news that I was going to fly across an ocean and see 34 dance performances in slightly less than three days evoked images of circus clowns in tiny cars, or the Keystone Kops. To me, at the end of the marathon late Saturday night, the whole experience seemed just exhausting.

title: State Sues E.P.A. for Files on Household Pollutants
description: ALBANY, Feb. 14 - As New York and other states grapple with the gradually tightening requirements of the Clean Air Act, the Environmental Protection Agency is refusing to turn over records detailing the levels of smog-causing compounds found in common household and industrial products like paints and varnishes.

title: From International All-Stars, a Mix of Styles
description: They don't make ballet galas like they used to. "Stars of the 21st Century International Ballet Gala," produced every year somewhere in the world by Solomon Tencer and directed by his wife, Nadia Veselova Tencer, rolled into the New York State Theater on Monday night looking more like a classy variety show.

title: 9 condemned to death for terror plotin Jordan
World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Election Challenge Quashed
description: The Supreme Court rejected a four-year effort by Morgan Tsvangirai, the former political opposition leader, to overturn Robert G. Mugabe's victory over him in the 2002 presidential election. Mr. Tsvangirai had argued that the election was flawed by vote fraud and intimidation, a judgment shared by many outside election monitors at the time. The court's five-judge panel said in a 20-page opinion that the charge was without merit. Mr. Tsvangirai's party, Movement for Democratic Change, has since been riven by internal bickering; its two factions will hold separate conventions in a few weeks to elect new leaders. Mr. Mugabe, who turns 82 this month and has ruled Zimbabwe for 25 years, recently said he might run for president again if his country needed him. MICHAEL WINES (NYT)

title: To Market a City Condom, Make It Catchy but Tasteful
description: It is probably safe to say that the marketing challenges posed by what may be the world's first municipal condom are a bit daunting.

title: Madison Square Garden Owners Discuss One-Block Move
description: The owners of Madison Square Garden, the storied arena that is inextricably tied to the city's sports history, are close to an agreement with two developers to move one block west to a new $750 million home on Ninth Avenue, according to real estate executives and government officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERKINS, JOAN T.
description: PERKINS--Joan T. Joan Titcomb Perkins, beloved wife of Roswell B. Perkins, mother of Roswell, Jr., of Little Compton, RI, Laura, of Cambridge, MA, and Nancy, of Washington, D.C., grandmother of Renny and Samantha Waldron, James and Christine Perkins, and sister of Elizabeth Blow, of Rhinebeck, NY, died of cancer in her home in Manhattan on February 13, 2006. In addition to her immediate family, Joan leaves nieces, nephews, and a host of friends and godchildren who will miss her enthusiastic, generous spirit and wonderful sense of humor. A memorial service will be held Friday, February 24 at 11 A.M., at All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Ave. (between 79th and 80th Streets). In lieu of flowers, contribution may be sent to either: Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 1250 Broadway, NY, NY 10001-3701, or to Little Compton Community Center, PO Box 926, Little Compton, Rhode Island 02837.

description: THE print media, beset by intensifying competition for advertising dollars, are seeking to strike back.

With New Lead, Much the Same Sound
description: Thousands of auditions produced 15 contestants, of various colors and sexes, for "Rock Star: INXS," the CBS reality show that selected a new lead singer for the Australian band INXS. The show ran three times a week and went through dozens of songs and countless wardrobe changes, power chords and live-your-dream clichs. Then INXS simply chose the closest sound-alike to Michael Hutchence, its original lead singer, who killed himself in 1997.

title: Westminster Result Feels Like an Upset, but Isn't
description: An athletic yellow Labrador retriever named Buzz was freed from its pen yesterday afternoon, and smiling people quickly gathered around, as they do when Labs are loose.

title: When Searching for Love, Don't Forget Your Calculator
description: A nonsensical mathematical formula drives the plot of "I Love You Because," a new musical at the Village Theater, so it seems appropriate to sum up the play with a formula that also sounds a little daffy: four characters you're sick of seeing, plus one story that has nothing new to say, equals -- an infectiously entertaining show?

title: Slaying Suspect Faking Insanity, Doctor Testifies
description: A man accused of killing an actress in a botched robbery on the Lower East Side after she challenged him by asking, "What are you going to do, shoot us?" is faking mental illness, a psychiatrist testified yesterday

title: Chirac Orders Return of Ship Over Asbestos Concerns
description: PARIS, Feb. 15 A President Jacques Chirac today ordered the return of the decommissioned aircraft carrier Clemenceau to French waters after France's highest court suspended the carrier's transfer to an Indian scrapheap over concerns that the ship contains unsafe amounts of asbestos.

title: Burgers With Lots of Sizzle and None of the Guilt
description: VEGGIE burgers are nothing new; I remember them from the kosher dairy restaurants of the Lower East Side when I was growing up. But they have gone mainstream  and in the process, for the most part, they've become worse.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Euro Zone Growth Slows to 0.3%
description: Growth in the $9 trillion euro zone economy grew only 0.3 percent in the fourth quarter from the previous three months, when it expanded at twice that rate, the European Union's statistics office said in Luxembourg. The German economy, the region's largest, failed to grow, a separate government report showed. But European finance ministers expressed optimism in the face of the sluggish figures. "The fourth-quarter growth results for the euro zone were rather disappointing, below what we'd expected," Jean-Claude Juncker, prime minister of Luxembourg, above, said after leading a meeting of his counterparts in Brussels. "Nonetheless, we have a view that growth is strengthening." Euro area growth weakened as oil prices held near $60 a barrel and the United States economy grew the least in three years. The commission will update its growth forecasts next week.

title: Students and Cardinal Call for Private-School Tax Aid
description: ALBANY, Feb. 14 - Thousands of students from yeshivas and Roman Catholic schools gathered on the steps of the Capitol on Tuesday with their teachers, rabbis and priests -- even Cardinal Edward M. Egan -- to call for the support of the governor's proposal to provide a tax credit that could be used to pay for private or parochial schools.

description: Retail Sales Rose 2.3 Percent Last Month, Showing Promise of a Strong 2006 Economy Shaking off a middling holiday shopping season and fears of higher heating bills, Americans spent freely in January as retail spending rose 2.3 percent in the month, up from 0.4 percent in December. The report provided reassurance that the economy is beginning the year with fresh strength. [Page A1.]

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Corruption Suspects Disarmed
description: The government's crackdown on corruption continued as the police ordered a cabinet minister, a former president's two sons and others tied to a decade-old misappropriation of funds to hand in their passports and any firearms they might hold. George Saitoti, who resigned as education minister under pressure Monday from President Mwai Kibaki's government, was at the top of the list of suspects in the so-called Goldenberg scandal. Others include Gideon and Philip Moi, the sons of former President Daniel arap Moi; a former chief prosecutor; a former intelligence chief; and a member of Parliament. MARC LACEY (NYT)

title: Lawmakers Plan an Effort to Reverse Royalty Relief
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 - Democratic lawmakers and the White House both said on Tuesday that oil and gas companies should not receive lucrative incentives when energy prices are near record highs.

title: Judge Ejects 9/11 Suspect After Outburst
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Feb. 14 - A federal trial judge ejected Zacarias Moussaoui from the courtroom on Tuesday after his latest outburst and said he could observe the next weeks of his trial only from a closed-circuit television system in a nearby cell.

description: THE first time I visited Stir It Up, Sonia Gordon, the restaurant's chef and owner, came out of the kitchen before we were seated and apologetically told our group that she had nothing left to serve us but goat roti.

title: Investigator Rebukes City Schools Over Retirement of a Principal
description: The special commissioner of investigation for the city school system rebuked the Department of Education yesterday for allowing the principal of Brooklyn Technical High School to retire days before the completion of an investigation into his daughter's improper enrollment in a Brooklyn elementary school.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 - When the White House press secretary, Scott McClellan, came to the press room just before 10 a.m. Tuesday and suggested he was wearing an orange tie to avoid a stray shot from Vice President Dick Cheney, it seemed to signal an effort to defuse the accidental-shooting story with a laugh.

title: New York in White and, Briefly, in Repose
description: A heavy snowfall visits the city in several stages. First it makes its entrance, grand and commanding, forcing every activity to pivot around its fall. The beauty of the falling snow last weekend was hypnotic. But it was outdone by the next stage, snowfall's end.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9 P.M. (ABC) LOST -- Is it possible that one of the plane-crash survivors on the island is part of the feared group know as the Others? Rousseau (a k a the crazy Frenchwoman) leads Sayid to a captive who could be one of them. Sawyer (Josh Holloway, left), who proved himself to be an unrepentant con man last week, is worried about a strange creature that won't leave him alone. And it turns out that Hurley, who seemed so harmless, has betrayed everyone's trust.

title: The Lewds and the Prudes Offer Much to Sing About
description: Felicity Lott's recitals tend to be livelier than most, probably because she doesn't worry much about keeping composers, eras, styles or even languages sorted into strictly defined groups. Her concern, instead, is with larger themes, assembled with songs of all stripes -- serious and comic, from the heart of the classical repertory or the periphery. And her programming signature is her way of weaving subsidiary themes through the evening.

description: "I wish it were one-tenth the cost, and if it were I would be giving it to almost everybody."

title: Advisories on Fish and the Pitfalls of Good Intent
description: SHOPPING for fish these days is fraught with confusion. There is so much contradictory information about what is safe and what isn't. Some nutritionists are worried that people will throw up their hands and choose steak instead.

title: Hussein, Gleeful, Badgers the Judge and Declares a Hunger Strike Over His Treatment
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 14 - A defiant Saddam Hussein marched into court on Tuesday and declared that he and his co-defendants had begun a hunger strike to protest their treatment by those overseeing their trial.

title: Ohio Board Undoes Stand on Evolution
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 14 - The Ohio Board of Education voted 11 to 4 Tuesday to toss out a mandate that 10th-grade biology classes include critical analysis of evolution and an accompanying model lesson plan, dealing the intelligent design movement its second serious defeat in two months.

title: Michael Gilbert, 93, Dies; Wrote Law Into His Mysteries
description: Michael Gilbert, who somehow managed to produce dozens of intricately plotted and gracefully written detective stories, police procedural novels, espionage thrillers, puzzle mysteries and crime-based plays for stage, radio and television while carrying on a separate career as a senior partner in a firm of London solicitors, died on Feb. 8 at his home in Luddesdown, Kent. He was 93.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 A Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff bears responsibility for a multitude of errors that prolonged the suffering of thousands of Gulf Coast residents, Republicans and Democrats on a Senate committee investigating the response to Hurricane Katrina charged today.

Paid Notice: Deaths  DASSEVILLE, REV. ARMAND
description: DASSEVILLE--Rev. Armand. The Capuchin Mission Association offers their prayers for Fr. Armand who passed into Eternal Life on February 13, 2006. Fr. Armand was a known preacher, promoter of the Province of St. Mary's Burse program and foreign missions, Director of the Secular Franciscan Order at the Capuchin Church of St. John the Baptist, and great devotee of recently canonized Padre Pio. He was a Capuchin Friar for 64 years, a priest, 59 years and he ministered from St. John's Friary for 40 years. May he rest in peace! Wake: February 16, 1:30 to 8 with a Prayer Service at 7 PM. Funeral Mass: Friday, 10:30 AM. Interment Capuchin Friars Cemetery, Yonkers, NY 1 PM. Services at the Church of St. John the Baptist, 210 W. 31 St, 564-9070.

Cherished sister of Diana and Richard. Also survived by many other family members and friends. Family will receive friends on Thursday, 6-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Funeral Mass Friday at 10 AM at the Cathedral of St. Patrick, 51st St and Fifth Ave. Private cremation to follow.

If the Next Mermaid You See Doesn't Know Salmon
description: ALL canned salmon in this survey is wild, according to the labels. Most of it is packed the traditional way, with the bones and the skin. Prices vary wildly. Dave's salmon was the most expensive but certainly tasted the best. When salmon is mixed with mayonnaise, sweet pepper relish and lemon, it is hard to distinguish a good-tasting one from a bland one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAWSON, DONALD S. GEN. USAF RET.
description: DAWSON--Donald S. Gen. USAF Ret. Exec. Asst. to Harry S. Truman, attorney, humanitarian, loving husband, father and friend. Died December 25 at age 97 of stroke at his home in Bethesda, MD. surrounded by family & friends. A true American patriot, born in El Dorado Springs, Missouri, graduated Univ. of Missouri 1930 & Law Degree from George Washington Univ. 1938. Instrumental in drafting The Marshall Plan, integration of armed forces, chaired White House Loyalty Review Board, established by Truman. Organized & directed Harry S. Truman whistle-stop campaign train in 1948 which was crucial to Truman victory. Became Sr. Ptr. in law firm of Dawson, Griffin Pickens in 1953 & later Dawson Riddell Holroyd Taylor & Davis. In 1968 went into solo practice. His leadership in national & international organizations included, president of Truman Library. Headed committee to rename State Dept Bldg The Harry S. Truman Building, Inst. of National & International Affairs, Humane Soc. of US, US College of the Virgin Islands, American Friends of Jamaica, The Dwight D. Eisenhower Society of Gettysburg, PA. National Reserve Officers Assoc. Hungarian Freedom Fighters, Arthritis & Rheumatism Foundation & The National Press Club. In lieu of flowers, in his memory, kindly send donations to: National Institute of Neurological Disorders & Stroke (310-496-4927). He is survived by his loving wife Virginia J. Dawson, daughters Diana Coyner Dawson, Virginia Fox, son Robert Fox, and four grandchildren & one great grandson. Interment will be at The Arlington National Cemetery following Memorial Service at The Washington National Cathedral on Thursday, February 16 at 11 A.M.

title: Merrill Lynch Reaches Deal on BlackRock
description: Merrill Lynch said today that it had reached a deal to sell its asset management business to BlackRock for a 49.8 percent stake in the combined entity, which would be the largest publicly traded fund company as measured by assets.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: France Tlcom to Cut Jobs
description: France Tlcom said it that would cut 17,000 jobs, or about 8 percent of its work force, as it predicted a shift into Internet telephony by the end of the year. "What has changed is the pace of evolution," said Didier Lombard, the chief executive of France Tlcom, in a Webcast conference with analysts. He said the company was "in crisis mode," and it would cut 23,000 positions and create 6,000 new ones. Separately, the company announced a 89 percent rise in net income to 5.71 million euros, but the figure was skewed by the acquisition of the rest of Equant, a data network company, and the sale of 45 percent of the Pages Jaunes Group, a telephone directory company, in 2004 and 2005.

title: U.S. Mounts a Vast Hunt for Church Arsonists
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Feb. 14 - In the largest manhunt in Alabama since the bombing of a Birmingham abortion clinic in 1998, 200 law enforcement officers are working to solve the arson that has damaged or destroyed 10 rural churches this month.

title: Study Finds Calcium Supplements Don't Prevent Broken Bones
description: Calcium and vitamin D supplements increased the risk of kidney stones but did not prevent broken bones or colorectal cancer in middle-aged and elderly women, according to an extensive study whose results are to be published Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: The Books of The Times review on Saturday, about "Timothy," by Verlyn Klinkenborg, misidentified the person who brought Timothy, a tortoise, to England in the 18th century. While the person is not identified in the book, it was not a son of Gilbert White; he had no son. The review also misstated the route. It was directly from Turkey to England, not via Madagascar. (Two other tortoises were brought to England from Madagascar by the son of a neighbor of White.)

title: 11 Killed, Including 4 Children, in Iraqi Violence
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 15 A At least 11 people, including four children, were killed in a surge of bombings and assassinations in the capital today.

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday with an article about the relative absence of disruptions in the New York region during the weekend snowstorm misstated a figure in some copies for the snow that had fallen at La Guardia Airport by 7 p.m. Sunday. It was 25.4 inches, not 19.5.

title: A One-House, $400 Million Bubble Goes Pop
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 14 - After buying their two-bedroom ranch-style home in Valparaiso, Ind., two years ago, Daelyn and Dennis Charnetzky gutted the bathroom, refinished the hardwood floors, painted, wallpapered and did some landscaping. The improvements undoubtedly increased the home's value, but by hundreds of millions of dollars?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANK, JACOB
description: FRANK--Jacob. Born in Lublin, Poland in 1913, he was the only member of his 64 person family to survive the concentration camps. He emigrated to the US in 1946 and became a successful tailor in New York City. He is survived by his beloved children Shirley and Steve and his grandchildren Eric, Rachel and Lauren.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the "Arts, Briefly" column of Weekend on Friday about the discovery of a manuscript by Robert Hooke, the astronomer and physicist, omitted a description of the adjoining picture. While some people believe it is Hooke, no authenticated portraits of him are known.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Jury Selection In Gotti Retrial
description: Jury selection began yesterday in the second trial of John A. Gotti, left, on charges that he ordered a June 1992 shooting attack on Curtis Sliwa, the Guardian Angels founder and WABC radio talk show host. The first trial, in Federal District Court in Manhattan, ended in September with the jury acquitting Mr. Gotti on one charge and being deadlocked on three charges. Prosecutors chose to try him again on the three undecided counts. For the new trial Mr. Gotti has changed lawyers, switching from Jeffrey Lichtman to Charles Carnesi.

title: Sharon's Son Is Sentenced to 9 Months in Jail
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 14 - Omri Sharon, a former member of the Israeli Parliament and the elder son of the prime minister, was sentenced Tuesday to nine months in jail after he pleaded guilty to illegally raising more than $1.3 million for one of his father's political campaigns.

title: National Briefing | Washington: $364 Million For Military Ousters
description: A new report says the Pentagon's policy of discharging gay military personnel cost the Defense Department about $364 million over 10 years, more than what a government study concluded a year ago. The new study, released by a commission organized by the Center for the Study of Sexual Minorities in the Military at the University of California, Santa Barbara, found that the government had underestimated the cost of recruiting and training military personnel to replace those who had been discharged. The panel also cited money lost in training personnel who were discharged for being gay. Last February, the Government Accountability Office, an investigative arm of Congress, reported that the military had spent about $200 million on training and recruiting such replacements. JOHN FILES (NYT)

(Jean) Frankel of Greenwich, CT and Judith M. (Evan) Novenstein of Potomac, MD. Brother of the late Abraham Frankel. Haitian Front-Runner Breaks Silence; Charges Fraud
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 14 - Ren Prval, whose support among the poor masses has made him the favorite to become Haiti's next president, stepped out of the silence he began after the election last week to charge Tuesday that "massive fraud and gross errors had stained the process."

title: A Chef Returns, Inspired by Ingredients
description: AT many restaurants the food swaggers and preens, not so much inviting attention as demanding it. At Telepan it does the equivalent of idling into view, confident that its moment of regard will come. It shuns trickery and puts its faith in fundamental virtues: its freshness; the pureness or punch of its flavors; the skill with which it's been cooked.

title: Dobbs's Outspokenness Draws Fans and Fire
description: Night after night, Lou Dobbs slides into his anchor chair, turns to the camera and becomes the sober and steady face of CNN. At 60, he has more than three decades of experience, silvering hair and a voice that rumbles with authority. And for most of his program, he looks and feels like a traditional, nothing-but-the-news television host.

title: A Compromise, but Not in Taste
description: OVERLOOKED in the claims and counterclaims about fish and consumers' health is the fact that it is easy to buy fish that have beneficial omega-3 fatty acids but do not have a high level of contaminants.

title: EU unfair, Microsoft says
Chester, Pa., Depressed for Years, Awaits a Casino
description: CHESTER, Pa. - As a former industrial planner at the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, Monir Z. Ahmed can mentally recreate every square foot of the 64-acre shipyard on the Delaware River southwest of Philadelphia.

title: Suffolk Charges 24 in Web Child Sex Sting
description: YAPHANK, N.Y., Feb. 14 - A lieutenant colonel in the Army Reserve, a firefighter and a college student are among 24 Manhattan and Long Island men accused of soliciting sex from detectives posing as children in computer chat rooms during a monthlong sting operation, the Suffolk County police said on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOLGIN, DR. MARTIN
description: DOLGIN--Dr. Martin, 86. Of Ardsley, NY on February 12, 2006. Loving father of Barbara and Hanna, Debbie and Robert, Stuart and Deborah. Cherished grandfather of Rachel and Sam. Memorial service will be announced at a later date. Donations to the New York University School of Medicine.

title: Senate Scrubs Hearings as Politics Trump Policy in an Election Year
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 - The Senate has never been a bastion of managerial efficiency. But as the campaign season gets into full swing, lawmakers say things are clearly getting worse.

title: Russia discusses price curbs with oil companies
World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Uranium Enrichment Confirmed
description: Iran said it had started small-scale enrichment of uranium, ending a two-and-a-half-year voluntary suspension, but said it was willing to resume talks with Russia next week on that country's proposal to enrich a low level of Iran's uranium in Russia. Javad Vaeedi, above, a senior Iranian nuclear negotiator, said it would be some time before the enrichment, at the Natanz plant, one of Iran's main nuclear sites, would have the capacity to produce nuclear fuel for reactors. "However, the preliminary phases have been launched," he was quoted as saying. The move comes two weeks after the International Atomic Energy Agency voted to report Iran to the Security Council for possible penalties over its nuclear program. After the vote, Iran announced that it would end its voluntary nuclear cooperation with the agency and begin production of enriched uranium. NAZILA FATHI (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the New York City health department's development of a city-branded condom misstated the surname of the health commissioner in some copies. He is Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, not Friedman.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side parking rules in New York City are suspended today because of the snowstorm. All other rules, including parking meters, remain in effect. Enforcement of alternate-side rules will resume tomorrow.

title: The End User: Dialing up your job
Arts, Briefly; NBC's Olympic Victory
description: With Olympics coverage on the Monday television schedule, it was no surprise that NBC was No. 1 for the night in Nielsen's estimates. The preliminary ratings indicated that the network delivered an average of 20.96 million viewers during its prime-time telecast of pairs figure skating, snowboarding and speedskating. In total viewers, CBS's lineup of mostly repeats was a distant second. ("Courting Alex" was CBS's sole original episode of the night, and attracted 11.19 million viewers.) In the 18-to-49 demographic, new episodes of "Skating With Celebrities" (7.52 million) and "24" (12.8 million) put Fox in second place behind NBC. Among that age group, ABC finished third over all. Its two-hour "Bachelor," partly devoted to visiting previous couples created by the show, drew an audience of 9.22 million.

title: Italy Scores a Small Victory
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 14 - The Italian women's hockey team scored a goal in the Olympic Games for the first time Tuesday, making it probably the best day in the team's short history.

title: Must Be Something In the Water
description: IN 1977 the American public saw its first television commercial for bottled water. Orson Welles crooned about a place in the south of France where "there is a spring, and its name is Perrier," and the response was feverish. American sales of Perrier went up more than 3,000 percent from 1976 to 1979.

title: Abu Ghraib Called Incubator for Terrorists
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 - American commanders in Iraq are expressing grave concerns that the overcrowded Abu Ghraib prison has become a breeding ground for extremist leaders and a school for terrorist foot soldiers.

title: New wave of bird flu, and fears, hits Europe
Dobbs's Outspokenness Draws Fans and Fire
description: Night after night, Lou Dobbs slides into his anchor chair, turns to the camera and becomes the sober and steady face of CNN. At 60, he has more than three decades of experience, silvering hair and a voice that rumbles with authority. And for most of his program, he looks and feels like a traditional, nothing-but-the-news television host.

title: Miller Falters, but U.S. Wins Gold
description: The United States won its first gold medal in the men's combined event -- the downhill and two slalom runs -- at the Turin Olympics, but hardly in the way it expected.

title: Loyalty to the Guys Is Gretzky's Flaw
description: TURIN, Italy - SO vigilant in protecting his halo, and wary of potential vixens, Wayne Gretzky was fabled for avoiding solo encounters with strange women in elevators, cabs and empty hallways.

title: Fed Chief Says Interest Rates May Need to Rise
description: In an generally upbeat assessment of the economy, the Federal Reserve's new chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, told members of the House of Representatives that the Fed may have to raise interest rates a bit further to assure that inflation does not flare up.

title: 'Taj Mahal' of Morgues Closes as Pace Slows in New Orleans
description: CARVILLE, La., Feb. 14 - After using it for only 10 weeks, the Federal Emergency Management Agency has shut down a $17 million state-of-the-art morgue built to handle victims of Hurricane Katrina, agency officials said Tuesday.

title: Roundup: Italians surprise U.S. in team pursuit
A Cancer Drug Shows Promise, at a Price That Many Can't Pay
description: Doctors are excited about the prospect of Avastin, a drug already widely used for colon cancer, as a crucial new treatment for breast and lung cancer, too. But doctors are cringing at the price the maker, Genentech, plans to charge for it: about $100,000 a year.

title: When Tehran Rocks, Discretion Rules
description: TEHRAN - Rock stars are a brash, in-your-face breed, often challenging their audiences with lyrics of defiance. But here, they are all that and a bit scared, too.

title: Do e-mail logs affect privacy?
Paid Notice: Deaths   CRIMMINS, ETHAN CUSTIS
description: CRIMMINS--Ethan Custis, 42. Beloved husband of Jo Crimmins & beloved son of Marcy Crimmins of Princeton, NJ and James Custis Crimmins of Santa Barbara, CA. Ethan died in his sleep from respiratory complications. He was a graduate of the Hotchkiss School 1981 and a graduate of the University of Colorado 1985. Ethan leaves behind four sisters, Samantha Smith, Page Seyfried, Tory Brangham and Courtney Crimmins, and ten nieces and nephews. He also leaves behind many loyal and lifelong friends in NY and LA. In work and life he combined his passions for music and travel. He was honest, straight forward with strong beliefs and a generous spirit. A memorial service to celebrate Ethan's life will be held at Trinity Church, Princeton, N.J. on Saturday, February 18 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers please make donations in Ethan's name to savethechildren.org

title: Protecting New Jersey's Children
description: New Jersey's new governor, Jon Corzine, has gotten off to a good start in the effort to reclaim one of the most notorious child welfare departments in the country. A task force has already recommended sweeping changes, and Mr. Corzine has named Kevin Ryan, formerly the state's child advocate, as director of the Human Services Department. The system needs a complete makeover.

title: China offers environmental plan;focus is sustainable development
U.S. Athlete Hurts Knee And Will Miss Games
description: BARDONECCHIA, Italy, Feb. 14 - Jayson Hale of the United States tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee Tuesday during a solo training session for the snowboardcross and will miss the Olympic competition.

title: Asbestos Bill Is Sidelined by the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 - The Senate decided on Tuesday night to all but kill legislation to create a $140 billion fund to compensate victims of asbestos poisoning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOW, RHODA
description: HOW--Rhoda. On February 13, 2006, age 100. Beloved mother of Julian Suez. Member of Riverside Church. Funeral Saturday 11:30 AM Ferncliff Chapel, Secor Road Hartsdale, NY. Memorials to the church of your choice.

title: Changes Ahead for a Theater Near You
description: LET'S say you decide to take a break tonight and go out to a movie. It's Wednesday, of course, so when you walk up to the ticket counter, there is not another person in line. You settle on "Glory Road," an inspirational basketball movie that has been out for a month. The theater is so empty that it almost feels as if you are watching it in your den. Your ticket costs $8.

title: INSIDE
description: Correction Appended

title: Roasting the notion of low-fat diets
Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, DAVID S.
description: BROWN--David S. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of David S. Brown, associated with The Times since August, 1956 until retiring in September, 1994.

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption yesterday with an article about the success of the United States snowboarders at the Olympics in Turin, Italy, referred incorrectly in some copies to the home state of Gretchen Bleiler, the silver medalist in the women's halfpipe. It is Colorado, not Ohio.

title: For Posada at 34, It's Sooner Rather Than Later
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 14 - Jorge Posada was the first player to take the field Tuesday morning, honing his swing with his uncle at the Yankees' minor league complex. He stood at the plate beside a device called a Jet-Tee, which looked like a blowtorch pointed up. His uncle Leo Posada, a former major leaguer, would lob a ball above the machine, which spewed air, and the ball would hang there, spinning, before Posada swung and served it into the outfield.

title: Haiti dump yields election materials
Luge: Austrian brothers win accident-plagued doubles luge
National Briefing
description: WEST

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Protest Over Immigration Proposal
description: Several thousand immigrants in cities around the country stayed home from work to protest a proposed federal law that would make illegal immigration a felony and would threaten with criminal penalties anyone who offered assistance to an illegal immigrant. Rallies were held in Delaware, Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Washington for the national Day Without an Immigrant protest. IAN URBINA (NYT)

title: Other Views: Sydney Morning Herald, Los Angeles Times, Globe and Mail
Tax Inquiry Said to Include German Bank
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan are investigating Deutsche Bank's role in questionable tax shelters that helped wealthy investors evade billions of dollars in taxes, according to people briefed on the case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GORDON, LILA
description: GORDON--Lila. Beloved wife of Alfred. Devoted mother of Nadine and Mark. Cherished grandmother of Jessica and Masha. She was a dedicated educator in the NYC school system for 30 years.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Friday about the Queens Democratic Party's endorsement of Andrew M. Cuomo for state attorney general omitted the name of one candidate in a list of his challengers for the nomination. She is Denise O'Donnell, a former United States attorney for western New York.

title: Golden Threads Among the Crystals
description: Salt was once so precious it was called white gold. Now there is golden saffron salt, to sprinkle on seafood, potatoes, poached chicken or soups. Saffron is expensive, and unlike many seasonings, it cannot merely be dusted onto food. Added to salt, it can be. Casina Rossa sea salt with saffron is available in a 3.5-ounce jar for $22 at www.salttraders.com. FOOD STUFF

title: A Red-Stater Even Before There Was Such a Thing
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 14 - Back in the 1960's, when politicians jokingly referred to Texas as a two-party state, dominated by conservative Democrats and not-so-conservative Democrats, Harry M. Whittington was a rare figure: a die-hard Republican.

title: Law to shoot down airliners overturned
Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,262 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Surreal Love Triangle
description: Today through Monday at the Museum of Modern Art Directed by William Kentridge Unrated, 78 minutes

title: Briefs: Morales faces protests
New Images of Abu Ghraib Abuse Are Broadcast in Australia
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 A An Australian television network broadcast today previously unseen pictures of Iraqi prisoners being abused by American soldiers, scenes the State Department said were "absolutely disgusting" but that added nothing to what was already known about the scandal.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: $1 Million Grant For Training Workers
description: The federal Labor Department announced yesterday that it was granting $1 million to the City University of New York to improve English language and customer service skills for retail and food workers. Secretary of Labor Elaine L. Chao said the money would finance a two-year project to train 240 workers recruited by the Queens Center Mall, the McDonald's Corporation and the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union. Training will be offered by the mall and four community colleges: La Guardia, Kingsborough, Borough of Manhattan and the New York City College of Technology.

title: Wines for Fish (And Other Foods) On South Street
description: One of the earliest signs of redevelopment around the old Fulton Fish Market is a new wine shop, Pasanella & Son. It's housed in a 19th-century building that was once a chandlery, then a brothel, and until a few weeks ago, a wholesale operation that handled 70,000 pounds of salmon a day. Marco Pasanella, an architect, and his wife, Rebecca Robertson, live in the upper floors of the building, at 115 South Street (Peck Slip), and opened the wine shop in the spacious, brick-walled ground floor. Their 400 or so labels are grouped according to the foods they can complement. They plan wine tastings and dinners in the back room and garden, (212) 233-8383 or pasanellaandson.com. The son is Luca, 7 months.

title: 3 More Die in Pakistan Cartoon Protests
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 15 A Three more people were killed today, as tens of thousands of protesters, incensed at cartoons depicting the Prophet Muhammad, took to the streets in Pakistani cities for a third straight day, clashing with police and torching western businesses, media reports and officials said.

title: Tuning Out Bush
description: To the Editor:

title: Which Water Is Tastiest?
description: ONE afternoon, several members of the Times Dining staff and one ringer, the chef Bill Yosses, gathered to answer one of the great questions of our time: Does bottled water really taste better than tap? New York tap water has fierce fans around the country. But some bottled waters inspire profound passions, too.

title: Military Recruiting Tactics
description: To the Editor:

title: Freestyle skiing Moguls: Australia strikes gold, only 3rd in Winter Games
Some See a Wine Loved Not Wisely, but Too Well
description: MONTALCINO, Italy - YOU need to have your museum legs for a visit to Il Greppo, the historic estate just south of this hillside town, where the Biondi Santi family virtually invented the wine now prized around the world as brunello di Montalcino. Within minutes of my arrival, Franco Biondi Santi, the family's 84-year-old patriarch, was opening a glass display case and showing me a rifle carried by his grandfather, Ferruccio, when fighting under Garibaldi against Austria in 1866.

title: Afghan Suicide Bombings, Tied to Taliban, Point to Pakistan
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, Feb. 12 - Arrests and interrogations of suspects in a recent series of suicide bombings in Afghanistan show that the attacks have been orchestrated from Pakistan by members of the ousted Taliban government with little interference by the Pakistani authorities, Afghan officials say.

title: Cutting and Splicing Pieces of a Friend's Madness
description: The playwright Neena Beber has met two extraordinary challenges in "Jump/Cut," a Women's Project production that opened at the Julia Miles Theater on Sunday night. She has made a play that, like Frederic Wiseman's documentary films, refuses to impose dramatic coherence on life. Something happens, or doesn't; causality and resolution remain hard to find, yet the assembled fragments accumulate an unforgettable power. And she has made a play about despair that does not leave an audience desperate. Instead, it is left exhilarated by the fierce beauty of her writing and by an utterly captivating performance by Luke Kirby as Dave, the brilliant young manic-depressive whose circular, inescapable fate is the central mystery of the work.

title: U.S. Faces Tough First-Round Group for World Cup
description: It would be too easy to assume that the United States men's national team will improve on its surprising and impressive performance in the 2002 World Cup. This time, in Germany, the American team is in a difficult first-round group (with the Czech Republic, Italy and Ghana), and one of the fears among the soccer cognoscenti in the United States is that an early exit would be used to ridicule the sport and again question its long-term prospects.

title: Chirac orders carrier back to France
Building a nation with words
Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about an arbitrator's ruling against a plan to eliminate conductors from some New York subway routes misidentified the line that includes the Lefferts shuttle, and a subheading misidentified the responsible agency. The train is the A, not the No. 5. The agency is New York City Transit, not the M.T.A., or Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Earplugs that strive for speaker sound
Taking the Bar as Seriously as the Cellar
description: THE world of wine has a long tradition of training and certifying experts. Not so the realm of spirits and cocktails, where there is no equivalent of a Master Sommelier diploma or a Master of Wine certificate. Indeed, most bartending schools are vocational, offering basic skills like the mechanics of mixing mojitos and cosmopolitans.

title: HUGHES TO ARRIVE TOMORROW
description: BARDONECCHIA, Italy, Feb. 14 - The figure skater Emily Hughes, the replacement for Michelle Kwan on the United States team, will arrive in Italy on Thursday. Kwan, who had petitioned her way on to the Olympic team, withdrew from the competition Sunday because of a groin injury. Hughes, 17, of Great Neck, N.Y., was not able to fly out earlier because of a snowstorm.

title: Truck Traffic Needs Work, Critics Say as Study Lags
description: The New York City Department of Transportation, which is two years behind schedule on a study on overhauling truck traffic, is facing criticism from lawmakers and neighborhood activists who say the city is failing to address the congestion, pollution, noise and safety issues associated with commercial vehicles.

title: The Weapon of Democracy
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank - I decided that before writing about Hamas's win in the Palestinian legislative elections, I had to talk to people in the West Bank first. I am so glad I did. Everything is now clear to me: What a mess!

title: Know Your Grapes? Advance 2 Spaces
description: Britt-Marie Bcke was looking for a more enjoyable way to learn about wine after studying tedious volumes to become a certified sommelier in Sweden. So she invented Bouquet, a sort of Trivial Pursuit for wine lovers. Its 900 question cards cover everything from the origin of gin to the predominant grape in Corsican wines to the name of the winery that makes Wedding Cuve. The game is designed for up to six players, but teams can also play. The markers are corks.

title: Orange chief sends a message
Europe Is Warned That Its Values Are Under Siege
description: STRASBOURG, France, Feb. 15 A In the face of escalating attacks against foreigners in the Muslim world by violent critics of cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad, the European Union's chief executive said today that Europe had to fight for its core European values, including freedom of speech.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DE GUNZBURG, BARON GUY GEORGES
description: de GUNZBURG--Baron Guy Georges, born in Paris January 1, 1911. With great sorrow, we announce the death of Baron de Gunzburg, January 16, 2006 in Miami. He will be mourned by his wife Baroness Mary de Gunzburg, his sister Madame Giorgio Uzielli; his children Baron JeanLouis de Gunzburg, Madame Eliane de Gunzburg Beckman and Baron Gerard de Gunzburg; his grandchildren Veronique Albersmeier, Jacques Heim, Alexia de Gunzburg, Gregory de Gunzburg and his twin greatgrandchildren Julia and Vanessa Albersmeier and by his stepchildren Robert Malcolm Buxton, Lucy Geppert and Mary Hess. Baron de Gunzburg was schooled in Paris and Switzerland and he survived the evacuation of Dunkerque in 1940 and served in the Free French and British Armies during WWII. Later he became an American citizen. Baron de Gunzburg had three friends who were always there for him personally and professionally: Peter De Gaetano, Joseph Cooper and Steven Thaler. A man of varied talents, he enjoyed sculpting and writing and cultivated a beautiful farm in Virginia. Baron Guy was a benefactor of the Mayo Clinic, Rochester and the Center for Excellence Program for Nurses at Baptist Hospital in Miami. All who knew him will miss him.

title: Poisoned Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: Games Found Lacking, in Fans and Atmosphere
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 14 - When the American speedskater Jennifer Rodriguez walked into Oval Lingotto on Tuesday for the 500-meter race, she said she could barely believe her eyes. In two previous Olympics, Rodriguez skated in front of roaring crowds, in Nagano, Japan, and in Salt Lake City.

title: Danone profit tripled in '05
Metro Briefing | New York: Inquiry Into Deportation Of Pregnant Woman
description: Federal immigration officials said yesterday that they would investigate allegations that their officers mistreated a pregnant Chinese woman who miscarried twins on Feb. 7 after she was taken from Philadelphia to Kennedy International Airport to be deported. Dean Boyd, a spokesman for Immigration and Customs Enforcement, called the accusations, which spurred protest rallies in two cities yesterday, "categorically false." But "as a matter of protocol," he said, they have been referred to the agency's Office of Professional Responsibility. Mr. Boyd said that immigration officers learned that the woman, Zhenxing Jiang, 32, was pregnant only when she reported to them that day at 9 a.m., and "they took special precautions in handling her." He said the agency had interviewed the officers and concluded that "contrary to the claims of her attorney, she was not pushed or bruised," ridiculed or denied food. He said that she made no complaints of pain until shortly before her flight, and that an ambulance was called immediately.

title: 2 Die as Pakistan Cartoon Rage Turns Violent
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan , Feb. 14 - Two people were killed and dozens injured on Tuesday in the nation's worst day of protests against the cartoons satirizing the Prophet Muhammad, officials said.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Arrest In School Switching
description: A Providence woman has been arrested and accused of lying about her address so her child could attend high school in Cranston. The woman, Maria Hernandez, 39, was arrested Friday on charges of submitting a false document and securing services, her child's public education, under false pretenses, a felony, said Col. Stephen McGrath of the Cranston Police Department. She could face up to five years in jail and a $3,000 fine. The city is likely to seek to have her reimburse it for at least $11,000, the city's annual per-pupil expense. Colonel McGrath did not say how long the child attended Cranston East High School. Mayor Stephen Laffey of Cranston said parents' lying about their addresses to get their children into schools they believed were better was a major problem for the city. Officials estimate that 8 percent of Cranston high school students do not live in the city. KATIE ZEZIMA (NYT)

title: LIBERTY SIGNS TWO PLAYERS
description: The Liberty, trying to fill a roster that has lost four starters this off-season, signed guard Ashley Battle and forward Iciss Tillis yesterday. General Manager Carol Blazejowski, who said she wanted a younger and more athletic team, said she expected both players to be in the team's rotation. Battle was cut by the Seattle Storm last year, two games into her rookie season. Tillis was cut last preseason by the Washington Mystics and did not play last season. Both women are currently playing in Spain. MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT (NYT)

title: Broader Inquiry Examines Ovitz Ties to Detective

Ovitz, the former Hollywood power player, and Anthony Pellicano, the celebrity private detective who was indicted on federal wiretapping charges.

description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Feb. 14 - Vince Carter sat on the Nets' bench early in the fourth quarter looking as if he had been punched in the gut. Next to him was Jason Kidd, who looked as if he had taken a hit to his pride.

title: John Belluso, Who Wrote Plays About Disability, Is Dead at 36
description: John Belluso, a young playwright who translated his own experiences with physical disability into a prolific body of promising work, died on Friday at a hotel in Manhattan. He was 36 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: The Right Way to Pressure Hamas
description: America and Israel have to walk a very narrow line in defining their relations with a democratically elected Palestinian government built around Hamas, a party that not only endorses terrorism but also commits it. They cannot possibly give political recognition or financial aid to such a government. Neither can any country that claims to oppose terrorism. That defines the right side of the line.
