Paid Notice: Deaths   RISLEY, WILLIAM S.
description: RISLEY--William S. Educational consultant and longtime resident of Washington, CT. Died February 12 of postoperative complications at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital in New York. Beloved husband of Jane, father of Mandy and Emily, stepfather of John and grandfather of Julia. He is deeply mourned as well by his stepmother, Virginia Risley deCourcy of Washington; brother John; sister Mary; and stepbrothers, Dr. Charles de Sieyes and David de Sieyes and a host of friends in Litchfield County, CT. A memorial service will be conducted Saturday at 11 A.M. in the Washington Club Hall on Route 47 in Washington. The family requests that remembrances be made in the form of contributions to the Steep Rock Association, Inc., the land trust, P.O. Box 279, Washington, CT 06794.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Contraceptives Must Be Stocked
description: The state pharmacy board ruled that Wal-Mart pharmacies were required under state law to stock and dispense emergency contraception pills. Three women sued the chain this month, citing a state law requiring all pharmacies to stock and dispense commonly prescribed medication. Wal-Mart does not carry the emergency contraception drug, known as the morning-after pill. Dan Fogelman, a Wal-Mart spokesman, said that the company would comply with the Massachusetts ruling, and that it was giving emergency contraception "a lot of thought." KATIE ZEZIMA (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Art in Review column in Weekend on Feb. 3 misspelled the surname of an artist who has a video work in the show "Do You Think I'm Disco" at Hostos Community College in the Bronx. She is Shirley Wegner, not Wenger.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about the hunting accident in which Vice President Dick Cheney shot Harry Whittington, a prominent Texas lawyer, misstated the distance between them in some copies. It was about 30 yards -- not feet.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Ex-J.F.K. Guard Sentenced In Killing
description: A 34-year-old former security guard at Kennedy International Airport was sentenced to 25 years to life yesterday for the November 2002 fatal shooting of a Woodside cab driver and the shooting of a Jackson Heights factory worker during a robbery three days later. The Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said the defendant, Paul Chandler, of East Elmhurst, was convicted last month of second-degree murder in the death of the cab driver, Luis Quizhpi, 52, and the attempted murder of Orlando Giraldo, a 42-year-old factory worker. An accomplice in the fatal shooting, Gary Hodges, 29, of South Jamaica, faces sentencing next week for second-degree murder, and a third man is awaiting trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JUTKOWITZ, J. DAVID, ESQ.
description: JUTKOWITZ--J. David, Esq. Of Rye, on February 14, 2006. Born in Yonkers 1911 to Jacob and Rose (Weiss) Jutkowitz. Mr. Jutkowitz was a First Lieutenant in the Quarter Master Corps during WWII. Husband of the late Bernice, father of Linda Jutkowitz Meyers and the late John G. Jutkowitz, grandfather of Karen Meyers Arrese (husband Gregory), Hope Meyers Bond (husband Mogolodi), great-grandfather of of Julia, Isabella, Grace and Maya. Predeceased by siblings Adolph Jutkowitz and Rose Palester. Service Thursday, 1:30 P.M. at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison. Interment Mount Hope Cemetery. Donations to a charity of your choice. For more info contact Zion Memorial Chapel, 914-381-1809.

title: Thrill Ride to Danger Leads to Questions About Safety

Loving grandfather of Elizabeth, Arthur Jr., Thomas, Lyn, Tamara, Lori and Kristi. Adored by his 13 great - grandchildren. Loved brother of Joan Green and Benjamin Jacobson, Jr. Some knew him as the great amateur golf champion that he was. Others knew him as a superb specialist and businessman for over 50 years on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. But first in his life was his family and he will be forever missed because he was such a loving Dad, Grandfather and GreatGrandfather. Services will be held at Frank E. title: A Tale of Moral Indecision Becomes One of Mystery
description: A broad beam of light is disturbing the shadows of John Patrick Shanley's "Doubt, a Parable" at the Walter Kerr Theater. The mysteries of human behavior that until recently enshrouded this Pulitzer Prize- and Tony-winning drama seem somehow to have dissolved, like frost in the midday sun, leaving only glints of uncertainty. Now under most circumstances, additional illumination in a drama is as welcome as wintertime warmth. But when a play's title is aptly and unironically "Doubt," firm answers to troubling questions are not an unqualified blessing.

title: From Russia, With All Kinds of Weird Stuff
description: There are films that need no introduction, but a Russian-language vampire-and-apocalypse movie isn't one of them. Luckily, there are two visually striking, complementary ways of previewing "Night Watch." One is to watch the traditional trailer, and the other is to catch a tantalizing version that goes faster than the speed of sight yet is blandly labeled "condensed featurette." Both suggest the neon look and zooming pace that has made "Night Watch" a megahit in Russia and, more crucially for American audiences, has led Fox Searchlight to bet on its potential here. The first film in a trilogy -- the sequels "Day Watch" and "Dusk Watch" will follow -- "Night Watch" opens Feb. 17 in New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco, and in other cities in the next weeks.

title: In Turin, Chocolate's the Champion
description: TURIN, Italy - THE streets of Turin may be overflowing with Olympics visitors for a few weeks, but they always overflow with chocolate. Perhaps in no other place in the world, and certainly no other city in Europe, do so many pastry shops and chocolate-makers roast and blend their own cacao beans. The cafes of Turin, still the world's most sumptuous and beautiful, are famous for serving the city's own hot-chocolate-and-espresso drink called bicerin, a fabulous layered concoction served in glass cups. It's easy to stroll down the arcaded shopping streets and sample bars and fancifully shaped pralines wrapped in foil and colored papers with appealing Art Nouveau designs.

title: A Historical Path Less Traveled, and the Differences Made
description: Satire via sledgehammer, Kevin Willmott's fake documentary about an alternative American history, "CSA: The Confederate States of America," opens with a quotation attributed to George Bernard Shaw. "If you're going to tell people the truth, you better make them laugh; otherwise they'll kill you." Another version of that same quotation opens Wesley Brown's novel "Darktown Strutters," an exploration of minstrelsy and identity hinged to a 19th-century Kentucky slave named Jim Crow who becomes a dancer in an all-white show. Mr. Brown ends the Shaw quotation with the admonition "make them laugh"; for his part, Mr. Willmott keeps the threat intact, which warns of a far heavier hand at work.

title: Gonzaga Gagged
description: Brokeback Mountain has entered the popular lexicon in all sorts of ways. Just yesterday, one of the rugrats directly addressed the Bagger in the comments section with a paraphrase from the film: I wish you could quit Dave Poland. But the movie as meme has struck in other ways, which may in fact be less funny. Apparently, some of the fans of the No. 5 Gonzaga basketball team have been chanting Brokeback Mountain to infer that the other team, well, plays for the other team. Officials at the Jesuit school have asked the fans to put a lid on the chant, although the Bagger heard that the chant had also cropped up at one of the better high schools in Los Angeles as well. title: SAG Bags a Settlement
description: They say, well, at least the Bagger says it, that there are no politics more venal than academic politics, save association politics. The Screen Actors Guild has reportedly resolved its knock-down with Greg Hessinger, its former CEO and national executive director, who was fired last fall after a dispute over his approach to running the union. Mr. Hessinger immediately retained  you guessed it, Bert Fields  and a nasty court case seemed in the offing, but SAG has apparently negotiated a truce. The Hollywood Reporter quotes sources saying that Mr. Hessinger was paid $500,000 of $1.6 million he has remaining on his contract.

title: Not-So-Secret Agent Man
description: As the investigation of Anthony Pellicano continues to ripple, substantial numbers on Hollywoods A-List are beginning to develop facial tics. Its a town where not only does everybody know every one else; they have probably sued each other a time or two. And one side usually lawyers up with Bert Fields. Given Mr. Fields historical hand-in-glove relationship with Mr. Pellicano, his many star clients are no doubt wondering whether they will get pulled in one way or another. According to a story by my colleagues David M. Halbfinger and Allison Hope Weiner, much of the investigation so far has centered on Mr. Pellicanos relationship with Michael S. Ovitz, although Mr. Ovitz has been questioned only as a witness so far. But the story contains a paragraph that should keep folks twitching for the time being:

title: Oscar Bump? Nah, Oscar Slump
description: We all know that in addition to parceling out the highest honors in American filmmaking, the Oscars tend to generate big chunks of cash. The so-called Oscar bump can be good for $5 million or $10 million, or even more, a windfall of cash at the box office that rewards those who made good films and ran good campaigns behind them. But the Bagger has been spending some quality time on Box Office Mojo and, more worrisome, with his own calculator. And what hes found is that this year, there will be no Oscar bump  far from it. The tale of the box office tape suggests that the Oscar sparkle will do little for the long-term business outlook of this years best picture nominees. True enough, the four still in theatrical release  Brokeback Mountain, Munich, Good Night, and Good Luck, and Capote  got a bit of a push the week after nominations were announced. They went from a collective weekend gross of $8.9 million before the announcements to $11.5 million the weekend after. But then they went right off the cliff. Last weekend, the carnage was everywhere. The four films (Crash came out earlier in the year and is only on DVD) were down a collective 43.4 percent from the previous weekend and took in just about $6.9 million. In other words, they were worse off than before the Oscars. Brokeback is still in almost 2,000 theaters and took in a robust $4 million, but Munich lost 600 screens, better than half its theaters, and took in a miserable $783,510. Given the level of heat and promotion behind the movie, it is clear that not many besides Academy members are taking Steven Spielberg up on his suggestion that people ignore the partisans and see the movie for themselves. Capote, which recently crept over the $20 million mark, took in $1.27 million while Good Night, and Good Luck, did $872,000. Pretty small beer for what are supposed to be the most lauded films of 2005.

title: Gores Supreme Disloyalty in Saudi Arabia
description: As House Democrats David Bonior and Jim McDermott may recall from their trip to Baghdad on the eve of the Iraq war, nothing sets conservative opinionmongers on edge like a speech made by a Democrat on foreign soil. Al Gore traveled to Saudi Arabia last week, and in a speech there on Sunday he criticized abuses committed by the U.S. government against Arabs after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. A burst of flabbergasted conservative blogging followed the Associated Press dispatch about the speech, with the most clever remark coming from Mark Steyn, who called the former vice president Sheikh al-Gore. description: BERLIN, Feb. 15 A When the annual Berlin International Film Festival started last week, the expectation was that this was going to be the year of politics.

title: Call for Openness at NASA Adds to Reports of Pressure
description: Top political appointees in the NASA press office exerted strong pressure during the 2004 presidential campaign to cut the flow of news releases on glaciers, climate, pollution and other earth sciences, public affairs officers at the agency say.

title: Australia moves closer to approving abortion pill
Corrections
description: The Gear Test feature on the Physical Culture page last Thursday, about ski goggles, misspelled the writer's surname. She is Sally Wadyka, not Wadkya.

title: Lovesick Ballads From a Victim in a Valentine's Day War
description: NEWARK, Feb. 14 - Tough, tattooed and conspicuously shy, Jaheim just might be the least flamboyant R&B star of his generation. Mellow without ever coming across as soft, he is equally at home alongside a rapper or an old-fashioned string section. Either way, he sounds less like a combatant in the battle of the sexes and more like a man who has already lost it. His lovesick ballads have traces of regret and helplessness: he sings like a prisoner of war.

title: Lost and Foreign in Manhattan
description: Cool, mysterious and defiantly foreign, "Love" plays out on the immigrant fringes of an indifferent New York City, in backstreet clubs and decrepit buildings where past and present uneasily coexist.

title: Walk the red carpet and win a gift bag
Roundup: Russian biathlete loses silver medal
Plushenko glides, as Weir just slips and slides
Review: White Ghost Girls
Europe: Economic facts of life
Beauty on the Black Market
description: MIAMI - SEVERAL times a week, friends of a Miami clothing importer tip her off about illegal beauty treatments offered by unlicensed practitioners. Recently they have recommended a doctor from Peru who flies in to perform plastic surgery in a Miami apartment, a woman from Colombia who gives shots that melt fat off the hips, and an aesthetician who injects material that permanently bulks up the buttocks, she said.

title: Radical Cleric Rising as a Kingmaker in Iraqi Politics
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 15 - Late Saturday night, on the eve of a crucial vote to choose Iraq's next prime minister, a senior Iraqi politician's cellphone rang. A supporter of the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr was on the line with a threat.

title: Venture Capitalists Are Investing in Educational Reform
description: Venture capitalists of Silicon Valley, who have backed hundreds of high-technology entrepreneurs, are eagerly financing a new group these days: schoolmasters.

title: Infineon wants IPO for unit
Pakistan's Violent Protests Over Cartoons Take a Political Turn
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 15 - Tens of thousands of protesters, incensed at cartoons satirizing the Prophet Muhammad, took to the streets in Pakistani cities for a third straight day on Wednesday, clashing with the police and setting Western businesses on fire, news media reports and officials said.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Economy Slowed in Fourth Quarter
description: Mexico's economic expansion slowed in the fourth quarter as consumer demand remained slack and hurricanes wiped out some bean, sugar and corn crops. Gross domestic product expanded 2.7 percent in the quarter from a year ago after growing a revised 3.4 percent in the third quarter, the government said. For the full year, Mexico expanded 3 percent, down from a revised growth rate of 4.2 percent in 2004. "The economy is just kind of treading water," said Neil Dougall, chief of emerging markets research for Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein in London. Sluggish growth among manufacturers that sell primarily in the domestic market suggests that consumption has yet to pick up after six interest-rate cuts by the central bank, Mr. Dougall said. That will most likely prompt central bankers to keep cutting the benchmark lending rate, bringing it down to 7 percent by year-end from a 15-month low of 7.75 percent now, he said. The Finance Ministry forecasts growth will quicken to 3.6 percent this year as the interest-rate reductions bolster demand.

title: Forgotten Girl Dies in Newark Fire, Official Says
description: NEWARK, Feb. 15 - A 6-year-old girl who had been entrusted to a baby sitter died early Wednesday after rescuers found her alone in the second-floor room of a burning apartment building in Newark, the Fire Department said.

title: Getting Fit With a Rock and a Broom. Who Knew?
description: MATT DOLLOFF lives to compete on the ice. To train for his Sunday curling matches, he runs, bikes or works out on the elliptical machine five days a week. For variety Mr. Dolloff, 26, an electrical engineer at NASA's Johnson Space Center in Houston, also lifts weights and sometimes plays basketball or tennis. But all of this is only preparation for the two hours a week he spends curling, a sport that many consider nothing more than shuffleboard on ice.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Parliament Votes To Oust Russian Troops
description: Parliament called for the withdrawal of Russian peacekeepers from South Ossetia, the separatist region in the country that remains closely aligned with Russia. About 500 Russian soldiers have policed the region since 1992, following a brief but fierce ethnic conflict. Georgia has long complained that Russian forces have sided with the separatists. Tensions over the peacekeepers have risen under President Mikheil Saakashvili, who has vowed to reunify the country. Parliament's vote has little immediate impact, but it could influence negotiations over a new mandate for the peacekeeping force. Georgia has indicated it would prefer troops from other countries. STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)

title: The New Eclecticism
description: Q. I have read about the new eclecticism, but I can't pin down what it is. Are there rules for pulling it off?

title: Plug In, Sit Down, Tune Out: A Cozy Way to Listen to Music
description: For the iPod generation, there is now an iChair by PBteen, with built-in speakers, volume control and a subwoofer. The chair, which sits on the floor and acts like an audio womb, also works with a television and video-game systems. Patrick Wynhoff, PBteen's senior vice president for design, said the chair gives teenagers another way to listen to their iPods while hanging out in their rooms. The chair plugs into an outlet, and a second cord links an iPod or an MP3 player to a control panel, above. A third cord can be connected to the audio output of a television or a video-game system. The chair is covered in charcoal gray or light blue fake suede; $399 at pbteen.com or (866) 472-4001.

title: A New Challenge Is Undertaken by an Army Division Born on Skis
description: FORT DRUM, N.Y. - The storied history of the 10th Mountain Division began as the war clouds gathered over Europe.

title: Rabbi Yehuda Chitrik, a Legend in Lubavitcher Circles, Is Dead at 106
description: Rabbi Yehuda Chitrik, a legendary storyteller in the Lubavitcher community, died on Tuesday at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 106 and lived in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, the hub of the worldwide Lubavitcher Hasidic movement.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MELTZER, ELTON
description: MELTZER--Elton. Remembered with everlasting love and treasured memories, by his adoring wife, children and grandchildren

title: Snowboarding's Adult Division Takes Its Bow
description: BARDONECCHIA, Italy, Feb. 14 - The newest breed of Olympic snowboarder grows a beard, supports a family and never, ever admits that he is superstoked.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Hamas Appoints Parliamentary Speaker And Leader
description: With the new Palestinian parliament set to meet for the first time on Saturday, Hamas officials said that Aziz Dweik, a geography professor and newly elected Hamas lawmaker from the West Bank town of Hebron, would be nominated as speaker and that Dr. Mahmoud Zahar, a senior Hamas leader in the Gaza Strip, would head the Hamas faction in parliament. Hamas, which won a solid majority of the seats in elections last month, has not announced its candidate for prime minister. Ismail Haniya, another Hamas leader in Gaza, is considered a strong possibility. GREG MYRE (NYT)

title: Yevgeny Plushenko Takes the Gold for Figure Skating
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 16 - Just as American figure skater Johnny Weir and seemingly the rest the world predicted, Russia's Yevgeny Plushenko won the gold medal in men's figure skating on Thursday night.

title: More Greenland Ice Flowing Into Sea, in Sign of Warming
description: The amount of ice flowing into the sea from large glaciers in southern Greenland has almost doubled in the last 10 years, possibly requiring scientists to increase estimates of how much seas could rise under the influence of global warming, according to a study to be published Friday in the journal Science.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the trial of two former Enron chief executives, Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay, and the testimony of Kenneth D. Rice, who ran the company's broadband business, misidentified the audience at a presentation in May 2001 during which Mr. Rice said that because of pressure from Mr. Skilling he gave a rosier outlook of the business than the facts supported. He spoke to the company's board, not to securities analysts.

title: Soccer: Thun edges Hamburg in UEFA Cup first leg
Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,265 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: New Yorker, Suffering Memory Loss, Is Found in Chicago
description: Raymond Power Jr. stepped out of his life some time on Aug. 1, 2005, the last day he awoke in Westchester County as a lawyer and New Rochelle resident, a 57-year-old husband and father of two, a Boy Scout leader and churchgoer.

title: Congressman Starts Inquiry of Windfall to Oil Companies
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 - A House Republican began a broad investigation on Wednesday of an Interior Department program that is expected to give billions of dollars in benefits over the next five years to companies that pump oil and gas on federal territory.

title: A Disastrous Trump Break? Don''t Give Up on That Slam
description: Arguably the most enjoyable one-day event on the calendar of the Greater New York Bridge Association is the Betty Kaplan Teams. This was contested last Saturday at the New York Helmsley Hotel in Midtown Manhattan. Every team consisted of four players. There were six nine-board matches, and each participant had to play two of these matches with each of her or his teammates.

title: Big Ideas for Governors I., Like a Gondola, Perhaps
description: Plans for a futuristic elevated gondola system linking Brooklyn to Manhattan by way of Governors Island on a tramway were introduced yesterday by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: City Rebuffed in Trying to Bar Mass Bike Rides
description: For 18 months, the city has spared few efforts -- on the street or in courts -- to clamp down on a group bicycle ride in Manhattan called Critical Mass that the authorities say causes havoc by blocking traffic.

title: An Unexpected Twist in the Celebrity Private Eye Case
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15 - Damage from the investigation of the celebrity private eye Anthony Pellicano reached the top of Hollywood's business community on Wednesday, when a federal grand jury issued wiretapping and conspiracy charges against the lawyer who handled Kirk Kerkorian's 2002 legal battle with his former wife.

title: Finding Beauty in a Rallying Call From the Siege of Leningrad
description: When the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam last performed in New York, in 2004, it was led by a guest conductor, Herbert Blomstedt, but its spectacular sound provided assurance that its departing music director, Riccardo Chailly, had left it in fine shape. Mariss Jansons took over as director a few months later, and this week he brought the orchestra to Carnegie Hall for two concerts that gave New Yorkers a first glimpse of this new collaboration.

title: A Jammed Video Arcade for Grown-Ups
description: WHEN I married and my husband asked me to convert, it was a pretty big deal. I was set in my ways. My orthodoxies were profound. But if I didn't abandon the personal computer for the Mac, he warned, the marriage wouldn't have a chance.

title: A Deadly Vacuum
description: In the Bush administration, there is no such thing as failure at the top. When something goes wrong because of bad leadership, punishment is meted out to the foot soldiers and middle management, while the people in charge remain unscathed. Now we'll see whether the rule holds true in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina.

title: When Old Stadiums Go, Everything Must Go!
description: ST. LOUIS - JUST as Mike and Jessica Barbieri began remodeling the basement in their ranch house in Sunset Hills, Mo., in November, Ms. Barbieri came across an item she deemed essential for the job: a 21-foot section of the padded outfield wall from Busch Stadium, then in the process of being demolished. Emblazoned with the words "National League Champions" and covered with scratches from outfielders' cleats and dents from batted balls, the wall was being sold by the St. Louis Cardinals in an online auction.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 2 about exercisers who struggle to gain weight misstated the number of members of SkinnyGuy.net, a program to help such people. It is 18,000, not 800.

title: For Pakistan, American Aid Is All Guns, No Butter
description: LAHORE, Pakistan - Syed Jawad Ahsan's Valentine's Day this year was a heartbreaking window into the box in which this country is trapped.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOEHM, FRANCES
description: BOEHM--Frances. Peacefully passed away, Tuesday, February 14, age 91. The supreme activist. Remembered for her boundless devotion to those she loved and the causes in which she believed. A long-time member of the Women's Strike For Peace and American Labor Party; a co-founder of the Five Towns Forum; an active supporter of the Center For Constitutional Rights; cocreator of the Nancy Boehm Coster Public Policy Fellowship at Dartmouth College, and supporter of countless social justice organizations. The much cherished wife of Robert Boehm, mother of Wendy Olesker, and Diane Boehm, grandmother of Katherine Olesker, Makeba Seargeant, and Daniel Winarick. The feisty, endlessly energetic, unifying spirit of our family. Memorial Service on February 26, 2006, The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave, 2PM.

title: Moving Sale for Tool Shop
description: Garrett Wade, a store known for its fine woodworking tools, is moving to Chelsea after 20 years at 161 Sixth Avenue (Spring Street), and the owners have put more than 700 items on sale. Some hammers are $9.95 (formerly $19.95); chisels, $3, were $10.20; low wood trestles, two for $19.95, were $35.85, and antique English planes are $24.95 (they were $41.60). Classic bentwood snow sleds are $89.95 (formerly $149.95). Folding paper globes, left, $14.95, were $21.95; garrettwade.com or (800) 221-2942.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Peru: Economy Grew 6.67% in 2005
description: Peru's gross domestic product expanded by 6.67 percent last year, the strongest showing since 1997, when the economy grew 6.84 percent. The 2005 economic expansion was led by strong growth in the mining and hydrocarbons sector, which rose 8.65 percent in the full year. Peru's economy should continue to grow at a robust pace this year, Finance Minister Fernando Zavala said. The official forecast is for an expansion of 5 percent this year, but Mr. Zavala called that conservative.

title: Swedes step ahead on ethnic harmony
Charge Your Batteries Way Off the Grid. (Best in Sunny Climes.)
description: When a rechargeable battery goes dead on one of your gadgets, you can usually plug in a charger and bring it back to life. If those batteries are AA or AAA cells, you can even buy nonrechargeable ones to keep you going until the old cells are charged up again. But what if you're out where there are no AC outlets and no stores?

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Wrongful Conviction Suit Dismissed
description: A $36 million wrongful conviction lawsuit filed on behalf of a Wisconsin man who was charged with murder last year after having served 18 years for a sexual assault he did not commit has been dismissed. The man, Steven Avery, 43, will receive a $400,000 settlement, up to 40 percent of which could be withheld for legal fees and costs, according to a stipulation filed in the Federal District Court in Milwaukee. Mr. Avery was charged last year in the killing of Teresa Halbach, a 25-year-old photographer. He had filed suit against Manitowoc County and the former prosecutor and sheriff involved in his sexual assault conviction after being released from prison in 2003. GRETCHEN RUETHLING (NYT)

title: The Girls Walk by Dressed in Their Summer Clothes
description: HOUSE keys? Check. Cellphone? Check. Last minute consult with weatherman. Er In planning her day, Melissa Briskman did give the weather a cursory thought. "Before leaving the house I stuck my head out the window," said Ms. Briskman, an actress and English teacher, who shivered perceptibly as she waited outside Cafe Gitane on Mott Street on Saturday.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Thai leader wins a legal battle in a larger war
National Briefing
description: WEST

title: A Small-Fish Businesswoman Takes on 2 Corporate Sharks
description: Here's one tactic the befuddled Democrats haven't yet tried: translating the party platform into rap routines. Make the midterm elections a Def Democrats Jam! It's a long shot, sure, but what have they got to lose?

title: Bush Promotes Health Accounts at Wendy's
description: DUBLIN, Ohio, Feb. 15 - President Bush campaigned for his plan to expand health savings accounts on Wednesday here at the headquarters of the Wendy's fast-food chain, declaring that his proposals were not just for the wealthy and would help some of the 45 million Americans who remain uninsured.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Peter Benchley, the author of "Jaws," referred incorrectly in some copies to the prep school from which he graduated. It was Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter, N.H., not Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass.

title: Shoe Allows Martnez to Get Off on Right Foot
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 15 - The most anticipated arrival here was not delivered by armed guards or a police escort or in a helicopter with an oversized swoosh on the door. It came rather unceremoniously, in a Federal Express truck, and was taken by a clubhouse attendant to the Mets' minor league clubhouse.

title: Tough G.I.'s Go to War Armed With Afghan ABC's
description: FORT DRUM, N.Y. - As the 10th Mountain Division prepared to go to Afghanistan this month, its Third Brigade ordered boxes of the Pakistani journalist Ahmed Rashid's seminal book "Taliban" to be issued to officers along with body armor, high-tech seven-layer cold weather uniforms and ballistic-grade Oakley Blade wraparound sunglasses.

title: Radical Cleric Rising as a Kingmaker in Iraqi Politics
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 15  Late Saturday night, on the eve of a crucial vote to choose Iraq's next prime minister, a senior Iraqi politician's cellphone rang. A supporter of the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr was on the line with a threat.

title: Rice Is Seeking Millions to Prod Changes in Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 - The Bush administration, frustrated by Iranian defiance over its nuclear program, proposed Wednesday to spend $85 million to promote political change inside Iran by subsidizing dissident groups, unions, student fellowships and television and radio broadcasts.

title: Early Adopter? For $499, a Player for 40 Movies
description: It may look like a DVD player, but it's really the first volley in the battle for which kind of high-definition disc you'll play on your TV.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BARTH, EDITH B.
description: BARTH--Edith B. February 16, 1997. Forever mourned, forever missed, forever loved. Your Family

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More Property Tax Rebates Proposed
description: City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. yesterday proposed expanding New York City's property tax rebate program to give about 81,000 low- and middle-income elderly homeowners up to $600 a year, on top of the standard rebate of up to $400 they already receive. The proposal, which would cost the city $50 million a year, would require the approval of the State Legislature and action by the City Council and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. The Legislature is already considering Mr. Bloomberg's request to extend the $400 rebates, which began in 2004 and are set to expire on July 1. Councilman David I. Weprin, a Queens Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee, said he would support the proposal. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

title: Mr. Cheney Meets the Press (Sort Of) (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: In Battle of Also-Rans, St. John's Beats Rutgers
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Feb. 15 - With their seasons going nowhere, St. John's and Rutgers can hope for little more than making the Big East Conference tournament.

title: A rage to buy: Europe's investors are restless, and hostile
World Briefing | Americas: Bolivia: Call To Expel U.S. Drug Agents Rejected
description: President Evo Morales, who this week was reappointed to lead the coca growers federation that he rode to political prominence, said American antidrug officials were welcome to remain in the country. Coca farmers have demanded that the agents be expelled, but Mr. Morales said, "It's important that we have international relationships." JUAN FORERO (NYT)

title: An American Salute to 'Egypt's Verdi'
description: A few years ago Hicham Chami, a young musician in Chicago who was researching early-20th-century Arab music, found some melodies he recognized from his school days in Morocco. The words were slightly different, but the music was unmistakable. And most important, it had a composer.

title: Falling Oil Price Overshadows Concerns on Interest Rates
description: Stocks rose yesterday as lower oil prices tempered concern that the Federal Reserve's new chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, might keep raising interest rates.

title: Nuclear plants planned for south China
Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Judge Bans Mention Of Escape Attempt
description: Evidence of a courtroom escape attempt will not be allowed in the trial of two men accused of raping and killing a Hunter College student in April 2003, a judge ruled yesterday. The defendants, Kayson Pearson and Troy Hendrix, are accused of using improvised knives to slash one of their lawyers and trying to take a court officer's gun. Seeking to show that the men acted in concert in abducting the student, Romona Moore, left, and another girl, a prosecutor had asked to introduce descriptions of the escape attempt. Lawyers for the defendants argued that their courtroom outburst was not relevant to their actions nearly three years ago. Justice Albert Tomei of State Supreme Court ruled that the evidence would prejudice jurors more than it would prove the charges. MICHAEL BRICK (NYT)

title: U.S. Skeleton Team Tries to Focus on Ice
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 15 - After two months of turmoil, the United States skeleton team finally takes the ice at the Olympics on Thursday in Cesana Pariol, with Katie Uhlaender in the women's race. The men race on Friday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Hevesi Faults Pataki Budget
description: State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi sharply criticized Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed budget yesterday, saying the state would be better off with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg managing its resources. Mr. Hevesi, a Democrat, has made an annual habit of charging that Mr. Pataki's budget proposals push too many of the state's financial problems into the future, but the latest report was particularly harsh, saying Mr. Pataki was squandering an opportunity to make wise use of a projected $2 billion surplus. He said that Mr. Pataki had proposed too much new spending without a plan to pay for all of it, and he derided the governor's plan to make large tax cuts that would start after he leaves office at the end of the year. The Pataki administration disputed Mr. Hevesi's assessments as "fuzzy math." DANNY HAKIM (NYT)

title: Global price-fixing inquiry adds 3 Asia cargo lines
Utility Output Fell in January
description: Industrial production unexpectedly fell last month as the warmest January in more than a century led to a record decline in utility use even as manufacturing strengthened, the Federal Reserve said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SANACORE, LUCY W.
description: SANACORE--Lucy W. On February 11, 2006 (nee Wasikiewicz). Beloved wife of Joseph A. Sanacore, MD. Devoted mother of Joseph A. Sanacore Jr. and Dale Pellegrino. Proud grandmother of Thomas & Michael Pellegrino. Family will receive friends at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 61-40 Woodhaven Blvd. Rego Park, Friday 6-8 PM and Saturday 9-10 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LITUCHY, DR. STANLEY
description: LITUCHY--Dr. Stanley. The Westchester Psychoanalytic Society mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague Dr. Stanley Lituchy. Past President of the Society, his skillsas leader, teacher and clinician will be dearly missed by all who knew him.

title: Science Academy Creating Panel to Monitor Stem-Cell Research
description: To fill a void in federal supervision, the National Academy of Sciences is setting up a committee to provide informal oversight over research with human embryonic stem cells.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Journal shut by China set to resume publication
Exonerated, Queens Man Decides to Sue Prosecutors
description: A man whose attempted murder conviction was overturned after he served 12 a dozen years in prison is planning on filing a lawsuit charging that Queens prosecutors have withheld evidence and misled juries in a broad pattern of misconduct that has led to dozens of wrongful convictions.

title: U.S. rejects UN's Guantnamo report
Rugby: Wales coach says he was asked to quit
Justice Department Reviews Role of Its Lawyers in Spying
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 - The ethics office of the Justice Department has begun a review of the department's role in the National Security Agency's domestic eavesdropping program, a move that could shed light on internal dissension over the legal status of the secret program.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (9) EVERYBODY HATES CHRIS -- Antonio Fargas, a k a Huggy Bear from"Starsky and Hutch," guest-stars as the owner of the corner store where young Chris (Tyler James Williams, left) reigns as the greatest Asteroids player in the neighborhood, Bedford-Stuyvesant. But he has new competition. Well, things are tough all over. Back home, Chris's parents are giving up their chocolate and lottery ticket habits so they can pay the Con Ed bill.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Law On Shooting Down Hijacked Planes Is Overturned
description: Germany's highest court struck down a law that authorized the military to shoot down hijacked civilian airliners, ruling that it was "incompatible with the fundamental right to life" to sacrifice the lives of innocent passengers to avert a potential greater death toll from a terrorist attack. VICTOR HOMOLA (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Feb. 8 about a new study finding that low-fat diets have no effect on the risk of cancer or heart disease misstated the incidence of breast cancer among women in the study. It was 42 per 10,000 per year in women in the low-fat-diet group, compared with 45 per 10,000 in women consuming their regular diet -- not per 1,000. (The difference was deemed statistically insignificant.)

title: World Briefing: Europe, Middle East and Americas
description: EUROPE

title: Regulator to Present Financial Education Program for G.I.'s
description: NASD will unveil today a financial education program it has developed exclusively for members of the armed forces and their families. The effort is part of the financial regulator's response to published reports about military personnel being widely exposed to deceptive and misleading sales pitches for insurance and other financial products.

title: Arts, Briefly; On the Pop Charts: 'Curious George' Is No. 1
description: A dark horse -- or rather, a fuzzy, inquisitive monkey -- is at the top of the Billboard album chart this week. "Sing-A-Longs and Lullabies for the Film Curious George" (Universal), below, by Jack Johnson and Friends sold 163,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, to become the first soundtrack to reach No. 1 in more than two years. A quarter of the sales were downloads, Billboard said. Mary J. Blige, who performed at the Grammy Awards last week, had a 23 percent sales boost for her album "The Breakthrough" (Interscope), which sold 152,000 to reach No. 2, pushing Barry Manilow, last week's chart-topper, to No. 3 and Andrea Bocelli to No. 4. Some other Grammy artists jumped up the chart: Mariah Carey, who won three awards, rose seven spots to No. 7; Kelly Clarkson, who won two, moved up 16 to No. 8. The Atlanta hip-hop group Dem Franchize Boyz reached No. 5 with "On Top of Our Game" (Virgin), which sold 102,000 in its first week. BEN SISARIO

title: Iraq ministry shelters Shiite death squad
Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about Iran's statement that it was still committed to the nuclear nonproliferation treaty misidentified the television program on which Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice responded to an earlier threat from the Iranian president to withdraw from the treaty. It was "This Week," on ABC, not "Meet the Press," on NBC. (Go to Article)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about Iran's statement that it was still committed to the nuclear nonproliferation treaty misidentified the television program on which Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice responded to an earlier threat from the Iranian president to withdraw from the treaty. It was "This Week," on ABC, not "Meet the Press," on NBC.

title: Profit Jumps 30% at Hewlett a Year Into Chief''s Tenure
description: Nearly a year into his job as chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, Mark V. Hurd is overseeing a company that is doing what he said it would do: increasing its revenue and improving its profit margins.

title: Despite Loss at Mercedes, DaimlerChrysler's Profits Rise
description: DETROIT, Feb. 16 A When Chrysler hit rocky times earlier this decade, the strength of Mercedes helped prop up their parent company, DaimlerChrysler A.G. Now Chrysler has returned the favor.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: Australia: Qantas Airways Profit Declines 9.6%
description: Qantas Airways, Australia's biggest airline, said first-half profit fell 9.6 percent as fuel costs rose to a record and it made payouts to dismissed workers. Net income dropped to 352.6 million Australian dollars ($261 million), or 18 cents a share, in the six months ended Dec. 31, from 390 million Australian dollars, or 21 cents, a year ago. Sales rose 8.5 percent, to 6.8 billion Australian dollars. The company is cutting 3 billion Australian dollars from costs by fiscal 2008 to counter rising fuel expenses, which surged 58 percent in the half. To reach the target, the company is considering moving maintenance jobs overseas, where labor is cheaper. Qantas has fared better than regional competitors that have released earnings in the last month. Thai Airways International reported a 33 percent decline in first-quarter net income. Japan Airlines said its loss tripled in the third quarter, and Singapore Airlines said third-quarter profit fell 15 percent. All cited rising fuel costs.

title: On The Street: Then
description: THE year 1990 was a signal one for hats, not the snug watch caps, felt trappers and newsboys that pass for adventurous now, but outrageous crowning statements that marked the wearer as a maverick. The essential garnish to a winter outfit, those toppers announced their importance, bulging at the crown, curling at the brim or rising to a commanding peak. Saucy porkpies vied for attention with bowlers and bishop's hats, and collapsed-looking stovepipes competed with tiny felt cones.

Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about continuing conflict between the president of Harvard and its faculty members misstated the name of the university's largest unit. It is the Faculty of Arts and Sciences, not Science.

description: A Safari

title: Blair Wins Parliament Vote Criminalizing 'Glorification' of Terror
description: LONDON, Feb. 15 - After a series of bruising parliamentary duels, Prime Minister Tony Blair secured victory in the House of Commons on Wednesday in a vote to expand counterterrorism laws by making "glorification" of terrorism a criminal offense.

title: Faso Stops Short on Talk of Outlawing Abortions
description: ALBANY, Feb. 15 - A day after he announced his bid for the Republican nomination for governor, John Faso said on Wednesday that if elected, he would strictly limit abortions for recipients of public health care.

Paid Notice: Deaths   PFISTER, WILLIAM A.
description: PFISTER--William A. Of Scarsdale, on February 13, 2006. Husband of the late Phyllis Pfister. Father of Alan, Jonathan, Mary Jo and Steven. Grandfather of Justin and Kasia Grieco, Abby and Kirsten Pfister. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 P.M. Friday. Mass of Christian Burial Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Scarsdale, Saturday, February 18 at 10 A.M.

title: In Warm January, Home Starts Surged 14.5 Percent
description: Home construction jumped 14.5 percent to a 33-year high last month, the government reported today, a sign that builders may have taken advantage of the unusually warm weather in January.

title: London developer lavishes space on top-end homes
Metro Briefing | New York: Hempstead: Transit Center Named For Rosa Parks
description: The Hempstead Transit Center will be renamed the Rosa Parks Hempstead Transit Center in honor of the civil rights leader, it was announced on Tuesday by Thomas R. Suozzi, the Nassau County executive. The center serves more than 25,000 bus riders each day. Mrs. Parks, who died in October, touched off the Montgomery, Ala., bus boycott by refusing to move to the back of a bus. The center will feature photographs and art about the civil rights movement.

title: New Orleans Will Hold Jazzfest This Spring
description: After financial hardships, dislocations and storm and flood damage to their site, the producers of the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival yesterday announced details of the festival's post-Katrina return over two weekends in late April and early May.

title: Iraq's sectarian fire
More Abu Ghraib Pictures Broadcast on Australian TV
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 - An Australian television network on Wednesday broadcast previously unseen pictures of Iraqi prisoners at Abu Ghraib being mistreated by American soldiers in 2003, scenes that the State Department said were "absolutely disgusting" but that add little to what is already known.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: Darfur: Stop the killing, or pay the price
Plushenko and Weir: Comrades on Skates
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 15 - Not far from Piazza Castello, the site of the Olympics medals plaza, is a complex of modern buildings called the Russia House, or Russky Dom, where the Russian delegation is based for the Winter Games.

title: 'Brokeback' Sells a Style
description: OF the many cinematic barriers broken by the success of "Brokeback Mountain," one previously overlooked achievement is that the film has made it acceptable to dress like a cowboy. The pristine chambray shirts and well-worn denim recall the feeling of thumbing through the pages of an old J. Crew catalog, before it went all preppy.

title: EU antitrust chief threatens energy suppliers with investigations
N.C.A.A. to Stop Accepting Transcripts From Schools Identified as Diploma Mills
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association, in a crackdown on correspondence schools and other nontraditional institutions that give fast, inflated grades to high school athletes seeking college scholarships, will not accept such transcripts starting this spring, leaders of an N.C.A.A. task force said yesterday after two days of meetings in Newport Beach, Calif.

title: UN calls on U.S. to close Guantanamo camp
Ask Science
description: Here are Gina Kolata's answers to several questions from readers regarding her article, "Maybe You're Not What You Eat." (Feb. 14, 2006)

title: Pakistan I: Musharraf on a tightrope
After a Sleepless Night, Dorfmeister Takes Gold and Kildow Ties for 8th
description: SAN SICARIO, Italy, Feb. 15 - Neither Lindsey Kildow nor her fellow competitor Michaela Dorfmeister slept much on the eve of the women's Olympic downhill Wednesday. Each was kept awake by a nightmare.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "I'm the guy who pulled the trigger that fired the round that hit Harry."

title: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: Australia: BHP Billiton Profit Soars 48%
description: BHP Billiton, the world's largest mining company, announced a 48 percent jump in profit for the latest six-month period, as soaring prices for iron ore, coking coal and copper raised its earning margins even as costs spiraled. Net profit for the six months through Dec. 31 climbed to $4.36 billion, the fifth consecutive six-month record for the company, and a new Australian record for corporate profit. Sales in the company's first half rose by a fifth, to $18.2 billion. The company said it was so confident of continued demand for iron ore and other metals that it would raise its dividend 30 percent and buy back $2 billion of its own stock. "We continue to see a strong benefit from the pricing environment in which we now exist," Charles W. Goodyear, BHP's chief executive, above, said at the company's headquarters in Melbourne.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Edna Lewis, the chef and author who wrote about refined Southern cuisine, misstated the order of her cookbooks. Her most famous one, "The Taste of Country Cooking" (Knopf, 1976), was her second, not her first. "The Edna Lewis Cookbook" (Bobbs-Merrill, 1972) was her first.

title: Scaling Great Heights for Very Different Causes
description: SOME controversy has been stirred up by the action-adventure game Marc Ecko's Getting Up: Contents Under Pressure, with anti-graffiti organizations warning that the game could encourage graffiti vandalism. I must admit that the game makes leaping from billboard to billboard high above the city streets intriguing, but personally I find myself dissuaded from pursuing a career as a graffitist by all the times graffiti artists apparently get hit in the head with crowbars.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: No Passage To India For Toxic Ship
description: President Jacques Chirac ordered the return of the decommissioned aircraft carrier Clemenceau, once the flagship of the French Navy, from the Indian Ocean after France's highest court suspended its transfer to an Indian shipyard to be dismantled and sold as scrap because of concerns that it contains unsafe amounts of asbestos. It has been marooned in the Indian Ocean for several weeks pending a decision by the Indian Supreme Court on whether to allow it into the country. Its impending return to France is the latest detour in a two-year odyssey that has seen the 48-year-old, 26,000-ton vessel crisscross international waters in fruitless efforts to have it decontaminated and broken up. Mr. Chirac's announcement, a victory for environmental groups led by Greenpeace that challenged the ship's transfer, came on the eve of an official visit to India. KATRIN BENNHOLD (NYT)

title: Jury Urges Millions in Penalties for Nuclear Contamination
description: DENVER, Feb. 15 - A federal jury has determined that cold war military contractors building nuclear bomb components near Denver contaminated lands owned by 12,000 neighbors with plutonium waste, and has recommended $554 million in payments and penalties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEYERS, JUDITH
description: MEYERS - Judith. The Trustees & Staff of Jewish Child Care Association are deeply saddened by the untimely death of Judy Meyers, Director of JCCA's tutoring program, Two Together for 11 years. Under her leadership the program grew from one site to four; the number of children & tutors doubled; parents became even more involved in their children's learning & Judy communicated her passion for teaching & learning to a new generation of young people. Her colleagues at JCCA, Two Together tutors, families, & most of all, the children who learned not only to read, but to love books will miss her terribly. Our heartfelt sympathy to Judy's husband, Howard & her whole family. Leonard Elman, President Barbara B. Mann, Chair Richard Altman, CEO

title: European Chief Defends Speech Freedom in Cartoon Dispute
description: STRASBOURG, France, Feb. 15 - In the face of attacks against foreigners in the Muslim world by violent critics of cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad, the European Union's chief executive said Wednesday that Europe had to fight for its core European values, including freedom of speech.

title: Tutoring Gap
description: The No Child Left Behind Act was supposed to improve education across the board and close the achievement gap between well-off children and poor children. But its goals will remain beyond reach if the Congress and the Education Department fail to provide clear help and guidance on crucial and complex aspects of the law.

title: When Democracy Led to Hamas

title: 'Dancing' Bumps 'Survivor'
description: CBS executives have become accustomed to a routine every time a new-edition "Survivor" hits the air: they hold their breath until the first ratings are in, hoping that the audience has come back.

title: Nordic Combined: Austria finally takes gold after German team fades
Knicks End Their Losing Streak
description: Their standards vastly reduced by misery and humiliation, the Knicks needed only the smallest doses of optimism to renew their faith before the season hit its All-Star Game lull.

title: Even if the Dialogue Seems a Little Off, the Lines Stay Straight
description: Wide-screen films are formatted for screens whose width is 2.35 times their height. When these films are projected on screens in other formats, the top and bottom of the image are sandwiched between horizontal black bars, and sharpness suffers because not all the projector's pixels contribute to the picture.

title: Rolling Stone Gathers Some Satisfaction for a Scot
description: PINEROLO, Italy, Feb. 15 - Rhona Martin returned to Scotland four years ago a national hero, extolled as a homemaker superstar for leading Britain's curlers to the gold medal at the Salt Lake Olympics on the match's final shot: the "stone of destiny."

title: Big Study Finds No Clear Benefit of Calcium Pills
description: A large, seven-year study of healthy women over 50 found no broad benefit from calcium and vitamin D supplements in preventing broken bones, despite widespread endorsement by doctors for the supplements.

title: When Democracy Led to ... Hamas (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: All Clones Are Not the Same
description: Hanover, N.H. - IT has been weeks since President Bush's State of the Union speech, and I have not heard any outcry over his policy statement on cloning: "Tonight I ask you to pass legislation to prohibit the most egregious abuses of medical research: human cloning in all its forms." I can only guess that this means the public doesn't care, or doesn't understand what Mr. Bush means by this, or agrees with his nonsensical concept of what "human" means, or that somehow the stem cell scandal in South Korea has led to widespread agreement that we should just give up on such research. Any of these possibilities would be a mistake, not just for American science, but for the very human life the president seeks to protect.

title: Briefly: On alert, EU panel tightens bird flu rules
Glacier flow in Greenland suggests big rise in oceans
Court Upholds Ban on Talking to Reporters
description: Gov. Robert L. Ehrlich Jr. of Maryland did not violate the First Amendment rights of two Baltimore Sun reporters by prohibiting state employees from talking to them, a unanimous three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, Va., ruled yesterday.

title: Capturing the Spirit of Flamenco in an All-Star Assemblage
description: Flamenco crops up all over town these days, commanding a large and loyal audience. But the annual New York Flamenco Festival, presented by the World Music Institute and an organization called Flamenco Festival Inc., remains the apex of the year's flamenco festivities.

title: Despite Afghan strictures, the poppy flourishes

description: The city's Education Department announced an amnesty program yesterday for school employees who enrolled their children in public schools even though they lived outside the five boroughs and did not pay nonresident tuition.

description: SAUZE d'OULX, Italy, Feb. 15 - Toby Dawson arrived in the United States with no name and no birthday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BALDWIN, ROSAMOND WILDER
description: BALDWIN--Rosamond Wilder. Died in New York City February 14, 2006, at age 96. A Manhattan resident for 42 years, she was a native of Gloucester, MA., widow of professor of history Dr. Summerfield Baldwin 3rd, and beloved mother of Patricia B. Andrews of Baltimore, Mary B. Baer of Annapolis, MD., and William W. Baldwin 2nd of New York City. Also surviving are seven grandchildren & 13 great grandchildren. She was a W.W. II night shift maker of parts for planes; a 1960's two-year VISTA volunteer; in the 1970's and 1980's a volunteer reading tutor for NYC school children. To the end she avidly explored literature with library discussion groups; she marched and spoke out for peace, humanism and social justice; and she walked with her dogs in the free air of NYC parks. A memorial service is planned for spring in Annisquam, Gloucester, MA. Donations to NYPL, 476 5th Avenue, New York City 10138; Catholic Worker, 55 E. 3rd St., NYC 10003; and Cape Ann Animal Aid Assn., 260 Main Street, Gloucester, MA. 01930.

title: Mittal Steel's Chief Seeking Political Allies
description: LONDON, Feb. 15 - European politicians are warming to the $23 billion hostile takeover bid by Mittal Steel for its rival, Arcelor, executives at Mittal declared on Wednesday.

title: If 'Grease' Is Bad, What Shows Can Go On?
description: To the Editor:

title: Icahn Expected to Step Up Time Warner Campaign
description: Carl C. Icahn will try to escalate his fight to break up Time Warner today by proposing a slate of directors that includes Dale M. Hanson, the former chief executive of a powerful pension fund, the California Public Employees' Retirement System, or Calpers, according to people involved in the plan.

title: Arts, Briefly; Dance Theater Workshop Loses Its Artistic Director
description: Cathy Edwards, artistic director of Dance Theater Workshop since 2003 and a central figure in the New York modern-dance community, is to step down on June 30, according to the workshop. She and her family will move to New Haven for new jobs there (Ms. Edwards's will be to program dance and theater at the International Festival of Arts and Ideas). Ms. Edwards, 40, has worked at Dance Theater Workshop since 1996 and is widely credited with injecting new life into its programming. In this, the first season for which she has been solely responsible, there has been an influx of new and innovative artists, as well as the evolution of a residency program to encourage the development of new work. Marion Dienstag, executive director, said that Ms. Edwards would continue as a consultant to the workshop and that a search for a new artistic director would begin immediately. This year, Dance Theater Workshop is celebrating its 40th anniversary. JOHN ROCKWELL

title: Robert W. Peterson, Negro Leagues Historian, Dies at 80
description: Robert W. Peterson, whose pioneering history of the Negro leagues, "Only the Ball Was White," recaptured a lost era in baseball history and a rich facet of black life in America, died Saturday at a hospital in Salisbury Township, Pa. Mr. Peterson, who lived in Lower Macungie Township, Pa., was 80.

title: Defendant in 9/11 Case Heeds Judge
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Feb. 15 - Zacarias Moussaoui resumed his place in a federal courtroom here on Wednesday and sat quietly as lawyers questioned potential jurors after he apparently reversed course and agreed not to disrupt the proceedings.

title: Pretty in Pink, and in Stainless Steel
description: There are very few areas of home design in which Karim Rashid has not dabbled, leaving his mark with organically shaped objects, often in his favorite color: bubble gum pink. This week an unlikely partner, the Danish silver company Georg Jensen, introduced stainless steel boxes by Mr. Rashid. The boxes, $70 to $170, are made to hold anything from keys to candies, and have a removable white liner, above. A limited edition of 4,000 will be lined in pink, below. They will be available at Georg Jensen stores in March; 683 Madison Avenue (62nd Street), (212) 759-6457.

title: From Arrival to Errant Shot, a Timeline of Cheney's Hunting Accident
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 15 - Harry M. Whittington had just made two great shots -- "a double, two birds with two shots" -- recalled Pamela Pitzer Willeford. He had dropped back to retrieve the quail and, she said, "the vice president and I started walking forward."

The unions said they would quit the Building and Construction Trades Department of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., not the federation itself.

description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 15 - For the next five days, the Nets will be able to savor the satisfying aftertaste of victory.

title: Confronting America's Racial Divide, in Blackface and White
description: Brian Sparks, a black man in whiteface, for the first time in his life had a salesman actually slip a shoe on his foot. Bruno Marcotulli, a white man in blackface, declared that the black Bruno and the white Bruno received the same general treatment. He was just waiting to be called a common racial epithet, he said, to show calmly how he would not allow the word to hurt him.

title: British Clinic Is Allowed to Deny Medicine
description: LONDON, Feb. 15 - When her local health service refused to treat her breast cancer with the drug Herceptin, 54-year-old Ann Marie Rogers sued. But on Wednesday, a High Court judge ruled against her.

description: TRENTON, Feb. 15 - Plunging into a contentious case of national interest, the State Supreme Court on Wednesday began weighing arguments about whether New Jersey should become the second state in the nation to permit same-sex marriage.

description: The puppets are folding.

title: Now Prozac Battles Dark Dreams That Khmer Rouge Left
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia - Mao Irang is an evangelist for the new magic in Cambodia, a treatment that can cure everything from headaches to blackouts to nightmares to bursts of violence.

title: Court Veteran Remembers a Scary Start
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 - No one will blame Justice Stephen G. Breyer if he flashes back more than 11 years to his own challenging start on the Supreme Court when Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. is ceremonially sworn in there on Thursday.

title: Latvia's Irbe a Marvel on Ice Against U.S.
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 15 - During last season's N.H.L. lockout, Tampa Bay Lightning goalie John Grahame got his hockey fix by watching "Miracle," the movie based on the 1980 United States Olympic team's gold-medal run. Possibly only the projectionists in the theaters where "Miracle" played saw the film more times than Grahame, who said the other day, "I'll be honest, I must have watched it 80 to 100 times."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OGDON, THOMAS H.
description: OGDON--Thomas H. Died February 15, 2006 in New York. Tom grew up in Tarrytown, NY. He was graduated from Amherst College and was Founder and President of The Ogdon Partnership, an executive search firm. He is survived by his beloved wife, Michele, adoring daughter, Kristin, sons, David H., William B. Ogdon, and a sister, Judith Ogdon Gardner. Tom will be missed by all who knew and loved him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BINGLEY, REV. HOWARD O.
description: BINGLEY--Rev. Howard O., 93, in Topsham, ME, on February 14. Episcopal priest for 30 years in the Diocese of New York; rector emeritus of St. John's Church, Staten Island. He led a life of service and was beloved by many. During WWII he fought in N. Africa, Italy (Battle of Anzio), Germany, France and Belgium, receiving a Purple Heart. A 1949 graduate of General Theological Seminary, he served at the Chapel of the Incarnation (now Church of the Good Shepherd) Manhattan, St. Andrew's Brewster, and for 17 years at St. John's. He was a diocesan youth leader and is a former director of Incarnation Camp, Ivoryton, CT. He retired to Maine in 1978. Marion, his beloved wife of 53 years, predeceased him in September 2005. They are survived by loving daughters Ann Gallops, Brooklyn, and Kathy DeCoster, Alexandria, VA, and 2 grandchildren.

title: Europe Takes Action as Bird Flu Spreads
description: BERLIN, Feb. 15 - Health officials across Europe issued restrictions for commercial poultry farms Wednesday after reports that the deadly bird flu virus had turned up at a surprisingly early date in migratory birds in several Western European countries.

title: Moscow Moves to Restore a Cap on Price of Gasoline
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 15 - Russian government officials said Wednesday that they were in talks with the country's large oil companies to restore a cap on gasoline prices here.

title: A Deal Is Reached to Name a Victor in Haiti's Election
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 15 - The front-runner in last week's presidential election, Ren Prval, is expected to be declared the winner as part of an agreement by leaders of Haiti's interim government to retabulate the votes, a high-ranking official of the Organization of American States said Wednesday night.

title: Norton Kiritz, 70, Teacher of the Art of Seeking Grants, Dies
description: Norton J. Kiritz, who found his niche teaching people with a worthy cause how to pitch it effectively to potential sponsors, died Jan. 30 in Los Angeles. He was 70 and lived in Redondo Beach, Calif.

title: Disney Media Downloads for the Youngest of Computer Users
description: Disney Online, best known for Toontown, a massively multiplayer Internet game for children, has begun a $50-a-year subscription service for the most discriminating of audiences: preschoolers.

title: Corrections
description: An illustration in Science Times on Feb. 7 with an article about energy-efficient ways to make ethanol from corn misidentified an ingredient in one manufacturing process. It is stillage, a byproduct of distillation. (Silage is raw plant matter preserved in a silo to make animal feed.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BURBECK, JOSEPH GRANT
description: BURBECK--Joseph Grant of Rye, New York, died February 13, 2006 at age 74. He is survived by his wife, Theresa Burbeck, daughter, Jennifer Burbeck Gardner, Fairfield, CT and grandchildren Colby and Libby Gardner. A graduate of Dartmouth College (1953) he served as Ensign/ LTJG in Navy 1953-1955, Assistant Boat Group Commander, USS Andromeda. He worked at Saatchi & Saatchi Compton Advertising, New York, NY for 30 years. He was a member of American Yacht Club and The Storm Trysail Club. An accomplished sailor and race judge, he was active in the Star and J30 fleets and winner of Long Island Sound's Ned Anderson Achievement Award. He also served as a past Chairman of American Yacht Club Race Committee. Funeral Services are to be held February 18, 2:00p.m. at The Rye Presbyterian Church. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the American Stroke Association 1-888-478-7653.

title: From the Scars of Katrina, Green Shoots and Blossoms
description: NEW ORLEANS - FIVE months after Hurricane Katrina blew through this city, a fragrant pale pink climber named Clotilde Soupert bloomed in the rose garden of the New Orleans Botanical Garden.

Metro Briefing | New York: Syosset: Service Disrupted After Train Hits Car
description: An eastbound Long Island Rail Road train hit a car parked on the tracks about 7 o'clock last night, setting the car aflame and shutting down part of the Port Jefferson line for several hours, the police said. A body was found in the vehicle, but the police could not immediately identify the victim. The crash took place at the Robbins Lane crossing. Passengers on the train, the 5:47 from Hunterspoint Avenue, were taken to Hicksville Station. Buses shuttled passengers between Hicksville and Huntington last night. Full service was expected to resume this morning. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)

title: Designer Introduces Her Own Line
description: Kristie Strasen, a colorist and textile designer who has worked for Schumacher and Designtex, has introduced her own collection of warmed-up modern fabrics, called Place. Inspired by her travels to Vermont, Venice and Turkey, her fabrics come in 11 styles, including tweeds, boucls, machine-washable synthetics, and wool fleece and cut velvet, above. Ms. Strasen offers them in 105 colors designed in subtle gradations so that any number can be coordinated in an easy way, she said. The fabrics (placetextiles.com), $35 to $150 a yard, are available to the trade at Pollack, in the Decoration and Design Building, 979 Third Avenue (59th Street), (212) 421-8755 , and at the store White Plus One, 309 Main Street, Port Washington, N.Y., (516) 767-2698.

title: Israel Plans Sanctions as Hamas Picks a Prime Minister
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 16 A Hamas appeared ready today to name its candidate for prime minister, while Israel's Defense Ministry drew up sanctions likely to be imposed after a new Palestinian Parliament, dominated by Hamas, is sworn in on Saturday.

title: Chertoff Hears Harsh Criticism From Senators
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 - The homeland security secretary, Michael Chertoff, endured two and a half hours of intense personal criticism Wednesday by Senate Republicans and Democrats investigating the response to Hurricane Katrina, several of whom said he bore responsibility for a multitude of errors that prolonged the suffering of Gulf Coast residents.

title: More U.S. Aid Will Be Sought for Louisiana
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 - Facing complaints that it has not done enough to rebuild New Orleans, the Bush administration announced Wednesday that it would ask Congress for $4.2 billion more to compensate Louisiana residents whose homes were severely damaged by Hurricanes Katrina and Rita.

description: AFTER almost 60 years of driving a cab and collecting fares in New York City, Ray Kottner decided to do something different.

description: No one can argue that country music is monolithic, especially not this week. On Valentine's Day, Willie Nelson released his recording of Ned Sublette's gay-cowboy song, "Cowboys Are Frequently Secretly (Fond of Each Other)." (The song is available on iTunes.)

title: A Bit of the Old West Finds It Hard to Resist the New West
description: ALPINE, Wyo. - The booming, glittering resort town of Jackson has always been 40 miles, and a whole universe, away from the Star Valley of far western Wyoming and its mostly Mormon farming communities.

title: Back Stiffness Puts a Slight Crimp in Pavano's Plans
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 15 - The record will show that before Manager Joe Torre said a word to the news media on his first day at spring training, the Yankees had issued their first medical bulletin on Carl Pavano.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hauppauge: Suffolk Clerk Shuts Down Web Site
description: After Newsday reported that the Social Security numbers of 7,000 to 8,000 Suffolk County residents could be retrieved from property records posted on a Web site of the county clerk's office, Acting County Clerk Judith Pascale shut down the site yesterday. Mrs. Pascale also pledged to seek legislation that would preclude such disclosures in the future. Her deputy, Chris Como, disputed the newspaper's figures, saying the number of Social Security numbers released was probably much smaller. And he said that however many there were, they were buried in the text of 40- or 50-page mortgage and deed documents, where "finding them would be like finding a needle in a haystack." He said that as a rule Social Security numbers were not included on property records. PAUL VITELLO (NYT)

title: A TV Ritual, Longstanding, Adds Cheney
description: Dick Cheney said there was nothing wrong with his handling of Saturday's shooting accident except, of course, his aim.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BELLUSO, JOHN
description: BELLUSO--John. The Public Theater deeply mourns the loss of John Belluso--a brilliant playwright, a tireless advocate for the disabled, a profound thinker, and a warm and generous friend. His words will inspire generations to come. Our heartfelt sympathies to his mother Sally & his sisters Sandi and Diane. Oskar Eustis, Artistic Director Mara Manus, Executive Director

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Whole Grain Labeling Recommendation
description: The Food and Drug Administration said manufacturers should not claim that products are "good sources" or "excellent sources" of whole grains because the agency had not determined what the phrases mean. But agency officials said they did not yet plan any action against anyone making such a claim. Companies have used the term for products with various amounts of whole grains. Federal dietary guidelines call for three one-ounce servings of whole grains daily. The agency is asking companies for voluntary compliance with the labeling recommendation, which is open for public comment for 60 days. MARIAN BURROS (NYT)

title: Thousands in Pakistan join protests of cartoons
The Music That Makes Them Dance Is Monteverdi
description: Richard Alston is a man with a mission. That mission, to judge by the Richard Alston Dance Company's performance on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, is to continue quietly exploring what interests him about dance. Music is one interest, and if his "Fever" looked and sounded a mite lugubrious for the program opener it was, well, that was just too bad. After all, "Gypsy Mixture" was still to come, with its wonderful clackety anarchic score. And in between, Mr. Alston's intimate "Such Longing" would give his dancers a chance to show off their expert dancing and individual presences.

title: The House of Worth
description: NEWPORT, R.I. - RONALD LEE FLEMING said he felt exultant when he purchased Bellevue House in 1999. The house, a Colonial Revival mansion built in 1910, was the work of the celebrated architect Ogden Codman Jr., and a repository of some particularly colorful social history. Codman had designed it for his cousin Martha Codman, a Boston heiress who scandalized Newport society with her 1928 marriage to a Russian opera singer 30 years her junior; later, the house belonged to a former Ziegfeld Girl who gave singing lessons to the heiress Doris Duke and outlived three wealthy husbands.

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 15 - At least 11 people, including four children walking to school, were killed in a surge of bombings and assassinations in the capital on Wednesday.

title: Places, Everyone. Action!
description: One of the most impressive things about us in Washington, you must admit, is our ability to unfailingly play our assigned roles. History throws unusual circumstances before our gaze, but no matter how strange they may at first appear, we are always able to squeeze them into one of our preapproved boxes so we may utter our usual clichs.

title: Skilling's Lawyer Portrays an Accuser as Out of Touch

Skilling, a former Enron chief executive, tried Wednesday to portray the head of the company's broadband unit as an out-of-touch manager who was criticized for his free-spending ways and did not even know how many employees were working under him.

title: Goodbye to Beige, Color Is King
description: COLOR and texture reigned in the textile area at Maison et Objets, the trade show held in Paris at the end of January. Christopher Hyland, owner of a fabric showroom in the D & D Building in Manhattan, has a theory about the high-octane colors he saw at the show: they reflect the evolution of dimmer switches, which now allow people to create "candlelight in an instant." (Back when lighting was always dim, interiors were often painted with intense hues, he said, adding, "Mount Vernon is full of bright, bright green.") The fabrics here are available at the D & D Building, 979 Third Avenue (59th Street), to the trade only, but there is a service for people without decorators; (212) 759-6894. Many of the companies have showrooms in other cities, which are listed at their Web sites. Prices may vary.

Legacy of Lives Under Glass
description: Since 1984, Ben and Natalie Heineman have been filling their Chicago apartment with contemporary glass sculptures. Last month the Heinemans, who are both 92, agreed to give 250 pieces, valued at $9.5 million, to the Corning Museum of Glass in Corning, N.Y. "The thought of living without them is a little hard on us," Mr. Heineman said. A 1988 striped slab by Bertil Vallien hangs from steel cables over their dining table (right), alongside a windowsill full of 1970's vessels by Dale Chihuly. The museum has promised to hold on to all of the objects and to display at least a quarter of them, starting perhaps in 2007; cmog.org.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Places First Despite Olympics
description: The ratings for NBC's primetime Olympics telecast couldn't surpass television's No. 1 show: "American Idol" lifted Fox to a victory in Tuesday's Nielsen estimates. The talent contest delivered an audience of 26.3 million, who watched the judges whittle down the first-round contestants to a group that will face public voting. At 9 p.m., Fox's "House" drew 20 million viewers and won the 18-to-49 demographic for the hour. But NBC managed to scratch its way ahead in viewers, with 20.8 million tuning in to Johnny Weir's skating performance and Bode Miller's disqualification from the men's combination skiing event. NBC placed second for the night in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. KATE AURTHUR
