title: Hercules' Last Travail: Domestic Spat
description: Audiences were baffled when Handel's "Hercules" was first presented in 1745 at the King's Theater in London. The work wasn't an opera, yet it didn't seem to be an oratorio either, though it was performed in concert. It failed to catch on even after Handel's death, despite being one of Handel's most complex and penetrating scores.

title: Review: Consuelo and Alva Vanderbilt

Now Hear This: Hemingway Audiobooks Are Coming
description: "Reading Hemingway is to listen to him, to 'hear' the dialogue," said Patrick Hemingway, the author's son, who joined yesterday with Simon & Schuster to announce that audiobook versions of major novels by Ernest Hemingway, right, would be sold to the general public for the first time beginning in May. The first three titles, "A Farewell to Arms," "For Whom the Bell Tolls" and "The Old Man and the Sea" will be released in May on CD and in downloadable format. (Simon & Schuster is waiting for contracts to be signed before announcing the readers.) One or more titles are then to be released monthly through January. Previous spoken-word editions of Hemingway's major works, which are published by Scribner, a division of Simon & Schuster, were available for libraries but not for sale to the public. Simon & Schuster Audio previously released three volumes of Hemingway short stories (read by Stacy Keach) and an audio version of the posthumous "True at First Light: A Fictional Memoir" (read by Brian Dennehy). EDWARD WYATT

title: At a Famous Brooklyn Oasis, Parched Throats Find a Dry Spell
description: Any regular can tell you that Farrell's Bar and Grill stopped serving food at least a half century ago, the name notwithstanding. Last week, however, Farrell's stopped something else. It didn't serve beer. Or whiskey. Or anything.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Closed Doors And New Jury In Editor's Killing
description: The trial of two men accused of murdering Paul Klebnikov, the American editor of Forbes magazine's Russian edition, resumed under a new judge, who oversaw the selection of a new jury. The previous judge fell ill. The new judge also rejected a defense appeal to open the trial to the public. The two Chechen defendants have pleaded not guilty. The decision to conduct the trial in secret -- reportedly because part of the evidence is classified -- has raised doubts about the strength of the government's assertion that the men conspired to kill Mr. Klebnikov in 2004 on behalf of a Chechen rebel commander. STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RISLEY, WILLIAM S.
description: RISLEY--William S. Educational consultant and longtime resident of Washington, CT. Died February 12 of postoperative complications at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital in New York. Beloved husband of Jane, father of Mandy and Emily, stepfather of John and grandfather of Julia. He is deeply mourned as well by his stepmother, Virginia Risley deCourcy of Washington; brother John; sister Mary; and stepbrothers, Dr. Charles de Sieyes and David de Sieyes and a host of friends in Litchfield County, CT. A memorial service will be conducted Saturday at 11 A.M. in the Washington Club Hall on Route 47 in Washington. The family requests that remembrances be made in the form of contributions to the Steep Rock Association, Inc., the land trust, P.O. Box 279, Washington, CT 06794.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST

In designing the base for China Team, the first Chinese entry in the Cup's 155-year history, Franoise Raynaud, a French architect, has flown in the face of these traditions. She said she intends the base, currently under construction in Valencia, Spain, for the 2007 Cup races there, to be "open and funny," adjectives that may never have been used in conjunction with the Cup.

title: For Those of You Keeping Score at Home
description: Down the street at Hollywood Elsewhere, Jeffrey Wells says its all over but the weeping. Its Ang, Philip, Reese and Rachel. The only competitive category remaining to his eye is best supporting dude, and he thinks its a fight between George Clooney and Paul Giamatti. The Bagger doesnt know how he knows all this, but there you have it. And Mr. Wells gives a big shoutout to Its Hard Out Here for a Pimp, the song from Hustle & Flow. Maybe hes right  its only proper that the song and movie get recognition from a town that knows something about making money by selling the assets of both the unwitting and the complicit.

title: Backlash to the Backlash
description: The O-Factor has a number of preoccupations, including the fact Brokeback Mountain has switched to silent running for the homestretch of the Oscar hunt. The O brothers point out that the Brokeback gang did not do interviews after the nominees lunch and that Ang Lee may be shunning further interviews. The blog says that there is plenty of method in the madness.

title: But What About the Dresses?

title: The Gift Economy
description: The Bagger was traveling for his day job yesterday and spent some quality time on the plane with Sharon Waxmans delicious take on the grasping, gifting industry that has blown up around the awards season. The Baggers favorite moment was when the board of the Hollywood Foreign Press Association had to decide what to do with left over gift bags worth $62,000. That sounds like a room full of children being outfitted with a box of hand grenades, but they decided that no one should get the goodies, all on advice of their able tax lawyer.

title: Mardis Gras, Anyway

title: It Will Play in Singapore

According to the BBC, the movie will be restricted to film-goers over 21, but will otherwise be seen unmolested by the censors there.

title: A Movie Without a Country

In her RiskyBiz blog, Anne Thompson straightens out the mess, as much as it can be, anyway. Read slowly, curves ahead.

title: Infighting in the House of Bush?

Among the prominent online conservatives singled out by Greenwald for this offense was National Reviews Jonah Goldberg. (Following the post, Andrew Sullivan and a few National Review writers have engaged in a small back-and-forth debate over who is more conservative, the anti-Bush Sullivan or the pro-Bush National Review.)

World Briefing | South Pacific: Tokelau: Islanders Reject Independence
description: It would have become the second smallest independent nation after the Vatican, but in a referendum, the people of Tokelau, a group of three small atolls midway between New Zealand and Hawaii, rejected independence and voted to remain the only colony of New Zealand. A total of 349 voters favored self-government against 232, but a two-thirds majority, or 388 yes votes, was required. New Zealand, which has administered Tokelau, population 1,400, since 1925, provides it with about $4 million a year, and Prime Minister Helen Clark sounded disappointed. New Zealand, she said, "would, of course, have been entirely comfortable" with a vote for self-government. RAYMOND BONNER (NYT)

title: The Listings: Feb. 17 - Feb. 23; JOE BRADLEY: 'KURGAN WAVES'
description: In art, pretending to be dumber, more juvenile or less rational than you are usually serves an advanced sophistication. It certainly does in the surprisingly sweet and mysteriously resonant exhibition by Joe Bradley, a young New York-based painter having his third solo show. Mr. Bradley's multipanel paintings consist of flimsy, store-bought canvases brusquely painted single colors and arranged to create the much simplified images of armless, big-shouldered figures resembling primitive video game characters. Standing almost nine feet, with their legs abutting the floor, these "big blocky guys," as the sculptor Dike Blair calls them in an essay written for the exhibition, seem to have gathered for some kind of tribal ceremony. A sky-blue canvas called "Mirror," lying on the stone floor in the center of the gallery, glows like a reflecting pool; a large, squarish canvas on the wall, painted all brown, evokes the earth (above from left "Trans," "Mirror" and "Machine Hash"). (That Kurgan is the name of an evil, immortal warrior in the cult movie "Highlander" may or may not be relevant.) To use a Minimalist vocabulary for such unabashedly anthropomorphic purposes is somehow comical. Joel Shapiro's blocky, puppetlike figures are similarly funny. Mr. Bradley's show might be a joke about what the critic Michael Fried saw as the essentially theatrical nature of Minimalist art. But it also vividly demonstrates how we may experience even the most abstract artworks as animated by life-like or supernatural energies. We may not be as sophisticated as we think. (Canada, 55 Chrystie Street, between Hester and Canal Streets, Lower East Side, (212) 925-4631, through March 4.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENINGSON, RENEE DORIS
description: BENINGSON--Renee Doris. Passed away on February 16, 2006, following a brief illness. She is survived by her husband of 52 years Bob, her daughters Robin and Susan, her sons by choice Joseph and William Coplin, her grandchildren by choice Max, Hannah and Maxine and an extended family. Renee lived an eclectic life as teacher, social worker, successful businesswoman, avid art collector, world traveller and activist in a variety of charities. Her passion for family and her sense of adventure enriched not only the lives of her extended and expanding family but all with whom she had contact. She founded with her daughter Robin, Antiquarium Ltd. Fine Ancient Arts Gallery in which she remained an active partner with Robin and Joseph. She was a graduate of Hunter College, with a degree in Social Work. While participating actively in many institutions and charitable organizations, she was currently serving on the executive board of the American Friends of the Israel Museum, an organization that was close to her heart for nearly 30 years. Funeral services will be held at Temple Beth-El, 350 Roxbury Rd., Stamford, CT, on Monday, February 20 at 12 noon. The family will be receiving at home, in Stamford following the service. Shiva will be at their home Monday and Tuesday evenings, 7 PM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Stamford Hospital or the American Friends of the Israel Museum.

title: Munch Was More Than a Scream
description: EDVARD MUNCH'S vision of modern angst, "The Scream," has been much in the news lately. The trial of six suspects in the theft of one version from an Oslo museum began this week; the painting has not been recovered. The image of "The Scream" has been so widely embraced and reproduced that if you hear the name Munch "The Scream" comes instantly to mind, and vice versa. Yet Munch (1863-1944) regarded "The Scream" as an aberration, one that cast the shadow of insanity on a body of art that he intended to address more universal aspects of human experience.

title: The Listings: Feb. 17 - Feb. 23; GARY WILMES
description: Ever since he croaked out an indie-rock song in the middle of Richard Maxwell's deadpan epic "House" in 1998, Gary Wilmes has been cursed with the label of avant-garde star -- which is a little like being called a tall midget. The lanky Mr. Wilmes has stolen scenes in a handful of plays by Mr. Maxwell, with whom he went to high school, and was also hailed by critics for his twitchy turn as the title character in Richard Foreman's "Bad Boy Nietzsche." His forays into more traditional theater, like his cameo role in "More Lies About Jerzy" at the Vineyard Theater, were mostly ignored. But that's not the case with his devilish performance as a self-absorbed and cruel Manhattan editor in Adam Rapp's "Red Light Winter," an involving play that nicely captures the casually misogynistic banter of overeducated postgraduate dudes. Mr. Wilmes (above, with Lisa Joyce), an athletic presence whose jangly limbs seem to follow the rest of his body across the stage, looks a little old for the part, but his laid-back adolescent arrogance is just right. And while this turn is in a realistic style, look closely enough and you'll notice something oddly unpredictable and ominous about his line readings. He pauses for longer than you expect, and when he cracks a mean joke, he never cracks a smile, as if he's still performing the distinctively flat dialogue of Mr. Maxwell. Mr. Wilmes may have crossed over to more conventional theater, but he has smuggled a bit of the avant-garde with him. (Barrow Street Theater, 27 Barrow Street, West Village, (212) 239-6200; $65.)

It's just not a date-night activity that leaps immediately to mind: checking in with the rap crew that in the 90's pretty much redrew the city map, with Staten Island as the epicenter of phantasmagoric violence and intrigue. But in fact, aside from the expected plugs for new products, the show at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Tuesday was all about love -- dedicated, as is the group's first tour in nine years, to the memory of its founding member Ol' Dirty Bastard, who died in November 2004.

title: Arts, Briefly; Pittsburgh Culture Center Honors August Wilson
description: The August Wilson Center for African American Culture will officially become the new name of the African-American Cultural Center of Greater Pittsburgh, center officials are to announce today. The cultural institution is the first in the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright's hometown to be named for him. Mr. Wilson, left, a Pittsburgh native who set almost all of his plays there, died of liver cancer last year at age 60. In October, the Virginia Theater on Broadway was renamed for him. "August Wilson is dear to our hearts," said Neil Barclay, the president and chief executive of the center. "We're trying to break out of the museum model and talk about our experience in a more holistic way. Not only was August Wilson a great literary figure, but his work is informed by jazz and visual artists like Romare Bearden, so he is an iconic figure who represents that holistic approach." The center in Pittsburgh, incorporated four years ago, will break ground this spring for a new 80,000-square-foot facility in downtown Pittsburgh designed by Allison G. Williams, principal of the San Francisco firm Perkins + Will.

Eliminating the tax abatement Manhattan residents receive for long-term garage parking would add $3 million a year to the city's coffers. And selling the 2,300 remaining units of city-owned housing at market rates, rather than through low- and moderate-cost housing programs, would raise $69 million immediately.

title: Song and Movement Meet, an Easygoing Couple in Love
description: Reggie Wilson takes chances in his choreography, but the risks aren't of the brazen, set-the-planet-on-fire variety. Dedicated to the pairing of vocals and dance, Mr. Wilson has long tried to find a seamless place for the forms to coexist -- or at least, mingle contentedly. His new work, "The Tale: Npinpee Nckutchie and the Tail of the Golden Dek," which opened Wednesday at Dance Theater Workshop, cultivates a concise gem of a world, where music and movement are sewn together by a social dance form called stepping.

description: LUSTBERG--Richard H., 80. Died unexpectedly February 14, of heart failure. "Dick" was the loving husband of Rena (Churgin), devoted father of David, Jamie, sonin-law Mark and adoring grandfather of Alexander. He is also survived by his brother, William of CA, his sister-inlaw Roseann and their children Roger and Cathy. Richard was a proud W.W. II vet. He graduated Cornell U. class of '49. His family owned Lustberg Nast & Co., a men's outerwear firm. Richard cofounded Europa Sport, and created the Hanaw Group Inc. representing fine men's clothing. Richard and Rena have homes in Southampton, NY and West Windsor, VT. He was a long time member of Sunningdale Country Club. Memorial will be held at Frank E. Campbell 3:30 PM, Wednesday, Feb. 22. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to: OCF, P.O. Box 9573, New Haven, CT 06535

Men's Team Gives Italy Another Golden Moment
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 16 - The chant of "Ol, ol!" has become synonymous with soccer, the sport that reigns supreme in this country.

title: Early Simon, Dressed by Mizrahi
description: THE mistakes begin with the wallpaper. When the curtain rises on the torturous new revival of Neil Simon's "Barefoot in the Park," the play's eager newlywed heroine (portrayed by Amanda Peet) is discovered applying, with laborious comic inefficiency, hypnotically striped paper to the walls of her first apartment. Not to put a damper on a young bride's early adventures in decorating, but instead of gluing on wallpaper, shouldn't she be slapping on paint? Then at least the audience would have the diversion of watching it dry.

title: RadioShack Chairman Offers Plan to Right Struggling Company
description: David J. Edmondson, the embattled chief executive of RadioShack, offered two apologies to investors today, for the performance of the company and for having lied about his educational background.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CRIMMINS, ETHAN CUSTIS
description: CRIMMINS--Ethan Custis, 42. Beloved husband of Jo Crimmins & beloved son of Marcy Crimmins of Princeton, NJ and James Custis Crimmins of Santa Barbara, CA. Ethan died in his sleep from respiratory complications. He was a graduate of the Hotchkiss School 1981 and a graduate of the University of Colorado 1985. Ethan leaves behind four sisters, Samantha Smith, Page Seyfried, Tory Brangham and Courtney Crimmins, and ten nieces and nephews. He also leaves behind many loyal and lifelong friends in NY and LA. In work and life he combined his passions for music and travel. He had recently begun work at Amazon on their new digital music project. He was honest, straight forward with strong beliefs and a generous spirit. A memorial service to celebrate Ethan's life will be held at Trinity Church, Princeton, N.J. on Saturday, February 18 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers please make donations in Ethan's name to savethechildren.org

title: 4 Former Insurance Executives Plead Not Guilty in Fraud Case
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Feb. 16 - Three former top executives at a Berkshire Hathaway subsidiary, the General Reinsurance Corporation, and a former senior executive of the American International Group pleaded not guilty on Thursday to federal fraud and conspiracy charges.

title: Stumbling Forward in Haiti
description: The internationally brokered deal that declared Ren Prval the official winner of last week's Haitian election provided the best available exit from a bad and worsening situation. It required reinterpreting the election rules after the votes had been counted, which tarnishes the democratic legitimacy this election was supposed to provide.

title: About 1,000 Muslims Protest Cartoons at U.N.
description: About 1,000 Muslims held a peaceful rally and prayed in a park near the United Nations today to protest the dozen caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad, originally published in a newspaper in Denmark, that have set off a series of violent demonstrations around the world.

title: German Cartoon of Suicide Bombers Angers Iran
description: BERLIN, Feb. 16 - A cartoon in a German newspaper likening Iranian soccer players to suicide bombers has provoked anger in Iran and an official demand for an apology.

title: Amazon Will Take On iPod With Its Own Music Player
description: Correction Appended

title: Displaying a Keen Eye, Even for the Repellent
description: At once unmoored and ruthlessly calculating, the Mexican film "Battle in Heaven" has everything for everyone -- or perhaps nothing at all. Among the attractions are sex, class, God, soccer, an ugly man, a beautiful woman, a dead baby, the dirt below them and the wide sky above. The film was written and directed by Carlos Reygadas, who after making a sensational feature debut four years ago with "Japn" has returned with a strangely mesmerizing and off-putting follow-up that finds him at the crossroads between inspiration and risky self-parody.

title: Obstacle, Yes, but Not a Career Ender
description: SESTRIERE, Italy, Feb. 16 - Kris Freeman, the best cross-country skier in the United States, will awaken here, eat breakfast and inject himself with insulin, a substance that is banned in every Olympic sport. Then he will make his way to Pragelato for the 15-kilometer classical race and try to finish in the top 10.

title: Let's Hope It Isn't Really 'Our Final Descent'
description: In a Pogue's Post entry last week, I expressed my annoyance at flight attendants and pilots who inexplicably insert the utterly redundant word "do" into every sentence. "We do thank you for choosing us," "We do expect to land on time," etc.

title: Barroso stresses Balkans' future in EU
Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about federal immigration authorities' defense of the practice of impersonating officials from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration to catch illegal immigrants omitted credit for the publication that first reported the development. It was Inside OSHA, a newsletter.

title: Munch Was More Than a Scream
description: EDVARD MUNCH'S vision of modern angst, "The Scream," has been much in the news lately. The trial of six suspects in the theft of one version from an Oslo museum began this week; the painting has not been recovered. The image of "The Scream" has been so widely embraced and reproduced that if you hear the name Munch "The Scream" comes instantly to mind, and vice versa. Yet Munch (1863-1944) regarded "The Scream" as an aberration, one that cast the shadow of insanity on a body of art that he intended to address more universal aspects of human experience.

title: Mob Figure Is Charged in Plot to Kill a Rival Gangster
description: A man convicted 20 years ago in one of organized crime's most infamous assassinations was charged again yesterday with murder and racketeering.

title: 'Old Goats' Lead by Example in a United States Victory
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 16 - The old guard raised Old Glory. Bill Guerin, Brian Rolston, Doug Weight and Mike Modano, who have a combined 57 years of N.H.L. experience and 11 Olympic appearances, led the United States to a 4-1 victory against Kazakhstan in a preliminary game Thursday at the Torino Esposizioni.

title: New York Rap the Way it Used to Be, Almost
description: The fact that the New York stop on the Wu-Tang Clan's reunion tour fell on Valentine's Day did seem a funny coincidence. It's just not a date-night activity that leaps immediately to mind: checking in with the rap crew that in the 90's pretty much redrew the city map, with Staten Island as the epicenter of phantasmagoric violence and intrigue. But in fact, aside from the expected plugs for new products, the show at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Tuesday was all about love  dedicated, as is the group's first tour in nine years, to the memory of its founding member Ol' Dirty Bastard, who died in November 2004.

title: A World Where Life Can Seem to Imitate an Imitation
description: WASHINGTON - HIROSHI SUGIMOTO, the celebrated Japanese-born photographer, designed the installation for his own retrospective at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden here, and it is inspired. The first half of the show is light, cool and stylishly sparse. The second half seems dusky and cushioned, as if it were set in a temple or a spacecraft, with pictures shining like windows in the dark.

title: Louisiana Lawmakers Pass Levee Oversight Plan
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 17 A Eager to demonstrate a new reputation for reform, Louisiana's legislators today passed a law consolidating the state's patronage-ridden levee boards, hoping to prove they could now be trusted with Washington's money, several said.

description: The Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, will announce his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for governor on Feb. 25, aides to his campaign and his administration said last night.

description: A Queens man pleaded guilty yesterday in the death of his girlfriend and the abandonment of her 4-year-old daughter, prosecutors said. The man, Cesar Ascarrunz, a building porter from Forest Hills, was charged with killing Monica Lozada, 26, in September and abandoning her daughter, Valery, on a street in Middle Village at night. He faces 25 years in prison for first-degree manslaughter and an additional 21/3 to 7 years for reckless endangerment.

description: STAUFFACHER--Charles B. Of Palm Beach Gardens, Florida died on February 11, 2006 at home. Mr. Stauffacher attended Pomona College and Harvard University Business School. He was with the US Budget Bureau from 1941 to 1952. Mr. Stauffacher was employed by Continental Can Company from 1952 to 1971. From 1971 to 1974, he was President of Field Enterprises in Chicago. He leaves a son, Charles D. Stauffacher of Roxbury, Connecticut and a daughter, Lillian S. Gillies, of Locust Valley, New York; three grandchildren, Heidi M. Martin, C. Barret Stauffacher and James T. Gillies as well as three great-grandchildren. A private memorial service will be held in Florida in the near future. Contributions can be made to Pomona College, 333 North College Way, Claremont, CA. 91711.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Kentucky: Mine Worker Is Killed
description: A worker in a southeastern Kentucky mine died after a roof collapsed, causing rock and debris to fall on him, the authorities said. The worker, Tim Caudill, 33, a roof bolter from Viper, had been moving equipment inside Hazard 4 mine in Perry County when the roof collapsed about 8:30 a.m., the mine's owner, the Perry Coal Corporation, said. The company, a subsidiary of the TECO Coal Corporation, based in Corbin, said co-workers of Mr. Caudill tried to revive him. GARY GATELY (NYT)

A small weather system of blue smoke gathers overhead as snowmobilers pull starter cords. The sleds make a peeved sound. The still morning falls in shards.

This week's contribution to our national slag heap and an early candidate for worst film of the year is "Freedomland," an inept, lethally dull drama directed by Joe Roth and written by Richard Price, based on his novel, about a white child who may have gone missing in a New Jersey public housing complex, where the residents are all black.

That's what Pink Martini did in its sold-out concert on Wednesday night at Town Hall. But it's not a Hollywood confection or just a nostalgic throwback.

title: HAVENS | Ruidoso, N.M.; The Biggest Attraction Is Just Outside the Back Door
description: THE drive from Albuquerque to Ruidoso goes for mile after mile through typical high-desert terrain: rolling hills dotted with low junipers. Distance is a tease. It's a New Mexico many imagine. Then the road inclines up, and off to the side the slopes are covered in Ponderosa pine. You're nearing Ruidoso, tucked into the Sacramento Mountains, with the 12,003-foot Sierra Blanca dominating its western sky.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about investment in alternative energy sources referred incorrectly to a shortage that is among factors slowing the growth of solar energy. The substance in short supply is purified silicon, needed to make solar panels; silica is in ample supply.

description: When the principal of the elite Fieldston school notified parents by e-mail of an assembly that was to feature two Palestinian speakers, he said that it would further the school's "progressive reputation" and that the Palestinian viewpoint was one that "few of us, students or faculty, are familiar with or can claim to understand."

Her second attempt to race after a jarring crash in training on Monday ended with another fall tonight, this time in the second run of the slalom portion of the women's Alpine combined.

The teaming of singers as gratingly mismatched as Faith Prince and Tom Wopat suggests that the chapel in which this union was sealed is light years from the celestial realm. A year ago, these singers, who can be compelling individually, were partly responsible for ruining a Carnegie Hall tribute to the composer Harold Arlen. Now they've put together an act at Feinstein's at the Regency: what were they thinking?

title: 'Worldy Desires'
description: The young Thai filmmaker Apichatpong Weerasethakul knows better than most one of the trickiest parts of his art: how much to impose his imaginative design on the world, and when to let life flow, raw and unmediated, full of all its quirks and longueurs, into his camera. His sly feature debut, "Mysterious Object at Noon" (2001), was a documentary about rural Thailand that played like a surrealist folktale. "Blissfully Yours" (2002) led a group of nonprofessionals into the jungle for an avant-garde picnic, fixing naturalistic actions into highly self-conscious structures. His deliriously inventive "Tropical Malady" (2005) developed this hybrid instinct to such a degree that it spoke with equal authority on the textures of everyday life in Thailand and the desires of a lovesick, shape-shifting tiger shaman. Each of Mr. Weerasethakul's films is an exploration of storytelling, a (head) trip into uncharted narrative terrain. His latest work, the digital short "Worldly Desires" (above), is the most meta of his movies, and perhaps the most enigmatic. The story is once again set in a Thai jungle thick with vegetation and metamorphic energies -- but precisely what sort of story is as ambiguous as ever. There is a film shoot in progress, and the staging of a peppy musical number, but the camera keeps wandering off to stare at the trees or look at a stray dog or linger near some casual talk.("The only foreigner I like is Keanu.") Is this an experimental documentary on the making of Mr. Weerasethakul's new feature? Or has the whole crazy, unclassifiable thing -- imagine a cross between "Symbiopsychotaxiplasm: Take 1" and a painting by Henri Rousseau -- been invented from scratch? "Worldly Desires" is another mysterious object, blissfully ours. (Thursday at 4:30 p.m., Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 875-5600; $10, 60+, $5; students $7.)

title: Pragmatic Hamas Figure Is Likely to Be Next Premier
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 16 - The militant group Hamas on Thursday appeared poised to name its candidate for Palestinian prime minister, while Israel's Defense Ministry drew up sanctions likely to be imposed after the new Palestinian parliament dominated by Hamas is sworn in on Saturday.

title: 36 Hours in Crested Butte, Colo.
description: THE former coal-mining hub of Crested Butte in the south-central Colorado Rockies began attracting skiers in 1961, when the ski area that wraps around the town's like-named peak opened. It remains one of the most historically authentic and captivating ski towns in the state. The small downtown, a National Historic District, oozes charm. Stroll down Elk Avenue, the main thoroughfare, and you're likely to spot residents cycling by, toting skis on their shoulders, and moms pulling toddlers in sleds on snow-packed sidewalks. No chain stores or overabundance of T-shirt shops mar the town's singular appeal. The Butte, as many refer to it, offers a combination of laidback lifestyle, abundant ski terrain at both resort and backcountry, and rugged beauty that perennially attracts some of Colorado's most soulful ski bums.

The service also said recently that it would do the same for the Purple Heart stamp and some holiday stamps that are released later in the year. A spokeswoman, Lauren Sposato, said reprinting the stamps was unusual, but not unprecedented. Ms. Sposato added that the Reagan and Purple Heart stamps were selected because of calls from the public, and because they had sold well when first released. MATTHEW HEALEY (NYT)

title: The Listings: Feb. 17 - Feb. 23; NEW YORK CITY BALLET
description: Nature seems to have realized only recently that it is, in fact, winter, so you could be forgiven for not realizing that New York City Ballet's winter season is almost over. The eight-week run at the State Theater concludes next weekend, but there's still time to catch a few role debuts, a rare appearance by the longtime principal Kyra Nichols (above right, rehearsing with Susan Stroman) and a Balanchine ballet or two. All of the remaining programs end with his works, including "Western Symphony," "Union Jack" and "Brahms-Schoenberg Quartet." (Ms. Nichols is to perform in the first movement of this 1966 ballet on Feb. 25.) The final week will also include four performances of Jerome Robbins's 1951 ballet "The Cage," set to Stravinsky and recently likened to "looking through a keyhole" into the dancers' world by the ballet master Jean-Pierre Frohlich. If you're more interested in taking a peek at newer works, there will be two performances each of the resident choreographer Christopher Wheeldon's "Scnes de Ballet," first performed in 1999, and last year's rapturously received "After the Rain." Also slated are dances by the ballet master in chief Peter Martins, including "Friandises," which had its premiere just last week. (. Tuesday and Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Thursday through Feb. 25 at 8 p.m., with matinees at 2 p.m. on Feb. 25 and 3 p.m. on Feb. 26, New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 870-5570. Program and cast information is at www.nycb.org, though both are subject to change)

title: Knights at the Met, Gunfire at a Parade, as Fiction Takes New York
description: AFTER a brief prologue set in Jerusalem and featuring "gargling shrieks of agony" in the year 1291, "The Last Templar" stomps its hoofprints onto Manhattan. Bursting out of "the marled darkness of Central Park" and galloping up the steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art are four horsemen in medieval armor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOEHM, FRANCES
description: BOEHM--Frances. The Five Towns Forum profoundly mourn the death of its founder, former Chairperson and present board member. Fran was committed throughout her life to the causes of peace and social justice. There was rarely a progressive cause in the United States that Fran and her beloved husband, Bob, were not in some way involved. She was a wonderful human being and knew the true meaning of friendship. We will miss her courage and clarity. Alvin and Rochelle Dorfman, Co-Chairs Five Towns Forum

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hamburg: No Major Damage As Small Earthquake Strikes
description: A small earthquake with a magnitude of 2.6 shook the northern part of Sussex County about 6:45 last evening, according to the United States Geological Survey. The epicenter was near Hamburg, about five miles underground. The ground shook for a few seconds, followed by a few aftershocks. "There may be a couple of cracked foundations that will have to be confirmed tomorrow," said Eskil Danielson, the county's director of emergency management. "But other than that, no major damage, no injuries." JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)

title: Enron Witness Says He Was Ordered to Mislead Company's Board
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 16 - Kenneth D. Rice, who headed Enron's broadband unit, testified Thursday that former chief executive Jeffrey K. Skilling directed him to paint a positive outlook for the company's board, even as Mr. Skilling knew the broadband division was struggling to survive.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Economy Rose 9.1% in 2005
description: Argentina's economy grew 9.1 percent in 2005 as exports jumped to a record high and a surge in government spending increased domestic demand. Argentina, South America's second-biggest economy after Brazil, has now expanded more than 8 percent for three consecutive years, rebounding from its worst recession on record.

title: He Made a Run to Freedom, and Kept Going
description: Sandu Rebenciuc has lived in Romania, Turkey, Italy and the United States. He went to boot camp one year and the Olympic trials the next. He has learned four languages and five sports: shooting, fencing, swimming and riding, in addition to running, which has been his constant companion for most of three decades.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Subway Station Will Remain Closed
description: The Cortlandt Street subway station, which has been closed since August, will remain closed for a year because of safety hazards resulting from work on the planned Fulton Street Transit Center. New York City Transit, which had planned to reopen the station this month, said yesterday that excavation and platform work made the station a "construction work zone." A 150-foot underpass beneath the station is to connect the new transit center with future developments at the World Trade Center. The station will be off limits to passengers and will be bypassed by trains on the R and W lines until spring 2007, the transit agency said. THOMAS J. LUECK (NYT)

title: This Time, Someone Has Stuck With Little
description: VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16 - Grady Little had doubts, nagging doubts, that he would manage a major league team again. Those doubts, he said, drifted in and out of his mind, staying as long as he would let them. Still, it must have felt like trying to control a migraine.

Accord in House to Hold Inquiry on Surveillance
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 - Leaders of the House Intelligence Committee said Thursday that they had agreed to open a Congressional inquiry prompted by the Bush administration's domestic surveillance program. But a dispute immediately broke out among committee Republicans over the scope of the inquiry.

description: BRAUNSCHWEIG--Willi Kirkham. February 17, 2004. Age can not wither her, nor custom stale her infinite variety.

title: The Quiet Resolve of a German Anti-Nazi Martyr
description: "Sophie Scholl: The Final Days" conveys what it must have been like to be a young, smart, idealistic dissenter in Nazi Germany, where no dissent was tolerated. This gripping true story, directed in a cool, semi-documentary style by the German filmmaker Marc Rothemund from a screenplay by Fred Breinersdorfer, challenges you to gauge your own courage and strength of character should you find yourself in similar circumstances. Would you risk your life the way Sophie Scholl (Julia Jentsch) and a tiny group of fellow students at Munich University did to spread antigovernment leaflets? How would you behave during the kind of relentless interrogations that Sophie endures? If sentenced to death for your activities, would you still consider your resistance to have been worth it? In a climate of national debate in the United States about the overriding of certain civil liberties to fight terrorism, the movie looks back on a worst possible scenario in which such liberties were taken away. It raises an unspoken question: could it happen here?

description: LONDON, Feb. 17 A One day after a British government minister endorsed a United Nations call for the GuantAnamo Bay detention facility to be closed, Prime Minister Tony Blair today called the camp an "anomaly" to be dealt with "sooner or later."

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Luxembourg: Arcelor Raises Dividend to Fight Bid
description: Arcelor, the world's second-biggest steelmaker, will almost double its dividend to 768 million euros ($915 million) as it tries to fend off a hostile $21.9 billion bid from Mittal Steel, the world's largest producer. Shareholders will get 1.20 euros a share ($1.43), up from 65 cents a year earlier, Arcelor, which is based in Luxembourg, said.

title: The Fiery Spirit of a Gypsy Camp Swirls Through the City
description: Flamenco crops up all over town these days, commanding a large and loyal audience. But the annual New York Flamenco Festival, presented by the World Music Institute and an organization called Flamenco Festival Inc., remains the apex of the season's flamenco festivities. The 2006 New York presentations of dance and music, which began on Feb. 3 and end on Sunday, have included concerts at the Skirball Theater, Symphony Space and Town Hall, and dance performances (which naturally also include music) at City Center. There were also performances in Washington, Boston and Chicago, and a North American tour by the Nuevo Ballet Espaol, and comparable events in London.

title: Don't Dumb Down the Army
description: Cambridge, Mass. - DESPITE claims to the contrary by Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld, the Army is facing a manpower crisis. The evidence can be found in two separate reports released last month -- one commissioned by the Pentagon, the other by Congressional Democrats -- and in this simple fact: last year the Army accepted its least qualified pool in a decade.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Archdiocese Hires Consultants
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago has hired independent consultants to examine how accusations of child sexual abuse are handled. Defenbaugh & Associates Inc., an international security consulting and investigations firm, will review the archdiocese's actions related to accusations of child sexual abuse involving two priests. The cases came under fire after it was disclosed that the priests had been monitored but not immediately removed from the ministry after being accused. The archdiocese also appointed a licensed clinical social worker to review the policies for monitoring accused priests. GRETCHEN RUETHLING (NYT)

title: Russian Is First Athlete Banished
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 16 - The Russian biathlete Olga Pyleva was thrown out of the Olympics and stripped of her silver medal Thursday, becoming the first athlete at these Winter Games to fail a drug test.

title: Ernie Stautner, 80, Who Starred as Undersized N.F.L. Tackle, Is Dead
description: Ernie Stautner, an undersized defensive tackle who became the best player on the Pittsburgh Steelers' woeful teams in the 1950's and was later enshrined in the Pro Football Hall of Fame, died yesterday in a nursing home in Carbondale, Colo. He was 80 and lived in Vail, Colo.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Rosneft Will Float Shares at Home and Abroad
description: Russia, eager to make the biggest splash possible, will float shares in the state oil company Rosneft on foreign and domestic stock exchanges simultaneously, the country's top securities regulator, Oleg Vyugin, said at a news conference. Rosneft hopes to raise $20 billion in the initial public offering, which would be the largest public offering ever, exceeding the $18 billion debut of NTT DoCoMo of Japan in 1998.

title: City Proposes Tougher Limits on Lobbyists
description: Saying they wanted to avoid the sort of influence-peddling scandal that is rocking Washington, New York City leaders yesterday proposed a set of strict new limits on lobbyists that would bar them from certain areas inside City Hall at certain times and severely limit their ability to shower officials with gifts and campaign donations.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Ukraine Deports 11 Uzbek Refugees
description: Ukraine deported 11 refugees from Uzbekistan, prompting an unusually sharp rebuke from the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, which said the Uzbeks had sought political asylum and called the action illegal. The Uzbeks were reportedly suspected of involvement in the armed uprising last May in the city of Andijon, where Uzbek troops killed scores of people. They were detained in Crimea on Feb. 7. A spokeswoman for Ukraine's security services said in a telephone interview that a court in Crimea had ordered their deportation, apparently without allowing them to appeal. STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)

title: Haitians Dance for Joy as Prval Is Declared Winner
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Feb. 16 - The protests that paralyzed cities across the country turned into celebrations on Thursday as news spread that Ren Prval, a former president with overwhelming support among this country's poor, had been declared the next president.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retail Sales Slowed in January
description: Retail sales in Britain fell the most in 13 months in January as consumers reined in their spending after a holiday splurge. Sales dropped 1.3 percent from December. The annual increase in sales slowed to 1.3 percent from a revised 4.3 percent.The Bank of England said Wednesday that "steady expansion" in consumer spending was likely over the next three years.

description: MOSCOW, Feb. 17  In a controversy with echoes of the Islamic anger over Danish cartoons depicting the Prophet Muhammad, the authorities in a central Russian city today ordered the closing of a newspaper that published a cartoon showing Muhammad along with Jesus, Moses and Buddha.

title: $8,000 Stolen From Safe in High School in Roslyn
description: ROSLYN, N.Y., Feb. 16 - For the past two years, since the first signs of the theft that would eventually unfold as an $11 million larceny of school funds, people here have reminded everyone that the real victims of the fraud were the students.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Faulted on Guantnamo Investigators working for the United Nations called on the United States to shut down the Guantnamo Bay camp and either try its detainees quickly or free them. They contended that many of the interrogation and detention practices amounted to torture. The White House dismissed the report. PAGE A6

Whittington. They are 0.095 inches in diameter, or 2.4 millimeters, as shown in an illustration with the article -- not about 5 millimeters.

title: Death Metal Sweetened by a Taste of Lingonberry
description: Suffice it to say that the Swedish death-metal revolution has never quite swept the American pop charts. More than a decade ago, In Flames and a handful of other bands figured out a way to sweeten up the roaring, snarling sound of death metal. By laying big, sometimes melancholy guitar lines over gruff, frenetic riffs, they created a style that was both fierce and sentimental. On a great 1995 album called "The Jester Race," In Flames perfected its grand, galloping sound: guttural vocals at the bottom, triumphal guitar lines on the top.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kyrgyzstan Refuses Asylum To Uzbek Refugees
description: Kyrgyzstan's Supreme Court rejected the refugee status of two Uzbeks who fled the bloody crackdown in Andijon last May, their lawyers said. They had been granted refugee status by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. The Kyrgyz government will now decide whether to send them back to Uzbekistan, where human rights groups and Western governments say torture is commonplace. The two men are accused by the Uzbek government of killing a regional prosecutor during the uprising. ETHAN WILENSKY-LANFORD (NYT)

description: Consolidated Edison continued to supply electricity to a nonexistent streetlight in Brooklyn nearly seven years after it was told to cut off power because the light was scheduled for removal, the utility acknowledged yesterday. On Wednesday morning, a dog was electrocuted on the same spot.

title: Corrections

Her sister was the first to receive a scholarship under a program set up in 1945 to recruit minority students, not the first black to enroll.

title: Mountains Are Making Room for Tubes
description: FOR a moment, imagine the scene: the snow-topped chateau, the piping hot toddy, the crackling fireplace. You're pulling off your boots, sinking back into the overstuffed couch -- hey, it has been a tough day on the slopes. "The black diamonds get you?" the waitress might ask. "Nope," you'd say. "Been tubing."

title: China Seeking Auto Industry, Piece by Piece
description: CHONGQING, China, Feb. 16 - China is pursuing a novel way to catapult its automaking into a global force: buy one of the world's most sophisticated engine plants, take it apart, piece by piece, transport it halfway around the globe and put it back together again at home.

description: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif., Feb. 16 - When the sun crested over Riviera Country Club on Thursday, it was already a different Nissan Open than a year ago, when puddles outnumbered people.

title: Season High
description: Rachel Steer of Anchorage recorded a season best 35th in the women's 7.5-kilometer sprint biathlon yesterday at Cesana San Sicario. Her time of 24 minutes 29.6 seconds was 1:58.2 off the winning time of France's Florence Baverel-Robert. "I had one prone penalty and shot clean on standing today," Steer said. "I definitely felt better than I did in the 15K. I felt like my skiing was better. My skis were great. " JOE WARD (NYT)

title: A Cold War of the Occult Heats Up in Moscow
description: If you were forced to reduce its mythological mechanics to a glib catch phrase, the story of "Night Watch," a convoluted Russian horror fantasy based on the novels of Sergei Lukyanenko, might be described as Star Wars Meets the Vampires in Moscow. That description barely begins to describe the clammy atmospheric intensity of much of the film, the first part of a projected trilogy based on Mr. Lukyanenko's novels.

title: 36 Hours in Crested Butte, Colo.
description: THE former coal-mining hub of Crested Butte in the south-central Colorado Rockies began attracting skiers in 1961, when the ski area that wraps around the town's like-named peak opened. It remains one of the most historically authentic and captivating ski towns in the state. The small downtown, a National Historic District, oozes charm. Stroll down Elk Avenue, the main thoroughfare, and you're likely to spot residents cycling by, toting skis on their shoulders, and moms pulling toddlers in sleds on snow-packed sidewalks. No chain stores or overabundance of T-shirt shops mar the town's singular appeal. The Butte, as many refer to it, offers a combination of laidback lifestyle, abundant ski terrain at both resort and backcountry, and rugged beauty that perennially attracts some of Colorado's most soulful ski bums. CINDY HIRSCHFELD

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: County Unveils Proposals For Coliseum Project
description: Two proposals emerged as finalists yesterday as officials completed their review of four bids for the construction of a $1.6 billion "hub" in central Nassau County. The project would renovate the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale and build a surrounding complex for offices, apartments, stores and entertainment. Officials will negotiate with the two bidders to make a final choice. One bidder is a partnership of Charles Wang, left, owner of the Islanders hockey team and former chairman of Computer Associates, and the Reckson development company. The other is a partnership of the Mets baseball organization, Sterling Equities and Blumenfeld Development. The project is subject to approval by the County Legislature and the Town of Hempstead. BRUCE LAMBERT (NYT)

title: What Do You Have on Your iPod?
description: The Bagger was speaking in Rochester, N.Y., and the flight back was just long enough to accommodate an episode of the American version of The Office. The episode, from season one, was called Office Olympics and had the Bagger making funny noises to suppress laughter. It was one of those little jets and the flight attendant was casting worried looks in his direction, but the Bagger stayed immersed in his iPod, transfixed by Steve Carells antics. And now word comes that Mr. Carell, in addition to Nicole Kidman and Will Smith, will get some podium time at the Oscars. Now, the Bagger is not so gob-smacked on the Oscars that he is unwilling to admit that much of the evening seems short on suspense and gravitas, but between Mr. Carell, Terrence Howard, and host Jon Stewart, it could be a fun night by turns. As the Bagger has noted before, this is something of a transitional year for the Oscars, and if the new new thing is not going to include cheesy production numbers and Catskills comedy, well, viva la neuvo, down with the old.

title: Well Always Have Poland
description: The Bagger has been chewed out by his readers for linking to Dave Poland, overlord of the Hot Button, but in the tiny town of those who are Oscar-obsessed, he is one of the few guys who really thinks about this stuff. Sure, he goes flying into the ditch every so often, but he says whatever is rattling around between his ears. Mr. Poland, for the time being, is bored and underwhelmed with this years campaign:

title: Topical Insecurity
description: The presence of Paradise Now at the Oscars  its up for best foreign film  reportedly has law enforcement officials on alert for an increased security threat. The web site TMZ says:

title: The Other Brother
description: Lots of people have been making cracks about the pictures in the Vanity Fair Hollywood issue, so the Bagger picked up a copy himself. The Bagger noticed a trussed-up Peter Sarsgaard, a VERY relaxed Sienna Miller, the ever-freakish old soul/new kid on the block Dakota Fanning, and lots of nekkid people. The Bagger is the kind of guy who showers with his shirt on, so he admires the courage of people who are willing to do all sorts of sharing with their public. But the most impressive picture for the Bagger was one entitled The Warriors. The image is not available online, so the Bagger, through precision use of his craft and well-chosen words, will do his best. There is a picture of Harvey Weinstein. Harvey looks good. Its not the fake Harvey, the jolly smile that he gets just before he is about to devour your soul. This was Harvey looking tough, smart, and yes, down to his fighting weight. Harvey was flanked by a very debonair businessman, a handsome guy whose face was writ with intelligence, a kind of executive warmth, and quiet resolve. The Bagger stared and stared at the picture and then finally looked at the caption. The guy in the jillion dollar suit next to Harvey was  his brother Bob. The Bagger does not know Bob well, but he has been in a few meetings with him. And Bob, surely a man who knows his way around his business and genre films in particular, is no threat to serve as the rack for the next fashion shoot in Esquire. Man, the Bagger knows Vanity Fair makes people look better than they are in real life and all, but the other brother looked amazing. The Bagger, who specializes in rumpled suits and untucked shirts, is a doughy white guy who covets the new Bob Weinstein look. He would do anything to look like that. Except allow Tom Ford to sniff his neck.

title: A Voter Sends the Bagger a Message. There is None.
description: The Bagger was talking last night with someone about something besides the Academy Awards  despite current appearances, the Bagger has other interests  but then the person on the other end of the phone made the mistake of mentioning that he was a member of the Academy.

title: Military Housing
description: Proposed legislation in the state of Maryland would require real estate agents to inform potential homebuyers about high noise levels if the property they are considering is located near a military installation that conducts flight operations, munitions testing, or military operations, according to the bills sponsor, State Senator Roy Dyson. The St. Mary County Democrat ,who represents Calvert, Charles and St. Mary counties, said he introduced the bill after talking with representatives of the U.S. Navy. It seems the Navy was getting a lot of calls about noise from homeowners on Marylands Eastern Shore where the Patuxent River Naval Air Station is located. A number of people are buying expensive retirement or summer homes in the area and didnt know they were near a naval base. RON NIXON

title: By George, the People Are Speaking
description: There has been a long-running assumption that many New York Times readers are tendentiously liberal, the type who reflexively suspect the current administration, share a certain New York senators tendency to see a vast right wing conspiracy around every corner and hold out George Cloooney as their pop cult demigod  not just because he is handsome, charming and erudite, but because he shares all the aforementioned political markers. (Hes on the cover of the forthcoming Sunday Times magazine, btw.) For the time being, those canards about Times readers seem to be true.

title: Gambling on Real Estate
description: One of the hottest real estate markets in the country right now is Biloxi, Miss.  the same Biloxi that was devastated by Hurricane Katrina. Many people who have sold their property have reported getting $40 to $50 per square foot, and some property owners stand to make $2 million on an acre of property, according to a local banker. The prices were closer to $10 to $15 per square foot before the storm. The reason for the hot market is developers who are hoping to rebuild casinos and add resorts and condos. At least one casino owner has expressed concerns that the record prices are slowing recovery in the area. RON NIXON

title: Race for Hall of Fame
description: The birthplace of Nascar faces big odds at being chosen to host the coveted Nascar Hall of Fame.

title: Video: Best Actress?
description: David Carr, a k a the Carpetbagger, who they think will win this years Best Actress Oscar  if he can get them to stop and talk.

title: The Web 2.0 Menace: Utopian Marxism
description: The latest Internet craze is Web 2.0, a concept that involves, in part, empowering users to create their own content and then to aggregate and disseminate it, using blogs and other online software. (John Battelle, author of The Search, argued that Web 2.0 is more than just a buzzword  in a Times op-ed last year.)

title: The Lifan Factory
Wings and Things
description: There are nights when even the most committed gourmand cannot wrestle with another Niman Ranch pork chop, ponder yet another panna cotta or hear another server murmur, Pardon my reach.

title: Any Limits to Cheneys Power?
description: In his Wednesday interview with Brit Hume on Fox News, Vice President Dick Cheney said that an executive order issued by the president gave him the authority as vice president to declassify information. Steve Clemons of the Washington Note questions Cheneys claim. In my view, the law says No, he writes. Clemons interprets President Bushs March 25, 2003, executive order No. 13292 , which everyone assumes is the order to which Cheney is referring, to mean that the vice president can classify but not declassify information. So, Cheney is engaged in Executive Branch over-reach again, implying he has a power that is not designated, Clemons concludes.

title: Dining in Packs (Cont.)
description: A reader correctly noted that limitations on what can be ordered are not the only special circumstances that large parties face. At restaurants that otherwise dont require credit cards to guarantee reservations, large parties will often be asked to provide precisely that.

title: Bought a Condo? Uh-Oh.
description: Motoko Rich found the perfect example to capture the collapse of sales in the condo market. From her article in todays New York Times:

description: The Calculated Risk blog says that Ben Bernanke, the new Federal Reserve chairman, is being too optimistic. The chairman said:

title: Iffy  Jobs in the Housing Industry
description: The Big Picture, another economics blog, questions Fed Chairman Ben Bernankes optimism about a soft landing for the real estate market. The blog points to Washington Mutual firing 2,500 people from its mortgage unit.

title: Cheney and His Shotgun
description: One of the elements of Cheneys account of the shotgun incident that doesnt ring true to me is the notion that he was 30 yards away from Whittington when the shooting occurred. At that distance, the pellets would be far more dispersed, rather than concentrated in the chest and lower left-hand side of his face. I frankly dont see how you could possibly get a shotgun pattern that would produce that many pellets in so concentrated an area at 30 yards.

title: Bush Speaks on Darfur
description: Im always complaining that Bush doesnt speak up more about Darfur. But today he actually brought it up in response to an unrelated question. Im delighted he did, and I hope he uses his bully pulpit even more. Heres what he said:

title: Are They Still Saying  This?
description: Keith at Housing Panic, one of the bubble blogs that enthustiastically find the gloom and doom, found a real estate agent who apparently hasnt seen the latest memo from David Lereah, the National Association of Realtors chief economist.

title: How Much is a Broker Worth?
description: Curbed.com, the New York City real estate blog, has found a good illustration of how much it costs to sell your place.

title: List of War Criminals
description: The American Prospect has just posted an article describing the secret U.N. list of war criminals linked to Darfur. It says that Salah Gosh, the top intelligence official for Sudan and a partner in our war on terror, is on the list. That raises obvious questions about cooperating with a figure who himself is responsible for instilling one of the worst forms of terror, i.e. genocide.

title: Danger: Curve Ahead
description: For anyone whose eyes glaze over at the mere mention of the inverted yield curve, Jonathan Miller over at Matrix walks us through an explanation of why it matters to anyone in real estate.

title: Reduced!
description: A price reduction doesnt necessarily mean prices are dropping. It could mean that the seller was too greedy to begin with and buyers have sobered up. (It could also be a game played by real estate agents to induce buyers into thinking they are getting a bargain, but agents wouldnt do that.)

description: A conversation with Pamela and Vincent Pagano about how they met and got married.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WASSERMAN, LEONARD
description: WASSERMAN--Leonard. Beloved husband of Germaine, devoted father of Eric & father-in-law of Joan. Loving grandfather of Shanna Zuspan and her husband Jarrett & Evan Wasserman, dear brother of Phoebe, Robert, loving uncle to Alyson Miller and Gary Roberts. Veteran of WWII and a dedicated trade unionist. A gentle spirit with an artist's heart and understanding nature. Services will be held 12:45 PM Sunday, February 19 at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Burial Monday, February 20 at Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Compassion for Cheney as Victim Heads Home
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Feb. 17 - Declaring that "accidents do and will happen," the 78-year-old man who was shot by Vice President Dick Cheney at a weekend quail hunt emerged from the hospital here Friday looking tanned, cheery, robust and speckled with bruises.

title: Testimony on 2 Air Marshals Hints at Wider Drug Inquiry
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 17 - Testimony on Thursday at the arraignment of two federal air marshals charged with using their credentials to engage in a cocaine smuggling conspiracy suggested that the case might involve other marshals as well.

description: NEWTON, Mass., Feb. 17 - It all started eight years ago as a sketch on a napkin.

title: You Think 401(k)'s Are Hard to Manage? Try Health Accounts
description: AMERICANS were handed -- some might say had forced upon them -- control of their retirement funds 32 years ago with the creation of the Individual Retirement Account. The 401(k), invented four years later, cemented the idea that individuals must take more responsibility for their financial future.

title: Wild Piano Ride for Double 70th Birthdays
description: It sounded like a false start. Lang Lang was sitting at the keyboard, the Israel Philharmonic was poised for the downbeat, Zubin Mehta lifted his arms, and there was a kind of stumble as the orchestra plunged into music that, for a moment, sounded badly wrong. The orchestra was playing "Happy Birthday" to the maestro.

title: Good Dog. But What About the Trainer?
description: THOSE who watched the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show this week saw animals trained to military precision, obeying commands at the flick of a finger.

title: Fired Editors of Chinese Journal Call for Free Speech in Public Letter
description: LANZHOU, China, Feb. 17 - The controversy over news media censorship in China continued Friday as two editors who had been removed from a feisty weekly journal, Freezing Point, issued a public letter lashing out at propaganda officials and calling for free speech.

title: No Jail Time Expected After Positive Drug Test
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 17 - Italian officials said Friday that the Russian biathlete who tested positive for drugs would almost certainly not face jail time under Italy's stiff antidoping laws, even as she was barred from her sport for two years.

title: Daviss Focus on His EventIs Paid Back in Gold
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 18 A A The first episode of speed skatingAs soap opera ended Saturday with the American Shani Davis of the United States skating around Oval Lingotto wearing a big smile, with a largely Dutch crowd standing and applauding a spectacular gold-medal-winning performance in the 1,000 meters Saturday.

description: SOUTHWEST

title: The Price of Going for the Gold
description: DURING the winter Olympics, you can count on figure skaters falling during a pivotal part in their routines, some young phenom setting a record during the downhill skiing, and lots and lots of reaction shots of parents watching their offspring go for the gold.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: 2 Opponents To Challenge Leader
description: Belarus's election commission registered three candidates to challenge President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, the country's authoritarian leader since 1994, in an election on March 19 that few expect to be free or fair. They include Aleksandr Milinkevich, a former physics professor chosen to lead a diverse coalition of Lukashenko critics, but also a second opposition leader, Aleksandr Kazulin, who sharply criticized the president during remarks at the commission's meeting in the capital, Minsk. "When Lukashenko was being elected, we did not have any enemies," The Associated Press reported him as saying. "Now we have enemies all over. We are the outcast of the 21st century." Another candidate, Sergei Gaydukevich, is a member of Parliament and leader of the Liberal Democratic Party who has allied himself with Mr. Lukashenko over the years. STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)

title: Two New TV Series Are Liberal and Proud
description: The filmmaker Robert Greenwald and others on the political left say real-life stories dealing with issues like gay rights, racial profiling and environmental pollution are needed in an era of conservative political leadership. To that end, Mr. Greenwald has helped the Sierra Club and the American Civil Liberties Union create their own television series. The two liberal groups see this as only the beginning of more such shows to get their messages out.

title: Asbury Park Gives Developer a Deadline for a Project Long Overdue
description: ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 15 - The Asbury Park City Council, under pressure to show more progress on redeveloping 56 acres on the blighted oceanfront, has given the master developer one month to negotiate changes in its agreement with the city to speed progress and prove its financial ability to fulfill the plan.

title: A Contrarian Says of G.M.: Buy Low
description: THE decision by General Motors to halve its dividend has left many investors unconvinced of the company's ability to solve the chronic problems that threaten its position as the world's largest carmaker.

title: Enough Shame to Go Around on China
description: I have a few simple questions," the congressman said, scowling at the four witnesses before him. "Can you say, in plain English, that you are ashamed of what you and the other companies have done?"

title: For a Dear Museum: Love, Hallmark
description: It could be a greeting card commercial. A major corporation compiles a stunning multimillion-dollar photography collection and then decides to give it away. Museums around the world covet it, yet the corporation chooses a hometown institution. You can almost hear the music swell as the museum director wipes a tear of gratitude from his eye.

title: Delphi Continues Talking to Unions, but Contracts Are Still in Peril
description: DETROIT, Feb. 17 - The Delphi Corporation, which is operating in bankruptcy, said Friday that it would keep talking with its unions and General Motors in a bid to reach a deal on lower wage and benefit rates.

Lowe is an assistant coach with the Detroit Pistons, but yesterday he was head coach for the rookie team that would play N.B.A. second-year players in the Rookie Challenge. Lowe wore a microphone so that the fans watching practice could hear him interact with his team.

description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 17 - There has never been a pitcher quite like Randy Johnson. Only a few have ever been as tall, and none of those have approached Johnson's success.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 - It is just the sort of parochial spending request that might lead Senator John McCain, nemesis of pork barrel projects, to give somebody an earful.

description: Susie Ibarra first made her mark in the early 1990's as an adept free jazz drummer in the Little Huey Creative Music Orchestra, led by the bassist William Parker. The arrival of a slight young Filipino-American woman into one of downtown's most raucous and adventurous ensembles was bound to create a stir, and it did.

title: Defendants in Terror Case Seek Removal From Solitary
description: Three Muslim men accused in an elaborate federal sting operation of plotting to provide training and money to terrorists have been held for months in solitary confinement, locked in cells at least 23 hours a day with the lights always on, their lawyers said yesterday.

title: Shuttle Astronauts Ready for Mission in May
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 17 - Six of the seven astronauts who are to fly the next space shuttle mission made their first joint appearance here on Friday, and the commander said NASA continued on course for a liftoff in May.

title: Rolling Stone Publisher Out After 2 Years
description: Steven DeLuca's two-year tenure as publisher of Rolling Stone ended yesterday after what magazine executives described a flare-up with Jann Wenner, the magazine's founder.

title: Barry Martin, Dancer and Choreographer, Dies at 44
description: Barry Martin, a modern dancer who turned to a career in choreography after an accident made him a quadriplegic, died on Feb. 6 at his home in Manhattan. He was 44.

description: A man raped a 20-year-old woman and two teenagers in their Bronx apartment buildings this week, the police said yesterday.
