title: Time Warner and Icahn Reach a Settlement
description: The sudden end of the assault by Carl C. Icahn on Time Warner yesterday came after a last-ditch effort by Mr. Icahn late Thursday night to gain representation on Time Warner's board.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Jan. 7 about problems encountered by American soldiers in Iraq with body armor referred imprecisely to a statement by the military's medical examiner, Dr. Craig T. Mallak, that information he was collecting on military deaths "screams to be published." Dr. Mallak's information concerned a range of noncombat and combat-related deaths and was not limited to armor-related incidents. The error was reported by a reader late last month, and this correction was delayed for additional research.

title: Albany's Second Step to Rehabilitation
description: New York's state government has been a standing joke for ages, but last year legislators and Gov. George Pataki made a good start at airing out their secret club. That first step will look pretty feeble, though, if they sit back now and pat their bellies in satisfaction. New York deserves a government people can look up to -- not laugh at. This is how to keep moving in the right direction:

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Wednesday about the record-setting $2.9 million sale of a 1904 photograph by Edward Steichen, "The Pond -- Moonlight," at a Sotheby's auction misstated the location of the pond. It was in Mamaroneck, in Westchester County, not on Long Island.

title: Hunting for a Straight Shooter
description: Correction Appended

title: KeySpan Says It Has Bidders
description: KeySpan, the Brooklyn-based utility company, confirmed yesterday that it was in talks with potential buyers.

title: Next Trick: Bring Back the Magic
description: NEW ORLEANS - Harry Anderson stalked out of a French Quarter bar this month to point at the garbage. An enormous pile of debris had accumulated there like a snowdrift of detritus at the corner of Decatur and Ursuline. He wanted the pile gone, but the city had not picked it up. He had offered to hire a truck and crew to remove it, he said, but FEMA would not allow that until it could determine whether the material was toxic.

title: Report on Impact of Federal Benefits on Curbing Poverty Reignites a Debate
description: A brief report this week from the Census Bureau, highlighting how welfare programs and tax credits affect incomes among the poor, has fanned the politically charged debate on poverty in the United States and how best to measure it, with conservatives offering praise and liberals saying it underplays the extent of deprivation.

title: Morocco's Past, Morocco's Future
description: Moroccans will mark a half-century of independence next month, but they have spent those years under monarchs with unchecked power. The security forces of the former king, Hassan II, arrested, exiled, jailed, tortured or killed thousands of critics or perceived critics and sometimes their families as well. Repression softened in the 1990's. Hassan's son, Mohammed VI, who succeeded him in 1999, established a truth commission to investigate the crimes of his father and grandfather. It was the first such commission in the Arab world, but its achievements would be an impressive attempt to deal with the past anywhere.

title: Interfaith Couples
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Sentenced to Probation for Shining Laser at a Plane
description: NEWARK, Feb. 17 - A man who pleaded guilty to shining a laser beam at a passing airplane, temporarily blinding the pilot and co-pilot, was sentenced to two years of probation in federal court here on Friday.

title: Report Details Dresdner Bank's Wartime Financing of a Death Camp
description: FRANKFURT, Feb. 17 - Dresdner Bank helped finance the construction of the Auschwitz death camp and was the bank of choice for Hitler's feared SS paramilitary, according to an independent report on the German bank's dealings during the Nazi era, released Friday in Berlin.

title: Gunmen in Iraqi Army Uniforms Kidnap a Wealthy Banker and His Son
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 17 - Gunmen dressed in Iraqi Army uniforms kidnapped an Iraqi banker and his son from their house in Baghdad, after shooting five of the family's bodyguards execution-style in the backyard, the police said Friday.

title: Olympic Ideals Give Dane Hope
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 17 - Sometimes, it seems that the arc of the universe bends toward one particular person. Right now and here, where the tribes of the world combat without killing one another, that person may be a Danish Muslim named Thomas Jeppesen, who is also a chiropractor.

title: Mardi Gras in Katrina's Shadow
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Birthplace of Nascar, Dim Hope of Daytona Glory
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16 - It doesn't get much better here than Speedweeks, when some 300,000 race fans pour into town for the white-knuckle Daytona 500, adrenaline rules and the soundtrack goes something like zoom, roar, ka-ching, ka-ching.

title: Corzine Nominates a Medical School President
description: TRENTON, Feb. 17 - Saying that he is determined to restore the credibility of New Jersey's financially troubled state medical school, Gov. Jon S. Corzine on Friday nominated a nationally recognized health care administrator to become its interim president.

title: Low-Fat Milk And Obesity in Kids
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Gift Bags For New Mothers
description: The state department of health has abandoned a proposed ban on gift bags containing infant formula and other items that hospitals give to new mothers. Critics of the bags said the free formula would encourage mothers to bottle-feed rather than breast-feed their babies. The ban was approved by a panel last year, but had not yet taken effect. State officials chose to reverse the decision after discussions with Gov. Mitt Romney, a Republican, who did not dispute the benefits of breast-feeding but said he did not want mothers to lose a potentially beneficial package. KATIE ZEZIMA (NYT)

title: Bid Your Longest Suit First? Not an Ironclad Rule
description: As mentioned on Thursday, the Betty Kaplan Teams is an amusing event. It was held on Feb. 11 at the New York Helmsley Hotel in Midtown Manhattan. There were six rounds of nine boards. Each competitor played two of these matches with each of her or his teammates.

title: Plushenko In Fender Bender
description: Hours after winning the men's figure skating title by a huge margin Thursday, Yevgeny Plushenko was involved in a car accident on the way to the airport Friday morning. On Plushenko's Web site, his agent, Ari Zakarian, said Plushenko was trying to catch a flight to St. Petersburg, Russia, from Milan so he could attend a celebration that St. Petersburg was holding in his honor. Plushenko was traveling with his coach and his choreographer; a representative of a Russian Olympic team sponsor was driving, Zakarian said. No one was injured.

title: For Dogs at J.F.K. Pound, a Long Layover
description: After Vivi, an award-winning whippet, escaped from her crate on Wednesday at Kennedy International Airport, she attracted a media circus but eluded a dragnet of police and animal rescue workers.

title: Cheney's Accident Holds Shooting Safety Lessons for All Hunters
description: For the past week, upland bird hunters and shotgun shooters have been scrutinizing the few details that have emerged about the shooting of Harry M. Whittington by Vice President Dick Cheney, his quail hunting partner. The shooting happened last Saturday on the Armstrong Ranch in South Texas.

title: Prosecutor Says Libby Seeks to Thwart Criminal Case
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 - A federal prosecutor has said I. Lewis Libby Jr., former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney, is trying to sabotage the criminal case against him by insisting through his lawyers that he be given sensitive government documents for his defense.

title: Two Defendants, Two Juries and Horrors Spoken Twice
description: The men on trial stare out from a screen like animated mug shots, images captured in fish-eye by cameras on Rikers Island. The screen is split to show two faces together yet apart, a backdrop to a courtroom where much appears in double.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVID, LIESEL
description: DAVID--Liesel. On Friday, February 17, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Joseph David. Devoted mother of Michael David. Loving grandmother of Joshua and Jonathan. Funeral services by the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, NJ, on Sunday, February 19. Interment at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Feb. 9 about multinational companies' use of China as a final assembly point for products made from parts manufactured in other parts of Asia misidentified the employer of Dong Tao, an economist who discussed how the strategy benefited the United States. He works for Credit Suisse, not UBS.

title: The Welcome Mat Is Out...
description: Correction Appended

title: A One-Man Gang
description: Los Angeles - COMPARING Kobe Bryant's 81-point game last month to Wilt Chamberlain's 100-point game is like comparing an orange to an avocado. Physically, Wilt was a totally different player from Kobe, and he had a whole different skill set. As a center, Wilt was suited to playing right around the basket, while Kobe has systematically perfected just about any offensive designation you can name. Passing the ball, shooting threes, driving to the hoop, pulling up for mid-range jumpers he does it all, and he does it all very well. His versatility sets him apart from the rest of the league.

title: Bush Sees Need to Expand Role of NATO in Sudan
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 17 - President Bush signaled a new American commitment on Friday to addressing the crisis in Darfur, saying he would support an expanded role by NATO to shore up a failing African peacekeeping mission there.

title: Mardi Gras in Katrina's Shadow
description: To the Editor:

title: The Shame of the Prisons
description: Who needs sophomoric cartoons to inflame the Muslim world when you've got the Bush administration's prison system? One reason the White House is so helpless against the violence spawned by those Danish cartoons is that it has squandered so much of its moral standing at Guantnamo Bay and Abu Ghraib. This week, the world got two chilling reminders of why both prisons must be closed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REINHOLD, WALTER
description: REINHOLD--Walter, 66. Died February 15 of cancer. Walter was a prolific local teacher and scholar who taught music history at NYU since 1968, honored by his students as NYU Teacher of the Year in 1992 and again in 1999. Other professional activity included his work since 1961 at the First Presbyterian Church in Kearny, New Jersey where he was the Organist and Master of the Music, Lecturer in Bible and Theology and an Elder-Trustee. Mr. Reinhold also was a Commissioned Lay Pastor in the Presbyterian Church. Funeral services will be held Sunday, February 19 at 5 PM at the Walter J. Johnson Funeral Home at 803 Raritan Road, Clark, New Jersey, with viewing at same location from 3-5 PM. A follow up memorial service will be held at a to be determined date at the First Presbyterian Church in Kearny, New Jersey.

title: Throttled in 2005, 2 Stars Look to Get Back in Chase
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17 - A season of struggle in 2005 ended with a 10-race chase for nothing for Nascar's two most marketable stars. Jeff Gordon and Dale Earnhardt Jr. were left out of the playoffs for the Nextel Cup championship, which might have been reason enough for them to measure their words and temper their expectations heading into 2006.

title: Senate Chairman Splits With Bush on Spy Program
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 - The chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee said Friday that he wanted the Bush administration's domestic eavesdropping program brought under the authority of a special intelligence court, a move President Bush has argued is not necessary.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LANDAU, EVA J.
description: LANDAU--Eva J. February 18, 1982, who found well deserved rest and peace 24 years ago today. Your loving son, Robert

title: Rambling Round Pittsburgh
description: The jazz legacy of Pittsburgh confounds easy generalization. There's no shorthand summary for a city that produced the buoyant pianist Earl (Fatha) Hines as well as the steamrolling drummer Art Blakey and the urbane composer Billy Strayhorn. So Jazz at Lincoln Center wisely makes no claim to comprehensiveness in its Pittsburgh Festival, which takes up two of the three performance spaces at Frederick P. Rose Hall.

title: Under Fire, RadioShack Offers a Plan to Revamp
description: David J. Edmondson, the embattled chief executive of RadioShack, offered two apologies to investors yesterday, one for the performance of the company and the other for having lied about his educational background. The company's stock fell to a three-year low.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Feb. 7 about cataract surgery misstated the site of the incision made in the eye. It is behind the cornea, not behind the iris.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZEIGEN, L. MARSHALL
description: ZEIGEN--L. Marshall. On Valentine's Day, one week after his 76th birthday. Beloved son of the late Bess and Samuel Zeigen. Cherished brother of H. Lylla Kleiman and her husband George. Devoted and loyal friend to many. U.S. Army Veteran. The family will leave Riverside Memorial Chapel on Sunday, February 19 and proceed to The Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Paramus, NJ where entombment will take place 12:30. Call (201) 262-1128 for directions. Buddy will always be remembered by all those who know him for his great humor, vast generosity, knowledge and zest for life.

title: A Shift Based on Science and Politics
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 - As a naval officer, Jimmy Carter helped design nuclear reactors for submarines. But as president, Mr. Carter banned the reprocessing of spent nuclear fuel to extract material that would be useful in reactors and bombs. Thirty years later, President Bush has proposed a new version of reprocessing.

title: Neither Rain Nor Cold Keeps Woods From Final Rounds
description: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif., Feb. 17 - Tiger Woods stood in the middle of a sopping-wet fairway, needing a par, an umbrella and a long winter's nap. A fever had chased him for the second consecutive round, and an afternoon rainstorm Friday had left him soaked.

title: Corrections
description: Three picture credits were interchanged on Sunday with an article about American service members who have lost limbs in Iraq. The picture of Lance Cpl. Matthew Schilling and his wife, Leigh Ann, was by Doug Mills of The New York Times; the one of Lance Cpl. Mark Beyers, seated on a couch, was by Ozier Muhammad of The Times; and the one of Corporal Beyers in his dress uniform was by Mike Groll for The Times.

title: Conor to Market Stent in Europe
description: Conor Medsystems said yesterday that it had won approval to market its coronary stent in Europe, a milestone that analysts say could make the company an attractive takeover candidate for several giant medical device makers.

title: Low-Fat Milk And Obesity in Kids
description: To the Editor:

title: At Religious Universities, Disputes Over Faith and Academic Freedom
description: A gay film festival opened at the University of Notre Dame last week with a sold-out showing of "Brokeback Mountain." On Valentine's Day, Notre Dame students staged a production of "The Vagina Monologues."

title: Arts, Briefly; Another Indictment in Case Of Celebrity Wiretapping
description: Federal authorities in Los Angeles yesterday disclosed a Feb. 8 conspiracy and wiretapping indictment of George Kalta in connection with the far-ranging investigation of the celebrity private eye Anthony Pellicano. The action brings to 13 the number of people charged in the investigation. The government contended that Mr. Kalta, who is scheduled for arraignment on March 6, paid for illegal wiretaps in connection with a legal case. A lawyer for Mr. Kalta could not immediately be reached for comment. Separately, Daniel Nicherie, who was previously charged with wiretapping in the investigation, pleaded not guilty and said he planned to represent himself. ALLISON HOPE WEINER

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 6 P.M. (BBC America) BLUE/ORANGE -- A young patient (Shaun Parkes) at a psychiatric hospital has hallucinations and exhibits signs of paranoia. He tells everyone that he is Idi Amin's son. One doctor (John Simm) wants to work with him longer

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   REGENSTREIF, LEFFLER, JEANNETTE
description: REGENSTREIF - LEFFLER -Jeannette. Lovingly missed, forever in my heart. Love, Herbert

title: Wider Loss at Wal-Mart's Japanese Subsidiary
description: Seiyu, Wal-Mart's struggling Japanese subsidiary, said its losses widened in 2005 and it forecast more red ink for this year, but said it would press forward with a plan to revamp its aging stores. The net loss grew to 17.7 billion yen ($150 million) in 2005 from 12.3 billion yen in 2004, Seiyu said, as the company wrote off losses from disposing of slow-moving inventory. Sales fell 3.3 percent, to 997.1 billion yen. The company also said it expected a bigger loss of 54.4 billion yen this year. MARTIN FACKLER (NYT)

title: The Love and Rage of an Irish Childhood
description: All Will Be Well A Memoir By John McGahern 289 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FIELDS, JANICE
description: FIELDS--Janice, 86, is at peace with her son Peter. Her family cherishes their time with her.

title: It's You Know Who, and You've Got Mail
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 17 - Who is Craig Bohnert, and why is he sending so many e-mail messages? At any moment, another "Bohnert" might alight into 891 selected in-boxes bearing the headline BREAKING NEWS.

title: In a Snap, Hughes Finds Herself the Center of Attention
description: Correction Appended

title: Ray Barretto, a Master of the Conga Drum, Dies at 76
description: Correction Appended

title: There's a Hole in the Medals, in Case You Haven't Noticed
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 17 - When Dario Quatrini designed the medals for the 2006 Winter Games, he envisioned a metaphor of the Italian way, of the Olympic ideal and the emotions that accompany it, molten in silver and plated in gold.

title: Putting the 'I' in the Lakers
description: Cincinnati - TOMORROW'S N.B.A. All-Star Game is a time to take stock of the league, and thus far the "highlight" of the season was Kobe Bryant of the Los Angeles Lakers scoring 81 points. That certainly created a buzz. Could he someday break 100, and eclipse Wilt Chamberlain's record from 1962? Possibly. But what's the point? However much he scores, he plays on a team that will have difficulty staying above .500, let alone making the playoffs.

title: Ex-Rising Star Makes a Healthy Return to the Ice
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 17 - As her figure skates grew rusty inside the trunk of her Volkswagen, Jamie Silverstein stood in front of a room of sorority women at Cornell University, took a deep breath and told them why she had quit the sport of ice dancing.

title: You Go, Lindsey
description: The sports world was buzzing yesterday about Lindsey Jacobellis's Olympic moment. The young American snowboarder seemed to have clinched the gold medal in the snowboardcross when she tried to get fancy on her next-to-last jump, crash-landed and scrambled miserably to her feet as Tanja Frieden of Switzerland blew by her to win the gold. Besides a silver, Ms. Jacobellis won an instantaneous reputation as a showboater who "got what she deserved," in the words of one sports commentator.

title: Chad's Oil Riches, Meant for Poor, Are Diverted
description: NDJAMENA, Chad, Feb. 11 - Students from the Institute of Mongo have everything they need to learn: desks, computers, professors, notebooks and inquisitive minds.

title: In Fulton, Mo., the Velvet Curtain of Censorship
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Adds Appointee to NASA Press Office
description: A fifth political appointee is being added to the public affairs office of NASA headquarters, space agency officials said last night.

title: German Muslim Leader Speaks Peace to Provocation
description: COLOGNE, Germany - AYYUB AXEL KHLER pads around his snug apartment here these days with three telephones that ring ceaselessly from sunrise until well after dark.

title: Rich Russian Plans to Sell His Holdings to a Partner
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 17 - Boris A. Berezovsky, a self-exiled Russian tycoon, said Friday that he would sell his remaining business interests to a partner, to free them from what he called unrelenting political pressure from the Kremlin.

title: Randolph Is Not Afraid of Going With the Flow
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 17 - The difference between Willie Randolph's first season and his second as manager of the Mets may be measured in decibels and whiskers, as well as victories and losses.

title: In Long-Term American Treasury Securities They Trust
description: GUESS who's financing the budget deficit of the United States? Hint: Very few Treasury securities are being purchased by American consumers or businesses.

title: 2 Brothers Arrested After Bomb Threat
description: Two brothers called in a fake bomb threat last month to a Long Island airport in an effort to stop their sister from boarding a plane there to escape an arranged marriage, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CURTISS, EDWARD I.
description: CURTISS--Edward I. On Wednesday, February 15, 2006; Beloved husband of Zelda. Beloved father of Laura (Warren) Sutnick and Julie Curtiss. Brother of Alan Curtiss. Grandfather of Michael, Sarah and Emily Sutnick. Services at Ralph Schugar Chapel, Inc., 5509 Centre Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA (1 - 888 621-8282), on Sunday at 1:00 PM. Visitation one hour prior to services (12 Noon-1 PM). Interment Homewood Cemetery, Pittsburgh, PA. Contributions may be made to University of Pittsburgh-Edward Curtiss Memorial Scholarship Fund at University of Pittsburgh, Office of Institutional Advancement, 200 South Craig St, Pittsburgh, PA 15260.

title: Approval Delayed for Weight-Loss Drug
description: Approval for Sanofi-Aventis's experimental drug for weight loss, Acomplia, was delayed yesterday by the Food and Drug Administration, which issued what it calls an "approvable" letter but said the company must meet certain conditions before the product could receive final clearance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAHER, WILLIAM F.X., S.J.
description: MAHER--William F.X., S.J. Died on February 16, 2006. Formerly an Economics professor at St. Peter's College. Wake Sunday, February 19, 2-4 & 7-9, McLaughlin Funeral Home, Jersey City. Mass at St. Peter's Church, at 10 AM Monday.

title: Bruch's Grand Emotions and an Elliott Carter Classic
description: The Bruch G-minor Violin Concerto was on the end of every violinist's bow for most of the 20th century but seems to have drifted slightly off the path most music lovers travel. Maybe we have become too dour for its heart-on-sleeve messages, or maybe there are fewer appropriate messengers around.

title: With a Final, Risky Flourish, Gold Turns to Silver
description: BARDONECCHIA, Italy, Feb. 17 - About 100 yards from the finish line, Lindsey Jacobellis hung in the air. She had only one jump remaining. Her closest competitor was about 50 yards behind.

title: Diabetes Is Seen As a Rising Risk In Mothers-to-Be
description: It has long been something of a quirk in the grim universe of diabetes: a small number of pregnant women would become temporarily diabetic. With proper care, the consequences were often thought to be mild. The babies were usually healthy. And the condition would vanish after the delivery, like a cough or a headache.

title: World Briefings: Africa, Middle East, Europe, Asia
description: AFRICA

title: More Than 1,000 Protest Cartoon Depiction of Prophet
description: More than 1,000 Muslims gathered yesterday for a rally and prayer session across the street from the Danish Consulate in Manhattan, protesting cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad that have set off a series of violent demonstrations around the world since their first publication in Denmark.

title: Arts, Briefly; NBC Enjoys a Night Without an 'Idol'
description: Though ABC and Fox have been directly challenging NBC's Olympics, CBS has mostly ducked out of the way this week. And since it is CBS that largely owns Thursday night, its "CSI" and "Without a Trace" repeats allowed NBC to regain first place after two defeats in a row by Fox's "American Idol" sledgehammer. In Nielsen's estimates for 8 to 11 p.m., NBC attracted 19.12 million viewers, versus CBS's 16.71 million. CBS's only original offering, "Survivor," drew fewer viewers than the first hour of ABC's 90-minute "Dancing With the Stars" for the second week in a row (17.06 million compared with 18.26 million), but "Survivor" still had a comfortable victory among adults 18 to 49. Vice President Dick Cheney's first public appearance since he shot his hunting partner last weekend produced above-average ratings for "Special Report With Brit Hume." The Fox News program, in which Mr. Hume pressed Mr. Cheney about the accident and its aftermath, brought in 2.1 million viewers, 513,000 of them in the 25-to-54 demographic sought by advertisers in the television news audience. The interview brought the show its highest ratings of the year so far. KATE AURTHUR

title: That Which We Call a Blog...
description: THE rise of blogging is often cast in black-and-white terms: blogs versus the "MSM" (the derisive term some bloggers apply to the mainstream media).

title: Davis's Focus on His EventIs Paid Back in Gold
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 18 A The first episode of speedskating's soap opera ended Saturday with Shani Davis of the United States skating around Oval Lingotto wearing a big smile, with a largely Dutch crowd standing and applauding a spectacular gold-medal-winning performance in the 1,000 meters.

title: Low-Fat Milk and Obesity in Kids (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: No Longer 'It'
description: TURIN, Italy - THERE are always select Olympians, those special athletes who always get the top bunk, land on the hottest magazine covers and bask in the kindest camera lighting on the "Today" show set.

title: In Fulton, Mo., the Velvet Curtain of Censorship (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Quinn Fires 61 From City Council Staff and Names a Finance Chief
description: Even as the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, fired 61 city employees yesterday during what her aides called a restructuring, she moved quickly to fill at least one of those newly vacated positions with a longtime political operative.

title: In Robot World She Turns More Hedda Than Hedda
description: The competition is heating up for best performance by a robot in the New York theater this season. For a while, it looked as if the automaton pretending to be Matthew Broderick in the revival of "The Odd Couple" had a lock on the category. But the bar has been raised by the real live -- oops, skip the live -- robots who are so happily reciting the words of Henrik Ibsen in "Heddatron," the dopey and strangely moving gloss on "Hedda Gabler" by Les Freres Corbusier at the Here Arts Center in the South Village.

title: A Week to Make Wall St. and Shoppers Happy
description: WHILE Vice President Dick Cheney's hunting accident dominated public discourse this week, many people still found time to buy and sell everything from toasters to the generating stations needed to power them.

title: Piazza Will Be Catching Games, Not His Breath
description: PHOENIX, Feb. 16 - In what looked at first glance like a small airplane hangar festooned with netting, the not-quite-ancient catcher stepped into the enclosed batting cage to begin his first day of spring training in the San Diego Padres' complex. He had traded in, involuntarily, as it happened, his Mets blue and orange of the previous eight seasons for the Padres' blue and yellow.

title: Iran Hints at Compromise on Nuclear Inspections
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 - A senior Iranian envoy, making a new bid to resolve the impasse over his country's nuclear program, was quoted Friday as saying Iran would allow the resumption of spot international inspections of its nuclear facilities if it could continue limited uranium enrichment.

title: The Forces of Life That Drive Vengeance and Human Conflict
description: VoiceTheater's production of "Retzach" by the Israeli playwright Hanoch Levin is all the right things: vivid, grim, frightening, sometimes mesmerizing. Watching it, though, leaves you a little unclear why the play caused such buzz when it had its premiere in Israel in 1997.

title: More Than 1,000 Protest Cartoon Depiction of Prophet
description: More than 1,000 Muslims gathered yesterday for a rally and prayer session across the street from the Danish Consulate in Manhattan, protesting cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad that have set off a series of violent demonstrations around the world since their first publication in Denmark.

title: Bullets, Not Beating, Killed Rookie Officer, Autopsy Finds
description: The city medical examiner's office has ruled that a rookie police officer who was shot three times by a colleague last month outside a Bronx White Castle restaurant died from those bullet wounds and not from a beating he suffered moments before the shooting.

title: 2 Senators Seek to Stop Ports Deal, Citing Security
description: The junior senators from New York and New Jersey have added their voices to objections about the Bush administration's approval of a deal that will give a Dubai company a central role in operating ports in New York and around the country.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROSENBERG, RUTH
description: ROSENBERG--Ruth. February 10, 1911-February 18, 2004. Remembering you with love and sadness. Carla

title: Roy Chapman, Breeder of Smarty Jones, Is Dead at 79
description: Roy Chapman, the owner and breeder of Smarty Jones, the 2004 Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes champion, died yesterday at his home in Doylestown, Pa. He was 79.

title: Mideast Dispute: The Rabbi vs. the Archbishop
description: LONDON, Feb. 17 - At a time of heightened religious tensions across Europe, Britain's chief rabbi, Sir Jonathan Sacks, assailed the Church of England on Friday for supporting divestiture from companies whose products support Israeli policies in Gaza and the West Bank.

title: Insurers Picking Up Recall Cost
description: When carmakers recall a vehicle, they provide a replacement part and cover the cost of the labor to install it. But producers of expensive medical devices have found a better way -- they often have others, like taxpayers and insurers, pick up the labor cost.

title: Competition Catches Up to U.S. Women
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 17 - The puck was on Angela Ruggiero's stick, and the game was in her hands. She was staring at an open net.

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: American International Drops Starr Business, Moving Further From Its Former Chairman In another move to distance itself from its former chairman, the American International Group said that it had terminated its relationship with the Starr Technical Risk Agency. Starr Tech, an insurance agency, is a subsidiary of C. V. Starr & Company, a closely held concern controlled by Maurice R. Greenberg, left, who was forced out as chairman and chief executive of A.I.G. last March after the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, began an investigation into accounting practices at the insurer. American International, which is based in New York, said that it "terminated the agency relationship" with Starr Tech. There was no immediate comment from Starr Tech. (AP)

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: No Bail For Padilla
description: A federal judge in Miami denied bail for Jose Padilla out of concern that he might be a flight risk and a danger to the community. Mr. Padilla, an American citizen who converted to Islam, was transferred to civilian custody in Florida last month from military custody and pleaded not guilty to criminal charges that he provided money and support to terrorism forces overseas. Mr. Padilla, 35, was arrested in 2002 at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago. He faces a life sentence if convicted. TERRY AGUAYO (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WELKOWITZ, JOAN
description: WELKOWITZ - Joan. New York University's Psychology Department mourns the loss of Dr. Joan Welkowitz who died February 11. Recently retired as Professor Emerita, she was on the NYU faculty for more than forty years and headed the Doctoral Program in Clinical Psychology. In long association with the NYU Medical Center she researched and published widely regarding emotional expression in faces and voice as manifested in various psychiatric and neurological disturbances. She was highly regarded for her textbook on statistics, now in its seventh edition. We extend our condolences to her family and many former students.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, ANNA (HONEY)
description: COHEN--Anna (Honey). Vice President of the Ladies Auxiliary of the Sephardic Home. She was our Raffle Chairperson for over 30 years. We extend our deepest condolences to her children, David and Len, and their families. She will be remembered for her dedication to the residents of the Sephardic Home and to all who were privileged to know her. The Board of Directors of Sephardic Home and LASHA

title: U.S. Criticized for Actions in U.N. Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 17 - Developing nations expressed anger on Friday at what they said was a United States-led effort to wrest power from them and give authority for bringing major change at the United Nations to the 15-member Security Council.

title: City School Cuts Seem Pointed at Albany
description: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced this week that he was killing plans for dozens of buildings that were to be built under New York City's school construction plan, he blamed leaders in Albany for not sending enough money to the city.

title: Mardi Gras in Katrina's Shadow
description: To the Editor:

title: A Public Servant Takes His Message to the Stage
description: Peter Goldmark has frequently found his way into the limelight. Throughout his 35-year career in public service he has played leading roles in local, national and international arenas. But for the next month or so, his efforts will be performed on a much smaller stage, one with an actual box office and a paying audience. The Old Arizona theater in Minneapolis is presenting "The Trial of Osama bin Laden," a play that Mr. Goldmark wrote with Mark Gerzon, a longtime friend and collaborator.

title: Despite Another Tumble, Things Could Still Fall Right for Kildow
description: SESTRIERE, Italy, Feb. 17 - Lindsey Kildow left the finish area with a bad limp, leaning on a ski pole in each hand as she went. Her second attempt to race after Monday's jarring crash during a training run ended Friday night with another fall, this time in the second run of the slalom portion of the women's Alpine combined.

title: Egypt Reports Bird Flu Cases, but Virus Is Not Found in Humans
description: CAIRO, Feb. 17 - After months of anticipation, Egypt on Friday confirmed its first cases of the deadly avian flu, and the government called a cabinet meeting to assure the public that all necessary measures were being taken to control its spread, government officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ARNOLD, REGINA
description: ARNOLD - Regina. Sarah Lawrence College mourns the loss of Regina Arnold, Associate Dean of Studies and, for 21 years, a Professor of Sociology at the College. A staunch advocate of experimental learning, Dr. Arnold was noted for her ability to engage students in dialogue and to help them to design meaningful research projects. She inspired and advanced the College's program of field work and service learning. Her efforts to forge connections between Sarah Lawrence and the local community made a lasting impact on the College. She was a deeply loved and admired member of the College community. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family. Michele Tolela Myers, President Barbara Kaplan, Dean of the College

title: An Olympic Relic Feels Like a Winner for Making It Home
description: Pragelato, Italy - HE shivered as he spoke in the swirling snow, cried as he recounted the time past, the money spent, the marriage lost, the father he buried two weeks ago.

title: Tkachuk Leaves Past in Past, but He Remains as Tough as Ever
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 17 - The flecks of gray in Keith Tkachuk's short-cropped hair are as disingenuous as a hockey player taking a dive. They give Tkachuk the appearance of being mature, mellowed -- stately, even.

title: A Chamber Orchestra This Side of a Rock Band
description: Not long ago, Alarm Will Sound was, at least in its New York performances, a fairly conventional chamber orchestra, except that it specialized in contemporary music. When it introduced itself with a Steve Reich program in 2001, it sat still and played.

title: Hamas Leader Faults Israeli Sanction Plan
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 17 - The man many expect to become the new Palestinian prime minister, Ismail Haniya of the militant Islamic group Hamas, on Friday criticized Israeli proposals to restrict the movement of money, people and goods into and out of the Gaza Strip and the West Bank under a Hamas-run Palestinian Authority.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Expansion At Harvard
description: Harvard announced that it would expand its scientific facilities with a 500,000-square-foot science and technology complex in the Allston section of Boston. The development, which will sit across the Charles River from the main Harvard campus in Cambridge, will house and expand the university's Stem Cell Institute. The university will break ground on the project next year. KATIE ZEZIMA (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Observatory column of Science Times on Tuesday about the effects of the 1883 Krakatoa explosion on ocean temperatures referred incorrectly to another volcanic eruption, that of Mount Pinatubo in the Philippines in 1991. Pinatubo was not the only 20th-century eruption similar in scale to Krakatoa; Novarupta, an Alaskan volcano that erupted in 1912, was also comparable in size and intensity.

title: New Cartoon Showing Muhammad Prompts the Closing of a Russian Paper
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 17 - In a controversy with echoes of the Islamic anger over Danish cartoons depicting the Prophet Muhammad, the authorities in a central Russian city on Friday ordered the closing of a newspaper that published a cartoon showing Muhammad, along with Jesus, Moses and Buddha.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "As a freestyler, I bow my head in shame."

title: Hamas and Abbas clash over path for Palestinians
Joan's Passion on the Screen, Plus Chorus and Orchestra
description: Should the composer Richard Einhorn's "Voices of Light" be heard as an oratorio that accompanies the 1928 silent film classic "The Passion of Joan of Arc"? Or is it the film, by the Danish director Carl Theodor Dreyer, that accompanies Mr. Einhorn's 80-minute musical work?

title: Robert Lewis, the Owner of Silver Charm and Charismatic, Is Dead at 81
description: Robert Lewis, the owner of the Kentucky Derby winners Silver Charm and Charismatic, died yesterday at his home in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 81.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend yesterday about record-setting prices paid for photographs at auctions this week referred incorrectly to the price of "Hands," by Alfred Stieglitz. It was seven figures -- $1.47 million -- not six figures.

title: The Inalienable Right to Hot Copy
description: Harry Whittington tried to calm the furor yesterday, but we must not let him. Leaving the hospital, he expressed regret for Dick Cheney's troubles over what he considered a simple hunting accident at a friend's ranch. But it was so much more.

title: Reality Could Lead to Tears in Ebersol's Kiss-and-Cry Control Room
description: On the seventh day of the Turin Winter Games yesterday, Dick Ebersol paced and talked inside his home office within NBC's Olympic compound. As he discussed his network's Olympic ratings, he circled around his black leather sofa, behind his desk and near his tidily made bed in a distant corner of the capacious room.

title: In Move to Change, Louisiana Will Consolidate Levee Boards
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 17 - Eager to demonstrate a new interest in political reform, Louisiana legislators passed a constitutional amendment on Friday consolidating the state's patronage-ridden levee boards, hoping to prove they could be trusted with Washington's money, several said.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Sept. 18 about the California trial of Susan Mae Polk in the murder of her husband, Dr. Frank Felix Polk, a psychologist, described their history together since she became his patient at age 15. The article said she was 16 when they first had sex. That account was based on assertions by Ms. Polk in the couple's divorce proceeding, which were not specifically challenged by Dr. Polk and were supported by statements from people who knew the couple.

title: Good Deeds, of a Sort, Toward Forgiveness
description: If there is a coherent narrative in Michael John Garcs's "Acts of Mercy: passion-play," it is resolutely kept from the audience. An evocative opening image of a dying man on a hospital bed, with a woman in white who seems almost to be an angel bent at his feet, prepares us for the drama of redemption suggested by the title. But the first scene in the hospital room, between half brothers, is played with a kind of would-be Pinter stylization that prevents engagement between the characters or emotional investment by the audience. For the record, according to the press release for the play, it is about two sons "hoping to gain redemption through small but life-giving acts of mercy" as they try to reconcile with their dying father.

title: Trying Hard to Be No. 1 in Latino TV
description: The 41 million Latinos in the United States make up a significant part of the American viewing audience, and media companies are beginning to notice. On Feb. 8, the No. 1 Spanish-language television network, Univision, announced that it was exploring a sale, drawing potential interest from companies, including Viacom and the News Corporation, in what analysts said could be a $13 billion deal.

title: Flawed Devices Sold
description: Medtronic continued selling flawed cardiac defibrillators for two years after learning that some of them might suddenly quit working, according to company documents filed in a California lawsuit.

title: Iraq Power Shift Widens a Gulf Between Sects
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 17 - Not long after the Americans occupied Iraq, strange things began happening in the family of Fatin Abdel Sattar, a Sunni Arab.

title: High Winds Cause 2 Deaths, and Thousands Lose Power
description: Two people were killed and hundreds of thousands of residents in upstate New York lost electricity after powerful winds on the heels of a cold front pummeled the region yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: 1,800 Feared Dead in Mudslide on Philippine Island Only 57 people were found alive after a day of searching in what was left of a farming village buried under 30 feet of mud and boulders. Rescue workers were losing hope for the other 1,800 residents. PAGE A3

title: Romance as Comic Montage
description: It was an education to see "Date Movie" with two dozen or so adolescent New York students and their teachers. Here are some things that members of Hollywood's favorite demographic find hysterically funny: fat women, old people, enormous buttocks, homosexuality, amorous cats having a go at dead bodies and flatulent cats with diarrhea. The source of the laughter appears to be a delighted revulsion.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Washington's Birthday, Feb. 22, will be observed.

title: Mardi Gras in Katrina's Shadow
description: To the Editor:

title: New Palestinian Parliament opens
Recipe for Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Division I's Youngest Coach Is Finding His Own Way
description: EVANSTON, Ill. - The rookie head coach, the youngest in N.C.A.A. Division I basketball at 26 -- looking hardly older than the players -- was conducting a practice with his team one afternoon when he blew the whistle and halted the proceedings, less than thrilled with the defense of one his players.

title: Platinum Producer in Pursuit of a Buyer
description: The platinum producer Lonmin said it was in preliminary discussions that could lead to a takeover of the company, sending its shares up sharply on the London Stock Exchange. Lonmin, which has all its mining operations in South Africa, is the world's third-largest producer of platinum. Lonmin could be worth almost 4 billion ($7 billion), based on the company's market capitalization yesterday. Lonmin did not identify its potential suitor, but analysts and bankers not involved in the deal pointed to Xstrata from Switzerland or Barrick Gold from Canada. HEATHER TIMMONS (NYT)

title: Mardi Gras in Katrina's Shadow (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Blair Calls Camp in Cuba an 'Anomaly'
description: LONDON, Feb. 17 - One day after a British government minister endorsed a United Nations call for the Guantnamo Bay detention center to be closed, Prime Minister Tony Blair on Friday called the camp an "anomaly" to be dealt with "sooner or later."

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about plans by Amazon.com to offer a digital music player to challenge the iPod misstated the number of iPods sold last year by Apple Computer. It was 32 million; 14 million was the figure for the fourth quarter.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Mental Health Bill Stuck
description: A bill that would allow doctors, social workers, family members and others to seek mandatory outpatient treatment for mentally ill people foundered this week in the Legislature. The bill had passed the House, but the Senate did not take a vote on it before the legislative session ended Thursday. Generally, mentally ill people who are accused of a crime can be forced into treatment, but the bill was aimed at those who show signs of illness but refuse to seek treatment and stay in it. RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD (NYT)

title: More Enter Race to Offer Space Tours
description: Now it's a space race.

title: Sleeping Pill Wars
description: Americans are popping sleeping pills at a rapid rate, thanks to heavy marketing by the drug companies and a belief that a new generation of sleeping pills is safer than its predecessors. The upsurge is raising justifiable concerns that the pills will be overused by people who don't really need them or that doctors may reflexively prescribe pills while ignoring underlying conditions that may be responsible for sleeplessness.

title: Feb. 12-18: Not All They're Cracked Up to Be
description: A major snowstorm in the New York region, calcium and vitamin D supplements for women, the Las Vegas production of "Avenue Q" and the U.S. women's hockey team.

title: Robel Teklemariam
description: Robel Teklemariam, the first Ethiopian Winter Olympian, discusses his path to becoming a ski racer and his mission to represent Ethiopia in the 2006 Olympic Games. Prod: Kassie Bracken
Selborne Journal: Wednesday, 18 February 1784: 29 6/10; 32; E, NE. Hard frost, dark & still, fog, dark & still.

title: The Sun Bright Hotel
Determined to Party
description: New Orleans's first parade of the Mardi Gras season looked and felt different in the wake of Hurricane Katrina

title: Day 8 at the Games
description: Shani Davis became the first black athlete to win an individual gold medal in a winter Olympics, prevailing in the men's 1,000 meters.

title: Harlem Vocabulary
description: Harlem has a real-estate vocabulary all its own, Alysia Reiner told me. In Harlem, its all about the certificate of no harassment.

title: Hope crumples on one bad break
Like Father, Like Son: Recipe for a Family Brawl
description: THE word on Brent Redstone, who is suing his billionaire father, Sumner M. Redstone, in an attempt to dissolve the family business, is that he does not have the drive, the stuff, the mojo, that his dad does. Thus Brent's sister, Shari E. Redstone, has been given the nod as the future successor to their father, suzerain of the recently divided CBS Corporation and Viacom Inc.

title: These 'Housewives,' en Espaol, Are Heard but Never Seen
description: LOS ANGELES - IN a small sound studio late on a Wednesday night, Larisa Asuaje is channeling Teri Hatcher. She sighs, giggles and gesticulates wildly with her hands, speaking in the halting, nervous ways of Ms. Hatcher's character, Susan, in "Desperate Housewives," only in Spanish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENINGSON, RENEE
description: BENINGSON--Renee. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Renee Beningson, whose deep commitment to our Women's Campaign strengthened the lives of millions in need. We extend our deepest sympathies to her beloved husband, Bob; her daughter, Susan; her daughter, Robin, and her husband, Sal; and the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEST, STEVEN G.
description: WEST--Steven G. Beloved husband to Mary. Loving father to Dan and Lee. Beloved brother to Marilyn. To all his dear friends at West Point, Annapolis, and the boating people. Interment Arlington National Cemetery, Tuesday, February 21, 11 AM.

title: Say, Pal, Can You Spare a BMW?
description: LAST night, as I tucked my 3-year-old son into bed after reading him "Go, Dog. Go!" he asked if we could go car shopping the next day.

title: Tempers Rising Over Day Laborers
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Olympics, the Crash Is the Thing
description: THE emergency room at the Centro Traumatologico Ortopedico in Turin, Italy, has been jammed lately. Practically every day, choppers have come chattering in from the Olympic luge run or the downhill courses, bearing the latest victims of wipeouts, wall-smacks and rollovers.

title: Making Brownfields Green Again
description: PICTURE brand-new luxury town houses on 11 waterfront acres a short commute from the city, with sweeping views of sunsets on Manhasset Bay and, after dark, the twinkling Manhattan skyline in the distance. In today's hot Long Island property market, it's a safe bet that they would be snapped up quickly, even at seven-figure prices.

title: An Adopted Bird As Metaphor
description: To the Editor:

title: In Chicago, Art Where You Least Expect It
description: THE festering slaughterhouses of the Union Stock Yards, so famously and gruesomely described by Upton Sinclair, are long gone. But the adjacent neighborhood of Bridgeport, on Chicago's South Side, has been home to other things as well, and most haven't been especially pretty: racial divisiveness, Chicago's notoriously shady political machine and, not least, its perennially losing White Sox.

title: How States Are Aiming to Keep Dollars Out of Sudan
description: THE latest American initiatives to put pressure on the government of Sudan are centered many thousands of miles away from its capital, Khartoum. A handful of state legislatures in the United States have passed laws that bar their public pension funds from investing in companies with ties to Sudan, which has been accused of extensive human rights abuses in a long-running civil war.

title: No Looking Back for an American Hopeful Gaining on the Africans
description: Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, site of this weekend's United States national cross-country championships, presents a vastly different environment for Lauren Fleshman than the Finnish track where she achieved her greatest triumph last summer. But Fleshman figures that if she made one breakthrough, she could make another.

title: Mind Over Splatter
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. - LAST year, 24 paintings were unveiled as previously unknown works by Jackson Pollock. Authenticated by one of the world's most respected authorities on Pollock's work, the paintings were to go on exhibition this year, the 50th anniversary of the artist's death.

title: He Takes the Shout Out of Talk Radio
description: WITH his soft-spoken demeanor and a preppy, bookish wardrobe that might seem more appropriate for a college professor, John Batchelor is not a particularly noticeable figure along the tree-lined streets of Briarcliff Manor, where he is one of Westchester's newest boldface names. Other than his involvement at the town's local Congregational church, where his wife is a pastor, Mr. Batchelor generally keeps a low profile.

title: Susan Sontag's Latest Mystery
description: Once all but forgotten, Susan Sontag's play "A Parsifal" is receiving its world-premiere production starting Thursday at P.S. 122. Few connected with Sontag, the novelist, essayist and critic who died in 2004, were even aware of the drama's existence, and at a mere six pages it was an unlikely candidate for an actual production. Its journey from obscurity to stage is a tale filled with puzzles, not the least being what prompted Sontag to create "A Parsifal" in the first place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZEIGEN, L. MARSHALL
description: ZEIGEN--L. Marshall. On Valentine's Day, one week after his 76th birthday. Beloved son of the late Bess and Samuel Zeigen. Cherished brother of H. Lylla Kleiman and her husband George. Devoted and loyal friend to many. U.S. Army Veteran. The family will leave Riverside Memorial Chapel on Sunday, February 19 and proceed to The Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Paramus, NJ where entombment will take place 12:30. Call (201) 262-1128 for directions. Buddy will always be remembered by all those who know him for his great humor, vast generosity, knowledge and zest for life.

title: Is 'Liberalism' a Fighting Word?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Magician of Rivington Street
description: THE Hotel on Rivington, a tower of glass set amid the brick tenements of the Lower East Side, is a place that aims to cater to the sophisticate set. The rooms feature copies of Surface magazine, and the music that plays in the lobby, bar and elevators is decidedly un-Holiday Inn, encompassing field recordings of pygmies, Glenn Gould sound collages and R&B stylings of Johnny "Guitar" Watson.

title: Jacobellis Enjoys Her Moment, but About That Flag ...
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 18  The United States snowboarder Lindsey Jacobellis cannot lie. "I was a little upset when I saw the flag was on the wrong pole," she said Saturday.

title: Risking One's Life For an iPod
description: To the Editor:

title: Arms maker takes aim in a less deadly field
Helmut Schulz, 93, Scientist in Physics, Rockets and Refuse, Dies
description: Helmut W. Schulz, a chemical engineer who received 64 patents in disparate fields like nuclear physics, rocketry and waste-to-energy processes despite having been blinded in a laboratory accident as a young man, died on Jan. 28 at a hospital in White Plains. Dr. Schultz, who lived in Harrison, N.Y., was 93.

title: Tempers Rising Over Day Laborers
description: To the Editor:

title: Within Islam's Embrace, a Voice for Malaysia's Women
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Feb. 12 - Sometimes it seems that Zainah Anwar -- articulate, a little brassy, a presence wherever she goes -- single-handedly keeps the flame for women's rights alive in Malaysia, a country that portrays itself as the model of a progressive Muslim society.

title: The Disappearing Horse Farms
description: COLTS NECK - SAM FIERAMOSCA, still coltish at 75, makes his early morning rounds at Colonial Farms here by ambling past the fence-lined paddocks sprinkled with grazing mares and sauntering through the white barns that hold the damp scent of hay and horse manure.

title: Briefs: Militants threaten to attack oil tankers
The Fire Dangers of Aluminum Wiring
description: ACCORDING to the Consumer Product Safety Commission, an estimated two million homes in the United States were built or renovated using electrical circuits with aluminum wiring. And, according to the commission and specialists in the field, unless certain safety procedures are undertaken, every outlet, light switch and junction box connected to such circuits is a fire waiting to happen.

title: Two Burgundies Catch the Eye
description: Inexpensive Burgundy is bought up fast. Two 2004 standouts at the Burgundy Wine Company, 143 West 26th Street (Seventh Avenue), deserve immediate attention.

title: DIEBOLD LARGESS
description: In December, Walden O'Dell resigned as chief executive of Diebold Inc., the maker of electronic voting machines, amid continuing controversy over those machines and his fund-raising for President Bush.

title: Up Front
description: As the long war over Darwinism continues, it can seem as if science and religion are approaching a kind of final intellectual battle. But Leon Wieseltier will have none of it. "Every true result of scientific research is compatible with the belief in God, if you believe in God," Wieseltier, the longtime literary editor of The New Republic, said in a telephone interview. "Science gives an account of nature, but nature must not serve as the basis for our beliefs about the meanings and the obligations of human life. The wisdom of nature is not the only wisdom there is." This week, Wieseltier reviews the philosopher Daniel C. Dennett's "Breaking the Spell," which offers a strictly Darwinian (and unapologetically pugnacious) account of religion. A Brooklyn yeshiva graduate who went on to study literature, philosophy and religion at Columbia, Oxford and Harvard, Wieseltier is no stranger to the traffic between reason and faith. His 1998 book, "Kaddish," was a meditation on the Jewish tradition of mourning, written in the wake of his father's death. But Wieseltier declines to define his own religious commitments even as he draws deeply on his religious learning. "For philosophical reasons," he said, "I live happily in the world of religion, but not always religiously." His review begins on Page 11. The Editors

title: Q & A
description: Q: On a flight from Minneapolis-St. Paul to Detroit last June, an extremely large man lifted up the arm-rest, sat down and occupied at least one quarter of my space. Would it have been possible to have someone from the airline tell him that he must purchase an additional seat? -- Jane Ralls, Minneapolis

title: Governor, Still on the Mend, Stays in Hospital Another Day
description: Gov. George E. Pataki, who was expected to be released from a Westchester hospital yesterday after surgery last week to remove his appendix, was kept in the hospital another day as a precaution, a doctor and an aide to the governor said.

title: Blargon
description: Every walk of life and field of endeavor generates its own insiders' lingo. Those of us in the MSM -- that's the superannuated, archaic mainstream media -- have our own jargon, of which the first sentence of an article is the lede, the early edition is the bulldog and the guys working into the wee hours make up the lobster shift.

title: Growing Old At Home, in Comfort
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Searching Buried Village And Finding Only Bodies Rescuers searched yesterday in the mud that buried Guinsaugon, the Philippines, where almost all the 1,800 residents were feared dead. Thick mud from a landslide on Friday covered the village on the island of Leyte. Fifty-seven people were rescued Friday, but no survivors have been found since then. Text messages were sent from a buried school shortly after the slide, saying that the 200 students and 40 teachers were still alive, but no further messages have been received. PAGE 6

title: Rubens and Rembrandt, a Day's Loot for Balkan Gangs
description: Correction Appended

title: Risking One's Life For an iPod
description: To the Editor:

title: Ciao, Edie: Warhol Girl Gets 15 More Minutes
description: IN life, when she provoked Princess Di-size press gaggles as the embodiment of the mid-60's youthquake, New York-style, Edie Sedgwick had all the ingredients for tabloid stardom. She came from money but seemed not to care, had looks that almost made people forget about her wholesome doppelgnger Audrey Hepburn and, most important, nobody really knew anything about the socialite-turned-Warhol girl, though many thought they did.

title: An Actor Embraces a New Role: Calligrapher
description: JANE LABANZ works in two very different worlds of scripts.

title: 'Afterlands'
description: An Esquimau playing Mendelssohn is a tremendous novelty. The local gentry fill the seats of the Main Street Memorial Hall, whiskery gentlemen in frock coats and wing collars, the ladies in gowns and layer-cake hats trimmed with ribbon and mock flora. Their elegant figures are shored up by trusses or corsets-synthetic exoskeletons fortified with whalebone. If any members of this audience make a connection between their own underclothes and the presence onstage of a child from the Arctic whaling grounds, they don't let on. They are effusive in their praise of the little Esquimau. She is clearly a prodigy. She is only ten years of age! She has been playing the piano for only three years! How charming she looks in her cream cotton dress with the puffed sleeves, the ends of her braids joined at the small of her back with a red ribbon bow. As they whisper and nod, a lush welling of self-appreciation and security warms their chests.

title: Steak and Wine, Served in a Soft Light
description: OCTAGON is one of the prettiest restaurants in this part of Connecticut. Its understated Art Deco design is spare but not cold, and the glow from the honey-colored wood softens the precise lines of the room.

title: Battling the Rules on Tick Eradication
description: A SURGE in the incidence of skin rashes among employees at Brookhaven National Lab during late summer and early fall in recent years has prompted the lab's natural resources director to look for ways to get tough on ticks.

title: If Dogs Could Only Learn to Sign Contracts
description: WHEN Michael Meyer invites you to be in touch if you need a broker, he does not slip you a business card. Instead, he hands you a red plastic scoop for dry dog food, with his contact information on the bone-shaped handle. Or a red lid for pet food cans with the same information.

title: Any Resemblance Is Coincidental. Really.
description: A Family Daughter

title: Uncool on Snow and Ice
description: SINCE when did Ronald McDonald become a sportswear designer? The question presented itself in Turin during this week's competition in snowboarding, one of many sports rarely on this observer's radar except during the two weeks of compulsive viewing that constitutes Olympics season.

title: Congress, Can You Spare a Dime?
description: Congress will not be in session this week. The legislators have all gone home, most to campaign, and are not expected back in Washington until Feb. 27. They left the capital without passing a law to extend unemployment benefits for 164,000 people who are still jobless from Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, even though the benefits start to expire at the beginning of March.

title: Can an Ex-Employee Return to the Fold?
description: Q. You recently resigned from a comfortable job, but you'd like to return. How can you engineer that?

title: In Eternal Spain, Architecture on the Edge
description: IN the eight years since Frank Gehry's Guggenheim Museum miraculously thrust a rusted-out Bilbao to the top of the world's travel list, Spain has become the showcase for some of the most exciting architecture in the world. Astonishingly innovative new buildings  be they public or private, large or small, located in cities or the provinces  have sprung up across the country, unraveling, at least in part, the very fabric of the tradition-bound Spain of collective imagination. Indeed, not since Mies van der Rohe's Barcelona Pavilion of 1929 has Spain been such a center for architectural marvels.

title: Snowed In, And Thankful for It
description: Less than a week after it closed early for the season because of a lack of business, the Powder Ridge Ski Area in Middlefield reopened on Monday after 18 inches of snow fell on its trails last weekend.

title: In Islip, a Big Man Besieged by Opposition and Scrutiny
description: Correction Appended

title: The Meat Raffle
description: Elizabeth Gilbert's true-life tale (The Funny Pages, Feb. 5) resonated with this Indiana-born Minnesota transplant. Gilbert captured Minnesota's unique culture. I delighted in her account of a night out at the Tiki Hut with the girls. How well she captured the sweet humor that exists in the heart of Minnesota. As I read about the meat raffle, I asked my husband, a Minnesota native, "Do they really raffle off meat up here?" His response, spoken in his best Minnesotan accent, "You betcha!"

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TRUNZ, GERALDINE M.
description: TRUNZ--Geraldine M. The North Shore-Long Island Jewish (LIJ) Health System mourns the passing of Gerry M. Trunz, the beloved wife for 28 years of Charles M. Trunz III, the health system's regional chief operating officer. Our thoughts and prayers are with the entire Trunz family, especially Charles and Gerry's children: Charles IV (Chas), Christiaan, Maximilian and Jack. The family requests contributions for the early detection and treatment of ovarian cancer be made in Mrs. Trunz's memory to the Gerry Trunz Fund, NS-LIJ Foundation, 125 Community Drive, Great Neck, NY 11021. North Shore-LIJ Health System Michael J. Dowling, President & CEO Daniel de Roulet, Chairman

title: China's Cyberdissidents and the Yahoos at Yahoo
description: Suppose that Anne Frank had maintained an e-mail account while in hiding in 1944, and that the Nazis had asked Yahoo for cooperation in tracking her down. It seems, based on Yahoo's behavior in China, that it might have complied.

title: Robert Altman's Long Goodbye
description: ROBERT Altman, who turns 81 tomorrow, will receive his very first Oscar in a couple of weeks: an honorary one, of the sort the academy so often employs to ease the bitterness of a veteran nonwinner's declining years. (And, of course, to square historical accounts and deflect the outrage of future generations of movie lovers, who might feel that the failure to honor an important filmmaker reflects sort of poorly on the awards' credibility.) Like King Vidor, who had to hang in for 85 years to cop a thanks-for-the memories statuette, Mr. Altman has five best-director nominations and zero Oscars to show for a long and prolific career, so he pretty emphatically qualifies as overdue. He has been overdue for 30 years.

title: Is 'Liberalism' a Fighting Word?
description: To the Editor:

title: Presto! Dry Hands Vanish
description: PROFESSIONAL magicians, like first-chair violinists and bomb defusers, are afforded no mistakes, however minor. A lone dropped card can snap an audience out of its collective amazement and ruin an entire show.

title: Georgette Poindexter and Peter Phillips
description: Georgette Chapman Poindexter and Dr. Peter Clayton Phillips were married yesterday in the Bahamas. Canon Harry Bain, an Anglican priest, officiated at the Westin at Our Lucaya resort.

title: Sorry, Superman, You'll Have to Change Someplace Else
description: For pay phones in New York and pretty much everywhere, time is expiring.

title: Corrections
description: The Surfacing column on Feb. 5 about limited-run restaurants misstated the title of Arne Hendriks, who was involved in the creation of a temporary restaurant in Amsterdam. He is the curator for exhibition space at Mediamatic, not the director.

description: In October, Shirley M. Tilghman, the president of Princeton, was named to the board of Google, perhaps the hottest company on the Nasdaq in a while.

description: HAHN--Dorothy Maslansky nee Gubkin. On February 11, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Nathan Hahn and Sidney Masliansky. Devoted mother of Melvin and Larry. description: Correction Appended

description: ARMSTRONG, Tex. - MORE than a century before it became the scene of a vice presidential hunting accident, this humble stretch of property had connections to another gun incident.

description: An article on Feb. 15 about Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, referred imprecisely to Mount Trebevic, the site of the bobsled competition in the 1984 Winter Games. It falls within the Bosnia-Croat Federation and the Serb Republic, both components of Bosnia. No part of the mountain is beyond Bosnia's borders.

title: Corrections

The building, a home of Ralph and Ricky Lauren, on Fifth Avenue, was by Angelo Donghia. A reader's letter to the writer about the error was initially misdirected at The Times.

title: Fighting Irish
description: Utterly Monkey

title: In Japan, Day-Trading Like It's 1999
description: TOKYO - YUKA YAMAMOTO dutifully quit work to assume her expected role as suburban homemaker when she married six years ago. But she quickly grew bored at home, and when she saw a television program about online stock investing, she took $2,000 in savings and gave it a try.

title: What Dick Cheney Taught Us About Hunting Last Week
description: THE discussions all week after the accidental shooting of a hunting partner by Vice President Dick Cheney revealed one thing: what many Americans don't know about hunting could fill a book. Here is some of what they learned.

title: Bungling Voting Machines
description: New York could well be the very last state in the country to meet requirements of the Help America Vote Act of 2002, which provides millions of dollars to improve the way we cast our ballots.

title: A Spectator's Role for China's Muslims
description: LINXIA, China - RELIGION is often hidden in China, so the unabashed public display of Islam here in the city known as Little Mecca is particularly striking. Men have beards and wear white caps. Women wear head scarves. Minarets poke up from large mosques. A bookstore sells Korans and religious study guides in Arabic.

title: Notice Anything Funny About the Folks Next Door?
description: SO here comes Bill Henrickson, thoughtful dad and ber-husband, steering the S.U.V. into his pocket of Utah exurbia after a long day overseeing home-improvement stores in one of the fastest-growing areas in America. The Beach Boys have already cued us to the rosy domestic themes to come, singing "God only knows what I'd be without you" through the credits. The likable lug loosens his tie, gives his best Rob Petrie "Honey, I'm home" look, and then makes his way toward one of the three women he has sex with, whose neighboring houses connect through the back doors. The next morning he leaves his bedmate, a willowy blonde with money problems, a $100 bill on the nightstand.

title: Tax Collectors Skeptical of Revenue Plan
description: SOME tax collectors are skeptical about Gov. M. Jodi Rell's plan to eliminate the car tax and give municipalities more revenue from the Indian casinos, fearing that their towns may eventually get less money from the state than they collect on their own.

title: Where Firefighting Is a Family Tradition
description: IN Ossining, volunteer firefighting is a family tradition, going back generations.

title: Divorce New York Style

title: The Liveliest Game at Corus? Anand Demolishing Karjakin
description: The prestigious Corus Chess Tournament in Wijk aan Zee, the Netherlands, Jan. 13 to 29, ended in a hot tie for first between the grandmasters Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria and Viswanathan Anand of India. Each won six games and lost one while outdistancing the rest of the 14-man field.

title: Ronit Friedman and Natan Bar-Chama
description: Dr. Ronit Bihary Friedman and Dr. Natan Bar-Chama were married on Thursday by Rabbi Samuel Shapira at the David InterContinental, a hotel in Tel Aviv. Rabbi David Prebor, a cousin of the bride, participated in the ceremony.

title: Paris: The City of Light, This Time for the Babar Bunch
description: THOUGH known as a city for lovers, Paris is also an idyllic -- even romantic -- destination for those traveling with the fruits of their love. There are hidden paths to discover in the city's gardens, majestic monuments to climb and intimate streets to explore, each colorfully lined with specialty food shops, novelty stores and flower markets.

title: More bodies found in Philippines landslide
Paris: The City of Light, This Time for the Babar Bunch

There are hidden paths to discover in the city's gardens, majestic monuments to climb and intimate streets to explore, each colorfully lined with specialty food shops, novelty stores and flower markets.

title: Man-Child in the Promised Land
description: WALLER, Tex.  In their crusade to take the pulse of contemporary art every two years, the curators of the Whitney Biennial often stray from the art world's beaten paths. But rarely have they strayed quite as far as this small farming town near Houston, along a road that leads to a beige-brick ranch house where a middle-aged man named Daniel Johnston lives with his elderly parents.

title: A Star in Harlem Is Reborn, One Velour Seat at a Time
description: Correction Appended

title: Don't Call. We Won't Either.
description: Zoje Stage submitted her writing -- screenplays, fiction and plays -- to studios, publishers and others nearly 1,000 times between 1993 and 2003, but she never once hit the jackpot. Undeterred, Ms. Stage, 37, saved every rejection letter and turned them into a 25-minute documentary, "Best of Luck," in which the camera pans across hundreds of the missives, rapid-fire, while she reads from them. It's an amusing take on the travails of aspiring writers, but in an unhappy twist the documentary itself was rejected by six film festivals. Ms. Stage persevered, however, tasting success with a screening in a Pittsburgh forum for local filmmakers (she has since moved to Rochester) and another on Wednesday in New York as part of the Anthology Film Archives' New Filmmakers series. Savoring a rare breakthrough, she offered a lesson in the taxonomy of a brushoff.

title: Inside the List
description: THE GOOD LIST: Six novels, three marriages and two decades since his publishing debut, Jay McInerney hits a new milestone this week: he becomes a New York Times best-selling author for the first time. His novel "The Good Life" lands at No. 16 on the hardcover list, in a statistical tie with Linda Fairstein's crime thriller "Death Dance" at No. 15. The novel follows two decadent couples adrift in post- 9/11 Manhattan, and is reviewed on Page 14 this week.

title: Here I Am Taking My Own Picture
description: MORGAN ADAMS, a recent college graduate, decided that her picture on her home page at MySpace.com had lingered a little too long, a full month. To snap a new one she called on the only photographer she thought she could trust: herself.

Is 'Liberalism' a Fighting Word?

title: Scalpers Squeezed; Seats Go Unfilled
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 18 - The frustrated ticket scalpers would like to call a truce. Call off the police, and they promise to fix the most glaring problem of the Turin Games: the absence of spectators, which means less enthusiasm for a spectacle defined, in theory, by passion.

title: U.S. Soldier and 4 Iraqi Policemen Are Killed
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 18 - An American soldier and three Iraqi policemen were killed Saturday in two roadside bomb attacks in Baghdad, while Iraqi and American forces in the snow-covered mountains of Iraqi Kurdistan searched for a missing plane that was carrying five German businessmen.

title: Determined Skater Makes History With Fierce Charge to the Gold
description: Correction Appended

title: Letting the 'Sun' Shine
description: QUIETLY, the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington has changed its tune on George Grosz's monumental 1926 painting "Eclipse of the Sun," probably the museum's most prized possession.

title: ON THE MARKET
