title: The Artist's Tribe
description: "IT'S more Carlos Castaneda than Margaret Mead," Richard Klein, the curator, told me during installation of Jennifer Zackin's exhibition at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield. But "Krippendorf's Tribe" is what came to mind, a Richard Dreyfuss movie in which an anthropology professor invents a lost tribe to account for the grant money he squandered.

title: Bossa Nova From the Source, Jazzed-Up Jazz From Italy
description: Antonio Carlos Jobim

title: Some Find Making Wine Superior To Buying It
description: MAKING wine, for many, seems like an art best left to professionals at commercial wineries. But two businesses in the county are encouraging oenophiles in the region to experiment with varietals and produce their own blends. And while the aspiring vintners may not yet be producing vintage wines, they are revitalizing family traditions that many say had fallen out of favor.

title: DATEBOOK
description: DUBLIN

title: Obsessed With Rodin
description: REJOICE, for the Wadsworth Atheneum, which for a time has been going through a rough patch (sloppy shows, abandoned building projects, patchy acquisitions) has a new, fabulous blockbuster. It is "Rodin: A Magnificent Obsession," organized and toured internationally by the Iris and B. Gerald Cantor Foundation, which owns the works.

title: On Feral Brood's Future, The 'Cat Law' Is Murky
description: WHEN Daniel D. Tartaglia went to law school, he probably never imagined that one day he could add "cat law" to his rsum. But being a lawyer for a homeowners' association in pet-friendly Westchester requires great versatility, so Mr. Tartaglia did his due diligence and ipso facto became the man to call with feline trouble.

title: Free to Be Yourself (by Hiring a Personal Assistant)
description: LIKE many other women in her position, Fransisca Strampher was tired. Before packing the family for a trip to the Sundance Film Festival, she paid the bills, boarded the dog, scheduled the painter for work, ordered asthma medicine, transferred a financial account to a new brokerage firm and downloaded music onto the iPod.

title: Something Borrowed, Something New
description: JERSEY CITY - IT'S hard to believe. Here is a contemporary artist who makes imitations of recently exhibited work by other artists. What is more, he often creates his reproductions from invitation cards to the exhibition where the original was shown, or galleries that neighbor the targeted site. He calls them "unauthorized collaborations."

title: That's 32 Years and Maybe Not Counting
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MATARASSO, DANIEL
description: MATARASSO--Daniel. Papu, we love you, that you know. One whole year of missing you so. Dos Renas, Emma and Dana

title: Sundays With Marty
description: Washington - LIKE most Americans, I was brought up to have deep respect for our judicial system.

title: India starts slaughter of 500,000 chickens
Meatpacking, Packed
description: AS a line of clubgoers winds around the Hotel Gansevoort nearly every night, the G Spa & Lounge is generating a deafening drumroll for having the tightest door in New York.

title: A Pop Quiz on Marriage
description: Usually Valentine's Day comes and goes with just a day or two of news media attention to courtship and marriage. Not this February. New Yorkers are debating whether to join the other 49 states in legalizing no-fault divorce -- even while conservative pro-marriage groups elsewhere plead with their legislatures to repeal it. Meanwhile, Congress has just approved financing for new marriage education programs. And state courts in New Jersey and Washington are expected to rule soon on same-sex marriage.

title: NEWARK AUTHORITY CRITICIZED
description: In their third blistering review since April, federal housing officials criticized the Newark Housing Authority last Wednesday for paying the City of Newark $6.9 million in federal money to add police and health services at its apartment buildings and then failing to document whether the residents ever received the extra aid.

title: Looking for Doping Evidence, Italian Police Raid Austrians
description: TURIN, Italy, Sunday, Feb. 19 - The Italian police raided the Austrian biathlon and cross-country teams' housing at the Winter Olympics on Saturday night, looking for evidence of doping and for a former coach who had been barred from the Games for his involvement in a 2002 blood-doping scandal.

title: The Other Side of the Mountain: Skiers Provide Lessons in Grit
description: SESTRIERE, Italy - THE details of Hermann Maier's folk tale are written in the topography of his oxlike body.

title: A Senate Dream Deferred, but a Possible Promise Extracted
description: WASHINGTON - SOON after Jon S. Corzine won a resounding victory in the governor's race last fall, Democratic leaders in New Jersey and Washington began bracing for the prospect of a political train wreck.

title: Lest We Forget: The Thunderbolt
description: To the Editor:

title: A Memorial In Mamaroneck
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising, Old and New
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Feb. 5 about changes in the American auto market contrasted its two biggest companies, General Motors and Ford, with the next four -- Chrysler, Toyota, Honda and Nissan. It said that while those four were expected to have a combined worldwide profit of $22 billion for 2005, G.M. and Ford together had a loss of $6.6 billion worldwide.

title: Nobody's Perfect
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Waxing About Weather and Waxing for Weather
description: PRAGELATO, Italy, Feb. 18 A The rumble of the snowplows woke the American wax technician Chris Hall at 3 a.m. on Friday, telling him that the long workday ahead was going to be longer than usual.

title: Another Way to Bring Out That Inner Rapunzel
description: TRACY DARNEY has a commercial pilot's license, an M.B.A. and a trim figure. But she never had long thick hair. So she has paid $6,800 to get it.

title: The Animal Self
description: Siebert's article was interesting. It would have been great if it had addressed the moral and ethical implications of the data it presented. If animals share so many feelings with people -- love, fear, altruism, etc. -- what justification is there for society's institutionalized abuse of them? What is the value of knowledge if it is not suffused with compassion?

title: Five Devils Quickly Alter Their Focus
description: Brian Gionta, the right wing on the Devils' top line, said recently that he had not thought too much about playing for the United States men's hockey team in his first Winter Olympic Games. Apparently, he had been too busy scoring goals.

title: Back Rent Won't Stop Norwalk Symphony
description: Richard A. Moccia, the mayor of Norwalk, said on Wednesday that the Norwalk Symphony Orchestra would still be allowed to perform in the auditorium in city hall, despite owing the city back rent.

title: Correction
description: An article Feb. 5 about a state effort to enforce restrictions on the kinds of products sold by wineries referred imprecisely to the law being enforced. The relevant provisions were added to the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law in 1976; they do not date from 1933, when that law was first enacted.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: In Global Harmony

title: Two Reds, Two Faces
description: A $66 outlay for two Roanoke Vineyards winter-weight reds can convey lots of information about the producer's playful, experimental styles. Just savor them side by side in similar glasses.

title: Economists Worry About the Rent, Too
description: THE Greenspan Federal Reserve did the heavy lifting, never missing a chance in its last 14 interest-rate-setting meetings to execute a quarter-point upward nudge. With the new-model Fed under Ben S. Bernanke widely viewed as planning another tweak or two, one market strategist said he would be fine-tuning the way he views an important piece of economic data this week.

title: Buenos Aires: Men's Wear
description: Buenos Aires is a city where, to the delight of Argentines and the chagrin of their neighbors, everybody always looks really, really good. The women are tall and longhaired, and so are the men, and the outfits they wear -- a sexy South American riff on British polo garb -- seem to fit just right. If there's any drawback at all to the look favored by Porteos (as residents of Buenos Aires are called), it's that it can be a little, well, monotonous. Another luxurious sweater-tweed combo? More butter-soft leather? Yes, you're hot, but so is everyone else, and in exactly the same way.

title: Overseas, the Shock of the Surcharge
description: WHILE credit and debit cards make it easier than ever to manage finances while away from home, changes in international fees and the unintended consequences of fraud-detection technology have made traveling with plastic a bit trickier and potentially more expensive than it used to be.

title: A Hyped Budget Shortfall? Wouldn't Be the First Time
description: There's no telling how much money the state of New Jersey does not have. In December, Gov. Jon S. Corzine said the shortfall for the next budget was probably close to $6 billion. No, no, former Gov. Richard J. Codey said last week, it is below $3 billion.

title: Illness Does What Rivals Can't, Knocking Out Woods
description: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif., Feb. 18 - Tiger Woods had kept tissues handy for two days while he sweated through tee shots and sneezed through interviews.

title: Corrections
description: The Journeys column on Feb. 5, about possible sites for the 2014 Winter Games, misstated the location of one contender, Pyeongchang, South Korea. It is a two-and-a-half-hour drive east of Seoul, not an hour west.

title: A 12-Term Brooklyn Congressman, in a Fight for No. 13
description: He has been in the House of Representatives for nearly a quarter-century and is known for his folksy ways and his common touch with the residents of Brooklyn. But as he runs for a 13th term, Edolphus Towns finds himself the target of determined efforts to end his career in Congress.

title: A High-Rise Looms in a Low-Profile Place
description: If it were to be built, it would become the tallest building in north TriBeCa and change the face of a neighborhood largely made up of garages and old, low-rise buildings. In the opinion of the more than 500 residents who have signed a petition opposing the project, it would also create a physical and psychological wall blocking the neighborhood from the Hudson River waterfront.

title: Takes One To Know One
description: HOUSTON - The five most valuable players of the new millennium -- along with a few other stars -- played guest analyst in handicapping this year's M.V.P race. The defending M.V.P., Phoenix point guard Steve Nash, would never vote for himself, but he earned the most praise from his peers.

title: Life After Lance? California Provides an Answer
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 A Is there life for bicycle racing in America after Lance Armstrong?

title: Pamela Davis and Vincent Pagano Jr.
description: PAMELA DAVIS had her back to sorority row, the three college friends she had relied on for precious advice leading up to her second marriage, and her eyes fixed on the fraternity she was joining, her new husband and the four sons they have between them, at the altar of the Park Avenue Christian Church in Manhattan.

title: Man-Child in the Promised Land
description: WALLER, Tex. - IN their crusade to take the pulse of contemporary art every two years, the curators of the Whitney Biennial often stray from the art world's beaten paths. But rarely have they strayed quite as far as this small farming town near Houston, along a road that leads to a beige-brick ranch house where a middle-aged man named Daniel Johnston lives with his elderly parents.

title: No Longer the Best Soul Singer Nobody Knows
description: WEST ORANGE - SOMETIMES a musical shout-out, the kind tacked to the end of a song as an improvised afterthought, is more than just a shout-out. Take "Joy," off Bettye LaVette's 2005 album "I've Got My Own Hell to Raise" (Anti-).

title: The 'Widow Tax'
description: To the Editor:

title: Rachel Kane and Tom Perrotta
description: Rachel B. Kane and Tom Perrotta are to be married this evening at the Tribeca Rooftop in Manhattan. Eric Kane, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism and the brother of the bride, is to officiate.

title: 'The Amalgamation Polka'
The Great New Show MoMA Doesn't Want You to See
description: There's an eclectic exhibition of contemporary paintings, drawings, sculptures, photographs and videos up at the Museum of Modern Art, but don't go looking for it. Though the museum's new building greatly expanded the public gallery space, this show -- the 2006 edition of the museum's staff art show -- is tucked into the corners and corridors of the fourth and fifth floors, where only curators and administrators are allowed to tread.

title: India, Oil and Nuclear Weapons
description: Exploding at the seams with building, investment and trade, India can hardly keep up with itself. Airplanes coming into Delhi and Mumbai routinely end up circling the airports for hours, wasting precious jet fuel, because there are not enough runways or airport gates. City streets originally built for two lanes of traffic are teeming with four and sometimes five lanes of cars, auto-rickshaws, mopeds, buses and trucks. This energy-guzzling congestion will only become worse as India continues producing fairly high-quality goods and services at lower and lower prices -- from automobiles that cost only $2,500 to low-budget airline flights for $50.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BROADWATER, BOWDEN
description: BROADWATER--Bowden. There will be a memorial program for Bowden Broadwater at 5 PM, Wednesday, February 22 at St. Bernard's School, 4 East 98th St. Contributions may be made in his name to St. Bernard's Scholarship Fund.

title: Drug Traffickers Find Haven in Shadows of Indian Country
description: ST. REGIS MOHAWK RESERVATION, N.Y. - He had eluded the authorities for years. Witnesses against him had mysteriously disappeared. Shots were fired from his highly secured compound here last year when the state police tried to close in.

title: Voting Machine Fumbles
description: New York could well be the very last state in the country to meet requirements of the Help America Vote Act of 2002, which provides millions of dollars to improve the way we cast our ballots.

title: In Eternal Spain, Architecture on the Edge
description: IN the eight years since Frank Gehry's Guggenheim Museum miraculously thrust a rusted-out Bilbao to the top of the world's travel list, Spain has become the showcase for some of the most exciting architecture in the world. Astonishingly innovative new buildings -- be they public or private, large or small, located in cities or the provinces -- have sprung up across the country, unraveling, at least in part, the very fabric of the tradition-bound Spain of collective imagination. Indeed, not since Mies van der Rohe's Barcelona Pavilion of 1929 has Spain been such a center for architectural marvels.

title: Changing a Mascot, to What?
description: WHILE some schools have done away with American Indian images as mascots and logos, the debate at Canton High School over its symbol, the Dancing Warrior, has centered mostly on what it should look like.

title: Susie Kim and Ira Levy
description: Susie Kim and Ira Steven Levy are to be married this afternoon at Blantyre, a hotel in Lenox, Mass. Rabbi Albert L. Sturmer is to officiate.

title: Wrestling With Faith While Making the Grade
description: Like thousands of other Muslim parents in the city, Fatiha Oummih eagerly looks forward each year to celebrating Id al-Adha, the Islamic Feast of Sacrifice, with her family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCOLNICK, WILLIAM STUART
description: SCOLNICK--William Stuart. The Board of Directors, Officers and associates of Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation mourn the passing of Bill Scolnick, Director Emeritus and former Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer. Bill was a dedicated associate for over two decades, served as a director of our company for over 44 years and was a role model to many. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his loving wife, Catherine, and their extended family. Mark Weber, Chief Executive Officer

title: Lawyers Compete to Represent an Unprepossessing Client
description: Andrew Goldstein was not, by most lights, a desirable client. He was not a celebrity. He was not rich, accomplished or fashionable. He had a diagnosis of schizophrenia, and he was one of the state's most notorious murderers until his conviction was overturned late last year. So why were these lawyers fighting over him like bridesmaids over a bouquet?

title: Yanks' Damon Checks In, Checks Out the Landscape
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 18 - Johnny Damon made his first appearance at spring training on Saturday, checking out his new locker (next to Jason Giambi's) and shaking hands with his new teammates. He also handled his first questions about George Steinbrenner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNFELD, STANLEY C.
description: BERNFELD--Stanley C. Of Woodland Hills, CA, formerly of Scranton, PA and Brooklyn, died peacefully on February 3. Survived by his loving family, wife Annette, daughters Lisa Bernfeld and Betsy Asen, son-in-law Ben Asen, grandsons Ivan and Harrison, his sister Pearl Shmishkiss. He was the smartest man we knew and he will be greatly missed.

title: Ray Davies Gets His Tocqueville Moment
description: THERE was a small man who arrived late for the Ray Davies show at the Supper Club in late November. It had been years since Mr. Davies, the former leader of the Kinks, the seminal rock band that some would describe as the first indie act, had played a rock show in the United States. As hundreds crushed in around him, Mr. Davies was trying out material from his America-inspired "Other People's Lives," an album written in and about New Orleans that will be out on Tuesday.

title: By 2025, Planners See a Million New Stories in the Crowded City
description: With higher birth rates among Hispanic and Asian New Yorkers, immigrants continuing to gravitate to New York City and a housing boom transforming all five boroughs, the city is struggling to cope with a phenomenon that few other cities in the Northeast or Midwest now face: a growing population. It is expected to pass nine million by 2020.

title: For the Flagship Automat, the Future Grows Dark
description: Of all New York's Automats, a little tooth-white building at 104 West 57th Street was among the best known. Its wide-mouthed, Art Moderne facade, completed in 1938, mimicked the food slots inside, with their steaming plates of mashed potatoes and creamed spinach. Its interior was typically ornate, with a patterned terrazzo floor, a six-foot-wide clock, and dolphin-shaped coffee spigots.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Musician in the House

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "There's just too many dead bodies. For now, we are just leaving the dead because our main concern is to recover the survivors if there are any."

title: OUT-BOX
description: Here are the five most e-mailed articles from nytimes.com/sports for Feb. 11-17.

title: Campaign to Help New York's Neediest Raises $7.2 Million
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has officially closed the books on its 94th annual fund-raising campaign, having raised more than $7 million to aid New Yorkers hobbled by poverty and in need of emergency relief.

title: A Family Daughter
Something New, Something Animated: An Artist's Playful Works
description: PURCHASE - BEHIND every successful work of art, there are often several dozen failures, sometime years of trial and error. This is one reason why artists, when they hit upon a winning formula, stick to it. And it is also why artists, when they look to change what they are doing, need to tread carefully.

title: Good News From New Guinea
description: No one, to my knowledge, keeps an index that measures just how bad the news is from day to day. But most of us can gauge its badness by the way good news makes us feel. A case in point is the article in this paper recently about a scientific expedition to the Foja Mountains of western New Guinea. During a monthlong field trip, biologists came upon new species of frogs, butterflies, birds, palms, and rhododendrons.

title: DYNAMIC DUO
description: In their own ways, Bill Gates and Oprah Winfrey are superlative: he has more money than anyone, and she, with a flick of her book-club wand, can sell more books than anyone.

title: They Served, and Now They're Running
description: FOR Democrats struggling to win back Congress, it seemed like the most obvious of election strategies: erase the Republican advantage on national security by running real-life combat veterans as candidates.

title: When One Island Leads to Another...
description: For a growing number of Caribbean visitors, one island just isn't enough. Enter the island-hopping vacation.

title: Assessments: Only Constant Is Inconsistency
description: SIZING up a home? Long Islanders know to look at more than the number of bedrooms, baths, garage doors and square feet. Everybody also asks about the taxes, because the answers can be all over the map.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, a letter last Sunday about the impracticality of many upscale amenities in new condominiums carried a misspelled signature. The writer was Ruth Barash, not Barish.

title: As Property Values Rise, Homeowners Feel Pinch
description: BOISE, Idaho - Charlotte Snow assails the rising property taxes on her 33-acre spread here in the windswept foothills above the state capital.

title: Firms vying for space on your phone
In Search of the Great American Hockey Novel
description: What accounts for the marginal place of hockey in the world of American professional sports? Might it not, in the end, have something to do with its marginal place in the world of American letters? While the literatures of boxing and baseball are vast, and basketball (John McPhee's "Sense of Where You Are") and football (Don DeLillo's "End Zone," H. G. Bissinger's "Friday Night Lights") also have their classic texts, hockey remains comparatively undocumented. Will historians of the future even know that at the beginning of the 21st century, rugged men from many nations gathered in artificially chilled arenas in Buffalo, Ottawa, St. Paul and Philadelphia to contest Lord Stanley's Cup? To paraphrase Saul Bellow: Where is the Chekhov of the Chicago Blackhawks? Who is the Stendhal of the stick to the groin?

title: 'Still the One'? A Rock Star Hits the Hustings
description: FISHKILL - WHETHER you favor the Democrats or the Republicans, or even if you wish a pox on both their houses, it's hard to dispute one thing: With candidates like Arnold Schwarzenegger, Ronald Reagan, Sonny Bono and Clint Eastwood, the Republican Party is the one that attracts more professional stage presence to the hustings.

title: Collateral Damage
description: LAST September, Jay McInerney wrote a curious essay for the British newspaper The Guardian. It began as a dissent from the contention, which appeared in these pages during the summer of 2005, accompanying an interview with V. S. Naipaul, that fiction had finally been rendered irrelevant by the events of 9/11 and their geopolitical aftershocks. But McInerney rather quickly veered into an account of his own struggle to write the kind of novel Naipaul had decreed unnecessary.

title: The Fixer
description: Mouthpiece

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: THE FILM SNOB'S DICTIONARY: An Essential Lexicon of Filmological Knowledge. By David Kamp with Lawrence Levi. (Broadway, paper, $11.95.) Wire services may have trained one generation of journalists -- the foreign correspondent Ryszard Kapuscinski among them -- to write tersely. But a younger generation of journalists learned the art of brevity by toiling away in the trenches of magazine margins. Cases in point: Kamp, a contributor to Vanity Fair and GQ, and Levi, who is on the staff of the editorial page at The New York Times, both once worked at Spy and, over the years, have burnished the 28-word-and-under profile to a sheen. (Kamp was also a co-author of "The Rock Snob's Dictionary.") In a guide to cinematic terms, actors and more, here's how they describe Robert Evans's life in the 1980's: "a cocaine bust, a link to a murder case, a spotty record as an independent producer, an ever more frightening array of tinted eyeglasses." On Peter Greenaway: "Arguably the perviest of the Brit-perv director set that includes Nicolas Roeg, Ken Russell and Derek Jarman." And the critic Stanley Kauffmann: "An unblurbable iconoclast in a Peter Travers age, Kauffmann perseveres in a time-warped intellectualist cocoon, conveying carnal excitement only when his crush, Emma Thompson, appears in a film." Aside from skewering various indie heroes, Kamp and Levi define genres frequently cited by film snobs, like "chop-socky" ("identified with the latter-day Hong Kong film industry that begat Jackie Chan, Chow Yun-Fat and John Woo"), "grindhouse" (as in, for example, "I Dismember Mama") and "W.I.P." ("Women in Prison"), providing a service for ordinary people who end up going out with snobs or, almost as bad, sitting near them at the movies.

title: Lieberman Faces a Challenge From the Left
description: FROM the outside, Ned Lamont's office building looks like many others in downtown Greenwich: nondescript and very corporate.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Feb. 19 - Feb. 25; FILM
description: If you plan to attend the Edvard Munch retrospective opening today at the Museum of Modern Art, watch the movie first. PETER WATKINS's 1976 masterpiece "EDVARD MUNCH" may not be the greatest of all biopics -- although a strong case can be made -- but it surely ranks with the most innovative and lucid. Here is a true life and times, both scholarly and poetic, in which the painter's everyday travails are fused with incisive cultural analysis. Mr. Watkins was way ahead of the curve in his blurring of documentary and fiction, scoring his material with an art-historical voice-over while a nonprofessional cast (headed by GEIR WESTBY in the title role) pantomime in period costumes on historically accurate sets. They have been instructed to stare into the camera in nearly every scene, obliterating the fourth wall in extended homage to Munch's "Death in the Sickroom." More Cubist than Abstract Expressionist, full of odd angles and dazzling patterns, "Edvard Munch" is a stylistic tour de force that reinvents portraiture as thoroughly as its subject did. The DVD will be released by New Yorker Video ($29.95) on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STERLING, SELMA
description: STERLING--Selma. On February 17, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Morry. Cherished daughter of the late Philip and Julia Aaronson. What a classy dame.

title: 2006 Ford Explorer: Polishing a Tarnished Trophy
description: ITS journey was long, bumpy and perilous, but the Ford Explorer managed to stay at the head of the S.U.V. pack for most of the last 15 years.

title: Sales-Tax Revenue Falls $12 Million Short
description: A $12 million shortfall in sales-tax revenue for 2005 has triggered a call for belt-tightening in Nassau County.

title: Davis Is Right to Let Dream Trump Team
description: TURIN, Italy - IF Bode Miller is the bane of the United States Olympic team for not taking the privilege of competing here seriously, how can Shani Davis be the selfish one for making one race his all-consuming priority?

title: Expanding New York City Into Yonkers
description: YONKERS - IF it is approved by local officials, a $3.1 billion proposal unveiled earlier this month to revive major areas throughout this gritty city with new residences, a ballpark and stores would be the largest municipal revitalization effort in Westchester County, far outstripping even the construction that is transforming downtown White Plains.

title: The Animal Self
description: Charles Siebert's article (Jan. 22) intrigued but didn't surprise me. Anyone who grew up on a farm knows about the wide variety of animal personalities: the calf who won't acknowledge your presence until she is spoken to, the sow who has to hear how beautiful her litter is before any piglets can be touched -- the examples are endless. I'm pleased that formalized studies are being conducted; we can only benefit when we know more about those beings who share our lives.

title: Schnitzel on the Brain
description: Your recipe for liptauer cheese brought back savory memories of the lunches my Hungarian mother used to prepare for me to take to school (The Way We Eat, Feb. 5). One of her favorites was liptauer cheese on pumpernickel bread. She made her spread with farmer cheese, butter, paprika and scallions. Ugh.

title: Menendez's Southern Strategy
description: PENNS GROVE - IT was a long way from Hudson County. But there was Robert Menendez -- a newly appointed United States senator -- on a recent Friday night, trying to assure a room full of local Democratic officials, union members and farmers in this blue-collar community hugging the Delaware River that he was just like them.

title: All the Comforts of Someone Else's Home
description: It's a conundrum faced by many high-end travelers when they go on vacation. Do they want the space and the seclusion afforded by the rental of a private home, or do they want the amenities, like daily housekeeping and access to a concierge, that come with a hotel stay?

title: Confessing to the Converted
description: Chicago - IT is standing room only in Transitions, a New Age bookstore in Chicago, and John M. Perkins, the author of "Confessions of an Economic Hit Man," is describing to his audience the quandary that faces Evo Morales, the recently elected president of Bolivia.

title: Eat, Memory: Sacr Cordon Bleu!
description: By late 1950, I felt ready to take my final examination and earn my diplme from the Cordon Bleu in Paris. But when I asked Mme. Brassart, the school's director, to schedule the test -- politely, at first, then with an increasing insistence -- my requests were met with stony silence. The truth is that Mme. Brassart and I got on each other's nerves. She seemed to think that awarding a student a diploma was like inducting them into some kind of secret society; as a result, the school's hallways were filled with an air of petty jealousy and distrust. From my perspective, Mme. Brassart lacked professional experience, was a terrible administrator and tangled herself up in picayune details and politics. Because of its exalted reputation, the Cordon Bleu's pupils came from all over the globe. But the lack of a qualified and competent head was hurting the school -- and could damage the reputation of French cooking, or even France herself, in the eyes of the world.

title: Comings & Goings
description: Scotland is trying to lure female tourists with, well, men in kilts. Earlier this month, the Scottish Tourism Board started dateahotscot.com, where women only can enter a sweepstakes to win a trip to Edinburgh to meet some Scottish hunks A including the bagpiper who played at Madonna's wedding. "With more than 450,000 single men between the ages of 20 and 40, where better to find the love of your life A or at least drink whiskey with some cute guys?" a press release said.

title: Fired Chinese editors call for press freedom
A Pitcher Who Surrendered, and Won
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 18 - This is the short version: Baseball kicked around Aaron Small for 16 years. He thought about quitting. He said a prayer. Four hours later, the Yankees called. He answered and won 10 games, lost none and made a million dollars.

title: Other Views: Christian Science Monitor, Asahi Shimbun, The Times
Israel freezes funds owed Palestinians
Cycling: Beware of rock-throwing baboon
Hong Kong: Four Seasons
description: THE BASICS Opened in September, the 399-room Four Seasons Hong Kong caps the final phase of development for the city's International Finance Center (IFC), a grand business and shopping complex parked on the Central neighborhood's waterfront. The hotel isn't the company's first foray here  Four Seasons managed the Regent before InterContinental Hotels bought it out in 2001  but it is the first major new hotel to open in Hong Kong in 15 years. There are five restaurants and bars, including a busy lobby lounge. The service is almost uniformly excellent, but some of the concierge staff may have been selected on the basis of language skills and appearance rather than local knowledge. (On a recent visit, a request for a good wonton-noodle restaurant resulted in a trip to a tea house with a decided lack of wonton noodles).

title: When Lobbyists Say 'I Do,' Should They Add 'I Won't'?
description: Correction Appended

title: Iraq Is Shaken by More Deadly Insurgent Attacks
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 19 A At least 15 people were killed in insurgent attacks across Iraq today, and Kurdish officials confirmed that five German businessmen and an Iraqi died in a private plane crash in the north.

title: Rachel Johnson and Robert Braman
description: Rachel Ann Johnson, the daughter of Arlene F. Johnson and Robert A. Johnson of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Russell Braman, the son of Mary E. Braman and Robert T. Braman of Millis, Mass. The Rev. Benjamin J. King, the Episcopal chaplain at Harvard, officiated at the Church of the Advent in Boston, with the Rev. John J. Unni, a Roman Catholic priest, participating.

title: WHY WE TRAVEL: INDIA
description: AT THE AJANTA CAVES, MAHARASHTRA STATE, NOVEMBER 2005 - Natasha Sen, 36, a lawyer from Brandon, Vt. "In a country that's majority Hindu, you sometimes forget it is the birthplace of Buddhism. These caves are hundreds and hundreds of years old; in each of them, at the very middle, there's a huge statue of the Buddha. My husband, Caleb, is a photographer. He's incredibly patient: he can sit and wait for the right scene to come by. I tend to be less patient, so I wander off and do my own thing; that's when he took this picture. India is so vibrant, and there are so many people around, but in the caves it was just so quiet, such an oasis -- yet at the same time, a bit eerie. Sometimes, hidden in the corner, are bats." As told to Seth Kugel

title: Underdog takes shot at giants in kids television
At a Scientific Gathering, U.S. Policies Are Lamented
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 18 - David Baltimore, the Nobel Prize-winning biologist and president of the California Institute of Technology, is used to the Bush administration misrepresenting scientific findings to support its policy aims, he told an audience of fellow researchers Saturday. Each time it happens, he said, "I shrug and say, 'What do you expect?' "

title: The Model President
description: LINCOLN

title: No Joke: Jimmy Fallon's Selling a Pair of Co-ops From the 1880's
description: THE actor Jimmy Fallon is selling a pair of neighboring apartments at 34 Gramercy Park East, an ornate red-brick and terra cotta building that has the distinction of being the city's oldest surviving co-op. He is asking $3.75 million for the units.

title: Rachel Webster and Moss Levenson
description: Rachel Gayle Webster, the daughter of Fredricka Jenkins of Cincinnati and Daniel A. Webster of Spokane, Wash., is to be married in a Quaker ceremony today to Moss Easton Levenson. The ceremony is to take place at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Rustin Levenson and Randal Levenson of Miami.

title: Earnhardt Says No to Wager
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18 - Nascar is long past the days when somebody can show up with a racecar and a dream and expect to make the field for the Daytona 500 -- not with the multimillion-dollar sponsorships that power the sport these days.

title: STATE HOUSE MAKEOVER
description: Work has began at the State House in Trenton that will add extra security at the 214-year-old building. The $1.2 million project will include the installation of surveillance cameras, metal detectors and an X-ray machine for screening packages.

title: This Year, the First Round Goes to the Risk Takers
description: YOU can divide investors into two camps these days. There are those who think that the stock market will return so little that it doesn't pay to take any risk for now. And there are those who think that the market will return so little that you must embrace risk if you want any meaningful gains.

title: Venturing Out on the Deep Blue Sea to Learn More About Land
description: THE annual cruises that Larry and Susan Cerrito take offer a myriad of on-board activities, from rock climbing and miniature golf to art auctions and high-stakes bingo.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Feb. 19 - Feb. 25; ART/ARCHITECTURE
description: In these trying times, there may be no better therapy than an afternoon spent in the "DADA" show at the National Gallery of Art in Washington. Few artists were able to expose the defects and absurdities of a mechanized society like the Dadaists, the loose-knit group of artists whose work was a reaction to the grinding carnage of World War I. But what's surprising about the show is the creative range of the works, which were produced between 1916 and 1924: from HANNAH HCH's wonderfully bizarre photomontages to the more politically edgy work of JOHN HEARTFIELD. The show traces the wanderings of Dada's principal actors from Zurich to Cologne, Hanover, Berlin, Paris and New York, and in the process reveals a movement that is as fresh -- and relevant -- today as it was in a Europe edging toward World War II. East Building, Fourth Street and Constitution Avenue, NW, (202) 737-4215, through May 14.

title: Mass slaughter of fowl in India after bird flu outbreak reported
At Ground Zero, No End to a Dispute That's Years Old and 1,776 Feet High
description: At a downtown breakfast meeting nearly three years ago, Gov. George E. Pataki made the tallest building planned for the World Trade Center site also its most richly symbolic one when he called it the "Freedom Tower."

title: Mama Retro
description: NEW BRUNSWICK - IT is early morning, and the sun is slicing through a window and illuminating a jar of olive oil on my kitchen counter. It is a sturdy glass jar that narrows at the top for better pouring, but it isn't strictly utilitarian -- a row of olive branches lines its shoulders and its ample hips. The label is gold and ivory, and the oil itself glows a dusky yellow from within.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHOLZ, LAWRENCE C. (LARRY)
description: SCHOLZ--Lawrence C. (Larry). Died February 17, 2006. Worked at Lockheed Astro Space Center in Princeton. Leaves wife Claire, son Richard, daughter Karen, brother William, and three grandchildren. At home: 11 AM to 4 PM, February 20-24. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to the Sierra Club.

title: He's Free to Talk if Someone Pays
Looking for the Lie
description: I can envision, a decade or so from now, the next iPod-like gadget: a pair of glasses with a built-in lie detector that flashes "He's lying!" as a floating subtitle just below the person you are watching. This science-imitating-art device would be quite useful when talking with a suitor ("I like you" He's lying; "I love you" He's really lying). Such a device would also be handy when talking with a car salesperson ("It gets 40 m.p.g. on the highway" Sure, maybe downhill, with a tailwind), stockbrokers ("Everybody I have talked to is buying this stock" You're the only person he talked to) and real-estate agents ("This is the hottest market in the state" Did I hear a bubble burst?).

title: The Case for Fewer but Stronger Currencies
description: OUTSOURCING isn't just a one-way street on which rich countries shift jobs overseas. In recent years, some developing countries have contracted out the work of setting monetary policy to the United States. Ecuador and El Salvador, in 2000 and 2001, respectively, abandoned their own currencies, adopted the dollar and placed their monetary policy in the capable hands of Alan Greenspan, then the chairman of the Federal Reserve.

title: Is 'Liberalism' a Fighting Word?
description: To the Editor:

title: San Diego
description: WHY GO NOW -- Despite the recent sudden abandonment of its "America's finest city" motto, San Diego is nonetheless a thriving destination thanks to the ever-idyllic weather and a recent influx of billions of dollars toward downtown development, a mature crop of boutiques and nightclubs and a suddenly hot restaurant scene. Local restaurateurs are gaining notice outside their once-insular community, and acclaimed chefs are foregoing high-profile jobs in San Francisco and New York for the opportunity to become big fish in this smaller -- but growing -- pond, making San Diego worth a pilgrimage for fine dining.

title: Is 'Liberalism' a Fighting Word?

description: FAR be it for a lifelong fan of baseball to offer advice to the wily entrepreneurs of the endless-left-turn circuit, but I would like to drop a couple of words of counsel on auto racing: Think Cooperstown.

title: Corrections
description: A Habitats column on Jan. 21, about the house of Andrea Arden and Rhett Butler in Red Hook, Brooklyn, referred imprecisely to Mr. Butler's role in the hardware design for the Seattle home of Bill Gates. Although Mr. Butler did put together a list of the required hardware and did supply much of it, Katonah Architectural Hardware in Katonah, N.Y., was hired to put together the final list.

title: When Rappers Keep Their Mouths Shut Tight
description: A fight erupts among acquaintances, words give way to violence and a bystander is fatally shot amid a crowd of onlookers.

Exploring the Effects of Disco's Beat
description: THE BRONX - RIDING the considerable wake of a well-received hip-hop and art exhibition at the Bronx Museum of the Arts in 2002, "Do You Think I'm Disco," a zany new exhibition at the Longwood Art Gallery @ Hostos, surveys the influence of disco music and dance culture on contemporary art. Not too surprisingly, much of the work is about sex, drugs and music.

title: I Vaguely Recall a Girl by That Name
description: ATLANTIC CITY - FROM gowns to programs to tiaras, the display windows at the Sheraton Atlantic City Convention Center Hotel are chock-full of Miss America memorabilia. In the lobby, a video drones on day and night with shrieks and cries, hugs and waves, from the winning moments of pageants past while outside, a life-size statue of Bert Parks, the longtime pageant M.C., croons the theme song, "There She Is," at the press of a button.

title: Japanese Pitcher Channels His Inner Warrior
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 18 - The tattoo on Yusaku Iriki's left shoulder reminds him why he is here and where he has come from.

description: Heading one of the world's biggest banks doesn't mean never having to say you're sorry. James Dimon, the chief executive of J. P. Morgan Chase & Company, learned that lesson this month after he made a joke at an investor conference at the expense of Michael Mayo, a veteran analyst of bank stocks.

title: Melissa Ladines and Eric Mejia
description: Melissa Roxanne Unson Ladines and Eric Mario Galang Mejia were married yesterday in Pasadena, Calif. The Rev. Francis Mendoza, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Catholic Church.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Feb. 19 - Feb. 25; THEATER
description: It was a disastrous fall for Off Broadway musicals. Except for MICHAEL JOHN LaCHIUSA's "See What I Wanna See," the noncommercial productions were also nondelightful, and the commercial ones, save "Drumstruck," all tanked. Watching that dismal parade, I wondered if the authors and producers hadn't mistakenly read "SECOND ACT TROUBLE" (Applause Books), STEVEN SUSKIN's new entry in the canon of theatrical schadenfreude, as a how-to instead of a how-could-they. What's amazing is that, point by point, the same mistakes made by deluded Broadway dilettantes of the last several decades were still being made, on a similar scale, off Broadway last season.

title: Punching Through
description: BARNEY ROSS

title: Dreams Deferred
description: ROANOKE, Va. - BED is a medicine," instructs an Italian proverb. Increasingly, Americans are inverting that counsel by ingesting sleeping pills to speed their slumber.

title: Worrying With Celebrities
description: Americans have been marveling at the bad luck of Michelle Kwan, whose ill-timed injury forced her to quit the Olympics, but my anxieties have lately been focused on another competitive skater: Kristy Swanson, who has made it to the Feb. 27 finals in "Skating With Celebrities." This Fox show, a ripoff of ABC's "Dancing With the Stars," pairs D-list famous people with past skating champions. On the show, Ms. Swanson's face has betrayed a certain what-in-God's-name-am-I-doing-here sentiment, and I -- a long-time Swanson loyalist -- can't help wondering the same thing.

title: Newspaper group urged to note failing on Jews
Torcello Offers a Refuge From the Tourist Crush
description: IT should come as little wonder that the island of Torcello is a refuge for visitors in search of a quick escape from the crowds of Venice. The island that rests quietly in the northern lagoon, a 40-minute ferry ride from the main islands of Venice, made its reputation as a haven 1,500 years ago -- nearly 500 years before Venice became an empire -- when mainlanders, escaping invading barbarians, settled here. It's also the spot where Ernest Hemingway holed up while writing "Across the River and Into the Trees" between duck hunting and bottles of wine with Giuseppe Cipriani--the founder of Locanda Cipriani, the island's famous inn and restaurant, and then owner of the Venice cornerstone Harry's Bar.

title: Looking for the Lie
description: In Robin Marantz Henig's fascinating article about lying (Feb. 5), she describes our "private territory" and writes, "Without lies, there can be no such sanctuary, no interior life that is completely and inviolably ours." In writing this, she assumes that our choices are limited to either lying or telling the truth. Instead, there is a third, bold choice. That choice is to say, in a way that feels appropriate, I choose not to share or discuss this topic with you. Thus we can maintain our "private territory" without being dishonest.

title: Bad Call
description: I was at my little job on Court Street in Brooklyn, in a vintage clothing store. It's not the most humiliating job I've ever had, but it is the most recent. One benefit is that I get to go to the bathroom at work. When I came out of the bathroom the other day, I saw the back of a man walking out the front door. As we don't carry men's clothing, my eyes scanned the desk to see if he had left fliers or menus. Nothing. Then I realized "nothing" included my cellphone, which had been sitting on the counter. I grabbed the house phone and dialed my cell number. No ringing in the store. Two girls moseyed in. I grabbed the store keys and pronounced: "You guys are going to have to leave. I've been robbed." They blurted words of encouragement and cooperatively dashed out, watching me lock the front door.

description: FLUFFED

title: New Hope for Old Suburbs
description: Remember these words: "First Suburbs." The term refers to places known variously as "inner-ring" suburbs or pioneer suburbs or Cheever country or Levittown or places where ideals of white picket-fence perfection coexist with madness and alienation and dysfunction and despair. Around here, we know them as Westchester and Nassau, but they exist across the country, on the outskirts of cities that saw an exodus of young families in boom years after World War II.

description: It is all too easy to make fun of opera plots. Even the great Verdi maestro Riccardo Muti joked recently that he would be hard pressed to lay out the plot of "Il Trovatore."

title: Spotted in Nirvana
description: THE language of letting go is not easy to master. In many cases it is not easy to take either. Self-help books teem with catchy maxims to help you feel better about yourself: more hopeful, more centered, more empowered! But in tossing around nebulous concepts like vibrations, negative energy and toxins, such tomes often seem as if the practical advice is disguised in obscure language solely for dramatic effect.

title: Corrections

description: For generations, young women entering college have lived in fear of the "freshman 15" -- not a difficult set of introductory courses, but the amount of weight female students are said to gain in their first year.

After finding the work interesting, she decided to take a college accounting course in her senior year of high school "to make sure it would be something I really liked."

title: U.S. Marines Join Search for Landslide Survivors
description: GUINSAUGON, Philippines, Feb. 19 A Dozens of American marines began assisting today in the search for survivors from last week's deadly landslide in the eastern Philippines, digging through the mud in the late afternoon and building roads throughout the evening.

description: For comedians, there was only one subject worth talking about last week: the hunting accident involving Vice President Dick Cheney.

title: Movies on TV
description: RECONSTRUCTION (2003) Tuesday at 10 p.m. and Saturday at 2:45 p.m. on Sundance They say love changes everything, but this is true in a daunting metaphysical way for Alex (Nikolaj Lie Kaas), a dashing Danish photographer. After he meets Aimee (Maria Bonnevie, above, with Mr. Kaas) and realizes they are meant for each other, he tries to go home but finds that there is no longer a door to what should be his apartment. And no one knows him, even his longtime girlfriend (Ms. Bonnevie in a Frances Farmer hairdo), which is both good and bad news. The fact that Aimee's husband (Krister Henriksson) writes romantic novels may explain a lot. The film, directed by Christoffer Boe, won the Camra d'Or, the award for best first feature, at the Cannes Film Festival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRITTO, ARTHUR J.
description: BRITTO--Arthur J. Of Babylon on February 17, 2006. Beloved husband of Winifred A. Britto. Loving father of Marian Minkin, Aileen Slack and Theresa Skvarla. Friends may visit Sunday, 7-9:30 PM, and Monday, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM, at the Claude R. BoydSpencer Funeral Home, 448 W. Main St., Babylon.

title: The Good Life
A Marriage, When the Spirit Moves Them
description: IT'S 10 p.m. and the wedding is in full swing in a ground-floor apartment in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. The groom, wearing a crisp white dress, is writhing belly-down on the floor and hissing fiercely. Soon he is going to look into his bride's eyes and pledge his everlasting love to her. But instead of the clink of champagne glasses, she cracks a hard-boiled egg for him, which he swallows whole -- like a snake. Because he is a snake. His name is Dambalah and he is a voodoo spirit about to marry a New Yorker.

Are They the Tools of Irrelevance?
description: With apologies to Punxsutawney Phil, whose eye is not what it used to be, winter officially returned to its hole last week with baseball fans' favorite words: pitchers and catchers report. Pitchers and catchers are as symbiotic as hot dogs and beer. From now through October, they will form their teams' most vital partnership.

title: Nation's Air Fares, Confusing as Ever, Are Heading Up
description: Among the minor frustrations of modern life, making sense of the bizarre patchwork of air fares has to rank pretty high. After all, you can fly cross-country for $100 or so, but it can cost several times that to fly a few hundred miles. Or fares can double from one day to the next.

title: With Ryan Newman
description: Ryan Newman, called Rocketman because he wins so many poles, enters his fifth full Cup season driving the No. 12 Alltel Dodge for Penske Racing South. Newman, an engineer with a degree from Purdue, has finished in the top 10 in points in each of his first four years, with a series-high 8 victories in 2003 and 12 over all. He and his wife, Krissie, created a foundation that supports animal shelters, educates about conservation and finances college scholarships. Newman will start 18th in the 43-car field for today's Daytona 500. VIV BERNSTEIN

title: Boathouse Built for the Bulldogs Is Soon to Bow Out
description: THE new Pearl Harbor Memorial Bridge, spanning New Haven harbor and scheduled for completion in 2014, promises to be a dramatic addition to the area -- a great suspension span with striking nighttime illumination. But to the $450 million cost of the bridge must be added an intangible loss -- the destruction of the Tudor-style Adee Memorial Boathouse, built in 1911 at the foot of the Quinnipiac River for Yale's crew teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIGGETT, JOSEPH
description: LIGGETT--Joseph. Beloved husband, father and grandfather died February 16 from complications of Parkinsons. He was 82 years old. Memorial service will be held on February 19 at 12 noon at Temple Emanu-El, 65 Street and 5th Avenue. Mylene, Joseph, Peter, Rosy and JP Liggett

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Feb. 19 - Feb. 25; DANCE
description: This is a very good dance week in New York City. But forced to choose among many tempting offerings (the NEW YORK CITY BALLET's final stretch, the FLAMENCO FESTIVAL, the JUILLIARD DANCE ENSEMBLE's three premieres to three new scores), I'd opt for the rather cheesily titled "KINGS OF THE DANCE" -- an all-star venture for four of the best male dancers on stage today. ANGEL CORELLA and ETHAN STIEFEL are from American Ballet Theater, the Danish-born JOHAN KOBBORG dances with the Royal Ballet, and NIKOLAY TSISKARIDZE is from the Bolshoi Ballet. Not only will they dazzle audiences with a variety of virtuoso leaps and spins in excerpts from the classical repertory, they have also commissioned new solos for the occasion by a quartet of slightly unlikely choreographers: Roland Petit (for Mr. Tsiskaridze), Nils Christe (for Mr. Stiefel), Stanton Welch (for Mr. Corella) and Tim Rushton (for Mr. Kobborg). Of even more interest is the commission of a new work for the four men by Christopher Wheeldon, economically titled "For 4" and set to Schubert. Thursday through Saturday at 8 p.m., next Sunday at 3 p.m., City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Midtown, (212) 581-1212 or www.citycenter.org; $35 to $150.

title: Company
description: Monday morning and there's one less donut than there should be.

title: Where Italian Is Spoken in Bronxville
description: BRONXVILLE - AFTER eating at Rosie's Bistro Italiano, a lively, good-looking restaurant here at the foot of Palmer Avenue, a guest observed that traditional Italian restaurants can be judged by two criteria: red sauce and espresso. Although Rosie's offers a hearty Bolognese sauce, on two occasions uneven meals that might have ended on a strong note instead ended on a weak, barely caffeinated, one.

title: Time Warner strife yields to agreement
A Report on Noise Draws Hardly a Peep
description: When Frank Sinatra sang about waking up in the city that never sleeps, the odds are that he was not referring to early-morning jolts from crying babies, barking dogs or heavy-heeled upstairs neighbors stomping about on uncarpeted floors. Yet, in this tightly packed city, these are the sounds that can pry a New Yorker's eyes open.

description: WASSERMAN--Rose. Age 85 in Reseda, CA. on February 12, 2006. Beloved sister of the late Harold Wasserman, aunt of Richard, Robert & Renee, great-aunt of Halle and Danielle. We cherish the memory of a truly remarkable gifted woman, her life long friendship, and her generosity of spirit. Esther and Stanley Nayer The Rainer Family

description: KAPLAN--Harriet W. Died February 16, 2006. Of Hollywood, FL, formerly of Rocville Centre. Cherished mother of Sue Ellen Schoeman & Leslie Melby. Beloved sister of Marvin Wasserman, adored grandmother of Eric, Robin and Lauren.

title: DataBank; Stocks Rise for the Week, Despite Inflation Worry
description: Despite worries about inflation that weighed on the stock market Friday, the three main market gauges rose for the week, buoyed by strong earnings reports and the possibility of a big utility merger.

description: WHEN Long Island University transferred the undergraduate programs at Southampton College to its C. W. Post Campus in Brookville last year, Stony Brook University took over Southampton's acclaimed marine sciences program and offered to buy its entire 80-acre campus for $35 million.

description: ZOLT--David. On February 17, 2006. Beloved husband of Beatrice. Loving father of Richard and Judy and Steven. Cherished grandfather of Alana & Tyler. Dear brother of Dorothy Farb. He will be forever in our hearts. Services Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, NY, 11:30AM Sunday

description: BENINGSON--Renee. Mourning the loss of dear friend Renee. With hearts full of love. Alice and Louis Weiss

title: Sunset Over Bohemia
description: ONE of the world's greatest flowerings of art and creativity occurred in the West Village from the 1940's to the 1970's, and although many of the artists, writers and poets who contributed to the era's richness have passed on, a few remain.

title: Is Ritual Circumcision Religious Expression?
description: The equal-protection argument with respect to female and male circumcision fails completely when you consider that, while some studies have concluded that there are health benefits that accrue to circumcised men, none -- at least to my knowledge -- have proved the same with respect to circumcised women. Quite the contrary.

title: Goya Tickles the Ivories
description: MAKING art from blobs and stains is a very modern thing to do. In art classes, it has become common to have students take a group of random dots and make them into, say, a bouquet, a horse, a house or a ballerina. The Surrealists excelled at this sort of visual free association, but before they came along, it was virtually unknown.

title: Women's Health Studies Leave Questions in Place of Certainty
description: So what do women do now? The results of two major studies over the past two weeks have questioned the value of two widely recommended measures: calcium pills and vitamin D to prevent broken bones, and low-fat diets to ward off heart disease and breast and colon cancer.

Letters

description: IF ever there was a year that Connecticut's maple syrup makers were sweating it, this would be the one.

title: Turkeys: The Restoration Period
description: When we consider turkeys, if at all, we tend to think of them in terms of dark meat and white meat. Well, the holidays are long over, but turkeys are still around. They're cold but not frozen, and there is a good chance that a couple of them have recently wobbled through your backyard.

title: Hitched to Miller, U.S. Skiing Slips Off Course
description: Correction Appended

title: A Lesson From Hamas: Read the Voting Law's Fine Print
description: DEMOCRACY rests on the will of the majority. Or so the speeches say. But in reality, election systems are almost never designed to achieve majority rule alone. Like the famous checks and balances of the American system, they also try to give a wide range of groups a portion of power. But sometimes the framers of an election law can wildly miscalculate, allowing one faction to game the system and gain power far out of proportion to its share of the vote.

title: Workers Uniting, Over Pirogi
description: THEY were a staple of Communist Poland, punishingly drab restaurants in which the menu was scrawled on a handwritten board above the cash register, room-temperature yogurt drinks sat lined up on the counter, and waitresses in smocks served food on trays through a small window.

title: Man, 68, Is Killed by Bus in Manhattan
description: A 68-year-old man crossing a crowded Manhattan street was killed yesterday when he was struck by a tour bus whose driver was unaware that he had hit anyone, the police said.

title: The Shining, Unscary Version
description: After several seasons worth of sequins, spangles and Swarovski crystals clinging to clothes like barnacles, the encrustacean era finally seems to be winding down. For spring, retailers are turning down the sparkle and turning up the shine, for a cleaner, more streamlined effect. Using sexy satins, glossy metallics and opalescent materials like mother-of-pearl, designers are keeping their clothes and accessories high gloss and low glare.

title: No Fuss or Hard Feelings as Ohno Fades to 3rd
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 18 - The inevitable question about 2002 was posed to Ahn Hyun Soo during a postrace news conference Saturday night: How upset were the people of South Korea, his home country, four years ago when the American Apolo Anton Ohno was given the gold medal after South Korea's top short-track skater, Kim Dong Sun, was disqualified?

title: Laptop Woes? Meet Mom and Pop

title: Strategy Tragedy?

Peterson, a big, witty officer in charge of training the Iraqi police force, spent two hours laying out a plan to bring order to a fractious country, a plan that was everything the American enterprise had always failed to be: bold, coherent and imagined all the way down to the hinges on the office doors.

title: Paperback Row
description: GOD LIVES IN ST. PETERSBURG: And Other Stories, by Tom Bissell. (Vintage Contemporaries, $13.95.) In his travel book, "Chasing the Sea" (2003), Bissell described the destruction of Uzbekistan's Aral Sea. His first collection of short stories revolves around Americans adrift in Central Asia. The opening story, "Death Defier," about an American journalist's ordeal in Afghanistan, is a powerful study of Western detachment in a 21st-century war zone. Our reviewer, Pankaj Mishra, said Bissell "reveals himself to be not only a subtle craftsman but also a mordant observer of a new generation lost in a complex and dangerous world."

title: Scenes From the Future of Ballet
description: CHRISTOPHER WHEELDON was just a promising young choreographer and soloist with the New York City Ballet when the curtain rose on his "Scnes de Ballet" in May 1999. But with that work Mr. Wheeldon began his fast climb to international renown as the choreographer who might single-handedly save classical ballet at a time when vital distinctions between classicism and modern dance had become troublingly blurred. And in the act of reaffirming the values central to his work, Mr. Wheeldon may well, like George Balanchine, expand the boundaries of what is considered classical ballet.

Its crossroads, a crowded commercial marketplace at Main Street and Roosevelt Avenue, is surrounded by charmless brick apartment buildings and several new towers rising simultaneously.

I was clingy and desperate and wore my heart on my sleeve, falling madly in love repeatedly, only to meet with heartbreaking rejection at every turn.

title: Great Performers
description: Around this time of year, acting in movies starts to feel like a kind of athletic event, with prizes awarded to the winners while the losers are reduced to being glamorous extras on televised award show after televised award show. By the time of the Academy Awards, which this year will take place on March 5, the spirit of the contest seems to take precedence over artistic achievement. This year, as in the previous two, The New York Times Magazine has tried to eschew this notion of competition by saluting the performances that moved, surprised and thrilled us, regardless of whether they were nominated for awards. Some -- like Reese Witherspoon's in "Walk the Line" -- have been acknowledged by Oscar, while others -- like Penlope Cruz's in the Italian film "Don't Move" -- were barely seen in America. And while it's very likely that you've caught Heath Ledger's heartbreaking turn in "Brokeback Mountain," you may have easily missed the explosive German film "Head-On," which starred Sibel Kekilli and Birol nel. In 2005, George Clooney may have had the most diverse year in film: he packed on weight to play a wary, melancholic C.I.A. agent in the largely overlooked "Syriana" and then masterminded and starred in "Good Night, and Good Luck," the story of Edward R. Murrow's clash with Senator Joseph McCarthy. Performances as enthralling and complex as those by (the nominated) Philip Seymour Hoffman in "Capote" or (the unnominated) Jeff Daniels in "The Squid and the Whale" should not be overshadowed by the suspense of who will and who won't receive a statuette. Once again, the photography team of Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin has beautifully composed and captured the variety of characters who resonated with us this year and distilled the essence of what makes great movie acting great.

title: Hopeful Words on European Union Expansion in the Balkans

title: 'The Bill From My Father'
QUICK BITE/North Plainfield; The Day Starts on Little Pigs' Feet
description: Some people have been known to order at least 15 trifles at one time, while others can't live without the potato salad. Many come for breakfast, and don't leave until they've finished lunch. "We opened with just three tables," said Nanny Claire Marie Lamont. "Now we have seven. Word of mouth sparked our business. After a full day on the job, no one wants to come home and start cooking. I want Nanny's Kitchen to be the kind of place you'll always want to come home to."

title: 'Consuelo and Alva Vanderbilt'
description: As the delay lengthened and nervousness grew, self appointed society experts in the crowd had time to debate one important question: had anyone seen the Vanderbilt family, whose apotheosis this was alleged to be? There could be no dispute that Vanderbilt gold was a powerful chemical element at work in St Thomas Church on 6 November 1895. It had given the bride her singular aura; it had drawn a duke from England; and without it, Alva would not now be waiting anxiously for her daughter to arrive. Scintillae of Vanderbilt gold dust brushed everything on the morning of Consuelo's wedding, from the fronds of asparagus fern to the glinting lorgnettes in the crowd outside. It was remarkable, therefore, that apart from the father-of-the bride, its chief purveyors should be so conspicuously absent; and even more striking that this scarcely mattered because of the force of character of the bride's Vanderbilt great-grandfather, whose ancestral shade still hovered over the players in the morning's drama as if he were alive.

title: A Puzzle Even Fargo North, Decoder, Couldn't Solve
description: HEEEEY yooou guuuuys! Here's what the new "Electric Company" DVD set is good for: Blowing your mind. If you went to elementary school sometime in the 1970's, you probably spent some time -- or, in my case, quite a lot of time -- watching the show. Created in 1971 when the United States Department of Education asked the Children's Television Workshop for a way to teach children to read, it stopped production in 1977 and has been off the air since 1985. Except for a four-year stint on the Noggin Network, the show has been in cultural deep storage.

description: Once, not that long ago, economics was the queen of the social sciences. Human beings were assumed to be profit-maximizing creatures, trending toward reasonableness. As societies grew richer and more modern, it was assumed, they would become more secular. As people became better educated, primitive passions like tribalism and nationalism would fade away and global institutions would rise to take their place. As communications technology improved, there would be greater cooperation and understanding. As voters became more educated, they would become more independent-minded and rational.

title: 'Spell ''World'' Backward'

description: After reading your article, I find that I am less interested in how we might detect a lie and more interested in why we lie (and so often). I think some of the answers may be found in Kenji Yoshino's Jan. 15 article, "The Pressure to Cover." Mainstream thinking and acting are what lead to success in our culture, and so we change the way we dress and think and what we say in order to gain that success -- even if it is not the truth.

title: Vaccination Verdict
description: I am a teacher. I have friends who refuse to vaccinate their children for fear of supposed side effects. Some have talked about getting faked doctors' forms that say their children have been vaccinated so they can attend public school. As someone legally and morally charged with the safety of children, I plan to report them to their respective school districts if they do so. Isn't this my duty?

title: Corrections
description: The Gretchen Morgenson column last Sunday, about SFBC International, a company that conducts clinical trials for drug makers, misstated its ranking in its field. It is among the largest companies, not the largest.

title: Children, the Littlest Politicians
description: IT was not so long ago that men and women voted along similar lines. Both sexes went overwhelmingly for Richard Nixon in 1972 and narrowly for Jimmy Carter in 1976.

title: Lawmakers Increase Criticism of Dubai Deal for Ports
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 A Legislators from both parties continued today to sharply criticize the Bush administration's approval of a recent sale that would give a Dubai company control over shipping facilities at six leading American ports, saying that it raised fundamental security issues.

title: And You Thought a Black Cat Was Bad Luck
description: MERIDEN, Conn. - THE most famous account of the mysterious Black Dog of the Hanging Hills hinges on this portentous declaration: "It may seem strange that a man of science should believe a thing of this kind -- an idle tale for the ignorant and superstitious, you will say -- but I do believe it. And if you would know why, listen:"

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Washington's Birthday, Feb. 22, will be observed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISFOGEL, ESTHER, DR.
description: WEISFOGEL--Esther, Dr. A distinguished obstetrician gynecologist, died February 9, 2006, in Boca Raton, FL, at the age of 80. She was a member of the International Society for the Study of Vulvo-Vaginal Diseases and of the Nassau County OB-GYN Society. Her specialization in vulvar diseases led to new and effective treatments. She was on staff at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, NY, where she achieved recognition for her diagnostic skills. She was known for her innovative procedures, which saved many lives, and her tireless dedication to her patients. During a period of pro bono work in American Samoa, she contributed her knowledge and skills as a practitioner of Western medicine in a third world area. She was born in Brooklyn, NY, March 13, 1925, and educated in the public school system; she graduated from Hunter College. Determined to fulfill her childhood ambition to become a doctor, in 1946 she entered NYU Medical School as one of the few women accepted. Besides her medical career, she was also a prolific poet, a painter, and a sculptor of welded metal. Dr. Weisfogel was the widow of Dr. Lawrence I. Kaplan, himself an accomplished physician. She is survived by daughters Robin Kaplan and Laura Obert-Thorn and three grandchildren, as well as her brother Dr. Jerry Weisfogel, sisterin-law Dr. Matonah Rubin, sisters Irene Braunstein and Florence Treistman, brotherin-law Benjamin Treistman and nieces and nephews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATZMAN, SARA
description: KATZMAN--Sara. On February 12, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Beverly Katzman and Shelley Katzman Selig; adored grandmother of Matthew Selig and Jane Selig Goldstein, loving great grandmother of Andrew and Emily Goldstein. She is also survived by her good friend Rose Idemne. Her love and generous spirit will be greatly missed.

But the Rolling Stones have never lacked for swagger, and on Saturday night about one and a half million people, according to the police and other authorities, flocked to Copacabana Beach for a free concert starring Mick Jagger and company.

In Midtown last Sunday, the record snowfall did not keep people away, and Atlas was etched in fresh powder. The New York Public Library and Bryant Park, right, were a poetic fantasy. In Gramercy Park, left, the Victorian treasures were dressed in wintry splendor. The carriage houses suggested a Currier and Ives illustration. The fashion picture in and around the park seemed unchanged by time. ON THE STREET

title: Hamas and Abbas Clash Over Path for Palestinians

title: New Occupant in a Familiar Spot

More recently, a string of other restaurants has tried to make a go of it there. Most were as good as Diwan, some better, but none lasted more than a few years.

description: An article last Sunday about regional accents misidentified the home borough of the television character Archie Bunker, from "All in the Family." He was from Astoria, Queens, not Brooklyn.

Now, coming off a triumphant production of "Hamlet," Geoffrey (PAUL GROSS), the company's mad director, has to find a worthy follow-up. "Macbeth," anyone?

title: Stolen Art?

The world is changing, and you have to play by the rules. It now appears that the piece came to us in a completely improper way -- through machinations, lies, clandestine night digging. As the representative of an honorable institution, I have to say no, this is not right.

description: AFTER more than two years of bickering with a fellow tenant, Lin Senfeng finally got Yang Jinhua to shut up. At lunchtime on an October day, Mr. Lin burst into the lobby of the Sun Bright Hotel in Chinatown, the building where they lived, covered in blood. Some was his own, oozing from his slit palms. The rest was Mr. Yang's, splattered across Mr. Lin's face. "Call the police!" Mr. Lin screamed. "I don't want him to die!"

description: THE opening bid was $1,000. "They will show you how to shoot if you don't know how to shoot," promised Anthony G. Gerrato, the auctioneer, trying to fan the bidding for a seven-course Italian dinner for eight with wine at Tiro a Segno, a private gun and supper club in Greenwich Village where the between-course entertainment is target practice.

title: 'Mouthpiece'
Aruba Renews Emphasis on Tourism
description: Aruba is getting a makeover. After suffering public-relations fallout from the Natalee Holloway disappearance in May 2005, the Caribbean island is now pumping more than $200 million into tourism projects. Most of the investment is in major hotel renovations and openings, below, including a new $20 million tower at the Divi Aruba Phoenix Beach Resort and the addition of 268 new rooms at the RIU Aruba Grand for $40 million. The government is putting about $16 million into a new park with walking and bike paths, intended to beautify the 10-mile stretch of beach from the airport to the hotel zone. And about $34 million is going into expansions of the airport and the cruise ship terminal. IN TRANSIT

title: Handling Hamas
description: While it is true that Hamas's victory in the Palestinian elections might have been prevented, this would not necessarily have been a good thing. The fact is that the Palestinian Arabs were given a free choice in a democratic election and chose to empower a terrorist group that calls for the destruction of the state of Israel. Hamas's electoral victory is saddening. Yet observers can no longer pretend that the Palestinian Arabs want peace. They had a choice and wasted it.

title: Hong Kong: Four Seasons
description: THE BASICS -- Opened in September, the 399-room Four Seasons Hong Kong caps the final phase of development for the city's International Finance Center (IFC), a grand business and shopping complex parked on the Central neighborhood's waterfront. The hotel isn't the company's first foray here --Four Seasons managed the Regent before InterContinental Hotels bought it out in 2001 -- but it is the first major new hotel to open in Hong Kong in 15 years. There are five restaurants and bars, including a busy lobby lounge. The service is almost uniformly excellent, but some of the concierge staff may have been selected on the basis of language skills and appearance rather than local knowledge. (On a recent visit, a request for a good wonton-noodle restaurant resulted in a trip to a tea house with a decided lack of wonton noodles).

ROBERT SPANO leads his Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, the Schola Cantorum de Caracas and the Orquesta la Pasin in two performances. Monday and Tuesday at 8 p.m. (Mr. Golijov discusses the work in a preconcert talk on Monday at 6:45), Rose Theater, Broadway at 60th Street, (212) 721-6500; $30 to $65.

title: The City's Water Connection
description: New York is among the very few American cities enjoying high-quality, largely unfiltered and remarkably inexpensive drinking water, most of it from reservoirs in the Catskill-Delaware watershed west of the Hudson River. Maintaining this happy state of affairs, however, requires constant vigilance to protect the streams feeding the reservoirs from contamination, which in turn means protecting the watershed as a whole from overdevelopment, poor farming practices and a host of other threats to the environment.

Auto racing once appealed primarily to a certain breed of hard-core fan, but it has exploded in popularity in recent years, now drawing viewers with widely varying demographics and levels of commitment. That makes finding the right pitch for the broadcast something of an art form.
