title: A Learning Experience
description: THE anxiety in Manhattan was palpable last week as parents made last-ditch efforts to get their children into the city's top private schools before acceptance letters are sent out in the next few days: strategizing over recommendations, pressuring influential friends to put in a good word, stalking the sidelines as nursery school directors traded their children's future like stock on the Nasdaq.

title: The Shawn Boys Move Beyond Puppet Shows
description: LONG before Wallace Shawn wrote the plays "The Fever" and "The Designated Mourner" or began work on "My Dinner With Andre," or immortalized himself as the comically arrogant kidnapper Vizzini in the movie "The Princess Bride," his chief dramatic experience was staging musical puppet shows in his parents' Upper East Side apartment with his little brother, Allen. The plays had to do with political conventions, princesses, ancient China and, once, a music teacher; and although they usually clocked in at under 60 minutes, a production of "Paradise Lost" lasted four hours. "People ate dinner in the middle of it," Wallace recalled as the brothers sat together recently in a lounge on Theater Row.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NORRIS, JOHN
description: NORRIS--John. Died peacefully at his home in Canada on Saturday, February 11, 2006. John was a construction industry icon, legendary builder, mentor, friend, teacher, athlete, fierce competitor, jokester and renaissance man. No better man to meet and beat any challenge. His skyline signature is in the 80 tall buildings he built around the world and the individual excellence he instilled in each team member and every trademan who made the impossible, possible. His accomplished career was spent largely with Olympia and York and Forest City Ratner. His handiwork includes the World Financial Center, One Canadian Place and all of the MetroTech buildings. In recent years he brought his vast experience to Cauldwell Wingate and relished his role as mentor. He was involved in projects including Rallye Motors, 277 Park Ave and 90 Church Street. He made each of us who had the privilege to work with him better builders who defy obstacles and make time for a fish story. Our thoughts and prayers are with his loving family. A nonsectarian memorial service will be held on Monday, March 20, 2006 at St. Boniface Church, located at 109 Willoughby St., Brooklyn, N.Y. 11201 at 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to John's memory to the Skyscraper Museum, 39 Battery Place, Battery Park City, New York City. His presence was larger than life...his legend is larger than life. Susan L. Hayes

title: New Growth Strategies Will Be Formulated
description: High-tech industries on Long Island are no longer growing as fast as health care, professional, business and social services, and new growth industries must be considered in formulating an Islandwide economic development strategy, an official of the Long Island Association said on Tuesday.

title: The shame of the prisons
Paid Notice: Deaths   TESSER, JEAN
description: TESSER--Jean. Our Woman of Valor. Beloved of the late Charles. Mother of Howard (Linda), Aaron (Adrienne), Don (Joan), Ronnie (Mac). Grandmother of nine, greatgrandmother of 13. She leaves an incredible legacy of love, strength and understanding for those of all ages who were fortunate to be touched by her presence.

title: 'A Plea for Eros'
description: My father once asked me if I knew where yonder was. I said I thought yonder was another word for there. He smiled and said, "No, yonder is between here and there." This little story has stayed with me for years as an example of linguistic magic: It identified a new space-a middle region that was neither here nor there-a place that simply didn't exist for me until it was given a name. During my father's brief explanation of the meaning of yonder, and every time I've thought of it since, a landscape appears in my mind: I am standing at the crest of a small hill looking down into an open valley where there is a single tree, and beyond it lies the horizon defined by a series of low mountains or hills. This dull but serviceable image returns when I think of yonder, one of those wonderful words I later discovered linguists call "shifters"-words distinct from others because they are animated by the speaker and move accordingly. In linguistic terms this means that you can never really find yourself yonder. Once you arrive at yonder tree, it becomes here and recedes forever into that imaginary horizon. Words that wobble attract me. The fact that here and there slide and slip depending on where I am is somehow poignant, revealing both the tenuous relation between words and things and the miraculous flexibility of language.

title: Deer Presence Remains A Problem on Merritt
description: After a deer crashed through the front windshield of a vehicle driven by Marian Patouhas, 61, on the Merritt Parkway in Greenwich last weekend, killing her after she lost control of the car, the State Police said deer continued to pose a significant risk on highways.

title: Lottery Numbers
'A Little White Death': Affairs of State
description: JOHN LAWTON is so captivating a storyteller that I'd happily hear him out on any subject, including pig farming. In fact, he does display an English gentleman's command of "pigmanship" in A LITTLE WHITE DEATH (Atlantic Monthly, $23) when the hero of his series, Scotland Yard's commander of criminal investigation, Frederick Troy, is called away from his family's estate (with its Gloucester Old Spot sow) to answer a distress call from Charlie Leigh-Hunt, an old friend who has fled to the Middle East after being run out of England as a Soviet spy.

title: Advertising, Old and New
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Ritual Circumcision Religious Expression?
description: The issue of metzitzah b'peh, or oral suction, should not be problematic in terms of religious freedom, especially in light of the publicity given to the principle of stare decisis in the recent Supreme Court nomination hearings (Jeffrey Rosen, Feb. 5). The first Supreme Court case in history dealing with the "free exercise" of religion clause in the Constitution was Reynolds v. United States, in 1878. In this case, which has served as an enduring precedent for 128 years, the court made a distinction between belief and behavior. A citizen can believe anything he or she wants, but behaviors physically harmful to oneself or another are prohibited. Such actions, the court found, are "in violation of social duties or subversive of good order."

title: 'Last Dance'
description: THERE WAS A TIME, a few years back, when it was very difficult for me to go to the Final Four when my team didn't make it there. Part of it, no doubt, was the disappointment I felt because we weren't still playing. I'm probably spoiled because we've made the Final Four on ten occasions since 1986, although I can honestly tell you that I have never taken getting there for granted. Each trip is special.

title: Crowds Drop Off, So Tussauds Will Close Its London Planetarium
description: London tourists have no problem paying to see the stars, but they apparently prefer wax celebrities over the celestial kind. The Tussauds Group, which runs London's famous wax museum, Madame Tussauds, right, and other attractions, plans to close its planetarium, which is more than 40 years old, in July because of dwindling interest. Even though entry is included in the admission to the wax museum next door, only 3 in 10 visitors go to the Planetarium, according to a company statement. Instead of an astronomy show, the building's new focus will be "fame and popular celebrity culture" the statement said. For astronomy buffs, a new planetarium is scheduled to open at the Royal Observatory in Greenwich, but not until 2007.

title: After Neoconservatism
description: As we approach the third anniversary of the onset of the Iraq war, it seems very unlikely that history will judge either the intervention itself or the ideas animating it kindly. By invading Iraq, the Bush administration created a self-fulfilling prophecy: Iraq has now replaced Afghanistan as a magnet, a training ground and an operational base for jihadist terrorists, with plenty of American targets to shoot at. The United States still has a chance of creating a Shiite-dominated democratic Iraq, but the new government will be very weak for years to come; the resulting power vacuum will invite outside influence from all of Iraq's neighbors, including Iran. There are clear benefits to the Iraqi people from the removal of Saddam Hussein's dictatorship, and perhaps some positive spillover effects in Lebanon and Syria. But it is very hard to see how these developments in themselves justify the blood and treasure that the United States has spent on the project to this point.

title: Israel freezes funds owed Palestinians
In Houston, the Way the Cookie Crumbles
description: HOUSTON - Fame and fortune are in your stars, predicted a fortune cookie that seemed especially apt at Yao Restaurant and Bar in Houston during All-Star weekend.

title: Any Color You Like, As Long as It's Black
description: CAMDEN - IT is time for the writer's workshop in Emily Vosseller's first-grade classroom. Sixteen students clad in blue slacks or blue skirts with crisp white shirts or the school's royal blue T-shirts sit quietly at their tables writing in their journals and taking turns getting advice from the teacher.

title: Home and Away
description: The idea of going along with my husband to the track was like a slice of heaven to me. He's a horse vet, and the racing season in Del Mar, Calif., was in full swing. My mother was visiting and could take care of our three small children. I wouldn't have to do the scolding or the soothing or the encouraging or the mediating. I wouldn't even have to speak at all if I didn't want to.

The NEW YORK DOLLS, who trashed up early-1970's glam-rock so much it anticipated punk, have been reconstituted by the surviving members, DAVID JOHANSEN and SYLVAIN SYLVAIN. They headline an all-night D.J. dance party. Sunday, 10 p.m., with the Dolls at 11:30 p.m.; Avalon, 47 West 20th Street, Flatiron district, (212) 807-7780; $30.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 - One of the perquisites of being president is the ability to have the author of a book you enjoyed pop into the White House for a chat.

title: Handling Hamas
description: Deborah Solomon's interview (Feb. 5) with Dennis Ross was very telling, both in its questions and the answers. Solomon asks, "Do you think the U.S. is at all responsible for the ascent of Hamas?" Simple answer: the Palestinians themselves are responsible for electing Hamas, no more, no less. Putting responsibility in the hands of anyone else is not only demeaning to the Palestinians, it also avoids having them take responsibility for their actions and the consequences of those actions. No one has forced them to do so up to now, and thus they have had no incentive to try to work out their problems.

title: Italian Quits Over Cartoons; 15 Die in Nigeria
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 18 - A day after at least 11 people were killed in Libya amid continuing violence over the Danish cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad, an Italian government minister resigned Saturday for wearing a T-shirt printed with the cartoons.

title: State Should Pay More, Not Less, for Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: The Man on the Bench
description: OUR neighbor Sam died two weeks ago. He lived on 82nd, 83rd and 84th Streets, between Riverside Drive and Broadway, and died under a corner scaffold sometime late on the night of Thursday, Feb. 2, or early the next day. A week later, at 10 on a Saturday morning, some 80 or 90 of us gathered at the bench beside Riverside Park where Sam was most often to be seen, to share stories and pool information about him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CORTESE, ARMAND, M.D.
description: CORTESE -- Armand, M.D. The Department of Surgery deeply mourns the loss of our distinguished colleague, Dr. Armand Cortese, Clinical Associate Professor Emeritus of Surgery. His internationally renowned professional career as a thoracic and general surgeon at New York Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center spanned over 50 years. Earning his medical degree from Cornell University Medical College in 1958, he completed his residency at The New York Hospital in 1966, and joined the attending staff in 1967. Over the years, he played a vital role and made significant contributions as a surgeon, teacher and mentor and he will be sorely missed. We express our profound sympathy to his wife Patricia, his children Amanda and Kevin, his brother Edward and sister Mimi, his many devoted patients and all who loved him. Fabrizio Michelassi, MD Prof & Chair, Dept of Surgery Weill Medical College of Cornell University Surgeon-in-Chief NY Presbyterian HospitalWeill Cornell Medical Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TSCHACBASOV, IRENE ZE VON
description: TSCHACBASOV -- Irene Ze von. Artist, muse, entrepreneur and philanthropist, died peacefully in her sleep Saturday, February 18. Beloved mother of Leonard Barton, devoted wife of the late Nahum Tschacbasov, sister of Fred Zivitofsky, and the late Martin Zivotovosky, sister-inlaw of Anne and Beverly, loving aunt and great-aunt, grandmother of Cookie Cohen and Robin Murphy, dear friend of Minnie Itkowitz and her gracious family. Irene leaves a legacy of good humor, style, extraordinary beauty, charm, tenderness and joy of life. She will be missed by family, friends and a host of neighbors at the Hotel Chelsea, her home for the past 50 years. Funeral services will take place Wednesday, February 22, 11:30 am, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave (at 91 St). The family requests that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to Lighthouse International.

description: BERS--Mary. 91, cherished wife of the late Lipman Bers, died peacefully. A compassionate teacher, staunch liberal and enduring source of strength for her family. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Dies After Traffic Stop
description: A man driving a 1991 Lexus collapsed and later died after police officers pulled him over for a traffic violation on Saturday afternoon in East Harlem, the police said yesterday. Officers pulled over the driver about 4:34 p.m. for a traffic infraction at East 106th Street and Third Avenue, the police said. The driver, whom the police identified as Andres Otero, 49, of Brooklyn, was taken into custody for driving with a suspended license, and he complained that he was having difficulty breathing. He was taken to Mount Sinai Hospital, where he died at 6:11 p.m., the police said. The medical examiner determined that Mr. Otero had died of a heart ailment, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOBREN, ABRAHAM, M.S. D.D.S.
description: KOBREN -- Abraham, M.S. D.D.S. Age 88, on February 16, 2006. Beloved husband of 63 years to Ruth Spevack Kobren, loving father of Susan and Murray Morrison of Fairfield, CT, Leonard and Barbara Kobren of Briarcliff Manor, NY, Roberta and Mark Simon of Scarsdale, NY, and devoted grandfather of Jennifer and Jordan Kanfer, Sarah and Aaron Kleinhandler, Adam and Benjamin Kobren, and Lauren Simon, adored great-grandfather of Noah and Rebecca Kanfer, and beloved brother of Anne Berman. He was a retired dentist of 36 years in White Plains, NY, past President and Trustee of the American Dental Association, Assistant Dean for Admissions, New York University College of Dentistry, and received an honorary Doctor of Science degree from Georgetown University. Dr. Kobren spent his adult life dedicated to dentistry. He was a noted lecturer, writer, innovator and respected mentor to his students and colleagues. He died after an extended battle with Alzheimer's disease. He was predeceased by a son, Robert Martin Kobren. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association. Services Sunday, 10:30 am, from Abraham L. Green and Son, 88 Beach Road, Fairfield, CT, with interment at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla. Shiva Sunday, Monday and Tuesday, with minyan at 7:30 pm, 3200 Park Avenue, Bridgeport, CT.

title: Company Town Relies on G.M. Long After Plants Have Closed

The ant is controlled by the worm, which, equally unconscious of purpose, maneuvers the ant into place.

title: Curt Gowdy, Versatile Sportscaster, Dies at 86
description: Curt Gowdy, the Wyoming-bred outdoorsman whose voice defined big-game network television sportscasting during the 1960's and '70's, died today. He was 86. Mr. Gowdy died at his home in Palm Beach, Fla., after a long battle with leukemia, said a spokesman for Mr. Gowdy's son, Curt Jr., the executive producer of SportsNet New York.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Two Buildings Damaged In Separate Fires
description: Firefighters endured frigid temperatures and wind while extinguishing separate fires that damaged two apartment buildings in Brooklyn late Saturday and early yesterday, the Fire Department said. The first fire, at a six-story brick apartment building at 1710 Carroll Street near Utica Avenue, was reported about 9:30 p.m. Saturday. Four firefighters and one resident were treated for minor injuries and the fire was declared under control at 10:51 p.m., said Firefighter Brian Conlon, a department spokesman. The second fire, in a four-story apartment building at 1440 Pacific Street, was reported at 4:41 a.m. yesterday. Firefighters rescued about 20 residents from the fire, Firefighter Conlon said, adding that seven firefighters and two residents suffered minor injuries. No cause was established in either fire, he said.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 - I.B.M. researchers plan to describe an advance in chip-making on Monday that could pave the way for new generations of superchips. The development, which comes from materials research in the design of advanced lenses and related technologies, will make it possible to create semiconductors with wires thinner than 30 nanometers, one-third the width in today's industry-standard chips.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OHLSSON, ALVAR
description: OHLSSON--Alvar. Died February 17, 2006, of melanoma. Born in Jonkoping, Sweden, he became a US citizen and worked at Electrolux as manager until retirement. He also worked briefly with AGA Industries of Sweden, then headed up CAG ONE Skate Sharpeners. Avid tennis player, proud of partnering the former King of Sweden. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Urged To Add Medicare Help To 311
description: The Manhattan borough president, Scott M. Stringer, called on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday to expand the 311 information line to help pharmacists and older residents navigate the Medicare prescription drug benefit that took effect on Jan. 1. About 600,000 state residents have been enrolled in the program, and it is estimated that half live in New York City. Mr. Stringer said 311 should help older residents appeal denials of drug requests and inform them about subsidies to pay out-of-pocket costs. Several social service groups, including the Community Service Society of New York and the Medicare Rights Center, support the proposal. Stu Loeser, a spokesman for the mayor, said 311 callers are referred to a federal hot line, 1-800-MEDICARE (1-800-633-4227), and to 40 walk-in centers run by the city's Department for the Aging. Since November, those centers have counseled 16,500 residents on the new benefit and given presentations to 7,000 others. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

Groups work on projects like robots with hands that can sense what they are touching, computers that can respond to human emotion and communal cars that stack together like shopping carts to save urban space.

title: William Blake and 'The Grave'
description: In 1805, William Blake, the poet and artist, was hired to engrave a series of 20 of his own watercolor illustrations for Robert Blair's poem "The Grave." This was an important opportunity for Blake. "What is Good must Succeed first or last," he wrote to a friend. Blake has indeed succeeded -- he looms large in our understanding of the artist's imagination -- but the commission for "The Grave" was doomed. The publisher hired another engraver in Blake's place. The original watercolors more or less vanished until 2001, when 19 were discovered as a group in a Glasgow bookshop. A tangled tale ensued. And now for the unhappy final chapter. They are to be broken up and sold at auction at Sotheby's.

title: Ligety to Take a Shot at His Second Medal
description: SESTRIERE, Italy, Feb. 19 - After several disappointing days for the United States ski team, the spotlight could return to the lone bright spot so far: Ted Ligety, who won the gold medal in the men's combined last week. Ligety will be going for a second Olympic medal, in the giant slalom, the featured men's Alpine event Monday.

At his death, he was Clinical Associate Professor Emeritus of Surgery at New York Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center. Family was the focus of his life. His honest, gentle and inquisitive nature was an inspiration to those who knew him. He is survived by his wife Patricia and children, Amanda and Kevin. His memorial service will be held at the Grace Church, Millbrook, NY, at 11 am, Saturday, February 25. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOERNER, NAOMI
description: KOERNER--Naomi. Of Scarsdale, NY. Died peacefully in her sleep on February 19, 2006. She was 77 years old. Born June 26, 1928, to Harry and Ceal Blumberg. She was the beloved mother of Alissa and Joshua, and a devoted grandmother to Hannah. She is also survived by her brother Lee Blumberg. She was predeceased by her husband Howard. A graduate of Hunter College, Naomi was a talented and dedicated educator, who taught for over 20 years at Greenvale School in Eastchester, touching and enriching the lives of hundreds upon hundreds of Eastchester residents. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St, in Mount Vernon, on Tuesday, February 21, at 10 am. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Eastchester Volunteer Ambulance Corps, 914-337-3051.

Native of Brooklyn; proud patriot and Socony Mobil worker in WW II. Funeral on Tuesday, February 21st, 10 AM, St. Charles Borromeo RC Church, Brooklyn Heights, where she worked in the rectory for the past five years. Calling hours Monday, February 20th, Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Ave. at 81st St. Manhattan, 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Scores Trapped After Blast at Mexican Mine
description: SALTILLO, Mexico, Feb. 19 - Scores of coal miners were trapped deep underground early on Sunday morning when a gas explosion caused an avalanche of rock that sealed off a mine shaft in the border state of Coahuila, state authorities said.

title: Go With Your Gut
description: Madison, Wis. - LAST week's reports that low-fat diets may not reduce the risk of heart disease and cancer have left Americans more confused than ever about what to eat. I'd like to make a radical suggestion: instead of wringing our hands over fat grams and calories, let's resolve to enjoy whatever food we eat.

title: There's No Place Like Home. Who Knew?
description: Why didn't "Wife Swap" come along sooner? It's such a simple idea: two married women with children change places for 10 days. You can have princesses swap with paupers, carnivores with vegans, obsessives with slobs. The twisted interior logic of a family is forced into public transparency, a full-on (if rigged) audit -- and that's fantasy for anyone who's ever thought her family was uniquely bonkers. The series is cheap to make, and rewarding: the families either decide they like the new woman better (which is intriguing but rare), or they want the old wife back, and there's a tearful reunion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEILIN, FRANK
description: BEILIN--Frank. Friday, February 17, at age 85, after a long illness. He grew up in NYC, was the caring brother of Irwin, and leaves many loving friends who will miss his enthusiasm and generosity. After a theater career, he headed Saks Fifth Avenue's direct mail operation, then becoming advertising manager. Ultimately, as a well known photographer's representative, he worked closely with the Estee Lauder Company, until his retirement. Burial will be February 24, at Green River Cemetery, Springs - Easthampton, LI. Memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: A Homeowner, and a Taste of Bureaucracy

There in her mailbox was a notice from the Buildings Department, informing her that someone had made a complaint about her home. An inspector had stopped by and, finding no one home, left instructions that she call and set up a new inspection date.

He grew up in Georgia and lived 45 minutes from Turner Field in Atlanta last summer.

description: A 40-year-old man was fatally shot yesterday evening in front of a Parkchester apartment building, the police said. The man, described as a California resident, was shot once in the back at 7:50 p.m. outside of 1891 Gleason Avenue, the police said. He was pronounced dead at Jacobi Medical Center, the authorities said. The cause of the shooting was unclear, the police said, and as of early this morning, there had been no arrests. The victim's identity was being withheld pending notification of his family. FERNANDA SANTOS (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MORSE, ANNE MENDELSOHN
description: MORSE--Anne Mendelsohn, 93. In memory of our dear mother, who passed away a year ago, on February 20, 2005. A long-time Brooklyn resident, she and husband Julius (1999) are missed by their many friends, neighbors, and fellow folk-dancing enthusiasts. Anne was a self-taught artist, a voracious reader, and a kind and supportive parent. She loved music, art, and especially dance. She enjoyed word games, travel, and the society of like-minded friends. She is survived by her sister Miriam Begg Maddux, son Robert, daughter Linda Heller, and grandchildren Clifford, Victoria, Russell and Brandice Heller, and Nicola & Murray Pearson. We are all grateful for the many years we were able to share with her

Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, FANNIE
description: COHEN--Fannie. A woman of valor. Devoted wife of the late Samuel Cohen. Beloved mother of Hanna and Julian, grandmother of Jeremy, Ava, Ali, and Julia, greatgrandmother of Sam and Billy. Loving mother-in-law of Pat and Jeffrey, grandmother-in-law of Kirsten, Bogart, Peter, and Darren. Born in Vishnevetz, Ukraine, in 1907, she made a new life in New York, the city she loved and never left. Family was everything to her, but she had countless friends and made them family too. Her proud spirit, wicked humor, and enormous curiosity about the world will live on in all who knew her. Funeral services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Tuesday, at 11 am. No flowers, please: donations to American Jewish World Service gratefully received. Always in our hearts, wherever she may be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRONGIN, ESTELLE
description: STRONGIN--Estelle. 94 years old, died peacefully of heart failure, at her home on February 19, 2006. The widow of Dr. Harry Strongin, Estelle was the beloved over protective and hands-on mother of Anne Navasky and Landey Strongin, and very beloved and endlessly worried grandmother of Bruno, Miri and Jenny Navasky. One of the first woman brokers on Wall Street, Estelle was working and vitally engaged as a Senior Vice-President at Smith Barney until the day she died. Her life will be celebrated by her family and friends at the home of Anne and Victor Navasky. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to breast cancer research.

description: The Metropolitan Museum Artists in Concert is a mouthful of a name for a group of young musicians who have struck a deal with the museum and created a chamber music series. There were five of them on Friday night, and they are good enough to deserve a bigger audience -- in the flesh, that is. This program of Dvorak, Schnittke, Kancheli and Schumann was also being broadcast live (by WQXR) and, for all I know, being recorded for distribution on public radio. At any rate, a lot more people will have heard it than those gathered in a half-filled Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium.

title: Bridge; Deciding to Keep It Simple, And Winning a Pro-Am Title

Ninety-six amateurs, each with fewer than 50 master points, were paired with a life master. The winners were Leo Soanes of Corona, Queens, and Robert Stayman of New Rochelle, N.Y. They finished half a match point ahead of Katherine Kolbert and Andrew Rosenthal of New York. In the final round, Soanes and Stayman scored 15.5 out of 18 match points, aided by the diagramed deal, their last board.

title: Met's Fears on Looted Antiquities Are Not New
description: When the Metropolitan Museum of Art announced early this month that it was pursuing a landmark deal to return to Italy a set of Hellenistic silver, a prized sixth-century B.C. Greek pottery vase and four other vessels in exchange for loans of Italian artwork, its reasons seemed clear: Philippe de Montebello, the museum's director, said that new information provided by the Italian government had convinced him it was "highly probable" the objects were looted from Italian soil.

title: Keeping score: The year-end film awards
Accusation From Nazi Era: Journalists Failed the Jews
description: Several prominent journalists have signed a petition asking the Newspaper Association of America to acknowledge publicly that its predecessor organization in the 1930's "was wrong to turn its back on Jewish refugee journalists fleeing Hitler."

title: Arts, Briefly; Mixed Victory for Olympics
description: Though the Winter Olympics continue to draw low ratings compared with previous years, the games gave NBC a victory in Nielsen's estimates on Friday. It wasn't a sweep, though: ABC's "Dancing With the Stars" won at 8 p.m., with 15.66 million watching Lisa Rinna get the boot in a voting upset that left the lumbering Jerry Rice in the competition, while 14.74 million watched the Olympics that hour. The games picked up steam over the course of the night, and NBC ended up drawing an average of 18.23 million viewers in prime time, as well as finishing first among adults 18 to 49. The most-watched program on advertiser-supported cable for the week ending Feb. 12 was a late-afternoon Nascar broadcast on TNT, the Budweiser Shootout (6.15 million on Feb. 12). In prime time, USA Network was No. 1 among cable channels that week, helped by "WWE Monday Night Raw" and various "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" reruns. Last week, USA's telecasts of the Westminster Dog Show attracted 2.77 million viewers on Monday and 2.44 million on Tuesday. KATE AURTHUR

title: You've never slept better . . .
Russian Talks With Iran on Nuclear Program Stall
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 20 A A Russian effort to forge a compromise over Iran's nuclear programs stalled today after five hours of negotiations in the Kremlin ended inconclusively. Negotiators for both countries agreed to hold new talks but did not announce when or where they would take place.

title: Stewart Fails to Heed His Own Safety Warning
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 - Tony Stewart warned last week that aggressive bump drafting could kill somebody in the Daytona 500, prompting Nascar's president, Mike Helton, to issue a stern warning about rough driving on Thursday and again before Sunday's race.

title: After genocide, a ray of hope
Facing Pressure, White House Seeks Approval for Spying
description: After two months of insisting that President Bush did not need court approval to authorize the wiretapping of calls between the United States and suspected terrorists abroad, the administration is trying to resist pressure for judicial review while pushing for retroactive Congressional approval of the program.

title: Nielsen Will Start to Measure TV Habits of College Students
description: Nielsen Media Research announced last week that it would include college students living away from home in its television ratings beginning in early 2007, a move that could bolster ratings on networks like Fox, MTV and the WB, which cater to younger viewers.

title: A Snapshot of the Market
description: ZipRealty, the discount real estate brokerge, keeps adding more useful features to its Web site. For instance, it does a snapshot of about two dozen real estate markets, including smaller ones like Walnut Creek, Calif., or Plano, Texas. That is useful because the sales information in those smaller markets are not blurred by data from nearby big cities.

title: Vermont and D.C. at the Top
description: As you work on your taxes, or hand them off to the accountant, consider this map at Bankrate.com of state income tax rates. Vermont and Washington, D.C., lead the pack with a top rate of 9.5 percent on top of the federal levy. California follows in third place with a 9 percent rate.

title: Celebrity House Hunters
description: Ive got Liza with a Z, Tom Ford and Angela Lansbury this week.

title: Which Is It? Up or Down?
description: The San Francisco Chronicle ran an article Sunday asking whether home prices are going up or down. It never answered the question. But it did present a wonderful chart showing the history of prices in the region.

title: Hot Property: The Lost Island
description: Where is that island in the hit ABC drama Lost?

title: Alis Missed Opportunity
description: I spoke to an audience of Washington University alumni last December at the new Muhammad Ali Center in Louisville, one of the most impressive monuments ever built to the memory of an athlete, living or dead. It would have been hard to imagine in the 1960s that Louisville would ever do such a thing for Ali. But as time has passed, Louisville must have come to the realization that, at least as a tourist attraction, Ali is their most famous and highly regarded native. And I suppose that many have come to love him there, as elsewhere, or at least to not hate him. He is a Muslim to boot, and we need to be nice to Islam these days in our war for hearts and minds in the Middle East.

title: New technology for nuclear reactor
Ice Dancers End 30-Year Medal Drought for U.S.
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 20 - In ice dancing terms, it is called a twizzle. Away from the rink, it is called a turn on one foot while gliding across the ice. Either way, messing one up Monday was the reason Tanith Belbin left the rink with a look of worry.

title: Hamas at the helm
Talks on Enriching Nuclear Fuel for Iran in Russia Seem to Stall
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 20 - A Russian effort to forge a compromise over Iran's nuclear program stalled Monday after five hours of talks in the Kremlin ended inconclusively. Negotiators for both countries agreed to hold new talks but did not announce when or where.

title: TALENT YES, BUT ALSO TENSION
description: The United States is sending an all-star team to the 1,500-meter speedskating race Tuesday with Joey Cheek, the gold medalist at 500 meters, Shani Davis, who won gold in the 1,000 meters, and Chad Hedrick, the winner of the gold at 5,000 meters. Add to those three Derek Parra, the gold medalist at 1,500 meters four year ago in Salt Lake. But beyond the foursome's success is tension, or perhaps lingering irritation between Hedrick and Davis, the first black athlete to win an individual Olympic gold medal in the Winter Games. After finishing seventh in the 5,000 meters on the first day of competition here, Davis said he would not race in the team pursuit so he could save his energy for the 1,000 meters.

title: Pataki Stays in Hospital 5th Day as Intestinal Problems Persist
description: Gov. George E. Pataki was being fed intravenously yesterday, his fifth day in a Westchester County hospital where he had surgery to remove a perforated appendix last week. A doctor at the hospital said the governor would almost certainly remain in the hospital today.

description: ALLEN--Rose, 88. On February 19, 2006. Beloved wife of the late David. Loving mother of Joseph and his wife Annette. Cherished grandmother of Jade and London. Funeral services Thursday, 9:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Interment to follow at Mt. Zion Cemetery.

title: Few Biologists but Many Evangelicals Sign Anti-Evolution Petition
description: In the recent skirmishes over evolution, advocates who have pushed to dilute its teaching have regularly pointed to a petition signed by 514 scientists and engineers.

title: A Most Familiar Tale, Told in a New Mix of Sounds
description: The composer Osvaldo Golijov fervently believes that a "new era of integration in music is beginning," as he writes in the program note to the festival of his works that Lincoln Center has been presenting. He sees an overdue dialog taking place between the past and the present, the popular and the serious, and, most important, between disparate international cultures. He has been an admirable instigator of that dialog.

title: Arts, Briefly; A Tug-of-War in NBC's Olympics Ratings
description: Though NBC has had consistent ratings for its Olympics broadcasts, those numbers have been consistently mediocre. When competing with ABC's Sunday powerhouses, the games once again fell short, and the two networks split a ratings victory for the night: NBC managed to draw the most viewers over all, but ABC easily took the all-important 18-to-49 demographic. According to Nielsen's estimates, the Olympics broadcast was No. 1 from 7 to 9 p.m. among both total viewers and adults 18 to 49, but then "Desperate Housewives" began on ABC, and the night became a downhill slope for NBC. "Housewives" not only dominated the hour in the 18-to-49 group but also brought in 23.34 million viewers over all, as opposed to NBC's 21.84 million. And when "Grey's Anatomy" took over on ABC at 10, that hospital soap opera became the night's most-watched program, with 24.35 million viewers (versus 18.58 million for the Olympics). For the second week in a row, "Grey's Anatomy," which ended with the indifferent but love-starved Meredith (Ellen Pompeo, above) getting together with her smitten roommate George (T. R. Knight), was more popular than "Housewives." KATE AURTHUR

title: Pleasantly Stunned, a Star Children's Author Hits the Tour Trail Again
description: ST. PAUL, Feb. 15 - The Valentine's Day "premiere" of Kate DiCamillo's latest children's book kicked off at the 1,100-seat Fitzgerald Theater here at 7 p.m., with Miss DiCamillo taking the stage before a packed house. The audience listened spellbound as the diminutive author with curly brown hair stood at the lectern and read the first six chapters of the new book, "The Miraculous Journey of Edward Tulane," the tale of a self-centered china rabbit who, through a series of heartbreaking experiences, learns to love.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 30 about the death of an Indonesian man whose body was found at the Indonesian Consulate in New York referred incorrectly to the original owner of an 1892 town house that is a back-to-back twin of the consulate. He was Charles L. Colby, not Charles S. And he was on the board of Colby College in Waterville, Me.; he did not endow it. The college's benefactor was Gardner Colby, his father.

title: States Curbing Right to Seize Private Homes
description: In a rare display of unanimity that cuts across partisan and geographic lines, lawmakers in virtually every statehouse across the country are advancing bills and constitutional amendments to limit use of the government's power of eminent domain to seize private property for economic development purposes.

Sarah Hughes was on more minds. Her father, John, was quoted more often.

description: Oil Prices Surge as Attacks in Nigeria Shut Down One-Fifth of Its Production Oil prices rose 2.6 percent after a series of militant attacks in the Niger Delta shut down nearly a fifth of Nigeria's oil production. Brent crude oil for April delivery jumped $1.57 a barrel, to $61.46, on London's ICE Futures exchange. Trading in the United States was closed because of Washington's Birthday. [Page C1.]

title: Alternatives: Evidence Is Slight for Melatonin as Sleeping Aid
description: Although melatonin is widely used as a sleep aid, a review of the research says there is little evidence that it works, either for jet lag, shift work or sleep difficulty caused by other medical or psychiatric problems.

Yesterday, the club announced it had donated $240,000 of that money to four high-performance distance running camps.

title: Arts, Briefly; The Dogs of 'Eight Below' Take the Weekend Box Office
description: "Eight Below" (Buena Vista), an Antarctic survival picture starring Paul Walker and Jason Biggs -- and a team of abandoned sled dogs that are the ones doing the surviving -- was the top film over Presidents' Day weekend, with an estimated $25 million in ticket sales from Friday through Monday. The film was inspired by a Japanese expedition in 1957 in which a severe storm forced the men to leave their dogs for six months, and all but two of the animals perished. (The film, which follows the dogs as they fend for themselves, has a happier ending.) "Date Movie" (Fox), a spoof of romantic comedies like "Hitch" and "Meet the Parents," opened at No. 2 with $22.3 million from Friday through Monday, followed closely by last weekend's top film, "The Pink Panther" (Sony), which took in $21 million for a two-week gross of $46.6 million. "Curious George" (Universal) dropped one spot, to No. 4, with $15.3 million in four-day ticket sales, and the thriller "Final Destination 3" (New Line), also in its second week, rounded out the Top 5 with $12.5 million. CATHERINE BILLEY

title: Embattled President of Harvard to Step Down at End of Semester
description: Lawrence H. Summers resigned yesterday as president of Harvard University after a relatively brief and turbulent tenure of five years, nudged by Harvard's governing corporation and facing a vote of no confidence from the influential Faculty of Arts and Sciences.

Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHOLZ, LAWRENCE C. (LARRY)
description: SCHOLZ--Lawrence C. (Larry). Died February 17, 2006. Worked at Lockheed Astro Space Center in Princeton. Leaves wife Claire, son Richard, daughter Karen, brother William, and three grandchildren. At home: 11 AM to 4 PM, February 20-24. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to the Sierra Club.

title: Pressure, Not the Jumps, Is What's Hard to Handle
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 20 - Until last year's world championships, Irina Slutskaya of Russia had a reputation for wilting under pressure. Sasha Cohen of the United States became known for following flawless short programs with collapses in the long. And Carolina Kostner of Italy built expectations after finishing third in last year's world championships but now must keep her poise in an arena full of flag-waving, horn-blowing countrymen.

title: How Often Are Patients Misdiagnosed?
description: The only sure way to study the extent of misdiagnosis is to compare autopsy results to a patient's final diagnosis. When researchers have done this, they have generally found a contradiction between the two in about 40 percent of cases. Roughly half of these misdiagnoses prevented the patient from getting treatment that could have made a difference.

title: Web Services Upend Old Ideas About the Little Guy's Role
description: THE old story of technology in business was a trickle-down affair. From telephones to computers, big companies came first. They could afford the latest innovations, and they reaped the benefits of greater efficiency, increased sales and expansion into distant markets. As a technology spread and costs fell, small businesses joined the parade, though from the rear.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about the mysterious deaths of eight whales in Mexico misstated the name of the state where the first signs of their remains were found. It is Sinaloa; CuliacAn is its capital. (Go to Article)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TOMBACK, LESTER ELLIOT
description: TOMBACK--Lester Elliot. Died peacefully of heart failure at the age of 98, one month short of his 99th birthday. He was the beloved husband of the late Mildred Gluck Tomback, father of Elinor Fine and Peter and daughter - in - law Roberta, grandfather to Melissa and Andrew, and great-grandfather to Talia, Jacob, Alexandra, Ariel and Drew. He is also survived by his partner, Harriet Marcus. He was a practicing attorney in New York and active in local civic affairs. Member of several clubs including Metropolis Country Club and Lake Isle Association. A living legend, always in good health. We shall miss his great spirit and zest for life. Funeral services today, 2 PM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COVITT, ELIZABETH (NEE KRANE)
description: COVITT -- Elizabeth (nee Krane). On February 19, 2006 at age 85. Beloved mother of Louise, devoted wife of the late Lee Covitt. Retired math teacher of 20 years at West Hempstead High School. Services today, February 21 at Gutterman's, Inc. (in the Parkside building), 98-60 Queens Blvd (at 66 Avenue), Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TSCHACBASOV, IRENE ZE VON
description: TSCHACBASOV -- Irene Ze von. Artist, muse, entrepreneur and philanthropist, died peacefully in her sleep Saturday, February 18. Beloved mother of Leonard Barton, devoted wife of the late Nahum Tschacbasov, sister of Fred Zivitofsky, and the late Martin Zivotovosky, sister-inlaw of Anne and Beverly, loving aunt and great-aunt, grandmother of Cookie Cohen and Robin Murphy, dear friend of Minnie Itkowitz and her gracious family. Irene leaves a legacy of good humor, style, extraordinary beauty, charm, tenderness and joy of life. She will be missed by family, friends and a host of neighbors at the Hotel Chelsea, her home for the past 50 years. Funeral services will take place Wednesday, February 22, 11:30 am, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave (at 91 St). The family requests that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to Lighthouse International.

title: Met to Sign Accord in Italy to Return Vase and Artifacts
description: ROME, Feb. 20  After three hours of talks, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Culture Ministry here reached an agreement on Monday for the Met to return 20 artifacts in its collection that experts say were illegally excavated from Italian soil, officials on both sides said.

title: City Seeks Wider Power in Child Care
description: Noting a strong correlation between domestic violence and child abuse, the New York City public advocate, with the support of the Bloomberg administration, proposed yesterday that child-welfare officials be given access to a state database of protection orders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, JAMES
description: BROWN--James. 77, of Wyckoff, NJ, died Saturday, February 18. Born April 4, 1928 in Washington Heights, NY. A graduate of Cardinal Hayes High School and Fordham University. Beloved husband to Mary; cherished father of Patricia, James, Carolyn, Denise and Erin and daughterin-law Suzy; adored Granddad of Brendan and Caitlin. Former Owner and Chairman of the American Desk Manufacturing Company. Prior to that he was Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Kidde, Inc. Past President of the Treasurers Club of New York and a member of the Economic Club of New York. Member of the New York Athletic Club and Ridgewood Country Club. Funeral Mass Thursday at 11:00 AM at St. Elizabeths R.C. Church, 700 Wyckoff Avenue, Wyckoff. Visitation at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home 257 Godwin Avenue, Wyckoff, on Tuesday from 7:00-9:00 PM and on Wednesday from 2:00-4:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM. vanderplaatfuneralhome .com

title: Former Star Now in Role of a Father
description: SESTRIERE, Italy, Feb. 20 - Pepi Stiegler was sitting in an empty cafeteria Monday morning, eating croissants and writing postcards. Although many of Austria's old-school skiing greats project an aura of entitlement, Stiegler keeps a low profile.

title: Staging Johnny Cash: 'American myth, and he lived it'
Paid Notice: Deaths   JOGODNIK, RICHARD
description: JOGODNIK--Richard, 70. Died on February 19, 2006. Beloved husband of Victoria. Father to Carrie Cohen, Benjamin Jogodnik and Amy Warshawsky. Father-in-law to Stephen, Jennifer and David. Grandfather of Brandon, Aaron, Leah, Jessica, Lina, Matthew and Kaya. Brother to Larry and his wife Barbara. Uncle to Nicholas and Gregory Jr. and good friend to many. He was predeceased by his first wife Lillian. He took care of all those he loved. He died as he lived, with strength and dignity. Richard dedicated his life to the health and well-being of animals as a veterinarian, owner of Stamen Animal Hospital, New Rochelle, NY, for 40 years. He was an avid fly fisherman, who found a close and loving community with those who shared his passion. He was on the Board of Catskill Fly Fishing Center and Museum in Livingston Manor, NY, a member and past President of the Croton Watershed Chapter of Trout Unlimited, and member of the Angler's Club of NY, the Atlantic Salmon Federation, and the American Museum of Fly Fishing in Manchester, VT. Services today, 12 noon, at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mount Vernon, NY. Donations can be made in Richard's memory to Trout Unlimited, PO Box 298, White Plains, NY 10602, or the New Rochelle Humane Society, 70 Portman Rd., New Rochelle, NY 10801. May his spirit live on a stream forever.

title: Violence in Nigeria Sends Oil Higher
description: Oil prices rose sharply yesterday after a series of attacks in the Niger Delta that shut down nearly a fifth of Nigeria's oil production.

title: The Safety of Aspartame
description: Aspartame, an artificial sweetener used by more than 200 million people around the world, has passed numerous safety evaluations in the past quarter-century. It is used as a tabletop sweetener (Equal, NutraSweet) and as an ingredient in more than 6,000 processed foods, including diet sodas, desserts, candy and yogurt, among others. But now comes a provocative if inconclusive report that says aspartame may cause cancer, even at levels long considered safe. There is no reason for panic, but surely good reason for regulatory authorities to look again at this much-studied sweetener.

title: In the Hidden Heartland, a Claim on the Spotlight
description: OMAHA, Feb. 19 - Doug Elgin was riding shotgun over the gentle plains of Iowa, past the silos and the brown dirt dusted with two-day-old snow. It was late Saturday afternoon, clear and bitter cold, and the Dodge Durango sped across Interstate 80, west toward another basketball game, toward what Elgin, the commissioner of the Missouri Valley Conference, hoped would be one more victory toward validation.

title: Contrasts in Sculpture, in Theme and in Medium
description: Woodcarving, like stone sculpture and film photography, is an endangered species of art. So if only because of its scarcity, it is interesting to see it when it does appear, as in a small exhibition of extraordinarily realistic and symbolically portentous works by Ricky Swallow at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City. The show is notable, too, because three of the five works were included in last summer's Venice Biennale, where Mr. Swallow, who is in his early 30's, represented Australia.

title: Atypical Collectors With Art to Share
description: GHENT, Belgium, Feb. 16 - When Anton and Annick Herbert began collecting art in this medieval Flemish city more than 30 years ago, he was a textile machinery salesman and she worked in the fashion business. Now, as the Barcelona Museum of Contemporary Art devotes two-thirds of its space to showing what they have acquired, the Herberts still hardly fit the conventional profile of collectors.

title: Danger of Philippine Landslides Often Ignored, Critics Say
description: GUINSAUGON, Philippines, Tuesday, Feb. 21 - According to official records, the government of the Philippines knew as early as last May that this village in the eastern part of the country, where more than 1,000 people may have died in a landslide Friday, was in grave danger.

description: Paul G. Allen, one of the founders of Microsoft, is officially seeking a buyer for The Sporting News magazine and its related properties, the company is set to announce today.

title: Driver Blamed for Series of Long Island Crashes, One Fatal
description: A man driving with two young girls strapped in the back seat carved a path of destruction along a busy road on Long Island yesterday, striking at least three vehicles before smashing into another one, killing its driver on the spot, the police said.

title: A Pay Plan to Avoid All Ledgers

title: Other views: Haaretz, The Independent, China Post
World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Chvez Considers End To Presidential Term Limits
description: A day after President Hugo Chvez announced that he might seek a constitutional change so he could govern well into the 21st century, the attorney general, Isaas Rodrguez, played down the comments, asking citizens to consider the president's comments an exaggeration. Mr. Chvez is expected to cruise to victory for another six-year term this year but would be constitutionally barred from running again in 2012. His remarks, made Sunday in his weekly nationwide broadcast, came just days after Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice warned that Venezuela had become a "challenge to democracy" in the region. In his broadcast, Mr. Chvez also responded to her, "Don't mess with me, girl."

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Gillette Brands Sold
description: Henkel, the German maker of Persil detergent and Fa shampoo, has agreed to buy brands including Right Guard and Soft & Dri from Procter & Gamble for about $420 million. The transaction will be completed by March 31, according to an e-mailed statement. Procter & Gamble was required to sell the products as part of an agreement with the Federal Trade Commission after the $57 billion purchase of Gillette last year. The brands had sales of $275 million in 2005. Henkel, based in the western German city of Dusseldorf, has added to its stable of United States brands over the last two years by acquiring the Dial Corporation for $2.9 billion and Clorox Company products like Soft Scrub cleanser and Combat pest control.

Paid Notice: Deaths   BARRETTO, RAY
description: BARRETTO--Ray. It is with deep regret and sadness that the family of the legendary Ray Barretto announces that the acclaimed Conga Maestro died Friday, February 17, 2006. Mr. Barretto died at the Hackensack University Medical Center in Hackensack, NJ at 5 AM EST. His family was at his bedside. A leading force in both the Salsa and Latin Jazz worlds, Ray was one of the most prolific, influential and recorded Latin percussionists in the history of jazz and a pioneer in the world of salsa. His salsa aficionados and fans are represented throughout the world. The man popularly known as "Hard Hands" (Manos Duras) was raised in East Harlem and the Bronx, but was enthralled by the big band sounds of Duke Ellington, Glenn Miller and Tommy Dorsey. During his military tour through Europe, the musical influence of Charlie Parker and Dizzy Gillespie claimed his attention at a GI jazz club. His world and his eventual global impact were never quite the same again. Just this past January, he received a most prestigious award from the National Endowment for the Arts for his legendary contributions to jazz. This is the highest honor that our nation bestows upon jazz musicians in recognition that this magnificent art form, so profoundly based in American culture, is one of America's greatest gifts to the world. Mr. Barretto is survived by his wife, Annette, their son, Chris (age 20), and Raun, Ray and Kelly from a former marriage. A public viewing will be held Wednesday, February 22nd, from 11 AM to 5 PM, 6 PM to 10 PM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Violinist With an Air of Vulnerability

But when Mr. Tetzlaff eased into the autumnal first movement of Brahms's G major Sonata, the hall shrunk by half. Building up from a stage whisper, he spun one long sinuous line after another, perfectly distilling the wistfulness at the heart of this music, its careful blending of honey and rue.

This film exposes the horrifying treatment that some dealers give the animals destined to be sold for that research (some of them stolen pets), and it never averts its eyes. The risk is the possibility that the chemistry can grow stale, or worse. The Auryn Quartet, from Germany, has played together in its current configuration since 1981; judging from its performance on Sunday afternoon at the Frick Collection, the chemistry is working fine.

His research was in the area of family processes among schizophrenics and developmental issues associated with neonatology and prematurity. He is survived by his life partner, Ernest Cusson, and brothers, Frank and Joe.

World Briefing | Americas: Canada: New Justices Will Face Public Hearings
description: Prime Minister Stephen Harper announced a change in the process of selecting members of the Supreme Court, with prospective judges now for the first time being required to face a televised parliamentary hearing before the prime minister makes his final decision to appoint. Mr. Harper will retain the sole power to select Supreme Court judges, but the change is intended to make the process more transparent and give the public an opportunity to hear the opinions of proposed judges. Mr. Harper said he would take the hearings into account before making a final decision on future selections.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Man Falls To Death From Kremlin Roof
description: A man sweeping snow from the roof of a Kremlin building fell to his death over the weekend, the Interfax news agency reported, as the Russian winter continued to claim victims. Clearing accumulated snow from roofs is a common sight in Russia, where workers scramble high above the streets and push it off, hoping to keep the snow from forming ice that endangers pedestrians below. The winter of 2006 has been unusually harsh, even by Moscow's standards, with deep freezes and steady snow.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Thresholds To Be Lowered
description: China plans to relax rules on so-called qualified foreign institutional investors, as part of efforts to widen access to the nation's capital markets. China intends to lower the minimum investment requirements for such investors and shorten the lockup up period on the shares they purchase, Zou Lin, vice director of State Administration of Foreign Exchange, said in a phone interview. Under the current rules of the program, investors with at least $10 billion in assets and $50 million to spend can apply to the securities and foreign exchange regulators for a license to buy yuan shares and bonds, and obtain a quota. Currently they are required to hold onto the stocks for at least a year. The government, as of last week, approved 34 foreign investors to buy a combined $5.745 billion worth of Chinese securities products.

Unfortunately, two camps own the conversation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VOLKMAN, SAMUEL
description: VOLKMAN--Samuel. 97. The family of Rabbi Samuel Volkman sorrowfully announces his death on February 18. His rabbinical leadership endured for over 70 years with brilliance, a profound sense of duty and great dignity. His wife was the late Sally B. Volkman. He is survived by two beloved daughters and a son-in-law, Suzanne & Nancy and Edward Skloot, and cherished grandson Joseph. Funeral services will be February 21 at Danzansky-Goldberg, Rockville, MD at 11 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRONGIN, ESTELLE
description: STRONGIN--Estelle. 94 years old, died peacefully of heart failure, at her home on February 19, 2006. The widow of Dr. Harry Strongin, Estelle was the beloved over protective and hands-on mother of Anne Navasky and Landey Strongin, and very beloved and endlessly worried grandmother of Bruno, Miri and Jenny Navasky. One of the first woman brokers on Wall Street, Estelle was working and vitally engaged as a Senior Vice-President at Smith Barney until the day she died. Her life will be celebrated by her family and friends at the home of Anne and Victor Navasky. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to breast cancer research.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Airbus Wins Large Order
description: Airbus won a $2.2 billion order from Indian Airlines, India's second-largest domestic carrier. The airline is buying 43 A320-series planes in a contract approved by the government in September and signed by the airline's chairman, Vishwapati Trivedi. Airbus is relying on demand from India and China in particular as some airlines in North America refrain from adding planes amid financial pressures. India's passenger traffic may grow an average 25 percent until 2015, the Indian civil aviation minister, Praful Patel, said.

title: My Survey Results Are Fascinating, but Then Ignorance Is Bliss

description: IT is the corporate version of keeping up with the Joneses: every day, it seems, someone arrives at the office with a shiny new gadget that combines a cellphone with all sorts of features you used to find only on your computer. They can get e-mail messages, surf the Web, manage contact lists and calendars, and even create Word and Excel documents that can run on a conventional PC.

The Bagger is willing to acknowledge a power greater than himself, but when it comes to Hollywoods taste in deities, he is pretty sure that the last three digits of the zip code should be 666, not 210.

title: Sound Decisions
description: The other night, the Bagger was having trouble sleeping and he started doing some research on film scores. He was in a coma in no time. Kidding. There is a science and art to this stuff and its all thoroughly explored on NPR.

description: Is there a correlation between getting stuck and getting gold?

title: Achievement Squared
description: Last summer, the Bagger had a chance to sit on a golf cart with Robert Altman talking about film. The Bagger had the common sense to do a lot of listening, but it was a gas to watch Mr. Altman shoot A Prairie Home Companion, with director Paul Thomas Anderson, of all people, hanging in the wings. Terrence Rafferty performs a whopper of a retrospective in a little local daily that shows that Mr. Altman has not lost the vinegar that made him such a tangy delight for decades of filmgoers. Now the Academy, which has always managed to step past Mr. Altmans work briskly, is pausing to acknowledge a lifetime of work. With his son manning the camera at the Fitzgerald Theater in St. Paul to film Garrison Keillors script, Mr. Altman did not mess around. As soon as a shot was set up, he would yell, Lets boogie! and the camera would roll. Mr. Altman, who is hardly hypnotized by the commercial prospects of his films, told the Bagger he thought Prairie Home might find an audience. Garrisons audience is like the Mel Gibson Jesus audience, he said. This movie is going to play for two weeks in places like Chicken Switch, Arizona, because the program has such strong rural appeal. The Bagger has spent a lot of time, metaphorically speaking, in Chicken Switch, and there isnt a lot of competition there for the disposable entertainment dollar. But then there probably isnt a movie theater either.

title: Walk the Line
description: The indictment of Terry Christensen, a respected member of the Los Angeles bar, has folks wondering where the marble will roll next in the Anthony Pellicano case. The turn of events has some wondering whether what looked like a B movie will end up a blockbuster.

title: Juicy Bits
description: How will Jon Stewart feather in his performance at the Oscars? Like Steve Martin, only better, if all goes well. He will stay inside the lines, but dont look for him to give Brokeback a total pass. To not talk about Brokeback Mountain at the Oscars would be like going to the White House correspondents dinner and not talking about the president, Ben Karlin tells Jacques Steinberg. And the veep who couldnt shoot straight will get a turn: Were doing it. Same goes for Herbie: Fully Loaded.

title: Mid-Atlantic Awards
description: The British Academy of Film and Television Arts swooned and swooned hard for Brokeback, loading up its bulging saddlebags with the picture, director and screenplay awards, plus an acting kudo. Jake Gyllenhaal, who through a fluke of marketing and contest machinations has been something of a forgotten man this awards season  the Bagger thinks he should get some kind of recognition for his Santa hat dance in Jarhead  acted genuinely surprised when the supporting actor award came his way. The best supporting award on the distaff side went to Thandie Newtown for her role in Crash  she may have been born in Zambia, but the British claim her as their own. Reese Witherspoon won best actress in a walk, but then, Felicity Huffman was not even up in that category. It will be fascinating to see whether Ms. Witherspoons demure approach to Oscar campaigning  she isnt doing it  will trump Ms. Huffmans willingness to show up just about anywhere there is a podium. The Bagger is not suggesting that there is something craven in Ms. Huffmans approach; it looks less like she wants it than that she is going to enjoy every single minute of her day in the sun. And the Academy could do worse than having a 43-year-old actress at the microphone who counted a good audition as one in which her bicycle was not stolen while she was taking her turn. Awards for screenplay, adapted and original, went to Brokeback and Crash respectively and it would be hard to envision BAFTAs American analogs doing it any differently.

title: Darfur Exports Death
description: A new report from Human Rights Watch underscores how the Janjaweed, backed by Sudanese military forces, are staging regular cross-border raids to attack Chadian villages. The report doesnt say so, but I think this may well be a prelude to a formal invasion of Chad and toppling of its president by a Sudanese proxy force based in Darfur. The H.R.W. report, Darfur Bleeds: Recent Cross-Border Violence in Chad, can be found here.

title: Alert the Others
description: The Bagger was at a party over the weekend of plain old civilians and noticed that they were talking about the Oscars, of all things. Up until now, the Bagger has felt as if he belonged to a small, fetish-driven cult. Sure, those of you in the racket or who live with a virtual attachment to all things Oscar think hes nuts, but guys, out here in the world, a lot of people care as much about the Oscars as the trade deficit. But thats changing. The Bagger listened to an animated discussion between Brokeback Mountain vs. Crash loyalists, and managed, with a tremendous amount of personal effort, to keep his piehole shut: Nothing can bring a nice party chat to a screeching halt more quickly than some dweeby know-it-all who has been sitting in his basement checking Oscar-related bookmarks for two months now. But now that the Academy Awards are just around the corner, normal people who have no idea who won best cinematographer in 1976 are starting to take an interest.

Because of the aftermath of the Iraq war, Fukuyama writes, the Bush Doctrine of pre-emptive warfare in the face of gathering threats is now in shambles.

title: A Sure Thing
description: A friend who dined at Aquavit on Valentines Day had an unhappy surprise. Her check appeared, and the sum was higher than she expected. Looking closely, she noticed that an automatic 20 percent gratuity had been added. And she said she hadnt been informed that this would happen when she made her reservation, nor did her server say anything about the gratuity when he presented the check.

title: No Menschen in Washington
description: Readers respond to Paul Krugmans Feb. 20 column, The Mensch Gap

title: Melanie Ward | Stylist
description: By choosing what feels good, the stylist, editor and muse Melanie Ward has risen to the top like Ronnybrook cream. I am very tactile, she says. I love cashmeres, silks and cottons on my skin. She also likes to turn things around when they dont feel right. For this shoot, she chose to wear a vintage Azzedine Alaa dress backward. I never like to feel that my clothes are wearing me. So understated and effortless is her style that Ward rarely slips on jewelry, and she walks in boots in winter and flip-flops in summer. For spring, shes wearing something new: her title as creative director of the Karl Lagerfeld line.

title: Pasta Puttanesca
description: Mark Bittman shows how to prepare pasta puttanesca.

title: Zillow Gets Broker License
description: Rich Barton, chief executive of Zillow.com, the online property data service, has repeatedly said that the company isnt going to compete against traditional brokers.

title: CocoRosie | Musicians
description: She wears heels, says Bianca Casady (left). I would never wear heels. The she in question is her older sister, Sierra, the girlier half of the band CocoRosie. Sierra rocks out with slinky tops and beaded earrings to counter Biancas XXXL sportcoats and vintage spectators. Theres a dialogue between our outfits, Bianca says. Marrying their styles, inspired for the moment by drag queens, Jean Genet and hip-hop, means frequent trips to the dollar store. This was especially so while touring with Antony and the Johnsons for CocoRosies second album, Noahs Ark. A sneaker fetish keeps Bianca on her feet. Fortunately, even in heels, her operatic sister has no problem keeping up.

title: Joyce Ma | Chief Executive
description: The global style setter and retail magnate Joyce Ma Euro-fied the wardrobes of Hong Kongs fashion-forward by bringing looks from the West to her customers in the East. Yet in truth, according to her exacting eye, all women look best in their national dress. So at home, with closet racks bookended by Prada and McQueen, its no real shock that 18th- and 19th-century Chinese garments lie in between. This woven silk summer gown of noble provenance represents Mas attitude toward the excess found in fashion today. Ive become totally simplistic, she says. Well, perhaps not totally. I do love a good entrance piece, Ma admits.

title: Marina Abramovic | Artist
description: Comme des Garons skirts, Prada shoes and Marc Jacobs dresses may be some of Marina Abramovics favorite topics to gab about, but youd never know it from her penchant for taking off her clothes, as witnessed in a recent show of her video projections at the Sean Kelly Gallery in Chelsea. If you work with an aesthetic, she says, you need to apply this same aesthetic to yourself. Born in Yugoslavia, Abramovic has a 1950s Italian cinema type of body, which she drapes in Galliano here, along with a plastic skeleton to show that she acknowledges and accepts her own death. All my life I try to be normal, but it just doesnt work, she says with a laugh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NORRIS, JOHN F.
description: NORRIS--John F. All of us at Forest City Ratner Companies mourn the passing of our friend and colleague John Norris. John excelled in everything he did-from ensuring the Queen of England's safety as a member of the Royal Horse Guards of the Household Cavalry to overseeing the construction of some of the most recognizable buildings in the U.S., the U.K. and Canada. He joined Forest City Ratner Companies in 1989 as the head of our Construction Department, and led the early construction of the first three buildings at MetroTech Center. He continued as our field construction representative, monitoring all of our projects under construction. Every building at MetroTech benefited from his insight and skill, as did Atlantic Center and Atlantic Terminal, the New York Mercantile Exchange, 330 Jay Street and the Museum of Jewish Heritage. Other notable projects in which John had a hand include First Canadian Place in Toronto and the World Financial Center in New York City. John was an avid outdoorsman with a passion for hunting, fishing and his dogs. But of all his accomplishments, perhaps the one in which John took the most pride was his loving family. We extend our sincere condolences to his beloved wife, Mary; children Andrew and Richard; grandson Michael and many other relatives and friends. His funeral was held at the Flameboro Baptist Church, 41 Fifth Concession in Waterdown, Ontario on February 18. A memorial service is planned for March 20 at 10:30 A.M. at St. Boniface Church, 109 Duffield Street, in the heart of the MetroTech Center that John helped to build. Bruce C. Ratner, President and CEO $(6$)NORRIS--John F. All of us at Forest City Ratner Companies mourn the passing of our friend and colleague John Norris. John excelled in everything he did--from ensuring the Queen of England's safety as a member of the Royal Horse Guards of the Household Cavalry to overseeing the construction of some of the most recognizable buildings in the U.S., the U.K. and Canada. He joined Forest City Ratner Companies in 1989 as the head of our Construction Department, and led the early construction of the first three buildings at MetroTech Center. He continued as our field construction representative, monitoring all of our projects under construction. Every building at MetroTech benefited from his insight and skill, as did Atlantic Center and Atlantic Terminal, the New York Mercantile Exchange, 330 Jay Street and the Museum of Jewish Heritage. Other notable projects in which John had a hand include First Canadian Place in Toronto and the World Financial Center in New York City. John was an avid outdoorsman with a passion for hunting, fishing and his dogs. But of all his accomplishments, perhaps the one in which John took the most pride was his loving family. We extend our sincere condolences to his beloved wife, Mary; children Andrew and Richard; grandson Michael and many other relatives and friends. His funeral was held at the Flameboro Baptist Church, 41 Fifth Concession in Waterdown, Ontario on February 18. A memorial service is planned for March 20 at 10:30 A.M. at St. Boniface Church, 109 Duffield Street, in the heart of the MetroTech Center that John helped to build. Bruce C. Ratner, President and CEO

Visiting 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM Wednesday EdwardsDowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave., Dobbs Ferry (exit 17, Saw Mill). Funeral Service 10AM Thursday Zion Episcopal Church, 55 Cedar Street, Dobbs Ferry. Flowers are welcome or memorials to Phelps Hospice, 701 North Broadway, Sleepy Hollow, NY 10591, or The American Cancer Society.

title: Weld Suffers Two Setbacks to Candidacy in One Day
description: ALBANY, Feb. 21 - William F. Weld, the former governor of Massachusetts, suffered a pair of significant setbacks on Tuesday in his campaign to become the next governor of New York.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Businessman Admits Tax Evasion And Fraud
description: A former business owner from Brooklyn pleaded guilty yesterday to failing to report more than $1.9 million in income he received between 1998 and 2001, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney. The man, Abie Moskowitz, 56, admitted that he did not pay the income tax while he was half-owner of Sea Jet Trucking, a shipping company in Carteret, prosecutors said. The prosecutors said Mr. Moskowitz also admitted to bank fraud and conspiracy to launder money.

title: Who Should Run America's Ports?
description: To the Editor:

title: Other views: Los Angeles Times, The Scotsman, JoongAng Daily
National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Ex-Official Sentenced To 3 Years
description: Carroll Fisher, the former state insurance commissioner who was convicted of failing to report a $1,000 campaign contribution and then converting the money to his personal use, was sentenced to three years in prison and fined $20,000, as was recommended by the jury. Mr. Fisher, 66, left, was impeached by the Oklahoma House in 2004 but resigned rather than face a trial in the Senate. Pending against Mr. Fisher are charges including income tax evasion and bribery. The judge set bond for Mr. Fisher at $50,000 and ordered him to wear a global positioning device. STEVE BARNES (NYT)

title: Testing Service Delays Rollout of Revamped Graduate Exam
description: The Educational Testing Service, the maker of the Graduate Record Exam, is delaying its rollout of a revamped test until the fall of 2007. The revised exam was supposed to go into effect in October.

title: Illness Claims a Firefighter Whose Awakening Made Headlines
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 21 - Donald Herbert had been virtually silent for nearly a decade after suffering a brain injury when a burning roof collapsed on top of him while he was fighting a fire in 1995.

Along with his wife, Charlotte, Irvin was devoted to the State of Israel and to the cause of higher education. description: The star ratings for the Michelin Guide France 2006, the red guide, were announced today with one addition to the list of three-star restaurants, Les Maisons de Bricourt of chef Olivier Roellinger in Cancale in Brittany. It's a restaurant that opened in 1982 and which many observers have long felt deserved elevation to three stars.

title: That's creativity with a capital B: Berlin plumbs its own dynamic depths
A Winning Comment It Wasn't
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 21 - Behind the closed door of the locker room at Torino Esposizioni, Bengt-Ake Gustafsson, coach of the Swedish hockey team, gathered his players Tuesday and delivered his pregame address. He told them to try to beat Slovakia, defenseman Niklas Lidstrom said.

title: A Cult Figure and Her Lore
description: Joanne Beretta could be the salty next-door neighbor who has lived in your Greenwich Village apartment building for decades and mellowed into a garrulous repository of local bohemian lore -- in her case, the area's cabaret life, in which she was once a vital participant. Now, after years of retirement from nightclubs, she has returned to Danny's Skylight Room with the pianist Franklin Underwood in a program that mixes songs, personal anecdotes, outspoken political rants and comedy.

title: Snow Isn't the Only Thing Crunching at New England Ski Resorts
description: SOME skiers slip hand-warmers into their gloves to keep their fingers warm, but at several slopes in New England there is a tastier option: waffles sold at a Waffle Haus, a tiny log cabin next to the lift lines.

description: Why does this page look this way?
