Paid Notice: Memorials   BROADWATER, BOWDEN
description: BROADWATER--Bowden. There will be a memorial program for Bowden Broadwater at 5 PM, Wednesday, February 22 at St. Bernard's School, 4 East 98th St. Contributions may be made in his name to St. Bernard's Scholarship Fund.

title: Beyond Strong Words on Darfur
description: It's good that President Bush is now talking tougher about the need for more robust military action, including increased support from the NATO alliance, to stop the killing in the Darfur region of Sudan. What would be even better would be a United States commitment to provide specialized reconnaissance and air support for the United Nations force being planned for Darfur later this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELLIOT, RICHARD M.
description: ELLIOT--Richard M. of New Rochelle, N.Y., died peacefully on February 20, 2006. His love of life and love of family inspired all who knew him. His beloved wife Beebe, adoring daughters Liz and Vicki and their husbands, Dennis and Nick, and cherished grandchildren Clifford, Julie, Remy and Kyra will love and miss him forever. He was proud to be an Eagle Scout and loved to do the NYT crossword puzzles, which he did in pen! Funeral services will be held at Riverside Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, N.Y. on Friday, February 24, 2006, at 10AM. $(6$)ELLIOT--Richard. Temple Israel of New Rochelle expresses deepest condolences to the family of Richard Elliot. Paul Warhit, President Michael Z. Cahana, Rabbi

New cardinals include China critic
Eli J. Segal, 63, Clinton Aide Who Led Major Initiatives, Dies
description: Eli J. Segal, who was the chief of staff in Gov. Bill Clinton's victorious campaign for president in 1992 and who went on to become an assistant in the Clinton White House, died Monday at his home in Boston. Mr. Segal, who headed the Clinton administration's AmeriCorps and Welfare-to-Work initiatives, was 63.

title: Headgear Offers a Peek at the Man Behind the Mask
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 21 - Anyone looking closely at the United States men's hockey team Tuesday night would have seen Kid Rock smoking a cigarette in goal, right next to Hank Williams Jr. strumming a guitar.

description: ROOM 4 DESSERT makes sense as a next step for Will Goldfarb, not only because he made a name for himself with avant-garde desserts at Cru and the Paul Liebrandt version of Papillon, but also because he's the rare chef who is equally at ease chatting with his diners and making cotton candy in front of them at his dessert bar. A natural host, he talks up anyone within earshot.

title: Roundup: Bangladesh addsSri Lanka's scalp
Cohen Ends a Long Night by Edging Ahead of Slutskaya
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 21 - The stage could not have been any larger or come with any more pent-up anticipation, but Sasha Cohen charged into her Olympic short program with the kind of guts and nerve she had never mustered before. Given the cruel, pressure-packed position of performing last among 29 skaters Tuesday night, Cohen showed she could not only weather the occasion but rise to it.

title: Lamoriello Will Keep Coaching
description: When Lou Lamoriello, the chief executive, president and general manager of the Devils, installed himself as the team's interim coach after Larry Robinson's unexpected resignation on Dec. 19, Lamoriello said it was a temporary move and that he would hire another coach before the end of the season.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: President Says He Would Veto Legislation to Prevent Port Deal President Bush, trying to put down a rapidly escalating rebellion among leaders of his own party, declared that he would veto any legislation that blocks a deal by a government-owned company in Dubai to take over management of port terminals in New York, Miami and other American cities. [Page A1.]

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about bipartisan Congressional support for whistle-blowers misstated the name of the federal agency that employed Russell Tice, who testified that he had been told not to discuss secret programs even in closed sessions with the intelligence committees. He is a former employee of the National Security Agency; there is no "security administration."

description: Correction Appended

title: Red Sox to Let Ramirez Report Late
description: TAMPA, Fla. Feb. 21 - Manny Ramirez will not arrive in spring training with the Boston Red Sox until March 1, one day after Major League Baseball's mandatory reporting date.

title: Iraqi Leader Scolds U.S. on Politics; Car Bomb Kills 21
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 21 - The Iraqi prime minister on Tuesday angrily denounced the growing American pressure to form an inclusive government, as a car bomb in a bustling market here killed at least 21 people and wounded dozens more, most of them women and children.

title: Knicks' Deal for Francis Is More Likely Than Not
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Feb. 21 - The rebuilding effort by Isiah Thomas is as unsightly as promised, probably more so, and there is no telling whether his next bold move, which appears imminent, will make matters better or worse.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 11 P.M. (Bravo) PROJECT JAY -- Winning is nice, but it doesn't always guarantee smooth sailing. Jay McCarroll (above) is the lucky, talented and funny aspiring fashion designer from rural Pennsylvania who beat out the competition in the first season of "Project Runway." Now he has to find an affordable apartment in New York (that would be a nice prize for some reality series to give away), design his first clothing line and market it. Not to mention creating a fabulous dress for Heidi Klum (the host of "Project Runway") to wear to the Emmy Awards telecast. She wants red, but Mr. McCarroll doesn't think that's going to look great next to the red carpet. Ms. Klum has just had a baby, making drastic alterations necessary. And there are other problems. This documentary is preceded by a reunion special starring second-season contestants at 10, and by a "Project Runway" marathon starting at 2 p.m.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Man Sentenced In Firebombing
description: A Baltimore man was sentenced to 80 years in prison for firebombing the house of a community activist who repeatedly reported drug dealing. Federal prosecutors said the man, Terrence Smith, 24, was the leader of a gang that planned the firebombing in January 2005 of the house of Edna McAbier, in an effort to kill her so she could not report drug dealing. Ms. McAbier was not injured in the attack. Two co-defendants have received 60-year prison sentences. GARY GATELY (NYT)

title: 2 Athletes Worried They Broke Law
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 21 - Austrian ski team officials said Tuesday that the two team members who fled after a police raid last weekend had confessed that they possibly "used illegal methods" in preparing for their Olympic events.

title: Square Feet; TRANSACTIONS
description: Recent Sale $37 million 625 Broadway (between Mercer and Houston Streets) Manhattan

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Foes Of Brooklyn Project Plan Appeal
description: Opponents of a Brooklyn real estate project will appeal last week's court ruling allowing the project's developer, Forest City Ratner Companies, to demolish six buildings on the site of the proposed project, and will ask the State Curt of Appeals to block the demolitions until an appeal can be filed. Justice David Friedman of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday declined their request to issue an immediate temporary restraining order against the demolitions, which are likely to begin within a week. But Justice Friedman said he would entertain a request for an injunction against the developer at a hearing scheduled for March 1, in advance of an expected hearing that month by the state's highest court. NICHOLAS CONFESSORE (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STILLMAN, ISRAEL H.
description: STILLMAN--Israel H. In his 93rd year. Adoring husband and soulmate of Leona, married for 66 wonderful years. Loving father of Celine and Pascal and Tom and Kathy. Grandfather of very special granddaughter Isabelle. A man of compassion, generosity and humor. Always true to himself, he lived an enviable life to the very end. We will miss him. Donations to: Jewish Guild for Blind. Memorial service: Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave at 91 St, Thursday February 23 at 12:15PM.

title: Justice Alito's Welcome
description: Talk about starting off with a splash. Yesterday, the Supreme Court took the occasion of Justice Samuel Alito Jr.'s first day on the nine-member bench to announce that it would step in during the next term to resolve the constitutionality of the 2003 federal ban on so-called partial-birth abortion.

title: Concerns Led to Revisions, Rumsfeld Says
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 - Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said on Tuesday that he rescinded the use of controversial interrogation techniques for detainees at Guantnamo Bay in early 2003 because he had learned that Pentagon lawyers thought some of them were illegal and verged on torture.

title: Italy and U.S. Sign Antiquities Accord
description: ROME, Feb. 21 - Announcing a "new page of cooperation," the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Italian government signed a watershed accord on Tuesday under which the Met will return 21 artifacts that Italy says were looted from archaeological sites within its borders.

title: Canadian Medical Group Fires Top Editors of Journal
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 21 - The Canadian Medical Association has dismissed the top two editors of its peer-reviewed journal in a move that some in medical circles said was related to a prolonged dispute over editorial independence.

title: From Hell to High Water
description: PREDICTING that a good number of evacuated residents will never return, a New Orleans mayoral commission recently declared that the city should abandon flood-ravaged neighborhoods, invest only in stable areas on high ground and shift residents to new developments. If a neighborhood isn't "sustainable," the city should raze it.

title: Big Half for Carter, Big Comeback for Nets
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 21 - After the Nets had fallen behind by as many as 16 points here on Tuesday night, Richard Jefferson chided Vince Carter, the team's lone All-Star Game selection, in the visitors' locker room at halftime.

title: Doughnuts, Filled for the Occasion
description: Mardi Gras means Fat Tuesday, which is the final day to binge before the 40-day menu austerity of Lent. It often involves fried foods. The French eat beignets. The Germans, for what they call Fasching, often eat plump jelly doughnuts called krapfen.

title: Hamas in Power: New Questions

title: Wal-Mart Tries to Find Its Customer
description: For all its success in the United States -- and there is plenty of it -- Wal-Mart Stores is still struggling to figure out its home turf, where sales growth at individual stores has sagged, its customers routinely flirt with rivals like Target for clothing and its advertising has often failed to inspire.

title: Skiing: Paerson wins first Olympic gold
Brazil market revives, but Goldman falters
Aerialist's Comeback Falls Short of Medal
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 21 - After making a dramatic comeback to reach these Winter Games, the freestyle skier Emily Cook will once again be watching, but not competing, in the finals of the women's aerials.

Iran Pledges Money to Hamas-Led Palestinian Authority
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 22 A A senior Iranian official pledged today to provide financial support to a Hamas-controlled Palestinian Authority, already in budgetary difficulties and facing further cuts in aid.

title: New York's Top Court Reverses Man's Conviction on Gun Charge
description: More than halfway through a Brooklyn man's 10-year sentence for carrying an illegal pistol, his conviction was overturned yesterday by the New York State Court of Appeals on the ground that the police discovered the weapon during an illegal search.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Feb. 15 illustrating the shotgun shell that Vice President Dick Cheney accidentally fired at a hunting partner, Harry M. Whittington, included an erroneous Texas Parks and Wildlife diagram of Mr. Whittington's wounds. They were on his right side, not his left.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALLERHAND, IRVING
description: ALLERHAND - Irving. The Yeshivah of Flatbush mourns the passing of its Honorary President, Irving Allerhand, A"H. Along with his wife, Ida, A"H, he served as a role model of dedication to family, Jewish education, and community for generations of Yeshivah of Flatbush, students, parents, faculty, and lay leaders. The Yeshivah extends its heartfelt condolences to Mr. Allerhand's familyto his children, Hershel Allerhand, Ruth Burian, Judith Boim, and Joseph Allerhand, to his grandchildren, great grandchildren, and their families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack Rahmey, President Dennis M. Eisenberg, Executive Vice President $(6$)ALLERHAND--Irving. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Irving Allerhand, beloved father of Joseph Allerhand, an esteemed leader whose generosity and service to our Board of Directors, Lawyer's Division, and to the New York Legal Assistance Group makes an indelible impact on the lives of those in need. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Joseph, and his wife, Randi Schatz, and their children, Lauren, Bruce, and David. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: White House says Bush did not know about ports deal
For figure skating gold, a 3-way battle
Arts, Briefly; Olympic Games Light A Night for NBC
description: Though ratings continue to be down in comparison with those for previous games, Monday's Olympics broadcast resulted in one of its better performances so far. In Nielsen's estimates for prime time, NBC was No. 1 among adults 18 to 49 and drew an average of 22.48 million viewers. Its highest-rated time period was at 10 p.m., which featured men's aerial skiing and, more notably, ice dancing and the soap opera antics of the feuding Italian pair Barbara Fusar Poli and Maurizio Margaglio, above, who appeared to broker their reconciliation during their time on the ice. That hour delivered 23.83 million viewers. Elsewhere on the networks, a Monday episode of "House" (14.06 million) and a regularly scheduled "24" (13.7 million) put Fox in second place for the night. CBS, which normally wins Monday nights, continued to get out of the Olympics' way and ran repeats, finishing third among total viewers and fourth (behind ABC) in the 18-to-49 demographic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GEWIRTZ, JULIUS
description: GEWIRTZ - Julius. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns with profound sorrow the passing of a most cherished member of its extended family. Julie ("Yidel"), a Chai Founder together with his partner in life, Hermine, was a respected founding member of our Board of Directors and also served with distinction as its Treasurer. Julie perpetuated a legacy of Ahavas Yisrael--Am Yisrael, Eretz Yisrael and Toras Yisrael--reflecting his lineage from a sainted rabbinic family, first demonstrated when, as a child scarcely seven years old, he waved a "pushke" at subway riders for Keren Kayemet to benefit Jewish settlement in Israel. We extend heartfelt condolences to Julie's wife Hermine, who in his own words, he described as "the most wonderful supportive wife, who is also my dearest and best friend", daughters Nancy and Joyce, grandchildren, great-granddaughter and the entire family. Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Raphael Benaroya, Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Josh Weston, Hon. Chairman Rabbi Ronald Gray, Exec. VP $(6$)GEWIRTZ -- Julie. Deepest sympathy to the Gewirtz family who, as everyone else who knew him, will forever be blessed with the memory and inspiration of this most gracious, honorable, kind man of extraordinary wisdom, sensitivity and humility. Peter L. Levine

title: How  We Eat Matters More Than We Think (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corporate Germany soars above economy
Fashion's Reality Star Faces the Real Thing
description: Reality television has created some exciting antagonisms. On the notionally verit shows ("An American Family," "The Osbournes," "The Anna Nicole Show," "Breaking Bonaduce"), the turbulent relationship between producer and stars is intriguing: the producers need the stars to act up without self-destructing, and the stars need the producers to give their instabilities context, visibility and parameters. HBO's outstanding tragicomedy "The Comeback" cleverly dramatized this tense interdependence.

title: Consumer Prices Rise on Food and Energy Costs
description: Sharp increases in energy and food costs pushed consumer prices higher last month, the government reported today, but prices of other goods and services rose more modestly.

title: Aristide, in Exile, Suggests a Speedy Return to Haiti
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 21 - Former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide said in a television interview on Tuesday that he hoped to return to Haiti from exile in South Africa "as soon as possible," joining his onetime protg, Ren Prval, who was officially declared the country's new president last week.

title: Furor Over Cartoons Pits Muslim Against Muslim
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 21 - In a direct challenge to the international uproar over cartoons lampooning the Prophet Muhammad, the Jordanian journalist Jihad Momani wrote: "What brings more prejudice against Islam, these caricatures or pictures of a hostage-taker slashing the throat of his victim in front of the cameras, or a suicide bomber who blows himself up during a wedding ceremony?"

title: Each Trapped in a Box, Trying to Think Outside It
description: The line dividing inspired whimsy from tedious nonsense can be a fine one, and much of "The Wooden Breeks," a new play by Glen Berger, falls on the wrong side of it. This elaborately conceived comedy, which opened last night at the Lucille Lortel Theater in an MCC Theater production, seeks to celebrate the consolations of storytelling through the saga of a Scottish tinker who dreams up imaginary worlds to keep despair at bay. But it's more the pitfalls of narrative, rather than its rewards, that Mr. Berger succeeds in demonstrating.

title: Correction
description: The Eating Well column last Wednesday, about tuna, misidentified the plaintiff in a lawsuit accusing canners of not warning consumers about the mercury in their products. The original plaintiff was the Public Media Center, a nonprofit media and consumer advocacy agency in San Francisco; the California attorney general joined the lawsuit later.

title: Fish Have No Monopoly

title: News Corp. Creates New Network for Orphaned Affiliates
description: In a move that amounts to turning lemons into lemonade, the News Corporation announced today that it was creating a new prime-time network to provide shows to stations it owns that are losing programming because of the merger of the WB and UPN networks.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sentencing In Home Depot Theft
description: A vice president of a Connecticut marketing firm was sentenced yesterday to a year in jail for stealing $363,000 from Home Depot, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. David Chass, a vice president of Velocity Sports and Entertainment, did publicity work for Home Depot in connection with the company's co-sponsorship of the Olympic Games. Prosecutors said that Mr. Chass proposed that Home Depot pay for the renovation of his apartment as part of the publicity campaign, and that when the company declined, he submitted the renovation costs on an invoice to Home Depot's event-marketing department. Prosecutors said he passed the cost off as payment for legitimate marketing work. The renovations to Mr. Chass's two-bedroom apartment on West 76th Street included new bathrooms, kitchen, floors and lighting, prosecutors said.

title: The Marquis's Daughter and the Inca Prince Who Loves Her

When it finally returns, it looks as if the company is holding its finger to the wind, trying to sneak it past an audience that either missed or has forgotten the original run, and hoping it's safe to slip it into the repertory.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Brokeback' Shirts Fetch Six Figures
description: The two iconic shirts from the final scene of "Brokeback Mountain," which was nominated for eight Academy Awards, sold for a staggering $101,100.51 to a Hollywood collector, after an auction on eBay on Monday night. In the Ang Lee film, and the Annie Proulx short story on which it is based, the shirts symbolize the thwarted love of the ranch hands Jake and Ennis. They were dirty from sweat and blood, and tucked one inside the other. The Los Angeles collector Tom Gregory won the bidding, which quickly reached the tens of thousands of dollars from an initial price of $9.99. "It's a great prop; it's the ruby slippers of our time," Mr. Gregory said in an interview. "It represents the love that would never go away no matter how much the world tried to push it away." He said he would leave the shirts, donated by Focus Features, on the hanger they share and frame them either for his home, or for a gay and lesbian foundation with which he is connected. The proceeds from the auction will benefit the Variety Children's Charity Auction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALLEN, MARK HENRY
description: ALLEN--Mark Henry. A retired senior partner of the New York law firm Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft died on February 20, 2006 at his residence in the Duncaster Community, Bloomfield, CT. Born in Brooklyn, NY, May 16, 1909, Mr. Mark was the son of the late Henry A. Mark and Mary Clyde McCarroll Mark. He graduated with honors from Polly Prep Day School, Williams College, and the Cornell Law School. He was a member of the Sigma Phi Society, Phi Delta Kappa, and Phi Delta Phi at the Masonic Lodge of Floral Park, NY. Mr. Mark served as the mayor of Garden City, LI NY, a member of the Washington, CT Planning Commission, and trustee of the Gunnery School, Washington, CT 1982-1986. He was predeceased by his wife Isobel Ross Arnold Mark. He is survived by a brother Captain William Mark, cousins and three nieces. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Judy and Paul, and to all the members of their family. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman Board of Trustees Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ira M. Millstein, Chairperson Board of Overseers Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Paid Notice: Deaths   FURMAN, SEYMOUR, M.D.
description: FURMAN--Seymour, M.D. On February 20, 2006. Beloved husband of the late Evelyn. Devoted father of Bruce, Gary and Neil. Surgeon at Montefiore Hospital for over 50 years. Services Thursday 11:45 AM at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. $(6$)FURMAN -- Seymour, M.D. Died February 20, 2006 after a prolonged illness. He is widely known as the pacemaker pioneer who, on July 16, 1958, first showed that pacemakers could stimulate the heart through plastic - covered wires inserted through veins into the heart, avoiding the need for opening the chest to sew electrodes onto the surface of the heart. His associates were Doris J.W. Escher, M.D., and the late John B. Schwedel, M.D. He invented telephone monitoring of pacemaker function in cooperation with bioengineer Bryan Parker. He was the Founder of the Heart Rythm Society (HRS), a professional organization, and long-time editor of its journal, PACE. Dr. Furman rose to international fame, with over 1000 publications, leadership of many national and international conferences, and presidency of (HRS). Many details are available at the HRS website, www.hrsonline.org. Seymour Furman was born in the Bronx in 1931, he graduated from NYU, and SUNY Downstate College of Medicine. He trained in surgery at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx, then served in the U.S. Navy Medical Corps. After training as a heart surgeon, he returned to Montefiore, with progressive emphasis on pacemakers, so that much of his career was spent with the cardiology division. He remained at Montefiore and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine where he became professor of both medicine and surgery. Dr. Furman was predeceased in 2002 by his wife, the former Evelyn Katz. He leaves behind three grown sons, Bruce, Neil, and Gary. He will be missed by many.

title: Met Trustee Seen as Set for Talks With Italy
description: In one of the first ripple effects of a deal struck by the Metropolitan Museum of Art to return some prized antiquities to Italy, the museum said yesterday that a Met trustee and benefactor was ready to address Italian allegations about works in her own collection of artifacts.

Border Jumping as a Culinary Sport
description: JOHN LAFEMINA'S first restaurant, Peasant, romances Italy to the point of presenting a menu entirely in Italian. Servers stand over your table and, item by item, for minutes on end, channel Berlitz instructors.

description: LA CRESCENTA, Calif., Feb. 21 - Leaf blowers, the most efficient way to keep lawns and sidewalks Desperate Housewives-immaculate, are a bane to both the air and the ear.

title: Knicks Obtain Francis in Deal With Orlando
description: The Knicks, mired in one of the worst seasons in franchise history, shook up the roster again today, acquiring former All-Star Steve Francis from Orlando in a splashy and potentially risky trade, the teams announced today.

title: The Quest
description: Web casting call: "Children's Auditions! 'The Lion King.' Broadway's Award-Winning Best Musical. Star in a show! Casting new performers for the Broadway and national touring companies. Minimum weekly salary is $1,381. Seeking children ages 9-12 with maximum height of 58 inches who can sing, dance and act to play the African lion cubs Simba and Nala. We encourage children of all backgrounds to attend. No performance experience necessary." Audio slide show: Hear the kids audition, and see more photos. nytimes.com/nyregion. LENS

title: Force-Feeding at Guantnamo Is Now Acknowledged
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 - The military commander responsible for the American detention center at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, confirmed Tuesday that officials there last month turned to more aggressive methods to deter prisoners who were carrying out long-term hunger strikes to protest their incarceration.

title: Embattled Harvard president quitting
Bush Would Veto Any Bill Halting Dubai Port Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 - President Bush, trying to put down a rapidly escalating rebellion among leaders of his own party, said Tuesday that he would veto any legislation blocking a deal for a state-owned company in Dubai to take over the management of port terminals in New York, Miami, Baltimore and other major American cities.

title: Boone's Point of No Return: Win a Job or Call It Quits
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 21 - Bret Boone stared at the words on the Mets' contract offer in January. They stared right back, almost mocking him.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 21 - In a sign of the video game industry's continuing struggles, Electronic Arts said on Tuesday that it planned to sell its much-awaited Godfather video game next month for $39.95, which is 20 percent less than it typically prices new games.

description: An ailing Gov. George E. Pataki was transferred yesterday to a hospital in New York City where he underwent surgery to try to alleviate the intestinal problems that have troubled him since he had his appendix removed five days earlier, state officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVIN, ALAN M.
description: LEVIN--Alan M. The management and staff of Thirteen/WNET New York bid a fond farewell to our esteemed colleague Alan M. Levin. He raised our consciousness and, in doing so, won our everlasting affection and admiration. The awardwinning programs he produced for Thirteen and for public television over so many years, set a gold standard for documentary film making. We offer our sincere condolences to his children, sisters and grandchildren. Management and Staff Thirteen/WNET New York

title: Theodore Draper, Freelance Historian, Is Dead at 93
description: Theodore Draper, a combative historian and social critic and one of the last of a generation of freelance intellectuals who wrote and lectured largely without academic affiliations or formal credentials, died yesterday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 93. His death was announced by his wife, Priscilla.

title: Stresses of poverty reflected in mortality
Metro Briefing | New York: Roosevelt: Arrest In Animal Cruelty Case
description: A 21-year-old man was arraigned yesterday on cruelty to animal charges after 20 mistreated pit bulls, apparently used for fighting, were found in his yard, the Nassau County police said. On Monday, the police received a report from an official with the Humane Society who saw 20 dogs in a backyard with no food or water, and one dog attacking a puppy. The police animal control and emergency services units went to the home and took the dogs to a shelter in Hempstead. The dogs' owner, Geoferda Rivera, was charged with animal fighting and aggravated cruelty to animals, said Joan Eames, a Nassau police spokeswoman.

title: Pope names new cardinals, including from Boston, Hong Kong and Poland
As Bird Flu Spreads, Officials Shift to Vaccination Campaigns
description: ROME, Feb. 22 A Concerned that migrating birds might seed European poultry farms with the H5N1 virus, the Netherlands and France were granted special permission by the European Commission today to protect their billion-dollar industries by vaccinating large numbers of domestic poultry.

title: Corrections

Matty Charles and Anthony da Costa will sing, in place of Bethany Yarrow and Rufus Cappadocia.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Ex-Finance Chief Is Sentenced
description: Peter Lim, former finance chief at the China Aviation Oil (Singapore) Corporation, was sentenced to two years in prison for his part in a derivatives trading scandal that cost the company, China's biggest jet fuel importer, $550 million. Mr. Lim, fired in December, conspired to cheat the adviser Deutsche Bank and released false information, Judge Liew Thiam Leng said at the Subordinate Court of Singapore. Mr. Lim, 48, who pleaded guilty, declined to comment. The city pledged stricter trading and disclosure rules to shore up its position as Asia's biggest oil-trading center.

title: Corrections

Justices Debate Federal Role in Regulating Water Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 - Supreme Court justices questioned the limits of the federal government to control pollution under the Clean Water Act in a series of cut-and-thrust exchanges on Tuesday.

title: With Little Fanfare, Newark's Mayor Is Said to Submit Petitions to Run a Sixth Time
description: NEWARK, Feb. 21 - Edging closer to a rematch with the upstart contender he beat four years ago, Mayor Sharpe James submitted petitions on Tuesday to run for an unprecedented sixth term, according to a city employee who reviewed the documents.

description: Continuing a management reorganization, Dow Jones & Company announced today that it would integrate its print and online publications, and it named a new publisher for its flagship publication, The Wall Street Journal.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 - Three Ohioans were charged in federal courts on Tuesday with conspiring to kill American forces in Iraq as part of an Islamic holy war against the United States.

Paid Notice: Deaths   STRONGIN, ESTELLE
description: STRONGIN--Estelle. 94 years old, died peacefully of heart failure, at her home on February 19, 2006. The widow of Dr. Harry Strongin, Estelle was the beloved over protective and hands-on mother of Anne Navasky and Landey Strongin, and very beloved and endlessly worried grandmother of Bruno, Miri and Jenny Navasky. One of the first woman brokers on Wall Street, Estelle was working and vitally engaged as a Senior Vice-President at Smith Barney until the day she died. Her life will be celebrated by her family and friends at the home of Anne and Victor Navasky. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to breast cancer research.

title: Abraham, Jets' Franchise Player, May Be Traded
description: The Jets designated defensive end John Abraham as their franchise player yesterday, but the move hardly cemented his status with the team.

title: Pataki Operation Is Said to Reflect an Unusual Complication
description: The operation that Gov. George E. Pataki underwent yesterday was for an unusual complication of the sort of surgery he had Thursday for a perforated appendix, according to surgeons not connected with his case.

title: Questions Over Method Lead to Delay of Execution
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21 - California officials indefinitely postponed the execution of a condemned killer because they said they were unable to comply with a federal judge's conditions for carrying out the sentence.

title: Spanish TV Joins the Big-Event Big Leagues
description: IT is a "big event" television program, watched by increasingly larger audiences. Because the program is live, viewers are more willing to watch as it is being broadcast rather than tape it for later. As a result, more marketers are eager to use the program to show off new advertising.

title: Russian Aircraft Industry Seeks Revival Through Merger
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 21 - When the Russian carrier Aeroflot announces next month which manufacturer will replace part of its aging fleet of long-range passenger jets, a Russian contestant will not even be in the running.

title: Asia Society Plans Bold Projects to Increase Its Global Presence
description: In an effort to increase its activities worldwide, the Asia Society is to announce tomorrow a major repositioning of the organization that will involve more than $100 million in new projects, including a $52 million center in Hong Kong designed by Tod Williams and Billie Tsien and a $40 million center in Houston by Yoshio Taniguchi. The plans are to be presented at the society's 50th anniversary gala dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow evening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEALD, DAVE
description: HEALD--Dave. Age 86. In Concord, NH on February 20, 2006. Of Elkins, NH and former National Marketing and Sales Manager to the Putnam Group of Mutual Funds in Boston, MA. Served in US Army during WWII. Survived by wife of 65 years, Jane (Winey) Heald of Elkins, NH; children, Dave of Riverwoods, IL, Ed of Carlisle, MA, Sally Winship of Hopkinton, NH, and Peter of New Haven, CT; eight grandchildren; and four great grandchildren. At Dave's request, there will be no service. Contributions in his memory may be made to Dartmouth College, Hanover, NH 03755 or to The New Hampton School, New Hampton, NH 03256. For info Chadwick Funeral Services of New London, NH

It found that 32 percent were white, 23 percent were Latino and 22 percent were black; the remaining 23 percent were of mixed race or other races or did not report their race.

Mittal to gather support in India for his steel company's bid for a rival, Arcelor, misstated the whereabouts of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton over the weekend. description: It isn't often that Washington generates a memorial structure simultaneously with the era it happens to exemplify. But the dollar-devouring construction pit known as the Capitol Visitors Center deserves a more candid title. The Big Debt Dig, perhaps, as the center's cost overruns mount apace with the egregious mass of deficit, debt and interest run-ups that will mark the larger budget folly of the Bush era for generations to come.

World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Barclays Profit Rises on Trading Revenue
description: Barclays said profit rose 10 percent in the second half as trading revenue at its securities unit rose and income outside Britain more than tripled. Net income climbed to 1.61 billion ($2.8 billion), or 23.7 pence a share, the bank said. Pretax profit at Barclays Capital, the investment banking unit run by Robert Diamond, rose 32 percent, to 569 million. Barclays built up its securities unit by hiring 3,200 people over two years and expanded in Spain, Portugal and Africa as consumer lending in Britain slowed. In July, the chief executive, John Varley, bought control of the Absa Group, South Africa's No. 1 consumer bank, for $4.5 billion, in its biggest purchase abroad.

title: Tips From a City Well Versed In Partying
description: Need a little help with personal revelry for Mardi Gras or any other party?

title: City to Warn New Mothers of Diabetes Risk
description: In an effort to improve outcomes for the rising number of women who get temporary diabetes during pregnancy, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that the city would routinely send information packets about the condition to all women who get the disorder.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Deadline To Collect 2002 Tax Refunds
description: The Internal Revenue Service said it had more than $2 billion of unclaimed tax refunds from 2002, which could be claimed by some of the nearly two million people who had not filed tax returns for that year. To collect the refunds, officials said, taxpayers must file such returns by April 17. "We want people to get the refunds they're entitled to," said Mark W. Everson, the I.R.S. commissioner. "Taxpayers can't get a refund if they don't file a return." The tax service, which generally allows people three years to claim refunds before it turns over the money to the United States Treasury, estimated that half of those who could claim refunds would receive more than $570. Taxpayers are not assessed a penalty for filing a late tax return if they qualify for a refund. JOHN FILES (NYT)

title: Mayor Seeks to Wield Influence on Security at Cruise Terminal
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, injecting himself into the growing debate over the proposed takeover of several American port operations by a Middle East company, signaled yesterday that the matter could lead the city to block the company from controlling the huge cruise terminal on the West Side.

title: Digital dialogue: IPod for sale: Is that a crime?
Demand Climbs for South-of-Chic Stretch of Fifth Ave.
description: The address is Fifth Avenue, to be sure, but for years, the stretch of the avenue heading north from 42nd Street to Rockefeller Center at 49th Street has seemed like a poor relation to the chic area just to the north, running from Saks Fifth Avenue to the Plaza Hotel at 59th Street.

title: Microsoft faces fresh antitrust challenge
Vote Due on South Dakota Bill Banning Nearly All Abortions
description: PIERRE, S.D., Feb. 21 - Lawmakers here are preparing to vote on a bill that would outlaw nearly all abortions in South Dakota, a measure that could become the most sweeping ban approved by any state in more than a decade, those on both sides of the abortion debate say.

title: Letter from Biloxi; Casinos Rise Out of Katrina's Wreckage
description: AT first glance, the scene last Friday in the post-Katrina Isle of Capri Casino Resort in Biloxi, Miss., seemed normal. Provocatively dressed cocktail waitresses were milling around against a backdrop of slot machines with flashing lights. The clanging noise of coins threatened to drown out the piped-in music of Donovan singing "Sunshine came softly through my window today."

title: Archbishop Marcinkus, 84, Banker at the Vatican, Dies
description: Paul C. Marcinkus, a prominent American archbishop and longtime head of the Vatican bank who was linked to a major Italian banking scandal in the 1980's, was found dead on Monday at his home in Sun City, Ariz. He was 84.

title: Kelly Reports Jump in Use of Police in Child Abuse Cases
description: In the weeks since the death of 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown in January, child welfare officials have significantly increased their requests for joint responses with police investigators to reports of child abuse, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday.

title: Slalom Gives Paerson Her First Taste of Gold
description: SESTRIERE, Italy, Feb. 22 A No medal ceremonies were more devoid of joy than the two in which Anja Paerson of Sweden accepted her bronze medals in the women's combined and downhill earlier in the Turin Olympics. Paerson, the 24-year-old overall World Cup champion, politely forced a wave to her fans in the grandstands, but did nothing to hide her disappointment.

title: No Soul on Ice
description: TURIN, Italy - THE point system that the International Skating Union adopted in the wake of the judging scandal in Salt Lake City four years ago and that is on display here at the Winter Olympics is a positive development, but there are some downsides.

title: Away From Mardi Gras, Glints of Life as the Hopeful Trickle Home
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 21 - At evening time in parts of the Gentilly neighborhood here, headlights become searchlights, skipping spectrally across the facades of empty houses, street after street, in the pitch of absence.

title: Rioja, Serene Above the Trendy Fray
description: LET me say it straight out: I am a Rioja partisan. While other regions all over Spain have won acclaim in the last decade for their new and exciting red wines, I keep returning to Rioja, the best-known Spanish region, which all too often is overlooked in the obsession for identifying the latest trends.

title: Astros' Plight: One Can Pitch, One Can't Throw
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla., Feb. 19 - There is a locker for Jeff Bagwell at Osceola County Stadium, neatly stocked with two Houston Astros uniforms, two pairs of cleats, one batting helmet, one glove and several boxes. The evidence points to Bagwell's imminent arrival.

title: Slow Pace of Mine Rescue in Mexico Angers Families
description: SAN JUAN DE LAS SABINAS, Mexico, Feb. 21 - For a third day, Mexican miners tunneled slowly through collapsed mine shafts here on Tuesday, trying to reach 65 of their comrades trapped since Sunday morning but making little or no progress.

title: The End User: Noticing a red flag
World Briefing | Europe: Russia-Georgia Tensions Escalate
description: Russia's embassy in Georgia announced it was refusing to issue visas to Georgian citizens, and the Georgian Foreign Ministry accused Russia of violating Georgian airspace with military planes. Russia denied flying aircraft over Georgian territory, but said it would restrict visas for Georgians because Georgia had been delaying visa renewals for Russian soldiers stationed in Georgia. The Kremlin and the pro-Western government in Georgia, a former Soviet republic, have quarreled over the fates of South Ossetia and Abkhazia, two separatist enclaves in Georgian territory receiving open Russian support. C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

title: Silvercup Studios Sets $1 Billion Complex
description: With New York City suddenly awash in film and television productions, Silvercup Studios has unveiled plans for a version of Hollywood on the East River, a $1 billion complex with soundstages, commercial space and housing on the Queens waterfront south of the Queensboro Bridge.

title: From Ono's New York to his own Hungary
Sect Allowed to Import Its Hallucinogenic Tea
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 - A unanimous Supreme Court decision on Tuesday gave a small religious sect the right to keep importing a hallucinogenic tea, central to its ritual observance, that the government wants to ban as a controlled substance under federal narcotics law.

title: Research Casts New Light on Human Migration to Europe
description: New advances in radiocarbon dating are threatening to upend old theories about when modern humans colonized Europe from Africa, and how rapidly they advanced.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Intelligence Agents Accused Of Murder
description: Five of six suspects accused of murdering a Kazakh opposition leader are members of an elite unit within Kazakhstan's intelligence agency, the government said, casting fresh suspicions over the second mysterious death of a prominent opposition figure since last fall. Altynbek Sarsenbaiuly, a member of For a Just Kazakhstan, was found dead last week, shot through the head. The government had said he was killed for business reasons, and President Nursultan Nazarbayev has vowed to solve the crime. C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 21 - In a country where the power is usually out, the police may rob you and few traffic lights actually work, it is perhaps surprising that Iraqis still get mail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARDOZO, REV. ABRAHAM LOPES
description: CARDOZO--Rev. Abraham Lopes. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a deeply cherished friend and member of the Sephardic Council of Overseers (SCO) who served for many years as Instructor of Occidental Sephardic Liturgy at the Philip and Sarah Belz School of Jewish Music, and a mentor to hundreds of Sephardic students. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Irma, a devoted SCO member, and their children Debbie (and Earl) Smith, Judith (and Sidney) Tenenbaum, their eight grandchildren and great-grandchild. Min hashamayim tenuhamu. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman Board of Trustees David Eshaghian, Chairman SCO $(6$)CARDOZO--Reverend Abraham Lopes. Congregation Shearith Israel mourns the loss of its esteemed Hazan Emeritus and extends its sympathy to his wife, Irma, his children and grandchildren. He served our congregation faithfully for 60 years and will be greatly missed. The funeral will take place today February 22 at 1:30 P.M. at Congregation Shearith Israel, 2 West 70th Street. Peter Neustadter, Parnus $(6$)CARDOZO--Reverend Abraham Lopes. The Officers and Employees of Riverside Memorial Chapel mourn the passing of a true Tzadik, a Righteous Jew. To his wife Irma and his entire family, we extend our sincere condolences. Charles S. Salomon, Pres. David A. Alpert, Sr Vice Pres. $(6$)CARDOZO--Rev. Abraham Lopes. The Sisterhood of the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue deeply mourns the loss of our Hazan, beloved husband of our Co-President, Irma. May his family be comforted by their memories of this "sweet singer of Zion." Carla Salomon Schein, Co-President

title: By Fat Transformed: The Confit, in All Its Splendor
description: AMERICAN chefs like David Kinch of Manresa in Los Gatos, Calif., insist on the freshest seasonal ingredients. And then what do they do with them? They often apply techniques that were originally used for preserving, in times and places where supplies of fresh produce, meat and fish were not guaranteed all year.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: A Warning Against Protectionism Over Mergers
description: Charlie McGreevy, who oversees the European single market, strongly criticized Poland, France and Luxembourg, accusing them of unfairly seeking to stop cross-border deals. Mr. McCreevy, left, the commissioner for the internal market, said moves by France and Luxembourg to shield the steel group Arcelor from a takeover by Mittal Steel were out of step with European law. At the same time, he threatened Poland with a lawsuit over its attempts to protect a domestic banking group. Poland has held firm in its decision to block the acquisition of Bank BPH by UniCredito, the last obstacle to Unicredito's $25 billion purchase of the HVB Group of Germany, which owns BPH. Protectionism is "the wrong message to be sending about the openness of the European Union to new investment," he said in a news briefing in Brussels. Mr. McCreevy's broadside came the same day that Thierry Breton, the finance minister of France, proposed legislation limiting unsolicited takeovers. The law would allow possible takeover targets the right to give shareholders the right to buy new stock at a discount to ward off hostile bids. JAMES KANTER (IHT)

title: Twists, Setbacks and an Impromptu Solo Moment
description: Last July, the pianist Fred Hersch kicked off his weeklong engagement at the Village Vanguard with an unexpected twist: he played solo, with no bass or drums behind him. That isn't common practice at the Vanguard, the no-muss temple of modern jazz; Mr. Hersch, like most pianists who play there, had been booked and billed with his trio.

World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Army Commander Fired Over Hazing Of Soldiers
description: Two days after the country was shaken by allegations that young army recruits were tortured and sexually assaulted by their superiors, President lvaro Uribe appointed General Mario Montoya, left, as the head of the army, replacing General Reinaldo Castellanos, who was forced to resign in the aftermath of the scandal. Mr. Uribe said he was furious to learn last weekend of the violent hazing of 21 young recruits. "It's painful, grave and inconceivable," the president said. The attorney general's office has opened an investigation into allegations that the recruits were beaten, branded and burned. JUAN FORERO (NYT)

title: Going Long With the Shorts
description: The short subjects category of the Academy has always been bursting with talent, but no one ever actually sees the movies. The Bagger is just betting many a member wouldnt know a nominee if he got mugged by one. But Magnolia Pictures, the distribution arm of Mark Cuban and Todd Wagners enterprise, is letting the public get the short end of the stick, in a nice way. The company is giving the shorts a pre-Oscar run, starting Feb. 24 at the Cinema Village in New York and Laemmle Fairfax in Los Angeles, as well as weeklong runs with Landmark Theatres in San Francisco, Detroit, Berkeley, Atlanta, Seattle, and Denver.

title: Revenge of the Not-So-Nerdy
description: Speaking of Salon, they give some credit where its due by highlighting the annual Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences annual Scientific and Technical Awards. You say you missed them? Well, the were last weekend, and Salons Scott Kirsner went so you didnt have to. Let the Oscar program diss these folks all they want; the Bagger knows that they are the ones that put the magic in the medium.

title: A Salon of Friends
description: Former Salon film critic Charles Taylor had his share of detractors  they seemed to be legion for a while there  but he is missed by some. He tells Jeremiah Kipp that the reason that he got the gate was that he failed to pass lefty muster when it came to his choice of targets:

title: Psychic Dividends
description: The Chicago Tribune performs triage on the motives on a trio of folks responsible for Corpse Bride, Crash and History of Violence, and finds out that, An Oscars nice if you can get it, but awards or peer recognition cant hold a candle to intrinsic rewards. Yep, the Bagger can identify with that. When he collects a bunch of links willy nilly, pounds in a few non-sequiters around them and pushes send, it is a moment when it is all about the craft.

title: Matt Dillon, Living the Dream
description: The AP spends some quality time with Matt Dillon, talking about what it is like to share a movie with a bug and why the movie he directed sank like a stone. Oh, and that movie where he plays a racist cop. He had his share of fond memories, including this one about co-star Thandie Newton: But nothing beats when we were up there on the top of the hill in San Pedro, losing the light, Thandie is upside down in the car, sliding around on broken glass, and Im happy.
Selborne Journal: Sunday, 22 February 1784: 29 3/10; 42, 43 1/2; S, SW. Deep fog, swift thaw, rain, rain. Snow melts, & the country is flooded. Flood at Gracious street.

title: A Season Goes Off Under the Caution Flag
description: Variety looks into the car wreck that is the domestic release schedule, an accident waiting to happen in which very few movies, even some mighty fine ones, do not get out alive. And were talking about the competition for the ultimate golden icon  the almighty dollar  not a collectible statue that is a monument of prestige.

title: No-Frills Web Games
description: There are many games available for those players who prefer simplicity in their digital diversions.

title: Isaac Mizrahi Justifies His Existence
description: Isaac Mizrahi (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

title: The Little Dickens
description: Roger Ebert, who has found a number of ways to get in the tank for Crash, goes over the top and stays there in his last tactical maneuver, suggesting that the parable of race and class is actually just a Dickensian version of contemporary life:

title: Personal Shopper
description: New lighting designs for the coming season take their inspiration from the past, with fixtures draped in a profusion of glass and crystal.

title: Another Vote for Gore as the New Nixon
Currents
description: 19th-century art sold the 21st-century way. the transformative power of a fresh coat of paint, defrosting the refrigerator on the outside and more.

title: Free David Irving
description: How long before jailed Holocaust-denier David Irving becomes a Mumia-style cause celebre? Writers and bloggers from across the ideological spectrum have objected to an Austrian courts decision to sentence Irving to three years in prison for denying Nazi genocide. While condemning Irving for his offensive beliefs and writings, these writers say Irvings free-speech rights must be defended, and they contrast the support in Europe for Irvings sentencing with the criticism directed at Muslims for opposing the Danish publication of cartoons lampooning the prophet Muhammad.

title: Ports in a Storm
description: The Times editorial page sided this morning with congressional critics of the Bush administrations plan to hand control of operations at major American ports to a company based in Dubai, in the United Arab Emirates, and controlled by that government and endorsed a bill that would put the decision on hold and require closer examination of the proposal.

title: Attack Destroys Golden Dome
description: Insurgents detonated powerful explosives inside one of Shiite Islam's most sacred shrines, in Samarra, Iraq, prompting protests across the country.

title: E-tiquette
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Day 12 at the Games
description: In Olympic action, the United States and Canadian men's hockey teams were eliminated in the quarterfinals.

title: The Most Expensive House in America?
description: My new guilty pleasure, reading the Americas Most Overvalued Real Estate Markets blog, gives us a new contest: The most expensive house in America.

title: Old Fish in a New Wrapper
description: A tip of the hat to BubbleMeter for finding a new book on Amazon.com by National Association of Realtors chief economist David Lereah.

title: Foreclosures in Minority Neighborhoods
description: An important story on The Timess front page today by Vikas Bajaj and Ron Nixon. It analyzes foreclosures in a Cleveland neighborhood to come up with some revealing conclusions about lending in what is called the subprime category.

title: When Modernity Flusters Traditional Societies
description: Readers respond to Thomas Friedmans Feb. 22 column, Empty Pockets, Angry Minds

title: Olympics: For China, strategy is to focus on best events
World Briefing: Africa, Europe and Americas
description: Correction Appended

title: Zambia's Plight Goes Begging in Year of Disasters
description: NANGWESHI REFUGEE CAMP, Zambia - Hundreds of refugees from Angola's civil war have walked away from this remote United Nations outpost where most have lived for years, many roaming on foot as far as the Namibia border, 85 miles away. The journey was not by choice. The refugees were looking for food.

title: Comparing Apples to Oranges...or Dells
description: Already, the pundits are speaking out on whether or not Apple's new MacBook Pro laptop (featuring an Intel processor) is a better deal than Dell's laptops with the same processors. Here's an intriguing dissection of that argument. Turns out comparing laptops is like comparing cellular plans or mattresses from different chains; because you can't create identical configurations, direct comparisons are almost impossible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NITCHUN, ARLEEN
description: NITCHUN--Arleen. On February 21, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Sidney Nitchun. Loving mother of Joanne Sackett and Marc Nitchun. Cherished grandmother of King, Mia, Nick, Blaise, Mary, Darius, Terina, Miranda, Alyssa and Anna, and greatgrandmother of Nora, Nicholas, Lily, Daniela, Sammy, Luke and Charlie. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Service Sunday, February 26, 11:30AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Decision In Lead Paint Case
description: Correction Appended

title: Sightings of Steinbrenner Are Plentiful and Playful
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 22 - George Steinbrenner had become a specter in his kingdom, practically invisible around the Yankees at spring training. Steinbrenner, the principal owner, would appear in the lunchroom or a hallway, but in an instant, a golf cart or an elevator would whisk him away. He often never said a word.

title: Reuters falls on outlook
Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Joel Dorius, a Smith College professor of literature who lost his job in a pornography scandal but was later exonerated, misspelled the surname of the literary critic who was a friend of Mr. Dorius's accuser. He was Malcolm Cowley, not Crowley.

title: EU proposes tariffs on shoes from Asia
Blast at Shiite Shrine Sets Off Sectarian Fury in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 22 - A powerful bomb shattered the golden dome at one of Iraq's most revered Shiite shrines on Wednesday morning, setting off a day of sectarian fury in which mobs formed across Iraq to chant for revenge and attacked dozens of Sunni mosques.

title: Bright New Ways to See the Light
description: NEW lighting designs for the coming season take their inspiration from the past, with fixtures draped in a profusion of glass and crystal. It's as if, in a trick of the eye, your grandmother's chandelier were made to look modern. At the Maison et Objet trade show held in Paris in January, Franois Bernard, a home-furnishings trend-spotter and an interior designer, set the mood with an installation of dozens of objects for the home, all made from transparent materials and shown on pedestals rising from pools of water. The exhibition halls were also filled with shimmering fixtures, some illuminated with small candles instead of bulbs. (One notable exception was David Emery, a French lighting designer, who showed fixtures made with fiber optic threads cascading from wood boxes.)

title: Other Views: Daily Star, Daily Telegraph, Chicago Tribune
Paid Notice: Memorials   WEITZ, WILLIAM
description: WEITZ--William. 3/2/25-2/23/ 76. Dad, it's been 30 years since you left us. You would be so proud of the women we have become. Our lives are rich, except for you not being here to share them with us. Still missing you so, so, much. With our love forever. Randi and Jill

title: Adding the Avian Flu to the Be-Prepared List
description: The possibility of an avian flu pandemic is enough to give any small- business owner nightmares. What if a quarter of your business was selling home-delivered and takeout chicken across the United States? Or your sales force in Asia was subject to quarantine? What if your employees couldn't work from home?

title: New Hope Seen for Global Trade Agreement
description: PARIS, Feb. 23 - The conditions are in place for resolving in the first half of this year the most contentious issues in negotiations for a world trade agreement, paving the way for a final accord before the end of 2006, a world trade official said Thursday.

title: Ex-Governor of Illinois Won't Testify at His Corruption Trial
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 22 - Former Gov. George Ryan announced Wednesday in federal court here that he would not testify in his criminal corruption trial. The court case, which has been going on for more than five months, could conclude within the next two weeks.

title: Philip Bowring: A boatload of ignorance on show
Pope Picks 15 Cardinals, One a China Critic
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 22 - Pope Benedict XVI named his first new cardinals on Wednesday, 15 in all. They include the bishop of Hong Kong, an outspoken critic of China's rulers, and Archbishop Sean Patrick O'Malley of Boston, appointed two years ago after the sex abuse scandal there forced the resignation of Cardinal Bernard Law.

title: Nestl reports sharp rise in net profit
On Podiums and in Parties, Russia Is Red-Hot
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 22 - Outside the Russia House, headquarters for the Russian delegation in Turin, a horde of people gathered at the entryway, looking frozen and distraught.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Charged Again In False Sales Scheme
description: A Manhattan man charged two months ago with stealing thousands of dollars from five businessmen by accepting money for electronic equipment that he never delivered has been rearrested and charged with defrauding nine additional people, prosecutors said. The defendant, Michael Ballister, 51, of Central Park West, was charged with grand larceny and fraud, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Ballister had posed as a manager for various electronic stores and promised deep discounts. After meeting the men at the stores and collecting their money, Mr. Ballister would disappear, prosecutors charged.

title: Dubai company vows not to sell 6 U.S. ports
The Work You Do When You're Not at Work
description: WHAT would you be doing if you were not at work? Scrubbing the bathroom or watching the Olympics? Fixing the car or playing golf? Darning socks or doing crossword puzzles?

title: Internet Calls, Even if You're Not Close to Your Computer
description: Skype, the program for making online phone calls, generally requires users to be tethered to a computer and an Internet connection. The VoSKY Call Center changes that equation, adding some interesting new options to the mix.

title: Thomson posts a loss but foresees '06 profit
Pop Them in, and They're Ready to Push You
description: IT'S not every personal trainer who inspires a client to write poetry in her honor. But after a few weeks of training with doe-eyed Maya, Glen Raphael couldn't help but extol her virtues in verse: "Sweet Maya never sleeps or even tires/I rarely get a sense that she perspires."

title: Annan Backs Plan for Human Rights Council, Despite Flaws
description: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 23 A Secretary General Kofi Annan and rights groups said today that a resolution on a new Human Rights Council had fallen short of their expectations but still provided the best option for replacing the discredited Human Rights Commission.

title: Airbus outflies Boeing on new orders in Asia
Swede Has Gold-Medal Celebration Down Cold
description: SESTRIERE, Italy, Feb. 22 - There were no more awards celebrations more joyless than Anja Paerson's accepting her two bronze medals in the women's combined and the downhill earlier in the Turin Olympics. She forced a wave to her fans in the grandstand, but Paerson, the reigning overall World Cup champion from Sweden, did nothing to hide her disappointment.

title: Turkey farm in France thought to host bird flu
Big Problem, Dubai Deal or Not
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 - In the political collision between the White House and Congress over the $6.8 billion deal that would give a Dubai company management of six American ports, most experts seem to agree on only one major point: The gaping holes in security at American ports have little to do with the nationality of who is running them.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: De Beers To Cut Supplier
description: The European Commission has ordered De Beers, the world's biggest diamond company, to stop buying rough diamonds from Alrosa of Russia as of 2009 in order to open the market to more competition. De Beers accounts for 70 percent of all rough diamonds in the world, while Alrosa accounts for 20 percent. De Beers agreed to cooperate, and will phase out purchases from Alrosa over the next three years, the commission said in a statement yesterday. "For the first time in the history of the diamond market, there is an opportunity for genuine competition," Europe's competition commissioner, Neelie Kroes, said. PAUL MELLER (NYT)

title: A Synthesizer, Audio Mixer and Video Editor, All in One
description: Many programs let you make music on the computer, but the MiKo, a portable media work center from Open Labs, is a computer designed to make music and a whole lot more. The MiKo -- a combination synthesizer, audio mixing station, video editing console and broadband Internet hub -- has a 64-bit A.M.D. Athlon processor and Windows XP under its considerably multifaceted hood.

title: Quiet simplicity from Antonio Marras
Dubai Sees Bias Behind Storm
description: Correction Appended

title: White House Report Advises Revamping Disaster Response
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  The Bush administration, acknowledging the multitude of Hurricane Katrina failures, advocated today giving federal agencies from the Pentagon to the Department of Justice a greater role in the nation's disaster response playbook.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRANER, BRUCE J.
description: KRANER--Bruce J., 67. Of Aventura, FL. Passed away February 21, 2006. He is survived by his devoted children Jason (Bonnie) Kraner and Debbie Schneider, four cherished grandchildren and dear sister Nancy (Henry) Silverman. Graveside services 12:45PM (Today) at Lakeside Memorial Park, Miami.

title: Study Plays Down Export of Computer Jobs
description: The movement of computing work abroad represents an economic and scientific challenge, but the fears of job migration far outweigh the reality so far, according to a new study by the Association for Computing Machinery.

description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KAYE, ROBERT
description: KAYE--Robert. 1/16/76 to 2/23/06. On this 10th Anniversary you are the diamond in the sky that will always sparkle for us. Love, Mom, Dad and Andy

title: For Iraqis, the mayhem turns personal
From Venezuela, a Serious Exodus to a Tango, Boldly Lit
description: Visions of jolly swabs filled my head as I made my way toward the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night, where Danzahoy was beginning a week's run. Soon, however, sober common sense prevailed, in more ways than one. Danzahoy comes from Caracas, and its name means Dance Today in Spanish. Far from jolly, the company was seriousness incarnate in its 65-minute "Exodo."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ARNOLD, JOSEPH, CPA.
description: ARNOLD--Joseph, CPA. Of New York City and Easthampton, passed away on February 22, following a brief illness. Joe was preceded in death by his wife of 63 years, Ruth, last November. Born in Brooklyn in 1920, Joe attended Boys High and the City College of New York and served in the Army Air Corps during WW II. A Certified Public Accountant, he was in private practice for over 50 years. A champion tennis player, Joe was a member of the Seventh Regiment Armory and the Easthampton Tennis Club, where he was Treasurer for many years and also the Club Champion on numerous occasions. Joe also played Men's Senior Doubles at the US Open in Forest Hills. He is survived by his children Deborah and Richard, both of Los Angeles.

title: Figure Skater Arakawa Gives Japan Its First Gold Medal
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 23 A Shizuka Arakawa won Japan's first ever Olympic gold medal in women's figure skating with an elegant long program while American Sasha Cohen and Russian Irina Slutskaya made critical errors to take themselves out of contention tonight in the Olympics' signature event.

title: Review: Death's Door
Corrections
description: Labels on a chart in Business Day on Saturday showing market share in secondary mortgages were reversed. Fannie Mae had a 24 percent share last year; Freddie Mac had 20 percent.

title: Guidant Discloses Claims
description: Guidant, which makes devices to correct abnormal heart rhythms, said in a regulatory filing yesterday that as many as 2,500 patients may seek damages after last year's recall of 109,000 implantable defibrillators linked to at least seven deaths.

title: Provocation in Samarra
Paid Notice: Deaths   BERKULE, LEE
description: BERKULE - Lee. Passed away February 21. Beloved wife, cherished grandmother, loving mother of Barry, Lloyd and Arlene. Grandmother of Erik, Samantha, David, Elizabeth and Amanda. We will always love you and miss you dearly. You will never leave our hearts. You will live forever for all the people who knew you. You will be loved forever. Service today, 10AM at the Riverside Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: LAMORIELLO WILL KEEP COACHING
description: Since Lou Lamoriello, the chief executive, president and general manager of the Devils, installed himself as the team's interim coach after Larry Robinson's resignation Dec. 19, Lamoriello had said it was a temporary move and that he would hire another coach before the end of the season.

title: McCain kicks off drive for guest worker program
Winning the Bronze Was Victory Enough
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 22 - Alisa Camplin, a perky Australian, was not good enough to defend her Olympic gold medal in aerials Wednesday, but she was not disappointed.

title: Lottery Numbers
Paid Notice: Deaths   SALOMON, BURTON L.
description: SALOMON--Burton L. On February 22, 2006. Cherished husband of Barbara. Beloved father of Douglas and Alan. Devoted brother-in-law to Claire and Cliff Kahn and Ruth Salomon. Grandest uncle to Ronni and Andy Lorrell, David and Kari Sastortas and Dr. Jeffrey, great-uncle to Sophie. Dedicated friend to many. Former President, Special Sales Division, Manhattan Industries. Services at Sunset Chapels, Manhasset, Friday, February 24, 12 noon. In lieu of flowers, donations to National Tay - Sachs -- NY would be appreciated.

title: A Rap Purist Who Aims to Succeed Through Brute Force
description: No drought lasts forever, so eventually a rapper is going to come along and return New York to its position of hip-hop prominence. Lots of veterans are jockeying for position: 50 Cent has made Ma$e and Mobb Deep part of his G Unit family; Sony is hoping to rehabilitate DMX's career; Pharoahe Monch has a new deal with SRC/Universal; Def Jam has signed Nas and has been negotiating with Fabolous.

title: Toward a Wordless Theater of Death-Haunted Imagery
description: Leszek Madzik, whose 40-minute piece "Odchodzi (Passing Away)" began a nearly three-week run at La MaMa Annex on Feb. 16, commands enormous respect among those in the know about Polish avant-garde theater. Since the early 1970's, he has been creating small-scale, slow-moving, wordless, melancholy performances that explore concentrated states of mind, organic processes and abstract philosophical and religious ideas. Reports in international theater journals over the years have described his works in hushed tones of reverence, comparing them with the theater of Jerzy Grotowski and Tadeusz Kantor.

title: CBS has $9 billion loss on write-down
A Tempest in a Seaport, and Politics
description: SOMETIMES metro really does matter. Or, put another way, all politics is local, as the great port imbroglio has again reminded us. Because underneath the security uproar -- supporting it as a foundation supports a building -- is, of course, politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAUFMAN, MABEL
description: KAUFMAN--Mabel. The full and generous life of Mabel Goldfarb Kaufman ended on February 9, but her memory will long remain with those who had the good fortune to know her. Born in New York City, she was the loving wife of Irving for 63 years; the nurturing mother of Alan and Marc; grandmother to David, John and Kaylin; sister to Kitty and Elayne; and mother-inlaw to Terrie and Lynn. She taught elementary school in Ann Arbor, MI and later was a professor at City College in New York, at Bank Street College of Education, and at Teachers College, Columbia University, where she had earned her doctorate in 1971. She was 82 at her passing and was buried at Shaarey Pardes Cemetery in East Hampton. A memorial service will be held later in the year. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the East Hampton library would be appreciated.

title: Everybody Can Exhale, as Bonds Has Arrived
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Feb. 22 - It was all a mystery, not quite worthy of Agatha Christie, or Inspector Clouseau, for that matter, but a nifty little conundrum: When would the 41-year-old potentate with 708 home runs arrive in camp to begin spring training?

title: Perfumer Draws Fire Over a Scent Called 'Peace'
description: LAURICE RAHM has a temperament too volatile to be contained in a bottle. But that, in a manner of speaking, is exactly what she has set out to do. Ms. Rahm, the hard-charging impresario behind Bond No. 9, a collection of Manhattan-centric fragrances with names like Park Avenue, New Haarlem, Chelsea Flowers and Chinatown, seems to have spiked each of them with a generous dram of her own personality.

description: Browse a photo album by any beginning photographer and you're likely to see blurry shots. The Joby Gorillapod, a 1.59-ounce tripod, can help budding photographers get a steady shot.

title: INSIDE
description: Supplements Fail to Stop Arthritis Pain, Study Says Two widely used nutritional supplements for arthritis pain, glucosamine and chondroitin sulfate, do not effectively soothe patients' aching arthritic knees, a large federal study has found.

Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about members of Congress and their aides who are married to lobbyists referred imprecisely to Debbie Dingell (identified in the article only as the wife of Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, and shown in a picture with him at their Dearborn home). While Ms. Dingell advises General Motors on lobbying strategy in her role as executive director of community and government relations, she is not currently a registered lobbyist.

description: To the Editor:

title: Lieutenant Governor Makes Bid for Mayor of New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 22 - Lt. Gov. Mitch Landrieu formally entered the race for mayor of New Orleans on Wednesday, adding a politically potent name to a foreshortened contest certain to raise the make-or-break issues facing this city.

title: Panel Saw No Security Issue in Port Contract, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 - The Bush administration decided last month that a deal to hand over operations at major American ports to a government-owned company in Dubai did not involve national security and so did not require a more lengthy review, administration officials said Wednesday.

title: U.S. Cardinals Helped Lead Response to Abuse Scandal
description: BOSTON, Feb. 22 - The two American archbishops named as cardinals on Wednesday by Pope Benedict XVI have played significant roles in responding to the church's sexual abuse crisis, a factor that experts say probably figured in the decision to elevate them.

title: For Generics, Bumpy Road to Pharmacy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 - A generic version of Flonase, a popular allergy spray, was approved for sale by federal drug regulators Wednesday. The generic should be available within days, its maker said.

title: WTO chief upbeat on trade pact this year
Europa: Arrogance on 2 sides clouds Guantnamo
Paid Notice: Deaths   FORSTER, LISSA
description: FORSTER--Lissa. The Brick Church School mourns the passing of Lissa Forster, a dedicated, most caring teacher at Brick for twelve years and a very brave person.

description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,272 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MISHCON, SIDNEY
description: MISHCON--Sidney, 88. On February 22, 2006. Of Long Boat Key, Florida and Great Barrington, MA. Adored husband of Mimi and loving father of Arnold, Judi, Jonathan, Melissa and June. Grandfather of Alyssa, Lindsay, Hillary, Sam, Harrison, Jacqueline and Bennett.

title: Bush Urges India to Split Civilian-Military Nuclear Plants
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 - President Bush pressed India on Wednesday to move more aggressively to separate its civilian and military nuclear programs so that a faltering nuclear agreement between the United States and India might win the approval of a skeptical Congress and America's nuclear-armed allies.

title: From Japan, Now Sold in New York
description: Hiro Odaira, an architect trained in Tokyo, shown far left, designs and sells lamps (starting at $350) and wall hangings made from washi, Japanese handmade parchment, which sells for $50 to $100 a square foot. Until now, when his clients have asked if they could buy more of the parchment, he has said no, since his favorite kind, made by the Kobo studio in northern Japan, was not available in the New York area. But last month he opened Precious Pieces, a store at 259 East 10th Street (First Avenue) that sells 20 patterns of Kobo parchment -- including Ame, shown on the table, which alternates solid bands of parchment with see-through bands of thin strips of fiber, and Mado, left, which is made with asymmetrical holes. Mr. Odaira sells sheets of parchment , lamps, wall hangings and cards at the shop. He can also order the parchment in custom sizes, including pieces as large as 30 by 100 feet, which take two years to make. Precious Pieces, (212) 598-5903, precious-piece.com.

title: A director and his American West End
The World Stage Still Suits Bettman and the N.H.L.
description: Turin, Italy - FROM high above the ice, in a luxury suite, it wasn't difficult to see that no miracle was forthcoming on the 26th anniversary of Lake Placid, only the potential misery of a fourth consecutive one-goal defeat for the United States.

title: An Artist Loved by No One but the Public
description: LONDON, Feb. 22 - For every critic who has sneered at Jack Vettriano's work, for every curator who has spurned or ignored it, there is someone like Liz Davison from Newcastle, who begs to differ.
