Paid Notice: Deaths   THOMPSON, RICHARD M.H.
description: THOMPSON--Richard M.H. Thompson, a chairman of a pioneering fuel-cell technology company, died yesterday at his home in Florida of cancer. He was 71. He served with Britain's Household Cavalry as a Queen's Lifeguard and graduated from Cambridge University and Harvard Business School. His father, Sir John, was in the Indian Civil Service and served as Governor of Bengal. He is survived by wife Elizabeth, first wife Daniele, children Caroline, Christopher, Victoria and Antonia and grandchildren Anna, Madeleine and Marcel. He will be greatly missed. He will be buried in England with a memorial to follow in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Hospice of Palm Beach County.

title: Specs: Cladding That Evokes Tractors but Cossets a Child
description: TO keep construction costs to about $50 a square foot, Upe Flueckiger used inexpensive materials like corrugated steel, center right.

title: Sectarian fury in Iraq undermines talks
Bruce Hart, 68, Lyricist for 'Sesame Street,' Dies
description: Bruce Hart, who wrote lyrics for "Sesame Street" and "Free to Be You and Me," died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68.

title: HealthSouth agrees to $445 million settlement
When the Lyrics Are Fragmentary and the Melodies Elusive
description: The challenge for a composer in selecting texts for musical setting is to find words that are meaningful and intriguing on their own terms but also invite music. John Harbison chose well in fashioning 10 poems by the Nobel Prize-winning writer Czeslaw Milosz into a text for "Milosz Songs," his 30-minute work for soprano and orchestra, which was given its premiere on Thursday night by the soprano Dawn Upshaw, for whom it was written, and the New York Philharmonic, which commissioned it. The piece was conducted by Robert Spano on a program including works by Bartok and Bernstein.

title: Wi-Fi to Go: The Hot Spot in a Box
description: YOU know what would be so cool? A portable Wi-Fi hot spot. Whenever you wanted Internet access, you wouldn't have to hunt for a wireless coffee shop or pay $24 a night to your hotel.

title: When the Going Gets Tough, Don't Sweat It
description: WARMTH, wicking and ventilation have always been virtues people look for in workout clothes. Now new "variable knit" technology, which combines different weaves in a single piece of fabric, offers all three properties at once, providing optimal temperature control body part by body part with no seams to chafe.

title: 'Girls with attitude' at Anna Molinari

San Francisco Gets Proposals for Free Citywide Wi-Fi Net
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22 - Google and EarthLink have teamed up to offer to build a free citywide wireless network here -- one of six proposals by companies and nonprofit groups vying to become the municipality's access provider.

title: Late-Winter Relief: Acres of Orchids
description: PICKING a favorite orchid is as difficult as picking a favorite child for Marc Hachadourian, the curator of the New York Botanical Garden's fourth annual Orchid Show, which opens to the public on Saturday. "I love them all," Mr. Hachadourian said early this week, in the midst of setting up the show, which will feature thousands of orchids from the garden's own collection of 8,000 specimens from all over the world.

title: Just Like His Old Watch, but Different
description: HOW is a wristwatch like modern man?

title: Jets Drop Seven, Including Law and Fiedler
description: The Jets severed ties with seven players yesterday, including cornerback Ty Law and quarterback Jay Fiedler, and restructured the contract of running back Curtis Martin -- all in an effort to reduce their bloated payroll.

title: Nets Honor Their Past by Ignoring Defense
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 22 - The Nets honored Julius Erving, the greatest player in franchise history, on his 56th birthday Wednesday night by wearing throwback uniforms from his glory days in the long-defunct American Basketball Association.

title: Correction
description: The Fashion Diary column on Feb. 9, about echoes of the 80's in current designs, misidentified the curator of "The Downtown Show," an exhibition about the 70's and 80's at New York University. He is Carlo McCormick. (Diego Cortez, also a curator, was not involved.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEMSER, CLAIRE
description: NEMSER--Claire. On February 20, 2006 at age 100. Loving sister of Lillian Gursky. Services Thursday 11:30 A.M. at "The Riverside", 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Seduction, Revived
description: MILAN - IN the Polly-want-a-cracker way the so-called style news media work in this city, the phrase being parroted this Fashion Week is "Sex is back." Sex, of course, is never far from the concerns of fashion, nor should it be, a truth that designers as unalike as Madeleine Vionnet and Tom Ford have understood.

Abraham Cardozo, Sephardic Cantor, Dies at 91
description: The Rev. Abraham Lopes Cardozo, the longtime cantor of a historic Manhattan synagogue and a major force in recovering and preserving the liturgical music of Spanish and Portuguese Jews, died on Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 91.

Canadian Coach Takes Chinese Aerialist to the Top
description: SAUZE D'OULX, Feb. 23 A Dustin Wilson, an Edmonton native, was coaching freestyle aerialists in Australia two years ago when representatives from the Chinese national sport federation approached him about coaching for China.

title: Accessorize With Pearls or Tattoos
description: FOR many years I knew only two people who wore clothing by the American manufacturer St. John. The garment they both chose was the St. John knit suit, an ensemble as sacrosanct as a nun's habit.

title: A State Official Unaware of Her Own Power (or at Least She Was for a While Last Week)
description: ALBANY, Feb. 22 - Twice over the past week, for about an hour at a time, Mary O. Donohue has been New York's acting governor.

title: In the Evening News Derby, CBS Is Betting on Folksy
description: It's a scary world, except on CBS News, where it seems downright cuddly.

title: Selling Well Everywhere but Home
description: ZIRNDORF, Germany - The sturdy little pirates, policemen and farmers of the Playmobil toy series owe their existence to the oil crisis of the 1970's, which drove up the cost of plastic, forcing their German creator to switch from hula hoops to smaller, more economical toys.

title: Justices Curb Postal Service's Immunity From Lawsuits
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 - The Postal Service may be sued by people who trip over packages or other mail that letter carriers have carelessly left in their path, the Supreme Court ruled Wednesday.

title: The Miller Saga Takes Another Strange Twist
description: SESTRIERE, Italy, Feb. 22 - The odds are stacked higher than ever against Bode Miller in the final men's Alpine race of the Olympics, the slalom Saturday. Miller twisted his ankle playing basketball with teammates Tuesday afternoon, and his coaches kept it secret until Wednesday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Oceanside: Infant's Body Found In Laundry
description: A worker at Oceanside Linen Services discovered a dead baby in a bundle of laundry from South Nassau Communities Hospital on Tuesday night, the police said. The worker was sorting a cart of soiled hospital linens when he found the infant girl's body, wrapped in a blanket, the authorities said. The baby had a plastic identification bracelet around her ankle that linked her to the hospital. The baby was born prematurely, on Sunday, weighing 10 ounces and living for only 30 minutes. Hospital staffers wrapped the body and placed it in a trundle in the morgue, said Lt. Dennis Farrell of the Nassau County Police Department. He added that someone probably mistook the wrapped body for soiled linens. SOPHIA CHANG (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLUMBO, ALICIA
description: COLUMBO--Alicia. The Board of Trustees and the Maimonides Medical Center family mourn the passing of Alicia Columbo, mother of our esteemed colleague, Veronica Santilli, M.D. We extend our sincere condolences to Dr. Santilli and her extended family. Martin D. Payson, Chairman, Board of Trustees Pamela S. Brier, President and CEO Maimonides Medical Center

title: China Unveils Plan to Aid Farmers, but Avoids Land Issue
description: BEIJING, Feb. 22 - The Chinese government, faced with rising inequality and unrest in the countryside, formally announced major initiatives this week to expand health, education and welfare benefits for farmers but left unresolved the fundamental issue of whether they should be allowed to buy or sell their land.

title: More on the Furor Over the Ports
description: To the Editor:

title: Declarer Holds a Powerhouse But Doesn''t Have X-Ray Vision
description: Bridge would be so much easier if we used glass cards. They would not even have to come from Tiffany & Company. The diagramed deal, from the Tuesday-Wednesday Knockout Teams at the District 3 Tri-State Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., on Jan. 10 and 11, is a good example.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Milosevic Says His Health Is Worsening
description: Judges for the international tribunal trying Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, for war crimes said they would decide this week on his request to travel to Russia for medical care. Mr. Milosevic has been pressing the court since December to allow him to go to the Bakoulev Scientific Center for Cardiovascular Surgery in Moscow. During his four-year trial he has been examined and treated by Dutch, French, Russian and Serbian specialists for his recurrent high blood pressure and heart and vascular problems, but he has complained that his condition is worsening. During the court session yesterday, Mr. Milosevic stopped questioning a witness because of what he described as "a thundering noise" in his head.

title: Meanwhile: Amateur hour at the Olympics
Corrections
description: A map on Sunday with an article about art theft by Balkan gangs carried an incomplete label for the country in which the crime was committed. It is Serbia and Montenegro; Serbia is a constituent republic.

description: A Piece of Cake A Memoir By Cupcake Brown 470 pages. Crown Publishers. $24.95.

description: Orchids, in Moderation

title: Briefs: Wal-Mart will widen health care eligibility
Haiti's Leader Says Aristide Can End Exile
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 22 - In his first news conference since being declared president of Haiti last week, Ren Prval kept up the mystery swirling around the possible return from exile of former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, saying only that the Constitution permits him to come home if Mr. Aristide so chooses.

title: Knicks Look Like '71 Team, Only Different
description: IT'S kind of like the day Earl (the Pearl) Monroe moved up the seaboard from Baltimore to New York. Kind of. That is to say, the Knicks now have a glut of players with more or less the same skills and job description.

title: Former Postal Worker, Infected in 2001, Still Feels Effects
description: TRENTON, Feb. 22 - First came the chills and fever. Next, it was the needles. And even now, more than four years after Jyotsna Patel was infected with inhalation anthrax, she continues to cope with headaches, memory loss, emotional distress and joint pain so severe that it is hard for her to leave the house.

title: Support for Poultry Vaccination to Fight Flu
description: ROME, Feb. 22 - National and international health authorities are rapidly shifting toward endorsing vaccination campaigns for bird flu as a steady stream of reports of bird deaths flow in from Europe and North Africa. The use of a vaccine is a strategy so far employed only in a few parts of Asia with deeply entrenched problems.

title: Four Hands Make Light Mozart
description: There is reason to think that Classical-era music played by four hands on one piano was intended for an audience of two: the people sitting on the bench. Mozart's four-hand music doesn't necessarily oppose the idea, but his target must have been some very good musicians.

title: A Corrugated House in a Sunburned Land
description: LUBBOCK, Tex. - THE first thing to know about the house Urs Peter Flueckiger built is that he did it for the startlingly low price of $51 a square foot, $50.87 to be exact, by using the kind of bulk metal siding usually associated with airplane hangars and toolsheds. The second thing to know is where he did it: here in the high plains of West Texas, one of the flattest, starkest, most sun-seared places on earth.

title: Iran Pledges Financial Aid to Hamas-Led Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 22 - A senior Iranian official pledged on Wednesday to provide financial support to a Hamas-controlled Palestinian Authority, which is already in budget trouble and facing more aid cuts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUVITT, ANNE

Adoring great-grandmother of Jack, Adam, Andrew, Sam and Maxine. Dear sister of Seymour and Tamara Pristin Graveside services Friday, 1:15 P.M. at Beth El Cemetery, New Jersey.

title: Thomas Taylor, Manager of Money for the Bass Brothers, Dies at 63
description: Thomas Malcolm Taylor, who managed money for the billionaire Bass brothers of Texas for more than 20 years, died Sunday in a snowmobile accident in the Adirondack region of upstate New York. He was 63.

title: Report on Fannie Mae Cites Manipulation to Secure Bonuses
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 A Investigators have uncovered new evidence that senior executives of Fannie Mae, the nation's largest buyer of home mortgages, manipulated its accounting in the 1990's to meet earnings projections so that top executives could receive more than $25 million in bonuses.

description: The efforts by Research in Motion to avoid a shutdown of its BlackBerry wireless e-mail service in the United States received support yesterday from the United States Patent and Trademark Office.

description: Change is not the Knicks' only certainty this season. Add losing to the list.

Adoring grandmother of Sasha and Arielle Chaifetz, Milo, Isaac and Leila Selchaif. Service Friday, 11:15 AM, at "The Riverside", 76th and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Dividing Rooms
description: Q. My sons, ages 7 and 9, share a room. Now one wants to erect a wall for privacy. What can we do?

title: A Dancer Apparently Felled by the Animal Skins on Drums
description: If one were to try to predict an accident befalling Vado Diomande, a natural guess would be a fall from stilts while "mask dancing," a frenetic performance that he was thought not only to have mastered, but one that he believed was his duty to his Ivory Coast ancestors to spread.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COPLEY, NOMA
description: COPLEY - Noma. Beloved companion of Flory Barnett passed away suddenly on February 22, 2006 in her 90th year. Friends are asked, in lieu of flowers, to donate to the Southern Poverty Law Center in memory of Noma.

title: WebMD Wants to Go Beyond Information
description: Marty Wygod, the entrepreneurial deal maker who built WebMD Health into one of the most-visited medical information sites on the Internet, is promoting the site as the next big thing in health care. Will shareholders reap the benefits?

title: In Surprise Stop in Lebanon, Rice Snubs Pro-Syrian President
description: BEIRUT, Feb. 23 A Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice made a surprise visit here today, a stopover whose most notable feature was her decision to snub Emile Lahoud, the pro-Syrian president of Lebanon.

title: Blair Comes to Prince's Defense in Diary Dispute
description: LONDON, Feb. 23 - With a dispute swirling - or, at least, effervescing - around the unplanned publication of a private journal written by Prince Charles, the heir to the British throne, he might be assumed to be in need of a friend.

title: Reporter for Arab TV and 2 colleagues killed in Iraq
Morgan Hires Two From Rivals
description: Morgan Stanley, in a bid to bolster its growing high-yield business, said yesterday that it had hired two senior bond executives from competitors Citigroup and Goldman Sachs.

title: Chinese Report Evidence of Early Semi-Aquatic Mammal
description: Scientists in China have uncovered fossils of a swimming, fish-eating mammal that lived 164 million years ago, well before it was thought that some mammals could have adapted to a semi-aquatic life.

title: More on the Furor Over the Ports
description: To the Editor:

title: Roof falls in Moscow, killing 66
The Transformative Power Of a Fresh Coat of Paint
description: Jorge Pardo, the Los Angeles-based Cuban artist, has painted the largest canvas of his career: the 40,000-square-foot facade of a former warehouse at 1016 Clare Avenue in West Palm Beach, Fla. The building, below, is a sales office for 550Q, a condominium being built nearby. Mr. Pardo created the mural on a computer and supervised painters from Sole Scenic in Orlando, who finished it this month.

title: Religion and politics a deadly mix in Nigeria
Portuguese hideaways outside the Algarve
Small Still, and Fierce, Cohen Has Nerves of Steel Now, Too
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 22 - Sasha Cohen's former coach said she knew the instant she saw Cohen strike a sassy, confident pose to start her Olympic short program Tuesday night that Cohen would fare well. Her current coach insists that despite Cohen's diminutive stature, she is more than tough enough mentally to win Thursday's long program and walk away a gold medalist.

title: Dentist's Surrender Sought in Inquiry Into Plot to Loot Corpses
description: A dentist at the center of a broad investigation involving corpses plundered for bone, tissue and other marketable parts turned himself in last night to the Brooklyn district attorney after receiving an order to surrender, the district attorney's office said.

title: Four Dancers, Four Schools of Training
description: "Kings of the Dance," the all-star display of male ballet dancing with Angel Corella and Ethan Stiefel of American Ballet Theater, Johan Kobborg of the Royal Ballet and Nikolay Tsiskaridze of the Bolshoi Ballet, is an intermittently engaging blockbuster with a divided soul. It opened a four-performance run Thursday at City Center.

title: Animal Longings, in a Light Meow Mix
description: "Indoor/Outdoor," a new play by Kenny Finkle, opened Wednesday night at the DR2 Theater. Directed by Daniel Goldstein, it's a comedy about a house cat, Samantha (Emily Cass McDonnell), who finds herself torn between her affection for a human companion, a nebbishy graphic designer named Shuman (Brian Hutchison), and her attraction to a sexy tomcat, Oscar (Mario Campanaro), who invites her to sample the pleasures of the outdoor life. A neurotic pet therapist, Matilda (Keira Naughton), mediates the conflict.

title: Report puts blame on Fannie Mae officers
Review: The Ice Museum
Tricky Years of Maneuver Ahead for Proposed Gas Pipeline
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 22 - A conditional agreement between Alaska and three big energy companies may be, as Gov. Frank H. Murkowski put it, a milestone toward building a natural gas pipeline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORIARTY, JAMES P.
description: MORIARTY--James P. On February 22, 2006. Manhattan College School of Engineering, Class of 1954. Postgraduate studies NYU and Columbia. Veteran United States Army Corps of Engineers. President of T. Moriarty & Son. Past President of the Emerald Society of Long Island, the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick and the St. Patrick Society of Brooklyn. Co-Founder and Chairman of the Cardinal's Committee for the Laity. Past Grand Marshal of the Brooklyn and the Rockaway St. Patrick's Day Parade. Selected by President Reagan to accompany him to the 40th Anniversary of D-Day in Normandy. Erected the United States Memorial Garden in Caen, France to commemorate the 50th Anniversary of the Invasion of Normandy. N.Y.S. Representative of the U.S. Congressional Advisory Board. Commissioner of the Brooklyn Bridge Centennial Celebration. Member of the Board of Directors of Dromoland Castle in Ireland and Nazareth High School. Board Member of the Ireland-U.S. Council. Member of the Executive Committee of the General Contractors Association as well as a member of the Knights of Malta and other charitable organizations. Beloved husband of 52 years to Anna (nee McLaughlin). Loving father of James (Marie), Anne Marie and Terence. Dear brother of Catherine, Mary and Teresa. Proud grandfather of Victoria, Cassie and Terence. Visiting Thursday and Friday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 10AM at St. Francis de Sales, 129-16 Rockaway Beach Boulevard, Belle Harbor. In lieu of flowers, donations to Manhattan College, Manhattan College Parkway, Riverdale NY 10471 for a scholarship to be named in his memory would be greatly appreciated.

title: Just for Fun, Casual Games Thrive Online
description: Not all gamers choose games based on how much adrenaline they muster, how elaborate the play is or how realistic the graphics are. Many looking for quick entertainment would instead prefer simplicity in their digital diversions.

title: Strangers at the Door
description: Washington - WHO could have imagined that, in the post-9/11 world, the United States government would approve a deal giving control over six major American ports to a country with ties to terrorism? But this is exactly what the secretive Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States has done.

title: N.F.L. Labor Talks Continue
description: With a deadline for a new collective-bargaining agreement looming, negotiators for National Football League's owners and the players' union met in Indianapolis yesterday and are scheduled to meet again today. Gene Upshaw, the head of the union, has set this weekend as a deadline for a new agreement. If no deal is reached, Upshaw has said, the 2006 season would be the last one played under a salary cap.

title: U.S. Sees Emirates as Both Ally and, Since 9/11, a Foe
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 - When the United Arab Emirates paid $6.5 billion for 80 advanced F-16 fighters from Lockheed Martin in 2000, the deal was applauded by members of Congress and local American officials as a milestone that would solidify relations and help preserve thousands of American aerospace jobs.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Premier Won't Block Utility Bid
description: Prime Minister Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero said that he would not use the government's so-called golden share in the electricity company Endesa to block its acquisition by the German utility E.On, a sign that Spain may be charting a different course from other European countries that are fiercely resisting cross-border acquisitions. Speaking in Parliament, Mr. Zapatero called Endesa a strategic asset for the economy. But he said the government did not plan to take advantage of its legal option to block the 29.1 billion euro ($34.7 billion) bid through its majority voting rights. The European Commission, meanwhile, warned Spain that it was still not in compliance with a ruling by the European Court of Justice in 2003 that outlawed the golden share in Endesa. The share, which was retained by the government during the privatization of Spain's energy industry, is to expire in June 2007. RENWICK McLEAN (NYT)

title: Knicks Deal 2 Backups For Another Star Guard
description: Steve Francis became a Knick yesterday, pushing the franchise's haphazard, fantastically expensive rebuilding process into a strange new phase.

title: A Specialist Brings N.F.L. Prospects Up to Speed
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. Feb. 20 - In the back of Disney's Wide World of Sports Complex here, 9-year-old girls ran around on a soccer field a few hundred yards away from 300-pound football players, some of the N.F.L.'s top prospects who had decided to go to camp to prepare for the league's scouting combine.

title: Insurance Dispute in Fatal Capsizing May Leave Survivors With Nothing but Debts
description: Five months after the Ethan Allen tour boat capsized under a clear sky in Lake George, N.Y., killing 20 of the 48 people onboard, the operator of the boat said yesterday that he could not pay out claims to survivors and the families of those who died because his insurance company contended that his policy covered accidents occurring on land, not water.

title: Hewlett-Packard Decides Store Photo Printing Is Its Turf
description: You can shoot a digital picture -- one of 140 billion snapped last year -- with a Hewlett-Packard camera. You can print that photo on a Hewlett PhotoSmart printer at home. Or you can upload the shot to Snapfish.com, which is owned by Hewlett-Packard, and have it send you prints.

title: 4 Ballet Kings From 4 Countries
description: Let's get the obvious out of the way. The title of "Kings of the Dance" -- a new ballet showcase for four marvelous male dancers, Angel Corella, Johan Kobborg, Ethan Stiefel and Nikolai Tsiskaridze -- is unfortunate at best, and a bit humiliating at worst. Of course, it's all about marketing. And "Lord" was already taken.

title: Freestyle Skiing: For China's Han, a historic victory
French Officials Now Say Killing of Jew Was in Part a Hate Crime
description: PARIS, Feb. 22 - French authorities say a young Jewish man who was tortured and killed here this month was singled out because of his religion, supporting claims by French Jews that his killing was in part a hate crime.

title: In Front of Friends and Relatives of Victims, Killer of 2 Detectives Gets Life Without Parole
description: For the murders of two detectives answering a call from his mother, Marlon Legere was sentenced yesterday to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

title: From the Dakota to the Danube
description: Budapest - YOU could say furniture was responsible for much of what has happened in life to Sam Havadtoy.

title: When a Bit of Benign Neglect Keeps the Boat From Rocking
description: If you want to know who Andrea Barca is, translate Andras Schiff's name into Italian. Mr. Schiff's Cappella Andrea Barca is in Carnegie Hall this week for three concerts of Mozart, and the title of his little band -- it could have been Orchestre d'Andr Bateau, or maybe the Andie Boat Orchestra -- gives him a chance to have his little fun, including a spurious biography in the program notes.

title: Facing Up to the Past: Japan Makes Its Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan seeks arrests of 2 North Koreans
Europe, Asia, Africa
description: EUROPE

title: Soprano Embraces the New as Audiences Follow Suit
description: Audiences don't like new music, yet new music is good for the health of the classical music field. That in a nutshell is the conventional wisdom. So presenters are continually striving to find ways to make contemporary works, the "vegetables" of the repertory, more palatable to consumers. Some audience members give lip service to their nutritional value; most would rather be eating dessert in the form of Beethoven, Rossini or Mozart.

title: Getting From Here to There, With a Musical Backdrop
description: Portable navigation systems that sit on dashboards can be moved from car to car, but they typically have small screens and controls that can be hard to reach. Built-in navigation-entertainment systems have bigger screens and convenient controls, but they can't be transferred to another car. The PMD-B100 Blackbird from Alpine combines features from both types.

title: Wallpaper-Hanging Routines That Don't Sink to Slapstick
description: Wallpaper often seems like a good idea until it has to be hung or removed. Now a few companies are easing those practical issues. Waverly has six collections, including Urban Attitude, left, that are easy to handle because the paste goes on the wall, not the paper. And the papers can be peeled off in one piece rather than scraped; $32.99 to $36.99 a roll; waverly.com or (800) 423-5881. Chesapeake Wallcoverings has prepasted papers that are dampened with water but don't absorb it. They hang easily and can be peeled off in full sheets. Double rolls are $68; cheswall.com or (800) 275-2037.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the importance of early treatment in anthrax cases referred incorrectly to the medical phenomenon known as pleural effusion. It is a buildup of fluids in the chest that can result from anthrax infection; it is not a procedure for draining those fluids.

title: New York City Man Has Inhalation Anthrax, Officials Say
description: A 44-year-old New York City man contracted inhalation anthrax last week from working with untreated animal hides in the first naturally occurring case of the illness in the United States in 30 years, officials announced yesterday.

title: Carlos y Carlos: Together at Last
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 22 - Carlos Delgado and Carlos Beltran were chatting with Fred Wilpon, the Mets' principal owner, next to the cage during batting practice Wednesday morning, when a batted ball ricocheted off the pitcher's protective screen and whizzed toward Beltran's head. He did not see it coming, but Delgado did. He snagged the ball a split-second before it would have smacked Beltran, averting the sort of misfortune that seemed to follow Beltran quite regularly last season.

title: Supplements Fail to Stop Arthritis Pain, Study Says
description: Correction Appended

title: Selling Junk Food to Toddlers
description: For all the talk about protecting children in America, too many of our youngest are threatened by a steady blast of industrial-strength advertising on children's television. Some ads, like those for toys and games, mostly threaten the family budget. But the commercials hawking sugary treats or empty calories can be more pernicious. Many health professionals now fear that junk-food advertising to toddlers and pre-teenagers is contributing to soaring rates of obesity and diabetes among the young.

title: Students E-Mail the Oddest Things
description: To the Editor:

title: 77 deaths on Runion laid to fever
White House Report Advises Revamping Disaster Response
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 - The nation must revamp the way it responds to major disasters or terrorist attacks, according to a new White House report that calls for more stockpiling of emergency supplies, a better-defined role for the military and a more concerted push to evacuate hospitals and nursing homes.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: A Modern Urban Concert Hall, Conceived as a Clearing in a Forest
description: In 1997, when Christian de Portzamparc, the Pritzker prize-winning French architect, was chosen to design the Grande-Duchesse Josphine-Charlotte Concert Hall in Luxembourg, he wanted to surround it with trees. "The idea was to create a filter between the exterior and the interior, in order to enter a field of music," he said. When he visited the site, however, he saw that there was no room for trees, and instead he created a filter with 823 columns that wrap around the recently finished, $108 million building, below. The architect describes a spiral ramp on the outside of the concert hall, bottom, as "a prismatic cliff," lighted by neon tubes that constantly change the colors of the walls.

title: Briefs: Coup attempt rumored in the Philippines
James E. Hinton, Chronicler in Pictures of 1960's Turbulence, Dies at 69
description: James E. Hinton Jr., a documentary photographer who chronicled the racial and social upheavals of the 1960's, died on Sunday at a hospital in the Bronx. He was 69 and lived in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Mr. Musharraf's Other War
description: If the Bush administration is wondering why the Pakistani Army has been losing the war against Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters in the northwestern frontier, it may want to look south. Pakistan's military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, has increasingly been diverting his armed forces to quell a growing insurgency in Baluchistan, the gas-rich province that borders Iran and the Arabian Sea.

title: A Milk Bone? Humph! Only Truffles Will Do
description: THIS is what it's come to on Fifth Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, a once-mean street now practically paved with foie gras.

title: Dutch diplomat says Mladic is unwell
New York history in an oyster shell
Dolce & Gabbana's imperial dreams
Saluting a Man Who Lent His Rhythms to Latin Life
description: Dozens of Puerto Rican men arrived well before noon yesterday outside a Manhattan funeral home for the wake of the Latin percussionist and bandleader Ray Barretto, who died on Friday at age 76.

title: Christianslead Korea rights drive
Paid Notice: Memorials   DENENY, JOHN FRANCIS
description: DENENY -- John Francis. Dad, the older I get, the more I understand life as you saw it. You were the best. Love, Joan

title: EU ponders bypassing Hamas on aid
Paid Notice: Memorials   MUFSON, JOANNA
description: MUFSON--Joanna. 8/16/69 to 2/23/83. "I only know that summer sang in me a little while, that in me sings no more." Love, Mom.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about members of Congress and their aides who are married to lobbyists referred imprecisely to Debbie Dingell (identified in the article only as the wife of Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, and shown in a picture with him at their Dearborn home). While Ms. Dingell advises General Motors on lobbying strategy in her role as executive director of community and government relations, she is not currently a registered lobbyist. (Go to Article)

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Ken Keuffel, 82, a Champion of the Single-Wing Offense, Is Dead
description: Ken Keuffel, the head football coach for 21 years at the Lawrenceville School in New Jersey and for 6 years at Wabash College and one of the last exponents of the single-wing offense, died Sunday at the University Medical Center in Princeton, N.J. He was 82 and lived in Lawrenceville, outside Princeton.

title: Enforcer Paints Picture of Gotti as Powerful Don
description: It was Christmas Eve 1988, Michael DiLeonardo said, when Jackie D'Amico, a captain in the Gambino crime family, told him, "Put a suit on, you're going to get straightened out."

title: A Messy Romance With Faded Grandeur
description: "IT was really a beast of a house," Belinda Rathbone said, sitting in the living room of her six-room condo in the Avon Hill section of Cambridge, Mass., on a crisp winter Sunday afternoon. Ms. Rathbone, a photography historian, was describing her initial impressions of the Guynd, a handsome but decaying Georgian mansion in northeast Scotland where she lived for 10 years with her now-estranged husband, John Ouchterlony, the 26th laird of his family's 400-year-old ancestral estate.

title: Malone Had Plan for a Role as Icahn Moved on Time Warner
description: It turns out that John C. Malone was interested in capitalizing on Carl C. Icahn's planned proxy fight at Time Warner, as well.

title: Scientists Again Defend Study on Vioxx
description: With a crucial personal-injury trial over Vioxx set to begin in New Jersey next week, the debate heated up again yesterday about whether Merck understated the drug's risks in a journal article in November 2000.

title: Sects and Violence
description: Monterey, Calif. - THE bombing of the Golden Mosque in Samarra, Iraq, is an ominous development for America, Iraq and the entire Middle East. Just when it looked as if Muslims across the region were putting aside their differences to unite in protest against the Danish cartoons, the attack showed that Islamic sectarianism remains the greatest challenge to peace. It also highlighted the poor job America has done in trying to balance the interests of Shiite and Sunni Muslims in Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STILLMAN, ISRAEL H.
description: STILLMAN--Israel H. In his 93rd year. Adoring husband and soulmate of Leona, married for 66 wonderful years. Loving father of Celine and Pascal and Tom and Kathy. Grandfather of very special granddaughter Isabelle. A man of compassion, generosity and humor. Always true to himself, he lived an enviable life to the very end. We will miss him. Donations to: Jewish Guild for Blind. Memorial service: Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave at 91 St, Thursday February 23 at 12:15PM.

description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Thursday, Feb. 23 - Saudi Arabia on Wednesday joined the list of Arab countries that said they were unwilling to cut off money to Hamas, as the United States has requested.

title: The Dissident Prince: Public, Prickly and Very Political
description: LONDON, Feb. 22 - British monarchs are supposed to be inscrutable to the point of banality. If they have interesting opinions about things like politics and foreign policy -- and it is not always clear that they do -- they are expected to keep them quiet.

title: Sectarian Fury Turns Violent in Wake of Iraq Shrine Blast
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 23 A At least 138 Iraqis, mostly Sunni Arabs and including some clerics, were killed in central Iraq Wednesday and today in the maelstrom of sectarian violence that followed the insurgent bombing of one of the country's most sacred Shiite shrines, Iraqi officials said.

title: Dow Jones Plans to Merge Online and Print Divisions
description: Dow Jones & Company, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, announced yesterday that it would merge its print and online operations, putting them under the control of L. Gordon Crovitz, who had been president of the company's online unit.

WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (NBC) 2006 OLYMPIC WINTER GAMES -- Sasha Cohen (above), the 21-year-old American figure skater, knocked the judges' socks off on Tuesday night, putting her slightly ahead of Irina Slutskaya of Russia. Emily Hughes, 17, was in seventh place after the women's short program. They meet again tonight in the women's free-skate competition. Tonight's other events, tape delayed from Turin, Italy, are freestyle skiing (men's aerials) and snowboarding (women's parallel giant slalom).

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Small Business section on Tuesday about Y Combinator, a venture capital firm that runs a boot camp and provides seed money for start-up companies, misstated the amount of equity it takes in them. The partners collectively own 1.2 to 12 percent of the start-ups, with an average of 6 percent -- not an average of 6 percent per person.

title: Nothing Inspirational About Modano and American Team
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 22 - Winning a gold medal would have been too much for the United States Olympic hockey team. Making a graceful exit has proven difficult enough.

title: Woods Gives a Healthy Pounding to Ames
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., Feb. 22 - It is supposed to be hard going from a sick bed to golf's version of bare-knuckle boxing, but there was Tiger Woods at La Costa Resort and Spa on Wednesday, healthy and mixing it up at the Match Play Championship, hammering a fellow golfer who dared to needle him.

description: The work of taking what the rest of the world makes and moving it to American consumers went on as usual in New York Harbor yesterday. Giant cranes lifted steel containers off the decks of some of the world's biggest ships and stacked them for transfer onto trucks and trains bound for warehouses and stores.

title: Vice Chairman of the Fed, a Greenspan Ally, Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 - Roger W. Ferguson Jr., whose views on policy matters at the Federal Reserve meshed closely with those of Alan Greenspan, resigned Wednesday as vice chairman of the central bank, less than a month after Mr. Greenspan's departure.

description: Daniel Bejar is the Vancouver singer-songwriter who performs as Destroyer. And with each of his last three albums, he has included something that's both indispensable and more or less useless: a lyric sheet.

description: FRIEDLAND--Sidney S., 74, Hartsdale, NY, died suddenly on February 20, 2006. title: World Briefing | Europe: France: 3 Photographers Fined A Euro For Diana Crash Pictures
description: A Paris appeals court has imposed a symbolic fine of one euro -- just over a dollar -- on three paparazzi for breaching France's privacy laws when they took pictures of Diana, Princess of Wales, and her boyfriend, Emad Mohamed al-Fayed, known as Dodi, on Aug. 31, 1997, the night they died in a car crash in Paris. The three paparazzi -- Jacques Langevin, Fabrice Chassery and Christian Martinez -- along with others who were chasing the couple's limousine, were earlier cleared of any criminal responsibility in the crash.

title: Corrections

Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, and shown in a picture with him at their Dearborn home). While Ms. Dingell advises General Motors on lobbying strategy in her role as executive director of community and government relations, she is not currently a registered lobbyist. (Go to Article)

description: In the small, impoverished West African nation of Ivory Coast, the ancient plague of anthrax still thrives, infecting and killing animals at one of the highest rates in all of Africa, according to the World Health Organization.

title: At Harvard, Resignation Puts Big Plans on Pause
description: Officials at Harvard University faced a divided campus yesterday along with fear that a search for a new president could put in limbo ambitious plans for an expansive new campus in Boston, an overhaul of undergraduate studies and a fund-raising campaign for $5 billion or more.

description: Four auditors from KPMG who were involved in its audits of the Xerox Corporation settled suits yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, with two of them agreeing to pay the largest fines ever levied by the commission against individual auditors.

title: Roof Collapse in Moscow Kills at Least 51
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 23 A A roof laden with snow collapsed over a vegetable market in the Basmanny suburb of Moscow early today, killing at least 51 people, mostly young men from Central Asia and the Caucasus who worked as laborers and produce traders.

title: Voter Groups See Flaws in Plan to Upgrade Balloting
description: ALBANY, Feb. 22 - Voter advocacy groups contended on Wednesday that New York was moving forward with a flawed proposal to modernize its voting system that could lead to widespread security problems on Election Day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHANE, JAKOB T., MD.
description: COHANE--Jakob T., MD. Jaks sheer brilliance, his mastery of seven languages, his insight into human nature and his gentleness endeared him to all those lives he touched. Against all odds, Jak put himself through medical school, he became a renowned internist, specializing in endocrinology, then recognizing the emotional pain of so many of his patients he became a Psychiatrist. His psychiatric residency was at New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center followed by a private practice in psychiatry. He retired in 1995. Jak will be sorely missed and leaves us all with loving memories. Andy, Joyce, Devona, Andrew & Jakob Morrissey

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Monday about the absence of black drivers in Olympic bobsled competition referred incorrectly in some copies to the distinction held by Joe McDonald on the World Cup tour. He was its first African-American driver; black drivers from other nations had competed on the tour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELKINS, JAMES ANDERSON JR.
description: ELKINS--James Anderson Jr. Loving husband, father, grandfather, and friend, died February 21, 2006. Born March 24, 1919 on Galveston Island to Isabel Sims Mitchell and -Judge-J. A. Elkins, he attended Kinkaid School, San Jacinto High School, The Hill School, and Princeton University, graduating in 1941. At thirteen, he began his career in banking as a runner for the City National Bank, retiring 56 years later as Senior Chairman of First City National Bank in 1988. He married the love of his life, Margaret Keith Wiess, on November 24, 1945, and due to their shared interest in the citizens of Houston, they made significant contributions to the business, civic, and cultural lives of the city they loved. In addition to his banking activities, he served as a director of American General, Cameron Iron Works, Eastern Airlines, Freeport-McMoran, and the Hill-Samuel Group, Ltd. He was involved with numerous organizations in Houston and served as a trustee or director of Baylor College of Medicine, Central Houston, Houston Grand Opera, the Menil Foundation, Princeton University, St. John's School, National Board of the Smithsonian Institute, Society for the Performing Arts, Texas Children's Hospital, and the University of Houston Board of Regents. Mr. Elkins was predeceased by his beloved wife of fifty-four wonderful years, his parents, and his brother, William Sims Elkins, and is survived by his children, Elise Elkins Joseph and husband Russell, James Anderson Elkins III and wife Jenny, and Leslie Elkins Sasser and husband Shannon; his grandchildren Jennifer Joseph Laporte and husband Christopher, Russell Charles Joseph Jr., Christopher Elkins Joseph, Margaret Wiess Elkins, James Anderson Elkins IV, Buck Arnold Elkins, John Caldwell Elkins, Harry Carothers Elkins, Samuel Hill Elkins, Lucy Gray Elkins, and Caroline Elise Sasser; and his nieces and nephew, Ann Elkins Flaten, Ellen Elkins DeGregory, William Sims Elkins Jr., Sandra Isabel Lloyd, Sharon Smith Keller, and Sydney Carothers Keith. Geo. H. Lewis & Sons (713) 789-3005.

title: Pataki Is Up and Around After Week of Hospitalization
description: Gov. George E. Pataki passed the one-week mark in the hospital last night as he recovered from unexpected complications from his appendectomy, and state officials said they did not know when he would be released.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 3 Charged In Check-Cashing Fraud
description: The three owners of a check-cashing business on Eighth Avenue have been indicted on charges of violating state banking laws and falsifying business records, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, said yesterday. The owners, Vadim Vassilenko, Yelena Barysheva and their son, Alexey Baryshev, run Western Express, an unlicensed check-cashing business at Eighth Avenue and 38th Street, Mr. Morgenthau said. Prosecutors said the business had illegally cashed checks and transmitted money on behalf of clients in Russia and Eastern Europe. From 2002 to 2005, $25 million passed through the business, prosecutors said. Mr. Vassilenko, 39, and Ms. Barysheva, 40, pleaded not guilty. Mr. Baryshev, 21, is a fugitive, prosecutors said.

title: Calm on the Waterfront
description: The terminal operator's change in ownership will have little effect on the daily life of the Port of New York, officials said. Page A18.

title: A Journey With Schubert From Restraint to Passion
description: Philippe Castagner, a tenor who won the Young Concert Artists auditions last year, has popped onto the radar in other connections as well. He has sung small roles at the Metropolitan Opera (having won the company's National Council Auditions in 2002), and in recent months he gave good accounts of himself in a chamber concert with Richard Goode and in Handel's "Messiah" at Carnegie Hall. On Tuesday evening, as part of his Young Concert Artists prize, he made his New York recital debut at Zankel Hall.

title: 19th-Century Art Sold the 21st-Century Way
description: With hedge fund managers and investment bankers busy calculating their next big art purchases, prices for paintings and photographs are being driven to record highs. Julian Merrow-Smith, a British painter living in the French village of Bdoin, near Avignon, has pushed off in the opposite direction. Nearly every day, in a project he calls Postcards From Provence, he creates a tiny oil painting and puts it up on the Web with a price tag fixed at $100 (plus tax and shipping).

title: Kicking Arabs in the Teeth
description: It's come to my attention that many of the foreign goods we import into our country are made by foreigners who speak foreign languages and are foreign. It's come to my attention that many varieties of hummus and other vital bread schmears are made by Arabs, the group responsible for 9/11. Furthermore, it's come to my attention that the Chinese have a menacing death grip on America's pacifier, blankie, bunny and rattle supplies, and have thus established crushing domination of the entire non-pharmaceutical child sedative industry.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Feb. 14 about a growing belief among psychotherapists that revisiting one's past is not essential for emotional healing referred imprecisely to the origins of a form of therapy that focuses on the present. The technique, cognitive behavioral therapy, was introduced by Aaron T. Beck and Albert Ellis, not by Dr. Beck alone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FAHEY, ELIZABETH K.
description: FAHEY--Elizabeth K. Died peacefully of old age in her 98th year. A woman of grace she is survived by her son, Msgr. Charles J. Fahey of Fordham University and the Milbank Memorial Fund. Her life was celebrated with a Mass of the Resurrection at Loretto, Syracuse where she and her beloved husband spent the latter part of their lives in the midst of skillful, loving care. A memorial Mass will be celebrated at Loyola Hall, Fordham University at a date to be announced. Contributions may be made to the Loretto Foundation.

title: Consumer Prices Rose in January, Report Says
description: Sharp increases in energy and food costs pushed consumer prices higher last month, but prices of other goods and services rose more modestly, the government reported yesterday.

title: Ban on Most Abortions Advances in South Dakota
description: PIERRE, S.D., Feb. 22 - Setting up South Dakota to become the first state in 14 years to start a direct legal attack on Roe v. Wade, lawmakers voted on Wednesday to outlaw nearly all abortions.

title: Bronx Complexes Going Co-op, and the Tenants Are Behind It
description: The tenants of two large working-class apartment complexes in the Bronx announced yesterday that they had arranged for a group of real estate investors to buy the buildings, turn the units into co-ops and sell them to current residents at prices they can afford -- a development with few precedents in the overheated New York housing market.

title: Claim Filed by Mother of Officer Who Died
description: The mother of the off-duty police officer fatally shot by another officer outside a Bronx fast food restaurant in late January filed a legal claim against New York City and the Police Department late yesterday, the lawyer for the mother said.

title: Playing With Pension Reform
description: Delta could soon become the third major airline in the past two years to default on its pensions. If it does, federal pension insurance would cover some $8.4 billion in benefits. Even so, many Delta employees could end up with less than they expected. And American taxpayers would move closer to the prospect of having to bail out the federal pension insurance agency.

title: No Justice, No Peace
description: If you talk to Maher Arar long enough, even on the telephone, you'll get the disturbing sense that you are speaking with someone whose life has been shattered like a pane of glass.

title: Defrosting The Refrigerator On the Outside
description: Now that stainless steel is so "very, very mainstream," said Rusty Zay, the vice president and general manager of Jenn-Air, upscale kitchen designers are casting about for what he calls a warmer, richer look. Meet Jenn-Air's fall 2006 line of "oiled bronze" appliances. Hand-finished to give off more complex hues than copper, Mr. Zay said, they can pick up other colors in the kitchen and -- when cabinets are coordinated -- might even fade discreetly into the background. As befits a luxury product aimed at early adopters, oiled bronze appliances will be priced above last year's models in stainless steel: dishwashers will be about $950 and refrigerators about $2,800.

title: Top Kazakh Aide Quits in Crisis After Killing of Opposition Figure
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan, Feb. 22 - President Nursultan Nazarbayev, struggling to stem a deepening political crisis, accepted the resignation of his chief national security officer on Wednesday, one day after five members of an elite national security squad were arrested in connection with the killing of a leading opposition politician.

description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 22 - Microsoft's antitrust battle in Europe intensified Wednesday when some of its biggest rivals filed a new complaint against it, accusing the company of a wide range of antitrust abuses.

New York Adds a Flagship and a Boutique
description: Calypso, the NoLIta purveyor of silk skirts and tunics and beaded blouses, has just opened a five-level store (below) at the corner of Madison Avenue and 68th Street, the former home of a Versace boutique. The new flagship has the capacity of a department store -- offering everything from shoes, jewelry and women's and children's clothing to housewares and linens -- but still maintains the boutique feel of the company's other shops, like Calypso Bijoux, Calypso Enfant and Calypso Home. The goods are arranged by floor, from jewelry and accessories on the first floor to housewares on the fifth.

title: Do You Know the Way to Sagittarius? Here's Help
description: The ancients who first described constellations certainly had vivid imaginations; so vivid, in fact, that with the exception of a few, like the Big Dipper, many star clusters bear virtually no resemblance to the creatures, people or objects they supposedly represent.

title: Star Going Supernova, in Front of Many Eyes
description: A star in a galaxy not so far way, at least in cosmic terms, is exploding, astronomers say.

title: Congress's $2 Billion Typo
description: Parliamentary finagling and arm-twisting abounded earlier this month when the House gave final passage -- by two votes -- to a $39 billion package of controversial spending cuts. President Bush quickly signed it into law. Whoops, as they say in the sausage-making business: because of a clerk's mistake, the House bill was not precisely the same as the one that was passed on a similarly narrow vote in the Senate.

title: Tokyo court convicts Red Army leader
Paid Notice: Deaths   ADLER, GERALDINE KOEPPEL
description: ADLER--Geraldine Koeppel, died at peace on February 21, 2006. Beloved wife of the late H. Henry Adler, M.D. Devoted mother of Edward A.K. Adler (Karen), Alyson Adler Green (William). Adoring grandmother of Alexander A. Green (Sarah), Heather A. Schoen (Frank), Courtenay A. Green and Trevor T. Adler. Cherished sister of Bevin D. Koeppel (Maureen), Louise K. Feldman, Grace K. Gold (Eugene) and the late Selma Friedman (survived by Theodore) and Alfred J. Koeppel (survived by Ruth). Her zest for life, kindness, thoughtfulness, and great love for her family are her enduring legacies. Services at Temple Beth El, 5 Old Mill Rd., Great Neck, on Friday, February 24, at 11:30 AM.

title: Arts, Briefly; A Valentine's Success
description: Jaheim, an R&B singer from New Jersey whose specialty is romantic ballads, timed the release of his third album, "Ghetto Classics" (Warner Brothers), below, to Valentine's Day, and the gimmick paid off: the album became his first to reach No. 1 on the Billboard chart. It sold 152,000 copies in its first week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, pushing last week's best seller, Jack Johnson's soundtrack to "Curious George" (Universal), to No. 2; Barry Manilow held at No. 3, while Mary J. Blige was No. 4 and Andrea Bocelli No. 5. Some of the biggest gains last week were in the bottom half of the Top 10: "High School Musical" (Disney), the soundtrack to the hit television musical, rose seven spots to No. 6 with a 32 percent weekly increase, and the "American Idol" alumna Carrie Underwood (No. 7) and the British singer James Blunt (No. 8) had sales bumps as well. BEN SISARIO

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: School Workers To Pay Back Tuition
description: Ten employees of the New York City public school system have acknowledged that they improperly send their children to city schools even though they live outside of the five boroughs, a spokesman for the Department of Education, David Cantor, said yesterday. The employees came forward early in a monthlong amnesty allowing nonresident school employees to pay the tuition they owe, about $5,500 a year. The program was announced last week, after a report by the Special Commissioner of Investigation for the city schools found that Lee D. McCaskill, the former principal of Brooklyn Technical High School, and his wife, a teacher, had improperly sent their daughter to a Brooklyn public school although they live in New Jersey. ELISSA GOOTMAN (NYT)

A Jerk Worth Spending Time With
description: FilmJerk slices, dices, annotates and crunches all sorts of numbers in search of Oscar insight. By the Jerks math, which was re-done yesterday to eliminate a few bumps, Brokeback Mountain is a clear numerical favorite. The site does come up with a few stats that will give pause to some about a few things, including the runaway favorite candidacy of Philip Seymour Hoffman as best actor. The actor nominated in a film that was the lowest-grossing of the group has never won the ultimate prize. And a number of metrics, all taken together, point to Keira Knightley, not Reese Witherspoon, as best actress. Matt Dillon gets the edge over St. George in the supporting category, but favorite Rachel Weisz comes out on top in the computations. What does it all mean? Not a great deal, as the site points out, but when is the last time that so much math got spent to such frivolous, fun ends?

title: Makeover at Mohonk
description: FOR 137 years Mohonk Mountain House, a resort blending rustic simplicity and Victorian-era formality on the outskirts of New Paltz, N.Y., has stood for timeless pleasures. Still run by the same Quaker family that founded it, Mohonk clings to tradition. Rooms are large and comfortable, but devoid of television sets, radios -- even clocks. Jackets are required for men at dinner. On summer Sundays, there is a nondenominational worship service in the Parlor, while every day at 4 p.m., guests gather for tea and cookies in the Lake Lounge.

But that's nothing new -- the administration has spent the past four and a half years refusing to do anything serious about protecting the nation's ports.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Killer Sentenced To Juvenile Center
description: A teenager convicted of murdering his father, stepmother and stepsister on a ranch owned by the newscaster Sam Donaldson was sentenced by a state judge to be held in a juvenile center until he reached age 21. The judge rejected arguments by prosecutors that the boy, Cody Posey, 16, who was 14 when the killings occurred in 2004, was unlikely to respond to therapy and should be sentenced as an adult to a prison term of as much as 50 years. Defense lawyers argued that he carried out the killings after years of abuse by his father, the foreman of the ranch near Hondo. On Wednesday, the teenager took the stand at his sentencing hearing and apologized for the killings. STEVE BARNES (NYT)

title: At 71, Still Celebrating Victories on the Slopes

Mr. Funk contemplated the gold medal he had just won. "This has been my best year ever in ski racing," he said.

title: In Bridgeport, Hockey, a Zoo and Barnum's World
description: IT was the second period of a closely contested ice hockey game, and Lauren DiFullio, 14, watched intently as the skaters prepared a five-on-three power play. The Sound Tigers of Bridgeport, Conn., quickly scored against the Admirals of Norfolk, Va., and the crowd went wild. Ms. DiFullio, clad in the home team's blue, gold and white jersey, let out a war whoop, settled back into her seat and high-fived her father. Around the arena, fans began doing the wave as enormous video screens flashed and rock music blared.

title: As Violence Ebbs, Iraqi Leaders Seek to Contain the Crisis

title: The White Mountains, the Wildcat River and a Serene Village
description: JACKSON'S town center, a tiny village of clapboard buildings and a 19th-century school, sits in a deep bowl in the Mount Washington Valley, surrounded by the White Mountain National Forest. Nearby, houses are tucked into the wooded hillsides. Coming into town from the south, through a one-lane covered bridge, is like crossing over into a bygone era. "It's a very relaxed environment," said Bob Denaro, an engineer from Nashua, N.H., who, with his wife, Beth, owns a Jackson vacation house.

title: Corrections
description: An article last April 19 about a Supreme Court decision to hear a case on whether the government could ban imports of a hallucinogenic tea central to the religious rituals of a small Brazil-based church included an incorrect spelling from court documents for the name of the religious organization. (The error was repeated in an article on Nov. 2.) The church is O Centro Esprita Beneficente Unio do Vegetal -- not Beneficiente. The misspelling came to light on Tuesday when the court corrected it in ruling that the government could not use federal narcotics laws to ban the tea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COX, DONALD M.
description: COX--Donald M. The trustees and staff of the American Federation of Arts are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and Vice President of the Board, Donald M. Cox. We will be forever grateful for his many contributions and immense generosity to the organization during his 26 years as a member of the Board, five as Board President. He was a man of integrity and thoughtfulness who cared deeply about art. His philanthropy, including the New Initiative Fund he established for the AFA, was visionary as well as munificent. He will be greatly missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Maria, and his nieces and nephews. Gilbert H. Kinney, Chairman Frank B. Bennett, President Julia Brown, Director

The original French text is by Alain Boublil and Jean-Marc Natel; the English lyrics are by Herbert Kretzmer, with additional material by James Fenton. The music was composed by Claude-Michel Schnberg.

title: The Listings: Feb. 24 - March 2; KT TUNSTALL
description: The Scottish-born singer KT Tunstall has a strong voice that in the same chorus can rasp like a blues mama and giggle like a giddy kid. This multi-instrumentalist pop songwriter's breakout single, "Black Horse and the Cherry Tree," with its jump-rope clack rhythms and forceful, dark minor-chord acoustic guitar strumming, offers a fresh twist on old folkie blues. Though the rest of her music may not break much new ground, Ms. Tunstall's debut album, "Eye to the Telescope," is happily occupied with grown-up concerns. Having paid her dues in bands in the United States, Ms. Tunstall has just won a Brit Award for best British female solo artist. There is lots of promise to her album, with some songs suggesting a bouncier Fiona Apple and others, less interestingly, conjuring a pricklier Dido or Nellie Furtado. Ms. Tunstall is touring here now amid buzz generated by the rainbow suspenders she sports over a sparkling shirt on her album's cover shot, interpreted by some fans as a lesbian symbol. Ms. Tunstall has said that she didn't know of the connection, but for a rising star, at this point, you assume any chatter is welcome chatter. (KT Tunstall plays a sold-out show Thursday night at 8 at the Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111; $15.)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Lebanon: Rice Snubs President
description: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice made a surprise visit to Beirut but decided to snub President mile Lahoud. "I've already met him," she explained. Her stated purpose for flying several thousand miles out of her way for a four-hour stay near the end of a Middle East tour was to show "support for the Lebanese people and the Lebanese government as they continue to recover their sovereignty." She held a news conference with Prime Minister Fouad Siniora and met with Christian, Muslim and Druse leaders, but the great divide now, as the State Department apparently sees it, is between the Lebanese politicians like Mr. Lahoud who supported Syria during its long occupation and those who did not. Parliament is debating whether to remove Mr. Lahoud from office. Asked for her view, Ms. Rice said that was "up to the Lebanese people." But for many of them, her decision not to see Mr. Lahoud probably spoke louder than words. JOEL BRINKLEY (NYT)

Six others have been arrested in the case, including five members of an elite national security squad. The president's chief national security officer has resigned, and the opposition is calling for the speaker to step down as well. C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

title: Attack on Saudi Oil Facility Thwarted
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Feb. 24 A An attempted suicide bomb attack on Saudi Arabia's sprawling Abqaiq oil facility was thwarted today when guards opened fire on two explosive-laden cars, causing them to detonate at a security gate about a mile from the main entrance, the Saudi Interior Ministry said. The attack was the first on Saudi Arabia's oil infrastructure, and ends a yearlong lull in violence in the kingdom.

The Patriots are one of those midmajor teams that do not play like a midmajor team. They came in with an eight-game winning streak and the 25th spot in the ESPN/USA Today poll. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHANE, JAKOB T., MD.
description: COHANE--Jakob T., MD. Jaks sheer brilliance, his mastery of seven languages, his insight into human nature and his gentleness endeared him to all those lives he touched. Against all odds, Jak put himself through medical school, he became a renowned internist, specializing in endocrinology, then recognizing the emotional pain of so many of his patients he became a Psychiatrist. His psychiatric residency was at New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center followed by a private practice in psychiatry. He retired in 1995. Jak will be sorely missed and leaves us all with loving memories. Andy, Joyce, Devona, Andrew & Jakob Morrissey

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOEHM, FRANCES
description: BOEHM--Frances. Peacefully passed away, Tuesday, February 14, age 91. The supreme activist. Remembered for her boundless devotion to those she loved and the causes in which she believed. A long-time member of the Women's Strike For Peace and American Labor Party; a co-founder of the Five Towns Forum; an active supporter of the Center For Constitutional Rights; cocreator of the Nancy Boehm Coster Public Policy Fellowship at Dartmouth College, and supporter of countless social justice organizations. The much cherished wife of Robert Boehm, mother of Wendy Olesker, and Diane Boehm, grandmother of Katherine Olesker, Makeba Seargeant, and Daniel Winarick. The feisty, endlessly energetic, unifying spirit of our family. Memorial Service on February 26, 2006, The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave, 2PM.

title: Dresses Are Fine, but Pajamas Are Divine
description: "Tell me!" Seen in cold print, these may not look like two of the sexiest words in the English language. But as spoken, shouted and sung by Harry Connick Jr. and Kelli O'Hara in Kathleen Marshall's delicious reinvention of "The Pajama Game," the 1954 musical that gave new meaning to labor-management relations, that simple little phrase transforms the private pleasures of pillow talk into a heady public celebration. And a little novelty number called "There Once Was a Man" becomes a rockabilly pelvis pumper that turns the thermostat way up on a show that has already been generating plenty of steam heat.

Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Gets 51 Years In Deliveryman's Death
description: The last of three defendants convicted in the fatal beating in 2004 of Huang Chen, an 18-year-old deliveryman in South Jamaica, was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court in Queens to 51 years in prison. The defendant, William Capehart, 19, was found guilty last month of charges including murder, robbery and gang assault. After Mr. Capehart was sentenced by Justice Robert J. Hanophy, Mr. Chen's father, Xing Shou Chen, 48, said, "I've never seen criminals such as these." One attacker, Charles Bryant, was convicted last year, and Nayquan Miller pleaded guilty in the attack and testified against Mr. Capehart. COREY KILGANNON (NYT)

title: Versace's new geometrics keeps to its DNA
Corrections
description: An article last April 19 about a Supreme Court decision to hear a case on whether the government could ban imports of a hallucinogenic tea central to the religious rituals of a small Brazil-based church included an incorrect spelling from court documents for the name of the religious organization. (The error was repeated in an article on Nov. 2.) The church is O Centro Esprita Beneficente Unio do Vegetal -- not Beneficiente. The misspelling came to light on Tuesday when the court corrected it in ruling that the government could not use federal narcotics laws to ban the tea.

title: Arts, Briefly; Riverhead Books Pulls Out of James Frey Deal
description: James Frey's publisher apparently has gotten cold feet. Riverhead Books, which published Mr. Frey's second memoir, "My Friend Leonard," has pulled out of an agreement to publish his next two books, including his first novel, said Lisa Kussell, a spokeswoman for the author. Riverhead announced on Jan. 5 that it had signed Mr. Frey, right, the author of "A Million Little Pieces," to a two-book deal, with the first book, a novel set in Los Angeles, expected to be published in the fall of 2007. Three days after the announcement, the Smoking Gun Web site published evidence that Mr. Frey made up many of the circumstances of his life as depicted in "A Million Little Pieces" and "My Friend Leonard." "A Million Little Pieces" has sold more than three million copies since its selection by Oprah Winfrey for her book club in September, but sales slowed considerably after Ms. Winfrey withdrew her support last month. Geoffrey Kloske, publisher of Riverhead Books, declined to comment on the withdrawal, which was first reported Thursday in The New York Post.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEGEL, ROSE
description: SIEGEL--Rose (105 years). Beloved wife of the late Milton M. Siegel, survived by her son David, three grandchildren and six great grandchildren. She lived a long, full life.

title: Paul Avrich, 74, a Historian of Anarchism, Is Dead
description: Paul Avrich, a historian of the anarchist movement that played a role in the Russian Revolution and flourished in America in the 19th and early 20th centuries, died on Feb. 16 at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 74 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Two Are Killed In Stabbing
description: Two men, ages 19 and 21, were stabbed to death in Lefferts Garden shortly before 10 p.m. yesterday, the police said. They said the stabbings, at 377 Rutland Street, were the result of a dispute, and investigators were looking for a man who lives in the building. The victims, who were not residents of the building, were pronounced dead at the scene. The 21-year-old victim, found in a stairwell, was identified as Andrew Fitzroy George by family members. The 19-year-old victim, found in an apartment, was identified by his girlfriend as Hakim Brown, a friend of Mr. George's. Mr. George's sister, Krystal, said her brother had been lured to the apartment building by a text message sent to his cellphone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUFRANO, CARMINE (CARM)
description: LUFRANO--Carmine (Carm). Age 89, died on February 20 after a long struggle with Alzheimer's Disease. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Joan (nee O'Brien), his sister Marie Maier, his brothers Louis (Rosemary) and Edward (Anne), sisters-in-law Rose O'Brien, Anne Kenny, Marie King and Jeanne Lufrano. He was adored by numerous nieces and nephews. Carm was born in New York City and was a lifelong resident. He served in WWII with the U.S. Americal Division in the South Pacific and was decorated for bravery on Guadalcanal. He spent his working career in the textile industry. His charm and wit will be missed by all who knew him. Abiding by his wishes there will be no service.

Adored grandmother of Jill and Michael Berman, Debby Wheeler, Peter and Tracy Newman, David Newman and Angela Merrill. Funeral on Sunday, February 26, at 10:15AM, at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 1025 S. Orange Ave., Short Hills, NJ.

Serving Up a Meaty Helping of Brahms Sonatas in Order

They offered the three Brahms violin sonatas in sequence, a program that, in menu terms, is like a meal of three thick steaks, with no salad, vegetables or dessert. (For the record, they offered an appealing if starchy side dish, the Dvorak Sonatina, as an encore.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FURMAN, SEYMOUR, MD.
description: FURMAN -- Seymour, MD. The President, Board of Trustees, and the entire Montefiore Medical Center community are profoundly saddened by the death of Seymour Furman, MD, an esteemed colleague and friend. Dr. Furman, on the faculty at Montefiore for half a century, was internationally renowned as an expert on pacemakers and related technologies. He developed the modern pace making system to stimulate the heart through plastic-covered wires inserted through veins into the heart, avoiding the need for open chest surgery. His groundbreaking work was a prelude to what today is the miniaturized pacemaker. Dr. Furman was predeceased by his wife, the former Evelyn Katz, in 2002. Our sincere and heartfelt condolences are extended to his sons Bruce, Neil and Gary and to his entire family. Spencer Foreman, MD, President Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARRY, JOHN A. (JACK)
description: BARRY--John A. (Jack). Age 76, of Newtown, Connecticut formerly of Larchmont, New York passed away February 21, 2006 at his home. Born and raised in Larchmont, he is predeceased by his parents John R. and Edna Barry. Jack attended Iona Prep and Holy Cross College. He was with the U.S. Marines and served in the Korean War. Jack retired from Diebold, Inc. where he worked for 31 years. He is predeceased by his wife Janet. He is survived by his loving sister Marilyn (Jack) McCarthy of Atlanta, GA and his four children: son Jack (Lil) Barry of Newtown Connecticut, daughters Janet Brennan of Marietta GA, Luann (Scott) Barry-Goldman of Los Angeles, CA, and Alice Lyn (Charlie) Romanek of Marietta, GA. He also leaves behind eleven grandchildren: John, Samantha, Alexis, and Joanna Barry; Kerry, Tim and Katie Brennan; Jake, Alex, and Casey Goldman; and Rebecca Romanek. He is also survived by many nieces and nephews and a host of other relatives. Visitation will be Saturday 7-9PM and Sunday 2-4 & 7-9PM at John J. Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont, NY. Mass Monday 10AM at St. Augustine Church in Larchmont. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne.

But Italian and Olympic officials said the case would likely still go forward, based not on tests on athletes, but on evidence seized by the police under Italy's tough anti-doping laws.

Metro Briefing | New York: New York City's Projected Surplus Grows
description: New York City stands to end the fiscal year ending June 30 with a surplus of up to $5 billion because of higher than expected revenues from real estate transactions, capital gains, corporate profits and Wall Street bonuses, according to a report released yesterday by State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, left. The projected figure is $500 million more than previously forecast. Mr. Hevesi praised Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg for proposing to transfer $1 billion from this year's surplus toward the cost of retiree health benefits in response to new accounting rules; another $200 million will be set aside to pay for capital projects now rather than incurring the costs of debt in the future. Mr. Hevesi attributed the city's fiscal health to the economic recovery, conservative revenue forecasts and "Mayor Bloomberg's steady stewardship," but also warned that job and wage growth had been weaker than in past recoveries and that the city faced risks from a softening real estate market, higher energy costs and weak consumer spending. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

title: City's Lawyer Criticizes State on Rules for Voting Machines

title: Outrage in Samarra
description: Blowing up one of the most revered sites of Shiite Islam, the gold-domed Askariya shrine in Samarra, was no everyday act of terrorism. It was a deliberate attempt to make it politically impossible to create a national unity government capable of leading Iraq to democratic stability. So far, the bombers have been successful, with at least 138 people killed in reprisal attacks and counterattacks. A Sunni Arab group has broken off coalition talks, blaming the Shiite-led government for encouraging revenge attacks against Sunnis.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Icahn And Partner Make Offer For KT&G
description: Carl C. Icahn and Warren G. Lichtenstein made an unsolicited offer to buy the KT&G Corporation, the largest tobacco company in South Korea, in a transaction valued at more than $10 billion. The New York-based financiers bid 60,000 won ($61.91) a share, 17 percent more than KT&G's closing price yesterday in Korea. The investors, who are waging a proxy fight for three seats on KT&G's board, own 6.6 percent of the company. "You have flatly refused to listen to any of the proposals that we have made," Mr. Lichtenstein said in a letter to Kwak Young Kyoon, the chief executive of KT&G. Mr. Lichtenstein and Mr. Icahn have been pressing the company to sell real estate assets and spin off its ginseng unit. They also want KT&G, which is based in Daejeon, South Korea, to raise its dividend in line with tobacco companies like the Altria Group and UST.
