title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEINFIELD, MALCOLM
description: BEINFIELD--Malcolm. Long time Westport Physician, dies at 84. Malcolm S. Beinfield, the first board-certified surgeon in Westport, Connecticut died Monday, February 20th at his home. He was 84. In 1976, the Yale-educated Beinfield founded the first community-based Surgical Residency program for Physician Assistants (PAs) in conjunction with the Yale School of Medicine and Norwalk Hospital. He remained director for 20 years. Beinfield was widely published in medical journals. One article proposed shortening lengthy post-operative hospital stays, leading to early discharge and ambulatory surgery. Beinfield became an early advocate for breast-conserving surgery in the management of malignancy, initiating clinical lumpectomy trials at Yale. Beinfield was Chief of Surgery at Norwalk Hospital, which he joined as an attending surgeon in 1951. Beinfield taught at Yale as an Associate Clinical Professor of Surgery. Along with his wife, Marjorie, Beinfield was a lifelong advocate of social justice. In addition to his beloved wife Marjorie of 60 years, Beinfield is survived by his children. They are Harriet Beinfield, Lynn Beinfield, Elizabeth Falsey, Bruce Beinfield AIA, and an adoptive son, John Edoga, a vascular surgeon, originally from Nigeria. He has eight grandchildren. A memorial service is scheduled for Friday at 2 P.M. at the Unitarian Church, 10 Lyons Plains Road, Westport. In lieu of flowers, the family requested that donations be made in his memory to The Aku Project, at 177 Madison Ave., Morristown, NJ 07960 to bring water to his adoptive son's village in Nigeria. www.akuproject.org

description: What would it be like if one day you discovered that you didn't remember anything -- not your name, the mother who died, the friends who didn't, your lover's caress or the wet kiss of a snowflake on your cheek? Such is the premise of the thought-stirring documentary "Unknown White Male," which recounts the bizarre saga of an East Village loft dweller, Doug Bruce, who in July 2003 walked into a Coney Island hospital claiming not to know who he was, thereupon becoming either a heart-wrenching casualty of a medical anomaly or the prime suspect in a mystery yet to be solved.

As in: once upon a hard-boiled time, there was a not-so-wise guy from New Jersey, Joey Gazelle (Paul Walker), who, when he wasn't taking care of his own family, was punching the clock, among other things, for his mob family. When the spooky kid next door, Oleg (professional spooky kid Cameron Bright), steals one of his guns, Joey gives chase into a long night crammed with tortured camera angles and creepy crawlers.

title: From South Africa, a Tough Thug Shows His Big Heart
description: The life and hard times of the criminal underclass has been a staple of the movies nearly as long as pictures have flickered across screens. Not only because violence is inherently captivating (nothing commands our attention faster than a brandished gun), but also because stories about the down and out almost invariably carry a patina of sociological import. In 1915, the great Hollywood auteur Raoul Walsh took to the Bowery to shoot "Regeneration," the story of an orphan who grows up to be a gang boss, only to be saved by a good woman. Now the South African director Gavin Hood has told more or less the same story in his film "Tsotsi."

description: When Kathy Dolan, a mother in Queens, sent her twin boys off to kindergarten, she had one wish: that they face the new hurdles of numbers and alphabets in the same class. title: 'Casino'
description: "Goodfellas" in Vegas: that's how a lot of people greeted Martin Scorsese's "Casino" when it came out in 1995. After all, both movies took their screenplays from Nicholas Pileggi books that burrow deep into the muck and minutiae of organized crime. In both, Joe Pesci plays an unhinged thug. Equal in scope and ambition, these epic cautionary tales are about vice, capitalism and the American Way. Unmistakably, they are also about the virtuosity of their maker. "Casino" supercharges the "Goodfellas" paradigm: wall-to-wall pop music, crackerjack montage, a quicksilver camera that glides through the scenery with curving, craning, whiplash sinuosity. Yes, "Mr. Scorsese has been here and done this already," as Janet Maslin wrote in her review of "Casino" in The New York Times, "but not with his new film's blistering bitterness or its peacock extravagance." And not with Sharon Stone (above, with Robert De Niro) in the performance of a lifetime as Ginger McKenna, an ambitious, unstable Strip hustler who catches the eye of the casino boss Sam Rothstein (Mr. De Niro, in a splendidly restrained performance that makes amends for his histrionics in "Cape Fear"). Mr. Scorsese is no more repetitive than Balzac and just as talented a historian. We should be so lucky as to see "Goodfellas" in Kansas, California or Washington. (Today and tomorrow at midnight, IFC Center, 323 Avenue of the Americas, at West Third Street, West Village, (212) 924-7771.)

Still run by the same Quaker family that founded it, Mohonk clings to tradition. Rooms are large and comfortable, but devoid of television sets, radios  even clocks. Jackets are required for men at dinner. On summer Sundays, there is a nondenominational worship service in the Parlor, while every day at 4 p.m., guests gather for tea and cookies in the Lake Lounge.

Paid Notice: Deaths   WEIL, FRED
description: WEIL--Fred, 81. Of Newtown, PA, died at home on February 18, 2006. He was born in Baden, Switzerland on January 27, 1925. He left Germany with his family in 1937 for New York. He served in the U.S. Army during W.W. II, throughout Europe and the Pacific. Fred was the owner of Winter-Wolff, Inc., and worked internationally in importing and exporting. He retired in 1988, after suffering a stroke. Fred lived on Long Island, N.Y. for over 40 years, and was involved in local politics and community service. He was an active member of the Long Island Ethical Humanist Society. He moved to Newtown in 2003. Fred was deeply devoted to his family and possessed a unique zest for life. His generous and loyal spirit was beloved by all. Fred is survived by Dorle Neumann Weil, his loving wife of 53 years; his children Judith Weil Epstein and her husband Lloyd of New York, N.Y., Evelyn Weil Browne & her husband Bill, of Augusta, GA., Margie Weil, of Philadelphia, PA., and Dan Weil and his wife Linda, of Sands Point, N.Y.; his brother, Max Harry Weil, of Rancho Mirage, CA., and his grandchildren Oren Epstein, Benjamin Epstein, Yoel Epstein, Chloe Browne, Maura Weil, Lia Weil, Andrew Weil, Kathryn Weil, and Thomas Weil. He will be missed as well by many devoted friends and family around the world. A memorial service will take place in Newtown on March 5, with final arrangement pending. In lieu of flowers, the family requests a contribution to the charity of your choice.

Mr. Ames was a graduate of the Hill School, Yale University, and Harvard Business School, and served as an Air Intelligence Officer in the U.S. Navy. He was a Director of Blyth & Co. Inc., and finished his career as Executive Vice President of Dean Witter Reynolds, Inc., serving on its Board of Directors and Executive Committee. He was also a Director of Montclair Savings Bank. At the time of his death he was majority owner and Chairman of Hammer Manufacturing Co. in Linden, NJ. A memorial service will be held Saturday, February 25, at 2:00 P.M. at Central Presbyterian Church, 46 Park St., Montclair, NJ. title: Arts, Briefly; More Smooth Sledding For 'American Idol'
description: Facing mostly repeats and a weak Olympics lineup, "American Idol" was extraordinarily popular on Wednesday night. The two-hour program, in which the 12 male contestants performed live to woo the voting public for the first time, delivered an audience of 31.43 million. Fox not only won the night; it nearly tripled the 18-to-49 rating of its nearest competitor, NBC. The Olympics in prime time brought in 15.54 million viewers, way down from the previous night's figure skating-fueled ratings. For the other networks, it was a race to the bottom, with the biggest loser being UPN, which broadcast a new episode of "South Beach" (1.45 million) and a rerun of "Veronica Mars" (1.64 million). Monday's prime-time episode of "SpongeBob SquarePants," in which SpongeBob and Patrick traveled back in time to the Middle Ages, was the highest-rated Nickelodeon program since 2001. It brought in 8.6 million viewers.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Church And State Agree To Protocols On Abuse
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago and the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services have put in effect a plan to improve communication in the handling of child sexual abuse accusations. According to the plan, the archdiocese will immediately report to the department any abuse accusations, including those from adults who say they were abused as minors. The department will share updates in investigations and will notify the archdiocese within two days of an investigation's conclusion. The department can also require the temporary removal of a clergy member or employee during an investigation and will provide training on abuse-reporting requirements. GRETCHEN RUETHLING (NYT)

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Rangel To Endorse Spitzer
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel said yesterday that he would announce his endorsement of Attorney General Eliot Spitzer for governor this morning, a month after the two Democrats sparred over Mr. Spitzer's choice of a running mate. Mr. Spitzer had chosen David A. Paterson, the Democratic leader in the State Senate, for lieutenant governor instead of Mr. Rangel's preferred candidate, Leecia Eve. (Ms. Eve subsequently dropped out.) Mr. Rangel, the dean of the New York Congressional delegation, will also endorse Mr. Paterson today. Asked what was most compelling about Mr. Spitzer, Mr. Rangel said, "That he doesn't stand a chance of losing." The Spitzer camp is rolling out endorsements by Mr. Rangel and others in advance of tomorrow's expected announcement by Thomas R. Suozzi, the Nassau County executive, that he will challenge Mr. Spitzer for the Democratic nomination. PATRICK D. HEALY (NYT)

description: PONCHATOULA, La. - When a big contracting company hired him to clean up this small town northwest of New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina, Matthew Lopez saw it as a way to help his neighbors and to make decent money: $9 for every cubic yard of hurricane debris he delivered to a dump.

title: 32 Indicted on Racketeering Charges in Manhattan
description: A Genovese crime family boss has been charged with capital murder, accused of ordering a mob killing -- with help from his lawyer -- while he was locked away in prison, federal and state authorities announced yesterday.

description: Regards The Selected Nonfiction of John Gregory Dunne By John Gregory Dunne. Foreword by Calvin Trillin. 403 pages. Thunder's Mouth Press. $16.95.

title: Italian firms put independence and family before economic logic
World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: HSBC Reorganizes Investment Bank
description: The British banking company HSBC Holdings reorganized its investment bank, handing more responsibility to its head of sales and trading, Stuart Gulliver. Debt and equity underwriting, previously part of the banking unit, which reports to John Studzinski, will be folded into the sales and trading division, according to a memo sent to employees. The investment bank will consist of three departments instead of four. "This marks a return to our previous structure of managing primary and secondary markets as a single business line," Mr. Gulliver and Mr. Studzinski said in the memo. HSBC's chairman, John Bond, who is retiring in May, recruited Mr. Studzinski from the investment banking unit of Morgan Stanley almost three years ago to run the investment bank with Mr. Gulliver.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVERMAN, BESSIE
description: SILVERMAN--Bessie. Longtime Manhattanite. Born in Vilna, died February 22, 2006 at the age of 98. Her liveliness, her delight in reading, and her passion for the New York Yankees will be muched missed by her sons Kenneth and Alexander; her grandchildren Willa and Ethan; her great grandchildren Benjamin, Eve and Isaac; her niece June and nephew Stanley; and by the others dear to them and to her: Michael Berkman, Jess Kasowitz, Jane Mallison, Bella Pilosov, and Ronit Silverman. May she now rest in peace.

title: Nets Trade Jackson and Gain Some Room to Maneuver
description: By dealing forwards Marc Jackson and Linton Johnson III to the New Orleans Hornets for the 25-year-old forward Bostjan Nachbar just before the N.B.A. trading deadline yesterday, Nets President Rod Thorn was able to accomplish two things.

title: Transit Union Opposes Request for Arbitration
description: The union representing New York City's subway and bus workers filed papers last night opposing the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's call for binding arbitration to settle their long-running contract dispute. The union said a new agreement could still be reached through negotiations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILLIAMS, BRUCE D.
description: WILLIAMS--Bruce D. Of Hackensack, NJ, February 21 at Englewood Hospital. Born June 15, 1932, Washington, DC. Raised in the Midwest, graduated Harvard 1954. Stanford MBA 1956. Spent 30 years as a corporate financial officer in industries including petroleum, heavy machinery, and M&A. Board member of Englewood Hospital from 1976-2002. Board member of Greater Bergen County YMCA for 20 years, 3 as President. Mr. Williams is survived by his wife, Deirdre, by his daughters, Katie Fahs of Atlanta and Nicole Dietrich of NYC, and four grandchildren. Service at First Presbyterian Church, 150 E. Palisades Ave, Englewood, 11AM Monday, February 27. Memorials to the Harvard Class of '54, 124 Mt. Auburn Street, Cambridge MA 02138 or Englewood Hospital, 350 Engle Street, Englewood, NJ 07631.

title: I'm My Own Bombshell
description: She had Marilyn Monroe-style hair, silky smooth skin and a knockout figure. But Christine Jorgensen wasn't always a beautiful woman; she wasn't a woman at all until she entered a Copenhagen hospital in 1952 and had a sex-change operation. The Daily News broke the story: "Ex-G.I. Becomes Blonde Bombshell," read the headline that launched her celebrity, briefly making her one of the most famous women in the world.

title: Europe doesn't get free speech
Campaigning for Human Rights, and Fishing for Souls
description: SEOUL, South Korea - After spending 18 months illegally in China in the mid-1980's and converting to Christianity, Kim Tae Jin was locked up for four years in North Korea's infamous prison camp No. 15 at Yodok.

title: The Listings: Feb. 24 - March 2; EWA PODLES with the MOSCOW CHAMBER ORCHESTRA
description: "Why isn't she at the Met?" wail many opera fans who will buy tickets to Sunday's concert for the Polish contralto Ewa Podles (pronounced AY-va POHD-lezh) alone. One of the few true contraltos singing today, with a dusky voice and profoundly expressive artistry, Ms. Podles is the opposite of the stereotype of a pretty singer; this is not a voice to play in the background at brunch, but one that has the power to move you to the tips of your toes as it rises from inky depths through a husky center to ringing top notes. And where many singers are limited to a few kinds of music, Ms. Podles has a huge range of repertory, some of which she will demonstrate in this concert, which takes her from a Rossini cantata, "Joan of Arc" (orchestrated by the contemporary Italian composer Salvatore Sciarrino), to one of her showpieces, Mussorgsky's "Songs and Dances of Death" (orchestrated by Shostakovich). The concert is not actually a recital, but the 50th-anniversary celebration of the Moscow Chamber Orchestra, which under its music director, Constantine Orbelian, will also play orchestral arrangements of Prokofiev's "Visions Fugitives," Shostakovich's Chamber Symphony in C minor and Haydn's Symphony No. 49. Well and good, but since the event represents Ms. Podles's only New York appearance this season, it's likely to attract a disproportionate number of opera lovers. Peter Gelb, are you listening? (Sunday afternoon at 3, Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500; $30 to $60).

title: World Briefing | Americas: Bolivia: 'Death To Yankees' Senator Loses U.S. Visa
description: The government said it wanted the Bush administration to explain why it canceled the visa of a close ally of President Evo Morales, Senator Leonilda Zurita, who was planning to travel to the United States for a speaking tour. Ms. Zurita has led rallies with chants of "Long live coca!" and "Death to the Yankees!" The State Department said her visa was revoked two years ago but gave no reason. JUAN FORERO (NYT)

title: Briefcase: Small businesses meet big disasters
Lowe Worldwide Will Get A New Chief Next Month
description: As the Interpublic Group of Companies works on a major reorganization of its most troubled large agency, Lowe Worldwide, the agency is getting a new chief executive.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the National Briefing column yesterday about a ruling by a Rhode Island jury against three companies that produced lead paint misstated the name of a company that was absolved in the case. It is Atlantic Richfield, not Atlantic Ridgefield.

title: The Fireworks of Elaine May
description: IT has been nearly 20 years since Elaine May directed a film, which makes sense only when you remember that the film was "Ishtar," one of the fabled disasters in Hollywood history. In fact, few people have been called legendary with such positive and negative meanings: rightly lionized for her work with Mike Nichols as part of the Nichols and May comedy team, she has also been castigated for the megabudget flop that was "Ishtar" (1987) and for her previous film, "Mikey and Nicky" (1976), a small-scale drama about two gangsters, for which she shot about twice as much film as "Gone With the Wind" needed. It's hard to survive as a director after back-to-back escapades like that, even if they are 11 years apart. But whether she abandoned Hollywood or Hollywood abandoned her, it was a great loss for filmgoers that she stopped directing.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FRIEDMAN, SAMUEL
description: FRIEDMAN--Samuel. January 12, 1920-February 24, 1985. Still an emptiness. Miss you. Love, Eleanor and Arthur

title: Sri Lanka to Talk With Rebels Again
description: CELIGNY, Switzerland, Feb. 23 - Sri Lanka and its ethnic Tamil rebels resumed talks for the first time in three years here this week and emerged Thursday evening with an unexpectedly cheerful agreement -- to talk again in April.

title: Actually, It's Amazing Anybody's Watching This Stuff
description: TURIN, Italy - In many ways, it is a miracle that American viewers pay attention to the Winter Olympics at all. Here is a collection of sports, except for figure skating, that fade to niches, or to black, from one Olympics to the next.

title: Loan Buyer Accounting Is Faulted
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 - An internal investigation has uncovered new evidence that senior executives of Fannie Mae, the largest buyer of American home mortgages, manipulated its accounting in the 1990's to meet earnings projections so that top executives could receive more than $27 million in bonuses.

title: Court Suspends London's Mayor for 4 Weeks
description: LONDON, Feb. 24 A A disciplinary panel today took the highly unusual step of suspending the mayor of London, Ken Livingstone, for four weeks to punish him for comparing a Jewish reporter to a Nazi concentration camp guard.

title: The Listings: Feb. 24 - March 2; HUMAN FEEL
description: During the first half of the 1990's, the ensemble known as Human Feel, above, was several things at once: a workshop for unruly improvisational tactics, a self-styled alternative to neo-conservatism, and a delivery system for some of the era's most unclassifiable new talent. Its founding core consisted of the multireedists Chris Speed and Andrew D'Angelo and the drummer Jim Black, a trio of Seattle natives transplanted via music school to Boston, where they shared an apartment as well as an aesthetic. Various others floated in and out of the group before the arrival of the guitarist Kurt Rosenwinkel, which proved definitive. As a bass-less quartet, Human Feel strained toward the ragged-edge postmodernism established by a previous generation of downtown avatars like John Zorn and Tim Berne, but with an emotional directness more closely derived from underground rock. It was energy music, plugged into the spirit of the age. Arriving in New York, the band's members were quickly absorbed into one scene or another: Mr. Speed and Mr. Black became one half of Mr. Berne's raucous Bloodcount, Mr. D'Angelo dug in with the drummer Matt Wilson, and Mr. Rosenwinkel became a mainstay at Smalls. The musicians have hardly been strangers since, but the last proper Human Feel album, "Speak to It" (Songlines), was released in 1996. This reunion -- the first in years -- comes amid reports of a new recording. And it offers a good measure of the ways in which the musicians, separately and in collaboration, have exceeded their early promise. (Sunday at 8 p.m., Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7501; cover, $10. Monday at 10 p.m., Fat Cat, 75 Christopher Street, at Seventh Avenue, West Village, (212) 675-7369; cover, $15.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NITCHUN, ARLEEN
description: NITCHUN--Arleen. On February 21, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Sidney Nitchun. Loving mother of Joanne Sackett and Marc Nitchun. Cherished grandmother of King, Mia, Nick, Blaise, Mary, Darius, Terina, Miranda, Alyssa and Anna, and greatgrandmother of Nora, Nicholas, Lily, Daniela, Sammy, Luke and Charlie. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Service Sunday, February 26, 11:30AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: For Austrians, Test Results Will Determine Legacy of These Games
description: SESTRIERE, Italy, Feb. 23 - As Austrian Olympic officials and athletes anxiously awaited the results of doping tests on 10 skiers, they have used nightly gatherings here to distract themselves from the issue that could put a damper on the sporting success they have enjoyed at these Winter Games.

title: Iran Has Started Producing Enriched Uranium
description: PARIS, Feb. 24 A International nuclear inspectors are expected to report next week that Iran has started producing enriched uranium on a very small scale, indicating that it is striving to solve technological problems in its nuclear program, European officials said today.

title: Aggressiveness of Bike Chases Stirs Questions for the Police
description: The patrol guidelines for the Police Department strongly urge officers to be careful when chasing suspects with cars, and national studies show that accidents involving police vehicles result in one death nearly every day.

title: Governors Take 2 Tacks On Releasing Medical Data
description: Gov. George E. Pataki is not the only governor in the hospital because of complications from a common medical problem that required surgery. Gov. Ernie Fletcher of Kentucky has been hospitalized since Feb. 12.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GELLIS, EDNA ALPERIN
description: GELLIS--Edna Alperin. 95 years old, died on Febraury 23, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Harold Gellis. Devoted mother of Willard and Shirley Gellis, Ann Gellis and Maxine Grolnick Colchamiro and her husband Harvey. Loving grandmother of Elizabeth, Jenny, Peter and Edward. title: The Best and Rest
description: Those of you/us/them who still insist there is a race for best actress might want to spend some time with the abundant handicapping at And the Oscar Goes To. Each of the nominees are scrutinized, and the Bagger, after spending time really turning over the odds and possibilities with a stick, came away more confused than ever.

title: O My
description: The boys at the O Factor  love that name, btw  pointed out that in the surge of coverage suggesting that yes, yes, there is a race for best picture, and that Crash is gaining momentum, whatever that is, people have forgotten that the critics actually didnt like Crash when it came out.

title: Movie Stills
description: The Bagger got all excited when Entertainment Weekly  his daughter has a shrine to the magazine in her bedroom, so its big around here  promised to give him a look at the past great performances of this years acting nominees. But when he clicked on the feature, all he got was static photos and some witty cutlines. Hey guys, its a web world out there and we want motion, clips and a real, actual look at performances, not some annotated stills.

title: Leaving Nothing to Chance
description: Worried that small movies and a lack of maypole stars will make this years Oscars a smaller affair, the Academy has turned on a fire hose of promotion, buying up spots and reminding people that the No. 1 entertainment show of the year would like to stay that way. According to Variety, the Academy is targeting 18-34s with spots on MTV and VH1, AMC, Oxygen, Bravo and Style. The ads will ramp up next week before the Sunday ceremony and grow to a frenzy the day of. Sid Ganis, the Academys president, said it is prudence, not panic, motivating the buys: The Academy is now a partner in the marketing. Were buying network cable, outdoor, spot radio and network radio, a lot of print ads. We are branded in a way that few other shows are. People notice.

title: A Movie with Stakes
description: Judy Shepard tells USA Today that shortly before her son Matthew was murdered in a hate crime in1998, he gave her a copy of the Annie Proulx story that inspired Brokeback. She said not many of her friends will head out to the movie theater to see it, but that doesnt mean they wont see it on their own terms at home on video:

title: Semiotics in Sheeps Clothing
description: On Wednesday, for a warm-up tasting before the east coast version of the Oscar night doings. I think the fact that the Academy has chosen lamb as an entre shows a pronounced bias toward Brokeback Mountain and an indication that all this talk of a Crash surge is just that. Well, maybe thats a bit of a reach, but when you have a race under way and no data to examine, you work with what you can.

title: An Empty Texas County
description: At last count, 16 people make Mentone, Tex., their home and 55 more are spread throughout the rest of Loving County's 645 square miles.

title: Billionaires Gift Bounces Back
description: Boone Pickens, the often controversial and always colorful Texas oilman turned investor, took advantage of a temporary tax break to give a $165 million gift to a tiny charity that landed back in a hedge fund he controls.

title: Where the Pigs Are
description: Selborne Journal: Tuesday, 24 February 1784: 29 6/10 1/2; S, SW; 25. Fog, wet, grey, wet. ALTON: The laurels, & laurustines are not injured by the severe weather. Snow scarce passable in Newton-lane!

title: PE Group Takes Jil Sander
description: Change Capital Partners, a London-based private equity firm, announced yesterday that it would buy Jil Sander fashion label from the Prada Group, after years of losses for the label and management battles that led to the resignation of its namesake designer  twice.

title: V.C.s in Love: The Sequel?
description: Tom Perkins, co-founder of Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield & Byers and a lion of the venture capital world, has just finished his first romance novel. The book ,Sex and the Single Zillionaire, has sold just a handful of copies, but Mr. Perkins not giving up.

title: Deutsche Said to Seek Settlement
description: Deutsche Bank is in talks with the Justice Department in an effort to settle a criminal investigation over the banks role in questionable tax shelters, The New York Times reported. For Deutsche Bank, the path toward a settlement may be rockier than previous tax shelter settlements, in part because it had a much larger role in the creation of some questionable tax shelters and the transactions underpinning them.

title: Keeper of the BlackRock Way
description: Laurence D. Fink, the CEO of BlackRock, has ascended to a career and personal mountaintop: last week, he clinched an industry-rattling $9.8 billion merger with Merrill Lynchs asset management unit. With BlackRocks stock soaring, he is worth more than $230 million, and, it seems, just about everyone on Wall Street wants to take him out to lunch.

title: Fannie Maes Accounting Is Faulted
description: An internal investigation has uncovered new evidence that senior executives of Fannie Mae, the largest buyer of American home mortgages, manipulated its accounting in the 1990s to meet earnings projections so that top executives could receive more than $27 million in bonuses.

title: Takeover Chatter Breathes Life into Barclays
description: Barclays got the banks reporting season off to a flying start this week, and the Collins Stewart Tullett analyst Sandy Chen reckons the group is the only UK bank that is a serious contender to be taken over.

title: KLA-Tencor Buys ADE for $488 Million
description: KLA-Tencor Corp., the No .2 U.S. chip-equipment maker, is buying ADE Corp. for about $488 million in stock, the companies said Thursday.

title: Guidant Post Mortem: A Case of Bid Em Up
description: Why is it that executives locked in takeover contests lose their wits? The first U.S. dust-up of 2006 was a classic case, according to Bloomberg News columnist David Pauly. It pitted Johnson & Johnson, the largest maker of medical devices, against Boston Scientific Corp., a rival one-eighth its size. The small fry won  but at quite a high price.

title: Moscow on the Potomac?
Shell Linked to Takeover of Wind Turbine Firm
description: The oil major Shell was linked yesterday to a possible $3.5 billion takeover of a leading wind turbine manufacturer, adding to the excitement around the alternative energy sector.

title: SAC Rebuts Conspiracy Claim in Biovail Suit
description: SAC Capital, one of Wall Streets largest hedge funds, has hit back at accusations that it conspired to manipulate the stock market and drive down the share price of a Canadian pharmaceuticals company.

title: Lonmin Says Potential Takeover Talks Fell Through
description: Lonmin Plc, the worlds third-largest platinum producer, said talks that may have led to a takeover bid have been terminated. The companys shares plunged.

title: National Grid Said to Lead KeySpan Bidding with $7.3B Offer
description: National Grid, the British utility company, confirmed this morning that its in discussing a possible transaction with KeySpan Corporation, which provides electricity and natural gas to more than a million customers on Long Island.

title: Burger Bound
description: I love burgers. And I do mean love.

title: Write Me Something, Mister
description: The throngs of reporters descending on the Crescent City this weekend to do the post-Katrina Mardi Gras mambo may want to heed Vanity Fair contributing editor Steve Garbarinos warning in Thursdays Wall Street Journal: New Orleans is no place for a writer. [$] The city has inspired writers such as Twain, Faulkner, Fitzgerald, Capote, Walker Percy and John Kennedy Toole, but most of them actually put pen to paper elsewhere, Garbarino writes:

title: Icahn, Lichtenstein Target South Koreas KT&G with $10B Bid
description: It didnt take long for Carl Icahn to seize on a new corporate target. The buyout veteran has joined U.S. investor Warren Lichtenstein to launch an unsolicited bid for KT&G Corp., South Koreas largest tobacco maker, valuing the company at $10 billion. The move gave the targets shares their biggest boost in four years.

title: As Port Fracas Deepens, Dubai Agrees to Delay P&O Deal
description: The Dubai company at the center of a political furor over its plans to take over some terminal operations at six American ports said last night that it planned to close the deal next week, but that it would not exercise control over its new operations in the United States while the Bush administration tried to calm opposition in Congress, the New York Times reported. The newspaper also pointed out an overlooked trend that helped set the stage for the current outcry: U.S. companies began withdrawing decades ago from the unglamorous business of stevedoring, ceding the now-booming industry to enterprises in Asia and the Middle East.

title: Kingdom Hotel says IPO to Value Firm at $1.59 Billion
description: Dubai-based hotel group Kingdom Hotel Investments said on Friday that shares in its initial public offering would be priced at $9.25 each, near the top of the offer range and valuing the company at $1.59 billion.

title: EndoGastric Solutions Raises $32 Million in Financing
description: EndoGastric Solutions Inc. has raised $32 million in venture capital financing  one of the largest financing deals in a Seattle-area company in the past 12 months.

title: A Step Back From Iraq
description: Opinion-makers are split on whether Iraq is on the verge of civil war, but theres broad agreement that the United States cant do very much about it either way. The New York Times editorial page says responsible Iraqi leaders from all religious groups and communities need to exert a calming influence. A Los Angeles Times editorial sums up the lets-cross-our-fingers consensus:

title: Mobile Firm Itouch Back on Market
description: Itouch, the British-based ring tone company, has been put up for sale by its Japanese owner just 10 months after it was bought for 180 million.

title: Intermix ex-CEO Sues VC Firm over Deal with News Corp.
description: Brad Greenspan, the former chief executive of Intermix Media Inc., filed a complaint Thursday against his former company, VantagePoint Venture Partners, over Intermixs sale last year to News Corp.

title: Mills Confirms Potential Sale; Pulls Earnings Guidance
description: Troubled mall developer Mills Corporation confirmed Thursday that is has hired advisers to explore a sale of all of part of the company. The real estate investment trust also announced plans for more layoffs and withdrew its 2005 earnings guidance.

title: LOreal Licks Lips Over Body Shop
description: Body Shop, the retail chain famed for its campaigns to save the whale and end global poverty, could be swallowed by LOral, the worlds largest cosmetics group

description: Julia Mancuso won a gold medal in the giant slalom. Chad Hedrick took silver and was gracious in defeat.  Sweden and Finland are headed to the gold medal round for men's hockey.

title: Video: A Taste of Oscar
description: David Carr, a k a the Carpetbagger, , where he surveys drinks and desserts based on this years nominated films.

title: CSX Reportedly Considers Minority Stake Sale
description: Three financial firms are reportedly in talks to buy a stake in the Chicago Stock Exchange, creating the potential for yet more alliances between Wall Street firms and regional exchanges. The trio  Goldman Sachs Group Inc., Bank of America Corp. and Bear Stearns Cos.  would acquire a minority interest, according to reports in the Wall Street Journal and Reuters. No price range was given, and the CSX declined to comment.

title: Tempers Flare as NYMEX Pushes Top Traders from Board
description: The New York Mercantile Exchange has raised tempers with its decision to force Eric Bolling and Kevin McDonnell, both prominent floor members, to vacate their positions on the board, SquawkBlog reports. The stated reason: A Commodity Futures Exchange Commission rule, which many traders say is rarely enforced, that bars traders with more than $5,000 in fines from serving on the NYMEX board.

title: Buyout Firms Reportedly Close to $8.6B VNU Bid
description: A private equity consortium is nearly ready to make a firm offer of about $8.6 billion for Dutch publishing company VNU NV, the Wall Street Journal reported Friday. The group, which includes AlpInvest Partners of the Netherlands, Permira Advisers Ltd. of the United Kingdom and Blackstone Group of the U.S., has been sifting through VNUs financial data ever since it made a tentative offer for the company in January.

title: Dana Said to Hire Restructuring Firm; Shares Plunge
description: Auto-parts maker Dana Corp. saw its stock price cut in half on Friday following a report that the company has begun working with restructuring firm Miller Buckfire & Co. LLC. A Dana spokesman wouldnt comment on the matter, but investors ran for the door, sending the companys shares plunging to $1.51, down 52%, by the close of trading.

title: How to Survive Lowball Offers
description: Heres a problem you havent seen addressed in a long, long time: how to deal with lowball offers on a house.The Boston Herald ran some advice, six specific tips that be boiled down to this:

description: Hey all you inverted rate curve junkies! Here is another article on what it means and why you should care.

title: A Huge Con
description: There are a lot of juicy details in this real crime tale. Two convicted scam artists were arrested on Tuesday for allegedly conning an 84-year-old real estate agent by posing as wealthy socialites who were interested in buying a $900,000 home in San Jose.

title: Turner Walks from Time Warner Board; More Room for Icahn?
description: Days after Time Warner Inc. reached a truce with activist investor Carl Icahn, the media conglomerate announced that longtime board member Ted Turner wouldnt stand for re-election as director this year. The company also said that board member Carla A. Hills will also step down under the boards retirement policy.

title: 'Slave Galleries' at St. Augustine's
description: Feb. 24 - The "Slave Galleries" of St. Augustine's Church on the Lower East Side of Manhattan help tell the early story of segregation in New York City. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

title: BlackBerry Gets a Reprieve  and a Warning
description: The maker of the BlackBerry mobile messaging device dodged a bullet Friday when a judge declined to issue an injunction in its bitter patent dispute with NTP Inc., according to Reuters via Yahoo. But the reprieve came with some stern words, as the court reminded the manufacturer, Research in Motion, that it had already been found to have infringed NTPs patents.

title: Commercial Property Hangs In There
description: The residential real estate market may be showing signs of slowing down, but there seems to be plenty of steam left on the commercial side, according to a new quarterly index released this week by the National Association of Realtors.

title: Trading Freely, but Safely
description: Readers respond to Thomas Friedmans Feb. 24 column, War of the Worlds

title: Vows: Ritter and Katz
description: The story of how an online encounter between Jennifer Ritter and Daniel Katz led to a theatrical engagement. (Producer: Nelli Black)

title: Emergency Rule in Philippines After Failed Coup Is Cited
description: MANILA, Feb. 24 - Saying that the Philippine government had foiled a military coup attempt and still faced the threat of violent overthrow, President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo declared emergency rule on Friday and banned rallies marking the 20th anniversary of the fall of Ferdinand Marcos, the former dictator.

title: How the Mars Rock Set the Earth Spinning
description: The Rock From Mars A Detective Story on Two Planets By Kathy Sawyer Illustrated. 394 pages. Random House. $25.95.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about attitudes in Dubai over whether Dubai Ports World should manage shipping terminals in several American cities misstated the surname of the editor in chief of Forbes Arabia, who said the reaction was a test for globalization. He is Sulaiman Al-Hattlan, not Hatlan.

title: A Word Recalls When Terror Was in the Mail
description: STRANGE how a single word can take you back, and aback. Hear the word, and the protective walls of repressed memory instantly give way to the autumn of 2001, when this city lost a jauntiness that has never quite returned.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Life Sentences For 9 Hindus In Killings Of Muslims
description: A court in Mumbai sentenced nine Hindus to life in prison for killing 14 Muslims, in an arson attack on a bakery during anti-Muslim riots in western Gujarat in 2002. The nine, part of a mob, had been acquitted in an earlier trial in Gujarat. The new trial acquitted eight other Hindus accused in the case. The arson was part of a wave of religious violence, and Muslim victims accused the Hindu-nationalist government in Gujarat of not taking action to stop the riots and of doing little to prosecute the rioters. HARI KUMAR (NYT)

title: A Car Seller Who Favors Fuel Taxes
description: Mike Jackson is saying things that some people may not want to hear.

title: Shining a Light Into the Abyss of Chile's Dictatorship
description: SANTIAGO, Chile - LONG before he became a judge, Juan Guzmn Tapia revered the rule of law. So it may be the supreme irony of his career that he will be forever associated with a man notorious for his disrespect for the law: Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORIARTY, JAMES P.
description: MORIARTY--James P. The Society of the Friendly Sons of Saint Patrick in the City of New York records with profound sorrow the death of James P. Moriarty, a Life Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Robert J. Reilly, President Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: Henry Michael, 92, Archaeology Groundbreaker, Dies
description: Henry N. Michael, an anthropologist and geographer who used the growth rings of ancient pine trees to help resolve problems of radiocarbon dating in archaeology, died last Sunday at a hospital in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 92 and a resident of nearby Ardmore.

title: Action on Port Deal Fails to Sway Critics
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 - Members of Congress on Friday welcomed the decision by a Dubai company to postpone its taking over operations at six American ports, but there was little sign that the move had quelled bipartisan opposition on Capitol Hill that still threatens to derail the deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COX, DONALD M.
description: COX--Donald M. Trustees, Fellows, and staff of the American Academy in Rome mourn the loss of a beloved friend, Trustee (1983-2003), Trustee Emeritus (2003 onward) and inspired Chair of the Finance committee. His tender guidance, generosity, wisdom, and deep commitment to the institution, artists, and the visual arts will long be felt. Don and Maria established an artist's Studio and History of Art Rome Prize that every year provides a transformative experience to an American, a cherished legacy. We extend our deepest condolences to Maria and the family. David M. Childs, Chairman Jessie Price, Chair, Executive Committee Adele Chatfield-Taylor, President Carmela Vircillo Franklin, Director

title: Dubai Port Deal: More Surprises?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: President Takes Lead In Vote
description: Early returns gave President Yoweri Museveni a healthy lead in his bid for a third term in office, but supporters of his main opponent, Kizza Besigye, complained of rigging and said their preliminary tallies had Mr. Museveni trailing in a tight race. Final results in the first multiparty election in 25 years are expected today, but Mr. Besigye's lawyers were already preparing a court challenge. MARC LACEY (NYT)

title: U.S. Skier Is Punished After an Altercation
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 24 - Jeret Peterson, an aerialist on the United States freestyle skiing team, was asked to leave the athletes' village Friday, after the police said he punched a friend in the face during an argument outside a bar in Sauze d'Oulx.

title: Sanofi to Pursue Approval of Weight-Loss Drug
description: Sanofi-Aventis, the French drug maker that suffered a setback to efforts to market its Acomplia drug last week, said yesterday that it still planned to start selling the product for weight loss this year.

title: Playful, Intimate Encounters, With Something More Serious
description: "There is only ever one first of anything, and this is it," said Charles Wright, the executive director of Dance New Amsterdam, which inaugurated its new theater on Thursday night with a performance by the Sean Curran Company. Previously known as Dance Theater Space, a mainstay organization for downtown artists since 1984, Dance New Amsterdam now has a sparkling new home in the landmark Sun Building in Lower Manhattan.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Miners' Families Rebel After Search Suspended
description: Relatives of 65 coal miners trapped underground since a methane gas explosion last Sunday rioted and roughed up the federal labor secretary after he and two mine officials informed them that rescue efforts were being suspended for at least two days because of unsafe methane levels in the collapsed shaft. Officials at the mine in the northern state of Coahuila have said that there is little chance any of the miners are still alive. JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. (NYT)

title: Helping the Poor Do Business
description: ENTREPRENEURS are often thought of as people who fill a market need, creating a very pleasant living for themselves.

title: Celebrity Lawyer in Talks About Wiretapping Evidence
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24 - Bert Fields, the Hollywood superlawyer, who frequently employed the disgraced private eye Anthony Pellicano, and his law firm are in talks with prosecutors to try to avoid charges in the wiretapping investigation that has already led to the indictment of at least 13 people, lawyers briefed on the case said.

title: Amazon to Take On IPod
description: OK, so the big announcement is that Amazon.com is going to try to develop its own iPod killer.

title: Arts, Briefly; NBC's Olympics Outruns The Competition
description: The reach of network television erodes nearly every year, so Thursday's full menu of popular choices spread among the big four broadcasters was a rarity. NBC's Olympics telecast, which featured the women's figure skating finals, carried the night, with an average of 24.49 million viewers in prime time, according to Nielsen's estimates. It was in the 8 p.m. hour when the four networks really collided. The results show of Fox's "American Idol," during which 4 contestants of the top 24 got the boot, was the clear winner, with an audience of 23.07 million. Competing against it were CBS's "Survivor" (14.85 million) and the first hour of ABC's "Dancing With the Stars" (14.78 million), as well as the Olympics (17.74 million). The three non-Olympic programs cannibalized one another, as "Idol" didn't perform at its usual heights, and "Survivor" had its lowest-rated original episode ever. ("Dancing" did rebound in its second hour, lifting its total audience to 17.68 million.) Between 10 p.m. and 11:30 p.m., skating took over, with an audience of more than 30 million tuning in to NBC. Over all on Thursday, Fox ranked second in the 18-to-49 demographic, followed by CBS and ABC. Among total viewers for this interesting night, ABC was No. 2, followed by Fox and CBS. KATE AURTHUR

title: Yin, Yang and Back Relief at 105 Degrees
description: I NEVER thought I'd find myself standing on one leg in a mirrored room heated to 105 degrees, staring at my "third eye" while pretending to be a tree. But then again, I never thought I'd be reckless enough to bust my back riding a polo pony for the first time in 30 years. Funny how the old yin tries to reconnect with the young yang when the executive pursuit of pleasure becomes a pursuit of pain relief at all costs.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Violence Between Israeli Forces And Palestinian Militants Escalates
description: Israeli soldiers killed two Palestinians they said were planting bombs along the border fence in the Gaza Strip. One of the dead men was Zayan Dukhan, the son of a new Hamas legislator, Abdel Fattah Dukhan. Later, Israeli missiles hit a car of a group of Palestinians launching a rocket across the Gaza border toward Israel. In another incident, a Hamas militant died when a bomb he was making as he trained other militants blew up. In the West Bank town of Nablus, Israeli troops suspended a six-day operation in which an explosives factory was destroyed, eight Palestinians were killed and dozens wounded, and 14 wanted men were arrested, the army said. The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, called on the United Nations Security Council to meet to discuss the Israeli operation. STEVEN ERLANGER (NYT)

title: Francis Comes Alive Too Late for Knicks
description: The Knicks had old uniforms, a flashy new marquee guard and the same miserable results last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Moscow Market Chief Charged In Roof Collapse
description: The director of a Moscow market whose roof collapsed under heavy snow on Thursday, killing at least 60 people, was charged with negligence, city officials said. The charge was filed as rescue workers continued to remove wreckage at the ruined bazaar, although the authorities held out little hope of finding anyone alive. The collapse has been variously attributed to a wet snowfall, maintenance problems and design flaws. C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

title: For Ex-Council Speaker, Few Regrets and a New Role as N.Y.U. 'Public Figure'
description: After four years of holding the second most powerful job in city government -- City Council speaker -- Gifford Miller has moved on to a new life as teacher, consultant and private citizen.

title: Two Are Stabbed to Death After Dispute in Brooklyn
description: A man fatally stabbed two men in Brooklyn on Thursday night, the police said, after a dispute that was about noise, according to one victim's relatives. The suspect, whose name was not released, was still at large last night, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROARK, MARY E.
description: ROARK--Mary E. Of New York City, died on October 31, 2005, age 81. Wife of Richard D. Thenebe. A Kentucky native, Mary graduated from Christian College in Columbia, Missouri with a degree in Music. In the early 1950's she moved to NYC where Robert Joffrey invited her to play for his ballet classes, beginning a long collaboration between a renowned teacher and a gifted pianist. The first performance of the Robert Joffrey Ballet Company was on October 2nd, 1956, with Mary as company pianist. She also performed and toured with the Joffrey Ballet Orchestra, playing for the City Center seasons as well as tours through-out the U.S. and Europe. Mary married fellow pianist Richard D. Thenebe in 1964. Until her death, she continued to be active as a class accompanist for many NYC schools and teachers. Remembered with great appreciation for her devotion to dance and dancers, Mary was also a respected member of the Ansonia Tenants' Coalition. Memorial: New York City Center Studios, 130 West 56th St (4th floor), Sunday, February 26 at 7:30 PM.

title: In Iraq, Deadly Signs of Civil War
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Search Ends For Mudslide Victims
description: Rescue teams on a southern island on Saturday called off the search for victims of a mudslide that buried a village eight days earlier. As many as 1,100 people may have died, according to government officials. Only 415 people survived and no one was pulled out alive after the first day.

title: Outside U.S., Puzzlement Over Reaction to the Dubai Port Deal
description: LONDON, Feb. 24 - The tempest over Dubai's takeover of some United States port operations has surprised and puzzled shipping officials and experts outside America, who called the criticism misguided and contrary to global trade.

title: Mets Play Daily Game of Waiting for Julio
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 24 - His locker contains eight unused hangers, five shirts, four pairs of Adidas shoes and a pair of sandals. About 25 pieces of fan mail, wrapped in a rubber band, sit unopened on the top shelf, just above a memo reminding him of a physical examination that he should have completed Wednesday.

title: Taking Spying to Higher Level, Agencies Look for More Ways to Mine Data
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Feb. 23 - A small group of National Security Agency officials slipped into Silicon Valley on one of the agency's periodic technology shopping expeditions this month.

title: Influenza Vaccine for Children
description: The nation's top advisers on vaccine policy have taken a wise if timid step in recommending that all children from 2 to 5 years old be vaccinated against influenza every year, along with their parents, siblings and caregivers. This unanimous advice from the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices expands upon the earlier recommendation that babies at least 6 months old and toddlers be vaccinated. It could herald an important shift away from the current emphasis on vaccinating those at the highest risk of death from influenza and toward nearly universal vaccination.

title: U.S. Subpoenas 2 Dow Writers, Then Backs Off
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 - The Securities and Exchange Commission took the rare step of issuing a subpoena to two journalists two weeks ago when it ordered columnists at two Dow Jones publications to provide information about conversations that they had with stock traders and analysts.

title: Judge Lets BlackBerry Stay in Play for Now
description: RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 24 - Owners of BlackBerry wireless e-mail devices can continue to use them, at least for now.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Spare Times for Children column in some copies of Weekend yesterday about "What If the Rock Musical," a production by the City Lights Youth Theater at the McGinn/Cazale Theater on Broadway at 76th Street, misstated the admission policy. Tickets are $12 for adults, $8 for students and $6 each for groups of 10 or more; the show is not free.
