description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Lost and Found New York
Welcome, but, Shhh, You'll Frighten the Fish
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla. - Competitive bass fishing is tough enough, Aaron Martens will tell you. Tougher than any other sport he has tried.

title: One E-Mail, One Vote in Hedrick-Davis Feud
description: TURIN, Italy - IT is just not enough to watch the Olympics on television anymore, not in the way we used to. Beyond action, we demand interactivity. We want to referee -- if not the competitions, at least the confrontations. Dick Ebersol, this has been your reality television wake-up call.

title: Muslim Clerics Call for an End to Iraqi Rioting
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 24 - With the streets of the capital and other major cities largely emptied by an extraordinary daytime curfew, imams across Iraq called Friday for an end to the sectarian rioting that has left more than 170 people dead over the past three days, as political leaders held emergency meetings to contain the crisis.

title: A 98th Year of Hoping This Is the Cubs' Year
description: MESA, Ariz., Feb. 20 - In the major leagues in the past two seasons, there were two positively, unequivocally incredulous occurrences, the hard-ball equivalent of the cow jumping over the moon, of Martians lining up to order lattes at Starbucks. One of them was enough to stun fandom; the second, on the very heels of the first, was sufficient for people to wonder if this was simply a coincidence for the ages or evidence of an invisible celestial hand.

title: 1 Cafe, 1 Gas Station, 2 Roads: America's Emptiest County
description: MENTONE, Tex. - How empty is Loving County?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUBNO, HERBERT, ESQ.
description: DUBNO--Herbert, Esq. 71, on February 24, 2006. A partner of the patent law firm of Karl F. Ross. Beloved husband of Phyllis. Devoted father of Dan and Lisa, Michael and Loren, and Erica. Adored grandfather of Zoe, Teddy, Zachary and Maya. Service Sunday, 1:15 PM, at "The Riverside," 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave.

title: After the Hit Records, a Search for His Roots
description: "Yes, I did 'My Adidas,' " Darryl McDaniels, the hip-hop pioneer and vocalist for Run-DMC, says of his 1986 hit.

title: Love, Dignity and Angels Hanging on Wires
description: The commercials for Tyler Perry's film "Madea's Family Reunion" seem to promise a slapstick comedy about an obese black woman in late middle age who takes no guff and enjoys beating people up. It isn't exactly, and that's a disappointment.

title: On Wall Street, the Inflation View Is Rosier Than It Is on Main Street
description: CONSUMER prices in the United States are rising rapidly. Or maybe they are not.

title: Dubai Port Deal: More Surprises?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Pearls of Wisdom On Making It Work
description: STEVE FRANCIS became slightly annoyed yesterday morning after the third question about how he would fit in with his new -- and latest -- backcourt mate, Stephon Marbury. He had already answered the question several times Wednesday during an introductory news conference after being traded to the Knicks from the Orlando Magic. Now, hours before his first game as a Knick, the news media were nipping at his heels again.

title: Senator Introduces Bill Creating Guest Worker Program
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 - The Republican chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee unveiled draft legislation on Friday that would create a temporary guest worker program that could allow hundreds of thousands of foreigners to fill vacant jobs in the United States for periods of up to six years.

title: Board Urged Archdiocese to Pull Priest, Official Says
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 24 - A review board of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago advised Cardinal Francis George to remove a priest accused of molesting young boys three months before he was arrested and removed from ministry, according to the state's top child welfare agency official.

title: Virus Link to Rare Form of Prostate Cancer Revives Suspicions of Medical Detectives
description: A team of scientists in Cleveland and San Francisco said yesterday that they had discovered a new virus in patients who had a rare form of prostate cancer. The patients all had a particular genetic mutation.

title: When Lyrics Are Fragmentary and Melodies Elusive
description: Correction Appended

title: Arabs Tell Rice Violence Like Iraq's Could Spread
description: SHANNON, Ireland, Feb. 24 - As violence spread across Iraq during Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice's visit to the Middle East this week, kings, presidents and prime ministers told her that they were concerned that sectarian violence could spread across the Middle East.

title: Roll Over, Carl Orff: Dancers Have the Floor
description: There's no need to search door numbers to find the apartment where Nicholas Leichter and his company are rehearsing their newest dance. As soon as the elevator opens onto the third floor of the building in Chelsea, Carl Orff's monumental choral work, "Carmina Burana," hurls itself into your eardrums. All you have to do is follow the ecstatic, surging line of voices down the hallway.

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: Mining Company Glamis Gold Agrees to Buy Western Silver of Canada for $1 Billion Glamis Gold said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Western Silver Corporation for 1.2 billion Canadian dollars ($1.04 billion). Glamis said it would pay 0.688 share for Western Silver and spin off the copper assets of the combined company. The bid is worth 24.78 Canadian dollars for each Western Silver share, a premium of 27 percent over Thursday's closing price. Acquiring Western Silver will increase Glamis's gold reserves by 85 percent, mostly from the Penasquito project in Mexico, the chief executive, C. Kevin McArthur, said on a conference call. Glamis is based in Reno, Nev., and Western Silver is based in Vancouver. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

title: London Mayor Is Suspended Over Comments
description: LONDON, Feb. 24 - A disciplinary panel took the highly unusual step on Friday of suspending the mayor of London, Ken Livingstone, for four weeks to punish him for comparing a Jewish reporter to a Nazi concentration camp guard.

title: Corzine Offers Plan to Replenish Road Fund
description: TRENTON, Feb. 24 - Gov. Jon S. Corzine unveiled a plan on Friday to replenish New Jersey's depleted fund for road and bridge maintenance by refinancing $1.8 billion of the fund's debt, a move that would add billions of dollars to the state debt over the next 30 years.

title: Republicans See a Rare Opportunity in Buffalo District
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 24 - Since its creation in 1990, the State Senate district encompassing much of Buffalo and all of Niagara Falls has been so firmly Democratic that Republicans have all but ceded the seat in every election.

title: Comparing Apples to Oranges...or Dells
description: Already, the pundits are speaking out on whether or not Apple's new MacBook Pro laptop (featuring an Intel processor) is a better deal than Dell's laptops with the same processors. Here's an intriguing dissection of that argument. Turns out comparing laptops is like comparing cellular plans or mattresses from different chains; because you can't create identical configurations, direct comparisons are almost impossible.

title: Armed Group Shuts Down Part of Nigeria's Oil Output
description: IN THE NIGER DELTA, Nigeria, Feb. 24 - They have, by all appearances, just a handful of boats, some machine guns and grenade launchers and, perhaps equally important, an e-mail address.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Turkish Film Pulled From German Screens

title: Silenced by Islamist Rage
description: With every new riot over the Danish cartoons, it becomes clearer that the protests are no longer about the caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad, but about the demagoguery of Islamic extremists. The demonstrators are undeniably outraged by what they perceive as blasphemy. But radical Islamists are trying to harness that indignation to their political goals and their theocratic ends by fomenting hatred for the West and for moderate regimes in the Muslim world. These are dangerous games, and they require the most resolute response.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLY, MATTHEW J.
description: KELLY--Matthew J. On February 22. Beloved husband of Patricia (nee McCrossan). Cherished brother of Hugh and Margaret Kelly Norman. Friends may call Sunday 2-4 and 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel), 81st St. at Madison Ave. Mass of the Resurrection Monday, February 27 at 10:30AM, St. Jean Baptiste R.C. Church, 76th Street at Lexington Ave. Private burial.

title: Ruling May Undercut Google in Fight Over Its Book Scans
description: A recent federal court decision in California might undermine a pillar of defense for Google in its dispute with publishers and authors who are challenging the company's right to scan books that are still under copyright.

title: Former Aide to Cheney Gains Access to His Notes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 - I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney who is charged with lying to investigators about his role in the disclosure of the identity of a C.I.A. officer, won the right Friday to review his handwritten notes for a nine-month period surrounding the publication of the information.

title: At Juilliard, Three Dance Premieres Set to Three Fresh Musical Works
description: Scores commissioned for dance are rare birds these days, so Juilliard's "New Dances/New Music," which opened on Wednesday night at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater, was noteworthy in offering no fewer than three new compositions to accompany three new dance pieces. It was also noteworthy in that one of the compositions -- Christopher Rouse's "Friandises" -- was the product of an unusual co-commission by Juilliard and the New York City Ballet, which first performed Peter Martins's eponymous ballet to Mr. Rouse's score just two weeks ago.

title: Armenian Furor Over PBS Plan for Debate
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24 - The Public Broadcasting Service's plan to show a debate after its documentary in April on the Ottoman Turks' massacres of Armenians has infuriated Armenian-Americans. The debate, which includes two people who deny that the massacre constituted genocide, has ignited an aggressive campaign against the network.

title: In Iraq, Deadly Signs of Civil War (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Attacks surge despite security measures in Iraq
National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Strategist Has Bloomberg Swinging Away
description: In September, a new sign went up on the Williamsburg Bridge, and it won national notice as another example of New York City's singularly abrasive charm: "Leaving Brooklyn, Oy Vey!" The sign, the brainchild of the Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz, gained attention in newspapers as far away as Pittsburgh and Kansas City.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a letter on Thursday about students' e-mail to professors incorrectly implied that the letter writer, James Boyk of Los Angeles, is still teaching at Caltech. He is retired from the Caltech faculty.

title: Corrections
description: For the Record

title: Deal Sets Stage for a Killer's Sentencing
description: SOMERVILLE, N.J., Feb. 24 - The convicted serial killer Charles Cullen abruptly dropped his resistance on Friday to appear at his sentencing next week, and in response, the judge in the case said that he "stands ready to help" Mr. Cullen fulfill his wish to donate a kidney to an ailing friend.

title: Lawyer's $4.1 Million Fee Angers Holocaust Survivors
description: From 1996 to 1998, Burt Neuborne represented Holocaust survivors in a historic lawsuit that accused Swiss banks of helping the Nazis loot hundreds of millions of dollars worth of Jewish holdings. His labors helped win a $1.25 billion settlement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCKOY, DR. JUDITH FAY, MD, PH.D.
description: McKOY--Dr. Judith Fay, MD, Ph.D. Died on February 21, 2006. She is survived by her loving mother Barbara, father Vernon, sister Carol and brothers Anthony, Vernon and Roy. She also leaves behind nephews Jelani, Lee and niece Charlie-Joy. Visitation Wednesday, March 1, 4-8 PM, at Benta's Funeral Home, 630 St. Nicholas Ave., NY. Funeral service Thursday, March 2, at 11 AM at St. James Presbyterian Church, 409 W. 141st St. at St. Nicholas Ave.

title: In Iraq, Deadly Signs of Civil War
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARK, HENRY ALLEN
description: MARK--Henry Allen. A retired senior partner of the New York law firm Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft died on February 20, 2006 at his residence in the Duncaster Community, Bloomfield, CT. Born in Brooklyn, NY, May 16, 1909, Mr. Mark was the son of the late Henry A. Mark and Mary Clyde McCarroll Mark. He graduated with honors from Polly Prep Day School, Williams College, and the Cornell Law School. He was a member of the Sigma Phi Society, Phi Delta Kappa, and Phi Delta Phi at the Masonic Lodge of Floral Park, NY. Mr. Mark served as the mayor of Garden City, LI NY, a member of the Washington, CT Planning Commission, and trustee of the Gunnery School, Washington, CT 1982-1986. He was predeceased by his wife Isobel Ross Arnold Mark. He is survived by a brother Captain William Mark, cousins and three nieces. The memorial service will be held at 11:00 AM at Duncaster, Bloomfield, CT, Monday, February 27, 2006 with the interment at the Kittanning Cemetery, Kittanning, PA. In Lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the Cornell Law School Annual Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ESTRIN, JOSEPH, M.D.
description: ESTRIN--Joseph, M.D. Of Brooklyn, NY died after a brief illness on February 23 at the age of 93. Beloved son of the late Max and Anna Estrin. Brother of the late Eva Kanof. Dr. Estrin received his undergraduate training at the City College of New York and received his M.D. degree from the Long Island College of Medicine in 1936. He practiced medicine and later general surgery in Brooklyn from 1936 until his retirement in 1985. His medical practice was interrupted by his service as a Captain in the Army Medical Corps stationed in the Pacific during World War II. He was on the faculty of the State University of New York College of Medicine at Downstate and was highly valued as an educator in the training of generations of medical students and surgical residents. He was affiliated with Maimonides Medical Center as an attending physician and surgeon for over 50 years and continued to be active serving on committees there until the time of his death. He was the author of "An Uncommon Commitment", a history of Maimonides Medical Center. In addition to having been a highly regarded surgeon, he was a talented artist, sculptor, lecturer on diverse subjects including word origins, and was a memorable raconteur. He will be deeply missed by his extended family, his many friends and colleagues. Graveside funeral services will be held at 2 P.M. on February 26 at Mount Judah Cemetery, Queens, NY.

title: How a Speech Won the Cold War
description: Amherst, Mass. - FIFTY years ago today, the Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev gave a "secret speech" at the 20th Communist Party Congress that changed both his country and the world. By denouncing Stalin, whose God-like status had helped to legitimize Communism in the Soviet Bloc, Khrushchev began a process of unraveling it that culminated in 1991 with the collapse of the Soviet Union. This great deed deserves to be celebrated on its anniversary.

title: Nurses Say Negotiations With City Are at Impasse
description: While hospitals across the country have pushed up salaries to attract nurses in response to a shortage, New York City's public hospitals have not given their unionized nurses a raise in more than three years.

title: Benno Besson, 83, Director of Plays and Brecht Disciple, Is Dead
description: Benno Besson, a disciple of Bertolt Brecht who became one of the most admired stage directors in Europe, died on Feb. 16 in a Berlin hospital. He was 83.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VAN DYKE, WILLIAM D
description: VAN DYKE--William D, 85, died February 23. He is survived by his devoted wife, Lee Van Dyke. Bill was a Captain US Army, WWII awarded the Purple Heart and Silver Star. He will be deeply missed and forever loved. He leaves a brother, Robert Van Dyke and sister, Camilla Thomas. Memorial service will be held Monday February 27, 2PM, at St. Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Ave., at 54th St. In lieu of flowers contributions to Andrew Heiskell Library for the Blind, 40 W. 20th St., NYC 10011.

title: Lawyers Sum Up Case Against Police Captain
description: A lawyer for Eric Adams, a Police Department captain facing punishment for comments he made on a television program last fall, told a department judge yesterday that the trial "should never have been."

title: 12-Tone Pieces of Warm, Not Daunting, Power
description: There's a spoof radio ad going around the Internet hawking a recording of greatest hits of the 12-tone repertory. But funnily enough, the music threatens to undermine the joke. As the announcer tells you that you won't want to miss a chance to have all this great music together, the music wells up behind his voice -- expressive, rich and beautiful.

title: Oil Worries, and Price, Rise After Turmoil Abroad
description: DISRUPTIONS in the oil patch served as bookends to the debate that consumed the nation this week over ports and national security.

title: Arts, Briefly; Yo-Yo Ma Wins $1 Million
description: Yo-Yo Ma, below, has been awarded a 2006 Dan David Prize, worth $1 million, for his contribution to "cultural heritage protection" through his Silk Road Project. The prize is one of three $1 million prizes sponsored annually by Mr. David, a Tel Aviv-based philanthropist and president of Photo-Me International. This year's winners were announced yesterday at the Ministry of Culture in Paris. Mr. Ma's prize was in the category of "past time dimension." The prize for the "present time" was shared by four print media journalists: Magdi Allam, an Egyptian-born Italian reporter; Mnica Gonzlez, from Chile; Goenawan Mohamad, from Indonesia; and Adam Michnik, from Poland. The "future time" prize was shared by two American cancer researchers: Dr. John Mendelsohn of the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center and Dr. Joseph Schlessinger of Yale University School of Medicine. The awards ceremony will be held at Tel Aviv University on May 21. ALAN RIDING

title: Political Memo; G.O.P. Stalwarts Line Up Behind a New Jersey Name
description: TRENTON, Feb. 23 - Although Election Day is still nine months away, some of the top figures in the national Republican Party are already stepping forward to help state Senator Thomas H. Kean Jr. in his effort to change the "state" in his job title to "United States."

title: Anthrax Traces Found at 3 Sites as Victim Worsens
description: The Greenwich Village home of a man infected with inhalation anthrax after working with unprocessed animal skins tested positive for the deadly germ, city officials said yesterday. Tests on the van and workplace used by the man, Vado Diomande, also tested positive for traces of anthrax.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) MRS. HARRIS -- Annette Bening and Ben Kingsley star in a television film about the most scandalous murder case of 1980. Jean Harris (Ms. Bening), the 56-year-old headmistress of a Virginia girls' school, shot and killed her longtime lover, Dr. Herman Tarnower (Mr. Kingsley, above, with Ms. Bening), the celebrity creator of the Scarsdale Diet. But she really had gone to his house to commit suicide, she said.

title: Reorganization Redux
description: If there's one thing that Hurricane Katrina has taught us, it is that just shuffling the bureaucratic deck does not make us safer.

title: I.R.S. Finds Sharp Increase in Illegal Political Activity
description: The I.R.S. said yesterday that it saw a sharp increase in prohibited political activity by charities and churches in the last election cycle, a trend that it aims to reverse as the country heads into the midterm elections.

title: Scramble to Back Port Deal: Making of Political Disaster
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHANE, JAKOB T., MD.
description: COHANE--Jakob T., MD. Jaks sheer brilliance, his mastery of seven languages, his insight into human nature and his gentleness endeared him to all those lives he touched. Against all odds, Jak put himself through medical school, he became a renowned internist, specializing in endocrinology, then recognizing the emotional pain of so many of his patients he became a Psychiatrist. His psychiatric residency was at New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center followed by a private practice in psychiatry. He retired in 1995. Jak will be sorely missed and leaves us all with loving memories. Andy, Joyce, Devona, Andrew & Jakob Morrissey

title: Military Contractor Pleads Guilty to Bribery
description: Correction Appended

title: Museums Assert Right on Showing Antiquities
description: Over the last decade the benign image of the antiquities collector has given way to a far more sinister one. Once cast as generous lenders and donors -- the lifeblood of American museums -- such collectors are now seen as central cogs in a conspiracy to move artifacts looted from foreign soil into museum display cases.

title: Democracy and Vouchers
description: To the Editor:

title: Queens Co-op Has It All: Golf, Shops and a Resident Gadfly
description: North Shore Towers, an upscale co-op complex in eastern Queens, consists of three hulking 33-story buildings along the Grand Central Parkway near the Nassau County border.

title: Responding to U.S. Restrictions, Venezuela Will Reduce Flights by American Carriers
description: BOGOT, Colombia, Feb. 24 - In its latest political dispute with the United States, Venezuela's populist government has announced that it is unilaterally reducing flights by American-owned airlines starting on March 1, a measure taken after Washington declined to lift restrictions on Venezuelan carriers for safety reasons.

title: South Dakota's Governor Says He Favors Abortion Ban Bill
description: Gov. Mike Rounds said yesterday that he was inclined to sign a bill that would ban nearly all abortions in South Dakota, the broadest measure to outlaw abortion anywhere in the country.

title: I.O.C. Is Losing in a Game With Drug Cheaters
description: TURIN, Italy - ITALIAN authorities are attempting to validate their raid of Austrian athletes last week by turning their investigation into a game of "Clue."

title: Oh, Those Hidden Monthlies
description: FOR more than a year I've been paying $4.95 a month for access to product reviews on the Consumer Reports Web site. I'm not an appliance junkie. I just happened to sign up when my husband and I were looking for a washer-dryer, and told myself: It's only $4.95 a month; I'll cancel as soon as we figure out what to buy.

title: Brooklyn Fire Kills 4, and Officials Suspect Arson
description: A fire that officials believe was deliberately started tore through a Brooklyn apartment building early yesterday, killing four people, including two children and their mother, and forcing a family of seven to jump from their second-floor apartment.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Kidnap Gang Suspect Held In Ivory Coast
description: France has asked Ivory Coast to extradite Youssouf Fofana, described as the leader of a gang accused of abducting and torturing a Jewish man, Ilan Halimi, and leaving him to die near a suburban Paris train station on Feb. 13. Mr. Fofana, 25, was arrested Wednesday in Abidjan, where he is believed to have fled after the body of Mr. Halimi, 23, was found. A total of 13 people have been arrested or placed under investigation. President Jacques Chirac and other French leaders attended a service for Mr. Halimi at a Paris synagogue on Thursday. Jewish organizations plan a march through Paris tomorrow to protest what they regard as the anti-Semitic nature of the crime. CRAIG S. SMITH (NYT)

title: Ousted Czechs Rooting for One of Their Own
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 24 - The handshake line started with four Rangers on one side and one on the other.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GELLIS, EDNA ALPERIN
description: GELLIS--Edna Alperin. 95 years old, died on Febraury 23, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Harold Gellis. Devoted mother of Willard and Shirley Gellis, Ann Gellis and Maxine Grolnick Colchamiro and her husband Harvey. Loving grandmother of Elizabeth, Jenny, Peter, Edward, Debbie, Wendy and Judy. Cherished great grandmother of Alexandra, Isabella & Sophie. Services Sunday 11:00 AM "Riverside - Nassau North Chapels", 55 N. Station Plaza (opp LIRR), Great Neck, NY

title: Arts, Briefly; Great Day in Jazz on DVD
description: "A Great Day in Harlem," Jean Bach's moving jazz documentary that commemorates the taking of a famous photograph of the jazz elite, is now available on DVD, with many extras. In August 1958, 57 musicians gathered on a Harlem stoop to be photographed for Esquire by Art Kane. In the film, Mona Hinton's home movie of the historic photo shoot and Mike Lipskin's still photographs of the event are interwoven with film clips of performances and interviews with 30 jazz greats to create an intimate, joyous suite on the jazz life. Extras on the DVD include a second disc that features many hours of video profiles of all the musicians involved in the photograph. STEPHEN HOLDEN

title: Morocco Moves Forward
description: To the Editor:

title: Harold Hunter, 31, Skateboarder With Celebrity Appeal, Dies
description: Harold Hunter, whose skateboarding prowess and outsize personality led him to modeling and movie roles, celebrity friendships and prominence in the downtown Manhattan scene, was found dead on Feb. 17 in the East Village housing project where he grew up. He was 31.

title: Former Friend Testifies Gotti Had a Lover; He Denies It
description: Despite his notorious past as an acting boss of the Gambino crime family, John A. Gotti was a devoted husband and father who frowned on a subordinate cheating on his wife, Mr. Gotti's lawyer told a federal jury this week.

title: Woods Falls When Putt on No. 18 Does Not
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., Feb. 24 - When Tiger Woods set his putter blade behind his ball and the amphitheater at La Costa Resort and Spa grew still, Chad Campbell stood off to the side on the 18th green and waited for Woods to make a birdie.

title: A Year Abroad (or 3) as a Career Move
description: It was a few months before she was to graduate from Colgate University in 2002, but Lauren DiCioccio was not ready for the briefcase or the Brooks Brothers look.

title: Welcome Back, Alumni
description: This month on "General Hospital," Luke Spencer -- a leading character in the soap opera, played as always by Anthony Geary, who joined the cast in 1978 -- was lying in a hospital bed with a mysterious illness. A man approached him, and Luke's eyes widened with recognition. "I'm dead," Luke said. "I'm dead and gone to hell."

title: Iran Is Said to Start Enriching Fuel, on Very Small Scale
description: PARIS, Feb. 24 - International nuclear inspectors are expected to report next week that Iran has started producing enriched uranium on a very small scale, indicating that it is striving to solve technological problems in its nuclear program, European officials said Friday.

description: I am just sitting here with a glass of wine in my hands, reflecting on what a really bad week you and your friends have had," read the e-mail message to Herb Greenberg, a well-known columnist for MarketWatch.com.

title: Abortion Returns to Center Stage
description: On Tuesday the Supreme Court agreed to consider the constitutionality of the Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act, a measure passed overwhelmingly by Congress in 2003 but rejected as unconstitutional by three federal appeals courts for not providing exceptions for a woman's health.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHIMMEL, ALFRED
description: SCHIMMEL--Alfred. On February 23. Beloved husband of Gertrude, father of Edward and the late Victor, father-in-law of Marlene and Sydney, grandfather of Diana, Gregory, Amelia and Joanna. Services Sunday, February 26, 2:15 P.M. at the The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: With One Gold in Hand, Ligety Isn't Content to Suddenly Play It Safe
description: SESTRIERE, Italy, Feb. 24 - On Saturday, Ted Ligety will attack the final Alpine skiing event of the Winter Games, the men's slalom, with his habitual desperation. He says he will not discover conservatism just because he won a gold medal in the men's combined last week.

title: After the Hit Records, a Search for His Roots
description: "Yes, I did 'My Adidas,' " Darryl McDaniels, the hip-hop pioneer and vocalist for Run-DMC, says of his 1986 hit.

title: Dubai Port Deal: More Surprises?
description: To the Editor:

title: Squeezing 4 Monarchs Into One Big Royal Court
description: "Kings of the Dance," the all-star display of male ballet dancing with Angel Corella and Ethan Stiefel of American Ballet Theater, Johan Kobborg of the Royal Ballet and Nikolay Tsiskaridze of the Bolshoi Ballet, is an intermittently engaging blockbuster with a divided soul. It opened a four-performance run Thursday at City Center.

title: A Visitor From the West Takes Charge of the Band
description: Gerald Wilson, the trumpeter, composer, arranger and conductor, is 87. On Thursday at the Rose Theater, taking part in "Central Avenue Breakdown," a Jazz at Lincoln Center concert centering on Los Angeles jazz, he hijacked the evening. It was not his band, and not his city, but he handled the 15-member Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra like a paper airplane.

title: A Blundering Dog and a Couple of Springs
description: In the making of movies for children these days, a burst or two of flatulence seems to be mandatory. But beyond a certain point, the time-honored gag becomes a sign of desperation. Certainly that has never been more evident than in "Doogal," an animated clunker that calls on its designated noisemaker (a moose voiced by Kevin Smith) something like a dozen times.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Finland Stops Russia With Another Shutout
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 24 - Teemu Selanne was chewing a huge wad of gum as he answered questions about Finland's 4-0 upset of Russia on Friday night at the Palasport Olimpico. This was no small feat. Selanne lost three front teeth Wednesday, when he was struck in the mouth by a stick during Finland's 4-3 victory over the United States.

title: INSIDE
description: Iran Is Said to Start Small-Scale Nuclear Fuel Work Inspectors are expected to report next week that Iran has started making enriched uranium on a very small scale, indicating that it still faces technical problems. At the initial pace, it would take years to fuel a bomb. PAGE A4

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Thursday, about a lawsuit filed by a fair housing group in Chicago against Craigslist.org, accusing it of publishing discriminatory advertisements, referred incorrectly to data from comScore Media Metrix. Of the 26.3 million people who used online classified ad services in 2005, nearly 9 million visited Craigslist; the figure did not represent those who posted ads.

title: Craft Nears Tricky Mars Orbit Amid Nail-Biting Time at NASA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 - The most advanced spacecraft ever sent to Mars will soon enter the most critical phase of its mission: slowing down enough to go into orbit around the planet.

title: The Faculty Club
description: Now that Lawrence Summers has resigned, it's time for the editor of The Harvard Crimson to follow his example. There is no excuse for the paper's decision to publish a poll showing that students, by a three to one margin, wanted Summers to remain the president of Harvard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THORBECKE, WILLEM H.
description: THORBECKE--Willem H. In Pittsburgh, PA. on February 20, 2006 died after a long illness. Past executive of Shell Oil, Mobil Chemical, and Dravo International in Japan, Holland, England, and the U.S. Leaves devoted wife Sonya Stokowski Thorbecke and four children.

description: AMERICAS

description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Sees a Tough Test for the Skills of the Iraqi Troops
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 - President Bush said Friday that the violence in Iraq this week was "a test for the Iraqi security forces," but he gave no hint whether he was considering a more vigorous response by American forces to restore order, or whether the spike in sectarian violence might delay their eventual departure.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Tribunal Rejects Milosevic Travel Demand
description: International judges trying Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, on genocide charges turned down his request to travel to Moscow for medical treatment for his heart condition and other ailments. The judges said that they were not convinced that he would return from Moscow, where his wife and son live, to complete his trial and said that his medical needs could be met doctors visiting him here. MARLISE SIMONS (NYT)

title: Hedrick, Falling Short of the Hype, Puts On a Happy Face
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 24 - As the last heat of the 10,000 meters wore on, Team Hedrick began to realize that the Olympics would not end with a golden tint. Chad Hedrick started to fade, dropping off the pace necessary to catch the Dutch star Bob de Jong, and the crowd of Hedrick's family and friends cheered with growing desperation each time he circled the track on Friday afternoon.

title: Hybrid Cars to Get High-Occupancy Waiver
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24 - Hybrid-power cars will be allowed to use high-occupancy-vehicle lanes on the Long Island Expressway starting on March 1, regardless of how few people are in the car, the Pataki administration said on Friday.

title: Frederick Busch, Author of Poetic Fiction, Dies at 64
description: Correction Appended

title: Office Humor Needs Work
description: MAGAZINES like Maxim may be sophomoric but at least they add a dash of self-irony that makes their puerility a bit easier to swallow. Office Pirates, the Webzine introduced this week by Time Warner and run by a former editor of Maxim, is an online version of that guy in your office who makes a lot of bad jokes and doesn't let the fact that nobody is laughing slow him down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PETROU, LILLIAN B.
description: PETROU--Lillian B. On February 22, 2006. Beloved wife of Dimitri. She will be sorely missed by her family and friends.

title: H&R Block Fumbles on Its Own Tax Return
description: Would you trust someone to do your taxes who can't even do his own?

title: Chairwoman of Universal Seems Poised to Leave
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24 - Universal Pictures teetered on the brink of a top executive change on Friday as Stacey Snider was given the weekend to decide whether to remain as studio chairwoman or to accept an offer to run DreamWorks, which was recently acquired by Paramount Pictures.

title: Street-Corner Immigration Reform
description: The illegal immigrants who trim our hedges, prepare our food and care for our children have been compared to an invading army. If so, they have descended on a land desperate for occupation. This is a nation that insists on paying as little as possible for goods and services, and as long as it remains impractical to send lawns, motel beds and dirty dishes overseas, determined immigrants and semiporous borders will continue to feed the American addiction to cheap labor.

title: Sheffield Rants, Then Gives Yanks a Rave
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 24 - Gary Sheffield is a talker, a relentless talker, and a defender, a persistent defender. When Sheffield is simultaneously talking about and defending himself, the combination can be combustible and, at times, confusing. Did he say that? Did he mean that? Has he changed his mind yet?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUBIN, MILDRED (COHEN)
description: LUBIN--Mildred (Cohen). February 24, formerly of Elmhurst. Wife of the late Bernard. Sister of the late Sydney, Ralph, and Dorothy. Aunt of Terry and Harriet Cohen, Ellen Grollman, Carl and Toby Sloane, Richard and Margie Sloane, Stephen and Kit Sloane, Todd Stephenson. Graveside services at Knollwood Park Cemetery, 57-80 Cooper Ave., Ridgewood, NY on Sunday, February 26 at 1:00 P.M. Expressions of sympathy to Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, 330 Brookline Ave., Boston, MA 02215. For information contact Stanetsky - Hymanson, Salem, MA.

title: Thai Premier Calls New Election but Refuses to Step Down
description: BANGKOK, Feb. 24 - Facing a storm over a tax-free windfall from the sale of his family communications company, Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra asked the king to dissolve Parliament on Friday, forcing an early election.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Money For Group Is Cut
description: The federal government has stopped financing the Silver Ring Thing, a group that promotes abstinence to teenagers. The deal, reached Wednesday, is part of a settlement with the American Civil Liberties Union, whose Massachusetts branch sued the Department of Health and Human Services last year, saying the Silver Ring Thing was overtly evangelical Christian and therefore not eligible for financial assistance. The department terminated the group's grant Jan. 31. The group, which operated nationwide, had received more than $1 million since 2003. KATIE ZEZIMA (NYT)

title: Doctors Trying to Put Pataki Back on His Normal Diet
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's doctors expect him to remain hospitalized through the weekend but are trying to re-establish a normal diet as he recovers from complications that followed his appendectomy, his spokesman said yesterday.

title: Drug Tests Are Clean, but Case Is Hardly Over
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 24 - The International Olympic Committee said Friday that doping tests on 10 Austrian skiers had come back negative for performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Amid Revelry, Evidence of City's Cruel Transformation
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 24 - For a long time I hated Mardi Gras, and tried to flee the city in those weeks.

title: Child Welfare Worker Seized on J.F.K. Drug Charge
description: A child welfare worker was arrested after screeners at Kennedy International Airport found two glass crack pipes in his carry-on luggage, the Port Authority Police Department said yesterday.

title: Gold Spangled, Cheek Is Now Star Spangled
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 24 - Joey Cheek was chosen to carry the American flag in the closing ceremony Sunday after rising above his fellow United States athletes, many of whom struggled in these Winter Games.

title: Suicide Bombers Fail to Enter Saudi Oil Plant
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Feb. 24 - A suicide bomb attack on Saudi Arabia's sprawling Abqaiq oil facility was thwarted Friday, when guards opened fire on two explosives-laden cars, causing them to detonate at a security gate about a mile from the main entrance, the Saudi Interior Ministry said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FERBER, DR. ROBERT M.
description: FERBER--Dr. Robert M. July 25, 1920--February 23, 2006. Beloved husband, father, grandpa, friend--He was a great conversationalist who took pleasure in being an independent thinker and superb craftsman. We miss him so much. "He plays the violin. He tucks it right under his chin, and he bows."

title: Sectarian Bloodshed Reveals Strength of Iraq Militias
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 24 - The sectarian violence that has shaken Iraq this week has demonstrated the power that the many militias here have to draw the country into a full-scale civil war, and how difficult it would be for the state to stop it, Iraqi and American officials say.

title: When to Play That Club King? Read All About It in the Bulletin
description: Most major national and international tournaments have daily bulletins. These provide information for the players, like the schedule and location of events, and include descriptions of interesting deals. They are a labor of love for the editors, who each day work well past the end of play and are rarely -- never? --paid a wage commensurate with the hours spent toiling over a hot computer keyboard. But what tournament has the best daily bulletins?

title: In Blinding Snow, Unsung U.S. Skier Finds Gold
description: SESTRIERE, Italy, Feb. 24 - Julia Mancuso stood in the start gate staring into a blinding snowstorm. Somewhere, several hundred feet below, through 42 gates and countless blowing snowflakes, was the finish line.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about the introduction of Heineken Premium Light beer, misstated the surname of a sales executive at Yahoo, whose Web site will carry ads for the product. He is Chris J. Karl, not Keil.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HOROWITZ, ZELDA
description: HOROWITZ--Zelda. February 25, 2001. Five years, 5 greatgrandchildren. Missing you always. Linda and family

title: Handmaidens in Red, Inspired by Margaret Atwood's Tale
description: For her first evening-length work, Carrie Ahern turned to "The Handmaid's Tale," by Margaret Atwood, for inspiration. In the novel, published in 1985 and set in the futuristic Republic of Gilead, a majority of women are infertile; the rest are forced to serve as handmaidens, or birth mothers for the upper class. Ms. Ahern's emotionally racked "Red" features eight such women -- aptly draped in long red dresses -- all straining to belong in such a spine-chilling place.

title: Schools Where the Only Real Test Is Basketball
description: Each day at Eldon Academy in Michigan, Dewayne Walker could sleep till 11 a.m., practice basketball for 90 minutes and never spend more than two hours in class. He said that the only other students were his teammates, that his only teacher was also his coach. "I'm not a Harvard-type person," Walker said, "but I thought it would be a lot more work."

title: Philippine police detain critics amid state of emergency
National Briefing | West: California: Levee Declaration
description: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger declared an "emergency" for the levees guarding the state's agricultural heartland from floods, ordering that more workers be shifted to shoring them up. State officials predict that an earthquake with a magnitude of 6.5 would result in a "catastrophic failure" of the flood-control system around the Sacramento River. That would threaten the drinking water of 24 million people and cost the state's economy as much as $40 billion, the governor said in the emergency order. He has proposed spending more than $30 billion on water and flood-control projects under his $222 billion infrastructure plan for the next two decades. After a tour of levees near Sacramento this week, the governor said they were vulnerable.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 15 about promotional gifts to celebrities overstated the value of leftover gift bags at the recent Golden Globe awards ceremony, which the board of the Hollywood Foreign Press Association decided against distributing to association members. The value was about $1,300 each, not $62,000. (The higher amount was the value of gift boxes for celebrity presenters at the event; Philip Berk, the association's president, said none of those were left over.)

title: Call Him Crazy, but Olympic Skier Auditions for a Wide Receiver Slot
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 24 - Just one week after competing in the Olympics in Italy, Jeremy Bloom is participating in this weekend's N.F.L. combine.

title: Comics Fans and Heroes, Discovered or Masked
description: The first New York Comic-Con came to Gotham City yesterday, where visitors were met by a life-size statue of (who else?) Batman, constructed from Legos.

title: A Move to Add Still More Fine Print to Advertised Airfares
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 24 - If a number of large airlines have their way, comparison shopping -- a main force in driving down airfares -- could get much more difficult.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Everybody seems to be imprisoned in their own sectarian or political affiliations. They don't seem to be able to rise above these things."

title: Love, Dignity and Angels Hanging on Wires
description: The commercials for Tyler Perry's film "Madea's Family Reunion" seem to promise a slapstick comedy about an obese black woman in late middle age who takes no guff and enjoys beating people up. It isn't exactly, and that's a disappointment.

title: Musical Rite of Passage
description: The New York debut, once a musical rite of passage, is not what it was. But an ambitious Ukrainian still wants to make his mark.

description: Classical pianist Vitalij Kuprij makes his Carnegie Hall debut. Narration by Classical Music reporter Daniel J. Wakin. (Producers: Angel Franco and Kassie Bracken)

Selborne Journal: Wednesday, 25 February 1784: 29 8/10; 45; S. Wet, clouds, sun & mild. SOUTH LAMBETH: Little snow on the road.

title: Evangelist Thrives in N.Y.C.
description: An evangelist thrives by embracing the city and its cultural identity.

title: Day 15 at the Games
description: Bode Miller's ignominious Olympics ended with another disqualification, while Apolo Anton Ohno won gold in the 500-meter short track.

title: Old Friends' Intentional Community
description: A group of elderly Californians, seeking alternatives to the conventional retirement home, are opting for old age on their own terms. (Producer: Brent McDonald)

title: Thank You for Not Smoking
description: If youre bothered by neighbors who smoke, tough luck.

title: Carrying a Big Stick to Harlem
description: Early one Saturday in the basketball capital of the world, the echoes of whistles and sneaker squeaks bounced off the gymnasium walls at A. Philip Randolph High School in West Harlem.

title: An Academic Retreat
description: "Domains" (Feb. 12) is one of my favorite features. As someone who is far from "finished," I'm relieved to read that a woman as accomplished as Donna Shalala considers herself the same. In an air-conditioned world, she is a breath of fresh air.

title: Betting on the Future
description: THE future of thoroughbred racing in New York State will take shape in the coming weeks as a committee assembled by Gov. George Pataki and state lawmakers drafts recommendations for reorganizing the industry. The committee's ultimate decisions could have major effects on consumers and taxpayers in the state.

title: Lautenberg and Menendez, Perfect Together
description: TRENTON - -- For all of the publicity that Senator Robert Menendez generated this last week for lambasting the Bush administration's decision to give a Dubai company the management of six American ports, there was someone who was noticeably absent: New Jersey's senior senator, Frank R. Lautenberg.

title: INSIDE
description: Bird Flu Raises Concerns in France and Nigeria French officials announced that they had discovered a deadly strain of bird flu among domestic turkeys, immediately disrupting the country's poultry market and raising citizens' fears that they too may be in danger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FONBERG, MACIA ZAZULA
description: FONBERG -- Macia Zazula. Died February 22. You touched our lives in so many loving and wonderful ways. You will always be in our hearts. Pegi, Ben, Johanna and Claudia

title: The Remix; L.A. Stories
description: In a town where power is measured by proximity to celebrities, even dead celebrities aren't immune to the latest craze: ghost busters. Who you gonna call? The prince of the paranormal, Dr. Larry Montz, who charges $500 and up to connect with supernatural superstars. At one Laurel Canyon home, for example, Montz and his team of Bill Murray manqus scoured the house looking for the ghost of Jim Morrison, who lived there in the 60's. Turns out that Morrison, or at least his specter, was in the closet (once a balcony where he wrote songs, according to Montz). "We confirmed he was in the house, and that's all the client wanted," says Montz, who has a Ph.D. in parapsychology, before adding that people in Los Angeles "usually want famous ghosts to stick around." But, proving that, in the minds of Angelenos, even the netherworld has a velvet rope, Montz explains that, for B-list ghouls, "we find out what the ghosts' issues are and why they are still earthbound, and try to get them to the other side."

title: Unfolding Microsoft's secret site
MySpace Draws a Questionable Crowd
description: PARENTS, educators and law enforcement officials in Connecticut are reacting with alarm to MySpace.com, the Internet hangout for teenagers and young adults, the content of which is shocking parents and, according to the police, attracting sexual predators.

title: Gaps in Security Stretch From Model Port in Dubai to U.S.
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Feb. 25 - To some American officials, the sprawling port along the Persian Gulf here, where steel shipping containers are stacked row after row as far as the eye can see, is a model for the post-9/11 world.

title: ASIA ON THEIR MINDS
description: With roots reaching back to 1919 in Shanghai, the American International Group seems a fitting global sponsor of the Asia Society's 50th anniversary season, celebrated at a dinner in New York last week. The first Western company allowed to sell life insurance on its own in China, A.I.G. faces potential competition from its former chairman and chief executive, Maurice R. Greenberg, who is exploring various investments there, including some in the insurance industry. Asked at the dinner if this concerned him, Martin J. Sullivan, A.I.G.'s president and chief executive and Mr. Greenberg's successor, said: "I'm just focused on running our business. I remain very upbeat about Asia."

title: FREQUENT FLIERS
description: "Fellow travelers" may not be a phrase that has ever been applied to John J. Mack, the chief executive of Morgan Stanley, and his predecessor, Philip J. Purcell. But together, the two men broke the $1 million barrier aboard Morgan Stanley's corporate jets last year.

title: When the Flag Falls
description: When the Flag Falls

description: Let's be blunt: this fuss about ports is really about Arabs.

title: Cabo This Year? The College Crowd Looks Beyond Cancn
description: Cancn's loss is Cabo's gain. With Cancn still recovering from last year's rash of hurricanes, many students are looking into alternative spring-break destinations like Acapulco (above) this year.

title: Not Always Strength in Numbers
description: THIS will be a "data-dependent week," predicts John Lynch, chief market analyst at Evergreen Investments. And with Ben S. Bernanke shaping up to be a data-dependent Federal Reserve chairman, investors may find several pitfalls ahead, Mr. Lynch warned.

description: Ethos Water

title: Democrats See Hope of Winning Governors' Seats
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 - At a time when considerable political attention is focused on the Democrats' uphill struggle to recapture Congress, leaders of both parties say Democrats appear to be in a much stronger position on another pivotal battlefield this November, the contests for governors.

title: Spool Days
description: At a dinner party over the holidays, the host -- a Hollywood agent with an eye for the provocative -- asked the seated group, whose members did not know one another well, a question that was designed to reveal the true self: What skill do you possess that would not be expected? Whenever questions like this are posed, there are always those who will come up with a self-flattering answer, as with the woman who twittered and then gushed, "Well, I'm good at -- " and proceeded, of course, to name a sex act that seemed utterly predictable. We all nodded, but none of us were surprised. Then, of course, there were the out-and-out braggers: "I'm great at windsurfing," said a studio executive who looked as if he had spent all of his disposable income on windsurfing lessons (and little outfits) just so that he could make this claim. "No," said our host. "Try and think of a less exclusive skill. Something that precedes your rise to power, something that would be apparent even if you were penniless."

description: A picture caption on Page 10 of the Travel section today with an article about a culinary cruise misspells the surname of a cook at the Bimini Road restaurant on Paradise Island in the Bahamas. She is Deanne Bastain, not Bastian.

title: City Officials Await Results of Anthrax Tests
description: The New York City man who contracted inhalation anthrax after working with untreated animal hides remained in serious condition yesterday, as the authorities awaited results of laboratory tests from the Crown Heights, Brooklyn, home of one of the man's colleagues.

Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance by e-mail, to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail, to Westchester Cultural Calendar, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036-3959.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEATY, CATHERINE RANDALL HILSON
description: BEATY--Catherine Randall Hilson. Passed away on February 23, 2006 in Waynesville, NC. Beloved wife of the late John Thurston Beaty, M.D. Born in Cincinnati, OH on June 13, 1928 to Mildred Kinsolving and Herbert Thomson Randall. Longtime resident of New York City and Greenwich, CT. while married to the late John Stern Hilson. Devoted mother of William Edwin Hilson of New Canaan, CT, Dwight Randall Hilson of Greenwich, CT and Melissa Hilson Parker of Point Manalapan, FL. Adoring grandmother of Maximilian Parker, Derek Parker, Beau Parker, Emlyn Hilson and Samantha Hilson. Services at Grace Church of the Mountains, 394 North Haywood Street, Waynesville, NC on Saturday, March 4, at 12:00 noon. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to the Haywood County Arts Council-Catherine Beaty Endowment Fund, P.O. Box 306, Waynesville, NC 28786.

title: A Piece of Cake
Iraqi leaders pledge to renew efforts to form new government; fresh attacks kill 5
The Remix; Lux-o-Meter
description: We all know that fashion is fickle. But who knew that world events could have such an impact at the cash register? In November, Unity Marketing reported that purchases of luxury apparel had dipped 27 percent from the previous year among luxury-goods shoppers in the wake of Hurricane Katrina, Harriet Miers's Supreme Court debacle and the indictment of I. Lewis Libby. A month later, that hell-in-a-handbasket feeling was alleviated as lower gas prices and increased hiring boosted consumer confidence. Here are our predictions for how high-end goods would fare based on realpolitik hypotheticals. CHRISTINE MUHLKE

title: The High Cost of Breaking Even
description: "Bug," the blood-drenched thriller by Tracy Letts, had all the hallmarks of a runaway success: fawning reviews, a young, hip cast and a movie deal. Despite running for 11 months at the Barrow Street Theater, though, the $200,000 production barely broke even, only collecting its first dollars in the black -- and there weren't many of them -- in its closing weeks in January 2005. It's a phenomenon that is all too familiar to commercial producers Off Broadway, which has been in a protracted slump in the last couple of years. "It's a constant struggle to justify the business," said Scott Morfee, one of the "Bug" producers. But what exactly makes the business so tough? Well, expenses, which keep growing, and audiences, which don't. "Bug" cost about $34,000 a week to run; some Off Broadway productions cost twice that. Mr. Morfee and his partners kept expenses down a number of ways, including managing the show themselves and staging it at the Barrow, where Mr. Morfee holds the lease. To show how hard it can be to make a go of it, Mr. Morfee took the rare step of opening his books on "Bug"; the figures at right are averages taken from several different weeks during the run. They include some one-time costs -- like the opening-night cast party -- amortized over the show's 11-month run. And while this is an average week, "Bug" broke even with the help of some sell-out weeks, when the profits were greater than those shown here. In the end, "Bug" sold about $2 million worth of tickets and cost about $2 million to run. All of which leaves Mr. Morfee a little bemused. "If we pop the Champagne every time we break even," he said, "I don't know what kind of business we're in."

title: Guilin

The limestone cliffs that surround the city and line the Li River have provided backdrops for countless Chinese paintings. Long a favorite destination for domestic tourists, the city has more recently become a stop on the global backpacker circuit. And now some first-class Western-style hotels are attracting a higher-paying clientele from beyond China.

title: That's My Baby
description: It is the maternal paradox: why does the smallest member of a family always require the most paraphernalia? To accessorize all the accessories, enter the diaper clutch, a diaper bag that has been micromanaged into a hand-held case, which can then be slipped into a regular handbag or tote. Don't be fooled by the diminutive size: Skip Hop's Pronto, ($30, 212-868-9850 to order) opens to a changing pad, complete with a tiny pillow and has compartments for wipes, ointments and diapers, and a zippered pocket for keys, wallet and cellphone. The pad zips off, and the clutch can be used separately. E. Berger Baby's version, left, is less elaborate but more chic; the quilted cotton case is lined with flannel in hip, graphic patterns ($45 at www.ebergerbaby.com or 203-341-9140). title: Up Front
description: Second terms are often unkind to American presidents. After winning re-election in a landslide in 1936, the seemingly invincible Franklin Roosevelt stumbled badly with his plan to pack the Supreme Court. Richard Nixon had Watergate, Ronald Reagan Iran-contra. Bill Clinton coasted to victory in 1996, then saw the name Monica enter the history books. Is George W. Bush, not yet halfway through his second term, heading down the same road? Two reviews in this issue suggest that the president is facing problems not only with Democrats but with members of his own camp. In his review of "My Year in Iraq," the memoir by L. Paul Bremer III (Page 8), Dexter Filkins recounts "a jaw-dropping scene" in which Bremer, who ran Iraq for 14 months, indicates that he knew what reporters like Filkins were seeing around them -- the White House had failed to provide sufficient troops to do the job they were sent to Iraq to do. On the domestic front, meanwhile, deep divisions have emerged among Republicans whom the administration had successfully kept united until now. Discussing Jeffrey Hart's "Making of the Conservative Mind" and Bruce Bartlett's "Impostor" (Page 9), George Will describes "conservatives at daggers drawn with one another," as tensions rise between religious populists and Goldwater libertarians. Indeed, as Will suggests, with Republicans of every stripe criticizing the president for one thing or another, the very meaning of the word "conservative" may now be up for grabs.

It included Corrado Antonini, chairman of Fincantieri, the Italian company that built the Noordam; the actress Marlee Matlin, godmother of the ship; and Pat Riley, president and head coach of the Miami Heat basketball team. Besides being the major shareholder in Carnival, Mr. Arison is the managing general partner of the Heat, which, coincidentally, was also in New York, playing the Knicks.

I wondered if I could find out too much, if Grandpa could become someone I wouldn't love. After all, this information suggested that I'd never really known him.

title: Beyond the Pale
description: What makes a dress innocent? Is it the color, the cut, the little bunches of lace that embroider the yoke and suggest a small girl's birthday attire? Or perhaps it is the absence of flesh, as the artist Adam Fuss posits in these melancholy photographs reminiscent of his series "My Ghost." Taken without a camera, using light and light-sensitive paper, these photograms, as they are known, merely suggest the aura of sweetness. It is the wearer who provides the rest.

title: An Inspired Riff on a Mediterranean Theme
description: HARTSDALE - ALTHOUGH it is right on Central Avenue, Cafe Mez is not easy to get into: the restaurant is popular, even on weekday nights, and finding a parking spot can be difficult. But stay the course. It's worth it.

title: The Greening of the Gold Coast
description: JERSEY CITY - IF you are rich enough, or connected enough, or even just good enough to eventually tee off on the second hole at Liberty National Golf Club, you will have the exquisite experience of being able to aim your shot right at the Statue of Liberty. And from the green of the 170-yard par-3 hole, with Lady Liberty standing in a semiprofile, her right arm extended south toward the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, it will look as if America's symbol of freedom is actually tending the pin.

title: Lamoriello Behind the Bench, But He Won't Take a Seat

The man in question is Victor Niederhoffer, son of a Coney Island cop, who in the mid-1990's was recognized as one of the most successful (and most idiosyncratic) money managers in the nation.

title: Whimsy Elevates the Ordinary
description: AMONG the modest post-Civil War brownstones and rather ordinary tenements of the South Bronx, the frantically diverse row at 407-427 East 140th Street presents a dizzy celebration of varying roof lines, materials, styles and decoration.

title: Sometimes a Bag Is Not Just a Bag
description: It is the Thursday evening before New Year's Eve, a time when most equable-minded people are busy laying in the Champagne and taking stock of their lives. Or reading on a chaise somewhere pretty and tropical, nibbling on papaya, or perhaps skiing down a white slope in Aspen, Colo., with the wind behind them. On this day you would have found me scurrying along Madison Avenue on my way to Barneys New York, that metropolitan mecca of all that is fabulously new and covetable, to return two bags. The items in question were a characteristically whimsical Marni evening pouch that had cost this side of $800 -- and that I had originally planned to wear to a nephew's bar mitzvah to offset a stark, synagogue-appropriate St. John Knits ensemble but in the end decided against in favor of a borrowed and less contrapuntal Lambertson Truex lizard clutch -- and an uncharacteristically unconstructed Jil Sander bag ($670) that had briefly spoken to me in my continuing search for an Edenic black bag. It goes without saying that neither one was a strictly necessary purchase (what bag after the first one is?) and that they were about far, far more than themselves.

title: DATEBOOK
description: NATCHEZ, MISS. Twice a year, in spring and in fall, the Natchez Pilgrimage (www.natchezpilgrimage.com) draws lovers of the Old South for special tours of local homes and other events celebrating the area's rich culture and history. The spring home tours -- offered between March 10 and April 14 -- feature 27 antebellum mansions. A pass for four houses costs $28, for three houses, $21.

Rediscovering a Relic of a Past Long Obscured
description: FOR the longest time, no one disturbed the two boxlike enclosures at the rear of the balcony in St. Augustine's Episcopal Church.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: THE FUGITIVE WIFE. By Peter C. Brown. (Norton, $24.95.) When you consider the inherent romance and adventure of hunting for buried treasure, it seems odd that America's gold rushes haven't yielded a more enduring literature: people left everything behind and suffered grueling hardship for the chance to find a fortune, and all we got out of it were Jack London's anthropomorphic dogs and "Oh My Darling Clementine"? Into the void steps "The Fugitive Wife," an enormously satisfying first novel about the dreamers and schemers who flocked to Alaska at the turn of the 20th century. The heroine, Essie Crummey, is a spunky Minnesota farm girl who has finally given up on her alcoholic husband after the death of their child. Fleeing home, Essie encounters a crew of Nome-bound prospectors, and when their foreman offers her a job tending the stables, she impulsively accepts.

title: Finding the Winning Mix of Jumps
description: Shizuka Arakawa won the women's figure skating gold medal without performing the full complement of triple jumps as the previous three winners had. She had planned two tripletriple combinations, which would have matched Sarah Hughes's feat. But Arakawa and her coaches may have made a strategic decision to play it safe after watching Sasha Cohen's less-than-perfect performance. Here is a look at the long program jumps of previous winners and this year's medalists. One caveat when comparing skaters from different eras: the maximum number of jumping passes has changed over the years. Baiul and Yamaguchi had eight jumping passes, while Lipinski and Hughes had six. Current rules allow seven jumping passes. ARCHIE TSE

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Feb. 26-March 4; TELEVISION
description: The Oscar edition of "THE BARBARA WALTERS SPECIAL" seems to be growing less Oscar-related. This year's (Wednesday at 10 p.m. on ABC) is four days before the Academy Awards. And three of its four interview subjects have never even been nominated for an Oscar. MATTHEW McCONAUGHEY won a People's Choice Award this year as favorite male action star. PATRICK DEMPSEY, basking in his surprise stardom on ABC's "GREY'S ANATOMY," was once nominated for an Emmy. MARIAH CAREY won the uncoveted Razzie as worst actress in her 2001 film "GLITTER." So the theory must be that GEORGE CLOONEY, with three nominations (one for "SYRIANA" and two for "GOOD NIGHT, AND GOOD LUCK"), makes up for that.

title: Preaching the Word and Quoting the Voice
description: In the twilight of the biggest snowstorm in New York City's history, the pews of a rented Baptist church on the Upper West Side of Manhattan were packed for the Rev. Timothy J. Keller's fourth sermon of the day.

title: Hanoi: Hilton Hanoi Opera
description: THE BASICS -- The infamous "Hanoi Hilton," where Senator John McCain spent five and a half years during the Vietnam War, has been largely demolished. Only a small museum remains of the Hoa Lo prison, involuntary housing for 300 American pilots captured in the conflict. The Hilton Hanoi Opera, open since 1999, takes pains to not celebrate a connection to Hoa Lo, even if the hotel's Web site is www.hanoi.hilton.com. Tourists still drop in to ask if the prison was located there, or at least nearby -- but none of the guests, the concierge assured during a recent stay, confuse the hotel with a prison.

title: Other Views: South China Morning Post, The Economist, Arab News
'Made in U.S.A.' Isn't a Hot Label on Goods in China
description: It has become an automatic reflex: mention the trade deficit, and the word "China" pops to mind. It is awfully easy to conjure images of wave upon wave of "made in China" stuff inundating our shores, dwarfing the influx from elsewhere.

title: Outlet: Florence Marni
description: If you thought the Prada outlet outside Florence was the Uffizi Gallery of off-price shopping, call Alitalia: it's time to go to the Mall. The newcomer to Leccio Reggello (a few Autostrada exits closer to Florence than Prada's Montevarchi outlet), the Mall offers a cross section of the best brands produced in the country. Sleek boutiques from Pucci, Gucci, Giorgio Armani, Valentino and others mix with Yohji Yamamoto, Yves Saint Laurent and a triple-whammy shop featuring Alexander McQueen, Stella McCartney and Balenciaga. Best of all is the museum-quality Marni shop, stocking styles all the way back to the turn of the century -- in all sizes. Replenish lost fluids at the slickly designed Dot.Com Caf, where a Campari-soda, a pizza bianca with speck and a bowl of tiramisu are just what the shopper ordered. Bag parking available. For more information, go to www.outlet-firenze.com. CHRISTINE MUHLKE The Remix

title: Israeli Minister Says Palestinian Leader Is Irrelevant
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 26 A Israel's foreign minister said today that Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, was "no longer relevant" in a Palestinian government that will soon be led by the militant Islamic group Hamas.

title: A Stiff Proposal For Cold Medicines

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CURTIS, FREDERICK S., FORMERLY FRITZ IDSTEIN
description: CURTIS--Frederick S., formerly Fritz Idstein, of Mannheim and Krefeld, Germany, passed away peacefully on February 21, 2006, at Mary Manning Walsh Home in New York shortly before his 96th birthday. He was the dearly beloved and loving husband of Ursel (nee Blumenheim) for 45 years. Cherished father of Vera Ginsberg and her companion Marsha Genard; adoring Opa of Jason and Stephanie; devoted brother of Kurt (Lisa); dear uncle of Linda (Robert) Sonderman; loving cousin of Evelyn (Joel) Ullman and their children Steven, Caren (Robert) Reich and Randie (Tony) Paterno. His humor was irrepressible to the end. Private graveside service was held at Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: The Shame of the United Nations
description: When it comes to reforming the disgraceful United Nations Human Rights Commission, America's ambassador, John Bolton, is right; Secretary General Kofi Annan is wrong; and leading international human rights groups have unwisely put their preference for multilateral consensus ahead of their duty to fight for the strongest possible human rights protection. A once-promising reform proposal has been so watered down that it has become an ugly sham, offering cover to an unacceptable status quo. It should be renegotiated or rejected.

The midway has become an outdoor park and shopping center, and a restaurant has been added, with the chef Wolfgang Puck choosing and preparing the menu.

title: The Way We Eat: Skin Deep

But before you dismissively turn the page, consider this: If it weren't for stories about once-hard-to-find ingredients like extra-virgin olive oil, prosciutto and fresh thyme, we would still be trying to make something edible out of canned peas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LICHTENSTEIN, IRA
description: LICHTENSTEIN--Ira. Former President of Eric Marder Associates, the market research company in New York City, and formerly a chemical engineer, died February 6, 2006 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering. He was 68 years old, born in Brooklyn, New York. He was the son of Irene Polansky Lichtenstein and A. Albert Lichtenstein. He began working at EMA in June, 1972. Lichtenstein became President of EMA in December, 1995 and retired as a Senior Associate in December, 2001. In 1958, upon graduation from City College of New York School of Engineering, he became a petrochemical engineer for Standard Oil of New Jersy. He earned a Master's Degree from New Jersey College of Engineering. He later worked for Lummus Corporation and Computer Associates. Ira Lichtenstein is survived by Judith Phillips, his loving wife of 28 years, and his three children: Scott Lichtenstein; Andrea Lichtenstein Bazer; Joshua Seth Lichtenstein; son-in-law, Ronald Bazer; daughter-inlaw, Nancy Lichtenstein; and former wife Francine Turner Lowenstein. He was very proud of his seven grandchildren, was a supporter of the arts. He was an avid swimmer until the end. His body was donated to NYU Medical School for research.

title: The Remix: Q.& A.; Zandra With a Z
description: The buzz at the collections was "very Zandra Rhodes." If you had to define your style, what would you say? My garments are totally based around what the print can do -- the print creating all the shape. I think of myself as a print designer who became a fashion designer. Do you take the view, like Chanel and Lagerfeld, that it is a compliment to be copied? Copying is always going to happen, so it is better to be copied and noted as mine. Are the patterns drawn from life or the imagination? The pattern is drawn from whatever I am inspired by, be it travel to China or knitting stitches on a sweater in Wales. The source of all my inspiration is my sketchbook. I travel everywhere with it. The Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is doing a show about British style in May. Do you feel you were part of a movement in the 60's? My 60's contribution comes from my English roots, but reinterpreting Warhol and Lichtenstein: light bulbs, comics, lipstick advertisements by Guy Bourdin in Vogue. I think most remarkable are the chic hippie looks of the late 60's and early 70's and the flowing caftans. Tell me about your museum in London. I founded the Fashion and Textile Museum because I believe British fashion and the U.K. art-school system have had a groundbreaking effect on world fashion. I felt people like Ossie Clark, Jean Muir and Bill Gibb have never had the recognition they deserve. I have found the museum an uphill task. Most of the money I have managed to raise has come from the American Friends of the Zandra Rhodes Museum. Do you feel helped by the Pucci revival and the change of mood or, for you, is it prints now and forever? I feel very positive by the way fashion has chosen to revamp old brands. Nothing succeeds if it does not change. SUZY MENKES

But recently I heard that the management was rejiggering its menu and had enlisted the help of Bill Taibe, the chef and an owner at Relish several blocks away. As an admirer of Mr. Taibe's cooking style, I felt this was worth checking into.

title: The Remix; Pop Quiz

Wide-legged slacks are traditionally punctuated with flats, while capris are best balanced with a stack-heeled sandal. But what do you pair with flared Bermudas? If you can match the correct shoe to the pants below, spring will be a breeze. CHRISTINE MUHLKE

title: Midnight Snacks, Outsized

Come 2 a.m. the licorice-thin ladies teeter out of clubs like newborn foals and head straight for the drive-through lane at Carl's Jr. or Jack in the Box. Who else could satisfy the nocturnal cravings of a starving starlet?

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Feb. 26-March 4; POP/JAZZ
description: Having discovered the mambo, the bassist ISRAEL LOPEZ, known as Cachao, is one of the most important musicians of the century. At 87, in his infrequent live appearances, he can still play a great tumbao with a rhythm section -- the airy, interlocking grooves that make Cuban music swing -- but he also likes to knock the bass around, play pizzicato, and otherwise not be weighed down by his own heavy legacy. This week he plays with a 10-piece band including some of the great Latin jazz players around today, among them the trombonist JIMMY BOSCH, the violinist FEDERICO BRITOS, and the percussionists RICHIE FLORES and JIMMY DELGADO. Tuesday and Wednesday, Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 475-8592; cover $45.

title: Dr. Gervais's Frankenstein
description: Karl Pilkington has debated the merits of eating a kangaroo's penis for breakfast, envisioned a wristwatch that counts down the time left in a person's life and proposed a new population control system in which elderly women give birth at the moment of their deaths. He has mused on topics ranging from caveman "bear pants" to dishwashers on Mars, and reported "news stories" about the triumphs of chimpanzees as bricklayers and television talk show hosts. In so doing, Mr. Pilkington, a 33-year-old unemployed radio producer from Manchester, England, has become the object of a global Internet cult, a Guinness world record-holder and the unlikely harbinger of a technological revolution.

title: Muslims in Southeast Asia
David Lynch, Still Disturbing After 20 Years
description: ONE of the very, very few rules about art you can take to the bank is that shock ages badly. But David Lynch's "Blue Velvet," unleashed on a largely unsuspecting public 20 years ago, is, I'm happy to say, breaking that rule as blithely and as decisively as, once upon a time, it broke most of the others. Even after two more decades of Lynchian eccentricity and sensual derangement -- years, besides, in which the bar for serious outrage in popular culture has risen to a nearly unreachable height -- "Blue Velvet" looks as odd and as beautiful as ever, and it's still a shock.

title: Just Be Patient, Pat Riley Says, Cruising By
description: Holland America Line, one of seven major cruise lines owned by the Carnival Corporation, dedicated its newest ship, the Noordam, in New York last week, and Carnival's chairman and chief executive, Micky Arison, brought an entourage to celebrate with him. It included Corrado Antonini, chairman of Fincantieri, the Italian company that built the Noordam; the actress Marlee Matlin, godmother of the ship; and Pat Riley, president and head coach of the Miami Heat basketball team. Besides being the major shareholder in Carnival, Mr. Arison is the managing general partner of the Heat, which, coincidentally, was also in New York, playing the Knicks.

Which explains why her beautifully made dresses, caftans, blouses and bathing suits are eminently packable. This string bikini certainly won't take up much space in your carry-on. About $460. The Heartland Dissident
description: Senator Chuck Hagel may be a loner, but he is not alone in feeling that the Republican Party has gotten off track (Joseph Lelyveld, Feb. 12). I know many people who, like myself,have beenlifelong Republicans but scarcely recognize our party today. Nevertheless, the odds against Hagel becoming president are no doubt long. If the Iraq war should turn out to be a success by 2008 -- even a qualified one -- skepticsmay well be swept aside. And if it is not, the Republican nomination may not be worth having.

title: A Cafeteria Food Fight Over Health

title: Movies on TV
description: SKY CAPTAIN AND THE WORLD OF TOMORROW (2004) Saturday at 7 p.m. on Showtime Truly gigantic robots (standing humans come up to their ankles) are clomping through the streets of Manhattan. Robot airplanes that flap their wings like birds are attacking. Important scientists are disappearing. Clearly, the world needs saving. The job falls to an aviator, Sky Captain, a k a Joe (Jude Law), and a metro-desk newspaper reporter named Polly Perkins (Gwyneth Paltrow, above, with Mr. Law). This entertaining comic-book-noir fantasy, made up mostly of computer-generated images, also offers swell, smart-alecky 1940's dialogue ("Can we, just for once, die without all this bickering?"); Angelina Jolie with an eyepatch and a British accent; and a cameo by Laurence Olivier, who has been dead for almost 17 years. Kerry Conran, a first-time filmmaker, wrote and directed.

title: A Special Election for Rediscovered Players

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 26, 2006
Beauty Bullies
description: 'Honey, can I tell you something, and you won't get mad?" I was 21 and excited to be out for a private dinner with my new boss -- my first boss -- a snobby gay publicist who confused his underlings with his paternalistic charm. Before I could answer, he leaned over my onion tart and declared, "Your hair is fried." My hair, I had thought, was quite cute. Sure, it was more just-out-of-college bottle blond than Bergdorf blond, but wasn't the point of working in the style industry that you got to express your, you know, personal style?
