title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAYLOR, THOMAS M.
description: TAYLOR--Thomas M. 63, "Big T", of Fort Worth, Texas, Greenwich, Connecticut and Nantucket, Massachusetts, died tragically on Sunday, February 19. Founder and Senior Partner of The Taylor Companies, an alternate investment and insurance advisory company. Beloved husband of Linda; loving father of Jason and his wife, Leigh, and Rhonda and her husband, Kevin McDonald; cherished grandfather of Taylor, "Little T," and Riley; and master of devoted pets, Moose and Tipsy. Also survived by his parents Sol and Annette Taylor of Fort Worth and his brother Bob Benjamin Taylor of New York City. Tommy was a native Texan--a graduate of TCU and a generous supporter of Beth-El Congregation of Fort Worth, Cook Children's Medical Center in Fort Worth, the Fort Worth Symphony as well as the Robin Hood Foundation, the MSPCA of Nantucket, the American Red Cross, Nantucket Children's Charities and the Nantucket Cottage Hospital. A beautiful, loving, caring and loyal friend, he will always be remembered for his brilliant mind, his extraordinary passion for living, his fascination with photography and love of sailing the world with family and friends on his beautiful "Avalon" (Gleam). He will be greatly missed. The family requests that donations in lieu of flowers be made to the Thomas M. Taylor Memorial Fund for Excellence in Education, in care of Greenwich Academy, 200 N. Maple Avenue, Greenwich, Connecticut 06830. Arrangements for a memorial service for Tommy will be delayed pending the recovery of his wife, Linda, who remains hospitalized.

title: Bird Flu Raises Concerns in France and Nigeria
description: PARIS, Feb. 25 - The announcement on Saturday that the deadly strain of bird flu was discovered in domesticated turkeys in France has disrupted the country's $7 billion poultry market and raised fears among the French that they could be vulnerable to the disease.

title: Dangerous Beauty
description: That Sarah Bernhardt, the most fashionable global celebrity of the 19th century, was born Jewish, gave rise, in fin-de-sicle France, to much hand-wringing and soul-searching and deep ambivalence. Splendid relics from the great tragedienne's career, alongside evidence of the public fascination with -- and hostility toward -- her larger-than-life persona, are on view in "Sarah Bernhardt: The Art of High Drama," at the Jewish Museum in New York through April 2. The daughter and niece of Jewish courtesans with connections to French nobility, Bernhardt was baptized a Catholic at age 12 and packed off (presumably at her shadowy father's insistence) for a proper convent education. But Jewishness clung to the general air of scandal surrounding her.

title: Adventures in Paradise
description: As shoppers blithely disregard seasonally appropriate dressing, all-weather clothes have taken the retail lead. Dresses by Fighting Eel are the new catch of the day: perfect paired with a blazer and boots but chic enough to stand alone in warmer weather.

description: THEORETICALLY, Madeleine Kunin said, she was never going to marry again. When her 34-year marriage ended in divorce in 1995, so, too, she thought, had the marriage chapter of her life. It's a life that has included chapters like governor of Vermont, three terms, 1985 to 1991; federal deputy secretary of education, 1993 to 1996; and ambassador to Switzerland, 1996 to 1999.

title: Bleeps and Blips as Far From Broadway as Possible
description: Michael Cerveris plays the throat-slicing, guitar-picking Sweeney in the pared-down revival of "Sweeney Todd." Though it's his fourth leading role in a Broadway musical (there were turns in "Assassins," "The Who's Tommy" and "Titanic"), Mr. Cerveris would rather be a rock star. In 2004, he released "Dog Eared" (Low Heat), with cameos by members of Sonic Youth and Sleater-Kinney. His vocals and guitar can also be heard on the "Sweeney Todd" cast album, released on Nonesuch in January, and he has plans for an early summer release of an EP, "hinterlands (the history of tears)" (Low Heat). Mr. Cerveris spoke with Winter Miller about what he has been listening to.

I'm old enough to recall a machine with a band that you'd put around your hips to jiggle away fat. I saw these machines mostly in garages and at yard sales, where they exhaled dashed hopes and broken resolutions.

title: COMINGS & GOINGS
description: Outer space may soon be in reach as a vacation destination. Earlier this month, Secretary of Transportation Norman Y. Mineta announced that commercial spacecraft could be cleared to carry passengers by 2008. Speaking to a group of space entrepreneurs, Mr. Mineta said that a number of companies should be set to take passengers into space and that the U.S. Department of Transportation would be ready to clear the flights within two years. Cathay Pacific (www.cathay-usa.com, 800-233-2742) introduced a new All Asia Pass this month that allows travelers to visit up to 18 Asian cities for $1,499. That's a price increase of $200 from last year, and now includes Colombo, Sri Lanka, and Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. Bookings must be made 30 days in advance. For a $200 discount, travelers must register online as a Cathay Pacific CyberTraveler before booking. British Airways (www.britishairways.com, 877-428-2228) is offering a London package deal for $398 that includes round-trip air fare from Kennedy Airport and three nights and daily Continental breakfast at either the Thistle Lancaster Gate Hotel or Thistle Kensington Gardens -- both four-star hotels. The package, which is available for travel through April 15, must be booked by March 24. Government fees and taxes are not included and can add about $150 to the price. IN TRANSIT

title: Why Old FJ's Never Die
description: LOS ANGELES - JONATHAN WARD and his wife, Jamie, run a time machine. Their shop, TLC, is where fanatically loyal Toyota FJ owners bring their tired, rusted-out, crunched-up Land Cruisers. The Wards turn back the clock and make the FJ's new again.

title: The Remix; Now Showing | Grey Ladies
description: If Jackie O. was the Snow White of American fashion, her wayward cousin Edith Bouvier Beale was the Cinderella who never made it to the ball. Little Edie, as she was known, has been a fashion antiheroine since she wrapped a skirt upside-down around her hips and called it "the best costume for the day" in Albert and David Maysles's 1975 cult documentary, "Grey Gardens." "I can't count the number of times I've been at a fashion shoot where someone says, 'Let's tie a sweater on her head and do an Edie Beale,"' says Simon Doonan, the creative director of Barneys New York. This spring, Beale, who died at age 84 in 2002, inspires a new generation through three projects: an off-Broadway musical based on Edie, her mother and their condemned mansion in East Hampton, N.Y.; a DVD with unseen "Grey Gardens" footage; and a scrapbook of Little Edie's photos and letters compiled by the New Yorker writer Hilton Als. Already there is buzz. "What is so intriguing about Little Edie is her belief in her own beauty," says John Bartlett, whose fall 2000 collection used "Grey Gardens" as a leitmotif. "To the outside world she must have seemed a freak, but to fashionistas she's an idol of self-expression." JOHANnA LENANDER

title: Trailblazer or Stereotype?
description: MONTCLAIR - IF the name Lincoln Theodore Monroe Andrew Perry doesn't quite ring a bell, his show-biz name, Stepin Fetchit, should suggest a film footnote of some consequence. Here at Luna Stage, the talented veteran actor Roscoe Orman is starring in "The Confessions of Stepin Fetchit," a labored solo exploration by Matt Robinson of the life and times of this Hollywood phenomenon.

title: London, in Wispy Images
description: IT is always heartening to see a contemporary painting exhibition at the Yale Center for British Art, especially one as visually sumptuous and straight-up intoxicating as John Virtue's "London" paintings.

title: Corrections
description: A picture last Sunday with an article about a pedestrian tunnel in Washington Heights was published in error. It showed a tunnel that connects the A train line at 190th Street and Fort Washington Avenue to Bennett Avenue, not the one to Broadway from the No. 1 line at 191st Street.

title: Lazy Days at the Lost and Found
description: IT'S nearly impossible to live long in New York without becoming a loser. When people think so many thoughts while running so many errands and dashing to so many places, the occasional lost item is par for the course. At times, it can seem as though the lost-and-found ecosystem comprises the entire population of New York's gloves, scarves, umbrellas and pens.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Feb. 26-March 4; DANCE
description: Dancegoers venturing into theaters this week may find themselves exploring strange artistic terrains. An empty and silent stage becomes a blank where three men have playful adventures, romping, skipping and stumbling in MARTINE PISANI's "sans." The Parisian choreographer's group, CIE. MARTINE PISANI, offers an event jointly presented by the Danspace Project and the Joyce Theater. Thursday, Friday and next Sunday at 8 p.m., Saturday at 7 and 10 p.m., Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street, (212) 242-0800 or www.joyce.org; $20.

title: Google Gotcha
description: After I was scheduled for a job interview at a university, a member of the search committee Googled me and found my blog, where I refer to him (but not by name) as a belligerent jerk. He canceled the interview. It was impolitic to write what I did, but my believing him to be a jerk does not mean I would not be great at that job, and the rest of the committee might agree. Was it ethical of him to cancel the interview?

title: Trinity Extends Its Reign as Squash Champion
description: WHILE Connecticut's college sports fans continue to focus on UConn's basketball teams and their annual campaigns for national championships, the men's squash team at Trinity College in Hartford quietly won its eighth consecutive national championship last Sunday.

title: The Rachel Papers
description: Rachel Weisz has a tattoo of a ladder on her hip. It's a symbol of her Cambridge days as a co-founder of Talking Tongues, an ambitious theater troupe that incorporated a ladder into one of its productions, and also of the spirit behind that endeavor. The tattoo is a reminder to have guts, take chances and throw yourself into what's scary and hard. "It's very difficult to get great roles," Weisz said in early January, over a late-afternoon tea of yogurt and orange juice (she was five months pregnant) at a coffee shop near her Manhattan home in SoHo. Weisz can look smoky and irresistibly alluring on film, which seems to bring out the dark lushness of her hair and eyes, but in person she has a lovely, fresh-scrubbed quality. On the day we met, this was accentuated by a white wool sailor cap and an oversize blue-and-white-striped nautical sweater. Although she had just returned from a Christmas holiday in sunny Jamaica with her fianc, the director Darren Aronofsky ("I'm in charge of the wedding," she explained about the reverse order of baby first and ceremony later, "and I haven't figured all that out yet"), Weisz was alabaster pale and looked less like a siren and more like a radiant English schoolgirl, home from university.

title: White Star
description: Coco Chanel's jeweled cuffs, Diana Vreeland's red lips, Katharine Hepburn's mannish trousers: chic women always have a signature. For the designer Carolina Herrera, it's a white shirt. Make that dozens of white shirts. "I think I was born in a white shirt," she says, laughing. "And I'm constantly finding new ones, because you know, you can't keep them for very long. Once they lose their crispness, they must be retired." Herrera has a couple other rules when it comes to button-downs, whether they hail from Banana Republic or her own design studio (like the one above): "Collar height is crucial. I like it a little bit higher, so you don't have to turn it up. And the shirt must be cotton, so it stays crisp. Silk doesn't work." Herrera's look travels well, too. "Whether I'm going to South America in the summer or Europe in the winter, I always pack at least six white shirts," she says. "I'll take different cuts, some with French cuffs, some with regular cuffs." Much of the white shirt's appeal lies in its blank-slate versatility. Herrera is as likely to wear one to a formal occasion as she is to the beach. "White shirts can be demure, elegant, mysterious or romantic," she says. "I love the idea of wearing one with a ball gown. Or over a bustier with the buttons open -- very 18th century." Or, better yet, by itself. "After all, there's nothing sexier than a woman in her husband's white pajama top." Sandra Ballentine TIMELESS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AIBEL, KATHERINE WEBSTER
description: AIBEL--Katherine Webster, AB Wells College MSW NYU School of Social Work, beloved wife of Howard, mother of David, Daniel and Jonathan, and grandmother of Lucien. She served in Stamford, CT schools, Person to Person, and Children in Placement as a guardian ad litem for children in the Connecticut Juvenile Courts. A passionate advocate for children and families, she touched many lives. She passed away peacefully in Weston, CT, on February 22, after a long illness. Burial was on February 23; a memorial service will be held at a future date. Donations can be made to Person to Person, St Luke's Parish, 1864 Post Road, Darien, CT 06820.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MULRANE, MARY ANN
description: MULRANE--Mary Ann. Of Manhattan passed away January 25, 2006 after a brief illness. Born in New York City on May 5, 1947, Mary Ann was a lifelong resident who embraced all the pursuits this city has to offer. Ms. Mulrane was a passionate supporter of the arts, particularly of cinema, theater and opera. She was also enthusiastic about current affairs; her knowledge on some subjects bordered encyclopedic. A spirited, intelligent and strong soul, Mary Ann left an indelible impression on friends, neighbors, and colleagues, all of who will no doubt miss her quick wit and compassion. Mary Ann was predeceased by her parents, Thomas Mulrane and Agnes (Herceg) Mulrane, and is survived by her sister Kathleen Parsell and her husband Harold of Monroe, Connecticut; her nephews Thomas Parsell of Manhattan and Michael Parsell and his wife Jennifer of Monroe, Connecticut; grandnephews Troy and Briggs; and grand-niece Augusta. For information Spadaccino Community Funeral Home.

At first glance, then, this sprawling group portrait of the movement that defined 19th-century American landscape art seems entirely beside the point. It is a collection of minor works.

Mr. Shim saw six quarters, but the boy, a native Hawaiian from a poor neighborhood, was unable to add them up and could not tell if he had enough to play video games.

title: An Academic Retreat
description: Thank you for your interesting and amusing interview with Donna Shalala. It reminded me of a personal anecdote. At our 1991 graduation ceremony at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, Shalala, then the chancellor of the university, personally handed out diplomas, one by one. I'll never forget the succinct words of wisdom she offered me as I approached her on the stage, words that continue to help me weather tough times today. Urging me along, she glanced up and said: "Keep moving, keep moving."

Guilin
description: WHY GO NOW -- The name Guilin may not have a familiar ring to many Westerners, but among Chinese this city in the southern China province of Guangxi is legendary for its beauty. The limestone cliffs that surround the city and line the Li River have provided backdrops for countless Chinese paintings. Long a favorite destination for domestic tourists, the city has more recently become a stop on the global backpacker circuit. And now some first-class Western-style hotels are attracting a higher-paying clientele from beyond China.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE GLASS CASTLE: A Memoir, by Jeannette Walls. (Scribner, $14.) Walls doesn't pull punches in this account of her hardscrabble upbringing. Dragged from one Southwestern mining town to another by their irresponsible parents -- free spirits who ended up as squatters on New York's Lower East Side -- Walls and her three siblings endured a catalog of nightmares. The stories are chilling: Walls says that when was 13, her father used her as sexual bait to distract a man he was hustling at pool. As the family's circumstances degenerate, Walls's narrative remains evenhanded and unjudging.

title: Ohno Captures Gold and Helps Brighten Games for the U.S.
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 25 - The United States' hope for one last individual medal at these Olympics looked to be its latest failure when Apolo Anton Ohno finished third in his semifinal heat of the 500-meter short-track speedskating Saturday night.

title: Critics may spurn his art, but public clamors to buy it
The Face; My Life in Pictures
description: Evelyn Lauder, beauty queen, colors her world with deep, dark hair, smart tailoring and just the right amount of bronze blush.

title: Yet Another Lap for a Stock-Car Hero
description: AS the team behind "Cinderella Man" is aware, when films don't find their audience the first time around studios have been known, on occasion, to give them a second chance. But it's the rare film that gets four chances.

title: These Walls Do Talk, for Now
description: DECLINING state aid and rising school budgets have already troubled the Three Village Central School District. Now the district and residents of Setauket are trying to come to terms with a different costly challenge: What to do about the suddenly sagging historic murals in Setauket Elementary School.

title: Man, 19, Is Fatally Stabbed in Street Fight in Brooklyn
description: A 19-year-old man was stabbed to death early yesterday and his brother-in-law was critically injured during a frenzied street fight outside a Brooklyn apartment building, the authorities said.

title: The Play's the Same Old Thing
description: Heard the one about Broadway no longer being interested in new ideas? Of course you have; it's become a clich by now that the city's leading stages prefer to reprocess old concepts, whether through revivals, quick adaptations of films or medleys of pop jingles.

title: Ghost Busting in Albany
description: A person attuned to science fiction might think of New York State government as a confluence of the real world and the otherworldly. There is the obvious side of government -- with the Legislature debating more in the open these days and Gov. George Pataki dragging legislative leaders into public discussions of the budget. But there is also a phantom government -- a universe where public-private authorities do a lot of public business in private.

title: Cox Draws Comparisons (Don't Mention Rivera)
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 23 - On one side of the Yankees' clubhouse at Legends Field is a locker for the greatest closer in World Series history. Mariano Rivera sits there.

description: NEW York politics has a way of veering toward the unpredictable, to the dismay of many a politician. Just when he thought he'd sail into office as the state's next governor, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer finds himself beating back a fellow Democrat who is way behind him in money and recognition -- but who can make Mr. Spitzer's life uncomfortable anyway.

title: For Fire Victim, a Clergyman Is Chosen to Bring Tragic News

description: STORRS, Conn., Feb. 26 - The question of Big East superiority may not be something that can be answered in February, but third-ranked Connecticut seemed intent on settling the debate anyway Sunday.

title: Having Cut Their Teeth on Bartok, They Hold On
description: The Takacs Quartet has received much attention of late for its excellent Beethoven recordings, but it cut its teeth much earlier on the Bartok quartets, and its credentials in that repertory remain impeccable. Founded in Budapest in 1975, the group studied Bartok's music with Zoltan Szekely, the Hungarian violinist for whom the composer wrote his Second Violin Concerto. It has made two superb recordings of the six Bartok quartets. And it has performed Bartok alongside the ensemble Muzsikas playing Hungarian folk music, with Bartok's own warbly field recordings piped in between tunes.

Correction
description: An Op-Ed article last Monday, about Mary Todd Lincoln, misstated part of her family's history. Abraham Lincoln could not have shepherded "a quartet" of sons to his office; the second of the Lincolns' four sons, Eddie, died before the youngest two were born.

title: Coming in May: A Possible Balkan Divorce
description: BELGRADE, Serbia, Feb. 26 - The European Union's chief foreign policy envoy, Javier Solana, in a statement on Sunday, urged Montenegro's independence movement to accept proposals intended to shape a referendum on its future.

title: Did an Expos Help Sink Harvard's President?
description: Two years ago, when David McClintick, an author and investigative journalist, agreed to write an expos on Harvard University's effort on behalf of the United States government to help Russia privatize its economy in the 1990's, he had little inkling the article would play a part in forcing the ouster of Harvard's president, Lawrence H. Summers.

title: Dungeon Masters in Cyberspace
description: Gary Gygax, the original dungeon master, can see as well as anyone how computers have changed the face of gaming. All he has to do is look down the hall at his home in Lake Geneva, Wis.

title: Why She's the No. 1 Target in the Glamour Business
description: Milan - As a microcosm, fashion occasionally finds itself in step with the larger world, where terrorism seems to be the default strategy for conflict resolution. It may strike some as trivial or humorous when the Vogue editor in chief Anna Wintour -- so often caricatured as some kind of Mme. Satan in an astrakhan wrap -- gets a pie in the face from activists, who profess to be standing up for oppressed chinchillas. But does violence ever have subtle shadings?

title: Afghan Cabinet Members to Be Confirmed Individually
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 27 A The Afghan Parliament decided today to confirm cabinet ministers individually, rather than to vote on the president's cabinet as a whole, setting the stage for a long and tortuous confirmation process.

title: EU proposes an increase in duty-free allowance
Pakistan rally foiled, enraging radicals
Danger Signs in Nigeria
description: Mayhem in Nigeria, the fifth-largest oil supplier to the United States and Africa's most populous country, is escalating. Since mid-December, crime and violence have regularly shut down about 10 percent of the country's oil output. In the last week, production has been cut by nearly 20 percent -- a shortfall of 455,000 barrels daily -- amid kidnappings of foreign workers, arson against offshore oil installations, bombings of pipelines and lethal clashes between Muslims and Christians.

While Donald Trump's epistolary exchange with Martha Stewart (she blamed him for her "Apprentice" spinoff's failure; he said the show was dreadful) is in the news, Mr. Trump brings 18 shiny new job candidates together. Their 15-week competition begins with a marketing project for Sam's, the members-only warehouse business. This season Mr. Trump's children Donald Jr. and Ivanka (above, with their father, at an awards ceremony in October) get into the act.

description: Two years after the designs for a memorial at the World Trade Center were unveiled with great fanfare, the nonprofit group charged with raising $500 million to pay for it is far from its goal, and has announced no significant contributions for the last three months.

title: Debt and Taxes
description: There's nothing Congressional Republicans would like more than to escape the inescapable need to raise the nation's debt limit. The upcoming increase, from $8.18 trillion to nearly $9 trillion, will be the fourth major hike in the last five years.

title: Italians End Up Treating the Games Like Their Own
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 26 - In the end, the weather turned sparkling again -- just as it had been for the opening ceremony -- and Turin bade goodbye Sunday to an Olympics that finally seemed popular at home even as it got mixed reviews from its visitors from around the world.

title: Mets Hope To Build Attendance Muscle
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 26 - In 1988, when Sid Fernandez and Ron Darling were in the rotation and Howard Johnson anchored third base, more than three million fans went to Shea Stadium, setting a Mets single-season attendance record that still stands. That was also the last year the Mets won a division title.

title: Saudi Forces Kill 5 in Raids on Terror Suspects
description: Security forces in Saudi Arabia raided two locations in the Riyadh area today, killing five people and arresting a sixth suspected of being part of a group involved in an attempted suicide bombing last week at a Saudi oil and gas plant.

title: 'Concept' comes home to Paris, and adds a silver lining

LOOKING AHEAD
description: POSTAGE PROTEST -- Nonprofit groups, including some on either end of the political spectrum, and small businesses will hold a news conference tomorrow to talk about their opposition to a plan by America Online and Yahoo to charge fees to guarantee delivery of bulk e-mail. Critics say the plan could harm free speech if nonprofits find themselves unable to consistently reach mailboxes without paying. AOL and Yahoo say it will help them in their efforts to stop junk e-mail from reaching their customers.

title: A Haunted House, Clinging to Secrets
description: Every winter, when the trees drop their leaves, a certain house in Laurelton, Queens, comes into full view. It is a decrepit Victorian on a cul-de-sac at 141-36 222nd Street, a structure whose condition has made it known as "the haunted house."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Fatally Shot
description: A man who had just walked his fiance to work at a market was fatally shot on a Bedford-Stuyvesant street corner on Saturday afternoon, the police and family members said. The man, Willie Montes, 24, was shot about 2:30 at Lexington and Nostrand Avenues. His family said the police told them Mr. Montes had been shot once at close range with a large-caliber gun. He was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he died about six hours later. Family members said Mr. Montes had been wearing a large gold and diamond Jesus medallion, but they did not know whether it was taken. Mr. Montes, who was called Chilly for his calm personality, was planning to get married soon and join the Navy. "He did not have any enemies," said Kazaya Jackson, 20, his fiance. "He was the sweetest guy you could know."

title: Immigration reform
Militant Inmates Riot and Seize Control of Cellblock in Afghan Prison
description: PUL-I-CHARKHI, Afghanistan, Feb. 26 - Prisoners in Afghanistan's main high-security prison, among them people accused of being members of the Taliban and Al Qaeda, rioted and seized control of one cellblock on Saturday evening, battling with guards through the night, the Afghan authorities said Sunday.

description: Otis Chandler, the former publisher of The Los Angeles Times, which he inherited from his parents and transformed into one of the most respected, widely read and profitable newspapers in the United States, died early today. He was 78 years old.

title: Is Microsoft Dropping Cryptic Hints About a New Gadget?
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 - A cryptic Web site that was set up by Microsoft but does not bear its name appears to hint that the company will reveal information about a new consumer product on Thursday. The site caused a flurry of speculation on Internet gadget gossip sites over the weekend.

title: Baghdad Is Calm After Days of Sectarian Violence
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 27 A Iraqis returned cautiously to the streets and to their jobs today after three days of government-imposed curfew, in a capital still reeling from the worst outbreak of sectarian violence since the fall of Saddam Hussein.

title: Bush Policies Are Weakening National Guard, Governors Say
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 - Governors of both parties said Sunday that Bush administration policies were stripping the National Guard of equipment and personnel needed to respond to hurricanes, floods, tornadoes, forest fires and other emergencies.

title: Grappling in China With the Legal Sale of Music Online
description: Record labels have tended to see mainland China as a vast, lawless frontier, where more bootleg CD's than legitimate ones are sold. Recently, several companies there have begun to sell legitimate digital downloads, from online sites set up a bit like the iTunes store from Apple Computer. But even on these, there are problems.

title: Accounts
description: Macy's, New York, a division of Federated Department Stores, named Starcom USA, Chicago, as the first agency to handle its estimated $200 million national media planning and buying account. The assignment had previously been handled internally. Macy's spends an additional $300 million a year in local media. Starcom USA is part of the Starcom MediaVest Group unit of the Publicis Groupe.

title: Cyberthieves Silently Copy Your Passwords as You Type
description: Most people who use e-mail now know enough to be on guard against "phishing" messages that pretend to be from a bank or business but are actually attempts to steal passwords and other personal information.

title: Indian Premier Assures Parliament on Nuclear Talks With U.S.
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 27 - Two days before the arrival of President George W. Bush, the Indian prime minister, Manmohan Singh, sought to temper Indian anxiety over the nuclear negotiations with the White House, telling Parliament this afternoon that no deal with the United States would compromise India's national security.

title: The Big Man Still Reigns in Hollywood
description: NEXT Sunday at the Oscars, directors, actors and producers from a handful of small films will pick up the majority of the big awards. The winners will talk about courage, about independence, about the women and men who were willing to step forward and triumph over the big Hollywood machine.

title: Messiaen as Audience Icebreaker, for One Night Only
description: A lucky audience at Zankel Hall on Saturday night heard the first and, very likely, the only performance by the Winged Harmony Ensemble. The three dozen gifted young American musicians in this group had been selected and brought to New York by Carnegie Hall's Weill Music Institute for an intensive six-day workshop with the conductor David Robertson, who coached them in three formidably difficult 20th-century scores by Messiaen and Varse. For this one-time concert the ensemble had to be called something. Hence, the fanciful Winged Harmony.

title: Labor Leaders to Convene, Faced With Uphill Battles
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 26 - When the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s leaders gather this week at a luxury seaside resort here, they will once again be on the defensive, a situation made worse by the split the labor federation suffered last year.

title: European Union to Provide Emergency Money to Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 27 A After receiving a dire warning that the Palestinian Authority was so short of money that it might collapse in two weeks, the European Union today offered $144 million in aid to the Palestinians before a Hamas government takes power.

description: Larry Brown had a wish list, of shot blockers and rebounders, of long-limbed swingmen who slap away passes, of small guys with quick feet who cut off the driving lanes.

Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Firefighters Suffer Burns At Blaze In An Apartment
description: Three firefighters were taken to hospitals for minor burns yesterday after battling a fire in a 24th-floor apartment near Van Cortlandt Park, the authorities said. The fire broke out about 4 p.m. at Tracey Towers, a 38-story building at 20 West Mosholu Parkway South. An assistant fire chief, Robert Sweeney, said the blaze was under control by 5:15. It was fed by high winds that roared into the apartment through a broken patio window, he said, creating what he called a "blowtorch effect." The three firefighters had burns on their hands and faces, Chief Sweeney said. Six other firefighters were treated for minor injuries at the scene. The cause of the blaze was under investigation last night. THOMAS J. LUECK (NYT)

title: Germany Disputes News Report on Its Pre-War Iraq Role
description: BERLIN, February 27 A The German government today labeled as "false" a report in The New York Times that two agents of the German Intelligence agency obtained Saddam Hussein's plan for the defense of Baghdad before the American invasion of Iraq, and that the information was passed along to American military intelligence in early 2003.

description: Food that looks tantalizing on the page is the hallmark of cooking magazines, but if you want a taste, you have to actually cook it yourself. title: Whimsically Tuning In to the Radio-Dial Past
description: The music of the home-recording savant Ariel Pink (originally Ariel Rosenberg) from Los Angeles has more in common with the pastiche created by crate-digging D.J.'s than with the noise-rock of his compatriots in the freak-folk scene. His elaborately constructed, half-remembered melodies and densely layered instrumentations are not so much improvised as already extant snippets, passionately recalled and quickly abandoned.

title: How a Deal Became a Big Liability for G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 - Representative Peter T. King of New York was in a room packed with reporters last week, complaining that the White House had jeopardized national security by contracting with an Arab-owned company to manage terminals in six American ports, when he felt his cellphone vibrate. It was Representative J. Dennis Hastert, the speaker of the House.

title: Sybille Bedford, Novelist and Memoirist, Dies at 94
description: Sybille Bedford, whose first novel won high praise among England's literary elite and earned her a place in its most celebrated and exclusive literary circles, died Feb. 17 at a hospital near her home in London. She was 94.

title: Where a Sled, Not a Ferrari, Is the Ultimate Luxury Vehicle
description: CESANA PARIOL, Italy, Feb. 26 - It was shortly before midnight on Saturday. The stands were empty. The Olympic luge, skeleton and bobsled competitions were over, and two young Turin Organizing Committee volunteers were already finding an alternative use for the Olympic track: climbing the railing that separates the snow and dirt from the refrigerated sliding surface and posing for photographs while lying in one of the huge banked turns.

title: A New Director Open to Adventure and a Challenge
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonic opened its 51st season on Saturday evening, with its new music director, Michael Christie, on its podium. Mr. Christie has his work cut out for him. His predecessor in Brooklyn, Robert Spano, conducted each of his programs twice, and before Mr. Spano, Dennis Russell Davies led weekend thematic extravaganzas. Now the orchestra's parlous finances cover only single performances. Clearly it is up to Mr. Christie to create an excitement that will attract audiences and money to make expansion -- or reclamation -- possible.

title: In France, a meal of intolerance
Don Knotts, Ever Proud to Be a Bumbler
description: Don Knotts was a high-status comic who played low-status roles. Actors who worked with him almost universally deferred to him as a comedic grandmaster, yet his characters were not jokers but the butts of jokes. He was absolutely flappable. No one had a better tremor or double-take, and with his unmistakable homeliness -- bulging eyes, receding chin, stooped shoulders, broad hips -- he didn't bother to play the wise fool; he wisely stuck to just the fool.

title: After Surviving Early Matches, Ogilvy Defeats an Erratic Love
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., Feb. 26 - A man and two small children were waiting when Davis Love III and Geoff Ogilvy passed by their backyard Sunday morning on the 13th tee at La Costa Resort and Spa, which has homes close enough to the fairways that residents can share their thoughts with the golfers.

title: Sports of The Times; Nets' Frank Proves He Deserves His Job
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. - I HADN'T taken the 20-minute trip from Manhattan to Continental Arena for at least a month. So yesterday, I crossed the George Washington Bridge to see the Nets.

title: A Mideast Conflagration All but Real
description: In the Republic of Iqra, things happen that sound eerily familiar, as if they might have happened before, in another, less fictional country. In fact, they're so eerily familiar that you might as well just pull some newspapers out of the recycling bin and read them.

title: Dungeon Masters in Cyberspace
description: Gary Gygax, the original dungeon master, can see as well as anyone how computers have changed the face of gaming. All he has to do is look down the hall at his home in Lake Geneva, Wis.

title: Parking Rules

title: Double, Double, and Then? Lots of Hearts, Little Trouble
description: Players from a dozen countries competed in the NEC Cup in Yokohama, Japan, from Feb. 6 to 12. Three American teams were in the field of 42. The event started with eight rounds of 20-board matches, from which eight teams moved forward to the knockout phase. The only survivors from the United States were Gaylor Kasle of Boca Raton, Fla., John Sutherlin of Dallas, Garey Hayden of Tucson and John Onstott of New Orleans. In the quarterfinals they played against an Australian team.

title: Dickensian Democracy
description: Stripping convicted felons of the right to vote is a slap at America's democratic ideals. Many states are backing away from this policy, understanding at last that voting rights are in fact basic human rights that should be abridged only in the rarest circumstances. That lesson has yet to penetrate the state of Washington, which has created a form of disenfranchisement that is straight out of "Oliver Twist."

title: Theater that knows that we're not well
When These Boil Over, They're Ready to Drive
description: SPEED records of any type rarely stand for long, but one -- for the fastest steam-powered car -- has gone nearly unchallenged for 100 years. This is not so much a reflection of how difficult it would be to break the existing mark, but a measure of how long ago steam engines, once the leading power source for industry, slipped into obscurity.

The step could help defuse the sectarian tensions that threatened to spiral into open civil war last week after the bombing of a Shiite shrine and the killings of Sunnis in reprisal.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 A The most pressing and unsettled questions in election law are those that concern the role of money, the role of race and the role of partisanship. The Supreme Court this week will take up all three.

title: Civic Fights Subside as Yonkers Hopes for $3.1 Billion Project
description: YONKERS, Feb. 23 - On the west side of this old mill city, a place defined not by what it is but by what it could be, prosperity is measured by the number of new buildings scattered along the Hudson River waterfront: a $53 million library, finished under budget and ahead of schedule; the refurbished Yonkers train station, with its arched windows and domed tiled roof; and two luxury condo towers and the restaurants, bars and banks that have sprouted around them.

title: Coast Guard Raised Concerns About Port Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 A Coast Guard intelligence officials in December raised the prospect of significant security risks associated with the takeover of some American port operations by a Dubai company, saying in a previously undisclosed document that broad "intelligence gaps" prevented them from even assessing the possibility of a terror threat.

title: Iran Moves Toward Deal With Russia on Uranium
description: TEHRAN, Feb. 26 - The top nuclear officials of Iran and Russia announced Sunday that they had reached initial agreement on a deal to enrich Iranian uranium on Russian soil and said that talks would continue over the details.

title: Voices Raised in Song at Grover's Corners
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Feb. 25 - Aaron Copland wanted to make it an opera. So did Leonard Bernstein. But Thornton Wilder, the author of "Our Town," turned both composers down. Now, 68 years after it was written and 30 years after Wilder's death, the play has made it to the opera stage. "Our Town," with music by Ned Rorem and a libretto by J. D. McClatchy, received its premiere here on Friday evening by the Indiana University Opera Theater, one of six commissioners of this opera.

title: Arts, Briefly; Olympics' Last Laps
description: Against modest competition, Friday's Olympics ratings did the job for NBC, though they were well off the highs achieved by figure skating earlier in the week. According to Nielsen's estimates, the games (left, Carl Verheijen of the Netherlands) drew an average of 15.51 million viewers. The other networks didn't come close, nor did they really try: second-place ABC broadcast two hours of "America's Funniest Home Videos" (9.4 million) and "20/20" (8.54 million), and third-ranked CBS was all repeats. On Thursday, ABC's "Primetime" drew its best ratings in nearly three years, with 12.4 million watching an exclusive interview with Joran van der Sloot, a suspect in the disappearance of Natalee Holloway in Aruba last year. On advertiser-supported cable, the NBA All-Star game on TNT Feb. 19 went up against the Olympics, as well as ABC's "Desperate Housewives" and "Grey's Anatomy." Its audience of 7.07 million was down about a million viewers from last year, but the game was by far the most-watched cable program of that week, taking TNT to first place in prime time. KATE AURTHUR

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Translation Dispute Resolved
description: The city's Department of Education will increase funds and tighten regulations for translation services for parents, as part of an agreement to resolve a running dispute between the City Council and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. The agreement will be announced today, according to Make the Road by Walking, an immigrant advocacy group that took part in the negotiations. The new services are an attempt to address a dispute over the Education Equity Act passed by the Council, which required the department to provide interpretation services at large meetings at which at least 10 percent of those likely to attend would be unable to speak English. Another requirement was that documents intended for parents, like report cards and important notices, had to be available in the nine languages most widely used in the city. The Council passed the act in December, on a 35-to-11 vote, but the mayor vetoed the measure in January, saying that, though he agreed with the substance of the proposal, only the state government could legislate on education matters. The agreement will have many of the same features as the Education Equity Act. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)
