title: People
description: Chris Pinnington was promoted to chief operating officer at Euro RSCG Worldwide, a new post. He had been chief executive of the agency's British operations. He will remain in London. Euro RSCG is part of Havas.

title: Which Twin Holds the Tennis Racquet?
description: A maker of tennis footwear, apparel and equipment is giving a new twist to an old saying, declaring that if you canAt beat Aem, create Aem.

title: U.S. Tells Northeast States to Pay More to Use Tracks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 - After failing in a three-year effort to hand over Amtrak's Washington-to-Boston tracks, and their costs, to a new federal-state consortium, the Bush administration is seeking tens of millions of dollars in extra fees from states for use of the tracks by commuter railroads.

title: For Palestinians in Gaza, work commute can be hardest part of day
Paid Notice: Deaths   KEUFFEL, KEN
description: KEUFFEL--Ken. I rejoice in the life of Ken Keuffel. He is a gentle man and my first mentor. My thoughts are with his family. Allan Lenzner

title: For savings, firms in Korea look north
India's war on poverty: Easy victory unlikely
Other Views: Business Times, The Australian, Deccan Herald
Arts, Briefly; How They're Doing
description: The first few months of 2005, with films like "Guess Who," "Hitch" and "Diary of a Mad Black Woman," were notably strong for comedies with African-American casts, and this year two have opened at No. 1. Last month it was "Big Momma's House 2" with Martin Lawrence, and this weekend another movie with a man in drag, Tyler Perry's "Madea's Family Reunion" (Lionsgate), took in $30.2 million in ticket sales, according to studio estimates yesterday. In a revival of his character from "Diary of a Mad Black Woman," a surprise hit last year, Mr. Perry, right, who wrote and directed the film, stars as a Southern grandma working to organize a family reunion; the film also features Cicely Tyson, Maya Angelou and Blair Underwood. Holdovers filled out the Top 5: "Eight Below" (Buena Vista), a survival tale about huskies in the Antarctic, dropped to No. 2 with $15.7 million; "The Pink Panther" (Sony) was at No. 3 with $11.3 million, bringing its three-week sales to $61 million; "Date Movie" (Fox) was at No. 4 in its second week, with $9.2 million; and "Curious George" (Universal) took in $7 million at No. 5, for three-week sales $43.1 million. CATHERINE BILLEY

title: Versace and Missoni: Innovation in a Familiar Vein
description: Milan - Twenty years ago few would have questioned whether Gianni Versace or the Dolce & Gabbana boys -- and back then, Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana were boys -- were innovative. These designers considered it their jobs to disturb the Italian peace. If they gathered fans for their type of sartorial mischief, great. But their sense of innovation wasn't separate from their brand identity. It was who they were, and that's what they wanted the world to know.

title: Danish Companies Endure Snub by Muslim Consumers
description: LONDON - A week ago, Arla Foods planned to remove its sponsorship logo from the Danish soccer team's training outfits when it plays Israel on Wednesday. By Friday, Arla Foods, a Danish dairy company that has borne the economic brunt of the Muslim outrage over newspaper cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad, had changed its mind. The company said the logo would be in its usual place for the match in Tel Aviv.

title: William F. Buckley: Failure in Iraq
Secret Lives
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Nine Dragons IPO Heats Up Hong Kong IPO Market
description: Chinas largest containerboard maker, Nine Dragons Paper Ltd. , demanded top dollar for shares in its US$438 million initial public offering Friday. Investors, eager to grab a piece of the biggest IPO in Hong Kong so far this year, paid HK$3.40 a share  the top of the offerings price range.

title: Belgium, Epicenter of Free-Wheeling Capitalism?
description: Unveiling record profits with stern faces in the latest reporting season, Britains bank bosses are at pains to stress that they only count the money domestically these days. It seems that celebrating capitalism has been outsourced to, well, Belgium. The land of mussels, frites and few famous people is just the place where capitalism can be praised without attracting protesters.

title: Investors Await Canadian Bank Results
description: A raft of Canadian and U.S. economic data along with quarterly results from Canadas big banks will give investors plenty to watch this week. On Thursday, Bank of Montreal, Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and National Bank of Canada release first-quarter results. And on Friday, Bank of Nova Scotia and Royal Bank of Canada complete the major banks reports.

title: Genuflecting Before the Citys Chief Father Confessor
description: The City does not have its own archbishop, at least officially. But if it did, the stately Robert Swannell, newly appointed vice-chairman of Citigroup Europe, would undoubtedly be the man with the Square Miles chasuble and thurible, says the Telegraphs Martin Baker.

title: U.S. Says Googles Privacy Concerns Unfounded
description: The Justice Department has denied requesting anything from Google that could threaten the privacy of the search-engines users, as the company recently contended.

title: Microsoft Vows to Fight South Korean Antitrust Decision
description: Microsoft Corp. vowed Friday to appeal a decision by South Koreas antitrust regulators concluding the U.S. company had abused its market dominance and ordering it to offer alternative versions of Windows. The commission had ruled that Microsofts practice of tying certain software to its flagship Windows operating systems was an abuse of its dominant position in the market.

title: The Pelicans Shadow
description: Bert Fields, a running buddy of Anthony Pellicano and one of the biggest lawyers in Hollywood, is bumping knees with the feds in the hopes that they all can just get along, with all parties of course, remaining at large. Prosecutors are presenting Mr. Fields and his firm, Greenberg Glusker Fields Claman Machtinger & Kinsella, with what they say is evidence against them, and giving them an opportunity to respond, the lawyers said, according to a story by Times reporters David M. Halbfinger and Allison Hope Weiner. For a fulsome look back at the B-Movie that has become Mr. Pellicanos libretto, put on the coffee and settle in.

title: Jordache Zips Up Earl Jean
description: Jordache Enterprises has acquired the Earl Jean brand from VF Corp. Jordache and a group of private investors purchased the womens and mens denim-based brand in a deal that was made final on Thursday, although terms were not disclosed.

title: Business, As Usual
description: Stacey Snider (Vince Bucci/Getty Images)

title: Donning the Big L with Pride
description: Any weekend savant with a dial-up connection can tell you who is going to win in most of the categories, but it takes a rare form of brilliance to figure out who is absolutely, no doubt about it, going to tank come Sunday night. Thats the primary challenge at Drews Script-O-Rama, where he is offering swag to those who can sense a halo of flies around the big losers. It may be easy to guess that this is not going to be Charlize Therons year  shes already won and she is in a movie almost no one saw and even fewer are bothering to talk about  but can you say with surety that Robert Elswit has not shot for his cinematography Oscar in Good Night, and Good Luck? We thought not. Go ahead, cant lose if you dont play.

title: Top Executive Is Leaving Universal to Run DreamWorks
description: Stacey Snider, chairwoman of Universal Pictures, will leave the studio to take a new job running DreamWorks, now a division of Paramount Pictures, Paramount said on Sunday. Ms. Sniders exit, which had been rumored for weeks, leaves a major gap in the executive ranks at Universal, where she had guided the development and production of films since 1999. At DreamWorks, a much smaller operation, the executive will make four to six movies a year in partnership with the producer and director Steven Spielberg.

title: New $120M Fund May Lift Colorado Startups
description: At least one venture capitalist eyeing Colorado has attracted a lot more money to put to work.And thats a heartening sign for startups in the state.  ITU Ventures has a new $120 million fund and says roughly a quarter of that cash ultimately could flow into the hands of grateful up-and-coming companies in Colorado.

title: British Hedge Funds in Watchdogs Crosshairs
description: London-based hedge fund managers are facing a regulatory clampdown from both British and American watchdogs. The Financial Services Authority will next month detail where it is going on regulating hedge funds and their managers, after a six-month consultation first revealed in The Independent on Sunday.

title: And the Money to Pay for It
description: Think all the talk of boutique movies and tepid ratings have the advertisers of America scared? Think again, says my colleague and advertising savant Stuart Elliott:

title: Nine-Figure Bar Tab
description: The business model of Hollywood may be in flux and the future may seem uncertain, but thats no reason to spoil the party. In fact, BizBash, which keeps track of such things, suggests that various swells will drop $150 million on Oscar-related festivities. Given the overall budgets of most of the years nominees, you could make about a dozen movies instead of buying all the shrimp and vodka, but hey, wheres the fun in that?

title: Lane Change Ahead
description: The persons at PricewaterhouseCoopers best check their routes, because the street crew is already on DefCon 4: Today they are closing down Hollywood Boulevard from Orange Drive to Highland until next Tuesday. That sound of plain old civilians in L.A. cursing their fates behind the wheel? Well, that just means that the Academy Awards are in high effect and its worth keeping an eye out for the sequel to Crash in and around the streets surrounding the Kodak Theater.

title: Oscar, Proud Luddite
description: At a time when refrigerators can be programmed to tell you they are out of milk, the Oscars are delineated the old-fashioned way  counted by hand in the same room where they keep Dick Cheney when the going gets tough. In a press release, PricewaterhouseCoopers lifts up the blankets just a bit on the process, sharing some fascinating Oscar trivia. For example, the fact that it takes 1,700 person-hours each year to count and verify the ballots. For the past 72 years, the persons at the accounting firm have guarded the Oscar results with abundant fervor, but that was before the NSA started monitoring domestic phone conversations. The Baggers sure the boys with the old gimlet eye have taken appropriate measures. Once the ballots are counted, the real black ops begin:

title: Drug Maker Microbia Lands $75m in Financing
description: Eight years after it was hatched as an idea in an MIT lab for yeast research, the private Cambridge , Mass., biotechnology company Microbia Inc. said today that it has received $75 million in new venture capital financing  the biggest biotech venture deal in New England since 2004. The 70-person company is pushing two experimental drugs through clinical trials, one for constipation and the other for high cholesterol.

title: The Pageant of Democracy
description: Brad Oltmanns, left, and Rick Rosas of PricewaterhouseCoopers wheel the final Oscar ballots to an awaiting U.S. Postal Service truck at the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences building on February 8, 2006 in Beverly Hills, California. (David Livingston/Getty Images)

title: Nippon Sheet Glass to Buy Pilkington for $3.14 Billion
description: Nippon Sheet Glass Co. agreed to buy Pilkington Plc for 1.8 billion pounds ($3.14 billion) to reduce its reliance on Japan and expand in 24 nations, including China. The acquisition gives Nippon Sheet new markets for windshields and cuts its reliance on glass for television and computer monitors.

title: Lawlessness in Chad
description: The chaos in Darfur, the war-ravaged region in Sudan where more than 200,000 civilians have been killed, has spread across the border into Chad.

title: A BlackBerry Apocalypse? Get a Grip
description: Masters of the universe from Wall Street to Washington and beyond breathed a sigh of relief on Friday when a federal judge in Virginia put off a decision on whether to shut down the BlackBerry wireless e-mail service, which has more than three million subscribers in the United States. Even so, fears of a meltdown by jet-setting executives have been hyperbolic to a fault. The world, it turns out, would not end if BlackBerry service did.

title: KeySpan Agrees to Be Sold to National Grid for $7.3 Billion
description: KeySpan, which provides power to 1.1 million customers on Long Island, agreed yesterday to be sold to National Grid, a British utility, for about $7.3 billion in cash. National Grid will pay $42 a share for KeySpan, a 16 percent premium to its share price at the time KeySpan acknowledged it was in talks to be sold.

title: In Indias Silicon Valley, Partying Like Its 1999
description: These are strange times in Bangalore, Indias fast-rising high-tech capital, whose abundance of bars and clubs have earned it the moniker Pub City. As their Bay Area counterparts did in the 1990s, the multicultural moneymakers and entrepreneurs of Indias Silicon Valley are creating a playground worthy of their rupees.

title: KT&G Rejects Bid by Icahn, Lichtenstein; Takeover Battle Ahead?
description: KT&G Corp. rejected a bid from U.S. investors Carl Icahn and Warren Lichtenstein that valued the tobacco maker at $10 billion, raising the prospect of the nations biggest hostile takeover battle. The last unwelcome bid by a foreign investor in South Korea, Asias third-largest economy, failed in 1997.

title: Over My Dead Body? Pearson Chief Pushed to Unload  FT
description: Pressure is mounting on Dame Marjorie Scardino, the chief executive of Pearson, to sanction the 500 million pound sale of the Financial Times  something she has said will only happen over my dead body. Two leading shareholders are publicly calling on the company to sell the newspaper, while others are telling Pearson behind the scenes to get rid of the Pink un.

title: Wall St. Research Said to Suffer Since Spitzer Deal
description: Mountains of red tape imposed by the government in the wake of the Internet bubble are causing an exodus of Wall Streets sell-side analysts, company executives and industry watchers say. Often, established analysts are fleeing to hedge funds and other buy-side investment firms, which offer richer pay and greater freedom. The result: fewer experienced analysts on the sell side, and a shrinking universe of coverage.

title: Citigroups Biglari Sees New Breed of Banker
description: Mergers and acquisitions are getting more complex, and so are the skills and teamwork required to get the deals done, according to Hamid Biglari. The global head for financial institutions at Citigroup Inc. has first-hand experience with the changing market. His M&A team recently scored a coup in helping put together BlackRock Inc. and Merrill Lynch Investment Managers.

title: We Plan On Doing an O. J. With Mr. Scrushy
description: Even if Kenneth L. Lay of Enron is aquitted, like Richard Scrushy of HealthSouth, he could still face financial ruin, at least if the class-action lawyers have their way.
Selborne Journal: 27 February 1759:  One pot of Millers Cantaleupes begins to appear. Continual heavy rain.

title: Gas Natural to Raise Bid for Rival
description: Gas Natural is expected to raise its bid for Endesa, its fellow Spanish utility, to beat a rival 29 billion euros offer from E.ON, of Germany. Endesas board has rejected both offers as too low, but the bid battle took a further twist when the Spanish Government passed a decree enabling an energy regulator to prevent foreign takeovers of Spanish energy companies.

title: PE Firms No Longer Pariahs in Germany?
description: Private-equity funds and other financial investors are fast becoming part of the fabric of corporate Germany. The term locust, used disdainfully to describe them last year by Franz Muntefering, now the countrys vice-chancellor, is changing into one of near endearment.

title: Maybe The Carlyle Group Should Hire Al Gore?
description: The Carlyle Group is expected to invest heavily in the renewable energy industry, the firms founder and managing director, David Rubenstein, said on Wednesday.

title: Excite Co-Founder Kraus Gets Wiki With JotSpot
description: Joe Kraus, a co-founder of founded search engine and Web portal Excite, is now focusing on his newest project, JotSpot (www.jot.com). The Palo Alto start-up concentraing on wiki technology, which is used to create Web sites where people can collaborate online. Kraus is aiming to make wiki technology easy for anybody to use, especially non-techies.

title: Giuliani Venture Inks Deal With Florida Firm
description: An obscure Florida financial firm is set to reap millions of dollars if a deal between a small New York security company and Rudy Giulianis consulting firm lasts three years. Command Security Corp., a Dutchess County security firm with a $22 million market value, signed a $2.1 million agreement with Giuliani Security & Safety to open the door for lucrative corporate deals, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: LG Card Gussies Up Ahead of Potential Sale
description: LG Card, South Koreas No. 2 credit card issuer, has improved its asset quality significantly, making it more attractive in preparation for the sale of the firm this year. The firm, which has been up for sale by its creditors, has seen its delinquency ratio, or the percentage of card bills and loans unpaid for 30 days and longer, drop to a record low of 7.36 percent in January.

title: Apax in Talks to Buy U.K. Department Store
description: House of Fraser, the British department store group, is holding takeover discussions with private equity firm Apax Partners after receiving an approach at the end of last week. A subject of regular takeover speculation, the group has confirmed that its latest suitor had made a very preliminary approach.

title: Texas Pacific Plans Asia Push
description: Texas Pacific Group, one of the worlds biggest private equity groups, plans a push into Asia amid signs that Newbridge Capital, its Asian affiliate, is too small to compete with global rivals for increasingly large deals. TPG wanted to deploy significantly more capital in Asia by using its new $10 billion to $12 billion buyout fund to work on deals alongside Newbridge, a joint venture with Blum Capital Partners.

title: NYSE Trading on Stock Sale, Merger for Future
description: Richard Grasso hadnt been pushed out of the New York Stock Exchange in September 2003 after disclosure of a $139 million compensation package, would the venerable Wall Street institution be going public? Well never know for sure, of course. But William Power, who serves on the NYSEs board of executives as well being a director at the Chicago Board Options Exchange, is certain that the uproar over the former chairman and chief executives hefty pay package was essential in forcing change on an insular institution.

title: Rosneft Chief  Wants to Take $20B IPO Global
description: Rosneft President Sergei Bogdanchikov is courting investors to build the Russian state oil companys $20 billion initial public stock offering into the main event on the worlds emerging markets this year.

title: Citigroup Says SEC Inquiry Over Argentina Expands
description: Citigroup Inc. said on Friday the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission has expanded an accounting investigation into the banks activities in Argentina, and subpoenaed materials for four additional years.

title: Dubai Deal to Face Deeper Inquiry
description: The Dubai company seeking to take over some terminal operations at six American ports formally asked the Bush administration on Sunday to conduct a deeper investigation into security concerns surrounding the deal. The request will leave President Bush in the politically delicate position of having to personally approve or disapprove the takeover.

title: Losing the House May Be Good for Bush
The Coming Clash?
description: In Slate, neocon-turned-war-critic Francis Fukuyama reviews the burgeoning and markedly alarmist literature on the Islamic threat to Europe, including Pat Buchanans 2001 book, The Death of the West, and Washington Times editorial page editor Tony Blankleys latest, The Wests Last Chance, which is subtitled, Will We Win the Clash of Civilizations?

title: Eyes Turn to LSE as Deadline Expires for Suitors
description: Britains competition watchdog is expected to kick-start the struggle for ownership of the London Stock Exchange within the next few days. However, potential bidders may be reluctant to come forward after the recent surge in the LSEs share price. Euronext, the operator of a number of continental exchanges, is officially still interested, but the LSE share price has risen to what is likely to be unaffordable levels since the two were last in talks a year ago.

title: DJ Ortho to Buy Aircast for $290 Million
description: Medical device maker DJ Orthopedics said Monday it agreed to buy cast manufacturer Aircast Inc. for about $290 million. The deal would be a significant transaction for DJ Orthopedics, which has a market value of about $658 million and makes orthopedic braces.

title: The Adviser Who Became the Activist
description: Bruce Wassersteins decision to play such a prominent role in Carl Icahns failed fight  and to declare the breakup plan his own  may have exposed him as Wall Streets Emperor With No Clout. And perhaps more important, it may have put him in a precarious position with his current and prospective clients, at least until Wall Streets notorious short-term memory fades.

title: Italy Sees War as Suez, GdF Try Defensive Merger
description: Suez SA and Gaz de France SA plan to merge in a one-for-one stock swap to create the worlds second-largest power and gas company, and fend off a hostile bid for Suez from Italys Enel SpA.

title: CNBC: Peltz Still Snapping Up Heinz Shares
Paris Collections
description: New looks from the fall 2006 collections of Bernhard Willhelm, Undercover, Viktor & Rolf and Yohji Yamamoto.

title: Arcelor Shareholders Courted in Mittal Takeover Struggle
description: Mittal Steel on Sunday kicked off a charm offensive to seduce Arcelor stockholders, saying their shares are already worth 36 percent more than their previous all-time high since Mittals $23 billion hostile takeover bid. In addition, the takeover of the worlds second-largest steelmaker by the worlds number one would accelerate growth, reaping even more profits for shareholders, Mittals chief financial officer said.

title: Will Wallets Stay Open?
description: Calculated Risk steers us to a research report by Merril Lynch economist David Rosenberg, who has been keeping an eye on the housing price boom and its impact on consumer spending.

title: Celebrity House Hunters
description: Not a lot going on this week, but much of what it is happening is on the sell side:L.A.Timess Hot Property: Val Kilmer is selling most of his New Mexico land for $18 million; Flea flees Los Feliz; Steve Wynn lists Beverly Hills lot for $7.25 million.

title: Questioning Bushs Port Position
description: Readers respond to Paul Krugmans Feb. 24 column, Osama, Saddam and the Ports

title: The Death of Ms. Bahjat
description: The Times of London carried a lovely tribute to the latest reporter killed in Iraq. She is one of the 11 reporters from Al-Arabiya channel who has been killed so far in Iraq. The paper wrote:

title: Ball Picks Up Alcan Unit for $180 Million
description: Alcan , the Canadian aluminum producer, said it would sell its plastic bottle operations in North America to Ball Corp. for $180 million. Alcan said the the deal was part of its continued strategy of focusing resources on markets where we enjoy scale and leadership positions.

title: Armor Offers $1.1B for Military Truckmaker
description: Armor Holdings Inc., which supplies protective gear for soldiers and vehicles used by United Statse forces in Iraq, has offered $1.1 billion in cash for military truckmaker Stewart & Stevenson Services Inc.

title: GE to Exit Genworth on High Note
description: General Electric Co. has filed with regulators to sell its 18 percent stake of onetime subsidiary Genworth Financial in a secondary offering, and it should get a much higher price this time around.

title: Dana Shares Whipsawed as Bankruptcy Question Looms
description: Shares of Dana  Corp. jumped nearly 50 percent early Monday, before falling back later in the day, as investors struggled to handicap the companys chances of avoiding a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing.

title: The Moderate Path in the Middle East
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Feb. 26 column, Keeping the Faith in Democracy:

title: Young Golfer Keeps Driving
description: Feb. 27 - As her mother battles cancer, 12-year-old Dakoda Dowd will be playing in her first L.P.G.A. tournament in April. (Producer: Matthew Orr)

title: Reaping the Dividends of War
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Feb. 27 column, Ike Saw It Coming.

title: All Together Now?
description: A question that a reader recently submitted dovetailed with a complaint I hear frequently from friends and a frustration I share. When most  but not all  members of a party arrive on time for their reservation at a restaurant, why are they sometimes required to wait for the others in the bar or somewhere else rather than at the table?

title: The Rise of Very Light Jets
description: Joe Sharkey discusses the future of very light jets - also known as microjets - as the eventual workhorses of a new air transportation system.

title: A Walk in the Woods
description: The Times's Jim Gorman walks through Central Park with Niles Eldredge, the curator of the Darwin exhibit at the American Museum of Natural History.(Producer: Craig Duff)

title: Bloomberg's Ex-First Deputy Takes Job With a Developer
description: Correction Appended

title: At Gotti Trial, Sliwa Tells of Stretching Truth for Attention
description: As he has done countless times on his radio program, Curtis Sliwa told a jury yesterday how he had been ambushed in a cab rigged so the doors and windows would not open, then shot at least twice by hit men he believes were connected with John A. Gotti, the heir to the Gambino crime family.

title: Beyond Rivalry, a Hidden World of Sibling Violence
description: From infancy until he reached the threshold of manhood, the beatings Daniel W. Smith received at his older brother's hands were qualitatively different from routine sibling rivalry. Rarely did he and his brother just shove each other in the back of the family car over who was crowding whom, or wrestle over a toy firetruck.

title: Almost Bringing the House Down With a Rarely Heard Rossini
description: Ewa Podles can certainly excite an audience. When Ms. Podles, a Polish-born contralto, finished her electrifying performance of a rarely heard Rossini solo cantata, "Joan of Arc," on Sunday afternoon, people throughout Avery Fisher Hall burst into frenzied applause and lusty bravos. There was so much foot-stomping the walls seemed to shake. One feared that the scheduled gutting and renovation of the auditorium were about to get an early start.

title: The Danish Cartoons
description: To the Editor:

title: Vatican seeks to catholicize Gypsies
I'd Rather Be Working, Pataki Says From Hospital
description: Correction Appended

title: Europeans Offer $144 Million Aid to Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 27 - After receiving a dire warning that the Palestinian Authority was so short of money that it might collapse in two weeks, the European Union on Monday offered $144 million in aid to the Palestinians before a Hamas government takes power.

title: Not a Lot of Sexy, but More Than a Little Sinister
description: PARIS, Feb. 27 - Donna Karan and Donatella Versace can take long looks in the mirror and ask themselves, as they did with their fall collections, Who am I? They can figure out a general idea of what once made them famous, then go back to their roots to great applause. But the trend of designers giving themselves personal evaluations, now in evidence at the start of the Paris collections on Sunday with a show Yohji Yamamoto cheerfully described as back to basics, is beginning to feel a little self-indulgent.

title: The Stress/Fun Equation of Bringing Children on Business Trips
description: The novelist Geraldine Brooks learned a hard lesson about child care on a book tour in New Zealand when her son was just a year old.

title: Congress's Search for Courage
description: It is time to end the lip service and outright evasion that Congress has been devoting to its most flagrant scandal -- the money-soaked symbiosis of lawmakers and Washington's runaway lobbying industry. Taxpayers are near furious at such routine outrages as incumbents' paying a token commercial ticket price for the unlimited borrowing of corporate jets for political sorties that come replete with in-cabin lobbyists. No less offensive is the lawmakers' abject reliance on lobbyists to solicit and bundle large amounts of campaign cash from corporate clients intent on buying backroom clout.

title: Coast Guard Addresses Sex Assaults
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 27 - The Coast Guard Academy in New London, Conn., facing questions over how it deals with complaints of sexual assault among cadets, released a report on Monday that showed the academy received eight complaints since 2000 that resulted in the dismissal of three students.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BAUMAN, LIONEL R.
description: BAUMAN--Lionel R. Beloved partner, friend and colleague. Died on February 27, 1987. Sorely missed by all. Eugene M. Grant & Co. LLC

title: Eat, Pray, Love: One Woman's Search for Everything Across Italy, India and Indonesia
A wife scorned (or maybe just a little miffed)
Franklin Foer Is Named Top Editor of New Republic
description: For a small outfit, The New Republic has always gone long on drama. Its changes in leadership have usually arrived in the form of rolling coups or lightning bolts from above. So it is refreshing, if a bit underwhelming, to report that Franklin Foer, a senior editor with the magazine, is quietly taking over the shop next week from the current editor, Peter Beinart, who has a book to promote and ambitions of returning to longer form writing.

title: Telling the Truth About Harvard
description: To the Editor:

title: Who invented golf? China takes a swing
Paid Notice: Deaths   RAPHAEL, HARVEY D.
description: RAPHAEL--Harvey D. Born March 9, 1930. Beloved husband of Nadine. Adored father of Caren, Cathy, James and Julia. Beloved father-inlaw of Mel, Stacey and Jeffrey. He will be dearly missed by his five grandchildren Gabe, Max, Alec, Ben and Isabella. Funeral services Tuesday 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. In lieu of flowers please make donations to Small Miracles (Childrens Critical Needs) attention Albert Einstein Network/ Small Miracles Development Department/SM Braemer Building, 5501 Old York Road, Philadelphia, PA 19141.

title: New DVD's
description: Lady and the Tramp

title: Stocks Fall on Signs of Weakness in Economy and at Google
description: Stocks fell broadly today after several economic reports signaled weakening in the housing market and consumer confidence and a Google executive warned that growth at the company was slowing.

title: Bosnia's Genocide Case Against Serbia Starts
description: PARIS, Feb. 27 - The International Court of Justice began hearings on Monday in its first genocide case, a suit in which Bosnia charges that Serbia tried to destroy the Muslim population of Bosnia.

title: Mardi Gras Draws Many Back to New Orleans, for Just a Day
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 28 A Virtually none of the people living here ever thought they would need a calendar to plan their Mardi Gras, since that would be like planning to attend February. But this year, many people pulled out their calendars and pointed their fingers at the Tuesday before Ash Wednesday and wondered whether to go.

title: INSIDE
description: Antiterrorism Changes Are Given Poor Grade A year after a sweeping government reorganization began, the agencies charged with protecting the United States against terrorist attacks have made some progress but remain troubled by high-level turnover, overlapping responsibilities and bureaucratic rivalry, former and current officials say. PAGE A12

title: Special Elections for the Legislature Today
description: Special elections are being held today for Assembly seats in Manhattan and Brooklyn that opened up when the incumbents resigned or were elected to other positions.

title: Nokia widens its lead in mobile phone market
Back in Class After Expulsion Over Paper
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 22 - Last week, a professor at Le Moyne College gave a homework assignment that made one of his students, Scott McConnell, groan. The students were asked to write a paper explaining why they wanted to teach.

title: Achievement of Preemies Is Found to Be Near Normal
description: The smallest surviving premature babies eventually attain levels of education, employment and independence that are almost indistinguishable from those of normal weight babies, according to the latest findings from a continuing Canadian study that began 28 years ago.

title: China accuses Taiwan on change in relations
Hamas: Integrate the militants
The Happiest Wives
description: Freud confessed that his "thirty years of research into the feminine soul" left him unable to answer one great question: "What does a woman want?" Modern feminists have been arguing for decades over a variation of it: What should a woman want?

title: Mardi Gras Dawns With Some Traditions in Jeopardy
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 27 - Surrounded by bags of feathers and beads in the bedroom of a temporary apartment, Monk Boudreaux had plans for the long Carnival weekend before Mardi Gras. Amid the parades, costume balls and general excess here, the 64-year-old Mr. Boudreaux would be doing what he has done for decades: sewing his suit for Mardi Gras on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CALLOW, JOSEPH
description: CALLOW--Joseph. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Joseph Callow, associated with The Times since November, 1946 until retiring in January, 1993.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HELLER, EDITH
description: HELLER--Edith. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Edith Heller, associated with The Times since August, 1956 until retiring in June, 1992.

title: U.S. and Colombia Reach Trade Deal After 2 Years of Talks
description: BOGOT, Colombia, Feb. 27 - After nearly two years of negotiations, the United States and Colombia agreed Monday to a trade deal that would be the largest Washington has concluded with a Latin American country since signing a free trade pact with Mexico in 1993.

title: An Invisible, Deadly Barrier to Journeys Through Space
description: Galactic cosmic radiation poses a major challenge for spacecraft designers looking to protect astronauts on long missions into deep space. Without adequate shielding, these high-speed particles would cut through an astronaut's body, damaging DNA and increasing the likelihood of developing cancer. So far, no method of shielding has proved both effective and practical. FRANK O'CONNELL

title: An Industrial Park in North Korea Nears a Growth Spurt
description: KAESONG, North Korea, Feb. 27 - On a cavernous factory floor here, where hundreds of North Korean women diligently cut and sewed women's jackets on Monday, a South Korean businessman seemed to have found an answer to China: wages of 26 cents an hour.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: Police Try to Trace Last Steps of a Student Found Slain
description: Detectives yesterday were retracing the last steps of a 24-year-old graduate student who disappeared after a night out in Manhattan and whose body was found, wrapped in a quilt, late Saturday in a desolate corner of Brooklyn off the Belt Parkway.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Pentagon Pay System Is Blocked
description: A federal judge blocked the Pentagon from instituting a merit pay system for civilian employees, saying it would undermine their collective bargaining rights. The judge, Emmet G. Sullivan of Federal District Court, said the plan would also make it too difficult for employees to appeal some personnel decisions. The suit was filed in November by 10 federal employee unions. JOHN FILES (NYT)

title: Francis Finds Way, but Knicks Remain Lost
description: SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 27 - Isiah Thomas leaned on the railing of a tunnel at the AT&T Center on Monday night, wearing a sharp beige suit. His hand was positioned near his chin, with a weary gaze fixed ahead, as if he were a college student enduring a lecture he did not want to attend.

title: The Oracle Suggests a Truce Between Science and Religion
description: It may seem that the longstanding war between science and religion is entering a new phase: Darwin versus intelligent design, religious opposition to stem cell research, Western secularism versus Islamic fundamentalism. All around we see growing tensions between the scientific demand for truth through reason and experiment, and the religious desire for consolation and revealed truth.

title: Jon Stewart and the Night Visitor
description: JON STEWART'S huge, downtown loft, 3 a.m. Stewart, in sweats, is sitting at his laptop. We sense that he is anxious, for he lifts his laptop and slams it repeatedly into his face, muttering something that sounds like "Stupid, Stupid, Stupid." Than he takes a long swig from a bottle of Stoli.

title: Play About Demonstrator's Death Is Delayed
description: A potential Off Broadway production of "My Name Is Rachel Corrie," an acclaimed solo show about an American demonstrator killed by an Israeli bulldozer while trying to stop the destruction of a Palestinian home, has been postponed because of concerns about the show's political content.

title: Telling the Truth About Harvard
description: To the Editor:

title: Artistry under cover
President Bush Goes to India
description: When President Bill Clinton went to India six years ago, he danced to folk music with women in a rural Rajasthani village, ate bowls of black lentil stew at a posh restaurant in New Delhi, and spotted a rare Bengal tiger at a wildlife reserve south of Jaipur. He was cheered wildly in India's Parliament.

title: Meeting the Challenge in an India of Fantasy
description: "Lakm" is another operatic triumph of unquenchable melody over theatrical forgettability. The "Bell Song" is an Olympic event for coloratura sopranos. The Lakm-Mallika duet has sung itself into the hearts of even the most anti-opera television viewer: once a manifestation of Oriental languor, now a commercial jingle exhorting the easy joys of air travel.

title: An Unusual Line Dance Greets the Trout Season
description: At 6:30 a.m. tomorrow, a spectacle will unfold on the streams of Missouri's trout parks. It is a celebration and a fishing adventure in the same event. Anglers standing shoulder to shoulder will, at the sound of a siren, cast as one into the waters before them in the first seconds of Missouri's annual trout season.

title: Briefly: Latvia approves plan for painless euro debut
Briefly: Juilliard School gets secret musical stash
Paid Notice: Deaths   PONTE, VINCENT PASCIUTO
description: PONTE--Vincent Pasciuto. A Harvard graduate and a world renowned town planner, died peacefully on February 9, 2006. He is survived by his two aunts, Ruth Mitrano and Esther Robertello. He worked with the world's most prestigious architectural firms designing concepts to minimize pedestrian traffic congestion in landmark projects in New York, Boston, Dallas, and other locations, including the subterranean pedestrian system of Place Ville Marie, in Montreal. He will be sadly missed by all who knew him.

title: Melatonin Musings
description: To the Editor:

title: Into the Cold to Find a Path Across the Top of the World
description: The cellphone was invented for men like Sir John Franklin. Pity that he was born about two centuries too early to make use of it.

title: Alluring Swordtail Scent Is Lost in Pollution
description: Better End of Life for Polystyrene

title: Carter Plays and Kidd Stars, but Nets Still Come Up Short
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 27 - Vince Carter eased his way into the game with the Atlanta Hawks on Monday night, fearful he might aggravate the right hamstring injury that kept him on the bench for most of Sunday night's loss to the Indiana Pacers. He got back on defense, but not at a full sprint. He worked to get open on offense, but only in spots.

title: Iraqis Return to the Streets After Curfew, but Cautiously
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Tuesday, Feb. 28 - Iraqis returned cautiously to the streets and to their jobs on Monday after three days of government-imposed curfew, in this capital still reeling from the worst outbreak of sectarian violence since the fall of Saddam Hussein.

title: An Assertive India Girds for Negotiations With Bush
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 27 - When President Bush lands in India early Wednesday, he will encounter an ever ambivalent American ally with one important difference from the past: this India has new power to assert its views, some of which align with Mr. Bush's agenda and some of which do not.

title: Shares Rally, Led by Retailers and Big Drop in Oil Prices
description: Correction Appended

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Coast Guard Raised Security Concerns Over Dubai Company's Ports Management Coast Guard intelligence officials in December raised the prospect of significant security risks associated with the management of some United States port terminal operations by a Dubai company. [Page A1.]

title: Obituary: Sybille Bedford, novelist, 94
Big Gain for British Publisher, Aided by U.S. Textbook Sales
description: Pearson, the British publisher, reported a strong gain for 2005 yesterday as The Financial Times posted its first profit since 2001 and the educational publishing division reaped the benefit of increased textbook spending in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEGEL, SIDNEY H.
description: SIEGEL--Sidney H. Died February 25, 2006 in Chapel Hill, NC. Former resident of NYC. Loving husband of Shirley Charnay Siegel, loving father of Bob and Barbara Siegel, loving father-in-law of Susan Siegel and Vic LaTessa, devoted grandfather to David, Kim and Nicole LaTessa, Callie and Charley Siegel and great-granddaughter Siena LaTessa. Private interment. The family will be receiving at the home of Susan and Robert Siegel on Wednesday & Thursday from 5-9PM. In lieu of flowers please make donations to the Ackland Museum of Art, Columbia St, Chapel Hill, NC 27514 or to The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, POB 4072, Pittsfield, MA. 01202.

title: More Tin Than Gold for Olympic Spots
description: AT last, the 20th Olympic Winter Games have finally finished. Rarely have so many worked so hard to produce so dull and disappointing an outcome. And rarely have the flops, flubs and foul-ups been so overwhelming.

title: Tom Ford, Clothing Designer, Will Open Store of His Own
description: Putting an end to months of speculation about his future in fashion, the designer Tom Ford announced yesterday that he would open his first store, in New York. The three-story 10,000-square-foot space on Madison Avenue, set to open in November, will showcase his men's wear collection, his first fashion line since leaving Gucci nearly two years ago.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Sunday about Thomas R. Suozzi, the Nassau County executive, who announced that he would seek the Democratic nomination for governor of New York, misspelled part of the name of the Manhattan law firm where he worked from 1990 to 1993. It is Shearman & Sterling, not Sherman.

title: Stopgap Accord Sought on Voting System
description: ALBANY, Feb. 27 - With the federal government threatening to sue New York State for failing to modernize its voting system, state officials said on Monday that they are trying to avoid a lawsuit by negotiating a stopgap approach that would leave the current system intact for this fall's elections but improve access for disabled voters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TUGENDHAFT, ROBERT I., M.D.
description: TUGENDHAFT -- Robert I., M.D. On February 23, 2006. Beloved husband of Gayle. Devoted father of Lynn Meyer, Joan Muller, Margie Bachner, Ann Gagliano and Michael Margulies. Adored grandfather of 14 and cherished great-grandfather of two. Services were held Sunday, February 26, 2006.

Standards: Even Approved Amount of Ozone Is Found Harmful
description: A study sponsored by the Environmental Protection Agency and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has found that air even at the E.P.A.'s current acceptable level of ozone -- 80 parts per billion -- can bring on a significantly increased risk of premature death.

title: Lobbyist Turns Senator but Twists Same Arms
description: Correction Appended

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "I have lost everything but my children. We have three bowls of grain left."

title: Standing on a Runway, Hailing an Air Taxi
description: WE have a getaway place in Tucson, near Saguaro National Park. Usually, we've noticed, the coyotes get to yowling around 4:30 in the morning. There must be a thousand of them in the desert and the Rincon foothills, and why they set up this commotion just before dawn is a question I cannot answer. The yowling chorus lasts no more than a minute. Then, inexplicably, they stop, the desert solitude returns and we drift back to sleep.

title: Canada's Private Clinics Surge as Public System Falters
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Feb. 23 - The Cambie Surgery Center, Canada's most prominent private hospital, may be considered a rogue enterprise.

title: It's time for an American foreign legion
Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Internal Turmoil at Device Maker as Inquiry Grew
description: As the Guidant Corporation came under scrutiny last spring for not telling doctors about potentially fatal defects in its heart devices, the company's public message was upbeat and insistent: concerns about the safety of its products were overblown, it said, and perhaps even irresponsible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ESTRIN, JOSEPH, M.D.
description: ESTRIN--Joseph, M.D., 93. Dr. Joseph N. Cunningham and the Department of Surgery at Maimonides Medical Center mourn the passing of our respected and admired educator and colleague, Dr. Joseph Estrin. He mentored generations of surgeons and was a source of wisdom and inspiration to us all. Avid historian, acclaimed writer and artist, Dr. Estrin will most notably be remembered for his passionate "Uncommon Commitment" to the entire Brooklyn and Maimonides Medical Center community.

title: UN warns on cost of Gaza cuts
World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Nippon Sheet Glass Buys Pilkington
description: Nippon Sheet Glass agreed to buy Pilkington for 1.8 billion ($3.14 billion) to become the world's largest supplier of glass used in buildings and cars. Nippon Sheet raised its cash offer for a fourth time, to 165 pence a share, it said yesterday, 30 percent higher than Pilkington's close before Oct. 31, the day of the first bid. Nippon Sheet Glass, based in Tokyo, already owns 20 percent of the British company, which shipped glass for 12 million vehicles in 2004.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAREISS, MOLLY
description: BAREISS--Molly. The staff and Committee of Prints and Illustrated Books at The Museum of Modern Art extend heartfelt condolences to Walter Bareiss, long-standing Committee member and valued friend of the Museum, for the loss of his wonderful wife, Molly. We offer our most sincere sympathy to the entire Bareiss family. Anna Marie Shapiro, Chair Joanne Stern, Chair Emerita Deborah Wye, Chief Curator

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about a proposed cultural district in Hong Kong misstated the position of the Museum of Modern Art on the project. While it has tried to learn more about the venture, it has not been vying for the right to run a museum there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TESSLER, BARRY A.
description: TESSLER--Barry A. Of NYC. Beloved son of the late Tillie and Irving. Devoted father of Renee (Jeffrey) and Jon. Loving brother of Barbara Kreitzman (Allan L.). Precious grandfather of Ilana and Allison. Funeral services at I.J. Morris, 21 East Deer Park Rd., Dix Hills, Tuesday, noon. For additional information, call 1-888-351-4414.

title: Briefly: Danish chief welcomes EU stand on cartoons
City Cries Out: Hang Up and Drive
description: NOTHING quite beats an appalling story about a baby to provoke a strong reaction.

title: Corrections
description: A cabaret review yesterday about Nellie McKay, at the Allen Room, gave an erroneous title in some copies for a song she performed from her album "Get Away From Me." It is "Sari," not "Sorry." The review also misstated the year the album appeared. It was 2004, not 2003.

title: Passengers in Greece stranded by transit strike
Meeting of experts adds to urgency on bird flu
A Thrill Ride to 'the Other Side of Infinity'
description: DENVER, Feb. 27  Video game technology and Einstein's work on relativity may at first seem as unlikely a couple as Oscar and Felix.

title: Year Into Revamped Spying, Troubles and Some Progress
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 - A year after a sweeping government reorganization began, the agencies charged with protecting the United States against terrorist attacks remain troubled by high-level turnover, overlapping responsibilities and bureaucratic rivalry, former and current officials say.

title: Fruit Bowl Safety
description: Q. Tourists in regions where the water has disease-causing micro-organisms are told not to eat fruit unless they peel it themselves. If the irrigation water is contaminated, isn't the fruit permeated with it, peeled or unpeeled?

title: Afghans Reject a Single Vote to Approve Karzai Cabinet
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 27 - The Afghan Parliament decided Monday to confirm cabinet ministers individually, rather than to vote on the president's cabinet as a whole, setting the stage for a long and tortuous confirmation process.

title: Arts, Briefly; Schreiber and Streep in Central Park
description: The Scottish play is bound for Central Park. "Macbeth," Shakespeare's epic tale of witch cuisine, misplaced ambition and the lack of good hand wash, will kick off the Public Theater's summer season at the Delacorte Theater, with a pair of big names already attached. Moiss Kaufman ("I Am My Own Wife") will direct Liev Schreiber, right, in the lead role, with performances starting on June 13. More casting is expected soon. "Macbeth" will run through July 9 before making way for "Mother Courage," featuring Meryl Streep, with direction by George C. Wolfe and a new translation by Tony Kushner. JESSE McKINLEY

title: Dubai and America's ports
Corrections
description: The David Leonhardt column in Business Day on Wednesday, about physicians' misdiagnoses of fatal illnesses, referred imprecisely to the medical condition of a girl named Isabel Maude. She had a flesh-eating infection, known as necrotizing fasciitis; she did not have a virus.

title: Tiny Jets May Usher in New Era, F.A.A. Says
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 A Thousands of tiny new passenger jets will begin flying around the country soon, opening new travel opportunities at small airports around the country, the Federal Aviation Administration said today. The first 100 or so are expected to start flying this year, the agency said, but it also cautioned that the additional traffic could gum up the air traffic system.

title: $92 million in loot and nowhere to spend it?

description: A bank created to provide emergency backup for the Treasury market will be ready to operate in the next 18 months, a bond industry group is set to announce today.

Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPERONIS, EFSTATHIOS G. (STATHIS)
description: KAPERONIS--Efstathios G. (Stathis). Suddenly, on February 24, 2006. Age 36. Restaurateur-owner of BronxBBQ and a member of the Riverdale Diner family in Kingsbridge, Bronx. Beloved husband of Gina (nee Tangalos). Loving son of George and Anna Kaperonis. Devoted brother of Tina and Brian Antash. Dear grandson of Dena Dennis. Adored uncle of George, Lauren and James Antash. Loving nephew of Betty and James Zafiros, Andreas and Tasia Douzous, Alexandra Kaperonis, James Kaperonis, John and Penny Dennis, and the late Nicholas and Helen Dennis. Also survived by many loving cousins. Family will receive friends Monday, February 27, from 7-9 pm, and Tuesday, February 28, from 2-4 and 7-9 pm, at Williams Funeral Home, Inc, 5628 B'way at West 232nd St, Bronx, NY. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, March 1, at Holy Trinity Church, 10 Mill Rd, New Rochelle, NY, at 10 am. Interment Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY.

title: Flood-Control Proposal Seeks Gates and 'Armored' Levees
description: The Bush administration has asked Congress to pay for two huge gates in the New Orleans area to close off the navigational canals that devastated the city's Lower Ninth Ward, along with "armored" levees that would not be destroyed when water washed over the top, according to the most recent details of its spending plan.

Enron Figures Tell How Results Were Manipulated
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 27 - Two minor figures in the Enron story added on Monday to testimony that the company had padded earnings and shifted hundreds of millions in losses from one division to another to disguise problems that might have concerned investors.

title: Nations Rebuild Barriers to Deals
description: LONDON, Feb. 27 - As the ties of world trade grow stronger and the tempo of globalization quickens, a boisterous player has re-emerged in the arena of cross-border mergers: government.

Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side parking regulations in New York City will be suspended tomorrow in observance of Ash Wednesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

description: Correction Appended

title: Patterns: Chewing Gum Along the Road to Recovery
description: Chewing gum after surgery may make hospital stays shorter for patients who have had colon operations. A small study published in the February issue of The Archives of Surgery reports that patients who chewed sugarless gum recovered bowel function faster and spent less time in the hospital than those who did not chew.

title: Supreme Court Backs Abortion Protesters in Unanimous Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 A Anti-abortion groups gained a victory in the Supreme Court today as the justices ruled, 8 to 0, that abortion clinics cannot rely on federal laws against racketeering and extortion to prevent demonstrations against abortions.

title: Fats Domino Sets an Example for New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 27 - Fats Domino starts his first album since 1993 by singing, "All over the country, people want to know/ whatever happened to Fats Domino." It continues, "I'm alive and kicking and I'm where I wanna be."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIRNBAUM, LILLIAN ''GOODIE'' GOODE
description: BIRNBAUM--Lillian "Goodie" Goode, 90. On February 26, 2006 of Pancreatic Cancer. A memorial service will be held at 11:30 AM on Wednesday, March 1 at Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76th St. Born in 1915 in Rochester, NY, she came to NYC to attend Beth Israel Hospital School of Nursing, earning her RN. Moved to Rockville Centre in 1952 with her husband Bernard Birnbaum and their three children. After her husband's death in 1970, she moved to Greenwich Village. She then worked for ten years at a Beth Israel Methadone Clinic. Survivors include her son and daughter-in-law Alan and Janet Blake, daughter Carol Brody, son and daughter-in-law Peter and Carol Lynn Birnbaum and grandsons Randall and Evan Blake. Contributions may be made to the Ida & Samuel Goode Family Fund at The Jewish Home of Rochester or The Village Temple Soup Kitchen.

description: ALBANY, Feb. 27 - An old saying being repeated in some legal circles these days warns that "judicial reform is no sport for the short-winded or for lawyers who are afraid of temporary defeat."

title: Otis Chandler, Publisher Who Transformed Los Angeles Times, Dies at 78
description: Otis Chandler, who inherited The Los Angeles Times from his parents and then, as its publisher, transformed it into one of the most respected, widely read and profitable newspapers in the United States, died yesterday at his home in Ojai, Calif. He was 78 years old.

title: Jets-Pennington Talks Continue
description: Negotiations toward a restructured contract for Jets quarterback Chad Pennington continued yesterday with renewed optimism that an agreement could be completed before Friday, according to a person with knowledge of the talks. The person was granted anonymity because he was not authorized to discuss the negotiations.

description: A Long Island murder-suicide made an orphan of a 6-year-old boy who was home Monday when his father shot his mother and then turned the gun on himself, the Suffolk County police said.

Whether it is a proposal to import liquefied natural gas to reduce the use of a dirtier fuel like coal or to build a nuclear plant for the same reason, someone in the neighborhood is going to scream.

description: Bronx prosecutors investigating former Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik obtained a court order to tap his cellular telephone last summer and listened to his calls for two months, according to two people with knowledge of the case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAUM, JACK
description: BAUM--Jack. Businessman, civic leader; survived by his wife Marion, son Steve, daughter Yvonne Baum Silverman and granddaughter Justine Silverman.

title: Dennis Weaver, 81, Sidekick on 'Gunsmoke,' Dies
description: Dennis Weaver, whose portrayal of Deputy Chester Goode in the classic television western "Gunsmoke" made him the favorite sidekick of the early television era, died on Friday at his home in Ridgway, Colo. He was 81.

title: Prosecutors Show Execution Orders They Say Hussein Signed
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 28 A As Saddam Hussein watched quietly from the dock, prosecutors displayed Tuesday what they said was his signature on orders of execution for 148 men and boys, some as young as 11, in what appeared to be the first evidence linking the former dictator to large-scale crimes since his trial began in October.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a gay rights group's criticism of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton referred incorrectly to her stance on same-sex marriage and misstated the title of a proposed constitutional amendment that would ban it. While Mrs. Clinton opposes same-sex marriage, she also opposes the amendment. (The title is the Marriage Protection Amendment. The Defense of Marriage Act is a 1996 law that bans federal recognition of such marriages, but allows states to recognize them; Mrs. Clinton has expressed support for that law.) (Go to Article)

title: S.E.C. Leader Issues Rebuke Over Journalist Subpoenas
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 - The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission rebuked the agency's enforcement division on Monday for issuing a subpoena to two journalists, accusing it of operating in a renegade fashion.

title: N.C.A.A. Wants to End Diploma Shortcuts
description: Theo Davis, a 6-foot-10 power forward from Toronto who is one of the top frontcourt recruits in Division I college basketball, went to Lutheran Christian Academy in Philadelphia last year to get what his summer coach called "a quick fix."

title: Germany Denies Giving U.S. Iraq's Plan to Defend Baghdad
description: BERLIN, Feb. 27 - The German government on Monday labeled as "false" a report in The New York Times that two agents of the BND, the German intelligence agency, obtained Saddam Hussein's plan for the defense of Baghdad before the American invasion of Iraq and that the information was passed along to the United States Defense Intelligence Agency ahead of the war in early 2003.

title: The Workplace: Strikers in Vietnam get little help from Europe
Terrorism Meets Absurdism in a Rural Village in Ireland
description: The good people of Inishmore cordially invite you to watch them paint the town red -- a vivid, sticky red that comes, as the phrase goes, straight from the heart. Gore and guts will be served in generous portions by some of the stupidest characters ever to cross a stage. So please turn off your political correctness monitor along with your cell phone. Because if your stomach is reasonably strong, you should find the disgusting spectacle that opened last night at the Atlantic Theater Company appallingly entertaining. More improbably, you should also find it enlightening.

title: Deborah Eisenberg Gets Attention With a Fifth Book of Stories
description: "I just want to be on my own branch twittering," said Deborah Eisenberg, author of the acclaimed new short story collection "Twilight of the Superheroes."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOLLINS, HERMAN
description: MOLLINS--Herman, 79. Of Monroe Twp., New Jersey, on February 27, 2006. Husband of Henrietta. Father of Amy Seroka, Carla Rinde, Ellen Firer, Beth and Diane Mollins. Grandfather of eight. Funeral on Tuesday at 12 noon Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels (www.msmc.us) Cranbury Road @ Evergreen Blvd., East Brunswick, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVY, MICHAEL H.
description: LEVY--Michael H. Founder and former CEO of the Standard Security Life Insurance Company of NY, died from complications resulting from a reaction to a diagnostic injection on February 25. At age 92, Mike was still working full time as a Financial Planner. Mike was a highly decorated Ranger Captain in WWII and a member of the 1932 US Olympic swim team. A man of encyclopedic knowledge and indomitable spirit, Mike was also a passionate civil rights crusader and environmental conservationist. Mike leaves behind his beloved wife of 48 years, Helen, his daughters Michel & Barbara and his much adored grandsons Jon, Keith and Ben.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, NATHAN
description: FRIEDMAN - Nathan. Temple Shaaray Tefila records with profound sorrow the death of our longtime member. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Charlotte, and their loved ones. May his memory be for blessing. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein Michael H. Laufer, President

description: Britten Score Surfaces

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Delay For J.F.K. Helicopter Service
description: Travelers who want to fly to Kennedy International Airport from Lower Manhattan will have to wait another month. U.S. Helicopter has delayed its start-up by two weeks, to March 27, while it sets up its Web site and sales operation. A spokeswoman said the company would begin selling tickets online today at the introductory price of $139 each way between the Downtown Manhattan Heliport and Kennedy Airport. After passengers and their luggage are screened by federal security agents at the heliport, they will be taken to a gate at the American Airlines terminal at Kennedy. The flights will be 10 minutes long. PATRICK McGEEHAN (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Prepping For Anthrax Cleanup
description: Officials with the federal Environmental Protection Agency examined floor plans and photographs yesterday as they prepared to clean up the Greenwich Village apartment of Vado Diomande, the drummer and musician who contracted inhalation anthrax this month. Mr. Diomande, 44, is in serious condition in a Pennsylvania hospital. He is believed to have inhaled anthrax spores from untreated animal skins that he used to make drums. On Friday, test results confirmed the presence of anthrax in his apartment, in a Dodge van he used and in a warehouse where he worked. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

title: Tom Ford, Clothing Designer, Will Open Store of His Own
description: Putting an end to months of speculation about his future in fashion, the designer Tom Ford announced yesterday that he would open his first store, in New York. The three-story 10,000-square-foot space on Madison Avenue, set to open in November, will showcase his men's wear collection, his first fashion line since leaving Gucci nearly two years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHERZER, IRWIN S.
description: SCHERZER--Irwin S. Passed away at the age of 73 on February 24, 2006. Beloved son of the late Hyman and Bertha Scherzer. Irwin grew up in Lynn, Massachusetts and was an honors graduate of Harvard College Class of 1954 and Harvard Business School Class of 1956. He served for two years as a commissioned officer in the U.S. Navy. He began his business career with west coast based RamoWooldridge Corp., but soon moved to New York and shifted his focus to the management of musical organizations. He got his start managing classical music bookings for Columbia Artists. Thereafter, he held several positions including Vice President of Grey Advertising with responsibility for the RCA classical musical label. In 1969, he became the founding administrative director of the newly formed Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. His management skills contributed mightily to the success of the fledgling effort, now one of the city's musical institutions. He worked closely with the directors of the Society including philanthropist Alice Tully. He subsequently became business manager and trusted adviser to Miss Tully who relied upon his many talents as she pursued her diverse activities in the arts and music. Irwin can only be described with superlatives. He was truly an example of the sui generis personality. Luminous intelligence, brilliant wit and raconteur, striking linguistic ability, generosity of spirit, a keen social conscience and indomitable courage in the face of adversity, these were the qualities that endeared him to his legion of friends. His knowledge of opera, classical music and the culinary arts was encyclopedic. His wit gushed forth in a seemingly unending flow of quips and jaunty apercus. He spoke six languages fluently and had a working knowledge of a half dozen more. He was never satisfied unless his friends shared fully in the realms that gave him pleasure, and thus did he enrich all who knew him. His social consciousness was manifested in his support of the battle against an outmoded social value. His zest for life never flagged despite daunting health issues. He lived a life filled with love and caring. Irwin is survived by his beloved partner, Chien Cho (JJ) Liu, and his devoted cousins Alicia, Babs, Harry, Gloria and Bobby. He will be sorely missed by his many friends who will forever cherish his memory and will find comfort in the warm remembrances of the good times spent with him. His memory can be honored by donations to Tannery Pond Concerts, P.O. Box 446, New Lebanon, NY 12125. A date for a memorial concert will be announced.

title: World Briefing: Asia, Middle East, Africa, United Nations and Europe
description: ASIA

title: Arts, Briefly; Millions to Renew the Pergamon Museum
description: The Pergamon Museum in Berlin, housing treasures like the 2,200-year-old Pergamon Altar from a Greek temple in Turkey and the Ishtar Gate, left, from Babylon, will be restored. The $420 million budget for the renovation project, starting in 2011 and expected to continue for about 15 years, was cleared unanimously after a yearlong struggle in the German legislature, representatives of the museum said yesterday. A fourth wing will permit the art of major civilizations from Mesopotamia, Egypt and Greece to be displayed on one level. Once the renovation is finished, the museum's director said, each collection will have its own wing with a separate entrance. The project is part of a $1.8 billion project to renovate Museum Island, the site of the Pergamon and other museums, which attracted 800,00 visitors last year. The Pergamon will remain partly open during construction. SARAH PLASS

title: Corrections
description: The Ink column last Tuesday, about Paul Schweitzer, owner of the Gramercy Typewriter Company in Manhattan, referred incorrectly to the type of printers he repairs. They are laser printers; there is no such thing as an inkjet laser printer. The column also misstated the brand name of a typewriter that a customer took in for repairs. It was a Remington, not a Pennington.

title: Unfussy French Baroque, With Arias of Gentle Drama
description: Now that the early-music movement is so ubiquitous as to have penetrated even Carnegie Hall, where Zankel Hall is offering a "Baroque Unlimited" series this season, there are a host of ways to approach the repertory. Les Violons du Roy, a Canadian ensemble, has opted to use the muscle of modern instruments with the style, and bowings, of Baroque ones. The result, as demonstrated at Zankel on Sunday night, is powerful, invigorating, not always completely clean, not at all fussy and very enjoyable.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a gay rights group's criticism of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton referred incorrectly to her stance on same-sex marriage and misstated the title of a proposed constitutional amendment that would ban it. While Mrs. Clinton opposes same-sex marriage, she also opposes the amendment. (The title is the Marriage Protection Amendment. The Defense of Marriage Act is a 1996 law that bans federal recognition of such marriages, but allows states to recognize them; Mrs. Clinton has expressed support for that law.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Insurance Contract Canceled
description: State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi will block the last year of a three-year contract with Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield to provide prescription drug coverage to 1.1 million state workers, Mr. Hevesi's office said yesterday. The contract would be worth $1.6 billion in 2008 to Empire, now a subsidiary of WellPoint. The comptroller's office said that Empire, formerly a nonprofit insurer, was given an unfair advantage in the bidding process by being allowed to change its bid three times. The company will be allowed to provide drug coverage through the end of 2007 to avoid disruptions in worker benefits, but the contract will be re-bid for 2008. DANNY HAKIM (NYT)

title: New Homes Sold Slower in January; Prices Rose
description: Sales of new homes fell sharply last month, but prices increased -- a sign that home builders are luring buyers with incentives rather than lower prices and that demand, while weakening, remains healthy.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: U.S. Rejects Rights Council Proposal
description: John R. Bolton, the United States ambassador, said that a compromise proposal for a new Human Rights Council for the United Nations released last week was not acceptable and that the United States would vote against it unless negotiations were reopened or the vote postponed. Jan Eliasson, the president of the 191-member General Assembly who drew up the new blueprint after months of contentious debate, has called for an Assembly vote as early as this week. The new council would replace the discredited Human Rights Commission, where seats are often held by well-documented human rights abusers. The proposal, which was criticized by Mr. Bolton when it was made public last Thursday, drops a requirement that members of the new council be elected by a two-thirds vote, calling instead for a majority of all Assembly members. DANIEL B. SCHNEIDER (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PALMER, JULIA REED
description: PALMER--Julia Reed, 90. Of New York City and Mt. Desert, Maine, on February 25, 2006, after a long life and a brief illness. Wife of the late Arthur E. Palmer, Jr. Beloved mother of Constance Hildesley, Lansing Palmer, Stewart Palmer and the late Susan Palmer, all of New York City. Devoted grandmother of Mark Hildesley, Morgan Hildesley, Laura Bartsch, Lansing Palmer, Jr., and Blair Palmer, and great-grandmother of Griffin and Spenser Bartsch, Emma and Sophie Hildesley, and Rebecca Palmer. She was an inspiration in the field of literacy, and continued to teach and to campaign for her causes to the last day. She had an answer for all, delivered with an earnestness belied by a twinkle in her eye. We will miss her always. Funeral service private. A memorial service will be held in Maine at a later date. In lieu of flowers, a contribution may be made to Jan Hus Presbyterian Church, 351 East 74th St, NY, NY 10021.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Rally For McCain Immigration Bill
description: Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, received a hero's welcome yesterday from 800 immigrants and other New Yorkers as he championed a federal immigration bill on the home turf of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who could be his opponent if they both run for the presidency in 2008. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, is co-sponsor of the bill, which would create a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants now in the country if they pay fines, successfully complete background checks, learn English, and work for a period of years. Representatives Charles B. Rangel and Anthony D. Weiner, both Democrats, joined Mr. McCain to support the bill. PATRICK HEALY (NYT)

Mr. Martin attended Canterbury School in New Milford, CT, and St. John's School in Annapolis, MD, and received his degree from the University of Virginia (Class of 1952). Cherished grandfather of Marisa Milo, Christina Morlano, Jessica Marvel-Piccolo, Alex Marvel and great grandfather of Jordan and Michael Milo. Adored godfather of William Michel. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Reposing at Aievoli and Son Funeral Home, 1275 65th Street, Brooklyn, NY, Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Service at Sts. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, Thursday, 11:30AM. Interment Greenwood Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NITCHUN, PHYLLIS
description: NITCHUN--Phyllis. Beloved cousin of Mary Astor and Shirley Vorspan. Cherished by a large and loving extended family as a speech language therapist and diagnostician with the NYC Board of Education, she devoted her career to working with children in the NYC public schools. She will be remembered fondly by many colleagues and by a circle of close friends who shared her life. In her last years she was attended with warmth and tenderness by her family and caregivers Joanne Cuenca and Mila Rosario as well as the nurses and staff at the Mary Manning Walsh Home. May the memory of this good woman be a blessing. Services Wednesday, 12:45 PM at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Worker Killed At Home Depot
description: An employee was fatally stabbed at a Home Depot store yesterday morning, the police said. The worker, Tunde Alonge, 24, of Brooklyn, was found stabbed shortly before 9 a.m. in the store, at 5700 Avenue U. He was taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, where he died. The police said that it was unclear who stabbed Mr. Alonge, or what the weapon was, but that they did not believe the assailant was another employee. Mr. Alonge immigrated from Nigeria 11 years ago, his family said. An aunt, Dorcas Momodu, said he had already packed his bags for a trip to Texas, where he had planned to become a real estate agent. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)
