title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRONG, DIANE SHALET
description: STRONG--Diane Shalet. On February 23, 2006 in Palm Springs. Founder of the Actors and Writers Lab in Manhattan, she was a charter member of the Lincoln Center Repertory Theatre under the direction of Robert Whitehead and Elia Kazan. She taught acting at UCLA and was a teaching associate of Robert Lewis for 14 years. A resident of Manhattan and Los Angeles, Diane acted in Broadway, Off Broadway, films (The Reivers, The Last Tycoon) and T.V. (The Waltons, Perry Mason, The Monkees). She was the author of "Greece in a Sunny Climate", a comedic novel about a grieving L.A. widow. She was preceded in death by her husband, actor Michael Strong. Her many friends will miss her wit and warmth. Tributes in Diane's memory may be made to UNAIDS (www.unaids.org) or Actors Fund of America (www.actorsfund.org)

title: Enter Suozzi, Stage Right
description: Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, for months the presumptive Democratic candidate for governor of New York, has a stone in his inaugural slippers: Thomas Suozzi, the Nassau County executive.

title: Roundup: Federer and Safin advance in Dubai
Echoes of Tass
description: To the Editor:

title: Envoy Says Sudan Doesn't Want U.N. Force in Darfur
description: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 28 A Sudan has withdrawn its support for a United Nations peacekeeping force to replace African Union troops now in the conflicted Darfur region and is lobbying other countries to help discourage the substitution, Jan Pronk, the United Nations envoy for Sudan, said today.

title: Energy, Urbanity and Versatility: A Lyricist's Best Friends
description: Only the most intrepid collectors of Broadway lore remember "Marilyn: An American Fable," a 1983 musical about Marilyn Monroe that opened at the Minskoff Theater and closed after 16 performances. But the lyricist David Zippel does. As he recalled on Friday evening at the Allen Room, he and Wally Harper were asked to try and rescue "Marilyn" by coming up with a last-minute showstopper along the lines of "Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend." It was their only contribution to the score.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the jazz and Latin percussionist Ray Barretto on Feb. 18 misidentified the town where he lived at his death. It is Warwick, N.Y., not Norwood, N.J.

title: Memo Pad
description: CLASS CONSCIOUS -- United Airlines said that it was planning to put a new emphasis on its premium-class cabins domestically and internationally, while cutting spending on economy-class customers.

title: Soaking Up New Role and Another Spring as a Yankee
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 27 - It was just another day on the spring-training schedule, like hundreds and hundreds before. It was another day in paradise for Bernie Williams, the wise old man of the Yankees.

title: Putin's power trip to Hungary and Czech Republic
No-glamour glossies: A guide back to basics
Under an 1815 Volcano Eruption, Remains of a 'Lost Kingdom'
description: One of history's most violent volcanic eruptions blasted the island of Sumbawa in the East Indies in 1815. The sulfurous gases and fiery ashes from Mount Tambora cast a pall over the entire world, causing the global cooling of 1816, known as the "year without a summer."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MISHRICK, ABDALLAH S., M.D.
description: MISHRICK--Abdallah S., M.D. on February 26, 2006 of Garden City. Beloved husband of Jacqueline. Loving father, grandfather and friend. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th Street, Garden City 7-9PM Tuesday and 2-4 & 7-9PM Wednesday. Religious service Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City Thursday, 10AM. In lieu of flowers donations to NSLIJ Foundation, in memory of Dr. Abdallah Mishrick, Att: D. Tascone, 221 Jericho Turnpike, Syosset, NY 11791.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AULETTA, KELLI ANNE
description: AULETTA--Kelli Anne, 38. Died on February 19, 2006 at home with her mother, Mary, father, Richard and sister, Kimberlee. Her smile and enthusiasm for life graced all who knew her. Memorial service Friday, March 3 at 2PM at St. Bartholomew's, Park Avenue and 50th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be given to the Kelli Auletta Fund for Ovarian Cancer Research and sent to: Mr. Richard Naum, Memorial Sloan-Kettering, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

title: New Tools for the Old Spy
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharon, Gravely Ill, Invited the Public Inside
description: When Ariel Sharon suffered his first stroke in December, he did what many national leaders who suddenly become ill rarely do. Mr. Sharon, the prime minister of Israel, told his doctors at the Hadassah Hospital Ein Kerem in Jerusalem to inform the public about his medical problems, Dr. Shlomo Mor-Yosef, the Hadassah Medical Organization's director-general, said in interviews in the United States last week.

title: The Turnpike As a Career Path
description: TRENTON, Feb. 27 - Of all the jobs in New Jersey politics, one of the most demanding may well be the position of personal driver -- the behind-the-wheel assistant who must deliver the candidate on time and without incident to Main Street parades, chicken dinner fund-raisers, back-room meetings and other stops in between.

title: Google tests terrain for 'pay-per-call' ads
Other Views: Sydney Morning Herald, The Times, Miami Herald
A Port in the Storm Over Dubai
description: THE political firestorm surrounding the takeover of five American container terminals by Dubai Ports World, a United Arab Emirates company, is a political distraction, but in many ways a welcome one. Americans are finally taking port security seriously.

title: Clinton Says Bush Adviser Obsesses About Her and '08
description: ALBANY, Feb. 27 - Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton took a swipe at the White House on Monday, saying that Karl Rove, the president's political adviser, "spends a lot of time obsessing about me."

title: National Briefing | Washington: Times Files Suit Seeking Documents
description: The New York Times Company filed a federal lawsuit against the Department of Defense under the Freedom of Information Act, seeking internal memorandums, meeting logs and e-mail messages about the National Security Agency's program of wiretapping in the United States without court warrants. The suit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, says the Pentagon made no "substantive response" to a Dec. 16 letter from a Times reporter, Eric Lichtblau, requesting the documents. Under the act, the department had 20 days to offer that response, the suit says. The department acknowledged the request on Dec. 30 with a pre-printed postcard, the suit says, but did not formally deny it or move to extend the deadline. JULIA PRESTON (NYT)

title: Supreme Court Set to Weigh Central Election-Law Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 - The most pressing and unsettled questions in election law are those that concern the role of money, the role of race and the role of partisanship. The Supreme Court will take up all three this week.

title: Spread of bird flu: Experts are puzzled
Merrill to Buy Back Stock
description: Merrill Lynch & Company will buy back as much as $6 billion of its own stock, the company said yesterday, after posting a third consecutive year of record profits.

title: Cycling: The next next Armstrong begs to disagree, for now
Google's Shares Drop After Warning of Slowing Growth
description: Google's share price tumbled more than 7 percent today after the chief financial officer told investors that the company saw few further advances in a technology that had allowed a substantial increase in its advertising revenue.

title: Schmidt an Open Book on Greenies
description: IF the use of steroids enhanced the power-hitting abilities of players, as the untested but commonly held belief goes, then we have already seen the effect of the elimination of steroids use. Last season, when fewer than 1 percent of major league players tested positive for steroids, home runs declined by 8 percent.

title: Telling the Truth About Harvard
description: To the Editor:

title: Anti-Darwin Bill Fails in Utah
description: Correction Appended

title: Aging: Too Old to Benefit From Exercise? Pish!
description: People are never too old to gain health benefits from exercise, a new study suggests.

title: 'Da Vinci Code' Trial Opens With Claim of Theft
description: LONDON, Feb. 27 - Opening arguments began here on Monday in a case that sets Dan Brown, megaselling author of "The Da Vinci Code," against the authors of a nonfiction book who contend that he stole their ideas for his book.

title: When family fiction is tamer than truth
Too Hot to Handle
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Tim Hortons Files for IPO
description: Canadian restaurant chain Tim Hortons, now owned by Wendys International Inc., may offer up to 29 million shares for between C$21 and C$23 a share, or about $18 to $20, according to a regulatory filing on Monday.

title: A Mickey-Mouse Idea: Apple Buying Disney
description: As the largest individual shareholder in Disney, would Steve Jobs be interested in having his Apple acquire Disney?

title: Is the Bond Trading Party Over?
description: Some of the easiest money ever made on Wall Street could start slipping away, as the five-year-long bond bonanza begins to dry up, according to The NEw york Post. New bond issues this year are expected to fall 13 percent in dollar terms, which combined with a drop in price volatility could hurt bottom lines at the big investment banks

title: Mardi Gras Returns
description: Susan Saulny, a Times reporter and New Orleans native, talks about the first Mardi Gras since HurricaneKatrina.(Producer:  Craig Duff)

title: After KeySpan Deal, Eyes Turn to NStar
description: Is NStar next?

title: Credit Suisse Banker in U.K. to Launch Hedge Fund
description: Yet another longtime banker is heeding the siren song of the hedge fund sector. Charles Kirwan-Taylor, the chairman of U.K. corporate broking at Credit Suisse, is leaving the Swiss bank after 15 years to set up a fund focused on European equities, according to The Times of London, which cited an internal memo.

title: Michael Dells New  Approach to Hedge Funds
description: With the backing of Michael Dell, SkyBridge Capital has taken a new apporach to hedge fund investing. Instead of investing in a fund or managing a fund, SkyBridge has gotten into the business of providing seed capital to funds, according to The Street.com. Apparently, the returns on this type of investment can make investing in a traditional hedge fund look like a joke.

title: The BlackBerry Showdown Continues With New War of Words
description: Research In Motion Ltd. and NTP Inc. publicly traded barbs yesterday, giving no indication that they were ready to heed the dire warning of a U.S. federal judge who has told the two to settle their patent fight before he enforces a solution.

title: Hedge Fund Returns Overstated?
description: Hedge fund growth is soaring, but is some of that being floated on hot air? A new study by Barclays Capital suggests that hedge fund indexes, because of flaws in they are compiled, may be overstating returns by as much as one to six percentage points a year.

title: MidOcean Takes a Ride With Secondary Buyout of Park Operator
description: MidOcean Partners LLP has signed an agreement to buy Palace Entertainment, an operator of 32 family-oriented theme parks, from Windward Capital in a secondary buyout. While the value of the deal was not disclosed, MidOcean typically puts between $50 million and $100 million of equity toward each of its deals, and purchase prices are generally in excess of $200 million.

title: Stanley ONeal Sets $6 Billion Buyback at Merrill
description: Merrill Lynch will buy back as much as $6 billion of its own stock, the company said onMonday, after reporting a third consecutive year of strong profits. The buyback will represent about 8.5 percent of outstanding shares based on the Friday closing price and will be its biggest share repurchase ever, the company said.

title: A Day of Insurgent Bombings in Baghdad
description: The bombings threatened to heighten tensions as Iraqis struggled to recover from the worst sectarian bloodletting of the war.
Selborne Journal: 27 February 1759:  One pot of Millers Cantaleupes begins to appear. Continual heavy rain.

title: Yahoo Sues Former Employees For Stealing Trade Secrets
description: Yahoo has filed a lawsuit against wireless content company MForma, accusing the company and a group of ex-Yahoo employees there with theft of trade secrets.

title: Big Board Cleared For Historic Merger; Whos Next?
description: The New York Stock Exchange has received approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission to merge with Archipelago Holdings and end 213 years as a member-owned stock market.

title: SEC Issues Subpoenas to Cramer and TheStreet
description: James J. Cramer, the money manager-turned Mad Money media star, has received a subpoena as part of the Securities and Exchange Commissions investigation into allegations of collusion between short-sellers and a stock-research firm. TheStreet.com, which Mr. Cramer co-founded, also received a subpoena.

title: Fat Tuesday Returns to New Orleans
description: Passing damage from Hurricane Katrina and with roughly half the attendance of prior years, the Zulu parade returns to New Orleans.

title: Fund Sends Offer, and Threat, to American HomePatient
description: Dangling the possibility of a proxy fight or even an eventual bankruptcy filing, activist investor Highland Capital Management has offered to buy home healthcare provider American HomePatient for $3.40 a share, or nearly $60 million.

title: A Bet on Oscar
description: The Bagger would never bet on the Oscars. Not that he has moral objections; he just generally loses enough in the office pool already as it is. But there those who do and Pinnacle Sports was the first site to set odds on the Oscars, minutes after the nominees were announced. The Bagger would be hard-pressed to think of something dumber than laying down serious money on the Oscars, but the odds are interesting to those who are handicapping for the sheer intellectual frisson of being right.

title: Why Mardi Gras Must Go On
Let the Wonkery Begin
description: Into the thick of Oscar week, comes real, actual science. Well, more like voodoo mixed with some extant metrics, but you have to love the attempt to make the Oscars comport to some sort of logic. The University of Oregons Iain Pardoe has been crunching the numbers for the past 30 years ad has come up with a statistical model that predicts in four major categories. His predictions happen to match the conventional wisdom, so no great shakes there.

title: Ted Turner Speaks Out About His Split From Time Warner and Icahn
description: In an interview with The Atlanta Journal-Constitution and later at a dinner at Emory University last night, Ted Turner talked openly for the first time about his resignation from Time Warners board and Carl Icahns campaign to break up the company.

title: Oscar, We Hardly Knew Ya
description: David Thomson does the unthinkable, imagining life without the Oscars.

title: Oscars Newfound Flexibility
description: If youre interested in sweeping historical context, you might want to check in on a Reuters story tracing Hollywoods relationship with gay subject matter. Much of the industrys success and many of its better films have been driven by gay artists and executives, but you would never know it to watch the movies. It all started with the Hays Code:

title: Ebert Goes for Done
description: Not only does Roger Ebert think Crash should win best picture, he thinks it actually will. He is like a dog on a meat bone, grabbing hold and shaking, and he will not let go until he is vindicated:

title: Mass Defection
description: Kristy Swanson and the professional figure skater Lloyd Eisler on Skating With Celebrities. (Kelsey McNeal/Fox)

title: KKR May Expand Stake in GM Mortgage Unit
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., the worlds biggest buyout firm, may increase its stake in General Motors commercial mortgage unit six months after buying 60 percent of the company, according to Bloomberg News.

title: To the Woodshed for Buckley?
description: War critics have been wondering if the editors of National Review would rebuke founder William F. Buckley Jr.  for writing last week that the American objective in Iraq has failed  with the same sort of rhetoric that has been used to denounce liberal critics of the Iraq war. Why does William F. Buckley Jr. hate America?  asked Eric Alterman at his Altercation blog at MSNBC.com. In his personal blog, David Corn, Washington editor of The Nation, challenged National Review editor Rich Lowry to answer the question, Is Buckley Weak on Tyranny? Corn cited some of Lowrys previous statements and asked, [D]oesnt integrity demand that he hurl (or politely toss) those insults at Buckley?

title: Paris Collections
description: Women's wear from the fall 2006 fashion shows.

title: When Education Doesnt Pay
description: Readers respond to Paul Krugmans Feb. 27 column, Graduates Versus Oligarchs

title: Children Can Dream, Cant They?
description: Its never too early to start thinking about a home of your own.

title: Chicken With Green Olives
description: Mark Bittman shows how to prepare chicken with green olives.

title: Amazon Buys Online Clothing Retailer
description: Amazon.com said Monday it would acquire Shopbop.com, putting the e-commerce giant in direct competition with other retailers on its site.

title: Meaningless Discounts? Then Just Drop Them
description: Slates Jack Shafer has sharply criticized my Sunday column that suggested some price-discount perks offered to Times news staffers could create the perception of a conflict of interest. A major point made by Mr. Shafer and by a couple of editors at The Times over the past two days is that many of the discounts offered at the paper  especially on cars  are less attractive than those that can be negotiated by consumers without any ties to a big employer.

title: The Cost of Getting It Right
description: When a friend and I ate lunch recently at Butterfield 8, the restaurant was still in its very first days, so we werent expecting an entirely smooth ride. And we didnt initially feel put out by our servers many warnings that the restaurant wasnt up to speed.
